instruction: Can I file a petition if I suspect someone is about to violate my rights?
input: part (3) : If a person commit or there is suﬀicient suspicion that he or she is going to commit any act in contravention of this Chapter, the person aggrieved from such an act may, for the enforcement of his or her right, file a petition in the High Court or District Court having territorial jurisdiction.
output: According to Section 26(3): The rule is that where a person commits or there is sufficient suspicion they will commit an act contravening the Chapter, the aggrieved person may file a petition in the High Court or District Court with territorial jurisdiction. Application/Conclusion: If you reasonably suspect someone will violate rights protected by this Chapter, you may file a petition in the appropriate District Court or the High Court to enforce your rights.

instruction: They arrested me unlawfully — what does the court have to do if my petition proves it?
input: Section no 26  part (4) : If it is found from inquiry into the petition filed pursuant to sub-section (1) that the person has been arrested or detained against law, the concerned court shall order to release him or her immediately.
output: According to Section 26(4): The rule is that if, after inquiry into a petition, the court finds the person was arrested or detained against law, the court shall order their immediate release. Application/Conclusion: If your petition shows your arrest or detention was unlawful, the court must order your immediate release.

instruction: My neighbour has already started acts that harm my rights and threatens more — can the court stop them?
input: Section no 26  part (5) : If it is found from inquiry in respect of the petition filed pursuant to sub-section (3) that the respondent has caused some damage or is about to cause damage to the petitioner’s right, the concerned court may issue an order requiring the respondent to refrain from committing, or causing to be committed, any act damaging the petitioner’s right, and where some act has already been committed, from committing, or causing to be committed, the remaining act, or to do any act.
output: According to Section 26(5): The rule is that if inquiry finds the respondent has caused or is about to cause damage to the petitioner’s right, the court may order the respondent to refrain from committing (or causing) damaging acts and, if some acts are already committed, to refrain from committing remaining acts or to perform any act. Application/Conclusion: The court can issue an order (injunction) to stop your neighbour from continuing harmful conduct and can require them to refrain from completing further harmful acts or to take certain actions to address what remains.

instruction: How long do I have to sue if no arrest or detention occurred? Found out about the harm today.
input: Section no 29 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit any time in the case of arrest or detention, and within a period of six months after the date on which such an act or action was done or taken, in the other cases.
output: According to Section 29: The rule is that in cases other than arrest or detention, a lawsuit must be brought within six months from the date the act or action was done or taken. Application/Conclusion: Since your case does not involve arrest or detention, you have six months from today (the date you discovered or the date of the act) to file suit under this Chapter.

instruction: Someone maliciously damaged my property/reputation — can I get compensation?
input: Section no 27 . Compensation to be awarded : (1) If, from the examination of the complaint filed pursuant to Section 26, the respondent is found to have maliciously committed any act causing damage to the complainant, the concerned court shall, having regard to the 12 circumstances, order the respondent to pay reasonable compensation to the complainant.
output: According to Section 27(1): The rule is that if, on examination of a complaint filed under Section 26, the respondent is found to have maliciously caused damage, the court shall order the respondent to pay reasonable compensation, considering the circumstances. Application/Conclusion: If the court finds the respondent acted maliciously and caused you harm, it can order them to pay you reasonable compensation based on the relevant circumstances.

instruction: A government employee violated my civil rights knowingly — who pays the compensation?
input: Section no 27  part (2) : If an oﬀicial or employee working in a governmental or public body is held to have knowingly violated the civil rights referred to in this Chapter, such an oﬀicial or employee shall personally bear the amount of compensation referred to in sub section (1).
output: According to Section 27(2): The rule is that if a governmental or public official/employee is held to have knowingly violated the civil rights in this Chapter, that official or employee shall personally bear the compensation amount ordered under subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: If a public official is found to have knowingly violated your rights, they are personally liable to pay the compensation the court orders.

instruction: Someone filed a complaint against me just to harm me — can I get compensation back?
input: Section no 28 . Compensation for filing false complaint : (1) If a person is held to have filed a complaint with the intention of knowingly causing pain or loss or damage to a person, the concerned court shall order the person so filing the false complaint to pay a reasonable compensation to the respondent.
output: According to Section 28(1): The rule is that if a person is found to have filed a complaint with the intention of knowingly causing pain, loss or damage, the court shall order that person to pay reasonable compensation to the respondent. Application/Conclusion: If the court determines your accuser filed a false complaint intentionally to harm you, you can get compensation ordered against that person.

instruction: Do I get my legal fees back if someone brought a false complaint to hurt me?
input: Section no 28  part (2) : The compensation to be awarded under sub-section (1) shall include the costs incurred by the respondent for defense before the court, court fees and legal practitioner’s cost.
output: According to Section 28(2): The rule is that compensation under subsection (1) shall include the respondent’s costs for defense before the court, court fees and legal practitioner’s costs. Application/Conclusion: If the court orders compensation for a false complaint, that compensation can cover your defense costs, court fees and lawyer’s fees.

instruction: Under which section does the law set out 'Compensation to be awarded'?
input: Section no 27 . Compensation to be awarded : (1) If, from the examination of the complaint filed pursuant to Section 26, the respondent is found to have maliciously committed any act causing damage to the complainant, the concerned court shall, having regard to the 12 circumstances, order the respondent to pay reasonable compensation to the complainant.
output: According to Section 27: The rule is that compensation to be awarded is set out in Section 27, which provides that if a respondent maliciously causes damage (on examination of a complaint under Section 26), the court shall order reasonable compensation. Application/Conclusion: You should refer to Section 27 for the legal basis and procedure for obtaining compensation for malicious acts causing damage.

instruction: I was detained years ago unlawfully — can I still sue now?
input: Section no 29 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit any time in the case of arrest or detention, and within a period of six months after the date on which such an act or action was done or taken, in the other cases.
output: According to Section 29: The rule is that for cases of arrest or detention, a person may make a lawsuit at any time (there is no six-month limitation). Application/Conclusion: Because your grievance involves unlawful detention, you may bring a lawsuit at any time — the six-month limitation that applies in other cases does not bar your claim.

instruction: When is a living being recognized as a legal person with rights?
input: Section no 30 . To be recognized as person : Every person shall, immediately after birth, be recognized as a person and be entitled to exercise rights under law until he or she survives.
output: According to Section 30: The rule is that every person is recognized as a legal person immediately after birth and is entitled to exercise rights under law until they survive. Application/Conclusion: From the moment of birth you are legally recognized and entitled to exercise rights under the law.

instruction: Do newborns have a right to a name? Can they use it respectfully?
input: Section no 31 . Right to Name : (1) Every person shall, immediately after birth, have right to name and be entitled to use the given name respectfully.
output: According to Section 31(1): The rule is that every person immediately after birth has the right to a name and is entitled to use the given name respectfully. Application/Conclusion: A newborn has the legal right to a name and to use it with respect; parents or guardians should ensure that right is respected.

instruction: I want to protect my reputation — can I transfer that right to my daughter?
input: Section no 31  part (2) : Every person shall have the right to defend his or her name, reputation and prestige and such right shall not be transferable to others.
output: According to Section 31(2): The rule is that every person has the right to defend his or her name, reputation and prestige, and that right is not transferable to others. Application/Conclusion: You cannot transfer your personal right to defend your name or reputation to your daughter; that right remains personal to you.

instruction: Is it legal to abuse someone else’s name online?
input: Section no 31  part (3) : No person shall be allowed to abuse another’s name.
output: According to Section 31(3): The rule is that no person shall be allowed to abuse another’s name. Application/Conclusion: Abusing someone’s name (including online) is not permitted under this provision and may give rise to legal action to protect the victim’s rights.

instruction: When am I considered a major and legally competent to act on my own?
input: Section no 32 . To attain competency : (1) Every person who attains eighteen years of age shall be considered to become a major, and shall, in the same capacity, be considered to be legally competent.
output: According to Section 32(1): The rule is that a person who attains eighteen years of age is considered a major and legally competent. Application/Conclusion: Once you turn 18 you are treated as a major under the law and have legal competency to exercise rights independently.

instruction: If I suspect someone will damage my rights, must I go to the High Court or can I go to District Court?
input: part (3) : If a person commit or there is suﬀicient suspicion that he or she is going to commit any act in contravention of this Chapter, the person aggrieved from such an act may, for the enforcement of his or her right, file a petition in the High Court or District Court having territorial jurisdiction.
output: According to Section 26(3): The rule is that the aggrieved person may file a petition either in the High Court or in the District Court that has territorial jurisdiction. Application/Conclusion: You may choose to file in the District Court with territorial jurisdiction or in the High Court, depending on your circumstances and strategic preference.

instruction: Some damaging acts have already happened and others are threatened — can the court force the respondent to do something to stop the rest?
input: Section no 26  part (5) : If it is found from inquiry in respect of the petition filed pursuant to sub-section (3) that the respondent has caused some damage or is about to cause damage to the petitioner’s right, the concerned court may issue an order requiring the respondent to refrain from committing, or causing to be committed, any act damaging the petitioner’s right, and where some act has already been committed, from committing, or causing to be committed, the remaining act, or to do any act.
output: According to Section 26(5): The rule is that the court may order the respondent to refrain from damaging acts and, where some acts have already been committed, to refrain from committing remaining acts or to perform any act. Application/Conclusion: The court can both stop further harmful acts and require the respondent to address or refrain from completing remaining harmful actions already started.

instruction: Can I freely express my opinion in Nepal?
input: part (2) (a) : To express one’s opinion and expression,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(a): Rule: Citizens have the right to express opinions and expressions. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to express your opinion; this constitutional provision protects that freedom.

instruction: Am I allowed to hold a peaceful assembly without weapons?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (b) : To assemble, hold assembly, conference peacefully without arms,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(b): Rule: People have the right to assemble and hold conferences or assemblies peacefully and without arms. Application/Conclusion: You may lawfully organize or join peaceful, unarmed assemblies under this provision.

instruction: Can I form a workers' union?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (c) : To form union and association,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(c): Rule: Citizens have the right to form unions and associations. Application/Conclusion: You are legally permitted to form or join a workers' union.

instruction: I want to move to another district in Nepal. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (d) : To move and reside in any part of Nepal,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(d): Rule: Every person has the right to move and reside in any part of Nepal. Application/Conclusion: You can lawfully relocate to another district within Nepal under this constitutional right.

instruction: Can I change my career and start a business?
input:
Section no 20  part (2) (e) : To practice any profession, employment, industry, business, 9
3
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(e): Rule: Individuals have the right to practice any profession, employment, industry or business. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to change careers or start a business; this provision protects that freedom (subject to other laws and regulations).

instruction: Can I get education in my mother tongue?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (f) : To obtain education of his or her choice or in his or her mother tongue,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(f): Rule: Persons have the right to obtain education of their choice, including in their mother tongue. Application/Conclusion: You may seek education in your mother tongue as protected by this provision.

instruction: Can I sell/transfer my property whenever I like?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (g) : To earn, use, transfer property and carry out any other transaction of property,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(g): Rule: Citizens have the right to earn, use, transfer property and carry out property transactions. Application/Conclusion: You have the constitutional right to transfer or sell your property, though such transactions must comply with applicable laws.

instruction: Can I practice the religion my family has followed for generations?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (h) : To profess and practice his or her religion practiced from time immemorial, subject to the compliance of public morality and traditions,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(h): Rule: Individuals may profess and practice a religion practiced from time immemorial, but this is subject to public morality and traditions. Application/Conclusion: You can follow your ancestral religion, provided your practice does not violate public morality or traditional norms recognized by law.

instruction: Can my community preserve its language and culture?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (i) : To preserve and promote the language, script or culture of his or her community,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(i): Rule: Persons have the right to preserve and promote their community's language, script, or culture. Application/Conclusion: Your community may lawfully work to preserve and promote its linguistic and cultural heritage.

instruction: Can I operate a temple and keep my religious community independent?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (j) : To operate a religious place and religious trust, by maintaining independent existence of his or her religious community,
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(j): Rule: People may operate religious places and trusts and maintain the independent existence of their religious community. Application/Conclusion: You may operate a religious place or trust and maintain your community's independent existence under this right.

instruction: Do I have a right to privacy over my letters and documents?
input: Section no 20  part (2) (k) : To protect or maintain privacy of his or her body, residence, property, document, correspondence or information.
output: According to Section 20 part (2)(k): Rule: Individuals have the right to protect or maintain privacy of their body, residence, property, documents, correspondence, or information. Application/Conclusion: Your letters and documents are constitutionally protected as part of your privacy rights.

instruction: Is entering someone's house without their consent a privacy violation?
input:
Section no 21 . Right to privacy deemed to be violated : (1) If any
person commits, save in accordance with law, any of the following acts without
obtaining consent of the concerned person, he or she shall be deemed to have
violated the right to privacy:
 Section no 21  clause (a) : Entry into any person’s residence,
output: According to Section 21(1)(a): Rule: Entry into a person's residence without consent (except as allowed by law) is deemed a violation of the right to privacy. Application/Conclusion: If someone enters your home without your consent and not under a lawful exception, that act is a violation of your constitutional right to privacy.

instruction: Is opening or listening to someone's telephone conversations without permission a violation?
input: Section no 21  clause (b) : Opening a person’s correspondence or using it, taping or recording or listening the discourse, speech, sound through the medium of telephone or other technology, 10
output: According to Section 21(1)(b): Rule: Opening correspondence, recording, taping or listening to someone's telephone or other technological communications without consent is deemed a violation of privacy. Application/Conclusion: Secretly recording or intercepting someone's calls or correspondence without consent would violate their right to privacy under this provision.

instruction: Can someone take my photo and violate my privacy?
input: Section no 21  clause (d) : Taking figure or photograph of a person,
output: According to Section 21(1)(d): Rule: Taking the figure or photograph of a person without consent is listed as an act that violates the right to privacy (unless lawful). Application/Conclusion: If someone takes your photograph without your consent, it can constitute a privacy violation under this clause.

instruction: Is it ever allowed to publish someone's photo for public interest?
input: Section no 21  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (d) or (e) of sub-section (1), if a person commits any act referred to in the said clauses for literary or artistic purpose or public interest, the right to privacy shall not be deemed to have been violated.
output: According to Section 21 part (2): Rule: Acts covered by clauses (d) or (e) (such as taking or imitating someone's figure/photograph) are not deemed privacy violations if done for literary/artistic purposes or public interest. Application/Conclusion: Publishing a person's photo may be permissible if it is for a literary/artistic purpose or public interest; in such cases the right to privacy is not considered violated under this provision.

instruction: Can I make contracts freely?
input: Section no 22 . Right to make contract : Every citizen shall have the right to make a contract subject to the law.
output: According to Section 22: Rule: Every citizen has the right to make contracts, subject to applicable law. Application/Conclusion: You are constitutionally entitled to enter into contracts, but those contracts must comply with governing laws and regulations.

instruction: Can the government tax my income without a law?
input: Section no 23 . No taxation except in accordance with law : No tax shall be levied on and collected from a person’s property or income save in accordance with law.
output: According to Section 23: Rule: Taxes on property or income may only be levied and collected in accordance with law. Application/Conclusion: The government cannot lawfully impose or collect tax on your income or property unless there is a legal basis permitting that tax.

instruction: Can I be forced to work against my will by an employer?
input: Section no 24 . Not to employ in work against will : No person shall be employed in a work against his or her will.
output: According to Section 24: Rule: No person shall be employed in work against their will. Application/Conclusion: You cannot be legally forced into employment against your will; compulsory employment would violate this constitutional right.

instruction: Can the State take my land for public use without following law?
input: Section no 25 . Property not to be acquired, requisitioned, auctioned or : forfeited: (1) The State shall not acquire, requisition, or otherwise create any right in, the property of anyone, except in accordance with law for the purpose of public interest. Provided that this provision shall not apply to a property earned illegally.
output: According to Section 25(1): Rule: The State may only acquire, requisition, or create rights in someone's property in accordance with law and for public interest; illegally earned property is excluded. Application/Conclusion: The government cannot lawfully seize your property for public purposes unless it follows legal procedures; property obtained illegally is not protected by this clause.

instruction: Can my property be auctioned away randomly by authorities?
input: Section no 25  part (2) : No property of anyone shall be auctioned or forfeited except in accordance with law. 11
output: According to Section 25 part (2): Rule: Property cannot be auctioned or forfeited except according to law. Application/Conclusion: Authorities must follow legal procedures before auctioning or forfeiting your property; arbitrary auction or forfeiture would be unlawful.

instruction: I was arrested. Can someone file habeas corpus on my behalf and where?
input: Section no 26 . Complaint may be filed : (1) A person who is arrested or detained or any one on his or her behalf may file a petition in the Supreme Court, High Court or District Court for the writ of habeas corpus.
output: According to Section 26(1): Rule: A detained or arrested person, or someone on their behalf, may file a petition for habeas corpus in the Supreme Court, High Court or District Court. Application/Conclusion: Either you (if detained) or someone acting for you can file a habeas corpus petition in those courts to challenge your detention.

instruction: If I file the same habeas corpus petition in two courts, what happens?
input: Section no 26  part (2) : If a person files a petition in more than one court, the petition filed in the higher court shall be maintained.
output: According to Section 26 part (2): Rule: When petitions are filed in multiple courts, the one filed in the higher court will be maintained. Application/Conclusion: If a habeas corpus petition is filed in more than one court, the petition in the higher court (e.g., High Court over District Court) will be the one that continues; the lower-court petition will not be pursued.

instruction: Is a Provincial Assembly considered a legal person under the law?
input: Section no 44  clause (h) : A Provincial Assembly,
output: According to Section 44 clause (h): A Provincial Assembly is expressly listed. Rule: A Provincial Assembly is included among the categories of legal persons enumerated in Section 44. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, a Provincial Assembly is recognized as a legal person under Section 44.

instruction: Does a Rural Municipality count as a legal person?
input:
Section no 44  clause (i) : A Rural Municipality, Municipality or District
Assembly or Local Level government oﬀice under such a body,
output: According to Section 44 clause (i): A Rural Municipality, Municipality or District Assembly or Local Level government office under such a body is listed. Rule: These local government entities are included in the statutory list of legal persons. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, a Rural Municipality (and the other listed local bodies) is a legal person under Section 44.

instruction: Is a commission set up by the Provincial Government treated as a legal person?
input:
Section no 44  clause (j) : A commission, committee or similar other body
set up in accordance with law by the Government of 24 Nepal, Provincial Government or Local Level Government,
output: According to Section 44 clause (j): A commission, committee or similar body set up in accordance with law by the Government of Nepal, Provincial Government or Local Level Government is listed. Rule: Such bodies established by the government are included as legal persons. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, a commission set up by the Provincial Government (if established in accordance with law) is treated as a legal person under Section 44.

instruction: Are corporations specifically included as legal persons?
input:
Section no 44  clause (k) : A corporation, corporate body or body set up in
accordance with law,
output: According to Section 44 clause (k): A corporation, corporate body or body set up in accordance with law is listed. Rule: Corporations and corporate bodies established by law are included among legal persons. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, a corporation is explicitly recognized as a legal person under Section 44.

instruction: Do temples, monasteries or graveyards count as organizations established for public purpose?
input:
Section no 44  clause (l) : Any organization established for public purpose
such as a shrine, temple, deity place, Chaitya, monastery, mosque, church, public rest house, public inn, and graveyard remained in operation from the time
immemorial and in possession of a property,
output: According to Section 44 clause (l): Any organization established for public purpose such as a shrine, temple, deity place, Chaitya, monastery, mosque, church, public rest house, public inn, and graveyard that remained in operation from time immemorial and is in possession of property is listed. Rule: These examples are treated as organizations established for public purpose and are included in the statutory categories. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, the listed religious and public-purpose sites (e.g., temple, monastery, graveyard) are recognized as organizations for public purpose under Section 44.

instruction: Is a community school or university considered a legal person?
input: Section no 44  clause (k) : A community school, college or university established for public purpose.
output: According to Section 44 clause (k): A community school, college or university established for public purpose is listed. Rule: Educational institutions established for public purpose are included among the categories of legal persons. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, a community school, college or university established for public purpose is treated as a legal person under Section 44.

instruction: Where is the address of a legal person determined if the incorporation document doesn't specify it?
input:
Section no 45 .
Address of location of legal person : The address of
location of a legal person shall be as specified at the time of incorporation of
the body corporate, and where such address is not so specified, the address
where its headquarters or registered oﬀice is located and where such oﬀice or
address also is not specified, the address where the main administrative oﬀice or
transaction and business of such a body corporate is located shall be considered
to be its address of location.
output: According to Section 45: The address of location of a legal person shall be as specified at the time of incorporation; and where such address is not so specified, the address where its headquarters or registered office is located; and where such office or address also is not specified, the address where the main administrative office or transaction and business of such a body corporate is located shall be considered to be its address of location. Rule: There is a three-step fallback for determining a legal person's address: incorporation specification → headquarters/registered office → main administrative office/where business is conducted. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, if the incorporation papers do not specify an address, you look to the headquarters/registered office; if that is also unspecified, the location of the main administrative office or where business is conducted will be treated as the legal person's address.

instruction: Who manages a legal person when its statute does not provide management rules?
input:
Section no 46 . Management and operation of legal person : (1) A legal
person shall, except as otherwise provided by law, be managed and operated in
accordance with the provisions set forth in the statute of such a person, and
where such provisions is not made, it shall be managed and operated by one or
more directors. 25
output: According to Section 46(1): A legal person shall, except as otherwise provided by law, be managed and operated in accordance with its statute, and where such provisions are not made, it shall be managed and operated by one or more directors. Rule: Management follows the statute; lacking statutory rules, management vests in one or more directors. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, if a legal person's statute is silent on management, the law presumes management and operation by one or more directors.

instruction: If directors manage the company, who is responsible for those management actions?
input:
Section no 46  part (2) : The legal person shall be responsible for the management and operation made by the director or directors pursuant to sub-section
(1).
output: According to Section 46(2): The legal person shall be responsible for the management and operation made by the director or directors pursuant to sub-section (1). Rule: Actions taken by directors in managing the legal person result in responsibility resting with the legal person. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, management acts by directors are attributable to the legal person itself, meaning the legal person bears responsibility for those management and operational decisions.

instruction: Who decides how business is operated on behalf of a legal person?
input:
Section no 47 . Operation of business of legal person : (1) In operating
business on behalf of a legal person, the business shall, except as otherwise
provided by law, be operated by the decision of directors of such a person.
output: According to Section 47(1): In operating business on behalf of a legal person, the business shall, except as otherwise provided by law, be operated by the decision of directors of such a person. Rule: Directors' decisions govern the operation of the legal person's business unless law provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, business operations for the legal person are generally carried out based on directors' decisions.

instruction: Can a director delegate his power to operate business to an assistant or another person?
input:
Section no 47  part (2) : In operating business pursuant to sub-section (1),
the director may delegate powers to any director or other person to operate any
business.
output: According to Section 47(2): In operating business pursuant to sub-section (1), the director may delegate powers to any director or other person to operate any business. Rule: Directors are permitted to delegate powers to other directors or to other persons for business operation. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, a director may lawfully authorize an assistant or another person to operate business functions, provided such delegation follows any other applicable law or internal rules.

instruction: If our company merges with another, who gets its rights and liabilities?
input:
Section no 48 .
Right or liability to devolve upon merger of legal
person : (1) If a legal person is, for any reason, merged with another legal
person, the right or liability of such person shall be as specified at the time of
such merger.
Section no 48  part (2) : If not specified pursuant to sub-section (1), the right
or liability of the legal person to be merged shall devolve on the legal person
with which such a person is merged.
output: According to Section 48(1)–(2): If a legal person is merged with another, the rights or liabilities shall be as specified at the time of the merger; if not specified, those rights or liabilities devolve on the legal person with which it is merged. Rule: The merger agreement or terms control; absent specification, rights and liabilities transfer to the surviving/absorbing legal person. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, if your merger documents set out who gets rights/liabilities, follow them; if they are silent, the legal person with which your entity is merged assumes those rights and liabilities.

instruction: Can a legal person act as an agent for someone else?
input:
Section no 49 . Legal person may become agent : A legal person may,
subject to law, act as an agent of any other person.
output: According to Section 49: A legal person may, subject to law, act as an agent of any other person. Rule: Legal persons are permitted to serve as agents, but this ability is subject to applicable law. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, an entity can act as an agent for another person provided such agency complies with relevant legal restrictions.

instruction: Can a member or director vote on a matter where they have a personal interest?
input:
Section no 50 . Not to participate in decision-making in case of conflict
of : interest: (1) A member or director of any body or institution shall not take
12
part in the decision making process on a matter involving his or her personal
interest.
output: According to Section 50(1): A member or director of any body or institution shall not take part in the decision-making process on a matter involving his or her personal interest. Rule: Members/directors must abstain from decision-making where they have personal interest. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, if a director has a personal interest in a matter, they are required to refrain from participating in the decision on that matter.

instruction: What happens if a decision was affected by a director's conflict of interest?
input:
Section no 50  part (2) : If a decision is affected by the conflict of interest
under sub-section (1), such a decision shall be void. 26
output: According to Section 50(2): If a decision is affected by the conflict of interest under sub-section (1), such a decision shall be void. Rule: Decisions affected by participation despite a conflict of interest are void. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, if a director's participation in a matter involving personal interest affected the decision, that decision is void and may be invalidated.

instruction: I want to appoint someone from outside the board to run a business unit — is delegation to 'any other person' permitted?
input:
Section no 47  part (2) : In operating business pursuant to sub-section (1),
the director may delegate powers to any director or other person to operate any
business.
output: According to Section 47(2): The director may delegate powers to any director or other person to operate any business. Rule: Delegation is expressly permitted to directors or other persons. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, you may appoint an external person to operate a business unit by way of delegation, subject to any other applicable laws or internal governance rules.

instruction: If the incorporation document specified an address, is that the official address of the legal person?
input:
Section no 45 .
Address of location of legal person : The address of
location of a legal person shall be as specified at the time of incorporation of
the body corporate, and where such address is not so specified, the address
where its headquarters or registered oﬀice is located and where such oﬀice or
address also is not specified, the address where the main administrative oﬀice or
transaction and business of such a body corporate is located shall be considered
to be its address of location.
output: According to Section 45: The address of location of a legal person shall be as specified at the time of incorporation of the body corporate. Rule: The address given at incorporation is the legal person's address unless that was not specified, in which case fallback rules apply. Application/Conclusion: Therefore, if the incorporation document specifies an address, that is the official address of the legal person.

instruction: When did this Act come into force?
input: Section no 1  part (2) : It shall come into force on 17 August 2018 (first day of the month of Bhadra of the year 2075).
output: According to Section 1(2): Rule: The Act specifies its commencement date. Application/Conclusion: The Act came into force on 17 August 2018 (the first day of Bhadra 2075).

instruction: Can I say I didn't know the law to avoid liability?
input: Section no 5 . Ignorance of law not to be excused : The ignorance of law shall not be excused. Every one shall be presumed to have the knowledge of law.
output: According to Section 5: Rule: Ignorance of the law is not a defense; everyone is presumed to know the law. Application/Conclusion: You cannot avoid legal consequences merely by claiming you did not know the law.

instruction: Someone damaged my property. Are they responsible for the loss?
input: Section no 8 . A wrongdoer to bear liability for loss or damage : (1) A person who causes loss or damage to another person by committing a wrong while doing, or causing to be done any act shall bear the liability for such loss or damage.
output: According to Section 8(1): Rule: A person who causes loss or damage by committing a wrong while doing (or causing to be done) any act must bear liability for that loss or damage. Application/Conclusion: If someone damaged your property by a wrongful act, that person is liable to bear the resulting loss or damage.

instruction: If I commit a wrongful act, must I personally bear the consequences?
input: Section no 8  part (2) : Every person shall himself or herself bear the consequences of any wrongful act committed by him or her.
output: According to Section 8(2): Rule: Every person must personally bear the consequences of wrongful acts they commit. Application/Conclusion: You are personally responsible for consequences arising from any wrongful acts you commit.

instruction: Can the court order compensation? How is compensation determined?
input:
Section no 8  part (3) : Except as otherwise provided for in this Act or law, the concerned person shall bear compensation to perform the liability referred to in sub-section (1).
Section no 8  part (4) : Determination of the Compensation shall be as provided for in the law.
output: According to Section 8(3) and 8(4): Rule: Unless another provision applies, the person liable must pay compensation for the loss; determination of compensation follows the methods provided by law. Application/Conclusion: A wrongdoer must compensate the victim, and the amount and method for calculating that compensation are determined by applicable law.

instruction: Can someone benefit from an act they themselves did wrongfully?
input: Section no 10 . Not to enjoy benefit of wrong : No person shall be entitled to enjoy benefit accrued from his or her own wrong.
output: According to Section 10: Rule: A person is not entitled to enjoy benefits obtained from their own wrongful act. Application/Conclusion: If any gain arises from your wrongful act, you cannot lawfully retain or enjoy that benefit.

instruction: Are acts against public interest allowed?
input: Section no 6 . Act against public interest not to be carried out : No one may carry out any act in such a manner so that it may be against public interest.
output: According to Section 6: Rule: Acts that are against public interest must not be carried out. Application/Conclusion: You must not perform actions that are against public interest; such conduct is prohibited under the Act.

instruction: Is an act contrary to law valid?
input: Section no 7 . Act contrary to law to be invalid : Any act contrary to law shall be invalid.
output: According to Section 7: Rule: Any act that is contrary to law is invalid. Application/Conclusion: If an action contravenes the law, it has no legal validity under this Act.

instruction: If there is a special law on an issue, does this Act override it?
input: Section no 3  : Not to prejudice special legal provisions: Where a law in force provides a separate provision in any matter regulated by this Act, no provision of this Act shall affect such a matter.
output: According to Section 3: Rule: When another law in force provides a separate provision on a matter covered by this Act, this Act does not affect that separate provision. Application/Conclusion: Procedural or substantive rules provided by another existing law on a subject take precedence; this Act will not override those special legal provisions.

instruction: How many days do I have to file a civil case if I discovered fraud today?
input: Section no 3  : Not to prejudice special legal provisions: Where a law in force provides a separate provision in any matter regulated by this Act, no provision of this Act shall affect such a matter.
output: According to Section 3: Rule: This Act defers to other laws that contain separate provisions on matters it regulates. Application/Conclusion: Time limits for filing (limitation periods) are matters typically specified in other laws; you must consult the specific law on limitation for civil actions because this Act does not change such special provisions.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me land but backed out. Can I get compensation?
input:
Section no 8 . A wrongdoer to bear liability for loss or damage : (1) A person who causes loss or damage to another person by committing a wrong while doing, or causing to be done any act shall bear the liability for such loss or damage.
Section no 8  part (3) : Except as otherwise provided for in this Act or law, the concerned person shall bear compensation to perform the liability referred to in sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 8(1) and 8(3): Rule: A person who causes loss or damage by committing a wrong must bear liability and, unless another law applies, must pay compensation for that loss. Application/Conclusion: If Ram's backing out amounted to a wrongful act causing you loss, he would bear liability and, subject to other applicable law, should compensate you for that loss.

instruction: Who counts as a 'person' under this Act?
input: Section no 2  clause (c) : “person” means a natural person and this term includes a legal person,
output: According to Section 2(c): Rule: 'Person' includes natural persons and also legal persons (e.g., corporations). Application/Conclusion: Both human beings and legal entities are considered 'persons' under the Act for rights and obligations.

instruction: What exactly does 'property' cover here?
input: Section no 2  clause (g) : “property” means any movable or immovable property,
output: According to Section 2(g): Rule: 'Property' is defined to include any movable or immovable property. Application/Conclusion: The term covers things like land and buildings (immovable) as well as goods, vehicles, and other movable items.

instruction: What does the Act mean by 'court'?
input: Section no 2  clause (a) : “court” means the Supreme Court, High Court or District Court, and this term includes a court, other judicial body or authority authorized by law to proceed and adjudicate any specific type of civil cases,
output: According to Section 2(a): Rule: 'Court' includes the Supreme Court, High Court, District Court, and any other judicial body or authority authorized by law to adjudicate specific civil cases. Application/Conclusion: References to 'court' in the Act can mean various courts or authorized judicial bodies depending on the matter and statutory authorization.

instruction: Is causing nuisance to others prohibited by the Act?
input: Section no 9 . Act causing nuisance to other not to be done : No person shall do, or cause to be done, any act that causes nuisance, annoyance or damage to prestige, reputation or property of another person.
output: According to Section 9: Rule: No person shall do or cause acts that cause nuisance, annoyance, or damage to another's prestige, reputation, or property. Application/Conclusion: Actions that create nuisance or harm someone's reputation or property are prohibited and can be challenged under the Act.

instruction: Can I make an agreement that harms someone under my guardianship?
input: Section no 11 . Act against interest to be invalid : Any act done against the interest of a person who is under one’s own guardianship, curatorship, subjection or influence or likely be under influence shall be invalid.
output: According to Section 11: Rule: Any act done against the interest of a person under your guardianship, curatorship, subjection or influence is invalid. Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully enter into or enforce agreements that are against the interests of someone under your guardianship; such acts are invalid under the Act.

instruction: Are there general principles in Chapter 2 that apply broadly?
input: Section no 4 . Principles and provisions applicable generally : The principles and provisions referred to in this Chapter shall generally be applicable to the matters of civil law.
output: According to Section 4: Rule: The principles and provisions in Chapter 2 are generally applicable to civil law matters. Application/Conclusion: The Chapter 2 principles (like those on liability, nuisance, etc.) serve as general rules guiding civil law cases unless specific provisions state otherwise.

instruction: Does the Act require us to recognize each other's personality?
input: Section no 12 . Personality to be recognized : Every person shall recognize other person’s personality.
output: According to Section 12: Rule: Every person must recognize the personality of others. Application/Conclusion: The law requires respect for others' personality; this underpins protections against acts that demean or harm another person's personality or dignity.

instruction: Who is an 'heir' according to the Act?
input: Section no 2  clause (h) : “heir” means a person who is in the order of priority for succession pursuant to Section 239.
output: According to Section 2(h): Rule: 'Heir' means a person who is in the order of priority for succession as set out in Section 239. Application/Conclusion: An heir is someone who falls within the succession priority defined elsewhere in the Act (Section 239); succession order determines who qualifies as an heir.

instruction: Can I ask the court to declare my missing husband dead after the landslide? What must I file?
input: Section no 40  part (4) : If the concerned person files a petition stating that any person has disappeared without a notice or died due to a disaster or accident and requests for a judicial declaration on such person’s death, disclosing therewith the date, place, cause of death and basis thereof, the court may, after examining the evidence, make an order of judicial declaration on the death of such a person.
output: According to Section 40 part (4)... Rule: A person may file a petition requesting a judicial declaration of death when someone has disappeared or died due to a disaster/accident, and the petition must disclose date, place, cause of death and the basis for the request. Application/Conclusion: You can petition the court for a declaration of death for your husband after the landslide by filing a petition that states he disappeared or died in the disaster and gives the date, place, cause and supporting basis; the court may grant the declaration after examining evidence.

instruction: My uncle was declared dead but has returned alive. Can the old declaration be cancelled?
input: Section no 40  part (5) : If a person already declared dead pursuant to sub section (4) comes back alive and files a petition in person to get the judicial declaration made earlier to be annulled or if his or her 19 successor files a petition for amendment to the previous judicial declaration on death for the reason that the date of death of such deceased happened to be different than the date referred to in the judicial declaration, the court shall, having examined into this matter, annul or amend the judicial declaration made pursuant to sub-section (4). Provided that
output: According to Section 40 part (5)... Rule: If a person previously declared dead under subsection (4) returns alive and petitions, or a successor petitions to amend the date of death, the court must examine the matter and may annul or amend the prior judicial declaration. Application/Conclusion: Since your uncle has come back alive and can file in person, the court can annul the earlier declaration after examining the evidence — you should file that petition so the declaration can be set aside.

instruction: Multiple relatives died in a bus crash. For succession, how do we determine who died first?
input: Section no 40  part (3) : Where more than one person are dead at one and the same time in an accident, each person so died is deemed, except as otherwise proved, to have been died at the same time. Provided that where, for a particular purpose, a question that which of the persons died first in such an accident requires to be settled, the person who was older by age at the time of death shall, unless otherwise proved, be deemed to have been died first.
output: According to Section 40 part (3)... Rule: When several people die at the same time in an accident, they are presumed to have died simultaneously; but if it is necessary to determine who died first, the older person is presumed to have died first unless proved otherwise. Application/Conclusion: For succession issues from the bus crash, you should assume simultaneous death unless you need to establish order for a specific purpose; in that case the elder among them will be treated as having died first unless evidence shows otherwise.

instruction: If someone was traveling by ship and the ship sank, when can they be legally treated as dead?
input: part (3) : In the case of a person traveling by an aircraft, ship or other vehicle that met with an accident, three years after the date of such accident.
output: According to Section 40 part (3)... Rule: In the case of a person traveling by aircraft, ship or other vehicle that met with an accident, that person is treated as dead three years after the date of the accident. Application/Conclusion: If the ship sank and the person remained missing, they may be deemed dead after three years from the accident date under this provision; you can rely on that period when considering legal steps for estate or benefits.

instruction: A man died alone in an accident; no one else was involved. Is he still 'deemed' to have died at the same time as others?
input: Section no 40  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (3) of the proviso to sub-section (1), if a person dies in an accident and there is no evidence of another person meeting with the same accident to remain alive, such a person also shall be deemed to have died at the same time.
output: According to Section 40 part (2)... Rule: Even if there is no evidence of another person surviving the same accident, a person who dies in an accident shall be deemed to have died at the same time (notwithstanding other provisos). Application/Conclusion: If your relative died alone in an accident and there’s no evidence anyone else survived that same incident, the law treats them as having died at the same time as relevant comparison persons under this rule, which can affect timing issues in succession or other matters.

instruction: I discovered an act taken under a death declaration that harmed me. How many months do I have to sue in general?
input: Section no 41  clause (c) : In any circumstance other than that referred to in clauses (a) and (b), within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action taken.
output: According to Section 41 clause (c)... Rule: For matters not covered by clauses (a) or (b), an aggrieved person must file suit within six months from the date the act or action was done. Application/Conclusion: Since your situation doesn't fall under the special cases in (a) or (b), you generally have six months from when the act that harmed you occurred to initiate a lawsuit.

instruction: I only learned today that someone amended a judicial death declaration under Section 40(5). How long do I have to challenge it?
input: Section no 41  clause (b) : In the case of the circumstance referred to in sub section (5) of Section 40, within one year after the date of knowledge of such an act or action,
output: According to Section 41 clause (b)... Rule: For actions related to subsection (5) of Section 40 (annulment/amendment of a prior declaration), an aggrieved person has one year from the date of knowledge of the act to sue. Application/Conclusion: Because this concerns an amendment/annulment under Section 40(5) and you just learned about it, you have one year from today (the date you gained knowledge) to bring a legal challenge.

instruction: A prior declaration of death affected property; is there a shorter deadline tied to Section 36 issues?
input: Section no 41  clause (a) : In the case of the circumstance referred to in Section 36, within three months after the date on which such act was done or action taken, 20
output: According to Section 41 clause (a)... Rule: For circumstances referred to in Section 36, the limitation period to sue is three months from the date the relevant act was done. Application/Conclusion: If your grievance arises from an act covered by Section 36, you must file suit within three months of that act; check whether your situation falls under Section 36 to determine this shorter deadline.

instruction: If someone's date of death in a judicial declaration is changed later, will earlier acts carried out under the original declaration be undone?
input: Section no 40  part (3) : The act that has already been carried out pursuant to the previous judicial declaration shall not be prejudiced by virtue of the establishment of a new date of death.
output: According to Section 40 part (3)... Rule: Acts already carried out pursuant to a previous judicial declaration are not prejudiced by establishing a new date of death. Application/Conclusion: If the court amends the date of death later, transactions or actions done under the earlier declaration remain valid and are not invalidated by the new date.

instruction: Does declaring someone dead harm their legal rights?
input: Section no 40  part (2) : There shall be no adverse effect on the legal right of the person declared to be dead.
output: According to Section 40 part (2)... Rule: A judicial declaration of death shall not have an adverse effect on the legal rights of the person declared dead. Application/Conclusion: Legally, the declaration itself should not harm the declared person's rights; if the person is later found alive, their legal rights are preserved under this rule.

instruction: If a judicial death declaration is later amended, can third-party rights under the original acts be affected?
input: Section no 40  part (4) : The right, interest or concern of the person provided by law shall not be affected by any act done or action taken pursuant to clause (3).
output: According to Section 40 part (4)... Rule: Rights, interests or concerns provided by law shall not be affected by acts done pursuant to clause (3) (i.e., acts carried out under a prior declaration). Application/Conclusion: Third-party or statutory rights established under earlier acts remain protected even if the date of death is later changed; those rights are not to be disturbed by the amendment.

instruction: My wife remarried after her husband was declared dead. Now he’s back. Can their marriage be restored?
input: Section no 40  part (1) : Where a living wife has concluded another marriage after such declaration, the matrimonial relationship with the person declared to be dead cannot be re-established.
output: According to Section 40 part (1)... Rule: If a living wife remarried after a judicial declaration of her husband's death, the original matrimonial relationship cannot be re-established. Application/Conclusion: Because the wife has lawfully remarried following the declaration, the prior marriage cannot be reinstated even if the husband returns alive.

instruction: What exactly does a 'judicial declaration on death' require? Explain plainly.
input: Section no 40  part (4) : If the concerned person files a petition stating that any person has disappeared without a notice or died due to a disaster or accident and requests for a judicial declaration on such person’s death, disclosing therewith the date, place, cause of death and basis thereof, the court may, after examining the evidence, make an order of judicial declaration on the death of such a person.
output: According to Section 40 part (4)... Rule: A judicial declaration on death is a court order made when someone petitions saying a person disappeared or died in a disaster/accident and provides the date, place, cause and basis; the court examines evidence before issuing the order. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, you must file a petition explaining when/where/how the person went missing or died and why you believe they are dead; the judge will review proof and may formally declare the person dead.

instruction: Under which section does a corporate body acquire legal competency once incorporated?
input: Section no 42 . Legal person to acquire competency : (1) A body corporate incorporated pursuant to law shall obtain legal personality, and obtain legal competency in the same capacity.
output: According to Section 42(1)... Rule: A body corporate incorporated under law acquires legal personality and legal competency in that capacity. Application/Conclusion: A company or similar body incorporated under the law immediately gains legal personality and the ability to act legally (competency) as that corporate entity under Section 42(1).

instruction: A successor wants the death-date in a judicial declaration corrected because inheritance distribution depends on it. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 40  part (5) : If a person already declared dead pursuant to sub section (4) comes back alive and files a petition in person to get the judicial declaration made earlier to be annulled or if his or her 19 successor files a petition for amendment to the previous judicial declaration on death for the reason that the date of death of such deceased happened to be different than the date referred to in the judicial declaration, the court shall, having examined into this matter, annul or amend the judicial declaration made pursuant to sub-section (4). Provided that
output: According to Section 40 part (5)... Rule: A successor may file a petition to amend a prior judicial declaration of death if the date of death in the declaration is incorrect; the court shall examine and may amend or annul the declaration. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a successor can petition the court to correct the date of death in the declaration for inheritance reasons; the court will review the evidence and may amend the earlier declaration.

instruction: I want to sue over an action taken after a judicial declaration of death, but it's been 8 months since I learned about it. Am I out of time?
input: Section no 41  clause (b) : In the case of the circumstance referred to in sub section (5) of Section 40, within one year after the date of knowledge of such an act or action,
output: According to Section 41 clause (b)... Rule: For matters connected to subsection (5) of Section 40 (annulment/amendment of a declaration), the limitation is one year from the date of knowledge. Application/Conclusion: If your claim relates to an amendment/annulment under Section 40(5) and you discovered the act 8 months ago, you still have time — you may file within one year of when you learned about it.

instruction: Short question: If someone disappears in a vehicle accident, after how long are they considered dead?
input: part (3) : In the case of a person traveling by an aircraft, ship or other vehicle that met with an accident, three years after the date of such accident.
output: According to Section 40 part (3)... Rule: A person traveling by aircraft, ship or other vehicle involved in an accident is deemed dead three years after the accident date. Application/Conclusion: Simply put, if someone vanished in such an accident, the law treats them as dead three years after the date of that accident.

instruction: Can my 12-year-old son sell his smartphone without my consent?
input:
Section no 34 . To be considered quasi-competent : (1) A person who
has attained ten years of age but not completed eighteen years of age shall be
considered as a quasi-competent person.

 Section no 34  part (3) : A quasi-competent person shall, in exercising a right,
obtain the consent of the guardian or curator or exercise the right through the
guardian or curator, as the case may be.

 Section no 34  part (4) : In executing a document by a quasi-competent
person, it shall be executed in the presence of his or her guardian or curator, as
the case may be. 15
output: According to Section 34(1), 34(3) and 34(4): Rule: A person aged 10–18 is a quasi-competent person and may exercise rights subject to law, but when exercising a right they must obtain the guardian's/curator's consent or act through them, and any document execution must occur in the guardian's/curator's presence. Application/Conclusion: Your 12-year-old is quasi-competent, so they cannot validly sell the smartphone alone — you (as guardian) must consent or the sale must be carried out through you and any document should be executed in your presence.

instruction: My 9-year-old signed a contract — is it valid?
input:
Section no 33 . To be considered incompetent : (1) Notwithstanding
anything contained in Section 32, a person who has not attained ten years of age,
or even if attained that age, is unable to protect his or her right and interest for
the reason of unsoundness of mind shall be considered to be legally incompetent.

 Section no 33  part (2) : An incompetent person does not have to bear any
type of legal obligation, and while exercising a right, it has to be exercised,
or cause to be exercised, only with the consent of the guardian or curator or
through the guardian or curator, as the case may be.

 Section no 33  part (3) : In executing a document on behalf of an incompetent person, it shall be executed, or caused to be executed, through his or her
guardian or curator, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 33(1), 33(2) and 33(3): Rule: A person who has not attained ten years of age is legally incompetent; an incompetent person does not bear legal obligations and may exercise rights only with the guardian/curator's consent or through them; documents for an incompetent person must be executed through their guardian/curator. Application/Conclusion: A contract signed by your 9-year-old is generally not validly binding on them — they are legally incompetent, so obligations from that contract would not normally bind the child and any valid execution should have been done through their guardian.

instruction: What does 'unsoundness of mind' actually mean here? Plain English, please.
input:
14 Explanation: For the purposes of this Act, the term “unsoundness of mind”
means the condition of being incapable, due to physical and mental ill health,
of knowing the act done by oneself in general understanding and consequences
thereof.
output: According to Section 33 Explanation: Rule: “Unsoundness of mind” means a condition, caused by physical or mental ill health, in which a person is incapable of understanding their own actions in general and the consequences. Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, it means someone who, because of illness, cannot grasp what they are doing or what will happen because of it — and that condition is what the law considers when deciding if a person is legally incompetent.

instruction: My elderly father with severe dementia needs surgery. He can't say yes. Who can consent?
input:
Section no 36  part (2) : If a person is so incapable that he or she cannot
express his or her consent, his or her guardian or curator, as the case may be,
for the interest of such a person, carry out, or cause to be carried out, the act
referred to in sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 36(2): Rule: If a person cannot express consent, their guardian or curator may, in the person's interest, carry out or cause to be carried out acts like examination, treatment or transplantation referred to in subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: Your father's guardian or curator (e.g., legally appointed guardian) can give consent for the surgery on his behalf, acting in his best interest.

instruction: Can a person who is declared incompetent be made to repay debts?
input:
Section no 33  part (2) : An incompetent person does not have to bear any
type of legal obligation, and while exercising a right, it has to be exercised,
or cause to be exercised, only with the consent of the guardian or curator or
through the guardian or curator, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 33(2): Rule: An incompetent person does not have to bear any type of legal obligation; they may exercise rights only with guardian/curator consent or through them. Application/Conclusion: Generally, an incompetent person is not personally bound to legal obligations such as debt repayment — the law relieves them of such obligations unless proper guardian/curator procedures apply.

instruction: There’s a fight in the family — they say my sister is mentally unfit to manage property. How is that resolved?
input:
Section no 35 . To be according to court decision : If a dispute arises
about a person’s competency, incompetency or quasi-competency, it shall be
settled according to the decision of the court.
output: According to Section 35: Rule: Any dispute about a person's competency, incompetency or quasi-competency must be settled by a court decision. Application/Conclusion: If your family disputes your sister's capacity to manage property, you must take the matter to court — the court will decide her legal status (competent, quasi-competent or incompetent) and that decision will govern what can be done.

instruction: Can I legally tell people how my cremation should be done before I die?
input:
Section no 37 . Power to specify method of one’s cremation, obsequies
rites or : funereal acts: (1) Any person may, while he or she is alive, specify
the manner of cremation, obsequies rites or funereal acts to be carried out after
his or her death.
output: According to Section 37(1): Rule: Any person may, while alive, specify how their cremation, obsequies rites or funeral acts should be carried out after death. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can legally specify your cremation and funeral wishes while alive, and those instructions should be respected after your death.

instruction: If someone is declared incompetent, how should their documents be signed?
input:
Section no 33  part (3) : In executing a document on behalf of an incompetent person, it shall be executed, or caused to be executed, through his or her
guardian or curator, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 33(3): Rule: Documents executed on behalf of an incompetent person must be executed, or caused to be executed, through their guardian or curator. Application/Conclusion: Any legal documents for an incompetent person must be signed by (or under the authority of) their appointed guardian or curator; direct signatures by the incompetent person are not the proper method.

instruction: Does a 15-year-old need a parent present to sign school permission forms?
input:
Section no 34  part (4) : In executing a document by a quasi-competent
person, it shall be executed in the presence of his or her guardian or curator, as
the case may be. 15
output: According to Section 34(4): Rule: When a quasi-competent person executes a document, it must be done in the presence of their guardian or curator. Application/Conclusion: A 15-year-old (quasi-competent) should execute important documents like permission forms in the presence of their guardian; the guardian's presence is required for proper execution.

instruction: Can a healthy adult donate an organ while alive?
input:
Section no 36 . Physical examination or change of organ may be made
: (1) Any person may, subject to law, get his or her body examined, treated or
transplanted or collected any organ or part or a sample of his or her body.
output: According to Section 36(1): Rule: Any person may, subject to law, undergo examination, treatment, transplantation or have an organ/part/sample collected from their body. Application/Conclusion: A healthy adult may donate an organ while alive if it complies with applicable laws and procedures — the statute allows such acts subject to legal requirements.

instruction: My uncle wrote explicit funeral wishes — can I simply ignore them and do like we always did?
input:
Section no 37  part (2) : If a person has specified the manner of cremation,
obsequies rites or funereal acts pursuant to sub-section (1), his or her successor
shall carry out his or her cremation, obsequies rites or funereal acts accordingly.
output: According to Section 37(2): Rule: If a person has specified the manner of their cremation or funeral acts while alive, the successor must carry them out accordingly. Application/Conclusion: You cannot ignore your uncle's explicit, specified wishes — his successor is legally required to carry out the cremation and funeral acts as he directed.

instruction: Are children younger than 10 always treated as legally incompetent?
input:
Section no 33 . To be considered incompetent : (1) Notwithstanding
anything contained in Section 32, a person who has not attained ten years of age,
or even if attained that age, is unable to protect his or her right and interest for
the reason of unsoundness of mind shall be considered to be legally incompetent.
output: According to Section 33(1): Rule: A person who has not attained ten years of age is considered legally incompetent. Application/Conclusion: Yes — under this law, children under 10 are treated as legally incompetent (unless some other legal provision overrides), and therefore cannot independently exercise legal rights or obligations.

instruction: Can a 17-year-old be held responsible for contractual duties?
input:
Section no 34  part (2) : A quasi-competent person may, subject to law,
exercise, bear and discharge any right, obligation and duty whatsoever.

 Section no 34  part (3) : A quasi-competent person shall, in exercising a right,
obtain the consent of the guardian or curator or exercise the right through the
guardian or curator, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 34(2) and 34(3): Rule: A quasi-competent person (10–18 years) may exercise and bear rights, obligations and duties subject to law, but must obtain guardian/curator consent or act through them when exercising rights. Application/Conclusion: A 17-year-old can in principle be subject to contractual duties, but practically the exercise of such rights/obligations typically requires guardian consent or to be done through the guardian — so enforceability depends on whether guardian consent/procedures were followed.

instruction: My cousin is 13 and signed a lease agreement — can the landlord enforce it without my parent's agreement?
input:
