 Section no 34  part (3) : A quasi-competent person shall, in exercising a right,
obtain the consent of the guardian or curator or exercise the right through the
guardian or curator, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 34(1) and 34(3): Rule: Ages 10–18 are quasi-competent persons who may exercise rights but must obtain guardian/curator consent or act through them. Application/Conclusion: The landlord cannot reliably enforce the lease against your 13-year-old cousin unless the guardian's consent was obtained or the lease was entered through the guardian; without that, enforceability is doubtful.

instruction: If a 14-year-old executes a will in front of a friend but not their guardian, is it valid?
input:
Section no 34  part (4) : In executing a document by a quasi-competent
person, it shall be executed in the presence of his or her guardian or curator, as
the case may be. 15
output: According to Section 34(4): Rule: A document executed by a quasi-competent person must be executed in the presence of their guardian or curator. Application/Conclusion: A will (a document) signed by a 14-year-old without the guardian's presence would not meet this statutory requirement — its validity would be questionable because the guardian was not present as required.

instruction: Who decides if someone is competent or not when family members disagree?
input:
Section no 35 . To be according to court decision : If a dispute arises
about a person’s competency, incompetency or quasi-competency, it shall be
settled according to the decision of the court.
output: According to Section 35: Rule: Any dispute over a person's competency status must be resolved by a court decision. Application/Conclusion: When family members disagree about competence, you must bring the matter to court — the court will determine the person's legal status and that decision governs subsequent actions.

instruction: If someone didn't state funeral wishes, how should successors decide what to do?
input:
Section no 37  part (3) : If a person has not specified the manner of his or
her cremation, obsequies rites or funereal acts pursuant to sub-section
 Section no 37  part (1) : , his or her successor shall conduct such person’s
cremation, obsequies rites or funereal acts according to the prevailing custom
and tradition.
output: According to Section 37(3) (as continued): Rule: If a person has not specified their cremation or funeral manner while alive, their successor shall conduct the rites according to prevailing custom and tradition. Application/Conclusion: If there are no written instructions, the successor should follow customary and traditional practices when arranging the cremation and funeral.

instruction: If someone over 10 still can't protect their interests because of mental illness, are they treated as incompetent?
input:
Section no 33 . To be considered incompetent : (1) Notwithstanding
anything contained in Section 32, a person who has not attained ten years of age,
or even if attained that age, is unable to protect his or her right and interest for
the reason of unsoundness of mind shall be considered to be legally incompetent.
output: According to Section 33(1): Rule: Even if a person has attained ten years of age, if they are unable to protect their rights and interests due to unsoundness of mind, they are considered legally incompetent. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a person over 10 can still be declared legally incompetent if mental illness prevents them from protecting their rights; their status depends on their capacity, not just age.

instruction: Can a company be held responsible if its employee acting for the company causes damage to my shop?
input:
. Legal person to be liable : If a loss or damage is caused to a
person from an act done and action taken by a person on behalf of a legal person,
such a legal person shall be liable and bear compensation therefor. Provided
that if any loss is caused by doing an act beyond the objective or competency
of the legal person or dishonestly, the director or a person doing such act shall
personally be liable therefor.
 Section no 52 .
output: According to Section 52... Rule: A legal person shall be liable and bear compensation if loss or damage is caused by an act done by a person on its behalf; but if the act was beyond the legal person's objective or competency or done dishonestly, the director or the person who did the act is personally liable. Application/Conclusion: If your shop was damaged by someone acting on behalf of the company and that act was within the company's objective/competency, you can claim compensation from the company. If the act was beyond the company's objective/competency or dishonest, you may pursue the director or the individual personally for liability.

instruction: My director abused his power and took money dishonestly. Can I sue him personally or only the company?
input:
. Legal person to be liable : If a loss or damage is caused to a
person from an act done and action taken by a person on behalf of a legal person,
such a legal person shall be liable and bear compensation therefor. Provided
that if any loss is caused by doing an act beyond the objective or competency
of the legal person or dishonestly, the director or a person doing such act shall
personally be liable therefor.
 Section no 52 .
output: According to Section 52... Rule: Where loss is caused by an act beyond the legal person's objective or competency or by dishonesty, the director or the person who did the act shall be personally liable. Application/Conclusion: Because the director acted dishonestly, he can be held personally liable; you are not limited to suing just the company.

instruction: Our NGO was dissolved last month. Who settles the debts and assets now?
input:
Assets or liability to be settled : If a legal person is
dissolved for any reason, the assets and liabilities of such a person shall be
settled in accordance with law.
 Section no 53 .
output: According to Section 53... Rule: When a legal person is dissolved, its assets and liabilities must be settled in accordance with law. Application/Conclusion: After the NGO's dissolution, its assets and debts need to be wound up following applicable law—creditors should be paid and remaining assets distributed per legal procedure.

instruction: I discovered a wrongful action today. How long do I have to file a lawsuit under this Chapter?
input:
Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within three months after the date of knowledge of such an act or action in the cases of Section 50 and within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action taken, in the other cases. 27 Chapter-3 Provisions Relating to Bankruptcy of Natural Persons
 Section no 54 .
output: According to Section 54... Rule: A person aggrieved may sue within three months after knowledge in cases of Section 50, and within six months after the act in other cases. Application/Conclusion: If your grievance falls under Section 50, you have three months from the date you learned of it to file; otherwise you generally have six months from when the act occurred.

instruction: Can creditors start bankruptcy against me if I have steady salary and can pay over time?
input:
Section no 54  part (2) (a) : If a person who has regular income or is certain
to earn income in the future proves that his or her income can pay or set off
debts or other liabilities in a certain period or the creditor is satisfied in such
matter,
output: According to Section 54(2)(a)... Rule: No bankruptcy proceedings may be initiated if a person with regular or certain future income proves that income can pay or set off debts within a certain period, or if the creditor is satisfied with that. Application/Conclusion: If you can prove your steady income will cover debts within an agreed period and creditors accept that, bankruptcy proceedings cannot be started against you.

instruction: I want to ask the court to stop bankruptcy and give me time to repay over years. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 54  part (2) (b) : If a person likely to be a bankrupt asks for a
period of up to five years specifying the period of time to repay the debts of
creditors and sources thereof from the date of origin of conditions necessitating
the commencement of bankruptcy proceedings in order to enjoin or cause to be
enjoined from initiating that proceedings,
output: According to Section 54(2)(b)... Rule: Bankruptcy proceedings may not be initiated if the likely bankrupt requests up to five years, specifying how and when debts will be repaid, to enjoin initiation of proceedings. Application/Conclusion: You can ask for up to five years and present a repayment plan and sources; if accepted, this can prevent bankruptcy proceedings from commencing.

instruction: My business has many small creditors. Who counts as a 'creditor' to block bankruptcy?
input: Section no 54  part (2) : For the purposes of clause (c), the term “creditor” means, where there are more than one creditor, creditors or a group of creditors who hold fifty percent or more debts out of the total debts of the person likely to become bankrupt.
output: According to Section 54(2)... Rule: For clause (c), 'creditor' means, among multiple creditors, those creditors or a group holding fifty percent or more of the total debts. Application/Conclusion: To meet the rule in clause (c), you need the agreement of creditors who together hold at least 50% of the debtor's total debt.

instruction: What exactly are 'assets' for bankruptcy purposes? Plainly please.
input: Section no 54  part (1) : For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “assets” means the concerned person’s property 28 standing for the time being or to be earned or likely to be earned up to the time prior to the completion of bankruptcy proceedings pursuant to this Chapter.
output: According to Section 54(1)... Rule: 'Assets' means the person's property currently held or to be earned or likely to be earned up until completion of the bankruptcy proceedings. Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, assets include what you own now plus income or property you will reasonably get before bankruptcy concludes.

instruction: If one creditor's claim is paid from my assets under this Chapter, does that mean I'm bankrupt?
input:
Section no 54  part (3) : If a debt or claim of a creditor is settled from the
assets of a person under this Chapter, such a person shall be deemed to become
a bankrupt.
output: According to Section 54(3)... Rule: If a creditor's debt or claim is settled from the person's assets under this Chapter, the person shall be deemed bankrupt. Application/Conclusion: If your assets are used to satisfy a creditor's claim under this Chapter, you will be legally considered bankrupt.

instruction: Will the court inform any office if I'm declared bankrupt?
input:
Section no 54  part (4) : The court shall send the record of the person being
bankrupt pursuant to sub-section (3) to the bankruptcy administration oﬀice
established for that purpose.
output: According to Section 54(4)... Rule: The court must send the record of the bankrupt person (per subsection (3)) to the bankruptcy administration office established for that purpose. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you're declared bankrupt under subsection (3), the court is required to forward your record to the bankruptcy administration office.

instruction: Does the bankruptcy office keep my record up to date after notification?
input:
Section no 54  part (5) : The bankruptcy administration oﬀice shall update
the records referred to in sub-section (4).
output: According to Section 54(5)... Rule: The bankruptcy administration office shall update the records referred to in subsection (4). Application/Conclusion: After the court sends your bankruptcy record to the office, that office is responsible for updating and maintaining your record.

instruction: If I'm declared bankrupt under this law, do I still have to pay my other unrelated debts?
input:
Section no 54  part (6) : Any person declared bankrupt pursuant to subsection
 Section no 54  part (3) : shall not be required to repay debt or fulfill the obligation other than the debt or obligation he or she has to pay or fulfill and
settle under this Chapter.
 Section no 54
output: According to Section 54(6)... Rule: A person declared bankrupt pursuant to subsection (3) shall not be required to repay debts or fulfill obligations other than those debts or obligations that he or she has to pay, fulfill and settle under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: Once declared bankrupt under subsection (3), you are generally relieved from repaying obligations outside the scope of debts being handled under this Chapter; you need only deal with debts prescribed under the bankruptcy process here.

instruction: My creditor refuses to agree to bankruptcy proceedings. Can they still force it?
input:
Section no 54  part (2) (c) : If the creditor does not agree to initiate, or
cause to be initiated, bankruptcy proceedings. Explanation:
output: According to Section 54(2)(c)... Rule: No bankruptcy proceedings may be initiated if the creditor does not agree to initiate, or cause to be initiated, bankruptcy proceedings (as per clause (c)). Application/Conclusion: If the relevant creditor(s) do not agree to start bankruptcy proceedings, that can prevent initiation — particularly where 'creditor' is interpreted per the provision defining majority-holding creditors.

instruction: I only found out about the harmful act three months after it happened under Section 50. Is it too late to sue?
input:
Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within three months after the date of knowledge of such an act or action in the cases of Section 50 and within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action taken, in the other cases. 27 Chapter-3 Provisions Relating to Bankruptcy of Natural Persons
 Section no 54 .
output: According to Section 54... Rule: In cases of Section 50, an aggrieved person may sue within three months after the date of knowledge of the act; in other cases, within six months after the act. Application/Conclusion: Since you discovered the act three months after learning of it and it falls under Section 50, you must act within three months from the date you found out — so check whether you are still within that three-month window to file.

instruction: A creditor settled some claims from my assets; does the court have to record me as bankrupt and notify the bankruptcy office?
input:
Section no 54  part (3) : If a debt or claim of a creditor is settled from the
assets of a person under this Chapter, such a person shall be deemed to become
a bankrupt.
 Section no 54  part (4) : The court shall send the record of the person being
bankrupt pursuant to sub-section (3) to the bankruptcy administration oﬀice
established for that purpose.
output: According to Section 54(3) and Section 54(4)... Rule: Settlement of a creditor's claim from the person's assets under this Chapter deems the person bankrupt; the court must then send that bankrupt person's record to the bankruptcy administration office. Application/Conclusion: If a creditor's claim was satisfied from your assets under this Chapter, you are deemed bankrupt and the court is obliged to forward your record to the bankruptcy administration office.

instruction: Can a temple stop me from entering because I'm from a different caste?
input:
Section no 18  part (2) : No person shall discriminated in any public and
private place on grounds of origin, religion, color, caste, race, sex, physical
condition, disability, condition of health, marital status, pregnancy, economic
condition, language, region, ideological conviction or on similar other ground;
and no person shall, on such ground, be prevented from using service, amenities
or utilities of public use or from entering into a public place or public religious
place or from performing religious act according to his or her will.
output:
According to Section 18(2):
Rule: No person shall be discriminated in any public or private place on grounds including caste, and no person shall be prevented from entering a public religious place or from performing a religious act on such grounds.
Application/Conclusion: The temple cannot lawfully bar you from entry solely because of your caste; you have the right to enter and perform religious acts unless there is some other lawful, neutral restriction that applies to everyone.

instruction: My company pays me less because I'm a woman. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 18  part (3) : No person shall be discriminated on ground of sex
with regard to remuneration and social security for the same work.
output:
According to Section 18(3):
Rule: No person shall be discriminated on the ground of sex regarding remuneration and social security for the same work.
Application/Conclusion: Your employer must pay equal remuneration and provide equal social security for work equal in nature; paying you less because you are a woman is prohibited and you can challenge it through available remedies.

instruction: I'm a foreigner wanting to enter into a contract in Nepal — do civil laws apply to me?
input:
Section no 16 . Applicable to foreigners as well : Except in cases where
the subject, context or nature requires application of any legal provision only
to a Nepali citizen, this Act or other provisions concerning civil law shall be
equally applicable to a foreigner as well. 7 Chapter - 3 Provisions Relating To
Civil Rights
output:
According to Section 16:
Rule: Civil law provisions apply equally to foreigners except where a provision expressly requires application only to Nepali citizens.
Application/Conclusion: As a foreigner you are generally covered by Nepalese civil law for contracts and related matters, unless the specific legal provision explicitly limits application to Nepali citizens.

instruction: Our family tradition says daughters can't inherit land. Is that valid?
input:
Section no 15 . Custom or tradition contrary to law not to be recognized : No custom or tradition contrary to law shall be recognized in the
dispensation of justice.
output:
According to Section 15:
Rule: Customs or traditions that are contrary to law shall not be recognized in dispensing justice.
Application/Conclusion: A family custom denying daughters inheritance that conflicts with the law is not legally valid and cannot be upheld by a court; daughters retain rights provided by applicable law.

instruction: They arrested me last night without showing any order. Can they deny my liberty like that?
input:
Section no 20 . Guarantee of freedoms and rights : (1) No person shall
be deprived of personal liberty except in accordance with law.
output:
According to Section 20(1):
Rule: No person shall be deprived of personal liberty except in accordance with law.
Application/Conclusion: Authorities cannot lawfully detain you arbitrarily; any deprivation of liberty must follow legal procedures and safeguards. If you were held without lawful basis, you may seek legal remedy to challenge the detention.

instruction: If someone is facing a criminal case, can they avoid civil suit for the same act?
input:
Section no 14 . Not to be relieved from civil liability : No person shall
be relieved from a civil liability under the law merely on the ground that the
proceeding of criminal offense is initiated or not initiated against him or her.
output:
According to Section 14:
Rule: Initiation or non-initiation of criminal proceedings does not relieve a person from civil liability.
Application/Conclusion: The accused can still be sued in civil court for damages or other civil claims even if criminal proceedings are ongoing or not started; criminal and civil liabilities are independent.

instruction: My friend was not selected for a government post because of his disability. Is that lawful?
input:
Section no 18  part (4) : In appointing any citizen to a governmental or
public oﬀice, he or she shall be appointed only on the basis of the qualifications
determined by the law. In so appointing, no citizen shall be discriminated on
grounds of origin, religion, color, caste, race, sex, physical condition, disability,
condition of health, marital 8 status, pregnancy, economic condition, language,
region, ideological conviction or similar other ground.
output:
According to Section 18(4):
Rule: Appointments to governmental or public office must be based on legally determined qualifications and must not discriminate on grounds including disability.
Application/Conclusion: Refusing your friend solely because of disability, if he meets the lawful qualifications, is prohibited; he may have grounds to challenge the appointment decision under the law.

instruction: The government has a quota for marginalized groups. Isn't that discrimination against others?
input:
Section no 19 . Discrimination not to be deemed where special provision is : made: Notwithstanding anything contained in Sections 17 and 18, any
special provision made by law for the protection, empowerment or development
of the citizens that are socially or culturally backward women, dalit, indigenous,
indigenous nationalities, Madhesi, Tharu, Muslims, oppressed class, backward
class, minorities, marginalized, peasants, workers, youths, children, senior citizens, gender and sexual minorities, persons with disabilities, pregnant women,
the incompetent or helpless, backward region and also economically indigent
Khash Arya shall not be considered to be a discrimination.
output:
According to Section 19:
Rule: Special legal provisions for protection, empowerment or development of disadvantaged or marginalized groups shall not be regarded as discrimination.
Application/Conclusion: Quotas or affirmative measures for marginalized groups are legally permissible and are not treated as unlawful discrimination under this section.

instruction: What does 'equal before the law' mean? Explain simply.
input:
Section no 17 . To be equal before law : (1) Every citizen shall be equal
before law.

Section no 17  part (2) : No citizen shall be deprived of equal protection of
law.
output:
According to Section 17(1) and 17(2):
Rule: Every citizen is equal before the law and no citizen shall be deprived of equal protection of the law.
Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, the law must treat all citizens without unfair favoritism or discrimination, and everyone is entitled to the same legal protections; government actions and legal processes should apply equally to all.

instruction: Can a private restaurant refuse service to someone for their political beliefs?
input:
Section no 18  part (2) : No person shall discriminated in any public and
private place on grounds of origin, religion, color, caste, race, sex, physical
condition, disability, condition of health, marital status, pregnancy, economic
condition, language, region, ideological conviction or on similar other ground;
and no person shall, on such ground, be prevented from using service, amenities
or utilities of public use or from entering into a public place or public religious
place or from performing religious act according to his or her will.
output:
According to Section 18(2):
Rule: No person shall be discriminated in any public or private place on grounds including ideological conviction, and no one shall be prevented from using services or amenities on such grounds.
Application/Conclusion: A private restaurant cannot lawfully refuse service solely because of a customer's political or ideological beliefs; such treatment would amount to prohibited discrimination under this provision.

instruction: Are customs ever accepted by courts if they conflict with statutes?
input:
Section no 15 . Custom or tradition contrary to law not to be recognized : No custom or tradition contrary to law shall be recognized in the
dispensation of justice.
output:
According to Section 15:
Rule: Customs or traditions that are contrary to law are not recognized in the dispensation of justice.
Application/Conclusion: If a custom conflicts with statutory law, courts will not accept or apply that custom; the law takes precedence over contrary traditions.

instruction: Under which section does it say foreigners are covered by civil law?
input:
Section no 16 . Applicable to foreigners as well : Except in cases where
the subject, context or nature requires application of any legal provision only
to a Nepali citizen, this Act or other provisions concerning civil law shall be
equally applicable to a foreigner as well. 7 Chapter - 3 Provisions Relating To
Civil Rights
output:
According to Section 16:
Rule: Civil law provisions are equally applicable to foreigners except where a provision specifically requires application only to Nepali citizens.
Application/Conclusion: Section 16 is the provision that establishes that foreigners are generally covered by civil law in Nepal, subject to exceptions expressly stated by law.

instruction: If someone commits an offense and is prosecuted, can the victim still claim damages in civil court?
input:
Section no 14 . Not to be relieved from civil liability : No person shall
be relieved from a civil liability under the law merely on the ground that the
proceeding of criminal offense is initiated or not initiated against him or her.
output:
According to Section 14:
Rule: The initiation or non-initiation of criminal proceedings does not relieve a person from civil liability.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the victim can still bring a civil claim for damages even if the offender is being prosecuted criminally; civil remedies remain available independently of criminal proceedings.

instruction: They told me I can't use the public library because I'm unemployed. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 18  part (2) : No person shall discriminated in any public and
private place on grounds of origin, religion, color, caste, race, sex, physical
condition, disability, condition of health, marital status, pregnancy, economic
condition, language, region, ideological conviction or on similar other ground;
and no person shall, on such ground, be prevented from using service, amenities
or utilities of public use or from entering into a public place or public religious
place or from performing religious act according to his or her will.
output:
According to Section 18(2):
Rule: No person shall be discriminated against in public or private places on grounds including economic condition, and no one shall be prevented from using public services or amenities on such grounds.
Application/Conclusion: A public library cannot refuse you access solely because you are unemployed; denying access for that reason would be discriminatory under this provision.

instruction: Can pregnancy be used as a reason to deny someone a public service?
input:
Section no 18  part (2) : No person shall discriminated in any public and
private place on grounds of origin, religion, color, caste, race, sex, physical
condition, disability, condition of health, marital status, pregnancy, economic
condition, language, region, ideological conviction or on similar other ground;
and no person shall, on such ground, be prevented from using service, amenities
or utilities of public use or from entering into a public place or public religious
place or from performing religious act according to his or her will.
output:
According to Section 18(2):
Rule: Discrimination on the ground of pregnancy is prohibited in public and private places, and no person shall be prevented from using public services or amenities on that ground.
Application/Conclusion: Pregnancy cannot lawfully be used as a reason to deny someone access to public services or amenities; such exclusion would be prohibited discrimination.

instruction: Short: Can police keep someone locked up without legal cause?
input:
Section no 20 . Guarantee of freedoms and rights : (1) No person shall
be deprived of personal liberty except in accordance with law.
output:
According to Section 20(1):
Rule: No person shall be deprived of personal liberty except in accordance with law.
Application/Conclusion: No — police cannot lawfully detain someone without legal cause; any deprivation of liberty must follow legal process and authority.

instruction: My boss says only Nepali citizens may have this job. Is that automatically lawful?
input:
Section no 16 . Applicable to foreigners as well : Except in cases where
the subject, context or nature requires application of any legal provision only
to a Nepali citizen, this Act or other provisions concerning civil law shall be
equally applicable to a foreigner as well. 7 Chapter - 3 Provisions Relating To
Civil Rights
output:
According to Section 16:
Rule: Civil law applies equally to foreigners except where the subject, context or nature requires application only to Nepali citizens.
Application/Conclusion: A blanket rule excluding all foreigners from a job is not automatically lawful; it is permissible only if the specific legal requirement or the nature of the position legitimately requires Nepali citizenship. Otherwise, civil-law protections apply to foreigners as well.

instruction: Can I state in writing that I want my organs donated after I die?
input: . Power to donate corpse or organ : (1) Any person may express in writing his or her will to donate, after his or her death, his or her 16 corpse or any organ of body or any part thereof to a person for the purpose of using, or causing to be used, such corpse or organ for a particular work.
output: According to Section 38(1)... Rule: Any person may express in writing a will to donate, after death, their corpse or any organ or part for use. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can make a written will expressing donation of your corpse or organs after death; the law recognises such a written declaration as the means to donate.

instruction: My father wrote in his will to donate his organs, but my mother (his successor) refuses. Can she stop the donation?
input: Section no 38  part (2) : If a person has expressed his or her will pursuant to sub-section (1), his or her successor shall use the deceased’s corpse, part of the body or a portion thereof according to the will of the deceased.
output: According to Section 38(2)... Rule: If a person has made the written will to donate under subsection (1), the successor must use the deceased's corpse or body parts according to that will. Application/Conclusion: The successor cannot lawfully override the deceased's written donation will; they are required to follow the deceased’s expressed wishes regarding the corpse or organs.

instruction: What happens if the person or institution meant to receive the donated organ is not available?
input: Section no 38  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if the person accepting such corpse, organ or any part thereof is not available or if it is not possible to detach such corpse, organ or any part thereof, cremation, 7 obsequies rites or funereal acts of such corpse shall be conducted pursuant to Section 37.
output: According to Section 38(3)... Rule: If the intended acceptor is unavailable or the organ/part cannot be detached, funeral rites (cremation etc.) shall be conducted pursuant to Section 37. Application/Conclusion: If the recipient cannot be located or detachment is impossible, the deceased’s body will be cremated or funeral rites carried out under Section 37 rather than waiting for donation.

instruction: For legal papers, what is considered a person's address of residence?
input: Section no 39 . To be considered address of residence : (1) If a person’s address of residence needs to be determined, the address given by him or her for that purpose, where he or she has so given, and if not so given, the place of his or her permanent residence within Nepal shall be considered to be the address of his or her residence.
output: According to Section 39(1)... Rule: The address given by a person for that purpose is the residence address; if none is given, their permanent residence within Nepal is taken as address. Application/Conclusion: For legal purposes, use the address the person has provided; if they gave none, use their permanent Nepali residence as their address of residence.

instruction: I don't know where my missing cousin lives — can his temporary abode be treated as his residence?
input: Section no 39  part (2) : If a person does not have residence or his or her residence is not traced out pursuant to sub-section (1), the place of his or her abode for the time being shall be considered to be the address of his or her residence.
output: According to Section 39(2)... Rule: If a person's residence isn't found under subsection (1), their current place of abode will be considered their address of residence. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you cannot trace a permanent address, the place where your cousin is currently staying (abode for the time being) will be treated as their residence address.

instruction: I run a shop but I don't live nearby. For service of documents, which address counts?
input: Section no 39  part (3) : If a person does not have a residence or his or her residence is not traced out pursuant to sub-section (1) or (2) and the person has carried on any trade, business, employment or transaction, the place where he or she has so carried on trade, 17 business, employment or transaction shall be considered to be the address of his or her residence.
output: According to Section 39(3)... Rule: If residence can't be traced under subsections (1) or (2) and the person has carried on trade/business/employment, the place where they carried on that activity is considered their residence address. Application/Conclusion: If your personal residence can't be traced, the shop/business location may be treated as your address for legal service and notices.

instruction: I just changed my city and live temporarily with friends — is that my legal residence now?
input: Section no 39  part (4) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), Section no 39  part (2) : or (3), where the address of a person’s residence is changed, the place where he or she is residing for the time being shall be considered to be the address of his or her residence.
output: According to Section 39(4)... Rule: Notwithstanding subsections (1)–(3), when a person's residence changes, the place they are residing for the time being is considered their residence address. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you've moved and are temporarily residing elsewhere, that current place is the person's address of residence for legal purposes.

instruction: I'm guardian of an adult who is mentally incapacitated. Where will the law say their residence is?
input: Section no 39  part (5) : If the residence of an incompetent or quasi-competent person needs to be determined, the place of his or her permanent residence and if such place is not traced out, the place where his or her guardian or curator resides shall be considered to be the address of his or her residence.
output: According to Section 39(5)... Rule: For an incompetent or quasi-competent person, their permanent residence is the address; if not traceable, the guardian's or curator's residence is considered their address. Application/Conclusion: The incapacitated person's permanent residence is used; if that's unknown, the guardian's residence (i.e., yours) will be treated as their address.

instruction: Can I pick any address to be treated as my residence for a specific purpose (like getting a document)?
input: Section no 39  part (6) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, if a person considers any address as the place of his or her residence for a particular purpose, such a place shall be considered to be the address of his or her residence.
output: According to Section 39(6)... Rule: Regardless of other rules, if a person considers any address as their residence for a particular purpose, that place shall be considered their address. Application/Conclusion: Yes — for a particular purpose you may designate an address and the law will regard that place as your residence address for that purpose.

instruction: A man has been missing without news for 12 years. Can I apply to have him declared dead?
input: Section no 40 . Presumed to be dead : (1) If a person misars without any notice for a period of consecutive twelve years or if a person for whom it is natural to have information about such disappeared person has not received any information about him or her for the last twelve years, such a person shall, except in cases where an evidence establishing that he or she is alive is received, be deemed to be dead. Provided that in the following circumstance, such a person shall be deemed to have died after the completion of the following period:
output: According to Section 40(1)... Rule: A person missing without notice for twelve consecutive years (or no information received by natural informants for twelve years) is deemed dead unless evidence proves they are alive. Application/Conclusion: If the person has been absent and without news for 12 years, you may treat them as presumed dead under the law unless evidence to the contrary appears.

instruction: My elderly aunt (aged 82) went missing five years ago. Is she presumed dead yet?
input: Section no 40  part (1) : In the case of a person having attained eighty years of age, five years, 18
output: According to Section 40(1)... Rule: For a person who has reached eighty years of age, the period for being presumed dead is five years. Application/Conclusion: Since your aunt was over 80 and missing for five years, she can be presumed dead under this provision.

instruction: My brother was deployed as a soldier and hasn't returned since the war ended three years ago. Can I have him presumed dead now?
input: Section no 40  part (2) : In the case of a soldier deputed to war-field, four years after the cessation of the war;
output: According to Section 40(2)... Rule: A soldier deputed to a war-field is deemed dead four years after the cessation of the war. Application/Conclusion: Because the required period is four years after the war ended, and only three years have passed, you cannot yet rely on this provision to presume him dead; you must wait until four years have elapsed after cessation of the war (unless other evidence arises).

instruction: We want to divide inheritance but one heir disappeared more than 12 years ago. Does the law allow distributing the estate?
input: Section no 40 . Presumed to be dead : (1) If a person misars without any notice for a period of consecutive twelve years or if a person for whom it is natural to have information about such disappeared person has not received any information about him or her for the last twelve years, such a person shall, except in cases where an evidence establishing that he or she is alive is received, be deemed to be dead. Provided that in the following circumstance, such a person shall be deemed to have died after the completion of the following period:
output: According to Section 40(1)... Rule: A person absent without news for twelve consecutive years is deemed dead unless evidence shows they are alive. Application/Conclusion: If the missing heir has been absent for 12 years with no information, they may be presumed dead—this would permit moving forward with inheritance distribution, subject to any court or official procedures for declaring death.

instruction: Is there any situation where someone missing for less than 12 years can be presumed dead faster?
input: Section no 40  part (1) : In the case of a person having attained eighty years of age, five years, 18
output: According to Section 40(1)... Rule: Yes — for persons aged eighty or over, the presumption period is five years. Application/Conclusion: If the missing person had already turned 80, they can be presumed dead after five years instead of the standard 12.

instruction: If I don't know someone's permanent address but they do business in my city, can I serve notices at their business?
input: Section no 39  part (3) : If a person does not have a residence or his or her residence is not traced out pursuant to sub-section (1) or (2) and the person has carried on any trade, business, employment or transaction, the place where he or she has so carried on trade, 17 business, employment or transaction shall be considered to be the address of his or her residence.
output: According to Section 39(3)... Rule: Where residence can't be traced under subsections (1) or (2) and the person has carried on trade/business/employment, that place of business is considered their residence address. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if their residence cannot be found and they conduct business here, the business location may be treated as their legal address for service.

instruction: My relative is missing and people who would normally know about them have had no news for 12 years. What does the law say?
input: Section no 40 . Presumed to be dead : (1) If a person misars without any notice for a period of consecutive twelve years or if a person for whom it is natural to have information about such disappeared person has not received any information about him or her for the last twelve years, such a person shall, except in cases where an evidence establishing that he or she is alive is received, be deemed to be dead. Provided that in the following circumstance, such a person shall be deemed to have died after the completion of the following period:
output: According to Section 40(1)... Rule: Absence without notice for twelve years, or lack of information by those who would naturally have it for twelve years, leads to the person being deemed dead unless evidence shows they are alive. Application/Conclusion: Given that those who would know have had no news for 12 years, you can treat the person as presumed dead under the provision, subject to formal procedures to declare death.

instruction: My father said he wanted to donate his body in writing but my siblings claim the organ can't be detached — what then?
input: Section no 38  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if the person accepting such corpse, organ or any part thereof is not available or if it is not possible to detach such corpse, organ or any part thereof, cremation, 7 obsequies rites or funereal acts of such corpse shall be conducted pursuant to Section 37.
output: According to Section 38(3)... Rule: If the acceptor is unavailable or it is not possible to detach the organ/part, funeral rites (cremation etc.) must be conducted pursuant to Section 37. Application/Conclusion: If detachment is impossible, the deceased's body will be cremated or the funeral rites performed under Section 37 despite the written donation — the donation cannot proceed if physical detachment cannot be done.

instruction: Short question: Under which section can a person donate their corpse or organ?
input: . Power to donate corpse or organ : (1) Any person may express in writing his or her will to donate, after his or her death, his or her 16 corpse or any organ of body or any part thereof to a person for the purpose of using, or causing to be used, such corpse or organ for a particular work.
output: According to Section 38(1)... Rule: Section 38(1) provides the power to donate a corpse or organ by a written will. Application/Conclusion: The right to donate a corpse or organ after death is set out in Section 38(1); you must express that intention in writing.

instruction: Can a group obtain legal competency by registering as a body?
input: part (2) : In order to obtain legal competency pursuant to sub section (1), any body shall be registered in accordance with law.
output: According to Section 42(2): Rule: A body must be registered in accordance with law to obtain legal competency under subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: If you want your group to become a legal person with legal competency, you must register it under the applicable law—registration is a prerequisite for competency.

instruction: What must I include when applying for registration? (short)
input: Section no 42  part (3) : Except where a separate provision has been made by law for registration pursuant to sub-section (2), an application shall be made to the competent authority, setting out the following matters:
output: According to Section 42(3): Rule: Where no separate provision applies, an application for registration must be made to the competent authority and must set out specified matters. Application/Conclusion: Your registration application must follow the statutory requirements listed by the competent authority—do not omit the required matters specified in the following subclauses.

instruction: Do I need to state the official name when registering a body?
input: Section no 42  part (3) (a) : Name of the body corporate,
output: According to Section 42(3)(a): Rule: The application must state the name of the body corporate. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the formal name of the body corporate must be included in the registration application.

instruction: Must I give the head office address on the application?
input: Section no 42  part (3) (b) : Head oﬀice of the body corporate, and address of such oﬀice,
output: According to Section 42(3)(b): Rule: The application must set out the head office of the body corporate and the address of that office. Application/Conclusion: You are required to provide the head office location and its address in the registration documents.

instruction: What about objectives — do we have to list them when registering?
input: Section no 42  part (3) (c) : Objectives and functions of the body corporate,
output: According to Section 42(3)(c): Rule: The application must state the objectives and functions of the body corporate. Application/Conclusion: Include a clear statement of your body's objectives and functions in the registration application; it is a mandatory element.

instruction: Do I need to disclose capital details in the registration?
input: Section no 42  part (3) (d) : Details of the capital structure, if any, of the body corporate,
output: According to Section 42(3)(d): Rule: The application must include details of the capital structure, if any. Application/Conclusion: If your body has a capital structure, those details must be disclosed in the registration application.

instruction: Anything else needed on the application form?
input: Section no 42  part (3) (e) : Other necessary details.
output: According to Section 42(3)(e): Rule: The application must include any other necessary details. Application/Conclusion: Beyond the specifically listed items, you must also provide any other details required by law or by the competent authority when submitting your registration.

instruction: After registration, are we automatically incorporated?
input: Section no 42  part (4) : After the registration of a body corporate pursuant to sub-section (2), such a body shall be deemed to have been incorporated.
output: According to Section 42(4): Rule: Once a body corporate is registered under subsection (2), it shall be deemed incorporated. Application/Conclusion: Registration confers incorporation—after registration, your body will be treated as an incorporated entity.

instruction: Do legal persons need a separate seal?
input: Section no 42  part (5) : A legal person shall have a corporate personality and use a separate seal for its activities.
output: According to Section 42(5): Rule: A legal person shall have corporate personality and use a separate seal for its activities. Application/Conclusion: As an incorporated legal person, your entity should have its own corporate personality and use a distinct seal for official activities.

instruction: Will the incorporated body continue indefinitely?
input: Section no 42  part (6) : A body incorporated pursuant to this Section shall be an autonomous and body corporate with perpetual succession, and 22 may, in the same capacity, subject to law, carry out as a person the following functions:
output: According to Section 42(6): Rule: A body incorporated under this Section is an autonomous corporate body with perpetual succession and may carry out functions as a person, subject to law. Application/Conclusion: Your incorporated body is intended to have perpetual succession—meaning it continues despite changes in membership—so it will exist until lawfully dissolved or wound up.

instruction: Can the incorporated body acquire and manage property?
input: Section no 42  part (6) (a) : To acquire, hold, earn, possess, dispose off, sell or otherwise manage a property,
output: According to Section 42(6)(a): Rule: An incorporated body may acquire, hold, possess, dispose of, sell or otherwise manage property. Application/Conclusion: Your incorporated entity has the legal capacity to own and manage property in its own name, subject to applicable law.

instruction: Is the body allowed to enter into contracts?
input: Section no 42  part (6) (b) : To execute a contract, exercise rights and discharge obligations under the contract or to assume any kind of right or obligation in any other way,
output: According to Section 42(6)(b): Rule: A body corporate may execute contracts and assume or discharge rights and obligations. Application/Conclusion: The incorporated body can lawfully enter into contracts and be bound by contractual rights and duties in its own capacity.

instruction: Can the company make its own statutes or bye-laws?
input: Section no 42  part (6) (c) : To frame statute or bye-laws required to operate its own functions, proceedings or business,
output: According to Section 42(6)(c): Rule: A body corporate may frame statutes or bye-laws necessary to operate its functions or business. Application/Conclusion: Your entity can adopt internal statutes or bye-laws to govern its procedures, provided those rules comply with the law.

instruction: A commission wants to hire staff. Are all bodies allowed to appoint employees?
input: Section no 42  part (6) (d) : To appoint necessary employees based on law to carry out its functions, Provided that the commissions, institutions or bodies referred to in clause (g) of Section 44 shall not be allowed to appoint employees.
output: According to Section 42(6)(d): Rule: A body corporate may appoint necessary employees in accordance with law, but commissions, institutions or bodies referred to in clause (g) of Section 44 are not allowed to appoint employees. Application/Conclusion: Generally, an incorporated body can hire employees as needed, but if the body is one of the commissions or institutions referenced in Section 44(g), that specific restriction prevents it from appointing employees.

instruction: Can the body open branches or other offices?
input: Section no 42  part (6) (e) : To open branches or other oﬀices, subject to its statute and bye-laws,
output: According to Section 42(6)(e): Rule: A body corporate may open branches or other offices, subject to its statute and bye-laws. Application/Conclusion: You may establish branches or offices, provided such actions comply with your entity’s statutes and bye-laws.

instruction: Can the corporation open and operate a bank account?
input: Section no 42  part (6) (f) : To open an account in a bank or financial institution and to operate the account,
output: According to Section 42(6)(f): Rule: A body corporate may open and operate an account in a bank or financial institution. Application/Conclusion: Your incorporated entity has the power to establish and operate banking accounts in its own name.

instruction: If they wrong me, can I sue the company in its name?
input: Section no 42  part (7) : A legal person may sue or initiate other legal action and may also be sued or subjected to other legal action by its name.
output: According to Section 42(7): Rule: A legal person may initiate legal action and may also be sued in its own name. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can sue the incorporated body in its corporate name, and conversely the body itself can sue others in its name.

instruction: When does an incorporated legal person get legal competency to do civil and commercial acts?
input: Section no 43 . To obtain legal competency upon incorporation : (1) A legal person shall, upon its incorporation, obtain legal competency to carry out civil and commercial acts and transactions, in addition to the acts mentioned in Section 42. 23
output: According to Section 43(1): Rule: Upon incorporation, a legal person obtains legal competency to perform civil and commercial acts and transactions, beyond the functions listed in Section 42. Application/Conclusion: The moment your entity is incorporated, it gains the legal capacity to engage in civil and commercial activities as specified.

instruction: How long does that legal competency last?
input:
Section no 43  part (2) : The legal competency obtained pursuant to subsection 
 Section no 43  part (1) : shall continue to exist until the legal person is liquidated, dissolved or wounded up in accordance with law.
output: According to Section 43(2): Rule: The legal competency obtained upon incorporation continues until the legal person is liquidated, dissolved or wound up in accordance with law. Application/Conclusion: Your entity’s legal competency endures indefinitely until it is lawfully liquidated, dissolved or wound up under the applicable legal procedures.

instruction: Are there bodies that are automatically assumed to have legal competency without registration?
input: Section no 44 . Legal competency deemed to be acquired, ipso facto : Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 42, the following body, as a legal person, shall be deemed to have, ipso facto, obtained competency:
output: According to Section 44 (opening): Rule: Notwithstanding Section 42, certain bodies are deemed to have obtained legal competency ipso facto. Application/Conclusion: There are specific bodies that do not need the registration steps of Section 42 to be treated as having legal competency; the statute expressly deems them competent automatically.

instruction: Is the State of Nepal automatically a legal person?
input: Section no 44  clause (a) : The State of Nepal,
output: According to Section 44(a): Rule: The State of Nepal is deemed to have obtained legal competency ipso facto. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the State of Nepal is automatically treated as a legal person with competency without needing registration under Section 42.

instruction: Does the Government of Nepal have ipso facto competency?
input: Section no 44  clause (b) : The Government of Nepal,
output: According to Section 44(b): Rule: The Government of Nepal is deemed to have obtained legal competency ipso facto. Application/Conclusion: Yes — by statute the Government of Nepal is automatically considered a legal person with legal competency.

instruction: Are courts and constitutional bodies automatically competent as legal persons?
input: Section no 44  clause (d) : A court, constitutional body or any oﬀice thereunder,
output: According to Section 44(d): Rule: Courts, constitutional bodies and offices under them are deemed to have legal competency ipso facto. Application/Conclusion: Courts and constitutional bodies are automatically recognized as legal persons with competency; they do not need registration under Section 42 to exercise such competency.

instruction: Do ministries and government departments automatically have legal competency?
input: Section no 44  clause (e) : A Ministry, Secretariat, Department of the Government of Nepal and any other government oﬀice,
output: According to Section 44(e): Rule: Ministries, Secretariats, Departments and other government offices are deemed to have obtained legal competency ipso facto. Application/Conclusion: Yes — these government organs are automatically treated as legal persons with competency without going through registration under Section 42.

instruction: Is a Province treated as having legal competency automatically?
input: Section no 44  clause (f) : A Province,
output: According to Section 44(f): Rule: A Province is deemed to have obtained legal competency ipso facto. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a Province is automatically recognized as a legal person with legal competency under the statute.

instruction: Can I continue doing business after I'm declared bankrupt?
input: Section no 54  part (8) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, if any person becomes bankrupt, he or she may carry on any trade, business or transaction other than any act or activity he or she is prohibited from doing or taking in that capacity according to law.
output: According to Section 54(8): Rule: A person declared bankrupt may carry on any trade, business or transaction except acts or activities that the law specifically prohibits for someone in that capacity. Application/Conclusion: You are generally allowed to continue business after being declared bankrupt, but you must ensure you do not perform any activity that another law or restriction forbids for bankrupt persons.

instruction: If I start a new trade after declaring bankruptcy, do I have to pay taxes to the government from that business?
input: Section no 54  part (7) (a) : Tax, fee or charge to be paid to the Government of Nepal, Province Government or Local Government
output: According to Section 54(7)(a): Rule: Taxes, fees or charges owed to the Government of Nepal, Province Government or Local Government are obligations to be fulfilled from trade, business or transactions started after a declaration of bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: Yes — taxes, fees or charges due to governmental bodies arising from a business you start after declaring bankruptcy must be paid from that business's proceeds.

instruction: Will I be personally responsible for fines or penalties ordered by a court that arise after my bankruptcy declaration?
input: Section no 54  part (7) (b) : Amount of penalty or fine to be paid according to the order of a court,
output: According to Section 54(7)(b): Rule: Amounts of penalties or fines ordered by a court are obligations to be fulfilled from trade, business or transactions started after bankruptcy is declared. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if a court orders a penalty or fine that relates to activities after your bankruptcy declaration, the amount must be met from the business or transactions you start post-declaration.

instruction: I was a guardian and property under my guardianship was embezzled. If I start a new business after bankruptcy, do I have to pay for that embezzlement from the new business?
input: Section no 54  part (7) (c) : Amount to be paid for the embezzlement of property of the person under his or her guardianship or curatorship,
output: According to Section 54(7)(c): Rule: Amounts payable for embezzlement of property of a person under one's guardianship or curatorship must be fulfilled from trade, business or transactions started after bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: Yes — obligations to pay for embezzlement of property under your guardianship are payable from any trade or business you commence after your bankruptcy declaration.

instruction: If goods are found to be stolen, and I start a business after being declared bankrupt, do I have to pay for those goods from the new business?
input: Section no 54  part (7) (d) : Amount to be paid for the goods stolen,
output: According to Section 54(7)(d): Rule: Amounts to be paid for stolen goods are obligations that shall be fulfilled from trade, business or transactions started after a declaration of bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: Yes — liabilities relating to stolen goods are payable from the proceeds of any trade or business you begin after being declared bankrupt.

instruction: Does embezzlement of trust property create an obligation that must be paid from a post-bankruptcy business?
input: Section no 54  part (7) (e) : Amount to be paid for the embezzlement of property of a trust.
output: According to Section 54(7)(e): Rule: Amounts payable for embezzlement of property of a trust are obligations to be met from trade, business or transactions started after bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you are liable for embezzlement of trust property, that amount must be fulfilled from any business or transaction you start after your bankruptcy declaration.

instruction: I think I may become bankrupt. What must my petition include when I file for bankruptcy myself?
input:
Section no 55  part (2) : In filing a petition by a person likely to become a bankrupt for bankruptcy pursuant to sub-section (1), the petition shall specify the following details:
 Section no 55  part (2) (a) : Actual statement of his or her total assets and value thereof,
 Section no 55  part (2) (b) : Statement of total amount of debts borrowed by him or her, interest accrued thereon and details of the creditor or creditors having lent such debts, along with their addresses,
 Section no 55  part (2) (c) : If he or she has to discharge other liabilities, details thereof,
 Section no 55  part (2) (d) : The reason for the failure to repay or discharge debts and other liabilities.
output: According to Section 55(2): Rule: A self-petitioning person must specify (a) a full statement of assets and values, (b) total debts with accrued interest and creditor details and addresses, (c) other liabilities if any, and (d) reasons for failure to repay or discharge debts. Application/Conclusion: Your petition must include all those details — a complete assets inventory, a debts summary with interest and creditor contacts, any other liabilities, and an explanation why you cannot repay.

instruction: I'm a creditor. What must I include in a petition to initiate bankruptcy against a borrower?
input:
Section no 55  part (3) : In filing a petition by a creditor or group of creditors for bankruptcy pursuant to sub-section (1), the petition shall specify the following details:
 Section no 55  part (3) (a) : Evidence indicating that the borrower is likely to be a bankrupt,
 Section no 55  part (3) (b) : Statement of the assets of the borrower and approximate value thereof, to the extent of the petitioner’s knowledge,
 Section no 55  part (3) (c) : Statement of the petitioner’s claim, and if the petitioner has knowledge of other creditor’s debt or claim, such debt or claim,
 Section no 55  part (3) (d) : Details including addresses of the creditors. 31
output: According to Section 55(3): Rule: A creditor's petition must include (a) evidence the borrower is likely bankrupt, (b) the borrower's assets and approximate values as known to the petitioner, (c) the petitioner's claim and known other creditors' claims, and (d) details and addresses of creditors. Application/Conclusion: When you file as a creditor, prepare and attach evidence of likely bankruptcy, an assets overview, a clear statement of your own claim (and any others you know), and full contact details for creditors.

instruction: Can a creditor file a bankruptcy petition without warning the borrower?
input: Section no 55  part (4) : Prior to filing a petition pursuant to sub-section (1) to initiate bankruptcy proceedings, a creditor or group of creditors shall give a notice to the borrower indicating that the borrower shall repay his or her debts or discharge other liabilities within a period of at least three months and that in the event of failure to repay the debts within that period, a petition shall be filed in the court to initiate bankruptcy proceedings.
output: According to Section 55(4): Rule: Before filing a petition, a creditor or group of creditors must give the borrower notice requiring repayment or discharge of liabilities within at least three months and warn that failure will lead to a petition. Application/Conclusion: No — creditors must first issue a notice giving the borrower at least a three-month period to repay before filing for bankruptcy.

instruction: How long must a creditor wait after giving notice before filing a petition?
input: Section no 55  part (4) : Prior to filing a petition pursuant to sub-section (1) to initiate bankruptcy proceedings, a creditor or group of creditors shall give a notice to the borrower indicating that the borrower shall repay his or her debts or discharge other liabilities within a period of at least three months and that in the event of failure to repay the debts within that period, a petition shall be filed in the court to initiate bankruptcy proceedings.
output: According to Section 55(4): Rule: The creditor's notice must give the borrower a period of at least three months to repay or discharge liabilities before a petition is filed. Application/Conclusion: The minimum waiting period after notice is three months — creditors must wait at least that long before initiating bankruptcy proceedings.

instruction: Can two small creditors join to file bankruptcy if together they hold 25% of the borrower's disclosed debts?
input:
Section no 55 . Petition to be filed to initiate bankruptcy proceedings : (1) A person who is likely to become a bankrupt may himself or herself, or a creditor or group of creditors having claim of at least twenty five percent or more of the total debts if the amount of debts is disclosed and, if the amount of debts is not disclosed, a creditor or group of creditors having claim of more than 14
 five hundred thousand rupees borrowed by such a person, may file a petition in the court, in order to initiate bankruptcy proceedings. 30
output: According to Section 55(1): Rule: A creditor or group of creditors holding claims of at least twenty five percent or more of the total debts (when debts are disclosed) may file a petition to initiate bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the two creditors together hold at least 25% of the disclosed total debts, they may jointly file a petition to start bankruptcy proceedings.

instruction: If the debtor hasn't disclosed total debts, how big must a creditor's claim be to file a petition?
input:
Section no 55 . Petition to be filed to initiate bankruptcy proceedings : (1) A person who is likely to become a bankrupt may himself or herself, or a creditor or group of creditors having claim of at least twenty five percent or more of the total debts if the amount of debts is disclosed and, if the amount of debts is not disclosed, a creditor or group of creditors having claim of more than 14
 five hundred thousand rupees borrowed by such a person, may file a petition in the court, in order to initiate bankruptcy proceedings. 30
output: According to Section 55(1): Rule: If the amount of debts is not disclosed, a creditor or group of creditors having a claim of more than fourteen five hundred thousand rupees (as stated) may file a petition. Application/Conclusion: The statute provides a monetary threshold when debts are undisclosed; under the text as written, a creditor or group must hold a claim exceeding the specified amount in the section to file — you should verify the exact numerical drafting in the official consolidated law text or with counsel because the printed phrase appears as "more than 14 five hundred thousand rupees."

instruction: What specific debt information do I need to list if I'm the debtor filing for bankruptcy?
input: Section no 55  part (2) (b) : Statement of total amount of debts borrowed by him or her, interest accrued thereon and details of the creditor or creditors having lent such debts, along with their addresses,
output: According to Section 55(2)(b): Rule: The debtor's petition must state the total amount of debts, interest accrued, and details (including addresses) of the creditors who lent those debts. Application/Conclusion: You must prepare a clear statement showing how much you owe in total, any accrued interest, and full contact details for each creditor when filing your petition.

instruction: Do I need to say why I couldn't repay when I file my own bankruptcy petition?
input: Section no 55  part (2) (d) : The reason for the failure to repay or discharge debts and other liabilities.
output: According to Section 55(2)(d): Rule: A debtor's petition must provide the reasons for the failure to repay or discharge debts and other liabilities. Application/Conclusion: Yes — your petition should include an explanation of why you could not meet your obligations.

instruction: As a creditor, must I provide evidence that the borrower is likely bankrupt when I file?
input: Section no 55  part (3) (a) : Evidence indicating that the borrower is likely to be a bankrupt,
output: According to Section 55(3)(a): Rule: A creditor's petition must include evidence indicating that the borrower is likely to be bankrupt. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you need to attach or present evidence supporting your assertion that the borrower is likely insolvent when filing the petition.

instruction: When creditors file, do they have to give addresses of other creditors too?
input: Section no 55  part (3) (d) : Details including addresses of the creditors. 31
output: According to Section 55(3)(d): Rule: The petition must include details including addresses of the creditors. Application/Conclusion: Yes — include the contact details and addresses of creditors as part of the creditor-filed petition.

instruction: If I, as a borrower, file for bankruptcy, will the creditors I list be notified? How long do they have?
input:

by a borrower pursuant to Section 55 to initiate bankruptcy proceedings, the
court shall issue a notice of thirty-five days and serve the same on the creditor
or group of creditors whose debts the borrower has specified as due and payable
and publish the notice in any national daily newspaper.
output: According to Section 56(1), the court shall issue a notice of thirty-five days and serve it on the creditor(s) specified by the borrower and publish the notice in a national daily newspaper. Rule: When a borrower files a petition under Section 55, the court must notify listed creditors and give them a 35-day period. Application/Conclusion: If you file the petition and list certain creditors, those creditors must be served and will have 35 days' notice (with publication) to respond or make claims.

instruction: How long is the statutory notice period for creditors when a borrower initiates bankruptcy?
input:

court shall issue a notice of thirty-five days and serve the same on the creditor

Application/Conclusion: Practically, creditors have 35 days from service/publication to act after a borrower's petition is filed.

instruction: I think I have a claim over the debtor's assets but wasn't named. How does the published notice help me?

claim, if any, over the assets of the person whose assets is under bankruptcy

output: According to Section 56(2), the published notice must invite any other person with any type of claim over the debtor's assets to make a claim with evidence within the specified time-limit. Rule: Publication must include an invitation for other claimants to submit claims with evidence within the notice period. Application/Conclusion: If you have a claim but were not named, the published notice gives you the opportunity to submit your claim with evidence within the stated time-limit (the 35 days referred to in subsection (1)).

instruction: If a creditor or other person files a claim within the advertised time-limit, is that claim final?
input:
Section no 56  part (3) : The claim made within the time-limit referred to in
sub-section (1) or (2) by the creditor or group of creditors or by other person
shall be considered to be the final claim made against the assets of the borrower,
and the bankruptcy proceedings of his or her assets shall commence on the same
basis.
output: According to Section 56(3), a claim made within the prescribed time-limit is considered the final claim against the borrower's assets and bankruptcy proceedings commence on that basis. Rule: Timely claims (by creditors or others) are treated as final for the bankruptcy process. Application/Conclusion: If you submit your claim within the notice period, it will be treated as your final claim and the bankruptcy will proceed based on those claims—late claims generally will not be considered.

instruction: A creditor filed a petition. The court sent me a notice. How many days do I have to appear and reply?
input:
Section no 57 . Notice to be given to borrower : (1) If a petition is filed by
a creditor or group of creditors pursuant to Section 55 to initiate the bankruptcy
proceedings of the assets of the borrower, the court shall serve a notice, along
with a time-limit of thirty-five days, on 32 the borrower to appear before the
court, along with a reply whether or not the bankruptcy proceedings require to
be instituted, and if there exists any ground for not instituting the bankruptcy
proceedings, and evidence thereof.
output: According to Section 57(1), the borrower is served with a notice including a time-limit of thirty-five days to appear before the court with a reply and any evidence showing grounds not to institute bankruptcy. Rule: When creditors file a petition, the borrower gets a 35-day period to respond and present evidence opposing bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: You have 35 days from service of the notice to appear and submit your reply and supporting evidence to challenge the petition.

instruction: After the borrower is served, are other creditors told to make claims? For how long?
input:
Section no 57  part (2) : If a notice is served on the borrower pursuant to sub
section (1), a notice shall be given to the other creditor or claimant to submit a
claim in that respect within a period of thirty-five days and such a notice shall
be published in any national daily newspaper.
output: According to Section 57(2), once the borrower is served, other creditors or claimants must be given notice and a period of thirty-five days to submit their claims, and that notice must be published in a national daily newspaper. Rule: The court must notify other creditors and allow them 35 days (with publication) to submit claims after the borrower is served. Application/Conclusion: If you are another creditor, you will receive (and see published) a notice giving you 35 days to submit your claim.

instruction: I missed the 35-day deadline to submit my claim after the notice was published. Is my claim still valid?
input:
Section no 57  part (3) : The claim of a person who fails to submit a claim
within the period referred to in sub-section (2) shall not be valid after that
period.
output: According to Section 57(3), any claim not submitted within the period referred to in subsection (2) shall not be valid after that period. Rule: Failure to submit a claim within the prescribed 35-day period renders the claim invalid thereafter. Application/Conclusion: Since you missed that deadline, your claim will not be valid and generally cannot be admitted later.

instruction: Who pays for the newspaper advertisement costs when notices are published?
input:
Section no 57  part (4) : The fee to be incurred in publishing a notice in a
national daily newspaper pursuant to sub-section (2) or sub-section
 Section no 57  part (1) : of Section 56 shall be recovered from the concerned
