output: According to Section 57(4), the fee for publishing the notice in a national daily newspaper pursuant to the referenced subsections shall be recovered from the concerned petitioner. Rule: The petitioner who caused the notice to be published bears the publication fee. Application/Conclusion: If you (or another party) petitioned to initiate bankruptcy and the court published notices, the petitioner must initially bear the cost of those newspaper notices.

instruction: Can the debtor be made to pay back the fee the petitioner paid for publication during bankruptcy?
input:
Section no 57  part (5) : The fee recovered pursuant to sub-section (4) may
be awarded to be paid by the debtor in the course of bankruptcy.
output: According to Section 57(5), the fee recovered under subsection (4) may be awarded to be paid by the debtor during the course of bankruptcy. Rule: Although the petitioner initially pays the publication fee, the court may order the debtor to reimburse that fee as part of the bankruptcy process. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the court can order that the debtor ultimately pay the publication fee during bankruptcy, so the petitioner may be reimbursed from the debtor's estate.

instruction: What does the court decide when a petition under Section 55 is filed — does it automatically start bankruptcy?
input:
Section no 58 . Order to be given to initiate bankruptcy proceedings
: (1) If a petition is filed in the court pursuant to Section 55 to initiate the
bankruptcy proceedings, the court shall make order as to whether it would be
appropriate to initiate the bankruptcy proceedings in respect of that petition
or not.
output: According to Section 58(1), the court must decide whether it is appropriate to initiate bankruptcy proceedings upon a petition under Section 55. Rule: Filing a petition does not automatically begin bankruptcy; the court makes an order after considering appropriateness. Application/Conclusion: The court will evaluate the petition and then order either to initiate or not to initiate bankruptcy — it is a discretionary judicial decision, not automatic.

instruction: If the court does order initiation of bankruptcy, can it freeze assets or require family members to keep things as they are?
input:
Section no 58  part (2) : If an order is made to initiate the bankruptcy
proceedings pursuant to sub-section (1), the court shall, at the request of the
person likely to become bankrupt himself or herself or of the creditor, order
any other family member of such a person 33 to maintain status quo of the
assets of the person in respect of whose assets the bankruptcy proceedings are
to commence, for the purpose of bankruptcy.
output: According to Section 58(2), if the court orders initiation of bankruptcy, it may, at the request of the person likely to become bankrupt or of the creditor, order any family member to maintain the status quo of the person's assets. Rule: The court can issue a status quo order over assets (including ordering family members to preserve them) to protect the estate during bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: If bankruptcy is ordered, the court can require family members to refrain from disposing of or altering the debtor's assets to preserve the estate for the process.

instruction: My creditor filed the petition and the court ordered bankruptcy. Can they make my sibling stop selling my property even though the sibling wasn't party to the case?
input:
Section no 58  part (2) : If an order is made to initiate the bankruptcy
proceedings pursuant to sub-section (1), the court shall, at the request of the
person likely to become bankrupt himself or herself or of the creditor, order
any other family member of such a person 33 to maintain status quo of the
assets of the person in respect of whose assets the bankruptcy proceedings are
to commence, for the purpose of bankruptcy.
output: According to Section 58(2), the court may order any family member to maintain the status quo of the debtor's assets at the request of the debtor or creditor when bankruptcy is initiated. Rule: Family members can be legally restrained from dealing with the debtor's assets to preserve them for bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the court can order your sibling (as a family member) to maintain the status quo and not sell or otherwise deal with your property once such an order is made.

instruction: I was not listed by the borrower but I have a small secured claim. How can I participate in the bankruptcy process?
input:

(1) shall also contain a statement inviting any other person having any type of
claim, if any, over the assets of the person whose assets is under bankruptcy

Rule: Unlisted claimants are given an opportunity by publication to come forward with evidence within the notice period. Application/Conclusion: You should submit your claim with supporting evidence within the published time-limit (the 35 days referenced) to be treated as a claimant in the bankruptcy.

instruction: Is there a clear statement that claims filed within the time-limit are considered final?

Section no 56  part (3) : The claim made within the time-limit referred to in

output: According to Section 56(3), a claim made within the specified time-limit is considered the final claim against the borrower's assets and bankruptcy proceeds on that basis. Rule: Timely claims are treated as final for purposes of commencing bankruptcy proceedings. Application/Conclusion: The law makes clear that only claims lodged within the prescribed period will be treated as final; ensure you file within the time-limit to preserve your rights.

instruction: Under which section does it say notices must be published in a national daily newspaper?

output: According to Section 56(1), the court must publish the notice in a national daily newspaper. Rule: Publication in a national daily is a required step when a borrower files a petition under Section 55. Application/Conclusion: The statutory requirement to publish the notice in a national daily newspaper comes from Section 56(1), so you should expect public notice as part of the process.

instruction: I filed the petition and paid for the newspaper notice. Can the debtor be ordered to reimburse that amount later?
input:

be awarded to be paid by the debtor in the course of bankruptcy.
output: According to Section 57(5), the fee recovered for publication may be awarded to be paid by the debtor during bankruptcy. Rule: The petitioner may be reimbursed from the debtor's estate as part of bankruptcy costs. Application/Conclusion: Yes — although you initially pay the publication fee, the court can order that the debtor reimburse you during the bankruptcy process.

instruction: Who can ask the court to order family members to preserve assets once bankruptcy is ordered — only the creditor or can the debtor ask too?
input:
Section no 58  part (2) : If an order is made to initiate the bankruptcy
proceedings pursuant to sub-section (1), the court shall, at the request of the
person likely to become bankrupt himself or herself or of the creditor, order
any other family member of such a person 33 to maintain status quo of the
assets of the person in respect of whose assets the bankruptcy proceedings are
to commence, for the purpose of bankruptcy.
output: According to Section 58(2), the court may act at the request of either the person likely to become bankrupt or of the creditor to order family members to maintain the status quo. Rule: Both the debtor and the creditor have standing to request such protective orders. Application/Conclusion: Either you (the debtor) or the creditor can ask the court to order family members to preserve assets once bankruptcy is ordered.

instruction: A notice was published inviting other claimants. If I submit my claim within the period, can the bankruptcy start based on my claim too?
input:
Section no 56  part (3) : The claim made within the time-limit referred to in

shall be considered to be the final claim made against the assets of the borrower,
and the bankruptcy proceedings of his or her assets shall commence on the same

output: According to Section 56(3), claims made within the time-limit under subsection (1) or (2) are final and the bankruptcy proceedings commence on that basis. Rule: Timely claims by any claimant will be included and treated as final for starting bankruptcy. Application/Conclusion: If you submit your claim within the published period with evidence, it will be treated as a final claim and the bankruptcy can proceed including your claim.

instruction: Can I sell my house after the court ordered bankruptcy proceedings against me?
input:
Section no 59 . Transaction to be, ipso facto , stayed or void : (1) If a court makes an order, pursuant to sub-section (1) of Section 58, to initiate the bankruptcy proceedings in relation to the assets of a person, any of the following acts cannot be carried out after the making of such an order, and if any of such acts has already commenced or is being carried out but not completed, such act shall, ipso facto, be stayed:
 Section no 59  clause (a) : To transfer in any manner to any person the title to, bail, pledge, mortgage or to lease or rent in any 34 manner for a period exceeding one year, the assets of a person who is likely to become bankrupt,
output:
According to Section 59(1)(a)...
Rule: Once a court orders the initiation of bankruptcy proceedings, transfers of title, bail, pledge, mortgage or leases/rents for a period exceeding one year in respect of the person's assets cannot be carried out and are stayed.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully sell (transfer title to) your house after such a bankruptcy order; any attempt to transfer the title would be stayed.

instruction: A creditor has a court judgment against me and is trying to attach my assets after the bankruptcy order. Can they proceed?
input: Section no 59  clause (b) : To attach, or execute the pledge, mortgage of, the assets of the person likely to become bankrupt pursuant to the judgment of a court,
output:
According to Section 59(1)(b)...
Rule: After the bankruptcy initiation order, attachment or execution of pledge/mortgage of the debtor's assets pursuant to a court judgment cannot be carried out.
Application/Conclusion: The creditor cannot lawfully attach or execute against your assets under that judgment once the bankruptcy order has been made; such actions are stayed.

instruction: Can my creditor take money from my assets to repay their debt once the bankruptcy proceedings start?
input: Section no 59  clause (c) : To repay debt or discharge liability of any creditor from the assets of the person likely to become bankrupt.
output:
According to Section 59(1)(c)...
Rule: After the court orders initiation of bankruptcy proceedings, repaying a debt or discharging a creditor's liability from the debtor's assets is prohibited.
Application/Conclusion: A creditor may not lawfully take money from your assets to satisfy their claim once the bankruptcy order is in place; such repayment acts are stopped.

instruction: Someone made a contract to buy my property after the bankruptcy order. Is that contract valid?
input:
Section no 59  part (2) : Any deed, contract, dealing, transaction or arrangement executed in contravention of the provision set forth in sub-section
 Section no 59  part (1) : shall, ipso facto be deemed to have been void.
output:
According to Section 59(2)...
Rule: Any deed, contract, dealing, transaction or arrangement done in contravention of the prohibitions in Section 59(1) shall be ipso facto void.
Application/Conclusion: The contract to buy your property executed in violation of Section 59(1) is automatically void; it has no legal effect.

instruction: If the court thinks my family will mismanage assets, who can the court appoint to manage them?
input:

Rule: If the court believes the assets may be embezzled or improperly managed by the person or family, it may, by petition or suo motu, entrust management responsibility to specified persons.

instruction: Can the ward committee be put in charge of managing my property by the court?

According to Section 58(3)(c)...
Rule: The court may entrust management of the assets to the concerned ward committee of the Local Level.

instruction: Could the court pick one of its officers or a lawyer to manage my assets?

practitioner as designated by the court.

According to Section 58(3)(d)...
Rule: The court may designate an officer/employee of the court or a law practitioner to manage the assets.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the court can appoint one of its officers or a designated lawyer to manage the assets if it deems necessary.

instruction: If someone other than me is entrusted with managing the assets, how must they manage them?
input: Section no 58  part (4) : The Local Level, trustee or person designated pursuant to sub-section (3) shall manage the assets of the person likely to become bankrupt, in accordance with the order of the court.

Rule: Any Local Level, trustee or person designated under Section 58(3) must manage the assets in accordance with the court's order.
Application/Conclusion: The appointed manager must follow the court's directions in handling the assets; they cannot act beyond the court's order.

instruction: What happens after the assets, debts and liabilities are ascertained — do creditors get a chance to negotiate?
input:
Section no 60 . Opportunity to be provided to reconcile sum of debts : (1) If the court has made an order to commence the bankruptcy proceedings pursuant to sub-section (1) of Section 58, the Local Level, trustee or person, as the case may be entrusted with responsibility to manage property pursuant to sub-section (3) of the same Section shall, after the assets, debts and other liabilities of the borrower are ascertained, call a meeting of the debtors, creditors or other claimants.
 Section no 60  part (2) : In the meeting called pursuant to sub-section (1), the creditor or claimant shall be provided with a reasonable opportunity to waive
17
his or her claim wholly or partly from all or any of the assets of the borrower
or to reconcile sum by taking amount lesser than his or her claim, by mutual
understanding between the person likely to become bankrupt and the creditor
or other claimant.
output:
According to Section 60(1) and (2)...
Rule: After assets, debts and liabilities are ascertained, the appointed manager must call a meeting of debtors/creditors where creditors are given a reasonable opportunity to waive claims wholly or partly or to accept a lesser sum by mutual agreement.
Application/Conclusion: Creditors will be formally invited to negotiate and can agree to reduce or waive claims through reconciliation at that meeting.

instruction: Can one creditor pay off other creditors and then claim a single lump sum from the debtor?
input: Section no 60  part (3) : In making reconciliation of sum pursuant to sub section (2), an arrangement may be so made that a creditor pays the 35 debt or claim of some or most creditors and submits a lump sum claim against such a person.
output:
According to Section 60(3)...
Rule: Reconciliation arrangements may allow a creditor to pay the debts/claims of some or most creditors and then submit a lump sum claim against the debtor.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — creditors may arrange for one creditor to pay others and then present a consolidated lump sum claim against the person likely to become bankrupt.

instruction: Who must call the meeting of debtors and creditors once liabilities are known?
input: Section no 60 . output:
According to Section 60(1)...
Rule: The Local Level, trustee or person entrusted with managing the property must call the meeting after ascertaining assets, debts and liabilities.
Application/Conclusion: The appointed manager (Local Level, trustee or designated person) is responsible for convening the creditors/debtors meeting.

instruction: My brother isn't licensed but wants to be appointed as the bankruptcy manager. Is that allowed?

instruction: We started transferring part of the title before the bankruptcy order, but didn't finish. What happens now?

According to Section 59(1)...
Rule: If an act listed in Section 59(1) has already commenced but not completed when the bankruptcy order is made, that act shall be ipso facto stayed.
Application/Conclusion: The partial transfer you began will be stayed (frozen) by operation of law; it cannot be completed after the order.

instruction: I want to lease a bankrupt person's property for six months after the order. Is that allowed?

According to Section 59(1)(a)...
Rule: The prohibition specifically mentions leases or rents for a period exceeding one year as acts that cannot be carried out after the order.

instruction: A creditor withdrew money from my account to repay their loan after the bankruptcy order. Is that withdrawal valid?

instruction: Will creditors be allowed to waive claims or accept less money in meetings after the court starts bankruptcy proceedings?

instruction: If the court entrusts management to the Local Level, must they follow the court's order exactly?

instruction: Can I keep three pairs of clothes and three pairs of shoes if I become bankrupt?
input: Section no 63  clause (b) : Clothes up to three pairs and shoes up to three pairs being worn or to be worn by the person who is likely to become bankrupt and an undivided family member of that person,
output: According to Section 63(1)(b)... Rule: Clothes up to three pairs and shoes up to three pairs being worn or to be worn by the bankrupt person and an undivided family member are exempt. Application/Conclusion: You are allowed to retain up to three pairs of clothes and up to three pairs of shoes for yourself and similarly for an undivided family member; these items should not be taken in the bankruptcy distribution.

instruction: I'm a teacher — will the books I use for teaching be seized in bankruptcy?
input: Section no 63  clause (e) : Books necessary to carry out study and teaching,
output: According to Section 63(1)(e)... Rule: Books necessary to carry out study and teaching are exempt from bankruptcy distribution. Application/Conclusion: Your teaching and study books that are necessary for your work or study are protected and should not be taken to satisfy creditors.

instruction: I run a small repair shop — can I keep my single set of tools during bankruptcy?
input: Section no 63  clause (g) : One set of tools or instruments related to the profession and employment of the persons referred to in clause (b).
output: According to Section 63(1)(g)... Rule: One set of tools or instruments related to the profession and employment of the referenced persons is exempt. Application/Conclusion: You may retain one set of tools or instruments necessary for your profession/employment; those essential work tools should not be sold in the bankruptcy process.

instruction: My family needs kitchenware and some furniture — are any household items protected?
input: Section no 63  clause (c) : One set of cooking and dining utensils, pots and cups, one set of bedding materials and reasonable number of furniture required for the undivided family member of the person likely to become a bankrupt,
output: According to Section 63(1)(c)... Rule: One set of cooking/dining utensils (pots and cups), one set of bedding materials, and a reasonable number of furniture required for an undivided family member are exempt. Application/Conclusion: Basic household items listed here for your undivided family member are protected and should remain with the family during bankruptcy.

instruction: Can I keep medicines and health equipment for my family if I'm declared bankrupt?
input: Section no 63  clause (d) : Medicines and health-related equipment required to the person likely to become a bankrupt and the undivided family member of that person,
output: According to Section 63(1)(d)... Rule: Medicines and health-related equipment required by the bankrupt person and their undivided family member are exempt. Application/Conclusion: Necessary medicines and health equipment for you and your undivided family member are protected from seizure in bankruptcy.

instruction: Can I stock food for my family during bankruptcy proceedings? How much?
input: Section no 63  clause (f) : Food necessary for subsistence for a period not exceeding three months to the persons referred to in clause (b), 38
output: According to Section 63(1)(f)... Rule: Food necessary for subsistence for a period not exceeding three months for the persons referred to in clause (b) is exempt. Application/Conclusion: You may keep food supplies sufficient for up to three months for the protected persons; food beyond that period could be considered part of the estate available to creditors.

instruction: Is there a total value limit on all these exempt household and personal items?
input: Section no 63  part (2) (d) : , (e), (f) or (g) of sub-section (1), the total value of the properties referred to in these clauses shall not exceed one hundred 19 thousand rupees.
output: According to Section 63(2)... Rule: The total value of the properties referred to in clauses (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g) of sub-section (1) shall not exceed one hundred 19 thousand rupees. Application/Conclusion: While individual exempt items are listed, their combined value cannot exceed the stated cap (one hundred 19 thousand rupees); if the combined value is higher, the excess may be available to creditors.

instruction: When I file for bankruptcy under Section 55, what must I file about my assets?
input: Section no 64 . Assets not to be concealed : (1) A person who files a petition pursuant to Section 55 for commencing the bankruptcy proceedings of his or her assets shall submit an exact inventory of his or her total assets.
output: According to Section 64(1)... Rule: A person who files a petition under Section 55 must submit an exact inventory of their total assets. Application/Conclusion: When you initiate bankruptcy proceedings under Section 55 you are legally required to provide a full and accurate inventory of all your assets.

instruction: If I deliberately hide assets when giving the inventory, can creditors sue me separately?
input: Section no 64  part (2) : In submitting an inventory pursuant to sub-section (1), if he or she hides or conceals such assets with mala fide intention of causing loss or damage to the creditor, a separate lawsuit may be instituted against him or her.
output: According to Section 64(2)... Rule: If, when submitting the required inventory, a person hides or conceals assets with mala fide intention to cause loss or damage to a creditor, a separate lawsuit may be instituted against that person. Application/Conclusion: Deliberately hiding assets in the inventory exposes you to a separate legal action by creditors — you should not conceal assets and must be truthful in the inventory.

instruction: I discovered hidden assets before the bankruptcy finished — what procedure applies?
input: Section no 64  part (3) : If assets are hidden or concealed pursuant to sub section (1), and such assets are discovered before the completion of the bankruptcy proceedings, the proceedings referred to in sub section (2) of Section 61 shall be carried out in respect of the creditor and the claimant having so discovered the assets and the other creditor and claimant as well.
output: According to Section 64(3)... Rule: If hidden assets are discovered before completion of bankruptcy proceedings, the proceedings referred to in subsection (2) of Section 61 shall be carried out regarding the creditor/claimant who discovered them and other creditors/claimants. Application/Conclusion: Because you found hidden assets prior to the end of bankruptcy proceedings, the special proceedings under Section 61(2) will be initiated involving you (as discoverer) and the other creditors/claimants to address distribution and related matters.

instruction: I found hidden assets only after bankruptcy finished. Do I get anything for finding them?
input: Section no 64  part (4) : If any creditor or claimant discovers any assets pursuant to sub-section (3) after the completion of the bankruptcy proceedings, ten percent amount of the assets so discovered shall be provided to the creditor or claimant who has so discovered the assets if such creditor or claimant has already satisfied the sum 39 according to his or her claim at the time of bankruptcy proceedings, and if his or her claim has not been so satisfied, his or her sum shall be caused to be satisfied from such assets and the remaining assets shall be distributed pursuant to the said sub-section to the other creditors and claimants. Provided that if the creditor or claimant is the successor or relative of the bankrupt person, he or she shall not be entitled to such facility.
output: According to Section 64(4)... Rule: If assets are discovered after bankruptcy completion, the discoverer-creditor/claimant may be given ten percent of the discovered assets if they had already been satisfied for their claim at the time of bankruptcy; if not satisfied, their claim is met from the discovered assets and remaining assets are distributed to other creditors/claimants. Application/Conclusion: If you found assets post-completion and you had already been paid under your claim, you may receive 10% of those assets. If you had not been paid, the discovered assets will first satisfy your claim and any leftover will be shared with other creditors. Note: successors/relatives of the bankrupt are excluded from this benefit.

instruction: I'm the bankrupt's son and I found hidden assets after the case closed — am I entitled to the 10% reward?
input: Section no 64  part (4) : If any creditor or claimant discovers any assets pursuant to sub-section (3) after the completion of the bankruptcy proceedings, ten percent amount of the assets so discovered shall be provided to the creditor or claimant who has so discovered the assets if such creditor or claimant has already satisfied the sum 39 according to his or her claim at the time of bankruptcy proceedings, and if his or her claim has not been so satisfied, his or her sum shall be caused to be satisfied from such assets and the remaining assets shall be distributed pursuant to the said sub-section to the other creditors and claimants. Provided that if the creditor or claimant is the successor or relative of the bankrupt person, he or she shall not be entitled to such facility.
output: According to Section 64(4)... Rule: The 10% award for discovering assets after completion applies to creditors/claimants who discovered assets and had already been satisfied at the time of bankruptcy, but successors or relatives of the bankrupt are explicitly excluded. Application/Conclusion: Because you are a relative/successor of the bankrupt person, you are not entitled to the 10% facility even if you discovered the hidden assets after completion.

instruction: If hidden assets remain after paying the entitled creditors, who gets the leftover assets?
input: Section no 64  part (5) : If the assets hidden or concealed pursuant to sub section (2) remain after payment to the creditor or claimant pursuant to sub section (4), such assets shall be returned to the concerned person.
output: According to Section 64(5)... Rule: Any hidden assets that remain after payment to creditors/claimants under subsection (4) shall be returned to the concerned person. Application/Conclusion: After discovered hidden assets have been used to satisfy claims and any entitled reward paid, any leftover assets must be returned to the person concerned (the owner of those assets).

instruction: How long will I be treated as bankrupt — I need to plan for the future.
input: Section no 65 . Status of bankruptcy to be terminated : (1) The status of a bankrupt person falling under bankruptcy shall remain for a period of twelve years from the date on which he or she became a bankrupt.
output: According to Section 65(1)... Rule: The status of a bankrupt person remains for a period of twelve years from the date they became bankrupt. Application/Conclusion: Your bankruptcy status will last twelve years starting from the date you were declared bankrupt; plan accordingly because legal consequences tied to that status persist for that period.

instruction: My creditor promised to let me keep tools but now says they will seize everything. Is there a clause protecting my professional instruments?
input: Section no 63  clause (g) : One set of tools or instruments related to the profession and employment of the persons referred to in clause (b).
output: According to Section 63(1)(g)... Rule: One set of tools or instruments related to the profession and employment of the protected persons is exempt. Application/Conclusion: The law protects one set of professional tools. If your tools are necessary for your employment and constitute that single set, they should remain with you despite the creditor's statement; you can assert this exemption in the bankruptcy proceedings.

instruction: I filed the inventory but later discovered I forgot an asset. If I add it later before the bankruptcy ends, what happens?
input: Section no 64  part (3) : If assets are hidden or concealed pursuant to sub section (1), and such assets are discovered before the completion of the bankruptcy proceedings, the proceedings referred to in sub section (2) of Section 61 shall be carried out in respect of the creditor and the claimant having so discovered the assets and the other creditor and claimant as well.
output: According to Section 64(3)... Rule: Assets hidden or concealed and discovered before completion of proceedings trigger the proceedings under Section 61(2) for the discoverer-creditor/claimant and other creditors/claimants. Application/Conclusion: If you report the previously omitted asset before the bankruptcy concludes, the special procedures under Section 61(2) will be followed involving you and other claimants — the asset will be treated as discovered during ongoing proceedings rather than after completion.

instruction: Under which section is the requirement to submit an exact inventory written?
input: Section no 64 . Assets not to be concealed : (1) A person who files a petition pursuant to Section 55 for commencing the bankruptcy proceedings of his or her assets shall submit an exact inventory of his or her total assets.
output: According to Section 64(1)... Rule: Section 64(1) requires a person filing a petition under Section 55 to submit an exact inventory of total assets. Application/Conclusion: The submission of an exact inventory is mandated by Section 64(1); you should comply fully with that requirement when initiating bankruptcy proceedings.

instruction: Can I marry someone within my clan even if some relatives say it's wrong?
input:
part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (b) of
sub-section (1), nothing shall bar the conclusion, or causing the conclusion of,
a marriage within the relationship that is allowed to marry in accordance with
the practices prevailing in their ethnic community or clan.
output: According to Section 70(2): Rule: Where a relationship is allowed to marry under the practices of their ethnic community or clan, nothing in clause (b) of sub‑section (1) prevents concluding such a marriage. Application/Conclusion: If your relationship is one that your ethnic community or clan permits, Section 70(2) says relatives' objections based on clause (b) of subsection (1) do not bar the marriage; so the customary permission controls and the marriage may be concluded.

instruction: Is it illegal to marry someone who is not 'in a condition' to marry under the law?
input: Section no 71 . Marriage not to be concluded : (1) No one shall conclude, or cause to be concluded, marriage with a man or a woman, as the case may be, who is not in a condition where marriage can be concluded pursuant to Section 70.
output: According to Section 71(1): Rule: No one may conclude or cause to conclude a marriage with a person who is not in the condition to marry as defined by Section 70. Application/Conclusion: If the person does not meet the conditions set out in Section 70, then concluding a marriage with them is prohibited under Section 71(1) and would be unlawful.

instruction: My husband hid that he has HIV. Can I get the marriage voided?
input: Section no 71  part (2) (a) : One who has contracted human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or Hepatitis ‘B’ or similar other incurable severe disease,
output: According to Section 71(2)(a): Rule: Concealment that a person has contracted HIV (or similar incurable severe disease) is listed as a condition of misrepresentation that bars concluding marriage. Application/Conclusion: If your husband concealed that he has HIV, that is a recognized misrepresentation under Section 71(2)(a); you can rely on the law's provisions concerning misrepresentation to seek nullification or other remedies.

instruction: My wife lied about being able to have children. What does the law say?
input: Section no 71  part (2) (b) : One who has already been proved to have no sexual organ, to be impotent or to have no reproductive capability,
output: According to Section 71(2)(b): Rule: Misrepresentation that a person is fertile—where in fact they have no sexual organ, are impotent, or lack reproductive capability—is a barred condition. Application/Conclusion: If your wife misrepresented her reproductive capability and she in fact cannot reproduce, this falls under Section 71(2)(b); you may treat the marriage as concluded by misrepresentation and pursue remedies available for such misrepresentation.

instruction: My partner failed to tell me they are blind and deaf. Can I void the marriage?
input: Section no 71  part (2) (c) : One who is dumb or has lost hearing capacity, being fully blind or is suffering from leprosy, 43
output: According to Section 71(2)(c): Rule: Concealing that a person is dumb, deaf, fully blind, or suffering from leprosy is a misrepresentation condition that bars concluding marriage. Application/Conclusion: If your partner hid such conditions when the marriage was arranged, Section 71(2)(c) indicates that this is a ground of misrepresentation and you may seek to have the marriage voided on that basis.

instruction: What if someone is of unsound mind—can a marriage be concluded with them?
input: Section no 71  part (2) (d) : One who is of unsound mind,
output: According to Section 71(2)(d): Rule: A person being of unsound mind is expressly listed as a condition that, if concealed, bars the conclusion of marriage. Application/Conclusion: If a person is of unsound mind, a marriage concluded with them (or caused to be concluded while hiding that fact) is barred under Section 71(2)(d), and the aggrieved party can seek to void the marriage.

instruction: My spouse was already married to someone else but didn't tell me. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 71  part (2) (e) : One who is already a married,
output: According to Section 71(2)(e): Rule: Concealment that a person is already married is a misrepresentation condition that bars concluding a new marriage. Application/Conclusion: If your spouse was already married and hid that fact, Section 71(2)(e) recognizes this as misrepresentation—this provides a ground to have the later marriage voided and to claim remedies.

instruction: I discovered my wife was pregnant from another man when we married. Can I void the marriage?
input: Section no 71  part (2) (f) : One who is a pregnant,
output: According to Section 71(2)(f): Rule: Concealment that a person is pregnant is a misrepresentation condition that bars concluding a marriage. Application/Conclusion: If your wife was pregnant (by someone else) and concealed it when the marriage was concluded, Section 71(2)(f) applies and you may seek to void the marriage on grounds of misrepresentation.

instruction: He never told me he had a criminal conviction for a serious moral crime. What does the law say?
input: Section no 71  part (2) (g) : One who has been convicted of a criminal offense involving moral turpitude by a court and sentenced for the same.
output: According to Section 71(2)(g): Rule: Hiding that one has been convicted of an offense involving moral turpitude and sentenced for it is a misrepresentation which bars concluding marriage. Application/Conclusion: If your partner concealed such a conviction, Section 71(2)(g) gives you a legal basis to seek voiding of the marriage and related remedies for misrepresentation.

instruction: I was deceived into marriage. Can I get compensation and void it?
input:
Section no 71  part (3) : A person who is aggrieved from the conclusion of
marriage by way of misrepresentation pursuant to sub-section (2) may get such
a marriage voided and claim a reasonable compensation from the person who
concludes, or causes to be concluded, marriage by misrepresentation.
output: According to Section 71(3): Rule: A person aggrieved by marriage concluded by misrepresentation (per Section 71(2)) may get the marriage voided and claim reasonable compensation from the person responsible. Application/Conclusion: If you were induced into marriage by any misrepresentation listed in Section 71(2), you can ask the court to void the marriage and claim reasonable compensation from the party who misrepresented.

instruction: When is a marriage ipso facto void?
input:
Section no 72 . Marriage to be void : (1) A marriage concluded on any
of the following conditions shall, ipso facto, be void:
output: According to Section 72(1): Rule: Marriages concluded on specified conditions (listed in the following clauses) are ipso facto void. Application/Conclusion: If a marriage falls under any of the conditions that Section 72(1) enumerates in its clauses (such as lack of consent or incest), it is automatically void without further action.

instruction: Is a marriage without consent valid?
input: Section no 72  clause (a) : A marriage concluded without consent of the man or the woman,
output: According to Section 72(1)(a): Rule: A marriage concluded without the consent of either party is void. Application/Conclusion: If your marriage was entered into without your consent, Section 72(a) makes it void ab initio and you may treat it as legally invalid.

instruction: My cousin and I got married — is that automatically illegal?
input:
Section no 72  clause (b) : A marriage concluded between the relatives,
punishable by law on incest.
output: According to Section 72(1)(b): Rule: A marriage between relatives punishable by law as incest is void. Application/Conclusion: If your marriage is between relatives that the law punishes as incest, then under Section 72(b) it is void; however, whether your particular cousin marriage is within that category depends on the specific incest rules in other laws.

instruction: What about marriages prohibited under Section 70(1)(d)? Are they void?
input: Section no 72  clause (c) : Marriage against Section 70(1) (d).
output: According to Section 72(1)(c): Rule: A marriage that is contrary to Section 70(1)(d) is void. Application/Conclusion: If the marriage you entered conflicts with the prohibition in Section 70(1)(d), then Section 72(c) declares that marriage void; you would need to check Section 70(1)(d) to confirm the specific prohibition.

instruction: I married someone while still legally married to another person. Is that void?
input:
Section no 72  clause (d) : Another marriage concluded by a man or woman
whilst the current marital relationship is still prevalent except in the situation
of being separated by taking partition according to law.
output: According to Section 72(1)(d): Rule: A subsequent marriage contracted while an existing marital relationship still prevails is void, except where the parties are legally separated by partition. Application/Conclusion: If you or your spouse entered a second marriage while the first marriage continued and no lawful partition/separation applied, Section 72(d) makes that second marriage void.

instruction: If a marriage is void under Section 72, when is it considered invalid from?
input:
Section no 72  part (2) : A marriage concluded pursuant to sub-section (1)
shall be invalid ab initio. 44
output: According to Section 72(2): Rule: A marriage declared void under subsection (1) is invalid ab initio (invalid from the beginning). Application/Conclusion: If your marriage falls under any voiding ground in Section 72(1), it is treated as never having had legal effect from the outset under Section 72(2).

instruction: Are there any exceptions where a marriage between relatives might not be void?
input:
Section no 72  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (b)
of sub-section (1), a marriage concluded pursuant to sub-section (2) of Section
70 shall not be void.
output: According to Section 72(3): Rule: Despite clause (b) (which declares incestuous-relative marriages void), a marriage concluded under Section 70(2) is not void. Application/Conclusion: If your marriage between relatives falls within the exception described in Section 70(2) (for relationships allowed by ethnic/community practices), Section 72(3) says that such a marriage is not void despite the general prohibition in clause (b).

instruction: Someone says they were tricked into marriage by lies. Can they void it on that basis?
input:
Section no 73 . Voidable marriage : (1) If a marriage is concluded in any
of the following circumstances and any person who concludes such a marriage
does not accept it, the person may get such a marriage voided:
output: According to Section 73(1): Rule: If a marriage is concluded under certain specified circumstances and the person does not accept it, that person may get the marriage voided. Application/Conclusion: Where a marriage was entered into under the listed circumstances (for example, misrepresentation per Section 71(2)), the aggrieved party may seek to void the marriage under Section 73(1) if they do not accept it.

instruction: If I was married by misrepresentation (like hiding HIV), what section allows me to void the marriage?
input:
Section no 73  clause (b) : If the marriage has been concluded, or caused
to be concluded, by way of misrepresentation pursuant to sub-section (2) of
Section 71.
output: According to Section 73(1)(b): Rule: A marriage concluded by misrepresentation as described in Section 71(2) is a voidable marriage and may be voided by the person who does not accept it. Application/Conclusion: Because misrepresentations listed in Section 71(2) (e.g., hiding HIV) render a marriage voidable, you can initiate proceedings to have the marriage voided under Section 73(1)(b).

instruction: My wife is pregnant now — can I unilaterally void the marriage I entered into by fraud?
input:
Section no 73  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), a marriage shall be void only with the consent of the woman if she is pregnant
or has delivered a baby as the consequence of the marriage.
output: According to Section 73(2): Rule: If the woman is pregnant or has delivered a baby as a consequence of the marriage, the marriage can be voided only with her consent. Application/Conclusion: If the marriage was procured by fraud but the woman is currently pregnant or has borne a child from the marriage, you cannot unilaterally void the marriage; voiding requires the woman's consent under Section 73(2).

instruction: If I pay all my creditors now, can I stop being bankrupt? What do I need to do?
input: part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if a bankrupt person pays all liabilities payable to the creditors at the time of bankruptcy, he or she may file a petition in the court to terminate the status of bankruptcy along with the evidence thereof.
output: According to Section 65(2): Rule: If a bankrupt person pays all liabilities payable to creditors at the time of bankruptcy, they may file a petition in court to terminate the bankruptcy status, attaching evidence of payment. Application/Conclusion: If you truly paid all liabilities that were due at the time of bankruptcy and you have documentary proof, you can file a petition in court asking to terminate your bankruptcy status; make sure to attach the payment evidence when filing.

instruction: After I file that petition, what will the court do about my creditors?
input: Section no 65  part (3) : The court shall make an order to summon the presence of all creditors who were either partially paid or unpaid at the time of bankruptcy of such a person within a period of fifteen days, excluding the time required for journey, to have a hearing on the petition filed pursuant to sub-section (2).
output: According to Section 65(3): Rule: The court must order that all creditors who were partially paid or unpaid at the time of bankruptcy be summoned for a hearing on the petition within fifteen days (excluding travel time). Application/Conclusion: Once you file your petition under 65(2), the court will issue summons to those creditors and hold a hearing within the 15-day period (plus travel time); expect creditors to be notified and given that timeframe to appear.

instruction: If the judge finds I actually paid everything, can they cancel the original bankruptcy order?
input: Section no 65  part (4) : If, in hearing the petition filed pursuant to sub-section 20 Section no 65 part (2) : , it appears that the bankrupt person has satisfied all the debts 40 and liabilities remained unpaid at the time of bankruptcy, the court may annul the order made at the time of his or her bankruptcy.
output: According to Section 65(4): Rule: If at the hearing the court finds the bankrupt person has satisfied all debts and liabilities that remained unpaid at the time of bankruptcy, the court may annul the bankruptcy order. Application/Conclusion: If you prove at the hearing that all previously unpaid debts were satisfied, the court has the authority to annul your bankruptcy order — annulment is discretionary but permitted under this provision.

instruction: If the court annuls my bankruptcy, am I free immediately or is there a waiting period?
input: Section no 65  part (5) : If an order is annulled pursuant to sub-section (4), the status of the bankrupt person shall be deemed have been terminated after one year from the date of the annulment of such an order.
output: According to Section 65(5): Rule: When a bankruptcy order is annulled under subsection (4), the bankrupt person's status is deemed terminated only after one year from the date of annulment. Application/Conclusion: Even if the court annuls the bankruptcy order, your official status as a bankrupt will only be treated as terminated one year after that annulment date — you should plan any legal or practical steps that depend on non-bankrupt status with that one-year delay in mind.

instruction: I learned about a problem covered by Section 54 today — how long do I have to sue?
input: Section no 66  clause (a) : In matters under Section 54, within three years from the date of accrual of the cause of action,
output: According to Section 66(a): Rule: For matters under Section 54, the limitation period to bring a lawsuit is within three years from the date the cause of action accrued. Application/Conclusion: Since your issue falls under Section 54 and you discovered it today at the time the cause of action accrued, you have three years from that accrual date to initiate legal proceedings.

instruction: I only found out about the wrongful actions under Sections 62/64 now — how long can I file a suit?
input: Section no 66  clause (b) : In matters under Sections 62 and 64, within two years from the date of knowledge thereof,
output: According to Section 66(b): Rule: For matters under Sections 62 and 64, a lawsuit must be brought within two years from the date of knowledge of the act. Application/Conclusion: Because this matter falls under Sections 62/64, your two-year limitation period runs from the date you knew (or should reasonably have known) about the wrongful act; you should prepare to file within that two-year window.

instruction: For other bankruptcy-related acts not in (a) or (b), what's the time limit to sue?
input: Section no 66  clause (c) : In the matters other than those referred to in clauses (a) and (b), within six months from the date of commission of such an act or action. 41 Part-3 Family Law Chapter-1 Provisions Relating to Marriage
output: According to Section 66(c): Rule: For matters not covered by clauses (a) or (b), the limitation period is six months from the date the act or action was committed. Application/Conclusion: If your complaint doesn't fall under Sections 54, 62 or 64, you generally have six months from the date of the act to start a lawsuit; act promptly because six months is a short window.

instruction: Can two people be married without a ceremony? Is that valid or not?
input: Section no 67 . Marriage deemed to be concluded : If a man and a woman accept each other as the husband and wife through any occasion, ceremony, formal or other act, a marriage shall be deemed to have been concluded.
output: According to Section 67: Rule: Marriage is deemed concluded if a man and woman accept each other as husband and wife by any occasion, ceremony, formal or other act. Application/Conclusion: Yes — under this provision, a marriage can be valid even without a formal ceremony, provided both parties accept each other as husband and wife through some occasion, act or form; the law treats such acceptance as a concluded marriage.

instruction: Is marriage permanent? Can it be ended whenever one partner wants?
input:
Section no 68 . Marriage to be inviolable social bond : (1) Marriage shall be a permanent, inviolable and holy social and legal bond, which is based on free consent and established to start conjugal and family life between a man and a woman.
Section no 68  part (2) : The marital bond referred to in sub-section (1) shall subsist until extinguished pursuant to Section 82.
output: According to Section 68(1) and 68(2): Rule: Marriage is a permanent, inviolable social and legal bond based on free consent and continues until extinguished under Section 82. Application/Conclusion: Marriage is intended to be permanent and cannot be unilaterally ended outside the legal process; to end the marital bond you must follow the procedures set out (such as those in Section 82), not simply by one partner's decision.

instruction: Do I have the right to choose whom to marry and keep my family life private?
input:
Section no 69 . Freedom of marriage : (1) Every person shall, subject to law, have the freedom to conclude a marriage, establish a family and spend a conjugal life.
Section no 69  part (2) : A marriage must be made, or caused to be made, public irrespective of the manner used to conclude it.
Section no 69  part (3) : Every person’s family life shall be inviolable.
output: According to Section 69(1), 69(2) and 69(3): Rule: Every person has the freedom to marry and establish family life (subject to law); marriages must be made public regardless of how concluded; and family life is inviolable. Application/Conclusion: You have a legal freedom to choose to marry, but the law requires that the marriage be made public in some form; your family life is protected from unlawful interference. So while you have choice, the marriage should be publicized as required by law.

instruction: My partner and I are cousins. Can we get married under this law?
input: Section no 70  clause (b) : If the man and the woman are not relatives, punishable by law on incest,
output: According to Section 70(b): Rule: A marriage may be concluded only if the man and woman are not relatives who are punishable by law for incest. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin relationship falls within the kind of kinship that the law treats as incest and punishes, you cannot lawfully marry; you must confirm whether your specific degree of relationship is covered by the incest prohibition before proceeding.

instruction: I'm still legally married to someone else. Can I marry another person now?
input: Section no 70  clause (c) : If matrimonial relationship of both the man and the woman does not exist,
output: According to Section 70(c): Rule: A marriage may be concluded only if neither party is currently in a matrimonial relationship. Application/Conclusion: Because you remain legally married to someone else, you cannot validly marry another person until the existing matrimonial relationship has been lawfully ended.

instruction: Is there a minimum age required to get married?
input: Section no 70  clause (d) : If both have attained twenty years of age.
output: According to Section 70(d): Rule: Both parties must have attained twenty years of age to conclude a marriage. Application/Conclusion: You must be at least 20 years old (and so must your partner) to lawfully enter into marriage under this provision.

instruction: What basic things are required for a marriage to be legally concluded?
input:
Section no 70 . Marriage may be concluded : (1) Subject to this Chapter, a marriage may be concluded between a man and a woman on the following conditions:
Section no 70 clause (a) : If the man and the woman agree to accept each other as husband and wife, 42
output: According to Section 70(1) and 70(a): Rule: Subject to the Chapter, a marriage may be concluded between a man and a woman if certain conditions are met; one basic condition is mutual agreement to accept each other as husband and wife. Application/Conclusion: At minimum, mutual agreement to accept each other as husband and wife is required for a lawful marriage; this is one of the enumerated conditions that must be satisfied alongside the other conditions in Section 70.

instruction: Under which section does the law say when a marriage is 'deemed to be concluded'?
input: Section no 67 . Marriage deemed to be concluded : If a man and a woman accept each other as the husband and wife through any occasion, ceremony, formal or other act, a marriage shall be deemed to have been concluded.
output: According to Section 67: Rule: The law deems a marriage concluded when a man and woman accept each other as husband and wife through any occasion, ceremony, formal or other act. Application/Conclusion: Section 67 is the provision that defines when a marriage is considered concluded; if you and your partner accepted each other as spouses by some act or ceremony, Section 67 treats that as a concluded marriage.

instruction: Creditors aren't responding — how long does the court give them to appear after I file to end my bankruptcy?
input: Section no 65  part (3) : The court shall make an order to summon the presence of all creditors who were either partially paid or unpaid at the time of bankruptcy of such a person within a period of fifteen days, excluding the time required for journey, to have a hearing on the petition filed pursuant to sub-section (2).
output: According to Section 65(3): Rule: The court must summon all partially paid or unpaid creditors to a hearing within fifteen days (excluding travel time) after the petition under subsection (2) is filed. Application/Conclusion: Creditors should be summoned and given notice to appear within that 15-day period (plus travel allowances); if they fail to appear, the court will still have followed the required summons process.

instruction: I found out today about an action under Section 62 that happened three years ago. Is it too late to sue?
input: Section no 66  clause (b) : In matters under Sections 62 and 64, within two years from the date of knowledge thereof,
output: According to Section 66(b): Rule: For matters under Sections 62 and 64, you must sue within two years from the date you became aware of the matter. Application/Conclusion: Because you only learned of the Section 62 action today but the two-year limitation applies from the date of knowledge, you generally have two years from today to bring suit; however, if this is beyond other applicable limitation triggers, consult a lawyer promptly to confirm.

instruction: If my bankruptcy is annulled, can I immediately apply for jobs that require a clean record?
input: Section no 65  part (5) : If an order is annulled pursuant to sub-section (4), the status of the bankrupt person shall be deemed have been terminated after one year from the date of the annulment of such an order.
output: According to Section 65(5): Rule: After annulment under subsection (4), the bankrupt person's status is deemed terminated only after one year from the annulment date. Application/Conclusion: You cannot treat your bankrupt status as officially terminated immediately after annulment for purposes like employment that check legal status; you should wait one year from the annulment before representing that your bankruptcy status has been terminated.

instruction: Can I file a joint petition to pause bankruptcy if both parties agree?
input: part (4) : If the parties reach mutual understanding pursuant to sub-section (2) or (3) or the concerned parties agree, for any reasons, to stay the bankruptcy proceedings for the time being, a joint petition may be filed in the court accordingly.
output: According to Section 60(4)... Rule: If the parties reach mutual understanding or agree to stay the bankruptcy proceedings for the time being, a joint petition may be filed in the court. Application/Conclusion: Since you and the other concerned party both agree to stay the proceedings, you may file a joint petition in court to request that stay.

instruction: If we file that petition, how long can the court stay the proceedings?
input: Section no 60  part (5) : If a petition is filed for staying the bankruptcy proceedings pursuant to sub-section (4), the court shall make an order to stay as requested the bankruptcy proceedings for a period not exceeding the period set forth in clause (b) of sub-section (2) of Section 54.
output: According to Section 60(5)... Rule: When a petition to stay is filed under sub-section (4), the court shall order a stay for a period not exceeding the period specified in clause (b) of sub-section (2) of Section 54. Application/Conclusion: The stay cannot exceed that statutory period; you must check clause (b) of Section 54(2) to know the exact maximum duration allowed.

instruction: If the court makes that stay order, can anyone start new bankruptcy proceedings against the debtor during the stay?
input: Section no 60  part (6) : If an order is made pursuant to sub-section (5), the bankruptcy proceedings in respect of the assets of such a person cannot be instituted until the expiry of that period.
output: According to Section 60(6)... Rule: Where the court makes a stay order under sub-section (5), bankruptcy proceedings with respect to that person's assets cannot be instituted until the stay period expires. Application/Conclusion: No new bankruptcy proceedings in respect of that person's assets may be initiated while the stay is in effect.

instruction: Who gets paid first when someone's assets are bankrupted? Be specific.
input:
Section no 61 . Priority order of paying debt or liability : (1) In carrying out or causing to be carried out the bankruptcy proceedings of the assets of a person pursuant to this Chapter, the debts to be paid or liabilities to be discharged by such a person shall be settled, on the basis of the following priority order, from the assets of such a person:
 Section no 61  clause (a) :
Costs incurred in the carrying out of the
bankruptcy proceedings,
 Section no 61  clause (b) : The liability of the secured creditor, who has provided debt against a pledge or mortgage, to the extent of such pledge or mortgage, 36
 Section no 61  clause (c) : Tax, fine to be paid to the Government of Nepal, Province Government or Local Government or other government charges and dues,
 Section no 61  clause (d) : Debts of the creditors other than those referred to in clause (b),
 Section no 61  clause (e) : Claim of the claimants other than those referred to in clause (b), (c) or (d).
output: According to Section 61(1)... Rule: Debts and liabilities from bankrupt assets are settled in a specified priority order: (a) costs of carrying out bankruptcy proceedings; (b) liabilities of secured creditors to the extent of pledge/mortgage; (c) taxes, fines and other government dues; (d) debts of other creditors (not secured as in (b)); (e) claims of other claimants not covered by (b), (c) or (d). Application/Conclusion: When assets are realized, costs of the bankruptcy process are paid first, then secured creditors from pledged assets, then government taxes/dues, then other creditors, and finally other claimants.

instruction: If two creditors have the same priority level, how will payment be divided?
input: Section no 61  part (2) : In paying or setting off debts or liabilities pursuant to sub-section (1), if there are more than one creditor or claimant of the same priority order, the debt or claim shall be paid or set off pro rata basis from the assets bankrupted in proportion to the debt or claim of each creditor or claimant.
output: According to Section 61(2)... Rule: Where multiple creditors/claimants share the same priority, payments or set-offs are made on a pro rata basis in proportion to each creditor's debt or claim. Application/Conclusion: If two unsecured creditors of equal priority are owed different amounts, each receives a share of the available assets proportional to their respective claims.

instruction: My mortgage bank got paid from the sale but there was extra money left over—can other creditors claim that surplus?
input: Section no 61  part (3) : In paying the debts of the secured creditors pursuant to clause (b) of sub-section (1), if, after recovery of his or her debts from the assets pledged or mortgaged to him or her, there remains any portion or sum of such pledge or mortgage, other creditors or claimants may make claim over such portion or sum. Provided that if the secured creditor’s debts cannot be fully recovered from such assets, he or she cannot claim other property.
output: According to Section 61(3)... Rule: After a secured creditor recovers their debt from the pledged/mortgaged assets, any remaining portion of that pledge may be claimed by other creditors or claimants. Conversely, if the secured creditor's debt is not fully recovered from those assets, the secured creditor cannot claim other property. Application/Conclusion: The surplus from sale of pledged assets is available for other creditors to claim; but if sale proceeds are insufficient, the secured creditor cannot pursue other debtor property under this rule.

instruction: Someone showed false debts to push me down the list. What does the law say about collusion and fake claims?
input: Section no 62 . Debt of creditor who shows excess debt not to receive priority : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) of Section 61, if it is held that, by a collusion between a person likely to become a bankrupt and any creditor, and being guided by a malafide motive to cause loss to another creditor or claimant, more debts or claims have been shown from any transaction which has never happened nor been carried on, the debt or liability of such a creditor shall be paid or set off only after the debt or liability of other creditor or claimant is satisfied.
output: According to Section 62... Rule: If it is found that a creditor colluded with the person likely to become bankrupt to show excessive or fake debts with malafide intent to harm other creditors, the colluding creditor's debt will be paid or set off only after other creditors' debts are satisfied. Application/Conclusion: If you can establish collusion and fabricated claims, the colluding creditor loses priority and will be paid only after genuine creditors have been satisfied.

instruction: Which assets should be excluded from bankruptcy distribution — e.g., my sister says her gift to our mother can be taken. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 63 . Property to be set aside : (1) Prior to effecting bankruptcy of the assets of a person pursuant to this Chapter, the following property shall be set aside and the bankruptcy proceedings shall be carried out from the remaining assets:
 Section no 63  clause (a) : Any property that remains as the personal property of a person other than one who is likely to become a bankrupt,
output: According to Section 63(1) and clause (a)... Rule: Before carrying out bankruptcy against a person's assets, property that remains as the personal property of someone other than the person likely to become bankrupt must be set aside; bankruptcy proceeds are to be made from the remaining assets. Application/Conclusion: If the property genuinely belongs to your mother (or another third party), it should be set aside and excluded from distribution among the bankrupt person's creditors.

instruction: Can a secured creditor go after other assets if the mortgage didn't cover the full debt?
input: Section no 61  part (3) : In paying the debts of the secured creditors pursuant to clause (b) of sub-section (1), if, after recovery of his or her debts from the assets pledged or mortgaged to him or her, there remains any portion or sum of such pledge or mortgage, other creditors or claimants may make claim over such portion or sum. Provided that if the secured creditor’s debts cannot be fully recovered from such assets, he or she cannot claim other property.
output: According to Section 61(3)... Rule: If a secured creditor cannot fully recover their debt from the pledged or mortgaged assets, that secured creditor cannot claim other property. Application/Conclusion: The bank cannot take additional non-pledged property of the bankrupt under this rule if the pledged assets do not fully satisfy the debt.

instruction: I am an unsecured creditor — where do I stand compared to taxes and secured creditors?
input:
Section no 61  clause (b) : The liability of the secured creditor, who has provided debt against a pledge or mortgage, to the extent of such pledge or mortgage, 36
 Section no 61  clause (c) : Tax, fine to be paid to the Government of Nepal, Province Government or Local Government or other government charges and dues,
 Section no 61  clause (d) : Debts of the creditors other than those referred to in clause (b),
output: According to Section 61(b)-(d)... Rule: Secured creditors’ liabilities from pledged assets and government taxes/fines are prioritized before debts of other creditors. Application/Conclusion: As an unsecured creditor, you fall under clause (d) and will be paid after secured creditors (to the extent of pledge) and after government taxes/fines have been satisfied.

instruction: Are government taxes paid before other creditors in bankruptcy?
input: Section no 61  clause (c) : Tax, fine to be paid to the Government of Nepal, Province Government or Local Government or other government charges and dues,
output: According to Section 61(c)... Rule: Taxes, fines and other government charges and dues are listed as a priority item in bankruptcy settlements. Application/Conclusion: Government tax/fine liabilities must be settled out of the bankrupt assets ahead of other non-secured creditors.

instruction: Do bankruptcy administration costs get paid from the assets first?
input:
Section no 61  clause (a) :
Costs incurred in the carrying out of the
bankruptcy proceedings,
output: According to Section 61(a)... Rule: Costs incurred in carrying out the bankruptcy proceedings are given priority. Application/Conclusion: Expenses of administering the bankruptcy are paid first from the bankrupt assets before other creditors receive payment.

instruction: If three creditors of equal priority are owed 10,000; 20,000; and 70,000 respectively and only 50,000 is available, how will it be split?
input: Section no 61  part (2) : In paying or setting off debts or liabilities pursuant to sub-section (1), if there are more than one creditor or claimant of the same priority order, the debt or claim shall be paid or set off pro rata basis from the assets bankrupted in proportion to the debt or claim of each creditor or claimant.
output: According to Section 61(2)... Rule: Creditors of the same priority receive payment on a pro rata basis proportional to their claims. Application/Conclusion: The total claims are 100,000 (10k+20k+70k). With 50,000 available, each creditor gets 50,000 × (their claim ÷ 100,000). So they would receive 5,000; 10,000; and 35,000 respectively.

instruction: My business partner and a creditor may have colluded to list fake transactions to grab our assets — what does law do to such a creditor?
input: Section no 62 . Debt of creditor who shows excess debt not to receive priority : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) of Section 61, if it is held that, by a collusion between a person likely to become a bankrupt and any creditor, and being guided by a malafide motive to cause loss to another creditor or claimant, more debts or claims have been shown from any transaction which has never happened nor been carried on, the debt or liability of such a creditor shall be paid or set off only after the debt or liability of other creditor or claimant is satisfied.
output: According to Section 62... Rule: Where collusion and malafide fabrication of debts are established, the colluding creditor's claim loses priority and will be paid only after other creditors' claims are satisfied. Application/Conclusion: If you can establish collusion and that the listed transactions never occurred, that creditor will be demoted in priority and paid only after genuine creditors have been satisfied.

instruction: Under which section is the priority order for paying debts in bankruptcy laid out? I need the exact reference.
input: Section no 61 . Priority order of paying debt or liability : (1) In carrying out or causing to be carried out the bankruptcy proceedings of the assets of a person pursuant to this Chapter, the debts to be paid or liabilities to be discharged by such a person shall be settled, on the basis of the following priority order, from the assets of such a person:
output: According to Section 61(1)... Rule: Section 61(1) sets out that debts/liabilities in bankruptcy are settled according to a specified priority order from the bankrupt's assets. Application/Conclusion: The priority order applicable to paying debts in bankruptcy is established under Section 61(1).

instruction: Short question: Can a third party's property be seized in the bankrupt's proceedings?
input:
Section no 63 . Property to be set aside : (1) Prior to effecting bankruptcy of the assets of a person pursuant to this Chapter, the following property shall be set aside and the bankruptcy proceedings shall be carried out from the remaining assets:
 Section no 63  clause (a) : Any property that remains as the personal property of a person other than one who is likely to become a bankrupt,
output: According to Section 63(1) and clause (a)... Rule: Property that remains the personal property of a person other than the one likely to become bankrupt must be set aside before bankruptcy proceedings proceed. Application/Conclusion: Third-party personal property should not be seized; it must be excluded from bankruptcy distribution and the proceedings must proceed from the remaining assets.

instruction: Help — informal: A creditor inflated the claim through a fake sale to his friend (the debtor). Will that claim get paid before mine?
input: Section no 62 . Debt of creditor who shows excess debt not to receive priority : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) of Section 61, if it is held that, by a collusion between a person likely to become a bankrupt and any creditor, and being guided by a malafide motive to cause loss to another creditor or claimant, more debts or claims have been shown from any transaction which has never happened nor been carried on, the debt or liability of such a creditor shall be paid or set off only after the debt or liability of other creditor or claimant is satisfied.
output: According to Section 62... Rule: A creditor who, through collusion with the debtor, shows excessive or fictitious debts with malafide intent will not receive priority. Their debt is paid only after other creditors' debts are satisfied. Application/Conclusion: If you can show the claim was fabricated in collusion, that creditor will be pushed to the end and will not be paid before you.

instruction: Can I keep using my maiden surname after marriage, or must I take my husband's name?
input: Section no 81 . Provision relating to use of surname by married woman : (1) A married woman may, after marriage, use the surname used by her father or mother or the surname of her husband or both the surnames.
output: According to Section 81, Rule: A married woman is permitted to use either the surname of her father or mother, the surname of her husband, or both surnames after marriage. Application/Conclusion: You may legally keep your maiden surname, adopt your husband's surname, or use both — the law gives you the choice.

instruction: If my husband says I must use his name in all official matters but I want to use my father's name, who is right?
input: Section no 81  part (2) : If a question arises as to the surname of a married woman, except as otherwise proved, she shall be deemed to have used the surname of her husband.
output: According to Section 81, Rule: Where a question arises about a married woman's surname, the default presumption (unless proved otherwise) is that she used her husband's surname. Application/Conclusion: If there is a dispute and you cannot prove you used another surname, authorities may presume you used your husband's surname; to avoid that, keep documentation showing continued use of your father's surname.

instruction: We divorced last month. Can I go back to using my father's surname?
input: Section no 81  part (3) : If the marriage of a woman who has used the surname of her husband is dissolved, she may, if she so desires, use the surname used by her father or mother.
output: According to Section 81, Rule: If a woman's marriage is dissolved and she had used her husband's surname, she may, if she wishes, resume using her father's or mother's surname. Application/Conclusion: Yes — following dissolution of your marriage you are legally allowed to revert to your parental surname if you choose.

instruction: In what situations is a matrimonial relationship considered terminated?
input:
Section no 82 . Matrimonial relationship deemed to be terminated : In any of the following circumstances, the matrimonial relationship between the husband and the wife shall be deemed to have been terminated:
 Section no 82  clause (a) : If marriage is annulled pursuant to Section 72 or 73,
 Section no 82  clause (b) : If marriage is dissolved according to law between husband and wife,
 Section no 82  clause (c) : If the wife concludes another marriage before effecting divorce pursuant to law.
output: According to Section 82, Rule: The matrimonial relationship is deemed terminated if (a) the marriage is annulled under Sections 72 or 73; (b) the marriage is dissolved according to law; or (c) the wife enters another marriage before obtaining a legal divorce. Application/Conclusion: If any of those events occurs in your case, the law treats the matrimonial relationship as ended.

instruction: Am I allowed to remarry? My previous marriage was legally dissolved.
input:
Section no 83 . Re-marriage may be concluded : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, a man or a woman may re marry in any of the following circumstances:
 Section no 83  clause (a) : If the matrimonial relationship between husband and wife is terminated pursuant to Section 82,
 Section no 83  clause (b) : If husband or wife dies,
 Section no 83  clause (c) : If husband and wife are separated upon partition in accordance with law. 50
output: According to Section 83, Rule: A person may remarry if the matrimonial relationship has been terminated under Section 82, or if a spouse has died, or if spouses are separated by lawful partition. Application/Conclusion: Since your previous marriage was legally dissolved (a Section 82 termination), you are permitted to remarry under the law.

instruction: My husband passed away last year. Can I marry someone else?
input: Section no 83  clause (b) : If husband or wife dies,
output: According to Section 83, Rule: Death of a spouse is a ground allowing remarriage. Application/Conclusion: Since your husband died, the matrimonial relationship ended and you are legally allowed to remarry.

instruction: We were separated by partition of property two years ago. Am I free to marry someone else now?
input: Section no 83  clause (c) : If husband and wife are separated upon partition in accordance with law. 50
output: According to Section 83, Rule: Separation of husband and wife by lawful partition is a circumstance permitting remarriage. Application/Conclusion: If your separation was effected through lawful partition, you may remarry under the statute.

instruction: If our marriage was annulled under Sections 72 or 73, can either of us remarry?
input: Section no 82  clause (a) : If marriage is annulled pursuant to Section 72 or 73,
output: According to Section 82, Rule: Annulment pursuant to Sections 72 or 73 is one of the circumstances that terminates the matrimonial relationship. Application/Conclusion: Because annulment ends the marital relationship under Section 82, either party may remarry as allowed by Section 83 (remarriage following termination).

instruction: I think my spouse took an action under this marriage chapter that harms me. How long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 84 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within three months after the date on which such act was done or action taken. 51 Chapter-2 Provisions Relating to Consequences of Marriage
output: According to Section 84, Rule: An aggrieved person must bring a lawsuit within three months from the date of the act or action taken under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: You generally have three months from when the harmful act occurred to file a case; act promptly to preserve your rights.

instruction: After we got married, are we legally husband and wife even if we haven't lived together yet?
input: Section no 85 . To be considered husband and wife : After the conclusion of marriage between a man and a woman, they shall, so long as such matrimonial relationship subsists, be considered each other’s husband and wife.
output: According to Section 85, Rule: Once marriage is concluded, the man and woman are considered husband and wife for as long as the matrimonial relationship subsists. Application/Conclusion: Yes — legally you are husband and wife after marriage is concluded, regardless of immediate cohabitation, as long as the marriage continues.

instruction: What duties do husband and wife owe to each other? Short answer.
input: Section no 86 . Relation and obligation of husband and wife : (1) The husband and wife must have mutual love and good faith.
output: According to Section 86, Rule: Husband and wife must have mutual love and good faith. Application/Conclusion: The law expects spouses to maintain a relationship founded on mutual affection and honest dealings.

instruction: Do we have to live together after marriage if one of us wants separate living arrangements?
