Application/Conclusion: Yes — a grandson or granddaughter is explicitly included among those who may be appointed guardian under the statutory priority.

instruction: Under which section does the law define 'To be considered guardian'?
input: Section no 135 . To be considered guardian : A person who is appointed or liable under this Chapter to protect the person, protection of rights and interest of an incompetent or quasi-competent person shall be considered to be a guardian.
output:
According to Section 135...
Rule: Section 135 defines who is to be considered a guardian — namely, a person appointed or liable under the Chapter to protect the person, rights, and interests of an incompetent or quasi-competent person.
Application/Conclusion: The definition of who is a guardian is set out in Section 135, so refer to Section 135 when determining whether someone qualifies as a guardian under this Chapter.

instruction: Can a ten-year-old choose their own guardian?
input: In the case of a person of sound mind and having attained ten years of age, a person chosen by him or her, Provided that in so choosing the guardian, a deed shall be executed to that effect and certified by the court.
output: According to Section 136(2)(b): Rule: A person of sound mind who has attained ten years of age may choose a person as their guardian, but the choice must be evidenced by a deed executed for that purpose and certified by the court. Application/Conclusion: If the ten-year-old (and is of sound mind) has a deed selecting a guardian and that deed is certified by the court, that selection is valid under the law.

instruction: I'm a minor from divorced parents — who is my guardian?
input: In the case of a minor of a couple whose matrimonial relationship has been extinguished in accordance with law, the father or mother who maintains him or her,
output: According to Section 136(2)(c): Rule: For a minor of parents whose matrimonial relationship has been legally extinguished, the parent who maintains the child is considered the guardian. Application/Conclusion: If your parents are divorced and one parent is maintaining you, that maintaining parent is legally your guardian.

instruction: If the first-priority guardian refuses or becomes incapable, who becomes guardian?
input: If any person who is in the first priority order declines to be a guardian, becomes of unsound mind or does not act in the capacity of a guardian, the person who is in the next priority order. Provided that if a person in the next order is to so become a guardian, the person shall get it certified by the court that he or she is the guardian.
output: According to Section 136(2)(d): Rule: If a person in the first priority order declines, becomes of unsound mind, or does not act as guardian, the person next in priority becomes the guardian; that person must obtain court certification that they are the guardian. Application/Conclusion: When the top-priority person cannot or will not serve, the next-in-line assumes guardianship but must get the court to certify their guardianship to be formally recognized.

instruction: Someone else started taking care of my uncle who is mentally incapacitated. Are they legally his guardian?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 136, if guardianship to an incompetent or quasi-competent person is provided by a person other than the one referred to in that Section, the person so 77 providing guardianship shall be considered to be a guardian of such a person. Provided that the person who so becomes a guardian shall get it certified by the court that he or she is the guardian.
output: According to Section 137: Rule: If a person not listed in Section 136 provides guardianship to an incompetent or quasi-competent person, that caregiver shall be considered the guardian, but must get court certification of that status. Application/Conclusion: The person caring for your uncle can be considered his guardian, but they should obtain court certification to formalize and secure their legal guardianship.

instruction: An orphanage says it's the child's guardian because the child lives there and has no relatives. Is that correct?
input: If a child, who is living in an organization, such as a child welfare house, orphanage, child home or children’s organization, registered pursuant to law with the object to have welfare of and protect rights and interests of children, has no other guardian, such an organization shall be considered to be his or her guardian.
output: According to Section 138(1): Rule: A registered organization (child welfare house, orphanage, child home or children’s organization) whose object is child welfare and protection becomes the guardian of a child living there if the child has no other guardian. Application/Conclusion: If the child truly has no other guardian and the organization is properly registered with the stated object, the organization is legally considered the child's guardian.

instruction: Who can sign papers or make decisions for a child living in a registered child home?
input: In doing any act or taking any action on behalf of a minor living in an organization referred to in sub-section (1), the chief of such an organization shall do such an act or take such an action. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter and Chapter-7 of Part-3, the term “chief” means the chief executive oﬀicer of that organization or the chairperson, general manager, managing director or other oﬀicer acting in that capacity.
output: According to Section 138(2): Rule: The chief of the organization shall perform acts or take actions on behalf of a minor living in that organization; 'chief' is defined to include the CEO, chairperson, general manager, managing director or equivalent officer. Application/Conclusion: Decisions and formal acts for the child should be carried out by the organization's chief (as defined), who is the authorized representative for that child.

instruction: In plain language, what does 'chief' mean in these rules?
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter and Chapter-7 of Part-3, the term “chief” means the chief executive oﬀicer of that organization or the chairperson, general manager, managing director or other oﬀicer acting in that capacity.
output: According to Section 138(2) (Explanation): Rule: 'Chief' refers to the organization's top executive — e.g., the chief executive officer, chairperson, general manager, managing director, or another officer acting in that role. Application/Conclusion: When the law says the 'chief' must act for a minor in the organization, it means the organization's top executive or equivalent officer should perform those duties.

instruction: Can a court appoint a guardian even if Section 136 already lists who should be guardian?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 136 or 137, the court may, in the following circumstances, appoint a particular person as the guardian, specifying the reason therefor:
output: According to Section 139(1): Rule: Despite Sections 136 or 137, the court has authority to appoint a specific person as guardian in certain circumstances, and must specify reasons for the appointment. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the court can appoint a guardian even when Sections 136 or 137 identify potential guardians, provided the court follows the specified procedure and records reasons for its appointment.

instruction: Our ward committee filed to appoint a guardian because the father declined. Is that provided for in the law?
input: If the concerned ward committee of the concerned Local Level files a petition in the court for the appointment of guardian in cases where any person declines to be a guardian pursuant to Section 136, 78
output: According to Section 139(1)(a): Rule: If a person declines to be a guardian under Section 136, the concerned ward committee of the Local Level may file a petition in court requesting appointment of a guardian. Application/Conclusion: The ward committee is expressly authorized to petition the court to appoint a guardian when an intended guardian has declined under Section 136.

instruction: Can someone other than the ward committee initiate guardian appointment proceedings?
input: If the stakeholder files a petition in the court for the appointment of guardian.
output: According to Section 139(1)(b): Rule: A stakeholder may file a petition in court for the appointment of a guardian. Application/Conclusion: Besides the ward committee, stakeholders are permitted to petition the court to have a guardian appointed.

instruction: When the court appoints a guardian, what must it consider about the person needing guardianship?
input: In appointing a guardian pursuant to sub-section (1), the court shall consider whether or not the rights, interests or protection of such incompetent or quasi-competent person may be secured.
output: According to Section 139(2): Rule: The court must consider whether the rights, interests or protection of the incompetent or quasi-competent person will be secured by the appointment. Application/Conclusion: The court's appointment decision must be guided by whether the proposed guardianship will adequately protect and secure the ward's rights and interests.

instruction: Does the court need the would-be guardian's consent before appointing them?
input: In appointing a guardian pursuant to sub-section (1), the court shall also obtain the consent of the person to be appointed as the guardian.
output: According to Section 139(3): Rule: The court must obtain the consent of the person whom it intends to appoint as guardian. Application/Conclusion: A person cannot be appointed by the court as guardian without first giving their consent; the court must secure that consent before finalizing the appointment.

instruction: After a guardian is appointed, does the court have to notify anyone?
input: After appointing a guardian pursuant to sub-section (1), the court shall give a written notice thereof to the person to be guardian and the Local Level.
output: According to Section 139(4): Rule: After appointing a guardian, the court must give written notice of the appointment to the person appointed as guardian and to the Local Level. Application/Conclusion: Once the court appoints a guardian, it is obliged to send written notice both to the guardian and to the Local Level, ensuring local authorities are informed.

instruction: If someone is providing care and acting as guardian but hasn't gone to court, are they protected as guardian?
input: Provided that the person who so becomes a guardian shall get it certified by the court that he or she is the guardian.
output: According to Section 137: Rule: A person who becomes a guardian by providing guardianship must get their guardianship certified by the court. Application/Conclusion: While caregiving may make someone the de facto guardian, they should obtain court certification to formalize and secure their legal status as guardian.

instruction: If the next-in-line wants to take guardianship after the first declines, do they need any court action?
input: Provided that if a person in the next order is to so become a guardian, the person shall get it certified by the court that he or she is the guardian.
output: According to Section 136(2)(d): Rule: A person in the next priority order who is to become guardian must obtain court certification of their guardianship. Application/Conclusion: The next-in-line must apply for and obtain court certification to be formally recognized as the guardian.

instruction: A child lives in a registered child welfare house but their father is claiming to maintain them. Does the organization still become guardian automatically?
input: If a child, who is living in an organization, such as a child welfare house, orphanage, child home or children’s organization, registered pursuant to law with the object to have welfare of and protect rights and interests of children, has no other guardian, such an organization shall be considered to be his or her guardian.
output: According to Section 138(1): Rule: An organization becomes guardian only if the child living there has no other guardian. Application/Conclusion: If the father is an existing guardian (i.e., the child has another guardian), the organization does not automatically become the guardian; the organization is guardian only where the child has no other guardian.

instruction: Can a stakeholder ask the court to appoint a guardian and what happens then?
input: If the stakeholder files a petition in the court for the appointment of guardian.
output: According to Section 139(1)(b): Rule: A stakeholder may file a petition in court requesting appointment of a guardian. Application/Conclusion: A stakeholder can initiate court proceedings to have a guardian appointed; the court will then consider the petition, ensure the ward's rights and interests are secured, obtain the would-be guardian's consent, and issue written notice upon appointment.

instruction: Can I demand the guardian hand over the account books now that I turned 18?
input: part (2) : The guardian shall submit the books and accounts maintained pursuant to sub-section (1) and the inventory proving the ownership of that property to the incompetent or quasi-competent person within one year after the date on which that person has attained majority pursuant to law or the date on which that person has notified in writing the court that he or she is competent to carry out business. 81
output: According to Section 144(2): The guardian must submit the books, accounts and inventory proving ownership to the formerly incompetent/quasi-competent person within one year after that person attains majority or after that person has notified the court in writing that they are competent. Therefore, since you have attained majority, the guardian is legally required to hand over those records to you within one year of your attaining majority (or sooner if you notify the court of competency).

instruction: I told the court yesterday that I'm competent — how long before the guardian must give me the records?
input: part (2) : The guardian shall submit the books and accounts maintained pursuant to sub-section (1) and the inventory proving the ownership of that property to the incompetent or quasi-competent person within one year after the date on which that person has attained majority pursuant to law or the date on which that person has notified in writing the court that he or she is competent to carry out business. 81
output: According to Section 144(2): The guardian must submit the books, accounts and inventory proving ownership within one year after the date on which the person has notified the court in writing that he or she is competent. Therefore, from the date you filed written notice of competency, the guardian has up to one year to deliver those records to you.

instruction: My brother died while under guardianship. When should the guardian give us the inventory?
input: Section no 144  part (3) : If an incompetent or quasi-competent person dies when he or she was under guardianship, the guardian shall submit the books and accounts and the inventory proving ownership of that property referred to in sub-section (1) to that person’s nearest successor within six months after the date of his or her death.
output: According to Section 144(3): If the ward dies while under guardianship, the guardian must submit the books, accounts and inventory proving ownership to the deceased person’s nearest successor within six months of the date of death. Therefore, the guardian is obliged to provide those documents to the successors within six months from your brother’s death.

instruction: Can my guardian file or defend a lawsuit for me?
input: Section no 145 . Power to institute legal action or defend case : The guardian may, for the protection of the rights, interests of an incompetent or quasi competent person under his or her guardianship, institute a legal action against such a person or defend a case filed against him or her. Provided that the guardian is not allowed to so renounce a claim or plea in relation to a case instituted upon the incompetent or quasi-competent person being its plaintiff or defendant or execute a deed of compromise in any case as to cause an adverse effect to him or her.
output: According to Section 145: The guardian may institute legal action or defend cases on behalf of the incompetent or quasi-competent person to protect their rights and interests. However, the guardian is not allowed to renounce a claim or plea or execute a compromise that would adversely affect the ward. Therefore, your guardian can sue or defend for you, but cannot abandon claims or settle in a way that harms your interests.

instruction: Can the guardian settle a pending case by compromise even if it hurts the ward?
input: Section no 145 . Power to institute legal action or defend case : The guardian may, for the protection of the rights, interests of an incompetent or quasi competent person under his or her guardianship, institute a legal action against such a person or defend a case filed against him or her. Provided that the guardian is not allowed to so renounce a claim or plea in relation to a case instituted upon the incompetent or quasi-competent person being its plaintiff or defendant or execute a deed of compromise in any case as to cause an adverse effect to him or her.
output: According to Section 145: While a guardian may institute or defend legal actions for the ward, the guardian is expressly prohibited from renouncing claims or pleas or executing a deed of compromise that would cause an adverse effect to the ward. Therefore, the guardian cannot lawfully settle by compromise if that settlement would harm the ward’s interests.

instruction: Can my guardian sign contracts on my behalf?
input: Section no 146 . Power to act on behalf of incompetent or quasicompetent : person: Subject to the provisions contained elsewhere in this Chapter, the guardian may carry out such act on behalf of the incompetent or quasi-competent person as may be carried out by that person according to law.
output: According to Section 146: The guardian may perform acts on behalf of the incompetent or quasi-competent person that the person themselves could legally perform. Therefore, if the contract is an act your competent self could lawfully do, the guardian can sign it on your behalf, subject to any other provisions in the Chapter.

instruction: My guardianship order specifically forbids selling property. Can the guardian still sell my land?
input: Section no 147 . Act may be carried out only in consonance with terms : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a person is designated as the guardian for an incompetent or quasi competent person with specification of certain terms, such a guardian shall have the authority to carry out acts only in consonance with such terms. 82
output: According to Section 147: If the guardian was appointed with specified terms, the guardian’s authority is limited to acts consonant with those terms. Therefore, if the appointment expressly forbids sale of property, the guardian does not have authority to sell your land beyond those specified terms.

instruction: How can a guardianship be terminated? I want to know my options.
input: Section no 148 . Termination of guardianship : (1) A guardianship shall be deemed to be terminated in any of the following circumstances:
output: According to Section 148(1): Guardianship is terminated under the circumstances listed in the subsequent clauses of that provision. Therefore, to know the specific grounds you must look at the enumerated clauses (a)–(d), which set out the situations that end a guardianship.

instruction: If I file a petition saying I can no longer be guardian, will the court end the guardianship?
input: Section no 148  clause (a) : If a petition filed by the guardian stating that he or she is unable to be a guardian is accepted by the court,
output: According to Section 148(a): If the guardian files a petition stating they are unable to continue as guardian and the court accepts that petition, guardianship is terminated. Therefore, if you petition the court and the court accepts your inability to continue, the guardianship will end.

instruction: Does guardianship end automatically if the ward becomes capable of managing their affairs?
input: Section no 148  clause (c) : If the incompetent or quasi-competent person becomes a competent,
output: According to Section 148(c): Guardianship is terminated if the formerly incompetent or quasi-competent person becomes competent. Therefore, once the person attains competency, the guardianship ends under this clause.

instruction: Can the ward ask the court to remove the guardian and end the guardianship?
input: Section no 148  clause (d) : If, at the request of the incompetent or quasi competent person under guardianship, the court removes the guardian.
output: According to Section 148(d): Guardianship is terminated if the court removes the guardian at the request of the incompetent or quasi-competent person. Therefore, the ward may apply to the court to have the guardian removed; if the court removes the guardian, the guardianship ends.

instruction: If the guardianship ends but both guardian and ward are still alive, does the old guardian still have duties?
input: Section no 148  part (2) : If a guardianship is terminated pursuant to subsection Section no 148  part (1) : and the person who was the guardian and the person who was under guardianship are surviving, the person who had worked as guardian shall continue to maintain (palan poshan) and take care of (herbichar) the incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship until another guardian is appointed.
output: According to Section 148(2): If guardianship terminates under the listed grounds and both the former guardian and the ward are still living, the former guardian must continue to maintain and care for the ward until another guardian is appointed. Therefore, the previous guardian retains caretaking obligations until a successor guardian is in place.

instruction: We have a court case where my guardian must appear. Guardianship ended last week — are we out of time to appear?
input: Section no 148  part (3) : If a guardianship is terminated pursuant to subsection Section no 148  part (1) : , the statute of limitation, time-limit or appointed date for appearance in relation to any legal proceedings required to be carried out by the guardian pursuant to this Chapter shall not be deemed to have been expired, from the date on which the guardianship is so terminated until another guardian is appointed.
output: According to Section 148(3): When guardianship is terminated, statute of limitations, deadlines or dates for appearance in legal proceedings that the guardian was required to carry out shall not be considered expired from the date of termination until another guardian is appointed. Therefore, the deadlines are effectively preserved (paused) during the interval until a new guardian is appointed, so you are not deemed to have lost time to act solely because guardianship ended.

instruction: My guardian is appointed with strict terms (only medical decisions). Can he bring a civil suit on my behalf about property?
input: Section no 147 . Act may be carried out only in consonance with terms : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a person is designated as the guardian for an incompetent or quasi competent person with specification of certain terms, such a guardian shall have the authority to carry out acts only in consonance with such terms. 82
output: According to Section 147: A guardian appointed with specified terms only has authority to act in accordance with those terms. Therefore, if the appointment limits the guardian to medical decisions, he would not have authority to initiate civil litigation about property beyond those specified medical-related powers.

instruction: Is there a section that explicitly says a guardian can act on behalf of an incompetent person?
input: Section no 146 . Power to act on behalf of incompetent or quasicompetent : person: Subject to the provisions contained elsewhere in this Chapter, the guardian may carry out such act on behalf of the incompetent or quasi-competent person as may be carried out by that person according to law.
output: According to Section 146: The guardian may carry out acts on behalf of the incompetent or quasi-competent person that the person could themselves perform according to law, subject to other chapter provisions. Therefore, Section 146 is the provision that grants the general power for guardians to act on the ward’s behalf.

instruction: Can a curator sell the immovable property of the person under curatorship to themselves or family?
input: Section no 163 . Transfer of title, ipso facto to be void : If a curator sells any immovable property belonging to the person under his or her curatorship to himself or herself or to any of his or her family members, with ulterior motive to disentitling such a person to that property or the title thereto happens to be transferred to him or her in any manner, such transfer of title shall, ipso facto, be void.
output: According to Section 163... Rule: Any sale by a curator of immovable property belonging to the person under curatorship to the curator or the curator's family, done with an ulterior motive to disentitle the person, renders the transfer of title ipso facto void. Application/Conclusion: If a curator sold such property to themself or a family member for the purpose of depriving the protected person of that property, that transfer has no legal effect and can be declared void.

instruction: My neighbor says the court can remove a curator if someone complains. True?
input: part (3) : If a complaint is filed with allegation that the curator has failed to look after of and protect the property pursuant to sub section (1), the court may remove the concerned person from curatorship.
output: According to Section 162(3)... Rule: Where a complaint alleges that a curator failed to look after and protect the property as required, the court has the power to remove that person from curatorship. Application/Conclusion: If there is a credible complaint that your curator neglected protection/management duties under subsection (1), you (or an interested person) can ask the court to remove the curator and the court may do so.

instruction: When does curatorship automatically end because of the minor's age?
input: Section no 164  clause (a) : In the case of a minor, if he or she attains eighteen years of age,
output: According to Section 164(a)... Rule: Curatorship for a minor terminates ipso facto when the minor attains eighteen years of age. Application/Conclusion: If the person under curatorship is a minor and has reached 18, the curatorship ends automatically and the curator no longer holds that status.

instruction: My brother was under curatorship because of unsound mind. He is improving — does curatorship stop?
input: Section no 164  clause (b) : In the case of a person of unsound mind, if he or she becomes of sound mind, 89
output: According to Section 164(b)... Rule: Curatorship for a person of unsound mind is terminated ipso facto when that person becomes of sound mind. Application/Conclusion: If your brother is now of sound mind, the curatorship ceases automatically; the curator must no longer act in that capacity.

instruction: If the child's parents take custody, does the curatorship end?
input: Section no 164  clause (c) : If custody of the minor is taken by the mother or father or both,
output: According to Section 164(c)... Rule: Curatorship terminates ipso facto if the minor's custody is taken by the mother, father, or both. Application/Conclusion: If the parents legally take custody of the minor, the existing curatorship ends automatically and the curator must cease.

instruction: A guardian was just appointed for the ward. Does that end the curator's role?
input: Section no 164  clause (d) : If the guardian of a minor or person of unsound mind is appointed,
output: According to Section 164(d)... Rule: Curatorship is terminated ipso facto when a guardian is appointed for the minor or person of unsound mind. Application/Conclusion: Once a guardian is lawfully appointed, the curator's role ends automatically and responsibilities transfer to the guardian.

instruction: If the court removes someone from curatorship under Section 162(3), is the curatorship terminated automatically?
input: Section no 164  clause (e) : If the court removes a person from curatorship pursuant to sub-section (3) of Section 162,
output: According to Section 164(e)... Rule: Curatorship is deemed terminated ipso facto if the court removes the curator under Section 162(3). Application/Conclusion: If the court has removed the curator following a proper complaint under 162(3), the curatorship ends automatically and the removed person no longer holds curatorship powers.

instruction: What if the curator doesn't meet the legal qualifications — does curatorship keep going?
input: Section no 164  clause (f) : If the curator has no qualification referred to in Section 158,
output: According to Section 164(f)... Rule: Curatorship terminates ipso facto if the curator lacks the qualifications required by Section 158. Application/Conclusion: If it turns out the curator does not meet the qualification criteria in Section 158, the curatorship ends automatically and the person must stop acting as curator.

instruction: Does curatorship end if either the curator or the person under curatorship dies?
input: Section no 164  clause (g) : If the curator or the person under curatorship dies.
output: According to Section 164(g)... Rule: Curatorship is terminated ipso facto upon the death of either the curator or the person under curatorship. Application/Conclusion: If either dies, the curatorship automatically ceases and any custody or responsibilities will need to be addressed by the court or by law.

instruction: If curatorship ends, do I get my property straight away?
input: Section no 164  part (2) : If curatorship is terminated pursuant to sub-section (1), the curator shall immediately return to the concerned person the property taken into custody in the capacity of curator.
output: According to Section 164(2)... Rule: When curatorship is terminated under subsection (1), the curator must immediately return the property taken into custody to the concerned person. Application/Conclusion: Once curatorship has ended for any listed reason, the curator is legally required to give back the property without delay to the person who had been under curatorship.

instruction: I need to go abroad and want someone to look after my property temporarily. Can I hand it over to a curator?
input: Section no 165 . Custody of property may be handed over : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a person is unable to protect and manage the property under his or her title, ownership or possession on his or her own, for the reason that he or she has to go elsewhere by leaving the place where he or she resides, he or she may appoint any person as a curator to that end and hand over the custody of such property to that other person.
output: According to Section 165(1)... Rule: A person who cannot protect/manage their property because they must go elsewhere may appoint a person as curator and hand over custody of the property. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you are leaving your residence and cannot manage the property, you can appoint someone as curator and give them custody to protect and manage it until you return.

instruction: If I hand over my house to someone as curator, must they return it when I ask?
input: Section no 165  part (2) : If the custody of property is handed over to any person pursuant to sub-section (1), the person taking the custody of such property shall protect and manage the property and return the property to the person handing over its custody as and when the handing over person so requires. 90
output: According to Section 165(2)... Rule: A person who takes custody of property as curator must protect and manage it and return it when the handing-over person demands. Application/Conclusion: If you hand your house to a curator under 165(1), that curator is legally obliged to safeguard it and must return the property whenever you request it.

instruction: Do I need a court certificate if I become a curator under Sections 153, 154 or 165?
input: Section no 166 . Requirement to certification by court : One who becomes a curator pursuant to Sections 153, 154 and 165 shall get that matter certified by the court.
output: According to Section 166... Rule: Anyone who becomes a curator under Sections 153, 154, or 165 must obtain court certification of that matter. Application/Conclusion: If you assume curatorship under those sections, you must get the appointment certified by the court to formalize your status.

instruction: Do other provisions like Sections 144–151 apply to curators and wards?
input: Section no 167 . Application of other provisions : The provisions contained in Sections 144, 145, 146, 147, 149, 150 and 151 shall also apply mutatis mutandis to the curator and the person under curatorship.
output: According to Section 167... Rule: Provisions in Sections 144, 145, 146, 147, 149, 150 and 151 apply mutatis mutandis to curators and persons under curatorship. Application/Conclusion: Those listed sections (with necessary adjustments) govern relationships and duties between curator and ward, so the rights and obligations in those sections extend to curatorship situations.

instruction: I discovered today my curator made an improper sale last year. How long do I have to sue?
input: Section no 168 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date of knowledge of such an act or action. 91 Chapter-8 Provisions Relating to Adoption
output: According to Section 168... Rule: An aggrieved person must bring a lawsuit within six months from the date they learn of the act or action under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: Since you only discovered the improper sale today, you have six months from today to file a lawsuit challenging that act.

instruction: If I accept a child as mine, is that child legally adopted automatically?
input: Section no 169 . To be deemed adopted son or adopted daughter : If a person accepts a son or daughter of another person as his or her son or daughter, such a son or a daughter shall be deemed to be an adopted son or daughter.
output: According to Section 169... Rule: If a person accepts another's child as their son or daughter, that child is deemed to be an adopted son or daughter. Application/Conclusion: By accepting the child in that manner, the law treats the child as adopted; you should still consider formal procedures, but legally the acceptance creates the status under this provision.

instruction: My uncle, who is curator, sold my land to his brother claiming I wouldn't find out. Can I void that transfer?
input: Section no 163 . Transfer of title, ipso facto to be void : If a curator sells any immovable property belonging to the person under his or her curatorship to himself or herself or to any of his or her family members, with ulterior motive to disentitling such a person to that property or the title thereto happens to be transferred to him or her in any manner, such transfer of title shall, ipso facto, be void.
output: According to Section 163... Rule: A transfer of immovable property by a curator to themselves or family, carried out with an ulterior motive to disentitle the ward, is ipso facto void. Application/Conclusion: If your uncle sold your land to his brother with the intent to deprive you, that transfer is legally void and you can challenge it to have the title set aside.

instruction: Short: Can a curator keep property after curatorship ends?
input: Section no 164  part (2) : If curatorship is terminated pursuant to sub-section (1), the curator shall immediately return to the concerned person the property taken into custody in the capacity of curator.
output: According to Section 164(2)... Rule: Upon termination of curatorship under subsection (1), the curator must immediately return the property. Application/Conclusion: No — the curator must return the property right away once curatorship has ended.

instruction: I want to appoint someone for temporary custody while I travel — do I need to go to court afterward?
input: Section no 166 . Requirement to certification by court : One who becomes a curator pursuant to Sections 153, 154 and 165 shall get that matter certified by the court.
output: According to Section 166... Rule: A person who becomes a curator under Sections 153, 154, or 165 must get that appointment certified by the court. Application/Conclusion: Yes — after you appoint someone under Section 165, that curatorship should be certified by the court to formalize and validate the arrangement.

instruction: I want to adopt a child. What is the first legal step I must take?
input: Procedures for effecting adoption : (1) If a person is desirous of adopting a child, he or she shall make a petition to the concerned court, along with a duly executed deed of adoption, in fulfillment of the legal requirements.
output: According to Section 177(1): Rule: A person desiring to adopt must make a petition to the concerned court and submit a duly executed deed of adoption satisfying legal requirements. Application/Conclusion: You must file a petition at the district court and attach a properly executed deed of adoption that meets statutory requirements before the court can consider your adoption.

instruction: If the court is satisfied with my adoption documents, what will it do?
input: Section no 177  part (2) : If, upon inquiring into the deed of adoption received pursuant to sub-section (1), the concerned district court finds that permission may be given to the petitioner for adoption, it shall issue 96 an order granting permission for adoption and shall authenticate such deed.
output: According to Section 177(2): Rule: When the district court, after inquiry into the deed of adoption, finds permission may be given, it issues an order granting adoption permission and authenticates the deed. Application/Conclusion: If your petition and deed satisfy the court after inquiry, the court will issue an order approving the adoption and will authenticate the deed, making the adoption legally recognized.

instruction: What happens if the court refuses my adoption petition?
input: Section no 177  part (3) : If, upon making inquiry pursuant to sub-section (2), the court finds that permission cannot be given to the petitioner for adoption, it shall issue an order accordingly and give information thereof to the petitioner.
output: According to Section 177(3): Rule: If the court, after inquiry, finds permission cannot be given, it must issue an order denying permission and inform the petitioner. Application/Conclusion: If the court determines you do not meet the requirements or there are other reasons, it will formally deny the adoption by order and notify you of that decision.

instruction: Will an adopted child have the same legal rights as my biological child?
input: Section no 178 . Entitlements and rights of adopted son or daughter : (1) The entitlements, rights, obligations and responsibilities of an adopted son or daughter shall be the same as that of a biological son or daughter of the adoptive person.
output: According to Section 178(1): Rule: An adopted child's entitlements, rights, obligations and responsibilities are the same as those of a biological child of the adoptive person. Application/Conclusion: Legally, an adopted child holds equal status to your biological child in terms of rights and responsibilities toward the adoptive parents.

instruction: If I adopt, then later have a biological child, does that affect the adopted child's status?
input: Section no 178  part (2) : Even if a son or daughter is born to a person who has already adopted a person, the equal status of such adopted son or adopted daughter to that of biological son or daughter shall not be prejudiced thereby.
output: According to Section 178(2): Rule: The birth of a biological child after adoption does not prejudice the equal status of the adopted child compared to the biological child. Application/Conclusion: Your later-born biological child will not reduce or change the adopted child's equal legal status—both remain equal under the law.

instruction: Can an adopted child take my surname?
input: Section no 179 . Surname of adopted son or daughter : An adopted son or daughter may use the surname of either or both of the adoptive father and mother. Provided that
output: According to Section 179: Rule: An adopted child may use the surname of either or both adoptive parents. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the adopted child may adopt your surname, either yours alone, your spouse's, or both, according to their or your choice.

instruction: Can the adopted child still use their biological surname if they want?
input: Section no 179  part (1) : If an adopted son or daughter so desires, he or she may use also the surname of his or her biological father or mother.
output: According to Section 179(1): Rule: An adopted child may, if they desire, also use the surname of their biological father or mother. Application/Conclusion: The adopted person retains the option to use their original family surname in addition to or instead of the adoptive surname if they wish.

instruction: If the adoption is annulled later, what surname will the adopted person have?
input: Section no 179  part (2) : If the adoption is annulled, his or her surname shall be that of his or her biological father or mother.
output: According to Section 179(2): Rule: Upon annulment of adoption, the person's surname shall be that of their biological father or mother. Application/Conclusion: If the adoption is annulled, the adopted person reverts to using their biological parent's surname as their legal surname.

instruction: Can an adopted child claim a share in their biological parents' property after adoption?
input: Section no 180 . Not allowed to claim partition share of father and mother : An adopted son or daughter shall not be entitled to claim partition share in the property belonging to his or her biological father and mother. 97
output: According to Section 180: Rule: An adopted child is not entitled to claim a partition share in property of their biological parents. Application/Conclusion: After adoption, the adopted person cannot demand inheritance or partition share from their biological parents' property under this provision.

instruction: What if the adoption is annulled — can the person then claim their biological parents' property?
input: Section no 180  part (1) : If the adoption is annulled, he or she may claim partition share in the property belonging to his or her biological father and mother,
output: According to Section 180(1): Rule: If adoption is annulled, the person may claim a partition share in their biological parents' property. Application/Conclusion: If an adopted person's adoption is later annulled, they regain the right to claim partition shares from their biological parents' property.

instruction: I received my biological parents' share before being adopted. Can I still keep it after adoption?
input: Section no 180  part (2) : If an adopted son or daughter has already obtained his or her partition share at the time of effecting adoption, he or she may receive such property as well.
output: According to Section 180(2): Rule: If the person had already obtained their partition share before the adoption, they may retain and receive that property. Application/Conclusion: If you were already given your partition share from biological parents before adoption, the adoption does not force you to return it—you may keep that property.

instruction: What duties does an adoptive parent have toward the adopted child — like schooling and healthcare?
input: Section no 181  clause (a) : To make arrangements for the maintenance, health care, sports, entertainment and proper education of the adopted son or daughter according to his or her reputation and capacity as if he or she were his or her biological son or daughter,
output: According to Section 181(a): Rule: The adoptive parent must arrange for maintenance, health care, sports, entertainment, and proper education for the adopted child according to their reputation and capacity, just as for a biological child. Application/Conclusion: You are legally required to provide for the adopted child's basic needs, healthcare, recreation and education to the same standard you would for a biological child, considering your means and standing.

instruction: Apart from maintenance, what other obligation must an adoptive person perform regarding the adopted child's rights?
input: Section no 181  clause (b) : To protect the rights and interests of the adopted son or daughter,
output: According to Section 181(b): Rule: The adoptive person must protect the rights and interests of the adopted child. Application/Conclusion: Beyond material support, you have a legal duty to safeguard the adopted child's rights and interests—meaning you should act to defend their legal, social and personal welfare.

instruction: Is there any authority adoptive parents are supposed to exercise under other provisions?
input: Section no 181  clause (c) : To exercise the authority as referred to in Chapter5 of this Part.
output: According to Section 181(c): Rule: Adoptive parents must exercise the authority provided for in Chapter 5 of this Part. Application/Conclusion: You are expected to exercise parental authority in accordance with the rules set out in Chapter 5 of the same Part (the statute), so refer to Chapter 5 for details of that authority and how it should be applied.

instruction: If I don't fulfill my duties as adoptive parent, can the adopted child leave and claim a share?
input: Section no 181  part (2) : If the adoptive person does not fulfill the obligations under sub-section (1), the adopted son or daughter may live separately by obtaining his or her partition share.
output: According to Section 181(2): Rule: If the adoptive person fails to fulfill obligations, the adopted child may live separately and obtain their partition share. Application/Conclusion: If you neglect the duties listed in Section 181(1), the adopted child has the legal right to live apart from you and claim their partition share to support themselves.

instruction: What responsibilities does the adopted child have toward their adoptive parents?
input:
Section no 182 . Obligations of adopted son or daughter : The obligations of the adopted son or daughter shall be as follows:
 Section no 182  clause (a) : To make arrangements for the maintenance, health care and care of the adoptive person according to 98 his or her reputation and capacity as if such person were his or her natural father or mother,
output: According to Section 182(a): Rule: The adopted child must arrange for maintenance, health care and care of the adoptive person according to the adoptive person's reputation and capacity, as if they were their natural parent. Application/Conclusion: The adopted child has a reciprocal duty to care for and support their adoptive parent in line with the parent's status and the child's capacity—similar to obligations toward a natural parent.

instruction: Quick — can my adopted child use both my and my spouse's surname, and also keep their original surname if they want?
input:
Section no 179 . Surname of adopted son or daughter : An adopted son or daughter may use the surname of either or both of the adoptive father and mother. Provided that
 Section no 179  part (1) : If an adopted son or daughter so desires, he or she may use also the surname of his or her biological father or mother.
output: According to Section 179 and Section 179(1): Rule: An adopted child may use the surname of either or both adoptive parents, and may also use their biological parent's surname if they so desire. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the adopted child can legally use your surname, your spouse's, both, and still has the option to use their biological surname if they wish.

instruction: Can a body corporate become the curator of a person who has no guardian?
input:
. Body corporate to become curator : (1) If any person
who has no guardian under Chapter-6 of this Part is under the supervision,
protection or custody of a body corporate, such a body corporate shall be the
curator of such a person.
output:
According to Section 156(1)...
Rule: If a person has no guardian under Chapter-6 and is under the supervision, protection or custody of a body corporate, that body corporate shall be the curator of that person.
Application/Conclusion: If the person you mention has no guardian under Chapter-6 and is under a body corporate's supervision, that body corporate becomes the curator by operation of Section 156(1).

instruction: If a body corporate is made curator, who actually exercises the curator's authority?
input:
Section no 156  part (2) : If a body corporate referred to in sub-section (1)
becomes a curator, the chief of such a body corporate shall exercise the authority
of a curator.
output:
According to Section 156(2)...
Rule: When a body corporate becomes curator, the chief of that body corporate exercises the authority of the curator.
Application/Conclusion: If a body corporate is appointed curator in your case, its chief (head) is the person who legally performs the curator's duties and exercises curator authority.

instruction: Who can ask the court to appoint a curator when there's no guardian and no one acting as curator?
input:
Section no 157 . Court may appoint curator : (1) If any person has no
guardian under Chapter-6 of this Part or no one acts as his or her curator, the
concerned ward committee of the Local Level may file a petition, stating the
details thereof, in the court for the appointment of a curator.
output:
According to Section 157(1)...
Rule: If someone has no guardian or no one is acting as their curator, the concerned ward committee of the Local Level may file a petition in court to appoint a curator.
Application/Conclusion: If there is nobody serving as guardian or curator for the person you describe, the local ward committee is the authorized party to petition the court to have a curator appointed.

instruction: What must the ward committee include when filing a petition to appoint a curator?
input:
Section no 157  part (2) : In filing a petition pursuant to sub-section (1), the
concerned ward committee of the Local Level shall set out the names, surnames,
addresses and professions of the potential persons who could be appointed as
the curator and also submit, along with the petition, a deed of consent given by
such potential persons to act as the curator.
output:
According to Section 157(2)...
Rule: The ward committee must list the names, surnames, addresses and professions of potential curators and submit a deed of consent from those potential persons with the petition.
Application/Conclusion: When your ward committee files for a curator, it must provide those identifying details for nominees and include each nominee's written consent; otherwise the petition will be missing required information under Section 157(2).

instruction: If the ward committee submits several names and consents, does the court have to appoint one of them?
input:
Section no 157  part (3) : If a petition is filed pursuant to sub-section (1),
the court shall make an order to appoint any one appropriate person, out of the persons whose names are submitted pursuant to sub section (2), as the curator.
output:
According to Section 157(3)...
Rule: Where the petition contains the names submitted under subsection (2), the court shall appoint one appropriate person from among those submitted as the curator.
Application/Conclusion: If the ward committee followed Section 157(2) and submitted names and consents, the court is required to choose and appoint one of those submitted persons as curator rather than appointing someone outside that list.

instruction: Can anyone become a curator, or are there restrictions?
input:
Section no 158 . Qualifications of curator : Any person other than a person
who is disqualified for being a guardian pursuant to Section 141 may become a
curator. 87
output:
According to Section 158...
Rule: Any person may become a curator except someone who is disqualified from being a guardian under Section 141.
Application/Conclusion: You can be appointed curator unless you fall into the categories that Section 141 uses to disqualify guardians; Section 158 bars those same disqualified persons from being curators.

instruction: What are the curator's duties regarding the property of the person under their care?
input:
Section no 159 . Curator to take custody of property : (1) The curator
shall take custody of, manage and operate, the property belonging to the person
under his or her curatorship.
Section no 159  part (2) : The curator shall arrange for the maintenance,
education and medical treatment of the person under his or her curatorship, to
the extent possible in view of his or her capacity, from the property taken into
custody by him or her.
output:
According to Section 159(1)-(2)...
Rule: The curator must take custody of, manage and operate the ward's property and use that property, to the extent possible, to provide for the ward's maintenance, education and medical treatment.
Application/Conclusion: If you become curator, you are legally required to take charge of the person's property and manage it so as to fund their upkeep, schooling and medical needs insofar as the property allows.

instruction: Can a curator spend income from the ward's property for the ward's upkeep and education?
input:
Section no 160 . Power to use property : A person who becomes a curator
may spend all the returns obtained from the property under his or her custody
for the maintenance, health of the person under his or her curatorship and for
the education of such a person, if he or she is a minor.
output:
According to Section 160...
Rule: A curator may spend all returns from the property in their custody for the ward's maintenance, health, and, if the ward is a minor, for education.
Application/Conclusion: As curator you are permitted to use the income generated by the ward's property to pay for their daily needs, medical care, and schooling (if the ward is a minor).

instruction: My ward has little movable property. Can I sell their land to pay for their care?
input:
Section no 161  part (1) : If the movable property belonging to the person
under his or her curatorship is insuﬀicient to meet the expenses required for the
maintenance, education or medical treatment of that person, the curator may
file a petition, setting out the matter, in the court for permission to sell the
immovable property or any part thereof for that purpose.
Section no 161  part (2) : If, upon inquiring into a petition filed pursuant to
sub section (1), it considers the reason for selling such immovable property to
be reasonable, the court may grant permission to so sell the immovable property
or any part thereof as it considers appropriate.
output:
According to Section 161(1)-(2)...
Rule: If movable assets are insufficient to meet the ward's needs, the curator may petition the court for permission to sell immovable property; the court may allow a sale if it finds the reason reasonable.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot unilaterally sell the land. If movable property doesn't cover required expenses, you must petition the court explaining the need; the court will decide and may permit sale if satisfied.

instruction: What standard of care is a curator required to follow for the ward's property, and what happens if they fail?
input:
Section no 162 . Property to be taken care of and protected rationally
and : carefully: (1) A curator shall look after of and protect the property 88
belonging to a person under his or her curatorship rationally and carefully.
Section no 162  part (2) : The concerned curator shall be liable for any
kind of loss or damage to the property belonging to the person under his or
her curatorship because of his or her failure to so look after and protect the
property pursuant to sub-section (1). Provided that the curator shall not be
liable for any loss or damage to such property due to a disaster.
output:
According to Section 162(1)-(2)...
Rule: A curator must look after and protect the ward's property rationally and carefully; the curator is liable for loss or damage caused by failure to do so, except losses from disasters.
Application/Conclusion: You must manage and safeguard the property prudently. If loss results from your negligence or failure to protect the property, you can be held liable; however you are not liable for losses caused by disasters.

instruction: Is the curator personally responsible if property is lost in a natural disaster?
input:
Section no 162  part (2) : The concerned curator shall be liable for any
kind of loss or damage to the property belonging to the person under his or
her curatorship because of his or her failure to so look after and protect the
property pursuant to sub-section (1). Provided that the curator shall not be
liable for any loss or damage to such property due to a disaster.
output:
According to Section 162(2)...
Rule: The curator is liable for loss caused by failure to look after the property, but is not liable for loss or damage caused by a disaster.
Application/Conclusion: If property is lost because of a natural disaster (or other disaster), the curator is not held liable under this provision; liability applies only where the curator failed to take proper care.

instruction: If I'm nominated as a potential curator, do I need to sign anything?
input:
Section no 157  part (2) : In filing a petition pursuant to sub-section (1), the
concerned ward committee of the Local Level shall set out the names, surnames,
addresses and professions of the potential persons who could be appointed as
the curator and also submit, along with the petition, a deed of consent given by
such potential persons to act as the curator.
output:
According to Section 157(2)...
Rule: The petition must include a deed of consent from each potential person to act as curator.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your name is submitted as a potential curator, the ward committee must include your written deed of consent with the petition; without that consent your nomination would be incomplete under Section 157(2).

instruction: Who is allowed to file the petition if no one is acting as curator — is it the family or the ward committee?
input:
Section no 157 . Court may appoint curator : (1) If any person has no
guardian under Chapter-6 of this Part or no one acts as his or her curator, the
concerned ward committee of the Local Level may file a petition, stating the
details thereof, in the court for the appointment of a curator.
output:
According to Section 157(1)...
Rule: The concerned ward committee of the Local Level is the party authorized to file the petition to appoint a curator when there is no guardian or no one acting as curator.
Application/Conclusion: The statute assigns this role to the ward committee rather than individual family members; the ward committee may file the petition in court to seek a curator's appointment.

instruction: Can a curator sell a piece of immovable property without court permission if the ward's movable assets run out?
input:
Section no 161  part (1) : If the movable property belonging to the person
under his or her curatorship is insuﬀicient to meet the expenses required for the
maintenance, education or medical treatment of that person, the curator may
file a petition, setting out the matter, in the court for permission to sell the
immovable property or any part thereof for that purpose.
output:
According to Section 161(1)...
Rule: The curator must file a petition and obtain court permission to sell immovable property when movable assets are insufficient; unilateral sale is not authorized by this section.
Application/Conclusion: You may not sell immovable property on your own authority simply because funds run out; you need to petition the court and obtain its permission before proceeding.

instruction: Under which section are the curator's qualifications specified?
input:
Section no 158 . Qualifications of curator : Any person other than a person
who is disqualified for being a guardian pursuant to Section 141 may become a
curator. 87
output:
According to Section 158...
Rule: Section 158 sets out that anyone may become a curator except those disqualified under Section 141 for being a guardian.
Application/Conclusion: The qualifications for becoming a curator are stated in Section 158: you are eligible unless you are disqualified under Section 141.

instruction: Is there a time limit specified here for filing a petition to appoint a curator after discovering there is no guardian?
input:
Section no 157 . Court may appoint curator : (1) If any person has no
guardian under Chapter-6 of this Part or no one acts as his or her curator, the
concerned ward committee of the Local Level may file a petition, stating the
details thereof, in the court for the appointment of a curator.
output:
According to Section 157(1)...
Rule: Section 157(1) authorizes the concerned ward committee to file a petition for appointment of a curator when there is no guardian or acting curator; it does not set or state any time limit for filing such a petition.
Application/Conclusion: Based on the text of Section 157(1), no specific procedural deadline for filing the petition is provided in this provision; the ward committee may file when appropriate, subject to other applicable laws or rules not quoted here.

instruction: Someone says the curator can spend the ward's capital whenever they want. Is that true?
input:
Section no 160 . Power to use property : A person who becomes a curator
may spend all the returns obtained from the property under his or her custody
for the maintenance, health of the person under his or her curatorship and for
the education of such a person, if he or she is a minor.
output:
According to Section 160...
Rule: The curator may spend the returns (income) from the property for maintenance, health and education; the section refers to returns, not the arbitrary spending of capital or immovable property.
Application/Conclusion: The curator is authorized to use income from the ward's property for those needs. This section does not authorize unrestricted disposal of the ward's capital or immovable property without following other provisions (e.g., Section 161 requires court permission to sell immovable property).

instruction: Can a foreigner adopt a child in Nepal? I'm not a Nepali citizen.
input: clause (e) : One who is not a citizen of Nepal. Provided that the provision of this clause shall not apply to a non-resident Nepali citizen who has obtained a foreign citizenship.
output:
According to Section (clause e)...
Rule: A person who is not a citizen of Nepal falls under this clause, but the clause does not apply to a non-resident Nepali citizen who has obtained foreign citizenship.
Application/Conclusion: If you are simply a foreign national (not a Nepali by origin who obtained foreign citizenship), this provision would apply to you (i.e., you are treated as 'one who is not a citizen of Nepal'). If instead you are a non-resident Nepali who later acquired foreign citizenship, this clause does not apply to you.

instruction: Is there a minimum age gap required between adopter and adoptee?
input: Section no 174 . Difference of age between adopter and adoptee : (1) The age difference between the adopter and the adoptee shall be at least twentyfive years.
output:
According to Section 174(1)...
Rule: The age difference between the adopter and the adoptee must be at least twenty-five years.
Application/Conclusion: You must be at least twenty-five years older than the person you wish to adopt, otherwise the adoption would not meet this statutory requirement.

instruction: I want to adopt my granddaughter (three generations). Does the 25-year rule apply?
input: Section no 174  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), no age restriction shall apply to the adoption of a person within the relation of three generations.
output:
According to Section 174(2)...
Rule: The 25-year age-difference requirement does not apply to adoption of a person within the relation of three generations.
Application/Conclusion: Because your granddaughter is within three generations, the statutory age-difference rule does not apply, so you can adopt her even if you are not 25 years older.

instruction: Can someone older than 14 be adopted? My cousin is 15 and I want to adopt him.
input: Section no 175  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (a) of sub-section (1), if the person to be adopted is a person within the relation of three generations or a son or daughter born to the ex husband of the wife, that person may be adopted even though he or she has completed fourteen years of age. 94
output:
According to Section 175(2)...
Rule: Even if a person has completed fourteen years of age, they may be adopted if they are within three generations or are a son/daughter born to the ex-husband of the wife.
Application/Conclusion: If your 15-year-old cousin is within the relation of three generations (or fits the ex-husband-child description), you may adopt them despite being over 14; otherwise the normal age rules apply.

instruction: Whose written consent is required to adopt a child whose both parents are alive?
input: Section no 175 . Consent to be obtained for adoption : (1) In effecting adoption of a child, the adopter shall obtain written consent of both father and mother of such a child, if both of them are surviving, and of the surviving father or mother, as the case may be, if either of them is surviving.
output:
According to Section 175(1)...
Rule: Where both parents survive, written consent of both father and mother is required; if only one survives, the surviving parent's consent suffices.
Application/Conclusion: You must obtain written consent from both parents if they are both alive. If only one parent survives, obtain that surviving parent's written consent.

instruction: My ex-wife and I divorced and the child lives with her by agreement. Who must consent to the adoption?
input: Section no 175  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if the father and mother are separated because of the dissolution of matrimonial relationship between the husband and wife or judicial separation, and a child living with such a father or mother according to the agreement made at the time of such dissolution or judicial separation is intended to be adopted, the adopter shall obtain consent of the person with whom, out of the father and the mother, the child has been living.
output:
According to Section 175(2)...
Rule: If parents are separated by divorce or judicial separation and the child lives with one parent under the separation agreement, the adopter must obtain consent from the parent with whom the child has been living.
Application/Conclusion: Since your child lives with your ex-wife by the separation agreement, the adopter needs your ex-wife's consent (the person with whom the child has been living).

instruction: Parents are missing; an NGO has been caring for a child. Can the NGO consent to adoption?
input: Section no 175  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), adoption of a child whose father and mother are not traced or surviving or a child whose father and mother are surviving but who has been maintained or cared by a person or organization following the conclusion of another marriage either by his or her father or mother may be effected by obtaining written consent of the person or organization so maintaining or caring the child. 95
output:
According to Section 175(3)...
Rule: If the parents are untraced/unavailable or if the child is maintained/cared for by a person or organization after a parent's subsequent marriage, adoption can proceed with written consent from that person or organization.
Application/Conclusion: Because the NGO is caring for the child in the circumstances described, the adopter may effect the adoption by obtaining the NGO's written consent.

instruction: Do I need the child's agreement if the child is 11?
input: Section no 175  part (4) : While adopting a child above ten years of age pursuant to sub-section (1), (2) or (3), written consent of such a child shall also be obtained.
output:
According to Section 175(4)...
Rule: For adoption of a child above ten years of age under subsections (1), (2) or (3), the child's written consent must also be obtained.
Application/Conclusion: Since the child is 11, you must obtain the child's written consent in addition to whatever parental or guardian consent the law requires.

instruction: How must a child sign consent for adoption? Who should be present?
input: Section no 175  part (5) : Written consent referred to in sub-section (4) shall be executed by the concerned child in the presence of his or her father, mother or guardian or curator exercising the maternal and parental authority.
output:
According to Section 175(5)...
Rule: The child's written consent (for those above ten) must be executed in the presence of the father, mother, guardian, or curator exercising parental authority.
Application/Conclusion: The 11-year-old's signature must be made while the child's parent, guardian, or curator (who exercises parental authority) is present.

instruction: Before getting consent for adoption, what must the adopter tell the person giving the child up?
input: Section no 175  part (6) : Before obtaining consent pursuant to this Section, information shall be given to the person putting a child up for adoption, guardian or curator and the child about, inter alia, the meaning, legal status and consequences of adoption.
output:
According to Section 175(6)...
Rule: Prior to obtaining consent, the adopter must inform the child, the person giving up the child, guardian or curator about the meaning, legal status and consequences of adoption.
Application/Conclusion: You must provide clear information to the child and the consenting parent/guardian/curator about what adoption means, its legal effects, and consequences before asking for consent.

instruction: Can I pay money to the birth parents to get their consent to adoption?
input: Section no 175  part (7) : No financial inducement of any type shall be made in obtaining consent pursuant to this Section and such consent requires to be given voluntarily.
output:
According to Section 175(7)...
Rule: No financial inducement of any type may be made to obtain consent; consent must be voluntary.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot pay or offer financial incentives to obtain consent for adoption; any consent must be given freely without inducement.

instruction: I adopted while separated from my spouse; later we reunited. Is that adoption considered by both of us?
input: Section no 176 . Adoption deemed to have been effected by couple themselves : If adoption was effected by the husband or wife living under judicial separation and, subsequent thereto, the husband and wife have lived jointly, the adoption effected before living so jointly shall be deemed to have been effected by the couple.
output:
According to Section 176...
Rule: If one spouse adopted while under judicial separation and later the spouses live together jointly, that earlier adoption is deemed to have been effected by the couple.
Application/Conclusion: Because you adopted during judicial separation and later you and your spouse resumed living jointly, the law treats that adoption as if both spouses jointly effected it.

instruction: My child's father died. Do I still need his consent to adopt?
input: Section no 175 . Consent to be obtained for adoption : (1) In effecting adoption of a child, the adopter shall obtain written consent of both father and mother of such a child, if both of them are surviving, and of the surviving father or mother, as the case may be, if either of them is surviving.
output:
According to Section 175(1)...
Rule: If one parent survives, the surviving parent's written consent suffices; both parents' consent is required only if both are alive.
Application/Conclusion: Since the father has died, you only need the surviving mother's written consent (or vice versa if mother deceased and father surviving).

instruction: I'm a 12-year-old. Do I have to sign to be adopted? Will a guardian be there?
input:
Section no 175  part (4) : While adopting a child above ten years of age pursuant to sub-section (1), (2) or (3), written consent of such a child shall also be obtained.

Section no 175  part (5) : Written consent referred to in sub-section (4) shall be executed by the concerned child in the presence of his or her father, mother or guardian or curator exercising the maternal and parental authority.
output:
According to Section 175(4) and Section 175(5)...
Rule: Children above ten must give written consent; that consent must be executed in the presence of a parent, guardian, or curator exercising parental authority.
Application/Conclusion: As a 12-year-old, you must give written consent for your adoption, and you must sign it in the presence of your parent, guardian, or curator who has parental authority.

instruction: Can a child be adopted by someone even if the adoptee is over 14 but is a son of the wife's ex-husband?
input: Section no 175  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (a) of sub-section (1), if the person to be adopted is a person within the relation of three generations or a son or daughter born to the ex husband of the wife, that person may be adopted even though he or she has completed fourteen years of age. 94
output:
According to Section 175(2)...
Rule: A person who is within three generations or who is a son/daughter born to the ex-husband of the wife may be adopted even if they have completed fourteen years of age.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the adoptee is the son of the wife's ex-husband (as described), they may be adopted even though over 14.

instruction: We're an organization that has cared for a child after the mother's remarriage. Can we provide consent to adoption?
input: Section no 175  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), adoption of a child whose father and mother are not traced or surviving or a child whose father and mother are surviving but who has been maintained or cared by a person or organization following the conclusion of another marriage either by his or her father or mother may be effected by obtaining written consent of the person or organization so maintaining or caring the child. 95
output:
According to Section 175(3)...
Rule: If a child is being maintained or cared for by a person or organization following a parent's subsequent marriage, adoption may be effected by obtaining the written consent of that person or organization.
Application/Conclusion: As the organization caring for the child after the parent's remarriage, you can lawfully give written consent that enables the adoption to proceed.

instruction: If parents are separated without judicial divorce but living apart, whose consent is needed?
input: Section no 175  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if the father and mother are separated because of the dissolution of matrimonial relationship between the husband and wife or judicial separation, and a child living with such a father or mother according to the agreement made at the time of such dissolution or judicial separation is intended to be adopted, the adopter shall obtain consent of the person with whom, out of the father and the mother, the child has been living.
output:
According to Section 175(2)...
Rule: The special consent rule applies where separation is due to dissolution of marriage or judicial separation and the child lives with one parent per the agreement; consent of the parent with whom the child lives is required.
Application/Conclusion: If the separation is not by judicial separation or formal dissolution (e.g., informal separation), this specific provision may not apply; the general consent rule of Section 175(1) (both parents if alive) would govern. If your situation fits judicial separation/dissolution and the child lives with one parent by agreement, secure consent from that parent.

instruction: I worry that the parent signed consent because I promised to pay them later. Would that be valid?
input: Section no 175  part (7) : No financial inducement of any type shall be made in obtaining consent pursuant to this Section and such consent requires to be given voluntarily.
output:
According to Section 175(7)...
Rule: Consent must be voluntary and cannot be obtained through any financial inducement.
Application/Conclusion: If the parent's consent was induced by a promise of payment, that consent would be invalid under this provision because financial inducement is prohibited; the adoption process could be challenged.

instruction: Can the court appoint someone to supervise a guardian?
input: Supervisor may be designated : (1) If a guardian is appointed by the court pursuant to Section 139, the court may, if it considers necessary to inquire into the acts and actions of such a guardian, designate any person as the supervisor.
output: According to Section 140(1): Rule: If a guardian is appointed by the court under Section 139, the court may, when it considers inquiry into the guardian's acts necessary, designate any person as a supervisor. Application/Conclusion: If you suspect a guardian's conduct and the guardian was appointed under Section 139, you can ask the court to designate a supervisor to inquire into the guardian's acts and actions.

instruction: What must a designated supervisor do after appointment?
input: Section no 140  part (2) : The supervisor designated pursuant to sub-section (1) shall make necessary inquiry into the acts and actions of the guardian and submit a report thereof to the court.
output: According to Section 140(2): Rule: A supervisor designated under subsection (1) must inquire into the guardian's acts and actions and submit a report to the court. Application/Conclusion: Once appointed, the supervisor is obliged to investigate the guardian's conduct and formally report findings to the court; you may expect an official inquiry and written report.

instruction: If guardianship is ended, does the supervisor's role stop automatically?
input: Section no 140  part (3) : If the guardianship is terminated pursuant to Section 148, the state of supervision shall also be, ipso facto deemed to be, terminated.
output: According to Section 140(3): Rule: If guardianship is terminated under Section 148, the supervision is automatically terminated as well. Application/Conclusion: If the court ends the guardianship under Section 148, any supervisory appointment ends immediately and you cannot rely on that supervisor's ongoing authority after termination.
