instruction: Can a person sentenced to 4 years' imprisonment be a guardian?
input: Section no 141  clause (c) : A person sentenced by a court to imprisonment for a term of three years or more. Provided that this clause shall not be deemed to prevent a person who is in the priority order under sub-section (1) of Section 136 from being a guardian.
output: According to Section 141(c): Rule: A person sentenced to imprisonment for three years or more is disqualified from being a guardian, but this disqualification does not prevent someone in the priority order under Section 136(1) from being a guardian. Application/Conclusion: Normally someone jailed for 4 years cannot be appointed guardian, but if that person is first in the statutory priority list under Section 136(1), the disqualification in this clause does not block their appointment; the priority exception applies.

instruction: Can a mentally incompetent person be appointed as guardian?
input: Section no 141  clause (a) : An incompetent or quasi-competent person, 79
output: According to Section 141(a): Rule: An incompetent or quasi-competent person cannot become a guardian. Application/Conclusion: If a person is themselves incompetent or quasi-competent, they are disqualified from acting as a guardian and cannot be appointed to that role.

instruction: Someone abused an incompetent person earlier — can they be a guardian now?
input: Section no 141  clause (b) : A person proved to have done an act against the rights and interests of an incompetent or quasi competent person,
output: According to Section 141(b): Rule: A person proven to have acted against the rights and interests of an incompetent or quasi-competent person may not become a guardian. Application/Conclusion: If the person has been shown to have harmed or violated the ward's rights or interests, they are disqualified from being appointed guardian.

instruction: What does clause (d) of Section 141 say about disqualification?
input: Section no 141  clause (d) : A person deemed disqualified to be a guardian by a count.
output: According to Section 141(d): Rule: A person whom a court deems disqualified to be a guardian is barred from guardianship. Application/Conclusion: If a court determines someone is unsuitable and declares them disqualified under this provision, that person cannot serve as guardian.

instruction: From which source must a guardian pay for the ward's maintenance and care?
input: Section no 142 . Maintenance (palan poshan) and care of (herbichar) : incompetent or quasi-competent person: (1) The guardian shall make arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care of an incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship from the property belonging to such a person, if any, and if such property is not available, from the property belonging to the guardian himself or herself.
output: According to Section 142(1): Rule: The guardian must arrange maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care for the ward from the ward's own property, and if none exists, from the guardian's property. Application/Conclusion: You must first use the ward's property to meet care needs; only if the ward has no property may the guardian use their own funds.

instruction: If the ward has no movable property, can their immovable property be sold to pay for care?
input: Section no 142  part (2) : The arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care of an incompetent or quasi competent person, 41 palan poshan, pursuant to sub-section (1), shall be made from the movable property belonging to such a person, if any, and where there is no such movable property or where arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care cannot be made from that property, his or her immovable property may be sold for that purpose with the prior permission of the court. 80 Provided that it is not required to obtain permission of the court to sell the immovable property where a person in the priority order under sub-section (1) of Section 136 is the guardian.
output: According to Section 142(2): Rule: Maintenance arrangements must first come from the ward's movable property; if none or insufficient, the ward's immovable property may be sold for that purpose with prior court permission, except that a guardian who is in the priority order under Section 136(1) need not obtain court permission to sell immovable property. Application/Conclusion: If the ward lacks movable assets, their immovable property can be sold to pay for care but normally only after obtaining the court's permission — unless the guardian is the priority person under Section 136(1), in which case court permission is not required.

instruction: Do guardians have a duty to supervise and protect the ward's property?
input: Section no 143 . Property to be supervised, protected and managed properly : (1) The guardian shall supervise and protect the property belonging to the incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship.
output: According to Section 143(1): Rule: The guardian must supervise and protect the property of the ward. Application/Conclusion: As a guardian you are legally required to take care of and safeguard the ward's property; failing to do so may be challenged in court or lead to supervisory inquiry.

instruction: Can a guardian invest the ward's assets to run a business?
input: Section no 143  part (2) : The guardian may carry on any business or transaction by investing the property belonging to the person under his or her guardianship.
output: According to Section 143(2): Rule: A guardian may carry on business or transactions by investing the ward's property. Application/Conclusion: The guardian is permitted to invest the ward's assets and conduct business or transactions with them, subject to their duty to supervise and protect the property and other applicable safeguards.

instruction: Am I required to keep detailed books of how I spend the ward's money?
input: Section no 144 . To maintain books and accounts accurately : (1) The guardian shall maintain accurately the books and accounts of expenditures incurred in the maintenance (palan poshan), health, education and care of (herbichar) the incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship, and of the incomes and expenditures made in the course of the management of the property belonging to that person and the inventory proving the ownership of such property. Provided that it is not required to maintain such books and accounts where a person in the priority order referred to in sub section (1) of Section 136 is a guardian.
output: According to Section 144(1): Rule: A guardian must accurately maintain books and accounts of expenditures for the ward's maintenance, health, education and care, as well as incomes/expenditures in property management and inventory proving ownership; however, this record-keeping is not required if the guardian is a person in the priority order under Section 136(1). Application/Conclusion: Unless you are a priority-order guardian under Section 136(1), you must keep clear accounts and inventory of all spending and property dealings relating to the ward.

instruction: My relative was appointed guardian but I think they are mismanaging funds. Can the court investigate?
input: Supervisor may be designated : (1) If a guardian is appointed by the court pursuant to Section 139, the court may, if it considers necessary to inquire into the acts and actions of such a guardian, designate any person as the supervisor. Section no 140  part (2) : The supervisor designated pursuant to sub-section (1) shall make necessary inquiry into the acts and actions of the guardian and submit a report thereof to the court.
output: According to Section 140(1) and 140(2): Rule: The court can designate a supervisor to investigate a guardian's acts, and that supervisor must inquire and report to the court. Application/Conclusion: You can petition the court to appoint a supervisor to investigate suspected mismanagement; the supervisor will conduct inquiries and submit a report for the court's consideration.

instruction: My guardian sold a house of the ward without asking the court — was that allowed?
input: Section no 142  part (2) : The arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care of an incompetent or quasi competent person, 41 palan poshan, pursuant to sub-section (1), shall be made from the movable property belonging to such a person, if any, and where there is no such movable property or where arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care cannot be made from that property, his or her immovable property may be sold for that purpose with the prior permission of the court. 80 Provided that it is not required to obtain permission of the court to sell the immovable property where a person in the priority order under sub-section (1) of Section 136 is the guardian.
output: According to Section 142(2): Rule: Immovable property of the ward may be sold to pay for care only with the court's prior permission, except when the guardian is a priority-order person under Section 136(1), in which case permission is not required. Application/Conclusion: If the guardian sold the ward's immovable property without court permission and the guardian is not the priority person under Section 136(1), that sale was not authorized; you may challenge it in court. If the guardian is the priority-order guardian under Section 136(1), they may sell without prior permission.

instruction: Who pays first: the ward's movable property or the guardian's own money?
input: Section no 142 . Maintenance (palan poshan) and care of (herbichar) : incompetent or quasi-competent person: (1) The guardian shall make arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care of an incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship from the property belonging to such a person, if any, and if such property is not available, from the property belonging to the guardian himself or herself.
output: According to Section 142(1): Rule: The guardian must use the ward's property first for maintenance and care; only if the ward has no property should the guardian use their own property. Application/Conclusion: You must exhaust the ward's assets before using the guardian's personal funds to meet the ward's needs.

instruction: Do guardians have to keep an inventory proving ownership of the ward's property?
input: Section no 144 . To maintain books and accounts accurately : (1) The guardian shall maintain accurately the books and accounts of expenditures incurred in the maintenance (palan poshan), health, education and care of (herbichar) the incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship, and of the incomes and expenditures made in the course of the management of the property belonging to that person and the inventory proving the ownership of such property. Provided that it is not required to maintain such books and accounts where a person in the priority order referred to in sub section (1) of Section 136 is a guardian.
output: According to Section 144(1): Rule: The guardian must maintain accurate books and accounts including an inventory proving ownership of the ward's property, unless the guardian is a priority-order guardian under Section 136(1). Application/Conclusion: You are required to keep an inventory showing ownership of the ward's assets alongside financial records, unless you fall under the priority-order exception.

instruction: Under which section does the law set out maintenance (palan poshan) and care obligations?
input: Section no 142 . Maintenance (palan poshan) and care of (herbichar) : incompetent or quasi-competent person: (1) The guardian shall make arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care of an incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship from the property belonging to such a person, if any, and if such property is not available, from the property belonging to the guardian himself or herself.
output: According to Section 142(1): Rule: Section 142 sets out the guardian's duties regarding maintenance (palan poshan) and care (herbichar) of an incompetent or quasi-competent person, including the source of funds. Application/Conclusion: For obligations about maintenance and care of a ward, refer to Section 142; it requires using the ward's property first and the guardian's property only if necessary.

instruction: Can a person who previously acted against an incompetent's interests ever be guardian if a court decides otherwise?
input: Section no 141  clause (b) : A person proved to have done an act against the rights and interests of an incompetent or quasi competent person,
output: According to Section 141(b): Rule: A person proven to have acted against an incompetent's rights and interests is disqualified from being a guardian. Application/Conclusion: If there is proof the person harmed the ward's rights or interests, Section 141(b) disqualifies them from guardianship; a court cannot appoint them unless the disqualifying facts are addressed under other legal provisions (not provided here).

instruction: I am in the priority order under Section 136 — do I need court permission to sell the ward's land for their care?
input: Section no 142  part (2) : The arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care of an incompetent or quasi competent person, 41 palan poshan, pursuant to sub-section (1), shall be made from the movable property belonging to such a person, if any, and where there is no such movable property or where arrangements for the maintenance, health, education, entertainment and care cannot be made from that property, his or her immovable property may be sold for that purpose with the prior permission of the court. 80 Provided that it is not required to obtain permission of the court to sell the immovable property where a person in the priority order under sub-section (1) of Section 136 is the guardian.
output: According to Section 142(2): Rule: Immovable property may be sold for the ward's care with prior court permission, but if the guardian is a person in the priority order under Section 136(1), court permission is not required. Application/Conclusion: Because you are a priority-order guardian under Section 136(1), you may sell the ward's land for care purposes without obtaining the court's prior permission (subject to any other applicable rules).

instruction: Can I adopt a son if I already have my own son?
input:
Section no 171 . Prohibition on adoption by person having child : (1)
No person having his or her own son shall adopt a son and no person having his
or her own daughter shall adopt a daughter pursuant to this Chapter.
output: According to Section 171(1)... Rule: No person who already has a biological son may adopt a son, and no person who already has a biological daughter may adopt a daughter. Application/Conclusion: Because you already have your own son, you are not permitted to adopt another son under this provision.

instruction: I live separately after getting partition of property. Can I adopt my own gender of child?
input:
Section no 171  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if a son or daughter does not live with a man or woman who is living
separately by the reason of judicial separation, such a man or a woman may
adopt a son or a daughter. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter and
Chapter-9 of this Part, the term “judicial separation” means a circumstance
where a person obtains partition in property according to the order of the court
or lives separately according to law or lives separately after separation of bread
and board from other coparceners.
output: According to Section 171(2)... Rule: Even if subsection (1) generally prohibits adopting the same gender when you already have one, a person living separately because of judicial separation (for example after obtaining partition of property or living separately by law or after separation of bread and board) may adopt a son or daughter. Application/Conclusion: Since you live separately due to partition, you fall within the definition of judicial separation and therefore may adopt a son or daughter despite subsection (1).

instruction: I already have a biological child but want to adopt another — can the court permit this? What must I include in my petition?
input:
Section no 171  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1) or (2), if a person who has a biological son or daughter makes a petition in
the concerned court for the adoption of another child, 92 disclosing therein his
47
or her financial capacity to make arrangements for the maintenance, health care,
education and care of the child, and if, upon inquiring into such a petition, it
appears that the petitioner has such status, the court may grant permission to
him or her to adopt such child.
output: According to Section 171(3)... Rule: A person who already has a biological son or daughter may petition the court to adopt another child, but the petition must disclose the petitioner's financial capacity to provide maintenance, health care, education and care; the court may grant permission if inquiry shows the petitioner has that capacity. Application/Conclusion: You can apply to the court to adopt another child, but your petition must clearly disclose and demonstrate financial ability to care for the child; if the court is satisfied, it may permit the adoption.

instruction: My wife and I married for 12 years and have no children — are we eligible to adopt?
input:
Section no 172 . Adoption may be effected : (1) The following person may
effect adoption of a child:
 Section no 172  clause (a) : A couple to whom no child has born even up to
ten years of the marriage,
output: According to Section 172(1)(a)... Rule: A couple who have not had a child even up to ten years of marriage may effect adoption. Application/Conclusion: Having been married 12 years without children, you and your wife meet this criterion and are eligible to adopt under this clause.

instruction: Can an unmarried woman of 40 adopt a child?
input:
Section no 172  clause (b) : An unmarried woman having completed forty-five
years of age, a widow, divorcee woman or judicially separated woman, having
no son or daughter,
output: According to Section 172(1)(b)... Rule: An unmarried woman may adopt only if she has completed forty-five years of age, or if she is a widow, divorcee or judicially separated woman having no son or daughter. Application/Conclusion: At age 40 you do not meet the "completed forty-five years" requirement, so you are not eligible under this clause.

instruction: I'm a 50-year-old single man. Am I allowed to adopt?
input:
Section no 172  clause (c) : An unmarried man having completed forty-five
years of age, a widower, divorcee or judicially separated man, having no son or
daughter.
output: According to Section 172(1)(c)... Rule: An unmarried man who has completed forty-five years of age (or a widower, divorcee or judicially separated man) and who has no son or daughter may effect adoption. Application/Conclusion: At 50 and single with no son or daughter, you satisfy this clause and may adopt under this provision.

instruction: Can someone of unsound mind adopt a child?
input:
Section no 172  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), the following person cannot effect adoption:
 Section no 172  part (2) (a) : One who is of unsound mind,
output: According to Section 172(2)(a)... Rule: Persons of unsound mind are explicitly prohibited from effecting adoption. Application/Conclusion: If a person is of unsound mind, they cannot adopt under this provision.

instruction: Is a person convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude allowed to adopt?
input:
Section no 172  part (2) (b) : One who is convicted by the court of a criminal
offense involving moral turpitude,
output: According to Section 172(2)(b)... Rule: A person convicted by the court of a criminal offense involving moral turpitude is not permitted to effect adoption. Application/Conclusion: A conviction for such an offense bars you from adopting under this rule.

instruction: What if I don't have money to provide for the child's education and healthcare — can I still adopt?
input:
Section no 172  part (2) (c) : One who does not have financial capacity to
afford maintenance, health care, education, sports facility, entertainment and
care of the minor. 93
output: According to Section 172(2)(c)... Rule: A person who lacks the financial capacity to provide maintenance, health care, education, sports facility, entertainment and care of the minor cannot effect adoption. Application/Conclusion: If you cannot financially provide these necessities for the child, you are not eligible to adopt under this provision.

instruction: If my husband and I live in a joint family, do we both need to agree before adopting?
input:
Section no 172  part (3) : In effecting adoption by the husband or wife living
in a joint family pursuant to this Section, they shall obtain each other’s consent.
output: According to Section 172(3)... Rule: When a husband or wife living in a joint family effects adoption under this Section, they must obtain each other's consent. Application/Conclusion: If you and your spouse live in a joint family, you must both consent to the adoption; one spouse cannot adopt without the other's consent.

instruction: Can I adopt a 15-year-old?
input:
Section no 173 .
Adoption not to be effected : (1) No one shall effect
adoption of any of the following persons:
 Section no 173  clause (a) : One who has completed fourteen years of age,
output: According to Section 173(1)(a)... Rule: Adoption cannot be effected of a person who has completed fourteen years of age. Application/Conclusion: A 15-year-old has completed fourteen years and therefore cannot be adopted under this provision.

instruction: Is it allowed to adopt the only son of a family?
input:
Section no 173  clause (b) : One who is the only son or daughter, Provided
that this provision shall not apply to the circumstance referred to in sub-section
(3) of Section
output: According to Section 173(1)(b)... Rule: Generally, adoption of a person who is the only son or daughter is prohibited, subject to an exception referenced in subsection (3) of another section. Application/Conclusion: You generally cannot adopt someone who is the only son or daughter, unless the specific exception in the referenced subsection applies (you would need to check that subsection to see if the exception fits your situation).

instruction: Can a child who was already adopted before be adopted again?
input:
Section no 175  clause (c) : One who has been once adopted as a son or
daughter, Provided that this provision shall not apply where the adoption is
annulled according to law.
output: According to Section 175(c)... Rule: A person who has already been adopted once cannot be adopted again, except where the previous adoption has been annulled according to law. Application/Conclusion: If the prior adoption still stands, the child cannot be adopted again; if the earlier adoption has been legally annulled, a new adoption may be possible.

instruction: Can I adopt a relative who is in a higher degree of relationship than me?
input:
Section no 175 clause (d) : One who is in higher degree of relationship than
the person adopting the son or daughter,
output: According to Section 175(d)... Rule: Adoption is not to be effected of a person who is in a higher degree of relationship than the person adopting. Application/Conclusion: You cannot adopt someone who is a relative in a higher degree of relationship than you—such an adoption is prohibited under this clause.

instruction: Does the law require adoption decisions to prioritize the child's best interests?
input:
. Adoption to be effected in a manner to protect the
best interests : of child: In effecting adoption pursuant to this Act, adoption
shall be effected in a manner to protect the best rights and interests of the child.
 Section no 171 .
output: According to Section 171... Rule: Adoption must be effected in a manner that protects the best rights and interests of the child. Application/Conclusion: Any adoption process must prioritize the child's best interests; decisions that do not protect those rights and interests would be contrary to this requirement.

instruction: Can I recover expenses I paid for my brother's maintenance while I acted as his guardian?
input: Section no 150 . Power to recover expenses : If any guardian has arranged the maintenance, health, education, sports, entertainment and care of (herbichar) the incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship from his or her own property, the guardian may recover the amount of expenses so incurred from the property belonging to the incompetent or quasicompetent person under his or her guardianship. Provided that such expense cannot be so recovered where a person in the priority order referred to in subsection (1) of Section 136 is the guardian.
output: According to Section 150... Rule: A guardian who uses his or her own property to provide maintenance, health, education, sports, entertainment and care for the incompetent or quasi-competent person may recover those expenses from the ward's property, except where the guardian is a person in the priority order referred to in subsection (1) of Section 136. Application/Conclusion: Since you acted as guardian and paid from your own property, you can generally recover those expenses from your brother's property unless you are the kind of guardian listed in the priority order under Section 136.

instruction: If I'm the guardian and I'm one of the people in the priority list under Section 136, can I reclaim money I spent on the ward's care?
input: Section no 150 . Power to recover expenses : If any guardian has arranged the maintenance, health, education, sports, entertainment and care of (herbichar) the incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship from his or her own property, the guardian may recover the amount of expenses so incurred from the property belonging to the incompetent or quasicompetent person under his or her guardianship. Provided that such expense cannot be so recovered where a person in the priority order referred to in subsection (1) of Section 136 is the guardian.
output: According to Section 150... Rule: A guardian may recover expenses paid from his/her own property from the ward's property, but this right does not apply when the guardian is a person in the priority order referred to in subsection (1) of Section 136. Application/Conclusion: If you are a guardian listed in the Section 136 priority order, you cannot recover those expenses under Section 150.

instruction: My guardian deliberately sold some of my property and lied about it. Can I get compensation?
input: Section no 151 . Amount of loss and damage may be recovered : If the guardian knowingly, deceitfully, fraudulently or dishonestly causes loss and damage to the property belonging to the incompetent or quasi competent person under his or her guardianship in such manner as to or not to benefit himself or herself, the incompetent or quasi competent person aggrieved therefrom may recover the amount of loss and damage caused to him or her from such a guardian.
output: According to Section 151... Rule: If a guardian knowingly, deceitfully, fraudulently or dishonestly causes loss or damage to the ward's property, the aggrieved incompetent or quasi-competent person may recover the amount of loss and damage from that guardian, whether or not the guardian personally benefited. Application/Conclusion: Because your guardian knowingly and dishonestly sold your property, you have the right to sue and recover the value of the loss or damage from that guardian under Section 151.

instruction: I only found out about the guardian's misuse of funds today — how long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 152 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date of knowledge of such act or action.
output: According to Section 152... Rule: A person aggrieved by any act or action under this Chapter must bring a lawsuit within six months from the date they acquired knowledge of that act or action. Application/Conclusion: Since you discovered the misuse today, you generally have six months from today to file a lawsuit challenging the guardian's conduct.

instruction: Who can act as a curator for a minor if there is no guardian?
input: Section no 153 . To be curator of minor : (1) If any minor does not have any guardian as referred to in Chapter-6 of this Part, any person may act in the capacity of curator of such a minor for the maintenance, health, education, care of, and protection of property belonging to, him or her, until the minor attains eighteen years of age.
output: According to Section 153(1)... Rule: If a minor lacks any guardian as per Chapter-6, any person may act as curator for that minor to provide maintenance, health, education, care and protection of the minor's property until the minor turns eighteen. Application/Conclusion: If the child has no guardian, you (or any willing person) can lawfully serve as the minor's curator and manage their care and property until they reach 18.

instruction: Can a parent choose someone else to be the curator for their child while the parent is alive?
input: Section no 153  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), a person may appoint any one as a curator for the maintenance, health, education and care of his or her minor.
output: According to Section 153(2)... Rule: A person (presumably the parent) may appoint any person as a curator for the maintenance, health, education and care of his or her minor, notwithstanding subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: Yes — a parent can appoint another person to act as curator for their child’s maintenance, education and care while the parent is alive.

instruction: A neighbor wants to help care for a person of unsound mind who has no guardian — is that allowed?
input: Section no 154 . Curator of person of unsound mind : (1) If a person of unsound mind does not have any guardian as referred to in Chapter-6 of this Part, any other person may act in the capacity of curator for the maintenance, care of, and protection of property belonging to, him or her.
output: According to Section 154(1)... Rule: If a person of unsound mind lacks a guardian as per Chapter-6, any other person may act as curator for that person's maintenance, care and protection of property. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor may lawfully act as curator for the person of unsound mind (if no guardian exists), handling their care and protecting their property.

instruction: If we can't find anyone to be curator for a mentally ill person, who becomes curator by default?
input: Section no 154  part (2) : If there is no curator or the curator cannot be ascertained under sub-section (1), the person under whose custody, supervision or oversight the person of unsound mind is living for the time being shall be the curator of such a person.
output: According to Section 154(2)... Rule: Where no curator exists or cannot be ascertained under subsection (1), the person who currently has custody, supervision or oversight of the person of unsound mind becomes the curator. Application/Conclusion: If no appointed curator can be identified, the individual who is currently supervising or keeping custody of the person of unsound mind will be the curator by operation of law.

instruction: My child's father disappeared and I'm remarried. Can I still be the curator of my 8-year-old?
input: Section no 155 . Mother to become curator of minor : Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 153, if the father of any minor below ten years of age has died or disappeared or become of unsound mind or is in abroad and the mother of such a minor is alive, she herself shall be the curator of that minor even though she has concluded another marriage.
output: According to Section 155... Rule: If the father of a minor below ten years has died, disappeared, become of unsound mind or is abroad, and the mother is alive, she shall be the curator of that minor even if she has remarried. Application/Conclusion: Yes — despite your remarriage, you are the curator of your 8-year-old under Section 155 when the father is absent for any of the listed reasons.

instruction: Can a guardianship right be transferred to a successor when a guardian dies?
input: Guardianship not to be transferred to successor : If a guardianship is terminated upon the death of the guardian pursuant to Section 148, 83 the right, authority and responsibility vested in him or her in the capacity of a guardian shall not be transferred to his or her successor. Provided that in cases where another guardian is required to be appointed for an incompetent or quasi-competent person, he or she shall, in the capacity of the successor to the 43 guardian, maintain (palanposhan) and take care of (herbichar) such incompetent or quasi-competent person until another guardian is appointed.
output: According to Section 149... Rule: When a guardianship terminates on the guardian's death (pursuant to Section 148), the guardian's rights, authority and responsibilities do not transfer automatically to a successor. However, if a new guardian must be appointed for an incompetent or quasi-competent person, the successor in the interim must maintain and take care of that person until another guardian is appointed. Application/Conclusion: The guardianship does not automatically pass to a successor on the guardian’s death. Still, whoever acts as successor must provide maintenance and care until a formal new guardian is appointed.

instruction: The guardian died yesterday — who looks after the incompetent person until a new guardian is appointed?
input: Guardianship not to be transferred to successor : If a guardianship is terminated upon the death of the guardian pursuant to Section 148, 83 the right, authority and responsibility vested in him or her in the capacity of a guardian shall not be transferred to his or her successor. Provided that in cases where another guardian is required to be appointed for an incompetent or quasi-competent person, he or she shall, in the capacity of the successor to the 43 guardian, maintain (palanposhan) and take care of (herbichar) such incompetent or quasi-competent person until another guardian is appointed.
output: According to Section 149... Rule: The guardian's rights do not transfer on death, but when another guardian needs to be appointed for an incompetent or quasi-competent person, the successor must maintain and take care of that person until appointment of a new guardian. Application/Conclusion: Although the deceased guardian’s authority does not automatically pass on, the successor (the person stepping in) must provide maintenance and care for the incompetent person until a formal guardian is appointed.

instruction: I paid for my niece's school fees from my pocket — can I demand reimbursement from her assets?
input: Section no 150 . Power to recover expenses : If any guardian has arranged the maintenance, health, education, sports, entertainment and care of (herbichar) the incompetent or quasi-competent person under his or her guardianship from his or her own property, the guardian may recover the amount of expenses so incurred from the property belonging to the incompetent or quasicompetent person under his or her guardianship. Provided that such expense cannot be so recovered where a person in the priority order referred to in subsection (1) of Section 136 is the guardian.
output: According to Section 150... Rule: A guardian who spends his/her own funds on the ward's maintenance, health, education, sports, entertainment and care may recover those expenses from the ward's property, except if the guardian is someone in the priority order under Section 136. Application/Conclusion: If you were acting as the niece’s guardian and paid her school fees from your property, you can typically reclaim those costs from her property, unless you fall into the Section 136 priority category.

instruction: Explain, in plain terms, what a 'curator' is for a minor.
input: Section no 153 . To be curator of minor : (1) If any minor does not have any guardian as referred to in Chapter-6 of this Part, any person may act in the capacity of curator of such a minor for the maintenance, health, education, care of, and protection of property belonging to, him or her, until the minor attains eighteen years of age.
output: According to Section 153(1)... Rule: When a minor has no guardian under Chapter-6, any person may act as curator to look after the minor’s maintenance, health, education, care and to protect the minor’s property until the minor turns eighteen. Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, a curator is a person who temporarily takes care of a child and their property when there is no official guardian, and stays responsible until the child reaches 18.

instruction: Is there any time limit to sue if I was harmed by a guardian's action — what if I found out late?
input: Section no 152 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date of knowledge of such act or action.
output: According to Section 152... Rule: A lawsuit must be filed within six months from the date the aggrieved person learned of the act or action under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: If you discovered the harmful act late, your six-month limitation begins on the date you gained knowledge. If that six-month window has already passed, you may be time-barred from suing under this provision.

instruction: Under which section can I sue a guardian for causing loss by fraud?
input: Section no 151 . Amount of loss and damage may be recovered : If the guardian knowingly, deceitfully, fraudulently or dishonestly causes loss and damage to the property belonging to the incompetent or quasi competent person under his or her guardianship in such manner as to or not to benefit himself or herself, the incompetent or quasi competent person aggrieved therefrom may recover the amount of loss and damage caused to him or her from such a guardian.
output: According to Section 151... Rule: Section 151 provides that an aggrieved incompetent or quasi-competent person may recover losses and damages caused by a guardian who knowingly, deceitfully, fraudulently or dishonestly damaged the ward's property. Application/Conclusion: You should rely on Section 151 to seek recovery from a guardian who caused loss by fraud.

instruction: My guardian damaged my property but didn't personally benefit. Can I still recover the damage?
input: Section no 151 . Amount of loss and damage may be recovered : If the guardian knowingly, deceitfully, fraudulently or dishonestly causes loss and damage to the property belonging to the incompetent or quasi competent person under his or her guardianship in such manner as to or not to benefit himself or herself, the incompetent or quasi competent person aggrieved therefrom may recover the amount of loss and damage caused to him or her from such a guardian.
output: According to Section 151... Rule: Recovery is available where the guardian knowingly, deceitfully, fraudulently or dishonestly causes loss or damage to the ward's property, whether or not the guardian benefited from the act. Application/Conclusion: Yes — even if the guardian did not personally benefit, you may still recover the amount of loss or damage from the guardian under Section 151.

instruction: Short: Who can be curator of a minor until they turn 18?

To be curator of minor : (1) If any minor does not have any guardian as referred to in Chapter-6 of this Part, any person may act in the capacity of curator of such a minor for the maintenance, health, education, care of, and protection of property belonging to, him or her, until the minor attains eighteen years of age.
output: According to Section 153(1)... Rule: Any person may act as curator for a minor without a Chapter-6 guardian, handling maintenance, health, education, care and property protection until the minor is eighteen. Application/Conclusion: So, any willing person can be the curator until the child turns 18.

instruction: If the curator cannot be found for an unsound-minded person, can the caretaker become the curator automatically?
input: Section no 154  part (2) : If there is no curator or the curator cannot be ascertained under sub-section (1), the person under whose custody, supervision or oversight the person of unsound mind is living for the time being shall be the curator of such a person.
output: According to Section 154(2)... Rule: When no curator exists or cannot be ascertained, the person who currently has custody, supervision or oversight of the person of unsound mind becomes the curator. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the current caretaker or custodian will become the curator by operation of Section 154(2) if no other curator is identifiable.

instruction: Can a foreigner adopt a Nepali child?

instruction: My child has been in a children home for five months. Can the home give him to a foreigner now?

instruction: I signed a deed and surrendered my kids to a children home because I can't afford them. Are they considered voluntarily abandoned?
input: Section no 191  part (3) : “Voluntarily abandoned children” means the following children who have been surrendered to the custody of a children home, through the District Administration Oﬀice, by the following person, upon being unable to make arrangements for their maintenance and education, by executing a deed relating thereto:

According to Section 191(3)...
Rule: Children surrendered to a children home through the District Administration Office by a person who cannot make arrangements for their maintenance and education by executing a deed are defined as 'voluntarily abandoned children.'
Application/Conclusion: Because you surrendered your children to a children home through the District Administration Office by executing a deed due to inability to maintain them, they fall within the statutory definition of 'voluntarily abandoned children.'

instruction: What exactly counts as an 'orphan child' in plain terms?
input:
Section no 191  part (2) : “Orphan child” means any of the following child certified as an orphan by the District Administration Oﬀice:

Section no 191  part (2) (a) : A child found unclaimed by the police, and whose father or mother is not found,

Section no 191  part (2) (b) : A child left unclaimed in a hospital or health institution,

Section no 191  part (2) (c) : A child whose father and mother are not traced out,

Section no 191  part (2) (d) : A child whose father and mother are both dead and who has no property for maintenance.
output:
According to Section 191(2)...
Rule: An 'orphan child' is one certified by the District Administration Office who is either (a) found unclaimed by police with parents not found, (b) left unclaimed in a hospital, (c) whose parents are not traceable, or (d) whose parents are both dead and who lacks property for maintenance.
Application/Conclusion: In basic terms, a child fitting any of those four situations and certified by the District Administration Office is legally an 'orphan child' under the statute.

instruction: A baby was left unclaimed in the hospital — is that child considered an orphan?

Application/Conclusion: Yes — a child left unclaimed in a hospital qualifies as an 'orphan child' under Section 191(2)(b), once certified by the District Administration Office.

instruction: Does the government have to check for trafficking risks before letting a foreigner adopt?
input: Section no 190 . Best interests of minor to be ensured in granting permission for : adoption: (1) Prior to granting permission to a foreigner for adoption, the Government of Nepal shall consider whether or not the best interests of the child will be ensured, his or her human rights will be protected and such a child will be abducted, sold, traﬀicked or otherwise abused.
output:
According to Section 190(1)...
Rule: Before granting adoption permission to a foreigner, the Government must consider whether the child's best interests and human rights are protected and whether the child could be abducted, sold, trafficked, or abused.
Application/Conclusion: The government is legally required to assess trafficking and abuse risks (along with best interests and human rights protection) before allowing a foreigner to adopt; such considerations must inform any permission decision.

instruction: Can a person from any country adopt via inter-country adoption, or are there limits?

instruction: Under which section does the law say the "best interests of minor" must be ensured?

instruction: What exactly is a 'children home' according to the law? I need a simple definition.
input: Section no 191  part (1) : “Children home” means a child welfare home and orphanage established in accordance with law, with the objective of protecting the rights and interests of children, and this term includes a children home or Balmandir established by the Government of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 191(1)...
Rule: A 'children home' is any child welfare home or orphanage established under law to protect children's rights and interests; it also includes government-established children homes or Balmandir.
Application/Conclusion: In plain language, a 'children home' is a legally established welfare home or orphanage (including government Balmandir) meant to protect children’s rights and interests.

instruction: If both parents are dead but the child has some property, is the child still an 'orphan' for adoption purposes?

Application/Conclusion: Yes — where an orphan child has no property, their guardian or curator is among the persons who may surrender the child to a children home, enabling the child to be considered for adoption under the law.

instruction: My wife and I want to adopt from Nepal but our country isn't listed in the Gazette. Can we proceed?

instruction: Can I have an adoption declared void if it broke the rules in Sections 171–175?
input: Section no 184 . Adoption to be void : If a person effects adoption in contravention of Section 171, sub-section (1) of, and clauses (a) and (b) of sub section (2) of Section 172, Sections 173, 174 and 175, such adoption shall ipso facto be void.
output: According to Section 184, if an adoption was effected in contravention of Section 171, sub-section (1) and clauses (a) and (b) of sub-section (2) of Section 172, or Sections 173, 174 and 175, then the adoption shall ipso facto be void. Rule: Adoption is automatically void when those listed statutory requirements are contravened. Application/Conclusion: If your adoption breached any of those specific provisions, you can treat the adoption as void by operation of law — no further validation is needed for voidness, though you may still need to assert that status in court or administrative processes.

instruction: My adoptive parent never looked after the property or managed it properly. Can I annul the adoption?
input: clause (b) : To protect, look after and properly manage the property of the adoptive person, Section no 182  clause (c) : To protect the rights and interests of the adoptive person.
output: According to Section 182, the adopted person has obligations including (clause (b)) to protect, look after and properly manage the property of the adoptive person and (clause (c)) to protect the rights and interests of the adoptive person. Rule: These are statutory duties expected of the adopted son or daughter. Application/Conclusion: If your adopted child failed to meet these duties (for example, did not protect or properly manage your property or did not protect your rights/interests), those failures relate to obligations under Section 182 and may ground annulment actions (see Section 185 procedures).

instruction: Can I annul the adoption if the adoptive person fails to do their duties under Section 181?
input: Section no 185 . Voidable adoption : (1) If an adoptive person fails to fulfill the obligations referred to in Section 181, any adopted son or daughter may have the adoption annulled. Provided that if such adopted son or daughter has already received a partition share, he or she shall not be entitled to have the adoption annulled.
output: According to Section 185(1), if an adoptive person fails to fulfill the obligations referred to in Section 181, any adopted son or daughter may have the adoption annulled. Rule: Failure by the adoptive person to meet Section 181 obligations gives the adopted child a right to seek annulment, subject to the proviso. Application/Conclusion: You can apply to annul the adoption if the adoptive person neglected their Section 181 duties — but if you (as the adopted child) have already received a partition share, you cannot seek annulment under this clause.

instruction: My adopted daughter is physically torturing me — can I annul the adoption?
input: Section no 185  part (2) (b) : If the adopted son or daughter expels him or her from home or subjects him or her to physical or mental torture, from time to time,
output: According to Section 185(2)(b), if the adopted son or daughter expels the adoptive person from home or subjects him or her to physical or mental torture from time to time, the adoptive person may have the adoption annulled. Rule: Ongoing expulsion or physical/mental torture by the adopted child is ground for annulment by the adoptive person. Application/Conclusion: Given your adopted daughter's physical abuse, you have statutory grounds under Section 185(2)(b) to seek annulment of the adoption.

instruction: The adopted child misused my assets. Can I cancel the adoption?
input: Section no 185  part (2) (c) : If the adopted son or daughter misuses his or her property,
output: According to Section 185(2)(c), if the adopted son or daughter misuses his or her property, the adoptive person may have the adoption annulled. Rule: Misuse of the adoptive person's property by the adopted child is a statutory ground for annulment. Application/Conclusion: If the adopted child has misused property belonging to you (the adoptive person), you can initiate annulment proceedings under Section 185(2)(c).

instruction: What if the adopted child leaves and lives separately without my consent for years? Can I annul the adoption?
input: Section no 185  part (2) (d) : If the adopted son or daughter leaves him or her and lives separately without his or her consent for three years or more.
output: According to Section 185(2)(d), if the adopted son or daughter leaves the adoptive person and lives separately without his or her consent for three years or more, the adoptive person may have the adoption annulled. Rule: An absence and separate living of three years or longer without consent is a ground for annulment. Application/Conclusion: If your adopted child has been living separately from you for at least three years without your consent, you have statutory grounds to seek annulment under Section 185(2)(d).

instruction: Can I annul adoption because my married adopted daughter left me?
input: Section no 185  part (3) : The provisions of clauses (a) and (d) of sub-section (2) shall not apply to the married adopted daughter.
output: According to Section 185(3), the provisions of clauses (a) and (d) of sub-section (2) shall not apply to the married adopted daughter. Rule: A married adopted daughter is excluded from annulment grounds in clauses (a) (failure to fulfill obligations under Section 182) and (d) (leaving and living separately for three years). Application/Conclusion: You cannot rely on clauses (a) or (d) of Section 185(2) to annul an adoption in respect of a married adopted daughter; different grounds (if any) would have to be considered.

instruction: If the adoption is annulled under Sections 184 or 185, what happens to the parent-child relationship?
input: Section no 186 . Termination of adoption : (1) If adoption is annulled pursuant to Section 184 or 185, the relationship between the adoptive person and the adopted son or daughter shall be deemed to have been terminated.
output: According to Section 186(1), if adoption is annulled pursuant to Section 184 or 185, the relationship between the adoptive person and the adopted son or daughter shall be deemed to have been terminated. Rule: Annulment under those sections terminates the adoptive relationship. Application/Conclusion: If your adoption is annulled under Section 184 or 185, the legal parent–child relationship ends and you will no longer be regarded as adoptive parent or child for future legal purposes.

instruction: Will rights and obligations acquired during valid adoption remain if adoption is later terminated?
input: Section no 186  part (2) : If the relationship between the adoptive person and the adopted son or daughter is terminated pursuant to sub-section (1), the entitlements, rights and obligations vested in him or her in the capacity of adopted son or daughter shall also be terminated. Provided that no facilities already enjoyed, rights acquired or exercised and obligations fulfilled in the capacity of adopted son or daughter during the validity period of adoption shall be prejudiced.
output: According to Section 186(2), termination of the adoptive relationship also terminates entitlements, rights and obligations vested in the capacity of adopted son or daughter, but any facilities already enjoyed, rights acquired or exercised and obligations fulfilled during the validity period shall not be prejudiced. Rule: Termination ends future rights/obligations arising from adoption, but does not undo rights or benefits already acquired or fulfilled while the adoption was valid. Application/Conclusion: After annulment, you lose continuing rights/obligations tied to the adoption, but anything already received or performed while the adoption was valid remains protected.

instruction: I discovered abuse related to an adoption last month. How long do I have to sue?
input: Section no 187 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within one year after the date on which such an act was done or an action was taken.
output: According to Section 187, a person aggrieved by any act or action under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within one year after the date on which such act was done or action taken. Rule: The limitation period for suits under this Chapter is one year from the date of the act/action complained of. Application/Conclusion: You generally have one year from when the abusive act or relevant action occurred to file a lawsuit under these adoption provisions — act promptly to preserve your rights.

instruction: Is it considered inter-country adoption if a foreigner takes a Nepali minor as adopted child?
input: Section no 188 . Inter-country adoption deemed to be accepted : If any foreigner accepts a minor of a Nepali citizen or of a foreigner domiciled in Nepal as an adopted son or daughter, it shall be deemed to be accepted as an inter-country adoption.
output: According to Section 188, if a foreigner accepts a minor of a Nepali citizen or of a foreigner domiciled in Nepal as an adopted son or daughter, it shall be deemed to be an inter-country adoption. Rule: Acceptance of such a minor by a foreigner is legally classified as inter-country adoption. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a foreigner accepting a Nepali minor as an adopted child is treated as an inter-country adoption under Section 188.

input: Section no 189 . Adoption not to be effected without obtaining permission : (1) No foreigner shall be allowed to hold any minor of a Nepali citizen or of a foreigner domiciled in Nepal as an adopted son or daughter, without obtaining permission from the Government of Nepal.

Rule: Government permission is mandatory before a foreigner may adopt a Nepali minor. Application/Conclusion: You cannot legally adopt or hold a Nepali minor as an adopted child unless you first obtain the required permission from the Government of Nepal.

instruction: I’m an adoptive parent — the adopted son keeps misusing my assets. What exact clause lets me annul the adoption?

Application/Conclusion: You may initiate annulment proceedings under Section 185(2)(c) on the basis of property misuse by the adopted son.

instruction: The adoption happened years ago but I only just learned it violated Section 171 — can I still get it annulled?

output: According to Section 184, adoption effected in contravention of Section 171 (and other listed provisions) shall ipso facto be void. Rule: Such a statutory contravention renders the adoption void by operation of law. Application/Conclusion: If the adoption truly contravened Section 171, it is void regardless of the passage of time — though you should also consider the one-year statute of limitation in Section 187 for actions asserting related grievances.

instruction: Short: Can an adopted child visit their biological parents?
input: Section no 183 . Facility of visit and making correspondences to be provided : The adoptive person shall provide facility to the adopted son or daughter to make visits to, and correspondence with, his or her biological father and mother, from time to time.
output: According to Section 183, the adoptive person shall provide facility to the adopted son or daughter to make visits to, and correspondence with, his or her biological father and mother, from time to time. Rule: Adoptive parents must allow visits and correspondence between the adopted child and biological parents. Application/Conclusion: Yes — under Section 183 your adopted child has a statutory right to visit and correspond with their biological parents, and you (as adoptive parent) must facilitate that.

Application/Conclusion: An informal acceptance or taking of a Nepali minor by a foreigner without the Government's permission is not legally permitted under Section 189(1); such actions would be unlawful absent the required authorization.

instruction: Will the Board coordinate with other agencies on adoption matters?

Section no 193  part (3) (b) : To make coordination between the various
agencies on matters of inter-country adoption,

instruction: Is the Board empowered to prevent undue financial gain in adoption processes?
input:
Section no 193  part (3) (c) : To prevent undue financial and other advantage
likely to be exchanged while giving or taking adoption,
output: According to Section 193(3)(c). Rule: The Board has the duty to prevent undue financial and other advantages that may be exchanged in adoption transactions. instruction: Can the Board share information with foreign central adoption agencies about adopted children?

instruction: What is the Board supposed to do to prevent child trafficking or abuse in adoption?

instruction: How does the Board decide which applicant should be recommended for which child?

Application/Conclusion: The Board will match applicants and children by comparing the documented details submitted (per Section 194(1)) plus the applicant's requests; the Board then recommends which applicant and which minor are appropriate for adoption.

instruction: Who gives final permission for a foreigner to adopt a Nepali minor — the Board or the Government?
input:
Section no 197 .
Permission to be granted for adoption : (1) If the
Board considers, from an inquiry into the recommendation received from the
selection committee pursuant to Section 196, that it is appropriate to grant
a minor as recommended for adoption by a foreigner, it shall make according
recommendation to the Government of Nepal.
Section no 197  part (2) : If, upon an inquiry into the recommendation
made by the Board pursuant to sub-section (1), it thinks reasonable to do so,
the Government of Nepal shall, according to the recommendation of the Board,
grant permission for the adoption of such a minor by the foreigner.
output:
According to Section 197(1)-(2)...
Rule: The Board recommends to the Government when it finds adoption appropriate; the Government may then, after inquiry, grant permission according to the Board's recommendation.
Application/Conclusion: The Board makes the recommendation but the Government of Nepal grants the final permission for adoption (if it finds the recommendation reasonable).

instruction: After permission is granted, is there any official document proving the adoption was approved? When is the adoption considered to have been effected from Nepal?
input:
Section no 197  part (3) : After permission has been granted pursuant to sub
section (2), the Government of Nepal shall issue a certificate relating thereto for
that purpose.
Section no 197  part (4) : After the certificate has been issued pursuant to sub
section (3), inter-country adoption shall be deemed to have duly been effected
from Nepal.
output:
According to Section 197(3)-(4)...
Rule: Once the Government grants permission it issues a certificate; after issuance of that certificate the inter-country adoption is deemed duly effected from Nepal.
Application/Conclusion: The Government issues an adoption certificate following permission, and the adoption is legally treated as having been effected from Nepal at the point the certificate is issued.

instruction: A child's father now says he wants the child back before the Government has given permission. Can the child still be given for adoption to the foreign applicant?
input:
Section no 197  part (5) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(2), if, prior to granting permission for the adoption of any minor by a foreigner,
the father, mother or other guardian of the minor desires 109 to take his or her
minor back, such a minor may not be granted for adoption.
output:
According to Section 197(5)...
Rule: If the father, mother or guardian desires to take the minor back prior to granting of permission, the minor may not be granted for adoption.
Application/Conclusion: If a parent or guardian wants to reclaim the child before the Government grants adoption permission, the adoption cannot proceed — the minor must not be given for adoption in that situation.

instruction: I and my spouse are adopting. My spouse cannot travel to Nepal. Can I still take the child alone?
input:
Section no 197  part (6) : If the Government of Nepal grants permission
for the adoption of any minor by a foreigner pursuant to sub-section (2), the
applicant shall appear in person and take over the concerned minor. Provided
that if the applicant is a couple and either of them is unable to appear in person,
the other spouse may take over such a minor on the basis of the certified deed
of consent executed by the absent spouse.
output:
According to Section 197(6)...
Rule: The applicant must appear in person to take the minor; if the applicants are a couple and one is unable to appear, the present spouse may take the minor if there is a certified deed of consent executed by the absent spouse.
Application/Conclusion: You can take the child alone only if your absent spouse has executed a certified deed of consent; otherwise both (or the applicant in person) must appear.

instruction: After permission is given, who does the Government inform about the adoption?
input:
Section no 197  part (7) : After permission has been granted for the adoption
of any minor by a foreigner pursuant to this Section, the Government of Nepal
shall give information thereof to the central agency responsible for inter-country
adoption situated in the country of the adoptive person and also to the embassy
of the concerned country designated for Nepal, if any.
output:
According to Section 197(7)...
Rule: After granting permission, the Government must inform the central inter-country adoption agency in the adoptive person's country and also the concerned country's embassy designated for Nepal, if any.
Application/Conclusion: Once permission is granted, the Government will notify the adoptive country's central adoption agency and its embassy (if there is one designated for Nepal).

instruction: If we are unhappy with Nepal's decision on our adoption application, what remedy is available?
input:
Section no 197  part (8) : A foreigner or couple making application for adoption may, if not satisfied with any decision made by the Government of Nepal,
make an appeal to the concerned High Court.
output:
According to Section 197(8)...
Rule: A foreigner or couple dissatisfied with any Government decision regarding adoption may appeal to the concerned High Court.
Application/Conclusion: You (or you and your spouse) can challenge an adverse Government decision by filing an appeal in the appropriate High Court.

instruction: What is the selection committee supposed to recommend — and when?
input:
Section no 195 . Provisions relating to selection committee : The Government of Nepal shall form a selection committee, by a notification in the Nepal
Gazette, for the purpose of making recommendations to the Board as to which
of minors may be appropriate for adoption by any foreigner or foreign couple,
after selecting the person or couple desirous of making adoption, and the minor.
output:
According to Section 195...
Rule: The selection committee's purpose is to recommend to the Board which minors are appropriate for adoption by foreigner(s), after the committee selects the prospective adoptive person or couple and the minor.
Application/Conclusion: The committee evaluates and recommends suitable minors for foreign adoption (and does so after selecting the applicant(s) and child), rather than making the final decision itself.

instruction: On what documentary basis will the Board determine what child suits an applicant?
input:
Section no 196 .
To make recommendation by selecting person effecting : adoption and child: The Board shall, based on the minor’s details
according to the applicant’s details and relevant matters received pursuant to
sub-section (1) of Section 194, and also having regard to the applicant’s request,
ascertain what type of minor is appropriate for being adopted by which applicant
and recommend the name of the applicant and the minor to the Board.
output:
According to Section 196...
Rule: The Board bases its ascertainment on the minor's details, the applicant's details and relevant matters received under Section 194(1), and the applicant's request.
Application/Conclusion: The Board will rely on the specific details and documents submitted under Section 194(1) and the applicant's stated preferences to decide which type of minor is appropriate for each applicant.

instruction: Who actually sets the amount of the application fee — the Board or the Government?
input:
part (4) : The application to be made pursuant to subsection (1) shall be accompanied by the application fee as determined by the
Government of Nepal, on the recommendation of the Board.
output:
According to Section 194(4)...
Rule: The application fee is determined by the Government of Nepal, acting on the recommendation of the Board.
Application/Conclusion: The Government fixes the fee amount, but it does so following a recommendation from the Board — the Board recommends, the Government determines and declares the fee.

instruction: If the Board recommends a child for adoption, must the Government follow that recommendation?
input:
Section no 197  part (2) : If, upon an inquiry into the recommendation
made by the Board pursuant to sub-section (1), it thinks reasonable to do so,
the Government of Nepal shall, according to the recommendation of the Board,
grant permission for the adoption of such a minor by the foreigner.
output:
According to Section 197(2)...
Rule: The Government shall grant permission according to the Board's recommendation if, after inquiry, it deems the recommendation reasonable.
Application/Conclusion: The Government is not automatically bound to follow the Board; it must first inquire and be satisfied the recommendation is reasonable — only then will it grant permission in accordance with the Board's recommendation.

instruction: Is an inter-country adoption legally complete as soon as Nepal issues a certificate?
input:
Section no 197  part (4) : After the certificate has been issued pursuant to sub
section (3), inter-country adoption shall be deemed to have duly been effected
from Nepal.
output:
According to Section 197(4)...
Rule: Once the Government issues the certificate pursuant to subsection (3), the inter-country adoption is deemed duly effected from Nepal.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — issuance of the Government's certificate marks the adoption as legally effected from Nepal.

instruction: A parent wants to withdraw consent right before Nepal grants permission — does that stop the adoption?
input:
