(2), if, prior to granting permission for the adoption of any minor by a foreigner,
the father, mother or other guardian of the minor desires 109 to take his or her
minor back, such a minor may not be granted for adoption.
output:
According to Section 197(5)...
Rule: If a parent or guardian desires to take the minor back prior to the Government granting permission, the minor may not be granted for adoption.
Application/Conclusion: A parent's or guardian's decision to take the child back before permission is granted prevents the adoption from proceeding.

instruction: My spouse signed a consent deed but didn’t travel. Can I still collect the child alone in Nepal?
input:
Section no 197  part (6) : If the Government of Nepal grants permission
for the adoption of any minor by a foreigner pursuant to sub-section (2), the
applicant shall appear in person and take over the concerned minor. Provided
that if the applicant is a couple and either of them is unable to appear in person,
the other spouse may take over such a minor on the basis of the certified deed
of consent executed by the absent spouse.
output:
According to Section 197(6)...
Rule: The applicant must appear in person to take the minor, but if one spouse cannot appear the other may take the minor on the basis of a certified deed of consent executed by the absent spouse.
Application/Conclusion: If your spouse has executed a certified deed of consent and the Government has granted permission, you may take the child alone on that basis.

instruction: Once Nepal grants permission for adoption, which foreign authorities are informed?
input:
Section no 197  part (7) : After permission has been granted for the adoption
of any minor by a foreigner pursuant to this Section, the Government of Nepal
shall give information thereof to the central agency responsible for inter-country
adoption situated in the country of the adoptive person and also to the embassy
of the concerned country designated for Nepal, if any.
output:
According to Section 197(7)...
Rule: After permission, the Government must inform the central inter-country adoption agency in the adoptive person's country and the concerned country's embassy designated for Nepal, if any.
Application/Conclusion: The Government of Nepal will notify both the adoptive country's central adoption agency and its embassy (where designated) once it grants adoption permission.

instruction: We were refused by the Government. Where can we challenge that decision?
input:
Section no 197  part (8) : A foreigner or couple making application for adoption may, if not satisfied with any decision made by the Government of Nepal,
make an appeal to the concerned High Court.
output:
According to Section 197(8)...
Rule: A foreigner or couple dissatisfied with a Government decision on adoption may appeal to the concerned High Court.
Application/Conclusion: You can file an appeal against the Government's decision in the appropriate High Court to seek review of the refusal.

instruction: As a foreigner who adopted a Nepali child, how often do I need to send updates about the child's care?
input:
. Details to be forwarded : A foreigner who makes adoption pursuant to this Chapter shall each year forward details relating to the arrangements he or she has made for the maintenance(palanposhan), education, health and care of(herchaha) the adopted minor until such minor attains the age of majority according to the law of the concerned country, in each six months for a period of two years and thereafter in each year to the Government of Nepal through the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in his or her country or Nepali mission abroad, and if such 112 mission is not situated there, through the Embassy of Nepal related to such a country.
 Section no 201 .
output: According to Section 201: Rule: A foreigner who adopts a Nepali minor must forward details of arrangements for the child's maintenance, education, health and care in each six months for a period of two years and thereafter once each year until the child attains majority under the law of the concerned country. Application/Conclusion: You must provide six-monthly reports for the first two years after adoption and annual reports thereafter until the child reaches majority.

instruction: Where should I send those reports if I live abroad?
input:
. Details to be forwarded : A foreigner who makes adoption pursuant to this Chapter shall each year forward details relating to the arrangements he or she has made for the maintenance(palanposhan), education, health and care of(herchaha) the adopted minor until such minor attains the age of majority according to the law of the concerned country, in each six months for a period of two years and thereafter in each year to the Government of Nepal through the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in his or her country or Nepali mission abroad, and if such 112 mission is not situated there, through the Embassy of Nepal related to such a country.
 Section no 201 .
output: According to Section 201: Rule: The reports must be forwarded to the Government of Nepal through the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the adopter's country or Nepali mission abroad; if such mission is not situated there, through the Embassy of Nepal related to that country. Application/Conclusion: You should send the reports via the Nepali Embassy/Consulate or mission in your country, or, if none exists there, via the Embassy of Nepal responsible for that country.

instruction: Can the Board itself check on how an adopted Nepali child is faring abroad, or must it always use someone else?
input: Section no 201 . To monitor : (1) The Board may itself monitor as to whether a foreigner who has adopted a Nepali minor has made arrangements for the maintenance (Palanposhan), health, education and care of (Herchaha) such minor until the minor attains the age of majority, or for that purpose, form, as per necessity, a sub-committee consisting also of a representative of the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the concerned country.
output: According to Section 201(1): Rule: The Board may itself carry out monitoring of a foreign adoption, or as necessary form a sub-committee (which may include a representative of the Nepali Embassy or Consulate) to do so. Application/Conclusion: The Board can directly monitor the child's welfare abroad, but it also has the discretion to form a sub-committee and include embassy/consular representatives to perform monitoring.

instruction: Who can be included in a sub-committee set up to monitor an adopted Nepali child abroad?
input: Section no 201 . To monitor : (1) The Board may itself monitor as to whether a foreigner who has adopted a Nepali minor has made arrangements for the maintenance (Palanposhan), health, education and care of (Herchaha) such minor until the minor attains the age of majority, or for that purpose, form, as per necessity, a sub-committee consisting also of a representative of the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the concerned country.
output: According to Section 201(1): Rule: A sub-committee formed by the Board for monitoring may include, among others, a representative of the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the concerned country. Application/Conclusion: If the Board forms a monitoring sub-committee, it can lawfully include an embassy/consular representative from the country where the adopted child resides.

instruction: Can the Board or its sub-committee visit the child's home to monitor their condition?
input: Section no 201  part (2) : The Board or sub-committee referred to in subsection Section no 201  part (1) : may, for that purpose, carry out monitoring by visiting the place where the child is residing.
output: According to Section 201(2): Rule: The Board or its sub-committee may carry out monitoring by visiting the place where the adopted child is residing. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the Board or its appointed sub-committee has authority to perform in-person visits to the child's residence for monitoring purposes.

instruction: After monitoring, does the Board have to report what it found to Nepal?
input: Section no 201  part (3) : The Board or sub-committee shall submit a report of monitoring conducted by it under sub-section (2) to the Government of Nepal.
output: According to Section 201(3): Rule: The Board or its sub-committee must submit the monitoring report to the Government of Nepal. Application/Conclusion: After any monitoring visit, the Board/sub-committee is obliged to send a report of its findings to the Government of Nepal.

instruction: What must the monitoring report say about the child's situation?
input: Section no 201  part (4) : The report referred to in sub-section (3) shall contain, inter alia, a statement whether the best interests of the adopted Nepali minor have been served when he or she is residing with the adoptive person or not.
output: According to Section 201(4): Rule: The monitoring report must include, among other things, a statement on whether the adopted minor's best interests have been served while residing with the adoptive person. Application/Conclusion: The report must expressly assess and state whether living with the adoptive parent(s) serves the adopted Nepali minor's best interests.

instruction: If a monitoring report says the child's best interests aren't being met, what will the Government of Nepal do next?
input: Section no 201  part (5) : If the report received pursuant to sub-section (3) contains a statement that the best interests of the adopted Nepali minor have not been served when he or she is residing with the adoptive person, the Government of Nepal shall, also taking opinion of the concerned minor if her or she is able to express his or her opinion or is above ten years of age, bring that matter to the 113 attention of the Government of the concerned country through the diplomatic channel.
output: According to Section 201(5): Rule: If the monitoring report states the adopted minor's best interests are not being served, the Government of Nepal shall (after taking the child's opinion if the child can express it or is above ten years) bring the matter to the attention of the government of the concerned country through diplomatic channels. Application/Conclusion: If monitoring finds the child is not doing well, Nepal will seek the child's input if possible and then raise the issue with the child's country's government via diplomatic channels.

instruction: What if nothing improves after Nepal raises the issue diplomatically?
input: Section no 201  part (6) : If the condition of the adopted Nepali minor is not improved even after the attention drawn pursuant to sub-section (5), the Government of Nepal shall, by a notification in the Nepal Gazette, remove such a country from the list of countries opened for their citizens to make inter-country adoption from Nepal.
output: According to Section 201(6): Rule: If the adopted minor's condition does not improve after Nepal draws attention to the matter, the Government of Nepal shall publish a notification in the Nepal Gazette removing that country from the list of countries permitted to conduct inter-country adoption from Nepal. Application/Conclusion: If diplomatic intervention fails to fix the situation, Nepal can formally bar that country’s citizens from adopting Nepali children by issuing a Gazette notification.

instruction: I was adopted from Nepal and only recently discovered the adoptive parents neglected me. Can I seek annulment of the adoption now that I’m an adult?
input: Section no 202 . Case may be filed : A case may be filed in the court of 59 the concerned country for the annulment of adoption, by a minor adopted as an adopted son or daughter within one year after the date on which the minor attained majority, on the grounds of failure to make arrangements for proper maintenance(Palanposhan), health, education and care of (Herchaha) him or her, and by the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the country where the adopted son or daughter is residing within one year after the date on which the adoptive person failed to make such arrangements.
output: According to Section 202: Rule: A person who was adopted as a minor may file for annulment in the court of the concerned country within one year after the date on which the minor attained majority on grounds of failure to arrange proper maintenance, health, education and care. Application/Conclusion: If you are within one year of attaining majority and can show neglect in maintenance, health, education or care, you may file for annulment in the appropriate court under the one-year deadline.

instruction: Who else can file an annulment case if the adoptive parents failed to care for the child?
input: Section no 202 . Case may be filed : A case may be filed in the court of 59 the concerned country for the annulment of adoption, by a minor adopted as an adopted son or daughter within one year after the date on which the minor attained majority, on the grounds of failure to make arrangements for proper maintenance(Palanposhan), health, education and care of (Herchaha) him or her, and by the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the country where the adopted son or daughter is residing within one year after the date on which the adoptive person failed to make such arrangements.
output: According to Section 202: Rule: The Nepali Embassy or Consulate located in the country where the adopted person resides may also file an annulment case within one year after the date on which the adoptive person failed to make the required arrangements. Application/Conclusion: If the adoptive parents fail in their duties, the Nepali diplomatic mission in the adoptee’s country can initiate annulment proceedings within the specified one-year period.

instruction: How long after attaining majority does the law allow filing annulment of adoption?
input: Section no 202 . Case may be filed : A case may be filed in the court of 59 the concerned country for the annulment of adoption, by a minor adopted as an adopted son or daughter within one year after the date on which the minor attained majority, on the grounds of failure to make arrangements for proper maintenance(Palanposhan), health, education and care of (Herchaha) him or her, and by the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the country where the adopted son or daughter is residing within one year after the date on which the adoptive person failed to make such arrangements.
output: According to Section 202: Rule: The annulment claim by an adopted person must be filed within one year after the date on which the minor attained majority. Application/Conclusion: You have a one-year limitation period, counting from the date you legally attained majority, to file a case for annulment on the grounds specified.

instruction: Do other provisions of the Act apply to sons or daughters adopted by foreigners?
input:
Section no 203 . Provisions of the Act to be applicable : (1) Provisions contained in Sections 173, 174, 175, 178, 179, 180, 181 and 183 in relation to adopted sons or daughters shall also apply to the sons or daughters adopted by foreigners pursuant to this Chapter.
 Section no 203
output: According to Section 203(1): Rule: Provisions in Sections 173, 174, 175, 178, 179, 180, 181 and 183 that relate to adopted children apply equally to children adopted by foreigners under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: Rights, obligations or procedures set out in those listed sections also govern adoptions by foreigners; you should refer to those sections for additional specific rules that apply to such adoptions.

instruction: Which specific sections from the Act are stated to apply to adopted children of foreigners?

 Section no 203
output: According to Section 203(1): Rule: The Act specifies that Sections 173, 174, 175, 178, 179, 180, 181 and 183 apply to adopted sons or daughters of foreigners. Application/Conclusion: The listed sections (173, 174, 175, 178, 179, 180, 181 and 183) are directly applicable to adoptions by foreigners and should be consulted for further legal detail.

output: According to Section 201(5): Rule: Before bringing the matter to the attention of the foreign government, the Government of Nepal shall take the opinion of the concerned minor if the child can express an opinion or is above ten years of age. instruction: If the Board finds problems with an adopted child's care, must it include whether the child's best interests were served?
input: Section no 201  part (4) : The report referred to in sub-section (3) shall contain, inter alia, a statement whether the best interests of the adopted Nepali minor have been served when he or she is residing with the adoptive person or not.

instruction: Can the Board choose either to monitor itself or set up a team including embassy reps to do checks?
input: Section no 201 . To monitor : (1) The Board may itself monitor as to whether a foreigner who has adopted a Nepali minor has made arrangements for the maintenance (Palanposhan), health, education and care of (Herchaha) such minor until the minor attains the age of majority, or for that purpose, form, as per necessity, a sub-committee consisting also of a representative of the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the concerned country.
output: According to Section 201(1): Rule: The Board has discretion to either monitor directly or form a sub-committee (which can include an embassy/consular representative) to carry out monitoring. Application/Conclusion: The Board can decide on the method of monitoring—either do it itself or appoint a sub-committee with embassy representation as needed.

instruction: If I believe the adoptive parent failed to provide education and health care, who can bring a case and within what time?
input: Section no 202 . Case may be filed : A case may be filed in the court of 59 the concerned country for the annulment of adoption, by a minor adopted as an adopted son or daughter within one year after the date on which the minor attained majority, on the grounds of failure to make arrangements for proper maintenance(Palanposhan), health, education and care of (Herchaha) him or her, and by the Nepali Embassy or Consulate based in the country where the adopted son or daughter is residing within one year after the date on which the adoptive person failed to make such arrangements.
output: According to Section 202: Rule: Annulment can be sought on grounds of failure to provide proper maintenance, health, education and care; the adopted person may file within one year after attaining majority, and the Nepali Embassy/Consulate may file within one year after the adoptive person failed to make such arrangements. Application/Conclusion: If you can show failures in education/health/maintenance, you (within one year after attaining majority) or the Nepali diplomatic mission (within one year of failure) can initiate annulment proceedings.

instruction: Can I be given priority if I apply to adopt a child who needs extra care?
input:
. Special provision relating to selection of families for
minors in : need of special care: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained
elsewhere in this Chapter, the Board may accord priority to those applicants
who have applied for the adoption of minors in need of special care and select
families to that effect. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term
“minors in need of special care” means those minors, out of orphan 110 minors
or voluntarily abandoned minors, who are in need of special care due to physical
or mental condition, unusual or abnormal growth or more age.
output: According to Section 198(1), the Board may accord priority to applicants who have applied for the adoption of minors in need of special care and select families accordingly. Rule: The Board has discretion to give priority to such applicants. Application/Conclusion: If you apply to adopt a minor classified as a 'minor in need of special care', the Board can place your application in a priority position and consider selecting your family for that adoption.

instruction: What exactly counts as a 'minor in need of special care'?
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “minors in need of special care” means those minors, out of orphan 110 minors or voluntarily abandoned minors, who are in need of special care due to physical or mental condition, unusual or abnormal growth or more age.
output: According to Section 198(1) (Explanation), a 'minor in need of special care' means an orphan or voluntarily abandoned minor who requires special care because of a physical or mental condition, unusual or abnormal growth, or advanced age. Rule: The definition limits the category to orphaned or voluntarily abandoned minors with such conditions. Application/Conclusion: If the child you seek to adopt is an orphan or voluntarily abandoned and has physical/mental health needs, abnormal growth issues, or is of greater age requiring extra care, they fall within this definition.

instruction: Who decides whether a child is a 'minor in need of special care'?
input: Section no 198  part (2) : The Board shall determine as to whether any minor is a minor in need of special care or not.
output: According to Section 198(2), the Board shall determine whether any minor is a minor in need of special care. Rule: The authority to make that determination lies exclusively with the Board. Application/Conclusion: You cannot unilaterally classify a child; the Board must assess and decide if the child qualifies as a 'minor in need of special care'.

instruction: My family requested a boy aged 6 in first priority but none match. Can the Board give us a different child instead?
input: Section no 198  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if, in selecting the families and the minors in need of special care pursuant to that sub-section, any detail relating to the age, sex and health of the minor as demanded by a family in the first order of priority does not match, those minors in need of special care who match to the details as demanded by such family may be selected respectively.
output: According to Section 198(3), if details (age, sex, health) demanded by a family in the first order of priority do not match, minors who do match those demanded details may be selected respectively. Rule: The Board must respect the specific age/sex/health criteria families set in priority and select minors who meet those specifics. Application/Conclusion: If no boy aged 6 matching your request is available, the Board should seek minors who do match your requested age/sex/health criteria rather than assigning a different child who doesn't meet them.

instruction: What other steps are there for selecting families for special-needs children?
input:
Section no 198  part (4) : The other procedures on the selection of families
for minors in need of special care and classification of such minors shall be as
prescribed by the Government of Nepal.
output: According to Section 198(4), other procedures regarding selection of families and classification of minors in need of special care shall be prescribed by the Government of Nepal. Rule: The detailed procedural rules are delegated to the Government. Application/Conclusion: For specific procedural steps beyond what the Board does, you must consult the regulations or rules issued by the Government of Nepal, since this Section defers those details to government prescription.

instruction: I'm a foreign national of high profile — can I apply to adopt from Nepal?
input:
Section no 199 . Special provision relating to permission to be granted
for : adoption: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if any renowned foreign citizen desires to adopt any minor as referred to
in Section 191, he or she may make an application to the Board, along with a
formal recommendation by the head of state, head of government or foreign minister of the concerned country.
output: According to Section 199(1), a renowned foreign citizen who wishes to adopt a minor referred to in Section 191 may apply to the Board, but must submit the application along with a formal recommendation by the head of state, head of government or foreign minister of the concerned country. Rule: Renowned foreign citizens can apply for adoption, but the application must be supported by an official recommendation from senior authorities of their country. Application/Conclusion: If you are a renowned foreign citizen, you can seek to adopt a minor from Nepal, but your application should include the required formal recommendation from one of those high-level officials.

instruction: Is a Nobel Prize winner treated as a 'renowned foreign citizen' for adoption purposes?
input: Section no 199  clause (c) : A laureate of the noble prize,
output: According to Section 199 clause (c), a laureate of the noble [Nobel] prize is listed as a 'renowned foreign citizen.' Rule: Nobel laureates are explicitly included in the categories of renowned foreign citizens. Application/Conclusion: If you are a Nobel laureate, you fall within the statutory definition of 'renowned foreign citizen' and may follow the special procedure in Section 199 to seek adoption (including submitting the required recommendation).

instruction: I earn over $300,000 a year. Does that make me a 'renowned foreign citizen' eligible under the special rule?
input: Section no 199  clause (d) : A person or entrepreneur who has an income of more than three hundred thousand US Dollars a year.
output: According to Section 199 clause (d), a person or entrepreneur with an income exceeding three hundred thousand US Dollars a year is considered a 'renowned foreign citizen.' Rule: High annual income is one of the statutory criteria for that designation. Application/Conclusion: Since you earn over USD 300,000 annually, you would fall into this category and may apply under Section 199's special procedure, subject to the other requirements such as formal recommendation.

instruction: Does the list of 'renowned foreign citizens' include heads of state?

Section no 199  clause (a) : Head of state or head of government of a foreign

Application/Conclusion: If you are a head of state or head of government of a foreign country, you are identified by the statute as a 'renowned foreign citizen' eligible to apply under the special adoption provision, subject to the procedural requirements.

instruction: If the Board thinks the adoption request from a renowned foreigner is reasonable, what happens next?
input: Section no 199  part (2) : If the Board considers, from an inquiry into an application received pursuant to sub-section (1), that it is reasonable to grant a minor as demanded by such a foreign citizen for adoption, it shall make recommendation to the Government of Nepal, Council of Ministers, accordingly.
output: According to Section 199(2), if the Board, after inquiry, deems it reasonable to grant a minor to the foreign applicant, it shall recommend to the Government of Nepal, Council of Ministers. Rule: The Board's favorable finding triggers a formal recommendation to the Council of Ministers. Application/Conclusion: If the Board reviews your application and finds it reasonable, it will forward a recommendation to the Council of Ministers to consider granting you permission to adopt.

instruction: Will the Council of Ministers automatically allow the adoption after the Board's recommendation?
input:
Section no 199  part (3) : If a recommendation is made pursuant to sub-section
 Section no 199  part (2) : , the Government of Nepal, Council of Ministers

Rule: The Council of Ministers has discretion ('may') to grant permission following the Board's recommendation. Application/Conclusion: Even after a positive recommendation by the Board, the Council of Ministers decides whether to permit the adoption; permission is not automatic but possible.

instruction: If a foreigner adopts under this special rule, are they free from other Chapter requirements?
input:
Section no 199  part (4) : Any foreign citizen making adoption pursuant to

set forth in this Chapter.

Application/Conclusion: If you obtain permission and complete an adoption under Section 199, you will still need to meet the other statutory requirements in the Chapter (e.g., formalities, post-adoption procedures) as applicable.

instruction: I applied for a special-needs child but my priority details don't match — can another child be selected instead?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if, in selecting the families and the minors in need of special care pursuant to that sub-section, any detail relating to the age, sex and health of the minor as demanded by a family in the first order of priority does not match, those minors in need of special care who match to the details as demanded by such family may be selected respectively.
output: According to Section 198(3), when a family's prioritized demands on age, sex and health of a minor do not match available minors, the minors who do match those demanded details may be selected respectively. Rule: The selection process should match families' specified criteria; mismatches lead the Board to select minors who fit the specified details. Application/Conclusion: If the child you hoped for doesn't match your stated priority criteria, the Board should instead select a minor who meets what you requested rather than assigning a mismatched child.

instruction: Do I need a recommendation from my country's foreign minister to apply as a renowned foreign citizen?
input:
Section no 199 . Special provision relating to permission to be granted
for : adoption: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if any renowned foreign citizen desires to adopt any minor as referred to
in Section 191, he or she may make an application to the Board, along with a

output: According to Section 199(1), an application by a renowned foreign citizen must be submitted to the Board along with a formal recommendation by the head of state, head of government or foreign minister of the applicant's country. Rule: The statutory requirement is that the application include one of those formal recommendations. Application/Conclusion: Yes — your application must be accompanied by a formal recommendation from one of those specified officials (head of state, head of government, or foreign minister) to be considered under this special provision.

instruction: Short question: Who classifies and selects families for special-care minors?
input:
. Special provision relating to selection of families for
minors in : need of special care: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained
