instruction: I found a child who is older and has health issues — will that child be considered as needing special care?
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “minors in need of special care” means those minors, out of orphan 110 minors or voluntarily abandoned minors, who are in need of special care due to physical or mental condition, unusual or abnormal growth or more age.
output: According to Section 198(1) (Explanation), minors who, as orphans or voluntarily abandoned children, need special care due to physical or mental condition, unusual growth, or advanced age are considered 'minors in need of special care.' Rule: The statutory definition includes older children with health issues as qualifying. Application/Conclusion: The older child with health problems you describe fits the statutory description and can be classified as a 'minor in need of special care' for priority adoption consideration.

instruction: Conflict scenario: I was told only families matching exact health specifications get chosen first. Is that in the law?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if, in selecting the families and the minors in need of special care pursuant to that sub-section, any detail relating to the age, sex and health of the minor as demanded by a family in the first order of priority does not match, those minors in need of special care who match to the details as demanded by such family may be selected respectively.
output: According to Section 198(3), selection must consider the age, sex and health details demanded by a family in first priority, and minors who match those demanded details may be selected. Rule: The law requires matching of specific prioritized criteria when selecting minors for families. Application/Conclusion: If you were told that only exact health/age/sex matches are chosen in first priority, that reflects what Section 198(3) provides — the Board should select minors who match the family's first-order priority specifications.

instruction: Can I relinquish my partition share by executing a deed?
input: . Relinquishment of partition share : (1) Any coparcener may, by executing a deed to that effect, relinquish his or her partition share, with or without taking his or her partition share in part or taking some cash or kind only in consideration for his or her partition share.
output:
According to Section 215(1)...
Rule: Any coparcener may relinquish his or her partition share by executing a deed to that effect; relinquishment may be full or partial and may be for cash or kind consideration.
Application/Conclusion: If you are a coparcener and wish to give up (all or part of) your partition share, you can do so by executing such a deed; you may also accept cash or some other kind in consideration as provided.

instruction: If I have an adult son, do I need his permission to sign a relinquishment deed?
input: While executing a deed on relinquishment of partition share pursuant to sub-section (1), if a coparcener has husband, wife, or son or daughter having attained the age of majority, the deed on relinquishment of partition share shall be deemed to have been executed only when consent of such a husband, wife, son or daughter has been obtained.
output:
According to Section 215(2)...
Rule: When a coparcener has a husband, wife, or son or daughter who is of majority age, the relinquishment deed is effective only if the consent of that spouse or adult child is obtained.
Application/Conclusion: Because your son is an adult, his consent must be obtained for your relinquishment deed to be deemed executed; without his consent the deed will not be effective.

instruction: Can a minor give up their partition share?
input: Provided that the entitlement of a minor coparcener to partition share may not be relinquished.
output:
According to Section 215(2) (Provided clause)...
Rule: The entitlement of a minor coparcener to a partition share cannot be relinquished.
Application/Conclusion: If the coparcener is a minor, their partition share cannot lawfully be relinquished; any attempt to do so would be contrary to this provision.

instruction: If I execute a relinquishment deed, does the law treat it as if I received my share?
input: If a deed on relinquishment of partition share is executed pursuant to sub-section (1), it shall be deemed as if he or she received his or her partition share.
output:
According to Section 215(3)...
Rule: A relinquishment deed executed under subsection (1) is deemed to have the legal effect of the coparcener having received his or her partition share.
Application/Conclusion: Once you properly execute a relinquishment deed, the law treats you as if you have already received your partition share, even if you accepted cash or some other consideration instead of physical share.

instruction: I cannot travel to Nepal to sign the deed. Can someone sign for me?
input: A coparcener shall have to appear in person for executing a deed on relinquishment of partition share or for receiving his or her partition share. Provided that if a coparcener is not able to appear in person, he or she shall, for that purpose, appoint an authorized attorney in accordance with law.
output:
According to Section 215(4)...
Rule: A coparcener must appear in person to execute or receive a relinquishment deed, but if unable to appear, the coparcener may appoint an authorized attorney in accordance with law.
Application/Conclusion: Since you cannot appear in person, you may appoint a lawful authorized attorney to execute or receive the deed on your behalf, provided the appointment complies with legal requirements.

instruction: How must partition be effected—do we need a written deed?
input: Partition to be effected : (1) In partitioning a property in common, a deed of partition shall be executed in writing between the coparceners, subject to this Chapter.
output:
According to Section 216(1)...
Rule: Partition of property held in common must be effected by executing a written deed of partition between the coparceners, subject to the Chapter's provisions.
Application/Conclusion: You and the other coparceners must execute a written deed of partition to legally partition the common property; an oral agreement would not satisfy this requirement.

instruction: When dividing property, how are debts treated? What are "debts in common"?
input: In effecting partition pursuant sub-section (1), partition of property in common and debts in common shall be so made that partition shares thereof are equal. Explanation: For the purposes of his Chapter, the term “debts in common” means any debts agreed to by the person acting as the head of family or by all coparceners or borrowed by the coparceners, who have attained the age of majority and live in the undivided family and carry on household work, farming, trade or any other work in various places or incurred in such transaction or incurred in transaction carried on by the other persons, who have attained the age of majority and live in the undivided family as to which such persons have consented in writing. 120
output:
According to Section 216(2)...
Rule: Partition must balance both common property and "debts in common" so that partition shares are equal. The term "debts in common" includes debts agreed by the head of the family or all coparceners, or borrowed by majority coparceners living in the undivided family for household, farming, trade or related transactions, with consent in writing where applicable.
Application/Conclusion: When you divide property, you must account for joint debts so each coparcener's overall share (property minus/plus debts) is equal; debts meeting the definition above are to be treated as common and balanced in the partition.

instruction: My brother refuses to agree when we try to balance high-value and low-value plots. What can we do?
input: Partition shall be effected by balancing both high value and less value properties, with the consent of all the coparceners, and failing such consent, by a lottery.
output:
According to Section 216(3)...
Rule: Partition should balance high- and low-value properties with all coparceners' consent; if consent cannot be obtained from all, partition may be effected by a lottery.
Application/Conclusion: If your brother will not consent to a negotiated balancing of properties, the law allows the partition to be carried out by a lottery procedure to resolve the impasse.

instruction: There's a dispute over one plot of land. Can we partition the rest?
input: If, in effecting partition, there arises a dispute on any property, partition shall be effected after the settlement of the dispute. Provided that if it takes a long time for the settlement of such a dispute, the property in dispute may be kept as undivided property and the other properties may be partitioned.
output:
According to Section 216(4)...
Rule: If a dispute arises over any property, partition should occur after settling that dispute; however, if settlement would take a long time, the disputed property may remain undivided while other properties are partitioned.
Application/Conclusion: You may proceed to partition the undisputed properties and keep the disputed plot undivided until the dispute is resolved (or resolved separately), rather than delaying the entire partition.

instruction: What must we put into the deed of partition? List the required matters.
input:
Matters to be specified in deed of partition : The following matters shall be specified in the deed of partition:

Section no 217  clause (a) : Name, surname, age, address of every coparcener and that of his or her mother, father, grand-father and grand-mother,

Section no 217  clause (b) : Property to be received by the coparceners,

Section no 217  clause (c) : If the part of a coparcener involves debts, moneys receivable, amount of such debts and moneys,

Section no 217  clause (d) : If, upon partition, any coparcener is to live with another coparcener, that details thereof,

Section no 217  clause (e) : A matter to the effect that no coparcener has hidden or concealed any property subject to partition,

Section no 217
output:
According to Section 217 (clauses a–e)...
Rule: The deed of partition must specify the identification of every coparcener and certain relatives, the property each coparcener will receive, any debts/moneys related to a coparcener's part (including amounts), arrangements if a coparcener will live with another, and a declaration that no coparcener has hidden or concealed any property subject to partition.
Application/Conclusion: When drafting your deed, include each coparcener’s personal details and relatives as listed, the exact properties allocated, clear accounting of any debts or receivables tied to shares, details of any post-partition living arrangements, and a clause confirming no concealment of property.

instruction: My share will include some debts—what must the partition deed state about that?
input: If the part of a coparcener involves debts, moneys receivable, amount of such debts and moneys,
output:
According to Section 217(clause c)...
Rule: If a coparcener's share involves debts or moneys receivable, the deed must specify those debts and the amounts.
Application/Conclusion: Your partition deed must list any debts or receivables attached to your portion and state their amounts so the partition accurately reflects liabilities and entitlements.

instruction: If I will live with my brother after partition, should that be recorded?
input: If, upon partition, any coparcener is to live with another coparcener, that details thereof,
output:
According to Section 217(clause d)...
Rule: The deed of partition must include details if any coparcener is to live with another coparcener after partition.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the partition deed should record the arrangement and details specifying that you will live with your brother following partition.

instruction: Do we need to state that no one has hidden property in the partition deed?
input: A matter to the effect that no coparcener has hidden or concealed any property subject to partition,
output:
According to Section 217(clause e)...
Rule: The deed must include a statement to the effect that no coparcener has hidden or concealed any property subject to partition.
Application/Conclusion: Include an explicit clause in the deed affirming that all coparceners have disclosed all property; this is a formal requirement under Section 217.

instruction: Under which Section is 'Relinquishment of partition share' defined?
input: . Relinquishment of partition share : (1) Any coparcener may, by executing a deed to that effect, relinquish his or her partition share, with or without taking his or her partition share in part or taking some cash or kind only in consideration for his or her partition share.
output:
According to Section 215(1)...
Rule: Section 215 sets out the rules on relinquishment of partition share, stating a coparcener may relinquish his or her share by deed, with possible partial or monetary consideration.
Application/Conclusion: The provisions on relinquishment of partition share are located in Section 215; that is the section to cite for this topic.

instruction: Can a coparcener relinquish only part of his share and accept cash instead?
input: . Relinquishment of partition share : (1) Any coparcener may, by executing a deed to that effect, relinquish his or her partition share, with or without taking his or her partition share in part or taking some cash or kind only in consideration for his or her partition share.
output:
According to Section 215(1)...
Rule: A coparcener may relinquish his or her partition share either fully or in part, and may take cash or kind as consideration.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the law permits relinquishing only part of a partition share and accepting cash (or other kind) in consideration for that relinquished portion.

instruction: If my spouse did not consent to my relinquishment deed, is the deed effective?
input: While executing a deed on relinquishment of partition share pursuant to sub-section (1), if a coparcener has husband, wife, or son or daughter having attained the age of majority, the deed on relinquishment of partition share shall be deemed to have been executed only when consent of such a husband, wife, son or daughter has been obtained.
output:
According to Section 215(2)...
Rule: The relinquishment deed is deemed executed only when consent of an adult husband, wife, or son or daughter (if such exist) is obtained.
Application/Conclusion: If your spouse did not consent, the relinquishment deed would not be deemed executed under this provision; you must obtain the required consent for the deed to be effective.

instruction: Is there a fixed time limit to keep disputed property undivided while we partition the rest?
input: If, in effecting partition, there arises a dispute on any property, partition shall be effected after the settlement of the dispute. Provided that if it takes a long time for the settlement of such a dispute, the property in dispute may be kept as undivided property and the other properties may be partitioned.
output:
According to Section 216(4)...
Rule: When a dispute exists over a property, partition should follow settlement of the dispute, but if settlement would take a long time the disputed property may be kept undivided while other properties are partitioned.
Application/Conclusion: The provision allows keeping disputed property undivided if settlement is prolonged and partitioning the other properties; the section does not specify a precise statutory time limit for how long the disputed property may remain undivided.

instruction: Can Section 191 be used when adopting a foreign minor living in Nepal?
input: part (2) : Provision of Section 191 shall not apply for the adoption of the minors of foreigners domiciled in Nepal.
output: According to Section 191: Rule: The provision of Section 191 does not apply to the adoption of minors of foreigners who are domiciled in Nepal. Application/Conclusion: If your question is whether the rules of Section 191 govern adoption of a foreign minor domiciled in Nepal, those specific provisions are inapplicable — Section 191's regime does not apply to such cases.

instruction: I discovered a wrongful administrative act under this Chapter today. How long do I have to sue?
input: Section no 204 . Statute of limitation : If a separate statute of limitation for making a lawsuit is specified in this Chapter, the lawsuit may be made accordingly, and if such statute of limitation is not specified, a person aggrieved from any act committed or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within one year after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken.
output: According to Section 204: Rule: If a special limitation period is stated elsewhere in this Chapter, that governs; if no specific limitation is provided, an aggrieved person must file a lawsuit within one year from the date of the act or action. Application/Conclusion: Since you found out about the act today and assuming no other specific limitation applies, you have one year from the date the act occurred to initiate a lawsuit under this Chapter.

instruction: Who counts as a coparcener for partition purposes?
input: Section no 205 . To be deemed coparcener : For the purposes of apportionment of a property in common, the husband, wife, father, mother, son and daughter shall be deemed to be coparceners, subject to the other Sections of this Chapter.
output: According to Section 205: Rule: For apportionment of common property, husband, wife, father, mother, son and daughter are deemed coparceners (subject to other Sections in this Chapter). Application/Conclusion: If you are any of those relatives (husband, wife, father, mother, son or daughter) you are treated as a coparcener for partition unless another provision in the Chapter changes that status.

instruction: My family wants to partition our ancestral property. Do all coparceners get equal shares?
input: Section no 206 . Equal entitlement to partition share : (1) Each coparcener shall have equal entitlement to partition share.
output: According to Section 206(1): Rule: Each coparcener has equal entitlement to the partition share. Application/Conclusion: At partition, all coparceners are entitled to equal shares of the property (subject to any other applicable provisions in the Chapter).

instruction: What happens to partition if my wife is pregnant at the time — can we still divide property?
input: Section no 206  part (2) : If a woman coparcener is pregnant at the time of partition, and the baby to be delivered by her is to become a coparcener, partition shall be made by treating also such would be born baby as a coparcener and only after setting aside his or her partition share of property.
output: According to Section 206(2): Rule: If a woman coparcener is pregnant and the unborn child will be a coparcener, partition must treat the unborn child as a coparcener and set aside that child's partition share before completing partition. Application/Conclusion: If your wife (a coparcener) is pregnant and the expected child will be a coparcener, you must reserve that child's share first and then proceed with partition of the remainder.

instruction: If the pregnant coparcener miscarries, what happens to the share set aside for the unborn child?
input: Section no 206  part (3) : If the pregnant woman under sub-section (2) does not deliver a live baby, the partition share set aside for such a baby shall be divided equally between the other coparceners.
output: According to Section 206(3): Rule: If the pregnant woman does not deliver a live baby, the share set aside for that unborn child is divided equally among the other coparceners. Application/Conclusion: In the event of no live birth, the reserved share is not retained but is distributed equally to the remaining coparceners.

instruction: My marriage was dissolved — do my children still get partition from me and their mother?
input: Section no 207 . Son and daughter born from couple whose matrimonial : relationship is dissolved to obtain partition share: A son and daughter born to a couple who cannot conclude a marriage or whose marriage cannot be considered valid or whose matrimonial relationship is dissolved according to law shall obtain their partition share from such a father and mother.
output: According to Section 207: Rule: Children born to a couple whose marriage couldn't be concluded, whose marriage is invalid, or whose matrimonial relationship is dissolved are entitled to obtain their partition share from their father and mother. Application/Conclusion: Your children born from a dissolved or invalid marriage remain entitled to partition shares from both parents' portions under this provision.

instruction: My father is missing and not traceable. Can I claim my partition from my mother?
input: Section no 208 . To obtain partition share from mother : (1) A son and daughter whose father is not traced out shall obtain their partition share from the property belonging to their mother only.
output: According to Section 208(1): Rule: If a child's father is not traceable, the child obtains partition share from the mother's property only. Application/Conclusion: Because your father cannot be traced, you can claim your partition share from your mother's property as specified by this Section.

instruction: A man kept a second wife without making the marriage public. After his death, can she or their children claim partition?
input: Section no 208  part (2) : A wife kept without making public or a son and daughter born from her shall not be entitled to claim a partition share after the death of the husband or father.
output: According to Section 208(2): Rule: A wife kept without making the marriage public, and any children born from her, are not entitled to claim partition share after the husband's or father's death. Application/Conclusion: Under this provision, the secret/kept wife and children from that relationship would be barred from claiming partition after the man's death.

instruction: Can the children or wives of my brother living in our undivided family claim from our family pot or only from their father's share?
input: Section no 209 . To obtain partition share from part of father or husband : (1) A son and daughter child or wives of brothers living in an undivided family shall obtain partition share only from the part of their respective father or husband, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 209(1): Rule: Sons, daughters, or wives of brothers in an undivided family obtain partition shares only from the part of their respective father or husband. Application/Conclusion: They cannot claim from the entire family pool indiscriminately; their entitlement is limited to the portion attributable to their own father or husband.

instruction: My husband died before partition. Do I and my children get his share?
input: Section no 209  part (2) : If the husband, father or mother dies before effecting partition, his wife or his or her child shall obtain the partition share to which the husband, father or mother is entitled.
output: According to Section 209(2): Rule: If a husband, father or mother dies before partition, his or her wife or child shall obtain the partition share to which that person was entitled. Application/Conclusion: Because your husband died prior to partition, you and your children are entitled to succeed to the partition share that he would have received.

instruction: If a man has multiple wives, how are partition shares distributed to them?
input: Section no 209  part (3) : If a person has more than one wife, they shall obtain their respective partition share only from the part of the husband.
output: According to Section 209(3): Rule: Where a person has more than one wife, each wife obtains her respective partition share only from the part belonging to the husband. Application/Conclusion: Co-wives do not take from other family members' portions; each wife's claim is limited to the husband's share, apportioned as appropriate among them.

instruction: Can the government make rules to implement these Chapter provisions?
input: Section no 203  part (3) : The Government of Nepal may, on the recommendation of the Board, make necessary Guidelines for the implementation of the provisions contained in this Chapter.
output: According to Section 203: Rule: The Government of Nepal may, upon the Board's recommendation, make necessary Guidelines to implement the Chapter's provisions. Application/Conclusion: Implementation details can be set out by governmental Guidelines made under this authority; where silence exists in the Chapter, such Guidelines may clarify procedures.

instruction: My brother refuses to partition; can I demand equal shares?
input: Section no 206 . Equal entitlement to partition share : (1) Each coparcener shall have equal entitlement to partition share.
output: According to Section 206(1): Rule: Every coparcener has equal entitlement to a partition share. Application/Conclusion: You can demand partition based on equal entitlement — each coparcener (including you, if you are a coparcener) is entitled to an equal share; refusal by another coparcener does not negate your equal entitlement under this Section.

instruction: I want to know: where is the deadline rule for filing suits under this Chapter written?
input: Section no 204 . Statute of limitation : If a separate statute of limitation for making a lawsuit is specified in this Chapter, the lawsuit may be made accordingly, and if such statute of limitation is not specified, a person aggrieved from any act committed or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within one year after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken.
output: According to Section 204: Rule: The statute of limitation for lawsuits under this Chapter is set out in Section 204 — either a specific limitation stated elsewhere in the Chapter applies, or the default is one year from the act/date of action. Application/Conclusion: The deadline rule is provided by Section 204 itself: use a specific limitation if present; otherwise you have one year to sue.

instruction: If a woman coparcener is pregnant and partition is being planned, do we finalize partition now or must we wait?
input: Section no 206  part (2) : If a woman coparcener is pregnant at the time of partition, and the baby to be delivered by her is to become a coparcener, partition shall be made by treating also such would be born baby as a coparcener and only after setting aside his or her partition share of property.
output: According to Section 206(2): Rule: Partition must treat the unborn child as a coparcener (if the child will be a coparcener) and set aside that child's share before completing partition. Application/Conclusion: You may proceed with partition provided you first reserve the unborn child's partition share; you do not simply ignore the unborn child's entitlement or finalize partition without setting aside that share.

instruction: Are sons and daughters of an invalid or non-concluded marriage entitled to property from their parents?
input: Section no 207 . Son and daughter born from couple whose matrimonial : relationship is dissolved to obtain partition share: A son and daughter born to a couple who cannot conclude a marriage or whose marriage cannot be considered valid or whose matrimonial relationship is dissolved according to law shall obtain their partition share from such a father and mother.
output: According to Section 207: Rule: Children born to couples with an unconcluded, invalid, or dissolved matrimonial relationship are entitled to obtain partition shares from their father and mother. Application/Conclusion: Even if the parents' marriage is invalid or dissolved, their children retain the right to claim partition shares from both parents under this provision.

instruction: Can I register a deed of partition myself? What does the law require for a deed to be valid?
input: Section no 218 . Deed of partition to be registered : (1) In effecting partition, a deed of partition shall be drawn up in presence of witnesses, bear signature and thumb-impression of the witness and the coparcener and registered in the concerned oﬀice, having duly fulfilled the legal requirements. 63
output: According to Section 218(1)... Rule: A deed of partition must be drawn up in the presence of witnesses, bear the signature and thumb-impression of the witness and the coparcener, and be registered in the concerned office after fulfilling legal requirements. Application/Conclusion: You (or the parties) must ensure the deed is executed before witnesses with signatures and thumb-impressions and then register it in the proper office for it to be a valid deed of partition.

instruction: I and my siblings made a partition before 10 January 1978 but never registered the deed. Is our partition still valid?
input: Section no 218  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), in cases where partition was effected in household making a balance between highly valuable and less valuable property, whether or not executing a deed of partition between any coparceners before 10 January 1978 (27 Poush 2034) and a coparcener has already taken his or her partition share and effected transmission thereof or the coparceners have individually possessed or sold or transacted their respective partition share of immovable property according to partition, partition shall be deemed to have been effected in spite of being the deed of partition not registered.
output: According to Section 218(2)... Rule: Where partition was effected in a household before 10 January 1978 and there was a balancing of more and less valuable property, if a coparcener has already taken and transmitted his/her share or coparceners have individually possessed, sold, or transacted their partition shares, the partition shall be deemed to have been effected even if the deed was not registered. Application/Conclusion: If your situation fits these conditions (pre‑10 Jan 1978, partition with balancing, and coparceners have taken/transmitted/possessed/sold their shares), the partition is deemed valid despite lack of registration.

instruction: My father, as head of family, gave a common property only to me without doing partition. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 219  part (1) : No person acting as the head of family shall, without effecting partition, provide a property in common to only a coparcener who has not taken partition share or who would be a coparcener. Provided that Section no 219  part (1) : That such a person may, with the consent of all the coparceners, provide any property to any coparcener. 122
output: According to Section 219(1)... Rule: A person acting as head of family shall not, without effecting partition, provide common property to only a coparcener who has not taken his/her partition share or who would be a coparcener — except that the head may provide property to any coparcener if all coparceners consent. Application/Conclusion: Your father's act is not allowed unless all coparceners consented. Without a partition or unanimous consent, providing common property to only one coparcener is prohibited.

instruction: Can the head of family give property to a coparcener without others' consent if it's only his own share?
input: Section no 219  part (2) : That such a person may, even without consent of the other coparceners, provide the property to the extent of his or her partition share, to any coparcener.
output: According to Section 219(2)... Rule: The head of family may, without the consent of other coparceners, provide property only to the extent of his or her own partition share to any coparcener. Application/Conclusion: If the property given equals the head's own partition share, he can do so without the others' consent. If it exceeds his share, other rules (e.g., partition or consent) will apply.

instruction: Father gave my brother some property and said the rest will be adjusted later. How must other property be partitioned when that happens?
input: Section no 219  part (2) : In effecting partition pursuant to this Chapter, the other property shall be partitioned by setting off the property provided to a coparcener pursuant to clause (1) of the proviso to sub-section (1) for the partition share to which the coparcener is entitled.
output: According to Section 219(2)... Rule: When partition is effected under this Chapter, the remaining property must be partitioned by setting off the property already provided to a coparcener (under the proviso) against that coparcener's entitled partition share. Application/Conclusion: The property your brother received will be treated as part of his share and the rest of the estate will be divided so that his total entitlement is balanced by setting off what he was already given.

instruction: I want to file a lawsuit to set aside my partition share. What must my plaint include?
input: Section no 220 . Lawsuit to be filed by setting out inventory of property : (1) If a coparcener is desirous of getting separated by setting aside his or her partition share, he or she shall file a lawsuit, specifying therein the date of separation of bread and board from the other coparceners and setting out an inventory of such property and debts and assets held in his or her name and that of the other coparceners, to the best of his or her knowledge, as is liable to partition. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “date of separation of bread and board” means the following date or day:
output: According to Section 220(1)... Rule: A coparcener seeking separation by setting aside his/her partition share must file a lawsuit specifying the date of separation of bread and board and setting out an inventory of property, debts, and assets held in his/her name and those of other coparceners (as liable to partition), to the best of his/her knowledge. Application/Conclusion: Your plaint should state the separation date and include a detailed inventory of all relevant property, debts, and assets for you and the other coparceners.

instruction: What exactly counts as the 'date of separation of bread and board'?
input: Section no 220  clause (a) : The date mentioned in the deed of separation of bread and board, Section no 220  clause (b) : If there is no deed of separation of bread and board, the date as agreed between the coparceners on the separation of bread and board, Section no 220  clause (c) : If no agreement is reached between the coparceners pursuant to clause (b), the day immediately before the day of filing a lawsuit, Section no 220  clause (d) : Except as otherwise agreed upon, in the case of a married daughter, the day of her marriage. 123
output: According to Section 220 clauses (a)–(d)... Rule: The date of separation of bread and board is (a) the date in a deed of separation, or (b) if no deed, the date agreed between coparceners, or (c) if no agreement, the day immediately before filing the lawsuit, and (d) for a married daughter (unless otherwise agreed), the day of her marriage. Application/Conclusion: Determine the applicable category for your case—use the deed date if there is one; if not, use the agreed date; if neither exists, the date is the day before you file suit (with a married daughter's marriage date as a special rule).

instruction: We never made any agreement and there's no deed. If I file suit today, what date will count as separation?
input: Section no 220  clause (c) : If no agreement is reached between the coparceners pursuant to clause (b), the day immediately before the day of filing a lawsuit,
output: According to Section 220(c)... Rule: Where there is no agreement between the coparceners, the date of separation is the day immediately before the day of filing the lawsuit. Application/Conclusion: If you file suit today and there was no prior agreement, the date of separation the court will treat is yesterday (the day immediately before filing).

instruction: I'm a married daughter. For partition suit purposes, what date is treated as my separation of bread and board?
input: Section no 220  clause (d) : Except as otherwise agreed upon, in the case of a married daughter, the day of her marriage. 123
output: According to Section 220(d)... Rule: Except where otherwise agreed, for a married daughter the date of separation of bread and board is the day of her marriage. Application/Conclusion: Unless you and the coparceners have agreed on a different date, your separation date for partition purposes will be your marriage day.

instruction: I have a deed of separation executed only among some coparceners. Does it take effect immediately or is registration needed?
input: Section no 220  part (2) : If the deed of separation of bread and board is executed between any coparceners only, such a deed shall come into force only on the date of its registration.
output: According to Section 220(2)... Rule: A deed of separation executed only between coparceners comes into force only on the date of its registration. Application/Conclusion: Your deed will not be effective until it is registered; you must register it for it to take legal effect.

instruction: Under which section is the requirement to register a deed of partition stated? (I need the exact section reference.)
input: Section no 218 . Deed of partition to be registered : (1) In effecting partition, a deed of partition shall be drawn up in presence of witnesses, bear signature and thumb-impression of the witness and the coparcener and registered in the concerned oﬀice, having duly fulfilled the legal requirements. 63
output: According to Section 218(1)... Rule: Section 218 requires that a deed of partition be drawn up in the presence of witnesses, bear signatures and thumb-impressions, and be registered in the concerned office after fulfilling legal requirements. Application/Conclusion: The statutory obligation to register a deed of partition is set out in Section 218; follow the procedures listed there to comply.

instruction: Can a coparcener sell his partition share even if formal partition wasn't done?
input: Section no 218  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), in cases where partition was effected in household making a balance between highly valuable and less valuable property, whether or not executing a deed of partition between any coparceners before 10 January 1978 (27 Poush 2034) and a coparcener has already taken his or her partition share and effected transmission thereof or the coparceners have individually possessed or sold or transacted their respective partition share of immovable property according to partition, partition shall be deemed to have been effected in spite of being the deed of partition not registered.
output: According to Section 218(2)... Rule: If partition conditions described (pre‑10 Jan 1978 balance, and coparceners have taken/transmitted/possessed/sold/transacted their shares) are met, partition will be deemed to have been effected even without a registered deed. Application/Conclusion: Where a coparcener has already sold or otherwise transacted his/her share under those historical conditions, such acts can support that partition is deemed effected despite absence of registration — meaning the sale may be recognized under Section 218(2) if the factual prerequisites are satisfied.

instruction: Ram promised to entrust his partition share to our cousin. Is entrustment recognized—what does the law require?
input: clause (g) : If the partition share of any coparcener is to be entrusted to any one, details thereof, Section no 217
output: According to Section 217(g)... Rule: If a coparcener's partition share is to be entrusted to any person, the details of that entrustment must be provided. Application/Conclusion: Ram's entrustment should be documented with the required details as contemplated by Section 217(g). Without those details properly recorded, the entrustment may lack the formal particulars the provision requires.

instruction: If a property is to devolve on a coparcener only after a parent's death, is that something the law asks to be specified?
input: clause (f) : If any property is to devolve on a coparcener only, upon the death of the father, mother, husband or wife, details thereof, 121 Section no 217
output: According to Section 217(f)... Rule: Where any property is to devolve on a coparcener only upon the death of the father, mother, husband or wife, the details of that arrangement must be provided. Application/Conclusion: If property is conditional on a parent's death, those conditions and details should be specified as required by Section 217(f) so the intended devolution is recorded.

instruction: What about 'other necessary matters'—does the law require them to be written down in partition records?
input: Section no 217  clause (h) : Other necessary matters.
output: According to Section 217(h)... Rule: The statute requires that other necessary matters (i.e., additional relevant details) be specified. Application/Conclusion: Any additional particulars relevant to the partition that are not specifically listed should still be recorded under the catch‑all requirement of Section 217(h) to ensure completeness of the partition documentation.

instruction: I only have a casual question: in simple terms, what must a 'deed of partition' contain so it's recognized?
input: Section no 218 . Deed of partition to be registered : (1) In effecting partition, a deed of partition shall be drawn up in presence of witnesses, bear signature and thumb-impression of the witness and the coparcener and registered in the concerned oﬀice, having duly fulfilled the legal requirements. 63
output: According to Section 218(1)... Rule: A deed of partition must be made before witnesses, include signatures and thumb‑impressions of witnesses and coparceners, and be registered in the concerned office after meeting legal requirements. Application/Conclusion: Put simply—your partition document must be formally written with witnesses, signed (and thumb‑printed) by the parties and witnesses, and then registered at the right office to be legally effective.

instruction: Can I file a lawsuit because I'm unhappy with my share after a partition done under subsection (1)?
input: part (2) : If the partition is effected pursuant to sub-section (1), no lawsuit may be entertained on the ground of dissatisfaction with the partition share.
output: According to Section 223(2)... Rule: If the partition is effected pursuant to sub-section (1), no lawsuit may be entertained on the ground of dissatisfaction with the partition share. Application/Conclusion: Because the partition was effected under sub-section (1), you cannot maintain a lawsuit merely because you are dissatisfied with the share you received.

instruction: We discovered some land after filing a partition suit that wasn't in the coparceners' inventory. Will the court deal with it?
input: Section no 223  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if a lawsuit is filed for the partition of a property not set out in the inventory of the property submitted by the coparceners but discovered subsequently, the court shall effect partition of that property.
output: According to Section 223(3)... Rule: When a property that was not in the submitted inventory is discovered after a lawsuit for partition has been filed, the court shall effect partition of that subsequently discovered property. Application/Conclusion: Because the property was discovered after the inventory was submitted, the court is required to include and partition that property as well.

instruction: What can the court do if someone refuses to submit an inventory and the house is locked?
input: Section no 224 . Power to take inventory by breaking padlock : If, because of the failure of a person to submit an inventory of the property required to be submitted by him or her, the inventory of property has to be taken by breaking the padlock of the house custody of which is taken by him or her, the court may, by opening the padlock in presence also of the person holding the key of the house, if he or she is present, and if not, in presence of at least two persons including the person requesting for partition share and a representative of the concerned ward of the Local Level, take an inventory of the property found there, by maintaining a record thereof. 126
output: According to Section 224... Rule: If inventory cannot be obtained because the property custodian failed to submit it and the house must be opened, the court may open the padlock (in the presence of the key-holder if available, or otherwise at least two persons including the partition claimant and a ward representative) and take a recorded inventory of the property. Application/Conclusion: The court has statutory authority to break/open the padlock and make a recorded inventory in the specified presence; you can request the court to do this if the other party refuses to provide the inventory.

instruction: Both the defendant and I failed to submit inventory. Will the lawsuit simply go away? What happens next?
input: Section no 225 . Partition to be effected when inventory produced : (1) If the person who has to submit an inventory fails to submit the inventory or lapses the time-limit by not submitting a statement of defense and the person filing a lawsuit requesting for the partition of property also fails to submit the inventory of property, the court shall, by causing the person filing the lawsuit to execute a deed of the same statement, abate the lawsuit subject to the condition that the partition shall be effected at the time when an inventory of the property is produced.
output: According to Section 225(1)... Rule: If both the person required to submit an inventory and the person filing the partition suit fail to submit inventories (or the defendant lapses the time-limit by not filing a statement of defense), the court shall cause the plaintiff to execute a deed and abate the lawsuit, but subject to the condition that partition will be effected when an inventory is later produced. Application/Conclusion: The suit will be abated rather than finally dismissed; you can later produce an inventory and seek partition, at which point the court must effect partition.

instruction: I had my partition case abated for lack of inventory. If I later submit an inventory and petition again, will the court start over from scratch?
input:
Section no 225  part (2) : If a lawsuit is abated pursuant to sub-section (1) and the person filing the lawsuit makes a petition subsequently, accompanied by an inventory, the court shall effect partition between the coparceners in 66
accordance with law, on the basis of the previous case-file itself.
output: According to Section 225(2)... Rule: When a previously abated lawsuit is revived by a subsequent petition accompanied by an inventory, the court shall effect partition based on the earlier case-file. Application/Conclusion: The court will not start a wholly new proceeding; it will proceed on the basis of the previous case-file and effect partition accordingly.

instruction: Can someone hide property to keep it from being partitioned?
input: Section no 226 . Prohibition of concealing or hiding property : (1) No person shall conceal or hide a property that is liable to partition.
output: According to Section 226(1)... Rule: No person shall conceal or hide property that is liable to partition. Application/Conclusion: Concealing or hiding property to prevent its inclusion in partition is prohibited; such conduct is not allowed by law.

instruction: My cousin hid a plot that he had in his name. If the court finds out later, can he still claim it?
input: Section no 226  part (2) : If a coparcener is subsequently held to have concealed or hidden any property which is held in his or her name and is liable to partition, at the time of effecting partition or at the time when asked by the court to submit an inventory, the coparcener so concealing or hiding the property shall have no right to obtain such property.
output: According to Section 226(2)... Rule: A coparcener who is found to have concealed or hidden property held in his or her name and liable to partition shall have no right to obtain that property. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin is proved to have concealed the plot, he cannot claim ownership of that plot in the partition; the law strips him of rights to the concealed property.

instruction: If one spouse hides property and it is found later, who gets that property?
input: Section no 226  part (3) : The property concealed or hidden under sub-section (2) shall be partitioned between the other coparceners.
output: According to Section 226(3)... Rule: Property concealed or hidden as described in sub-section (2) shall be partitioned between the other coparceners. Application/Conclusion: The concealed property will be excluded from the concealer's share and will instead be partitioned among the remaining coparceners.

instruction: I received a share that turns out to be legally defective and I can't possess it. Do I get compensated?
input: Section no 227 . Partition share to be reimbursed : If a coparcener is not allowed to own and possess any property falling in his or her partition share 127 due to the property being defective under law, all the coparceners shall proportionately reimburse to him or her property equal to the defective property.
output: According to Section 227... Rule: If a coparcener cannot own or possess property in his/her partition share because that property is legally defective, all coparceners must proportionately reimburse that person with property equal to the defective property. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to proportional reimbursement from the other coparceners in property of equivalent value because the share you received is legally defective and you cannot possess it.

instruction: Can I swap the plot I got in partition with another coparcener because I don't like it?
input: Section no 228 . Partition share not to be exchanged : Except in the case of mutual consent among the coparceners, no coparcener shall be entitled to exchange any property received by him or her by way of partition for the reason that after partition it is disordered, damaged or he or she does not prefer it.
output: According to Section 228... Rule: A coparcener may not exchange any property received by way of partition unless there is mutual consent among the coparceners. Application/Conclusion: You cannot unilaterally exchange your partitioned plot just because you dislike it; an exchange requires mutual consent of the coparceners.

instruction: My brother refused to hand over the key and won't show inventory. Can the court open the house without the key-holder present?
input: Section no 224 . Power to take inventory by breaking padlock : If, because of the failure of a person to submit an inventory of the property required to be submitted by him or her, the inventory of property has to be taken by breaking the padlock of the house custody of which is taken by him or her, the court may, by opening the padlock in presence also of the person holding the key of the house, if he or she is present, and if not, in presence of at least two persons including the person requesting for partition share and a representative of the concerned ward of the Local Level, take an inventory of the property found there, by maintaining a record thereof. 126
output: According to Section 224... Rule: The court may open the padlock and take inventory in the presence of the key-holder if present; if the key-holder is not present, the court may proceed in the presence of at least two persons, including the person requesting the partition share and a representative of the concerned ward. Application/Conclusion: The court can lawfully open the house even if the key-holder is absent, as long as the required witnesses (including a ward representative and the claimant) are present to record the inventory.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me his partition share but later concealed a piece of land in his name. What remedies do I have?
input:
Section no 226  part (2) : If a coparcener is subsequently held to have concealed or hidden any property which is held in his or her name and is liable to partition, at the time of effecting partition or at the time when asked by the court to submit an inventory, the coparcener so concealing or hiding the property shall have no right to obtain such property.

Section no 226  part (3) : The property concealed or hidden under sub-section (2) shall be partitioned between the other coparceners.
output: According to Section 226(2) and 226(3)... Rule: A coparcener who conceals property held in his/her name and liable to partition loses rights to that property, and such concealed property shall be partitioned among the other coparceners. Application/Conclusion: Because Ram concealed the land, he cannot claim it; the concealed land should be taken out of his entitlement and partitioned among the remaining coparceners, which gives you a remedy through the partition process.

instruction: I missed the deadline and didn't file my statement of defense. What does the law say will happen to the partition suit?
input: Section no 225 . Partition to be effected when inventory produced : (1) If the person who has to submit an inventory fails to submit the inventory or lapses the time-limit by not submitting a statement of defense and the person filing a lawsuit requesting for the partition of property also fails to submit the inventory of property, the court shall, by causing the person filing the lawsuit to execute a deed of the same statement, abate the lawsuit subject to the condition that the partition shall be effected at the time when an inventory of the property is produced.
output: According to Section 225(1)... Rule: If a required party lapses the time-limit by not submitting a statement of defense (and inventories are not submitted), the court shall cause the plaintiff to execute a deed and abate the lawsuit, with partition to be effected when an inventory is later produced. Application/Conclusion: Because you missed the deadline, the suit may be abated rather than finally adjudicated; it can be revived later when an inventory is produced, so you should prepare to submit the inventory to proceed.

instruction: Under which section is concealing or hiding partitionable property prohibited?
input: Section no 226 . Prohibition of concealing or hiding property : (1) No person shall conceal or hide a property that is liable to partition.
output: According to Section 226(1)... Rule: Section 226(1) explicitly prohibits any person from concealing or hiding property that is liable to partition. Application/Conclusion: The prohibition against hiding partitionable property is found in Section 226(1); you can cite this section if someone conceals property.

instruction: If a lawsuit was abated for lack of inventories, and I now have the inventory, will the court rely on the earlier file or start anew?
input:
Section no 225  part (2) : If a lawsuit is abated pursuant to sub-section (1) and the person filing the lawsuit makes a petition subsequently, accompanied by an inventory, the court shall effect partition between the coparceners in 66
accordance with law, on the basis of the previous case-file itself.
output: According to Section 225(2)... Rule: When a petition is made after abatement with an accompanying inventory, the court shall effect partition on the basis of the previous case-file. Application/Conclusion: The court will proceed using the earlier case-file rather than treating it as an entirely new suit; you should attach the inventory to revive the prior file.

instruction: My brother promised to support our mother but now refuses and keeps mixing his partition share with ours. Can I ask for my share and leave?
input: Section no 211  part (2) : If a person who is bound to make arrangements as referred to in sub-section (1) fails to make such arrangements, the coparcener is entitled to get separated by obtaining his or her partition share.
output: According to Section 211(2): Rule: If a person obligated to make maintenance/medical arrangements under subsection (1) fails to do so, a coparcener is entitled to be separated by obtaining his or her partition share. Application/Conclusion: Because your brother is bound to make arrangements and has failed, you may lawfully demand separation and obtain your partition share to live separately.

instruction: Can my husband marry another woman before partition and will that new wife get any share from our family's property?
input: Section no 210  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a person whose wife is surviving concludes another marriage before effecting partition, the partition shares of the other coparcener shall first be set aside and the woman who is so married shall be provided with a partition share from the part to which he is entitled. 117
output: According to Section 210(2): Rule: If a person whose wife is surviving marries again before partition, the other coparceners' partition shares must first be set aside and the new wife shall be provided a partition share from the part to which the husband is entitled. Application/Conclusion: If your husband remarried before partition, the law requires that the existing coparceners' shares be set aside first and the new wife must be given her partition share from the husband's own entitled part.

instruction: My wife threw me out of the house. Can I take my partition share and leave the joint family?
input: Section no 213  clause (a) : If the husband or wife expels the wife or husband from the house,
output: According to Section 213(a): Rule: Expulsion of a spouse from the house is one of the circumstances in which a husband or wife may obtain separation by taking their partition share. Application/Conclusion: Since you were expelled, you have the legal ground to get separated at any time by obtaining your partition share.

instruction: My husband regularly insults and harms me mentally. Is that a ground to separate and take my share?
input: Section no 213  clause (b) : If the husband or wife causes physical or mental torture to the wife or husband.
output: According to Section 213(b): Rule: Causing physical or mental torture to a spouse is a ground for that spouse to obtain separation by taking their partition share. Application/Conclusion: Because you have been subjected to mental torture, you may lawfully separate from your husband and claim your partition share.

instruction: We all agree among siblings to divide the family land. Do we need court approval or can we separate anytime?
input: Section no 212 . Separation may be effected at anytime : (1) If there is a mutual agreement between the coparcener, they may get separated at any time by obtaining their respective partition share.
output: According to Section 212(1): Rule: Mutual agreement among coparceners allows them to separate at any time by obtaining their respective partition shares. Application/Conclusion: If all siblings mutually agree, you can effect partition and separate at any time by taking your respective shares without needing to wait.

instruction: What duties do family members sharing property have regarding maintenance and medical treatment?
input: Section no 211 . Right to obtain partition share : (1) A husband, wife, father, mother, son and daughter having property in common shall make, according to their reputation and income, arrangements for the maintenance and medical treatment of the wife, husband, son, daughter, father and mother, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 211(1): Rule: Coparceners (husband, wife, father, mother, son, daughter) who share property must, according to their reputation and income, make arrangements for maintenance and medical treatment of family members. Application/Conclusion: This means each family member with shared property has a duty, proportionate to means, to provide maintenance and medical care to other listed relatives.

instruction: My father says he as head of family can stop me from taking my share. Who counts as 'person acting as the head of family'?
input: Section no 212  part (2) : If the husband, father, mother or person acting as the head of family considers it appropriate for the coparcener to obtain their respective partition share and get separated rather than living in a single family, the coparcener may get separated by effecting partition at any time. Explanation: For the purposes of this Act, the term “person acting as the head of family” means a person who has attained the age of majority pursuant to law and acts as the head of family or who has the responsibility to run the household affairs living in the joint family by engaging in farming, trade, business or any other work in various places.
output: According to Section 212(2) (Explanation): Rule: A 'person acting as the head of family' is someone of majority who acts as family head or has responsibility to run household affairs in the joint family (engaging in farming, trade, business or other work). Application/Conclusion: Your father qualifies only if he is of legal age and actually acts as household head or runs household affairs; that status alone does not prevent a coparcener from obtaining partition if separation is considered appropriate.

instruction: I am a widow now. Can I take my partition share and leave the marital joint family whenever I want?
input: Section no 214 . Widow may effect separation by taking her partition share : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, a widow may get separated at any time by taking her partition share.
output: According to Section 214(1): Rule: A widow may, notwithstanding other provisions, get separated at any time by taking her partition share. Application/Conclusion: As a widow you have the clear legal right to take your partition share and separate whenever you choose.

instruction: If I remarry after getting my widow's share, will that property stay mine or go to my children from the previous marriage?
input: Section no 214  part (2) : If a widow concludes another marriage, the property obtained by her by way of partition share shall devolve on the son and daughter, if any, born to her from the previous husband and, if there is no such a son or daughter, she herself may retain such property.
output: According to Section 214(2): Rule: If a widow remarries, the property she obtained by partition devolves on any son or daughter from the previous husband; if there are no such children, she may retain the property. Application/Conclusion: If you remarry and have children from your earlier marriage, your partition property will pass to those children; if you have no such children, you may keep it.

instruction: My father mixed his partition share with ours while living together and later married another woman. Can that new wife get a share from the family's property?
input: . Latter wife or child to obtain partition share from part of : husband or father: (1) If a person concludes another marriage or a child is born from the wife so married, after effecting partition between his wife, son, daughter or while he is living together with such a wife, son, daughter after mixing his partition share with that of them, such a wife, son or daughter shall obtain her or his partition share only from the part of the property of the husband or father, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 210(1): Rule: If a person remarries or a child is born from the later wife after partitioning or after mixing his partition share with the family's, that new wife or child shall obtain their partition share only from the part of the property belonging to the husband/father. Application/Conclusion: The new wife can only claim a share from the husband's own part of the property, not from the coparceners' portions you and others already own.

instruction: Our family head says he prefers we split up. Can a coparcener get separated just because the family head thinks it's better?
input: Section no 212  part (2) : If the husband, father, mother or person acting as the head of family considers it appropriate for the coparcener to obtain their respective partition share and get separated rather than living in a single family, the coparcener may get separated by effecting partition at any time. Explanation: For the purposes of this Act, the term “person acting as the head of family” means a person who has attained the age of majority pursuant to law and acts as the head of family or who has the responsibility to run the household affairs living in the joint family by engaging in farming, trade, business or any other work in various places.
output: According to Section 212(2): Rule: If the husband, father, mother or person acting as head of family considers separation appropriate, the coparcener may obtain partition and separate at any time. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the family head deems it appropriate, a coparcener may effect partition and separate by taking their share.

instruction: Is there a general exception that allows a spouse to separate even if Section 211 says to provide maintenance?
input: Section no 213 .Husband or wife may get separated by obtaining partition : share: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 211, the 118 husband or wife may, in any of the following circumstances, get separated at any time by obtaining his or her partition share:
output: According to Section 213(1): Rule: Notwithstanding Section 211, a husband or wife may, in specified circumstances, get separated at any time by obtaining their partition share. Application/Conclusion: This means that even though Section 211 requires coparceners to make maintenance arrangements, Section 213 allows a spouse to separate and take a partition share in the listed circumstances (see subsequent clauses).

instruction: Under which section is the 'right to obtain partition share' set out?
input: Section no 211 . Right to obtain partition share : (1) A husband, wife, father, mother, son and daughter having property in common shall make, according to their reputation and income, arrangements for the maintenance and medical treatment of the wife, husband, son, daughter, father and mother, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 211(1): Rule: Section 211 is titled 'Right to obtain partition share' and sets out the duties of coparceners to make maintenance and medical arrangements. Application/Conclusion: The right and duties regarding obtaining partition share are established in Section 211, which you should consult for entitlement and obligations among family members sharing property.

instruction: If a man mixed his part with family property and then a child is born from the later wife, where does that child's share come from?
input: . Latter wife or child to obtain partition share from part of : husband or father: (1) If a person concludes another marriage or a child is born from the wife so married, after effecting partition between his wife, son, daughter or while he is living together with such a wife, son, daughter after mixing his partition share with that of them, such a wife, son or daughter shall obtain her or his partition share only from the part of the property of the husband or father, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 210(1): Rule: A child born from the later wife, where the husband mixed his partition share with the family's property, obtains his or her partition share only from the husband's/father's part of the property. Application/Conclusion: The newborn child cannot claim from other coparceners' portions; the child's entitlement is limited to the father's/husband's own part.

instruction: A widow married again after taking a partition share. I am her son from the previous husband — do I get her partition property?
input: Section no 214  part (2) : If a widow concludes another marriage, the property obtained by her by way of partition share shall devolve on the son and daughter, if any, born to her from the previous husband and, if there is no such a son or daughter, she herself may retain such property.
output: According to Section 214(2): Rule: If a widow remarries, the partition property she obtained devolves on any son or daughter from the previous husband; if no such children exist, she may retain it. Application/Conclusion: As her son from the previous husband, you (and any siblings) would inherit the partition property she obtained if she remarries.

instruction: My spouse was abusive and also kicked me out. Can I rely on more than one ground to get my share?
input: Section no 213 .Husband or wife may get separated by obtaining partition : share: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 211, the 118 husband or wife may, in any of the following circumstances, get separated at any time by obtaining his or her partition share:
output: According to Section 213(1): Rule: Section 213 allows a husband or wife to obtain separation by taking their partition share notwithstanding Section 211, and lists qualifying circumstances. Application/Conclusion: If your spouse both expelled you and caused physical or mental torture (the listed circumstances), you clearly fall within Section 213's grounds and may obtain your partition share and separate.

instruction: If someone refuses to arrange medical treatment for an elderly parent despite sharing property, can a coparcener take a partition share immediately?
input: Section no 211  part (2) : If a person who is bound to make arrangements as referred to in sub-section (1) fails to make such arrangements, the coparcener is entitled to get separated by obtaining his or her partition share.
output: According to Section 211(2): Rule: Failure by a person bound under subsection (1) to make maintenance/medical arrangements entitles a coparcener to separate by obtaining his/her partition share. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the obligated family member refuses to arrange medical treatment, a coparcener may lawfully claim separation and take their partition share.

instruction: Can a coparcener be forced to stay in a joint family if the head wants separation?
input: Section no 212  part (2) : If the husband, father, mother or person acting as the head of family considers it appropriate for the coparcener to obtain their respective partition share and get separated rather than living in a single family, the coparcener may get separated by effecting partition at any time. Explanation: For the purposes of this Act, the term “person acting as the head of family” means a person who has attained the age of majority pursuant to law and acts as the head of family or who has the responsibility to run the household affairs living in the joint family by engaging in farming, trade, business or any other work in various places.
output: According to Section 212(2): Rule: If the family head considers separation appropriate, coparceners may effect partition and separate at any time. Application/Conclusion: A coparcener cannot be forced to remain if the head (meeting the definition) or other qualifying persons decide separation is appropriate; the coparcener may obtain their share and separate.

instruction: I filed a suit but couldn't attach an inventory. What should I do?
input: part (3) : If the person filing a lawsuit pursuant to sub-section (1) is unable to submit the inventory of property, he or she shall also specify the reason therefor.
output: According to Section 220(3), Rule: If the person filing a lawsuit is unable to submit the inventory of property, they must specify the reason for not submitting it. Application/Conclusion: In your case, when you file the suit you should include a clear statement explaining why the inventory is not attached. Failure to state a reason would leave a gap in compliance with Section 220(3) and the court may require further steps or compliance.

instruction: As the defendant, do I have to state whether I'll give a partition share and submit my inventory?
input: Section no 220  part (4) : If a lawsuit is filed pursuant to sub-section (1), the concerned person also shall submit a statement of defense, together with a statement whether the plaintiff is to be provided with a partition share or not and if he or she agrees to provide a partition share, together with an inventory of the property held in his or her name and the debts and assets.
output: According to Section 220(4), Rule: When a lawsuit under subsection (1) is filed, the concerned person (defendant) must submit a statement of defense and must state whether the plaintiff is to be provided a partition share; if the defendant agrees to provide a partition share, the defendant must also submit an inventory of property held in their name and details of debts and assets. Application/Conclusion: As a defendant you are legally required to say in your defense whether you will provide a partition share. If you agree, you must attach an inventory listing your property, debts and assets.

instruction: What exactly must be listed about land when preparing the inventory?
input:
Section no 221  clause (a) : The place of location of land, plot No., area and
approximate value thereof,
output: According to Section 221 clause (a), Rule: The inventory must set out the place of location of the land, plot number, area and the approximate value of the land. Application/Conclusion: For any land you list, include its exact location, plot number, size (area), and an approximate monetary value so the inventory complies with Section 221(a).

instruction: What details are required in the inventory for a house?
input:
Section no 221  clause (b) : In the case of a house, place of location, plot no,
area, Kabal (rooms), Naal (size), storey of the house, whether it is concretely
built or mud made, and approximate value thereof,
output: According to Section 221 clause (b), Rule: The inventory for a house must include place of location, plot number, area, number of rooms (Kabal), size (Naal), number of storeys, construction type (concrete or mud), and an approximate value. Application/Conclusion: For your two-storey concrete house, list its location, plot number, area, room count, size, that it is concrete and two-storey, plus an approximate value to meet Section 221(b) requirements.

instruction: Do I need to list my motorbike in the inventory and what information is needed?
input:
Section no 221  clause (g) : In the case of a motor vehicle, details and
approximate value thereof,
output: According to Section 221 clause (g), Rule: A motor vehicle must be listed in the inventory with its details and an approximate value. Application/Conclusion: You must include your motorbike in the inventory, providing identifying details (make/model/registration) and an estimated value as required by Section 221(g).

instruction: What must be declared for cash, bank accounts and shares in the inventory?
input:
Section no 221  clause (d) : In the case of cash, details thereof, and also
details of bank balance, share, debenture, treasury bills, if any, 124
output: According to Section 221 clause (d), Rule: The inventory must set out details of cash and details of bank balances, shares, debentures, treasury bills, if any. Application/Conclusion: You should list any cash on hand and provide the relevant details of bank account balances and any investments (shares, debentures, treasury bills) in the inventory to comply with Section 221(d).

instruction: I own cattle and goats — what information about livestock must go in the inventory?
input:

output: According to Section 221 clause (e), Rule: Livestock must be listed with details and an approximate value. Application/Conclusion: For your cattle and goats, include species, number, identifying details (if any) and an estimated monetary value for each in the inventory to satisfy Section 221(e).

instruction: How should gold and jewellery be mentioned in the inventory?
input:
Section no 221  clause (f) : In the case of gold, silver and jewelries, details
and approximate value thereof,
output: According to Section 221 clause (f), Rule: Gold, silver and jewellery must be described with details and an approximate value. Application/Conclusion: List each item or category of jewellery and precious metals with brief identifying details and an estimated value so the inventory complies with Section 221(f).

instruction: If we disagree on the value of a property or it's not listed, how will the court fix the price?
input:
Section no 221  part (2) : If the value of any property is not set out pursuant
to sub-section (1) or a dispute arises as to the value thereof, the court shall
take the basis of the price fixed by the Land Revenue Oﬀice, in the case of an
immovable property, and of the prevailing market price for the time being, in
the case of a movable property.
output: According to Section 221(2), Rule: If property value is not stated or is disputed, the court will use the price fixed by the Land Revenue Office for immovable property and the prevailing market price for movable property. Application/Conclusion: If you and the other party cannot agree on a land's value, the court will reference the Land Revenue Office price; for movable goods it will use current market price.

instruction: If all heirs submit inventories with the lawsuit, how does the court effect partition?
input:
Section no 222 . Partition to be effected by taking inventory : (1) If
it appears from the lawsuit filed or statement of defense submitted pursuant to
Section 220 that partition requires to be effected and an inventory of property is
submitted along with the lawsuit or statement of defense, the court shall effect
65

property they have submitted is the only property to be partitioned and that
they have not concealed or hidden any other property.
output: According to Section 222(1), Rule: When partition is required and inventories are submitted with the lawsuit or defense, the court will effect partition after having the coparceners execute a deed confirming that the submitted property is the only property to be partitioned and that no other property has been concealed. Application/Conclusion: If all heirs submit inventories with the suit, the court will proceed to partition the listed property but will require each coparcener to sign a deed declaring completeness and non-concealment before final partition.

instruction: I didn't submit inventory with my statement of defense. Will the court give me time to submit it?
input:
