output: According to Section 222(2), Rule: If an inventory is not submitted with the lawsuit or statement of defense, the court will set a time-limit and require coparceners to submit the inventory; if they do so within that time-limit the court will effect partition and require execution of the deed described in subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: The court can and will give you a specified time-limit to submit your inventory; if you submit it within that time the court can still effect partition upon the required deed execution.

instruction: One heir didn't submit inventory within the time-limit. Can the court partition without their inventory?
input:
Section no 223 .
Partition to be effected on the basis of inventory
received : (1) If a person who in to submit an inventory of property within
the time limit referred to in Section 222 fails to submit the inventory or has
elapsed the time-limit without submitting a statement of defense, the court
shall effect partition on the basis of the inventory of the property submitted by
other coparceners.
output: According to Section 223(1), Rule: If a person fails to submit an inventory within the time-limit under Section 222 or the time-limit elapses without a statement of defense, the court shall effect partition based on the inventory submitted by the other coparceners. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the heir missed the deadline or did not file a defense, the court may proceed to partition using the inventories provided by the other heirs without waiting further for the missing inventory.

instruction: My brother didn't file a defense and time expired — will the court still proceed with partition?

Application/Conclusion: Since your brother did not file a defense and the time expired, the court can lawfully proceed to partition using the inventories filed by the other coparceners.

instruction: If I agree to give the plaintiff a partition share, do I still have to list debts and assets?

instruction: Can I force partition if a coparcener has pledged a property and all coparceners agree?
input: Partition of pledged or mortgaged property : (1) If a coparcener is found to have pledged or mortgaged a property that is liable to partition, the court shall, if all the coparceners so agree, effect partition of the property by causing the property to be released from, or on the condition of having an obligation to release it from, the property in common.
output: According to Section 229(1). Rule: If a coparcener pledged or mortgaged property liable to partition, and all coparceners agree, the court will effect partition by causing the property to be released from common ownership or on condition of an obligation to release it. Application/Conclusion: Since all coparceners agree in your situation, you can ask the court to effect partition and have the pledged/mortgaged property released from common ownership (or released on condition). The court is empowered to do so under Section 229(1).

instruction: My father, the head of family, mortgaged a joint property and my siblings and I don't all agree to partition. What can the court do?
input: Section no 229  part (2) : If all the coparceners do not agree pursuant to sub section (1) and the court finds that the person acting as the head of family has pledged or mortgaged the property or that the other persons having attained majority living in the undivided family have, taking signature and thumb-impression also of the person acting as the head of family, pledged or mortgaged it, the court shall effect partition of the property by causing the property to be released from, or on the condition of having an obligation to release it from, the property in common.
output: According to Section 229(2). Rule: If not all coparceners agree and the court finds the head of family (or majors with the head's signature/thumb-impression) pledged or mortgaged the property, the court shall effect partition by releasing the property from common ownership or on condition of an obligation to release it. Application/Conclusion: Because your father (the head) mortgaged the property and not all coparceners agree, you can apply to the court to effect partition under Section 229(2). The court may partition by causing the property to be released from common ownership (or on condition of obligation to release).

instruction: One coparcener mortgaged our land without the head's consent and others disagree. What happens to partition?
input: Section no 229  part (3) : Save in the cases referred to in sub-section (1) or (2), if a coparcener is found to have pledged or mortgaged a property liable to partition, the court shall effect partition by causing the property to be released from, or on the condition of having an 128 obligation to release it from, the property falling in his or her partition share.
output: According to Section 229(3). Rule: Except where subsections (1) or (2) apply, if a coparcener alone pledged/mortgaged property liable to partition, the court will effect partition so that the property to be released corresponds to that coparcener's partition share. Application/Conclusion: Since this pledge/mortgage does not fall under (1) or (2), the court will partition the property so that the pledged/mortgaged portion falls within the pledging coparcener's share; you should seek partition under Section 229(3) to have the burden confined to that person's share.

instruction: I filed a partition suit and after the inventory I asked the court to withhold income from the property. Can the court do that?
input: Section no 230 . Power to withhold property or income until partition is : effected: If one filing a lawsuit appears to obtain a partition share in a case of partition and, after the inventory of property has been submitted, 67 makes a petition to the court, praying that the property to the extent of his or her partition share or income thereof be withheld, the court may withhold the property to the extent of his or her partition share or income of such property until partition is effected in the fulfillment of the legal requirements.
output: According to Section 230. Rule: After inventory is submitted, if a plaintiff petitions that property or its income up to their partition share be withheld, the court may withhold that property or income until partition is effected per legal requirements. Application/Conclusion: Yes — because you filed suit and submitted the inventory, you can petition the court to withhold the property or its income up to your partition share, and the court has discretion to do so until partition is completed under Section 230.

instruction: My parcel will have no road after partition. Who must provide access?
input: Section no 231 . Partition to be so effected as to have provision of way or : passage: While effecting partition, if there is no access to way or passage to a house or land partitioned to a coparcener and if such way or passage can be managed from the land of other coparcener, partition shall be so effected that the concerned coparcener shall have to provide the way or passage for access to such house or land.
output: According to Section 231. Rule: When a partitioned house or land lacks access and access can be managed from another coparcener's land, partition must be effected so that the concerned coparcener shall provide the way or passage for access. Application/Conclusion: If your parcel would be landlocked but access can be arranged across another coparcener's land, the partition should be done so that the coparcener who benefits must provide the necessary way or passage for access under Section 231.

instruction: Can the court assign the joint family debt to one coparcener without the creditor's consent?
input: Section no 232 . Debtor not to be specified without consent of creditor : (1) Partition shall not be so effected as to give the responsibility of payment of the debt of joint family to a sole coparcener without consent of the creditor.
output: According to Section 232(1). Rule: Partition cannot be made so as to place responsibility for repayment of the joint family debt solely on one coparcener without the creditor's consent. Application/Conclusion: No — the court should not assign the whole family debt to a single coparcener unless the creditor agrees. You cannot be made solely responsible for the joint family debt without creditor consent under Section 232(1).

instruction: If a partition court assigns the whole debt to one person despite creditor not consenting, are the other coparceners still liable?
input: Section no 232  part (2) : Even if the responsibility of payment of the debt is given solely to any coparcener contrary to sub-section (1), all the coparceners shall pay the debt in common equally, if the creditor does not so agree.
output: According to Section 232(2). Rule: If, contrary to subsection (1), responsibility is given solely to a coparcener without creditor agreement, all coparceners nevertheless remain jointly liable to pay the debt equally if the creditor does not agree to the sole allocation. Application/Conclusion: Even if the court assigns the debt to one person without the creditor's consent, the creditor can hold all coparceners equally liable — meaning you and other coparceners share equal liability for payment under Section 232(2).

instruction: Someone who wasn't entitled filed a partition suit against me. Can I get compensation?
input: Section no 233 . Compensation to be paid if lawsuit filed by person not entitled : to partition: If a person who is not entitled to receive a partition share is held to have filed a lawsuit for receiving it, the court shall order the law-suit filing person to pay to the defendant a reasonable compensation, having regard to the amount in controversy, if set out from the case-file, and if such amount is not set out, to the status of such a person.
output: According to Section 233. Rule: If a person not entitled to a partition share is held to have filed a suit to receive it, the court shall order that person to pay the defendant reasonable compensation, considering the amount in controversy or, if not set out, the person's status. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the court finds the plaintiff was not entitled and filed suit to receive a partition share, you can obtain an order for reasonable compensation against that person under Section 233, calculated based on the disputed amount or the plaintiff's status.

instruction: Under which section does the law say the court may withhold property or income until partition is effected?
input: Section no 230 . Power to withhold property or income until partition is : effected: If one filing a lawsuit appears to obtain a partition share in a case of partition and, after the inventory of property has been submitted, 67 makes a petition to the court, praying that the property to the extent of his or her partition share or income thereof be withheld, the court may withhold the property to the extent of his or her partition share or income of such property until partition is effected in the fulfillment of the legal requirements.
output: According to Section 230. Rule: Section 230 provides power to the court to withhold property or its income to the extent of a plaintiff's partition share until partition is effected. Application/Conclusion: The withholding power you ask about is set out in Section 230; you may rely on this section to petition the court to withhold property or income pending partition.

instruction: If all coparceners agree, can the court release a mortgaged property from common ownership on a condition?
input: Partition of pledged or mortgaged property : (1) If a coparcener is found to have pledged or mortgaged a property that is liable to partition, the court shall, if all the coparceners so agree, effect partition of the property by causing the property to be released from, or on the condition of having an obligation to release it from, the property in common.
output: According to Section 229(1). Rule: When all coparceners agree, the court shall effect partition by causing a pledged/mortgaged property to be released from common ownership or released on condition of an obligation to release it. Application/Conclusion: Yes — with unanimous agreement, the court can release the mortgaged property from common ownership or do so conditioned on an obligation to release, per Section 229(1).

instruction: The head of family signed a mortgage and others also signed with his thumb impression. We don't all agree — can partition still be done?
input: Section no 229  part (2) : If all the coparceners do not agree pursuant to sub section (1) and the court finds that the person acting as the head of family has pledged or mortgaged the property or that the other persons having attained majority living in the undivided family have, taking signature and thumb-impression also of the person acting as the head of family, pledged or mortgaged it, the court shall effect partition of the property by causing the property to be released from, or on the condition of having an obligation to release it from, the property in common.
output: According to Section 229(2). Rule: Even without unanimous agreement, if the head of family pledged/mortgaged the property or majors did so with the head's signature/thumb-impression, the court shall effect partition by releasing the property from common ownership or on condition of obligation to release. Application/Conclusion: Because the head's involvement meets the subsection's conditions, the court may proceed to effect partition and cause release from common ownership (or conditional release) despite lack of full agreement under Section 229(2).

instruction: A coparcener mortgaged property but neither everyone agreed nor did the head sign. Who bears the burden when court partitions?
input: Section no 229  part (3) : Save in the cases referred to in sub-section (1) or (2), if a coparcener is found to have pledged or mortgaged a property liable to partition, the court shall effect partition by causing the property to be released from, or on the condition of having an 128 obligation to release it from, the property falling in his or her partition share.
output: According to Section 229(3). Rule: Where neither subsection (1) nor (2) applies, a coparcener who pledged/mortgaged property shall have the property released from the portion that falls into his or her partition share. Application/Conclusion: Since the mortgage was done without unanimous consent and without the head's relevant involvement, the court will partition so that the pledged portion is confined to that coparcener's own share under Section 229(3).

instruction: I want the court to withhold the property to my partition share after we've submitted inventory — what must I do and what can court do?
input: Section no 230 . Power to withhold property or income until partition is : effected: If one filing a lawsuit appears to obtain a partition share in a case of partition and, after the inventory of property has been submitted, 67 makes a petition to the court, praying that the property to the extent of his or her partition share or income thereof be withheld, the court may withhold the property to the extent of his or her partition share or income of such property until partition is effected in the fulfillment of the legal requirements.
output: According to Section 230. Rule: After filing suit and submitting the inventory, a plaintiff may petition the court to withhold property or its income up to their partition share; the court has authority to withhold until partition is properly effected. Application/Conclusion: You should file a petition after submitting the inventory requesting withholding; the court may grant withholding of the property or its income to the extent of your partition share until partition is completed under Section 230.

instruction: During partition, will the court order creation of a passage if my allocated land has no access?
input: Section no 231 . Partition to be so effected as to have provision of way or : passage: While effecting partition, if there is no access to way or passage to a house or land partitioned to a coparcener and if such way or passage can be managed from the land of other coparcener, partition shall be so effected that the concerned coparcener shall have to provide the way or passage for access to such house or land.
output: According to Section 231. Rule: If a partitioned plot lacks access and access can be arranged from another coparcener's land, partition must be effected so that the concerned coparcener provides the necessary way or passage. Application/Conclusion: The court should arrange partition to secure access — the coparcener whose land can provide the access must provide the way or passage, ensuring your parcel has access under Section 231.

instruction: If a creditor refuses to accept assignment of debt to one person, can partition nevertheless allocate the debt to a sole coparcener?
input:
Section no 232 . Debtor not to be specified without consent of creditor : (1) Partition shall not be so effected as to give the responsibility of payment of the debt of joint family to a sole coparcener without consent of the creditor.
 Section no 232  part (2) : Even if the responsibility of payment of the debt is given solely to any coparcener contrary to sub-section (1), all the coparceners shall pay the debt in common equally, if the creditor does not so agree.
output: According to Section 232(1) and 232(2). Rule: (1) Partition cannot assign sole responsibility for joint family debt to one coparcener without creditor consent. Application/Conclusion: The court should not allocate the debt solely to one person without creditor consent. instruction: Someone who had no right to a share sued us for partition — how does the court calculate compensation?
input: Section no 233 . Compensation to be paid if lawsuit filed by person not entitled : to partition: If a person who is not entitled to receive a partition share is held to have filed a lawsuit for receiving it, the court shall order the law-suit filing person to pay to the defendant a reasonable compensation, having regard to the amount in controversy, if set out from the case-file, and if such amount is not set out, to the status of such a person.
output: According to Section 233. Rule: The court orders a plaintiff found not entitled to a partition share to pay reasonable compensation to the defendant, considering the amount in controversy if set out, or otherwise the plaintiff's status. Application/Conclusion: Compensation will be assessed based on the disputed amount shown in the file; if that amount isn't set out, the court will consider the plaintiff's status to determine reasonable compensation under Section 233. You can request such compensation when the filer lacks entitlement.

instruction: Can the court effect partition by making the mortgaged property be released from the property in common on condition of obligation to release?
input: Partition of pledged or mortgaged property : (1) If a coparcener is found to have pledged or mortgaged a property that is liable to partition, the court shall, if all the coparceners so agree, effect partition of the property by causing the property to be released from, or on the condition of having an obligation to release it from, the property in common.
output: According to Section 229(1). Rule: The court may effect partition by causing a mortgaged/pledged property to be released from common ownership or by releasing it on condition of an obligation to release. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the statute explicitly allows the court to release a mortgaged property from the property in common on condition of an obligation to release it, when the coparceners agree, so you can seek that outcome under Section 229(1).

instruction: I want to know: if a person not entitled files a partition suit, does the law mandate any remedy for the defendant?
input: Section no 233 . Compensation to be paid if lawsuit filed by person not entitled : to partition: If a person who is not entitled to receive a partition share is held to have filed a lawsuit for receiving it, the court shall order the law-suit filing person to pay to the defendant a reasonable compensation, having regard to the amount in controversy, if set out from the case-file, and if such amount is not set out, to the status of such a person.
output: According to Section 233. Rule: The law mandates that a plaintiff not entitled to a partition share who filed suit must pay reasonable compensation to the defendant, based on the amount in controversy or the plaintiff's status. Application/Conclusion: There is a statutory remedy for defendants — you can obtain reasonable compensation from a baseless filer under Section 233, calculated as the court deems appropriate.

instruction: I am the son of a deceased person and I came forward within the deadline. Do I get any of the property that was kept by the person who performed the funeral?
input:
Section no 249  part (6) : If the heir of the deceased appears within the
time-limit referred to in sub-section (4) or (5), the property that remains after
deducting therefrom the expenses incurred in the performance of obsequies of
the dead person or providing such expenses the person having performed such
obsequies, and ten percent of the property, shall be returned to the concerned
heir.
output:
According to Section 249 part (6):
Rule: If an heir appears within the stated time-limit, the person who performed the obsequies may be reimbursed for funeral expenses from the estate, and after that deduction the remaining property, plus ten percent of the property, shall be returned to the concerned heir.
Application/Conclusion: Because you appeared within the deadline as an heir, the estate-holder must deduct funeral expenses paid to the person who performed the obsequies and then return the remaining property (including ten percent of the property) to you.

instruction: What happens if no heir can be found after the time limit?
input:
Section no 249  part (7) : If no heir of the dead person appears within the
time limit referred to in sub-section (4) or (5) or his or her address is not traced
out, the property that remains after providing the expenses incurred in the
performance of obsequies of the deceased to the person having performed such
obsequies shall devolve on the Local Level.
output:
According to Section 249 part (7):
Rule: If no heir appears within the specified time or the heir's address cannot be traced, after paying funeral expenses to the person who performed the obsequies, the remaining property devolves to the Local Level.
Application/Conclusion: If you cannot be located or no heir comes forward in time, the estate (after funeral expense payment) will pass to the Local Level rather than to private individuals.

instruction: I performed the funeral for a person who died and no family turned up. Can the local government use that property however it likes?
input:
Section no 249  part (8) : The property received by the Local Level pursuant
to this Section shall be used only for public interest. 139
output:
According to Section 249 part (8):
Rule: Property received by the Local Level under this Section must be used only for public interest.
Application/Conclusion: The Local Level cannot use the property for private gain; it must allocate or use the inherited property for public-interest purposes.

instruction: I just learned someone opened succession years ago. How long do I have to file a lawsuit about succession matters?
input:
Section no 250 . Statute of limitation : A lawsuit may be made within the
statute of limitation, if any, set forth elsewhere in this Chapter, and in the other
cases, within a period of three years after the date on which the succession is
opened. 140 Part-4 Laws Relating to Property Chapter-1 General Provisions
Relating to Property
output:
According to Section 250:
Rule: A lawsuit must be filed within any specific limitation set elsewhere in the Chapter; otherwise, the default period is three years from the date the succession is opened.
Application/Conclusion: Unless another provision in the Chapter gives a different time limit for your particular claim, you generally have three years from the date succession opened to bring a lawsuit.

instruction: In simple words, what counts as 'property' under the law?
input:
Section no 251 . Deemed to be property : Any cash, goods or work shall be
deemed to be a property if such cash, goods or action can be used or transacted
in or the title thereto can be transferred by way of purchase, sale or otherwise or
any benefit can be derived therefrom. Explanation: Except otherwise provided
for in this Act, the term “goods” means a physical property capable of being
purchased or sold.
output:
According to Section 251:
Rule: Anything (cash, goods, or work/acts) that can be used, transacted, transferred by purchase/sale/other means, or from which a benefit can be derived is 'property.' 'Goods' generally means physical things that can be bought or sold.
Application/Conclusion: In everyday terms, money, physical items, and even actions that produce transferable benefits are treated as property under the law — so your convertible assets, earnings, or sellable items can all be legally 'property.'

instruction: Is a thing always movable or immovable? How does the statute treat that?
input:
Section no 252 .
Property deemed to be in movable or immovable
form : A property shall be deemed to be in either movable or immovable form
irrespective of its physical or non-physical, tangible or intangible form.
output:
According to Section 252:
Rule: Property is classified as either movable or immovable regardless of whether it is physical/non-physical or tangible/intangible.
Application/Conclusion: The legal classification (movable vs immovable) depends on statutory definitions, not on whether the item is physical or intangible — so you must check the listed categories to know which class applies.

instruction: Is my house considered immovable property under the law?
input:
Section no 253 . Property deemed to be immovable : (1) The following
property shall be deemed to be an immovable property:
Section no 253  clause (a) : A building or land or structure fixed thereto,
output:
According to Section 253 clause (a):
Rule: A building, land, or a structure fixed to land is deemed immovable property.
Application/Conclusion: Your house qualifies as immovable property because it is a building fixed to land.

instruction: What about things that are attached permanently to a building — are those immovable?
input: Section no 253  clause (b) : Any goods attached to a building or land permanently,
output:
According to Section 253 clause (b):
Rule: Goods permanently attached to a building or land are deemed immovable property.
Application/Conclusion: Permanently fixed fixtures (for example built-in cabinetry or permanently affixed machinery) are treated as immovable under this clause.

instruction: Are minerals like stones or ores in the ground treated as movable or immovable?
input: Section no 253  clause (c) : A mine, stone or mineral embedded in land,
output:
According to Section 253 clause (c):
Rule: A mine, stone, or mineral embedded in land is deemed immovable property.
Application/Conclusion: Minerals or stones embedded in the soil are legally immovable — they form part of the land until lawfully severed.

instruction: Is groundwater or a pond considered immovable property?
input:
Section no 253  clause (d) : Natural water, surface water and underground
water,
output:
According to Section 253 clause (d):
Rule: Natural water, surface water and underground (ground) water are deemed immovable property.
Application/Conclusion: Groundwater and natural water bodies are treated as immovable under the statute, so they are part of the land for legal purposes.

instruction: What about a house built to float on a lake permanently — is that immovable?
input: Section no 253  clause (e) : A building or other structure so made permanently that it can float over a river, lake or pond, 141
output:
According to Section 253 clause (e):
Rule: A building or structure constructed permanently so it can float over a river, lake or pond is deemed immovable property.
Application/Conclusion: A permanently floated structure (for example a permanently moored floating house designed to remain afloat) is treated as immovable.

instruction: Are trees and crops on land considered immovable?
input:
Section no 253  clause (f) : A standing tree, plant or fruit tree or fruit or
flower growing on such a tree, plant or fruit tree or crops in the land, or
output:
According to Section 253 clause (f):
Rule: Standing trees, plants, fruit on trees, and crops in the land are deemed immovable property.
Application/Conclusion: Trees and crops growing on land are legally immovable, so they form part of the immovable property until removed.

instruction: If I attach a machine to a building, does it become immovable?
input:
Section no 253  clause (g) : A movable property attached to an immovable
property.
output:
According to Section 253 clause (g):
Rule: A movable property that is attached to an immovable property is deemed immovable.
Application/Conclusion: If your machine is attached to the immovable property (in a manner covered by the statute), it may be treated as immovable for legal purposes.

instruction: If something fixed to land is later detached, does it remain immovable?
input:
Section no 253  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if any structure, goods or any part thereof, fixed or attached to any immovable property gets or is detached or unfixed in any manner, the structure, goods
or part so detached or unfixed shall be deemed to be a movable property.
output:
According to Section 253 part (2):
Rule: If any structure or goods fixed to immovable property are detached or unfixed, the detached items become movable property.
Application/Conclusion: If a previously fixed item (for example a built-in fixture) is detached, it will be considered movable after detachment, not immovable.

instruction: Is cash considered movable property?
input:
Section no 254 . Property deemed to be movable : The following property
shall be deemed to be a movable property:
Section no 254  clause (a) : Cash or goods that can be transacted as cash or
foreign currency,
output:
According to Section 254 clause (a):
Rule: Cash and goods that can be transacted as cash or foreign currency are deemed movable property.
Application/Conclusion: Cash is explicitly movable property under the law, so monetary assets are movable.

instruction: Are gold, silver and jewelry treated as movable property under the statute?
input: Section no 254  clause (b) : Gold, silver, jewelry, Ratna, gold or silver ornament or precious stone,
output:
According to Section 254 clause (b):
Rule: Gold, silver, jewelry, precious stones and similar items are deemed movable property.
Application/Conclusion: Your gold and jewelry are movable property and will be treated as such in legal transactions or succession.

instruction: I have goods that I can lift and move to another city. Legally, are these movable?
input:
Section no 254  clause (c) : Other good that can be moved from one place
to another, except those referred in clause (a) or (b),
output:
According to Section 254 clause (c):
Rule: Goods that can be moved from one place to another (other than cash, currency or precious metals/stones listed earlier) are deemed movable property.
Application/Conclusion: Items you can physically move and transport are legally movable; you can treat them as movable property for sale, transfer or succession matters.

instruction: Can I sell property I inherit if my brother refuses to accept the succession?
input: part (3) : If a person does not accept a succession within the period referred to in sub-section (2), such succession shall be deemed to have been devolved upon the other heir in the successive order of preference for succession.
output: According to Section 244(3): Rule: If an heir does not accept succession within the prescribed period, the succession is deemed to have devolved on the next heir in order. Application/Conclusion: If your brother formally and timely declines or does not accept the succession, the law treats the succession as passed to the next entitled heir — if that next heir is you, you become the person on whom succession has devolved and, subject to other obligations (like debts and funeral costs), you would have the rights to deal with the inherited property (including selling it).

instruction: Do I still have to perform the funeral rites even if I refuse to accept inheritance?
input: Section no 244  part (4) : Even if a person does not accept a succession pursuant to sub-section (1), he or she shall have to conduct obsequies of the deceased in accordance with the rites and rituals.
output: According to Section 244(4): Rule: A person who does not accept succession is nevertheless required to conduct the deceased's obsequies according to rites and rituals. Application/Conclusion: Refusing the inheritance does not relieve you of the duty to perform the funeral/obsequies; you remain legally obliged to carry out those rites.

instruction: My cousin murdered the decedent to get the land. Can that cousin inherit?
input: Section no 245 . Disqualified for succession : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a person who kills, or causes the death of, another person with intent to serve any premeditation or with ulterior motive to obtain succession, such person and the heir to the person who so kills or causes death shall be disqualified from the succession of the deceased or his or her heir.
output: According to Section 245: Rule: A person who kills or causes death with premeditation or to obtain succession, and that person's heir, are disqualified from succeeding to the deceased's estate. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin killed the decedent with the motive of obtaining succession, both the cousin and the cousin's heirs are disqualified from inheriting; they cannot claim succession under this Chapter.

instruction: What are my duties if succession devolves on me? (short list)
input: Section no 246 . Obligations and rights of person upon whom succession is : devolved: (1) The obligations and rights of the person upon whom succession is devolved shall be as follows:
output: According to Section 246(1): Rule: The statute sets out specific obligations and rights for the person on whom succession devolves. Application/Conclusion: When succession is devolved on you, the law requires you to follow the listed obligations and entitles you to the listed rights (the detailed duties and rights are then specified in the sub-clauses of Section 246).

instruction: Am I required to conduct the funeral rites if I've inherited the property?
input: Section no 246  clause (a) : To perform, or cause to be performed, funeral and obsequies rites of the deceased according to his or her rites and rituals,
output: According to Section 246(1)(a): Rule: The heir on whom succession devolves must perform or ensure performance of the deceased's funeral and obsequies according to rites and rituals. Application/Conclusion: As the person who inherits, you have a legal obligation to perform or arrange the funeral/obsequies in accordance with the deceased's rites.

instruction: Do I have to pay the deceased’s loans if I inherit?
input: Section no 246  clause (b) : To repay the debt borrowed by the deceased to the creditor,
output: According to Section 246(1)(b): Rule: The heir is obliged to repay debts borrowed by the deceased to creditors. Application/Conclusion: If you inherit, you are responsible for repaying the deceased's debts from the succession (subject to limits discussed elsewhere, e.g., not beyond the value of the inherited estate).

instruction: I lent money to my late friend. Does the heir get that debt obligation?
input: Section no 246  clause (c) : To have right over the debt lent and investment made by the deceased. 135
output: According to Section 246(1)(c): Rule: The person on whom succession devolves has rights over debts lent by the deceased and investments made by the deceased. Application/Conclusion: If you were the deceased's creditor or investor, the heir who receives succession has the right to collect debt or benefit from investments the deceased made; you may claim repayment from the heir who succeeded to the estate.

instruction: Someone else performed the funeral for my late parent — can I make them pay back costs?
input: Section no 246  part (2) : If the funeral and obsequies rites of a deceased has been performed by a person other than one who is entitled to the succession, the person so entitled shall pay the costs incurred in the performance of funeral and obsequies rites of the deceased and additional twenty-five percent of such costs to the person who has performed such rites. Provided that if any person has, instead of doing on his or her own, caused another person to perform the funeral and obsequies rites of the deceased, he or she shall be liable to pay only the actual costs incurred in the performance of such rites.
output: According to Section 246(2): Rule: If someone not entitled to succession performed the funeral, the entitled heir must reimburse the costs plus an additional 25%; if the entitled person caused another to perform the rites, they pay only actual costs. Application/Conclusion: As the heir, you must reimburse the person who performed the funeral for actual costs plus 25%. If you arranged for someone else to carry out the rites, you only owe the actual expenses.

instruction: Can creditors take money from the heir who gets the property?
input: Section no 247 . Creditor may recover debt : If succession to one’s property is opened and one has creditors, such creditors may recover their debts and liabilities from the person upon whom succession has devolved. Provided that no heir shall be obliged to pay debts and liabilities in excess of the deceased’s property succeeded to by him or her.
output: According to Section 247: Rule: Creditors can recover debts from the person on whom succession devolved, but heirs are not liable beyond the value of the property they succeeded to. Application/Conclusion: Creditors may claim repayment from you as the heir, but you are not personally liable to pay more than the total value of the inherited estate.

instruction: There were no family members. Who gets the leftover property after funeral costs and debts?
input: Section no 248 . Local Level to receive property under succession : (1) If succession to the property of a person is opened and he or she has no heir or his or her heir declines to accept such succession, the property of the dead person remaining after deducting the costs incurred in the performance of his or her funeral and obsequies rites and even after payment of debts due to his or her creditors shall be devolved on the Local Level.
output: According to Section 248(1): Rule: If there is no heir or the heir declines succession, the remaining property after funeral costs and creditor payments devolves to the Local Level. Application/Conclusion: When a deceased has no accepting heirs, any estate left after paying funeral expenses and debts becomes property of the Local Level (local government).

instruction: I performed the obsequies for a person who had no heirs — what must I do next?
input: Section no 248  part (2) : If a person dies and has no heir but has property, a person who performs his or her obsequies or maintains his or her 136 books and accounts shall immediately give a notice thereof to the Local Level.
output: According to Section 248(2): Rule: A person who performs obsequies or maintains accounts of a person with no heirs must immediately notify the Local Level. Application/Conclusion: You must promptly notify the Local Level that you performed the rites or are maintaining the deceased's books/accounts so the Local Level can take the next procedural steps.

instruction: After I notify the Local Level about a property with no heir, what will they do?
input: Section no 248  part (3) : If a notice is received pursuant to sub-section (2), the Local Level shall prepare an inventory of the properties of the deceased in witness of at two local persons and forward the inventory, accompanied by a copy of the memorandum (Muchulka) executed to that effect, to the concerned district level administrative oﬀice.
output: According to Section 248(3): Rule: Upon receiving the notice, the Local Level must prepare an inventory of the deceased's properties in the presence of two local witnesses and forward that inventory with a memorandum to the district administrative office. Application/Conclusion: After your notice, the Local Level will inventory the property with two witnesses and send the record and memorandum to the district administration for further action.

instruction: If I caused someone else to perform the funeral, do I get the 25% extra paid to the performer?
input: Section no 246  part (2) : If the funeral and obsequies rites of a deceased has been performed by a person other than one who is entitled to the succession, the person so entitled shall pay the costs incurred in the performance of funeral and obsequies rites of the deceased and additional twenty-five percent of such costs to the person who has performed such rites. Provided that if any person has, instead of doing on his or her own, caused another person to perform the funeral and obsequies rites of the deceased, he or she shall be liable to pay only the actual costs incurred in the performance of such rites.
output: According to Section 246(2): Rule: The entitled heir must pay the performer costs plus 25%; however, if the entitled person caused another to perform the rites, that person owes only the actual costs. Application/Conclusion: If you arranged for someone else to perform the funeral rather than performing it yourself, you are liable only for the actual costs — you do not have to pay the additional 25% to the performer.

instruction: Under which section is disqualification for succession stated?
input: Section no 245 . Disqualified for succession : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a person who kills, or causes the death of, another person with intent to serve any premeditation or with ulterior motive to obtain succession, such person and the heir to the person who so kills or causes death shall be disqualified from the succession of the deceased or his or her heir.
output: According to Section 245: Rule: Section 245 sets out disqualification from succession where a person kills or causes death with premeditation or to obtain succession; that person and their heir are disqualified. Application/Conclusion: Disqualification for succession is provided under Section 245 — if someone caused the death to obtain inheritance, they (and their heirs) cannot succeed.

instruction: My uncle ignored the notice and didn't accept succession. What's the legal consequence?
input: part (3) : If a person does not accept a succession within the period referred to in sub-section (2), such succession shall be deemed to have been devolved upon the other heir in the successive order of preference for succession.
output: According to Section 244(3): Rule: Failure to accept succession within the prescribed period results in the succession being deemed to have devolved to the next heir in line. Application/Conclusion: If your uncle failed to accept succession in time, the succession automatically passes to the next entitled heir according to the order of preference — your uncle loses his right to that succession.

instruction: I am a creditor. Where can I recover my debt if the debtor died?
input: Section no 247 . Creditor may recover debt : If succession to one’s property is opened and one has creditors, such creditors may recover their debts and liabilities from the person upon whom succession has devolved. Provided that no heir shall be obliged to pay debts and liabilities in excess of the deceased’s property succeeded to by him or her.
output: According to Section 247: Rule: Creditors may recover debts from the person on whom succession has devolved, but not beyond the value of the inherited property. Application/Conclusion: As a creditor, you can claim repayment from the heir who succeeded to the estate; however, you cannot force that heir to pay more than the total value of the property they inherited.

instruction: If no one claims the estate and I found the deceased's accounts, what must I do?
input: Section no 248  part (2) : If a person dies and has no heir but has property, a person who performs his or her obsequies or maintains his or her 136 books and accounts shall immediately give a notice thereof to the Local Level.
output: According to Section 248(2): Rule: A person who performs obsequies or maintains the deceased's books/accounts when there is no heir must immediately notify the Local Level. Application/Conclusion: You should promptly notify the Local Level that you are maintaining the deceased's accounts or performed the rites so the Local Level can proceed with inventory and further administration.

instruction: Can I ask the court to enforce a partition or payment after a judgment if I haven't received my share?
input: Partition share, money or expenditure may be awarded : (1) If a person who is entitled to obtain a partition share, money or expenditure from any person according to the judgment, files, having failed to so receive, a petition in the court of first instance which has passed judgment in the case, the court shall, if the parties are the same, cause the partition, money or expenditure according to the judgment to be awarded as soon as possible.
output: According to Section 234(1): Rule: If someone entitled under a judgment has not received their partition share, money or expenditure, they may file a petition in the same court of first instance that passed the judgment. The court must, where the parties are the same, cause the partition or payment to be awarded as soon as possible. Application/Conclusion: You can petition that same court to enforce the judgment and obtain the partition or payment; the court is required to act promptly to award what the judgment ordered.

instruction: They still didn't give me the money after the court order. Can I get compensation?
input: Section no 234  part (2) : If the partition share, expenditure or money is not provided pursuant to sub-section (1), the person who has to provide the partition share, money or expenditure shall be caused to pay a reasonable compensation as well to the petitioner.
output: According to Section 234(2): Rule: If the partition share, expenditure or money is not provided pursuant to subsection (1), the person obligated to provide it shall be caused to pay reasonable compensation to the petitioner. Application/Conclusion: Yes. If the ordered share or money is not delivered under Section 234(1), you can seek reasonable compensation from the person who should have provided it.

instruction: I never got a partition—how long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 235  clause (a) : Any time, where partition has never been effected or a common general deed has been executed in effecting partition and even though there is no deed where both the parties have enjoyed the property upon making calculation,
output: According to Section 235(a): Rule: Where a partition has never been effected (or only a general deed or informal enjoyment has occurred), a person may bring a lawsuit at any time. Application/Conclusion: If no formal partition was ever carried out, you are not bound by a short limitation period — you may file a suit at any time to seek partition.

instruction: I was unhappy with a partition made recently. How long do I have to challenge it?
input: Section no 235  clause (b) : Within three months from the date of partition if one is not satisfied with such partition, 130
output: According to Section 235(b): Rule: If a person is not satisfied with a partition, they must file suit within three months from the date of that partition. Application/Conclusion: You have three months from the date the partition was effected to challenge it; if more than three months have passed, this provision bars the claim unless another exception applies.

instruction: I found out that my co-heir hid some property. Is there any time limit to sue?
input: Section no 235  clause (c) : In case of concealing or hiding of property, till the life of the concerned coparcener,
output: According to Section 235(c): Rule: In cases of concealing or hiding of property, the aggrieved person may make a lawsuit until the life of the concerned coparcener. Application/Conclusion: If property was concealed, you can bring a suit at any time during the life of that coparcener — there is no short fixed limitation period in such concealment cases.

instruction: If my grievance doesn't fit the special cases, how long do I have to file after the wrongful act?
input:
Section no 235  clause (d) : In the cases other than that referred to in clauses (a),

Section no 235  clause (b) : and (c), within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action taken.
output: According to Section 235(d) (read with the continuation): Rule: For cases other than those in clauses (a) and (c), a lawsuit must be filed within six months after the date on which the act was done or the action taken. Application/Conclusion: If your situation is not covered by the 'no partition' exception or the concealment exception, you generally have six months from the date of the act to bring a lawsuit.

instruction: Where is the statute of limitation for actions under this Chapter stated?
input: Section no 235 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit as follows:
output: According to Section 235: Rule: Section 235 sets out the statute of limitation for actions under this Chapter and then enumerates the specific time limits in its clauses. Application/Conclusion: For time limits on suits relating to partition and related acts, refer to Section 235 and its clauses (a)–(d); that is the statutory provision governing limitation periods here.

instruction: There was a partition done before this Act came into force. Does the law treat it as valid now?
input: Section no 236 . Partition deemed to be executed : (1) A partition effected pursuant to the law prior to the commencement of this Act shall be deemed to have been effected pursuant to this Act.
output: According to Section 236(1): Rule: Partitions effected under the law before this Act commenced are deemed to have been effected under this Act. Application/Conclusion: Yes. A partition carried out before the Act's commencement is treated as valid and as if it were effected under the present Act.

instruction: I accepted "Jiuni" (maintenance for living) instead of my share before this Act started. Is that considered taking my partition share?
input: Section no 236  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if a person has taken maintenance for living ( Jiuni ) in consideration for his or her partition share prior to the commencement of this Act, the person shall be deemed to have taken his or her partition share.
output: According to Section 236(2): Rule: If a person took maintenance for living (Jiuni) as consideration for their partition share prior to the commencement of the Act, they are deemed to have taken their partition share. Application/Conclusion: If you accepted Jiuni in lieu of your partition share before the Act began, the law treats that as having taken your partition share.

instruction: When does succession to a deceased person's property open?
input:
Section no 237 . Succession deemed to be opened : Upon the death of a person, succession to his or her property shall be deemed to be opened.
Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “succession” means devolution of liabilities and rights in regard to debt, wealth and property of the deceased upon his or her heirs in accordance with law.
output: According to Section 237: Rule: Succession is deemed to open upon a person's death; succession means the devolution of the deceased's liabilities and rights regarding debt, wealth and property to his or her heirs under the law. Application/Conclusion: Succession begins at death — from that moment heirs inherit both rights and liabilities of the deceased in accordance with the law.

instruction: Who is entitled to succeed when someone dies?
input: Section no 238 . Heir entitled to succession : Where succession to a person’s property is opened, his or her nearest heir shall be entitled to such succession.
output: According to Section 238: Rule: When succession opens, the nearest heir is entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: The person or persons considered the nearest heir(s) under the law will inherit the deceased's estate when succession opens.

instruction: Is the spouse living in the undivided family first in line to inherit?
input: Section no 239  clause (a) : Husband or wife living in the undivided family,
output: According to Section 239(a): Rule: The husband or wife living in the undivided family is listed as the first preference among nearest heirs. Application/Conclusion: A spouse who was living in the undivided family has priority in the order of preference for succession under Section 239.

instruction: Do children and a widow daughter-in-law living in the undivided family get preference in succession?
input: Section no 239  clause (b) : Son, daughter, widow daughter-in-law living in the undivided family,
output: According to Section 239(b): Rule: Sons, daughters, and a widow daughter-in-law living in the undivided family are included among the preferred nearest heirs. Application/Conclusion: Yes — children and a widow daughter-in-law residing in the undivided family are given preference in the order of succession.

instruction: Are parents and grandchildren included among preferred heirs?
input: Section no 239  clause (c) : Father, mother, step mother, grand-son, grand daughter, grand-daughter-in-law, on the side of son or daughter, living in the undivided family,
output: According to Section 239(c): Rule: Fathers, mothers, step-mothers, grand-sons, grand-daughters and grand-daughter-in-law on the side of son or daughter who live in the undivided family are included in the order of preference. Application/Conclusion: Parents and certain grandchildren who lived in the undivided family are among the heirs with preference for succession under this clause.

instruction: What about separated relatives — do they appear in the order of succession?

Section no 239  clause (d) : Separated husband, wife, son, daughter, father, mother, step-mother,

Application/Conclusion: Separated family members are specifically included in the succession order; they receive a position in the hierarchy as set out in clauses (d)–(f).

instruction: Which section tells me the court must act promptly to award partition or payment stated in a judgment?
input: Partition share, money or expenditure may be awarded : (1) If a person who is entitled to obtain a partition share, money or expenditure from any person according to the judgment, files, having failed to so receive, a petition in the court of first instance which has passed judgment in the case, the court shall, if the parties are the same, cause the partition, money or expenditure according to the judgment to be awarded as soon as possible.
output: According to Section 234(1): Rule: The court of first instance that passed the judgment must, upon petition by an entitled person who has not received the partition or payment, cause the partition or payment to be awarded as soon as possible when the parties are the same. Application/Conclusion: Section 234(1) is the provision requiring the court to act promptly to enforce a judgment ordering partition or payment.

instruction: If my two sisters and I are in the same order of preference, how is the inheritance divided?
input:
If there are more than one heir in the same order
of preference pursuant to sub-section (1), all of them shall equally be entitled
to the succession.

 Section no 239  part (3)
output: According to Section 239(3)... Rule: When more than one heir exists in the same order of preference, all of them are equally entitled to the succession. Application/Conclusion: You and your two sisters each get an equal share of the inheritance under that order.

instruction: My cousin was serving my late uncle. Can my cousin claim the inheritance instead of me (a nearer heir) while I'm also being served by my uncle?
input:
So long as the person who is in the first order of
preference referred to in sub-section (1) at the time when succession to one’s
property is open is serving the person in the subsequent order of preference shall
not be entitled to succession.

 Section no 239  part (2)
output: According to Section 239(2)... Rule: If a person in the first order of preference is serving someone in a subsequent order at the time succession opens, that subsequent person shall not be entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: If you are a nearer heir (first order) and you are being served by the person in a subsequent order, that subsequent person (your cousin) cannot claim succession while they are being served by you.

instruction: My elder brother says he won't accept the inheritance. Who gets it then?
input:
If any heir in the order of preference entitled to
succession does not intend to succeed, the other heirs in the same order shall be
entitled to succession, and even any heir in that order of preference does not
intend to accept succession, the heir in the successive order of preference shall
be entitled to the succession.

 Section no 239  part (4)
output: According to Section 239(4)... Rule: If an heir in a given order refuses succession, other heirs in that same order take it; if none in that order accept, succession passes to the next order. Application/Conclusion: If your elder brother refuses, other heirs in the same order (e.g., you or other siblings) get the share; if all in that order refuse, heirs in the next order will be entitled.

instruction: Is my uncle entitled to inherit if he lived in the joint family?
input:
Section no 239  clause (h) : Uncle, aunt, nephew, niece, living in the joint
family,
output: According to Section 239(h)... Rule: Uncle (and aunt, nephew, niece) living in the joint family are included among heirs. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your uncle lived in the joint family and succession is open, he is among the persons entitled under that clause.

instruction: Are daughters-in-law (widow elder brother’s wife) considered heirs in the undivided family?

Grand-father, grand-mother, elder brother,
younger brother, elder sister, younger sister, widow elder brother’s wife or

69
 Section no 239  clause (g)
output: According to Section 239(g)... Rule: Widow elder brother’s wife or younger brother’s wife living in the undivided family are listed among heirs. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a widow of an elder or younger brother who lives in the undivided family is included as an heir under this clause.

instruction: I lived apart after taking my partition share and cared for my father who died while staying with me — do I have succession rights?
input:
(1) If a person dies when that person was staying with any heir who has lived separately, after taking his or her partition share of property, because an un separated heir has not maintained (Shyahar samhar) and taken care of that person, such separated heir shall be entitled to the succession of that person.

 Section no 242 . Separated heir entitled to succession : (1)
output: According to Section 242(1)... Rule: A separated heir who has lived separately after taking partition share and has the deceased staying with them because an unseparated heir did not maintain the deceased shall be entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: Since you lived separately after taking partition and your father stayed with you because others did not maintain him, you are entitled to succession.

instruction: But what if my father stayed with me only for a few days and hadn't taken any partition share — can I claim succession?
input:
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if a person dies when that person was staying with any heir only for few
days, without taking his or her partition share of property, the heir with whom
that person had so stayed shall not be entitled to succession of that person.

 Section no 242  part (2)
output: According to Section 242(2)... Rule: If the deceased stayed with an heir only for a few days and had not taken partition share, that heir is not entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: If your father stayed with you only briefly and you had not taken a partition share, you cannot claim succession based on that short stay.

instruction: My distant cousin looked after my deceased uncle and kept him when nearer heirs didn't. Can that distant cousin inherit?
input:
If a nearer heir has not maintained and taken care of
a person but a distant heir has done so, the distant heir who has so maintained
and taken care of him or her shall be entitled to succession.

 Section no 241 . Maintaining (Shyahar samhar) and caretaking heir
entitled to : succession:
output: According to Section 241... Rule: A distant heir who maintained and took care of the deceased when nearer heirs did not shall be entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: Yes — because the distant cousin cared for your uncle while nearer heirs failed to, that distant cousin is entitled to succession.

instruction: I (a non-relative) cared for my neighbor for years because the family wouldn't. If they died, can I claim succession?
input:
Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if another person has maintained (Shyahar samhar) and taken care of the deceased because the heir has not done so, the person who has so maintained (Shyahar samhar) and taken care of shall be entitled to such succession.

 Section no 243 . Maintaining (Shyahar samhar) and caretaking person
entitled : to succession:
output: According to Section 243... Rule: Even if not an heir, a person who maintained and took care of the deceased because the heir did not shall be entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: Yes — as the non-relative caregiver who maintained the deceased in place of negligent heirs, you can be entitled to succession under this provision.

instruction: Under which section is 'Distant heir entitled to succession' described?
input:
Section no 240 . Distant heir entitled to succession : If a person dies when
he or she was staying with any distant heir after taking his or her partition share
of property in spite of having his or her nearer heir and succession to him or
her is open, the heir with whom that person was so staying shall be entitled to
his or her property succession. 133
output: According to Section 240... Rule: Section 240 defines when a distant heir is entitled to succession — specifically when the deceased died while staying with that distant heir after taking partition share despite having nearer heirs. Application/Conclusion: The rule for distant heirs claiming succession is set out in Section 240; if those conditions are met, the distant heir with whom the deceased stayed is entitled.

instruction: My uncle took his partition share and lived with my aunt until he died. There were nearer heirs but they neglected him. Who gets succession?
input:
If a person dies when he or she was staying with any distant heir after taking his or her partition share of property in spite of having his or her nearer heir and succession to him or her is open, the heir with whom that person was so staying shall be entitled to his or her property succession. 133

 Section no 240 . Distant heir entitled to succession :
output: According to Section 240... Rule: If the deceased died while staying with a distant heir after taking partition share despite having nearer heirs, the heir with whom they stayed is entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: Since your uncle stayed with your aunt after taking partition share and nearer heirs existed, your aunt (the heir with whom he stayed) is entitled to his succession under Section 240.

instruction: My brother refuses succession. I'm the only other heir in that order. Do I automatically get everything?
input:
If any heir in the order of preference entitled to
succession does not intend to succeed, the other heirs in the same order shall be
entitled to succession, and even any heir in that order of preference does not
intend to accept succession, the heir in the successive order of preference shall
be entitled to the succession.

 Section no 239  part (4)
output: According to Section 239(4)... Rule: If an heir refuses succession, the remaining heirs in the same order become entitled; if none accept, the next order gets succession. Application/Conclusion: Since your brother refused and you are the only remaining heir in that order, you are entitled to the succession that would have passed in that order.

instruction: I was caring for my elderly aunt because her nearer heirs ignored her. She died and left property. The nearer heirs now challenge my right. What does the law say?
input:
Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if another person has maintained (Shyahar samhar) and taken care of the deceased because the heir has not done so, the person who has so maintained (Shyahar samhar) and taken care of shall be entitled to such succession.

 Section no 243 . Maintaining (Shyahar samhar) and caretaking person
entitled : to succession:
output: According to Section 243... Rule: A person who maintained and took care of the deceased because the heir did not shall be entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: Your caretaking gives you entitlement to succession; nearer heirs' challenge does not override this statutory right unless other legal facts apply.

 Section no 239  clause (g)
