instruction: My relative had two heirs in the same order but one refused — can a more distant heir then claim part of it?
input:
If any heir in the order of preference entitled to
succession does not intend to succeed, the other heirs in the same order shall be
entitled to succession, and even any heir in that order of preference does not
intend to accept succession, the heir in the successive order of preference shall
be entitled to the succession.

 Section no 239  part (4)
output: According to Section 239(4)... Rule: Preference stays within the same order if some heirs refuse; only if all in that order refuse does succession pass to the next order. Application/Conclusion: A more distant heir cannot claim while any heir in the same order accepts; the distant heir is entitled only if all heirs in the prior order decline succession.

instruction: Conflict scenario: My brother and I both are in same order. He refuses and my cousin (next order) says he should get it. Who's right?
input:
If any heir in the order of preference entitled to
succession does not intend to succeed, the other heirs in the same order shall be
entitled to succession, and even any heir in that order of preference does not
intend to accept succession, the heir in the successive order of preference shall
be entitled to the succession.

 Section no 239  part (4)
output: According to Section 239(4)... Rule: Other heirs in the same order take succession when one refuses; only if all in that order refuse does the next order get succession. Application/Conclusion: Since you are in the same order as your brother and he refused, you (as the other heir in that order) are entitled, not your cousin from the next order.

instruction: Procedure question: I told family I won't accept my share today. How long do I have to inform the District Court in writing?
input:
A person who declines to accept a succession shall
give information thereof in writing to the concerned District Court within a
period of three years of the devolution of succession.

 Section no 244  part (2)
output: According to Section 244(2)... Rule: A person who declines succession must submit written notice to the concerned District Court within three years of the devolution of succession. Application/Conclusion: You have up to three years from the devolution of succession to file that written notice with the District Court.

instruction: I was staying with my late brother after taking my partition share even though our parents were alive — does that give me rights over his property when he died?
input:
If a person dies when he or she was staying with any distant heir after taking his or her partition share of property in spite of having his or her nearer heir and succession to him or her is open, the heir with whom that person was so staying shall be entitled to his or her property succession. 133

 Section no 240 . Distant heir entitled to succession :
output: According to Section 240... Rule: A person who dies while staying with a distant heir after taking partition share, despite having nearer heirs, means the heir with whom they stayed is entitled to succession. Application/Conclusion: If you were that distant heir with whom your brother stayed after you took partition, you would be entitled to his succession under Section 240 despite the existence of nearer heirs.

instruction: Can I sell my private property without asking anyone?
input: Section no 256  part (2) : Any person shall be entitled to exclusively deal with his or her private property, subject to this Act.
output:
According to Section 256(2):
Rule: Any person shall be entitled to exclusively deal with his or her private property, subject to this Act.
Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to deal (for example, sell) your private property exclusively. That entitlement is subject to the rest of the Act, so any specific limitations elsewhere in the law would still apply.

instruction: Does the law list intellectual property as a kind of property?
input: Section no 254  clause (e) : Intellectual property,
output:
According to Section 254(e):
Rule: Intellectual property is listed among types of property.
Application/Conclusion: Intellectual property is expressly recognised as a form of property under the listed provisions.

instruction: Is a promissory note treated as property under these provisions?
input: clause (d) : A bond, security, promissory note, bill of exchange, letter of credit or other negotiable instrument or a benefit derived therefrom,
output:
According to Section 254(d):
Rule: Bonds, securities, promissory notes, bills of exchange, letters of credit and other negotiable instruments (and benefits derived from them) are treated as property.
Application/Conclusion: A promissory note is recognised as property under this provision.

instruction: My uncle says goodwill isn't 'property'. Is he right?
input: Section no 254  clause (g) : A trade good-will or franchise, 142
output:
According to Section 254(g):
Rule: Trade goodwill or a franchise is listed as a type of property.
Application/Conclusion: Goodwill is expressly classified as property, so the claim that it is not property contradicts this provision.

instruction: We run a farm together. Is produce/property from the farm considered common property?
input: Section no 257  clause (c) : Property earned by the coparceners from the farming, industry, trade or business in common or property accrued therefrom.
output:
According to Section 257(1)(c):
Rule: Property earned by coparceners from farming, industry, trade or business in common (and property accrued therefrom) is deemed property in common.
Application/Conclusion: Produce or assets generated by your jointly-run farm are deemed property in common of the coparceners.

instruction: I inherited a house by succession. Is it private property or common property?
input: Section no 256  clause (b) : Property acquired by way of donation, bequeath, or succession,
output:
According to Section 256(1)(b):
Rule: Property acquired by way of donation, bequeath or succession is listed among properties deemed to be private property of the person who acquired it.
Application/Conclusion: Property you acquired by succession is deemed your private property under this provision.

instruction: If my wife earns a salary, is that hers alone or ours?
input: Section no 257  part (2) : Except where separated in accordance with law, any property earned by the husband or wife or property accrued therefrom shall be deemed to be the property in common of the husband or wife.
output:
According to Section 257(2):
Rule: Except where separated according to law, any property earned by the husband or wife (and property accrued therefrom) shall be deemed property in common of the husband and wife.
Application/Conclusion: Your wife's salary is presumed to be property in common of both spouses unless there has been a lawful separation of property.

instruction: What does 'government property' mean here?
input: Section no 255  clause (f) : Government property,
output:
According to Section 255(f):
Rule: The statute classifies 'government property' as one category of property according to ownership.
Application/Conclusion: 'Government property' is formally recognized as a classification of property under the ownership-based classification in Section 255.

instruction: I got money before marriage — is that mine alone?
input: Section no 256  clause (g) : Property earned or acquired by a woman prior to marriage or acquired from her parental side at the time of marriage or accrued therefrom,
output:
According to Section 256(1)(g):
Rule: Property earned or acquired by a woman prior to marriage or received from her parental side at the time of marriage (and property accrued therefrom) is deemed private property of that woman.
Application/Conclusion: Money you earned before marriage is deemed your private property under this provision.

instruction: If a husband grants property to his wife and says she'll have exclusive rights, does the law recognise it?
input: Section no 256  clause (h) : Property so granted to a woman by the husband or with consent of all coparceners of the husband side that she will have exclusive right in it or movable or immovable property received from the relatives or friends of the husband side and property accrued therefrom,
output:
According to Section 256(1)(h):
Rule: Property granted to a woman by the husband (or with consent of all husband's coparceners) so that she will have an exclusive right in it, and movable or immovable property received from the husband's relatives or friends (and property accrued therefrom), is recognised under private property provisions.
Application/Conclusion: If the husband grants property to the wife with the intended exclusive right (or all coparceners consent), that grant is recognised so she will have exclusive rights in that property according to this provision.

instruction: Does ancestral property count as property in common?
input: Section no 257  clause (a) : Property inherited from ancestors, 144
output:
According to Section 257(1)(a):
Rule: Property inherited from ancestors is deemed to be property in common among coparceners.
Application/Conclusion: Ancestral property is classified as property in common, regardless of which coparcener currently holds it.

instruction: Is 'property other than immovable property' recognised here?
input: Section no 254  clause (h) : A property other than the immovable property.
output:
According to Section 254(h):
Rule: The statute explicitly lists 'a property other than the immovable property' among types of property.
Application/Conclusion: Movable or other non-immovable property is expressly included in the property definitions under this provision.

instruction: I lost a letter of credit—is that considered property I can claim for?
input: clause (d) : A bond, security, promissory note, bill of exchange, letter of credit or other negotiable instrument or a benefit derived therefrom,
output:
According to Section 254(d):
Rule: Letters of credit and other negotiable instruments (and benefits derived from them) are enumerated as property.
Application/Conclusion: A letter of credit is treated as property under the law; that classification supports treating loss or claims relating to it as matters concerning property.

instruction: If I invent something by my skill, is that mine under these rules?
input:
Section no 256  clause (a) : Property earned by way of his or her knowledge, skills or effort,
 Section no 256  clause (e) : Property acquired by way of intellectual property or royalty,
output:
According to Section 256(1)(a) and 256(1)(e):
Rule: Property earned by way of a person's knowledge, skills or effort is private property; property acquired by way of intellectual property or royalty is also private property.
Application/Conclusion: An invention produced by your knowledge and skill, and any intellectual property rights or royalties arising from it, are deemed your private property under these provisions.

instruction: What does 'joint property' mean in the ownership classification?
input: Section no 255  clause (c) : Joint property,
output:
According to Section 255(c):
Rule: 'Joint property' is listed as a category in the classification of property according to ownership.
Application/Conclusion: The law recognises joint property as one of the ownership classes; specific rights and consequences would follow from that classification under the Act.

instruction: If spouses separate and live apart, does property they get while apart belong solely to them?
input: Section no 256  clause (f) : Property acquired in any manner whatsoever while living apart by separating bread and board in accordance with law or while managing one’s accommodation at one’s cost despite not so living apart,
output:
According to Section 256(1)(f):
Rule: Property acquired in any manner while living apart (separating bread and board in accordance with law) or while managing one’s accommodation at one’s cost is identified among properties deemed private.
Application/Conclusion: Property you acquire while lawfully living apart (or while maintaining separate accommodation at your cost) is considered your private property under this provision.

instruction: Is 'trust property' one of the ownership categories?
input: Section no 255  clause (g) : Trust property.
output:
According to Section 255(g):
Rule: Trust property is included as a category of property according to ownership.
Application/Conclusion: The statute recognises trust property as a distinct ownership classification.

instruction: My sibling says the house he received as a gift is common property. Is a donated property private or common?
input: Section no 256  clause (b) : Property acquired by way of donation, bequeath, or succession,
output:
According to Section 256(1)(b):
Rule: Property acquired by way of donation is listed among properties deemed to be a person's private property.
Application/Conclusion: A house you received by donation is deemed your private property under this provision, not property in common.

instruction: Can I build a fence along the edge of my land?
input:
clause (f) : To make any kind of physical structure, wall or
fence or delimit boundary, in his or her land or change the form of any property
or otherwise protect it,
output: According to Section 288 clause (f): Rule: A person may make any kind of physical structure, wall or fence, or delimit boundary, in his or her land or change the form of any property or otherwise protect it. Application/Conclusion: If you are the lawful holder of the land, you have the legal rule allowing you to build a fence or boundary on your land to protect or delimit it.

instruction: Can I use the space above or below my land for storage or construction?
input:
Section no 288  clause (g) : To use his or her land or part below its surface
or goods therein or sky above its surface,
output: According to Section 288 clause (g): Rule: A person has the right to use his or her land or parts below its surface and the sky above its surface, and goods therein. Application/Conclusion: You may use underground space and the airspace above your land (and goods contained within) in accordance with this right, subject to any other applicable laws or restrictions.

instruction: If I want to demolish an old shed on my property, does the law allow it?
input: Section no 288  clause (h) : To destroy or dispose of property in any manner,
output: According to Section 288 clause (h): Rule: A person is permitted to destroy or dispose of property in any manner. Application/Conclusion: You are legally permitted to demolish or dispose of structures on your property, provided you lawfully hold the property and comply with other laws or contractual obligations.

instruction: Can I sue someone over my property rights?
input:
Section no 288  clause (i) : To institute a legal action in any manner in
relation to the acquisition or security of the property.
output: According to Section 288 clause (i): Rule: A person may institute legal action in relation to acquisition or security of property. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the law recognizes your right to bring legal proceedings concerning acquisition or protection of your property.

instruction: What does 'possessory right to be deemed' mean in simple terms?
input:
Section no 268 .
Possessory right to be deemed : If a person holds a
property with him or her lawfully with intention to possess the property, the
person shall be deemed to have the possessory right over such property.
output: According to Section 268: Rule: A person who lawfully holds property with the intention to possess it is treated by law as having possessory right over that property. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if you lawfully possess something and intend to possess it, the law will recognize you as its possessor even if you are not the formal owner.

instruction: How can someone acquire possessory right? List the ways.
input:
Section no 269 .
When possessory right can be acquired : (1) The
possessory right may be acquired over any property in the following manner:
 Section no 269  clause (a) : By holding the property in the capacity of its
owner,
 Section no 269  clause (b) : By acquiring the property owned by another
person, in accordance with law,
 Section no 269  clause (c) : By obtaining consent to have possessory right.
output: According to Section 269(1) clauses (a)-(c): Rule: Possessory right may be acquired by (a) holding the property as owner, (b) acquiring property owned by another according to law, or (c) obtaining consent to possess. Application/Conclusion: A person can gain possessory right by being the owner, lawfully acquiring another's property, or by having consent from the owner to possess the property.

instruction: If I started possessing land believing it was mine, does that count?
input:
Section no 269  part (2) : Only the possessory right which is acquired in good
faith, peacefully or openly shall be deemed to have been acquired lawfully.
output: According to Section 269 part (2): Rule: Only possessory rights acquired in good faith, peacefully, and openly are deemed lawfully acquired. Application/Conclusion: If you took possession believing in good faith that the land was yours, and did so peacefully and openly, that possession may be recognized as lawfully acquired under this provision.

instruction: Can I appoint someone to possess land on my behalf?
input:
Section no 270 . Person competent to acquire possessory right : (1) A
person may acquire the possessory right either in person or through his or her
agent.
output: According to Section 270(1): Rule: A person may acquire possessory right in person or through an agent. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can have an agent acquire or hold possessory right for you; possession through an authorized agent is recognized.

instruction: If someone is mentally incompetent, can they still gain possessory rights?
input:
Section no 270  part (2) : A person who is incompetent or quasi-competent
may acquire the possessory right through his or her guardian or curator.
output: According to Section 270 part (2): Rule: An incompetent or quasi-competent person may acquire possessory right through a guardian or curator. Application/Conclusion: A person lacking competence cannot directly acquire possessory right but may do so lawfully through their legal guardian or curator.

instruction: Do possessors have a right to uninterrupted possession?
input:
Section no 271 . Rights of possessor : (1) A person, in the capacity of a
possessor, shall, subject to law, have the following rights:
 Section no 271  clause (a) : To uninterruptedly possess the property in his
or her possession, subject to the laws in force or the contract, if any, entered
into in relation to the property,
output: According to Section 271 clause (a): Rule: A possessor has the right to uninterrupted possession of the property, subject to existing laws and any contracts. Application/Conclusion: As a possessor you are entitled to continue possessing the property without disturbance, provided you comply with the law and any contractual terms.

instruction: Am I allowed to use benefits from the land I possess (like crops or rent)?
input:
Section no 271  clause (b) : To use any benefits of the property in his or her
possession.
output: According to Section 271 clause (b): Rule: A possessor has the right to use any benefits of the property in their possession. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you lawfully possess the property, you can use benefits arising from it (such as crops, rents, or other yields), subject to applicable laws or agreements.

instruction: I looked after my neighbor's house in good faith and paid for repairs. Can I get reimbursed?
input:
Section no 271  part (2) : In the event of acquisition of, by a person, the
possessory right in bona fide over any property owned by anyone else, the person
shall be entitled to reimbursement from the owner of that property for essential
expenses incurred in the management, maintenance or care of (rekh dekh) such
property while it was under his or her possessory right.
output: According to Section 271 part (2): Rule: A bona fide possessor of property owned by another is entitled to reimbursement from the owner for essential expenses incurred in management, maintenance or care of the property. Application/Conclusion: Because you acted as a bona fide possessor and paid for essential repairs, you may claim reimbursement from the owner for those necessary expenses.

instruction: If I paid for upkeep of a property I possessed in good faith, must the owner pay me back before I return the property?
input:
Section no 271  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(2), the former possessor shall be entitled to retain such property with him or
her unless and until the expenses referred to in that sub section are reimbursed.
output: According to Section 271 part (3): Rule: A former possessor is entitled to retain the property until the essential expenses referred to in subsection (2) are reimbursed. Application/Conclusion: You may lawfully retain possession of the property and not return it to the owner until you are reimbursed for the essential expenses you incurred as a bona fide possessor.

instruction: I attached a new doorframe to a house I possessed in good faith. Can I remove it when returning the house?
input:
Section no 271  part (4) : If a bona fide possessor of any property not in his
or her ownership has attached any goods to such property, the possessor shall
be entitled to detach or take out the goods so attached by him or her from the
property without tempering with such property.
output: According to Section 271 part (4): Rule: A bona fide possessor who has attached goods to the property may detach or remove those goods without damaging the property. Application/Conclusion: You can remove the doorframe you attached, provided you detach it without tempering with or damaging the underlying property.

instruction: My cousin abandoned the barn he was occupying. Does his possessory right end?
input:
Section no 272 . Circumstances when possessory right is extinguished : The possessory right of a person over a property shall be deemed to have been
extinguished in any of the following circumstances:
 Section no 272  clause (a) : If the person abandons the property,
output: According to Section 272 clause (a): Rule: Possessory right is extinguished if the person abandons the property. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin has truly abandoned the barn, his possessory right over it is deemed extinguished under this provision.

instruction: If someone transfers the property they were possessing, what happens to their possessory right?
input: Section no 272  clause (b) : If the person transfers the property,
output: According to Section 272 clause (b): Rule: Possessory right is extinguished when the person transfers the property. Application/Conclusion: When a possessor transfers the property, their possessory right over that property comes to an end.

instruction: When does a possessory right end if the property is ruined?
input:
Section no 272  clause (c) : If the property gets totally destroyed or becomes
useless.
output: According to Section 272 clause (c): Rule: Possessory right is extinguished if the property is totally destroyed or becomes useless. Application/Conclusion: If the property you possess is completely destroyed or rendered useless, your possessory right over it is extinguished under this clause.

instruction: Under which section is the rule that possession gives you a deemed possessory right stated? (I need the exact section.)
input:
Section no 268 .
Possessory right to be deemed : If a person holds a
property with him or her lawfully with intention to possess the property, the
person shall be deemed to have the possessory right over such property.
output: According to Section 268: Rule: The law states that a person who lawfully holds property with the intention to possess it shall be deemed to have the possessory right. Application/Conclusion: The rule that possession with lawful intention creates a deemed possessory right is stated in Section 268.

instruction: Can I sell my share of a house that I own jointly with my sister if she refuses to consent?
input:
Section no 258  part (2) : The right or share of a joint holder in the joint property shall be as set forth in a deed setting out such rights and share, and failing such a deed, the holders of that property shall be deemed to have equal rights and share.
Section no 258  part (3) : The use and management of, transfer of title to, and other provisions relating to, the joint property shall be governed by this Chapter and the other Chapters of this Act.
output:
According to Section 258(2) and Section 258(3).
Rule: Each joint holder's rights and shares are determined by a deed; failing a deed, all holders are deemed to have equal rights and shares. Use, management and transfer of title in joint property are governed by this Chapter and other Chapters of the Act.
Application/Conclusion: If you and your sister have a deed that sets out your respective shares and that deed permits you to transfer your share, you may sell in accordance with that deed and the applicable provisions. If there is no deed, you and your sister are deemed to have equal shares, so transfer must comply with the rules on joint property (meaning you cannot unilaterally dispose of the whole property; you can typically sell only your share subject to any procedural rules in this Chapter and other Chapters).

instruction: What counts as 'joint property' under the law? Explain simply.
input: Section no 258 . Property deemed to be joint property : (1) Any property owned by two or more persons except the coparceners living in a joint family or property accrued therefrom shall be deemed to be a joint property.
output:
According to Section 258(1).
Rule: Any property owned by two or more persons is deemed joint property, except property owned by coparceners in a joint family or property arising from that joint-family coparcenary.
Application/Conclusion: So, if two or more people (other than coparceners in a joint family) own property together, the law treats it as joint property.

instruction: My mango trees sit exactly on the boundary between my land and my neighbor's land. Whose property are the trees?
input: Section no 259 . Trees, plants or goods on boundary to be deemed joint : property: Except as otherwise proved, the trees, plants or goods lying on the boundary of two or more owners of adjoining lands shall be deemed to be the joint property of all owners.
output:
According to Section 259.
Rule: Trees, plants or goods lying on the boundary between adjoining owners are presumed to be joint property of those owners, unless proved otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: Your mango trees located on the boundary are presumed joint property of you and your neighbor unless one of you can prove a different legal entitlement.

instruction: How should joint property be managed when all owners agree? I'm asking about the normal rule.
input: Section no 260 . Management, protection and maintenance of joint property : (1) The management, protection and maintenance of a joint property shall be made as per the consent of the owners of that property.
output:
According to Section 260(1).
Rule: Management, protection and and maintenance of joint property must be carried out according to the consent of the property's owners.
Application/Conclusion: If all owners agree on how to manage the joint property, they should follow that agreed plan — unanimous consent governs management in the ordinary case.

instruction: My co-owners are divided on what to do with a shared field. If we can't agree, who decides?
input: Section no 260  part (2) : Failing consent between the owners in relation to the management, protection and maintenance of a joint property pursuant to sub-section (1), the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property shall be made according to the decision of majority members.
output:
According to Section 260(2).
Rule: If owners cannot reach consent on management, the decision of the majority of owners governs management, protection and maintenance of the joint property.
Application/Conclusion: When co-owners are split, the majority's decision controls how the shared field is managed — provided you can establish who constitutes the majority for decision-making.

instruction: If there is no majority opinion among co-owners, who must take responsibility for managing the property?
input: Section no 260  part (3) : Failing a majority opinion between the owners in relation to the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property pursuant to sub-section (2), the owner who has the largest right or share in that property shall make its management, protection and maintenance. Provided that if the owners have equal right, all owners shall have to make management, protection and maintenance of such property on an equal basis.
output:
According to Section 260(3).
Rule: If there is no majority decision, the owner with the largest right or share must manage, protect and maintain the joint property; if rights are equal, all owners must manage, protect and maintain equally.
Application/Conclusion: If no majority can be reached, the co-owner holding the largest share must take responsibility. If all shares are equal, responsibility is shared equally among all owners.

instruction: I paid to repair a shared well. Can I make the others pay me back, and on what basis?
input: Section no 260  part (4) : Expenses incurred in the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property, if any, made by any owner 146 pursuant to sub-section (2) or (3) shall be borne by all owners in proportion to their respective right or share.
output:
According to Section 260(4).
Rule: Expenses incurred for management, protection and maintenance by any owner (after majority decision or largest-share action) must be borne by all owners in proportion to their respective rights or shares.
Application/Conclusion: You can require the co-owners to reimburse their proportional shares of the repair costs based on each owner's right or share in the joint property.

instruction: I paid for maintenance last month; how long do others have to reimburse me?
input: Section no 260  part (5) : The owner who does not manage, protect and maintain the joint property pursuant to sub-section (4) shall pay the expenses incurred in the management, protection and maintenance of that property to the owner who has made such management, protection and maintenance within a period of one year.
output:
According to Section 260(5).
Rule: A non-managing owner must pay their share of expenses to the owner who carried out management, protection and maintenance within one year.
Application/Conclusion: Your co-owners have up to one year to reimburse you for maintenance expenses you paid on behalf of the joint property.

instruction: If one co-owner refuses to pay their share after a year, what remedy does the paying owner have?
input: Section no 260  part (6) : If any owner fails to pay the expenses incurred in the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property within the period referred to in sub-section (5), the owner who has made management, protection and maintenance thereof shall be entitled to purchase the right and share of that other owner in that property at the prevailing price. Such purchaser of the joint property may deduct management and maintenance expenses of his or her portion.
output:
According to Section 260(6).
Rule: If an owner fails to pay their share within one year, the owner who paid may purchase the defaulting owner's right and share at the prevailing price; the purchaser may deduct the management and maintenance expenses attributable to their portion.
Application/Conclusion: If a co-owner doesn't reimburse you within one year, you may buy their share at market price and deduct the maintenance costs from the amount payable for their share.

instruction: Is property that parents earn for partition between them and their children treated as common property?
input: part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, any property earned by the parents for the purpose of partition between the parents and their children shall also be deemed to be the property in common.
output:
According to Section 257(3).
Rule: Property earned by parents for the purpose of partition between parents and their children is deemed to be property in common, notwithstanding other provisions of the Chapter.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — property earned by parents specifically for partition with their children is treated as common property under Section 257(3).

instruction: Where does the law say how to use or transfer rights in property deemed to be 'in common'?
input: Section no 257  part (4) : The use of, and transfer of right in, the property in common and other provisions shall be as set forth in the other Chapters of this Act.
output:
According to Section 257(4).
Rule: The use and transfer of rights in property deemed to be in common are governed by provisions set forth in other Chapters of the Act.
Application/Conclusion: For procedures and rules on using or transferring rights in property in common, you must consult the other Chapters of the Act referenced by Section 257(4).

instruction: Under which section is it stated that joint holders have equal rights if there's no deed?
input: Section no 258  part (2) : The right or share of a joint holder in the joint property shall be as set forth in a deed setting out such rights and share, and failing such a deed, the holders of that property shall be deemed to have equal rights and share. 145
output:
According to Section 258(2).
Rule: Joint holders' rights and shares follow a deed; if there is no deed, holders are deemed to have equal rights and shares.
Application/Conclusion: The law specifying equal rights in absence of a deed is in Section 258(2).

instruction: If co-owners have exactly equal shares, who must do the maintenance work?
input: Section no 260  part (3) : Failing a majority opinion between the owners in relation to the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property pursuant to sub-section (2), the owner who has the largest right or share in that property shall make its management, protection and maintenance. Provided that if the owners have equal right, all owners shall have to make management, protection and maintenance of such property on an equal basis.
output:
According to Section 260(3).
Rule: If owners have equal rights or shares, all owners must manage, protect and maintain the property on an equal basis.
Application/Conclusion: With equal shares, every co-owner is obliged to participate equally in maintenance and related responsibilities.

instruction: I paid the upkeep after a majority decision; can I recover costs from others proportionally?
input:
Section no 260  part (2) : Failing consent between the owners in relation to the management, protection and maintenance of a joint property pursuant to sub-section (1), the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property shall be made according to the decision of majority members.
Section no 260  part (4) : Expenses incurred in the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property, if any, made by any owner 146 pursuant to sub-section (2) or (3) shall be borne by all owners in proportion to their respective right or share.
output:
According to Section 260(2) and Section 260(4).
Rule: When management follows a majority decision, expenses incurred by any owner are borne by all owners in proportion to their rights or shares.
Application/Conclusion: Since you acted pursuant to a majority decision, you can require the other owners to reimburse their proportional shares of the expenses you paid.

instruction: If one owner doesn't want to participate in protecting joint property, are they still liable for costs?
input:
Section no 260  part (4) : Expenses incurred in the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property, if any, made by any owner 146 pursuant to sub-section (2) or (3) shall be borne by all owners in proportion to their respective right or share.
Section no 260  part (5) : The owner who does not manage, protect and maintain the joint property pursuant to sub-section (4) shall pay the expenses incurred in the management, protection and maintenance of that property to the owner who has made such management, protection and maintenance within a period of one year.
output:
According to Section 260(4) and Section 260(5).
Rule: All owners must bear expenses proportionately; an owner who does not participate must still pay their share within one year to the managing owner.
Application/Conclusion: Even if an owner refuses to participate, they remain liable for their proportional share of management costs and must reimburse the managing owner within one year.

instruction: Who may deduct maintenance expenses when buying out a defaulting co-owner's share?
input: Section no 260  part (6) : If any owner fails to pay the expenses incurred in the management, protection and maintenance of the joint property within the period referred to in sub-section (5), the owner who has made management, protection and maintenance thereof shall be entitled to purchase the right and share of that other owner in that property at the prevailing price. Such purchaser of the joint property may deduct management and maintenance expenses of his or her portion.
output:
According to Section 260(6).
Rule: The owner who managed and paid the expenses may purchase the defaulting owner's share at the prevailing price and may deduct management and maintenance expenses attributable to their portion.
Application/Conclusion: If you buy the defaulting co-owner's share after their non-payment, you may deduct the relevant management and maintenance expenses when determining the amount payable.

instruction: My parents set aside some land for partition with us children. Is that land 'property in common' automatically?

instruction: Under what section does it say 'trees on the boundary are joint' — I need the citation for a complaint I'm drafting.

output:
According to Section 259.
Rule: Trees, plants or goods on the boundary between adjoining owners are presumed joint property unless proved otherwise.

instruction: If a memorandum and inventory are received and the deceased's address is found, how long do I have to appear to claim the property?
input: part (4) : If a memorandum, along with the inventory of properties, is received pursuant to sub-section (3) and the address of the deceased is traced out, such an oﬀice shall send a notice in accordance with law to the heir of the deceased to appear to receive the property of the deceased within a period of three months.
output: According to Section 248(4): Rule: Where a memorandum and inventory are received and the deceased's address is traced, the office must send a legal notice to the heir to appear to receive the property. Application/Conclusion: If you are the heir whose address has been traced, you will be given a period of three months from the notice to appear and claim the property.

instruction: They couldn't find the heir or the heir didn't come — what does the office do next?
input: Section no 248  part (5) : If the heir does not accept the property pursuant to sub section (1) or the heir of the deceased does not appear within the time-limit referred to in sub-section (4) or the address of such heir is not traced out, such an oﬀice shall publish a notice in a national newspaper, inviting his or her heir, if any, to appear to claim the property of the deceased, within a period of thirty five days.
output: According to Section 248(5): Rule: If the heir does not accept, does not appear within the three‑month time, or their address is not traced, the office must publish a notice in a national newspaper inviting any heir to claim the property within 35 days. Application/Conclusion: If you did not receive the earlier notice or the office could not trace the heir, the office will run a public notice and anyone wishing to claim must do so within 35 days of that publication.

instruction: I saw a notice and I went to claim within 35 days. What share do I get after funeral expenses?
input: Section no 248  part (6) : If the heir of the deceased appears within the timelimit referred to in sub-section (5), the property that remains after deducting therefrom the expenses incurred in the performance of obsequies of the deceased or providing such expenses to the person having performed such obsequies, and ten percent of the property, shall be returned to the concerned heir. 137
output: According to Section 248(6): Rule: If an heir appears within the 35‑day period, the heir is entitled to the property remaining after deducting funeral (obsequies) expenses and ten percent of the property. Application/Conclusion: Since you appeared within the 35 days, you will receive the estate after the funeral expenses are covered (or paid to the person who paid them) and after a deduction of ten percent as specified.

instruction: No one claimed the property after the notice — who gets it?
input: Section no 248  part (7) : If no heir of the deceased appears within the timelimit referred to in sub-section (5) or his or her address is not traced out, the property that remains after deducting therefrom the expenses incurred in the performance of obsequies of the deceased, which amount is to be provided to the person having performed such obsequies, shall devolve on the concerned Local Level.
output: According to Section 248(7): Rule: If no heir appears within the 35‑day period (or address cannot be traced), the remaining property after deducting funeral expenses (paid to the person who performed them) devolves to the concerned Local Level. Application/Conclusion: If nobody claimed the estate in time or the heir cannot be found, the property will pass to the Local Level after funeral costs are accounted for.

instruction: Who must hand over property to the Local Level when it devolves?
input: Section no 248  part (8) : The concerned heir or the oﬀice under sub-section (3) shall hand over the property receivable by the Local Level pursuant to sub-section (1) or (7) to the Local Level in accordance with law.
output: According to Section 248(8): Rule: Either the concerned heir or the office (that prepared the memorandum) must hand over property receivable by the Local Level pursuant to the law. Application/Conclusion: When property is destined for the Local Level under the law, the office that handled the case (or the heir, if involved) is responsible for formally transferring it to the Local Level in accordance with legal requirements.

instruction: Can the Local Level use the property it receives for public projects?
input: Section no 248  part (9) : The Local Level shall use the property that it has received pursuant to this Section for public interest.
output: According to Section 248(9): Rule: Property received by the Local Level under this Section must be used for public interest. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the Local Level is required to employ such property for public interest purposes rather than private uses.

instruction: A foreigner died here and I performed their last rites. What must I do right away?
input: Section no 249 . Succession to property of foreigner died in Nepal : (1) If a foreigner who dies in Nepal has property without heir in Nepal, a person 72 who performs his or her obsequies or maintains his or her books and accounts shall immediately give a notice thereof to the nearby Local Level.
output: According to Section 249(1): Rule: If a foreigner dying in Nepal has property and no heir in Nepal, the person who performed obsequies or who maintains their books/accounts must immediately notify the nearby Local Level. Application/Conclusion: Since you performed the rites, you are legally required to immediately inform the nearest Local Level about the deceased and their property.

instruction: After I notify the Local Level about the foreigner, what must that Local Level do with the property?
input: Section no 249  part (2) : If a notice is received pursuant to sub-section (1), the Local Level shall prepare an inventory of the properties of the deceased in witness of at two local persons and forward the inventory, accompanied by a copy of the memorandum (Muchulka) executed to that effect, to the concerned district level administrative oﬀice.
output: According to Section 249(2): Rule: Upon receiving notice, the Local Level must prepare an inventory of the deceased's properties in the presence of two local witnesses and forward it with a copy of the memorandum to the district administrative office. Application/Conclusion: The Local Level will document the assets with two local witnesses and send those records plus the memorandum up to the district office for further action.

instruction: What does the district office do once it gets the inventory and memorandum about the foreigner's property?
input: Section no 249  part (3) : If a memorandum, along with the inventory of properties, is received pursuant to sub-section (2), such an oﬀice shall immediately give information thereof to the Federal Ministry of Home Affairs. 138
output: According to Section 249(3): Rule: When the district office receives the memorandum and inventory, it must immediately inform the Federal Ministry of Home Affairs. Application/Conclusion: The district office is required to promptly notify the Federal Ministry once it has the inventory and memorandum regarding the foreigner's estate.

instruction: I'm an heir abroad. Will the Federal Ministry contact me? How will they send notice?
input: Section no 249  part (4) : If information referred to in sub-section (3) is received, the Federal Ministry of Home Affairs shall also send a notice, in accordance with law, through the diplomatic channel of the concerned country, to the heir of the dead person to appear to receive the properties of the deceased within four months.
output: According to Section 249(4): Rule: The Federal Ministry must send a notice through the diplomatic channel of the deceased's country to the heir, asking them to appear to receive the property within four months. Application/Conclusion: If you are an identified heir living abroad, the Ministry will notify you via your country's diplomatic channel and give you a four‑month period to appear and claim the property.

instruction: What if the deceased was from a country that has no diplomatic relations with Nepal — how will heirs be informed and how long do they have?
input: Section no 249  part (5) : If information under sub-section (3) is received upon the death of a citizen of a country having no diplomatic relation with Nepal, the Federal Ministry of Home Affairs shall publish a notice in a national daily English newspaper for receiving such property within six months, and the Federal Ministry of Home Affairs shall also put such notice on its website.
output: According to Section 249(5): Rule: Where the deceased is from a country having no diplomatic relations with Nepal, the Federal Ministry must publish a notice in a national English daily and place it on its website, inviting claims within six months. Application/Conclusion: In absence of diplomatic channels, heirs (or interested persons) are informed by public notice and have six months from publication to claim the property.

instruction: Under which section does the law deal with succession to property of a foreigner who died in Nepal?
input: Section no 249 . Succession to property of foreigner died in Nepal :
output: According to Section 249: Rule: Succession to property of a foreigner who dies in Nepal is governed under Section 249, which sets out notification, inventory, forwarding, and notice procedures. Application/Conclusion: For matters involving foreigners who die in Nepal without local heirs, consult Section 249 for the required steps and timelines.

instruction: The office told me the heir didn't accept the property 'pursuant to sub section (1)'. What does that trigger?
input: Section no 248  part (5) : If the heir does not accept the property pursuant to sub section (1) or the heir of the deceased does not appear within the time-limit referred to in sub-section (4) or the address of such heir is not traced out, such an oﬀice shall publish a notice in a national newspaper, inviting his or her heir, if any, to appear to claim the property of the deceased, within a period of thirty five days.
output: According to Section 248(5): Rule: If an heir refuses to accept property as per subsection (1), or fails to appear within the subsection (4) time-limit, or cannot be traced, the office must publish a notice in a national newspaper inviting any heir to claim the property within 35 days. Application/Conclusion: A refusal or failure to appear triggers the public notice procedure—any potential heir then has 35 days from that publication to come forward.

instruction: Who gets paid for funeral expenses when property is distributed or devolved?
input: Section no 248  part (7) : If no heir of the deceased appears within the timelimit referred to in sub-section (5) or his or her address is not traced out, the property that remains after deducting therefrom the expenses incurred in the performance of obsequies of the deceased, which amount is to be provided to the person having performed such obsequies, shall devolve on the concerned Local Level.
output: According to Section 248(7): Rule: Funeral (obsequies) expenses are deducted from the estate and that amount is to be provided to the person who performed the obsequies; the remaining property then devolves to the Local Level. Application/Conclusion: The person who paid for or performed the funeral rites is entitled to receive the funeral expenses from the estate before any remaining assets are transferred to the Local Level.

instruction: Who prepares the inventory of a deceased foreigner's properties and in whose presence?
input: Section no 249  part (2) : If a notice is received pursuant to sub-section (1), the Local Level shall prepare an inventory of the properties of the deceased in witness of at two local persons and forward the inventory, accompanied by a copy of the memorandum (Muchulka) executed to that effect, to the concerned district level administrative oﬀice.
output: According to Section 249(2): Rule: The Local Level must prepare the inventory of the deceased's properties in the presence of two local witnesses and forward it with the memorandum to the district administrative office. Application/Conclusion: The Local Level (not an individual) compiles the inventory and does so with two local persons as witnesses to authenticate the record before sending it up the chain.

instruction: I'm an heir and the Ministry says they'll use diplomatic channels — how long will I have to appear?
input: Section no 249  part (4) : If information referred to in sub-section (3) is received, the Federal Ministry of Home Affairs shall also send a notice, in accordance with law, through the diplomatic channel of the concerned country, to the heir of the dead person to appear to receive the properties of the deceased within four months.
output: According to Section 249(4): Rule: The Federal Ministry will notify heirs via diplomatic channels and require them to appear within four months. Application/Conclusion: As an heir to a foreign deceased with diplomatic ties, you will be given a four‑month period from the diplomatic notice to come and claim the property.

instruction: A local office told me 'send memorandum with inventory' — what happens after they get it and trace address?
input: part (4) : If a memorandum, along with the inventory of properties, is received pursuant to sub-section (3) and the address of the deceased is traced out, such an oﬀice shall send a notice in accordance with law to the heir of the deceased to appear to receive the property of the deceased within a period of three months.
output: According to Section 248(4): Rule: When the office receives the memorandum and inventory and the deceased's address is traced, it must send a legal notice to the heir to appear within three months to receive the property. Application/Conclusion: Once those documents are in and an address is found, the office will formally notify the heir and the heir has three months to respond and claim the estate.

instruction: I have been farming a plot of land that actually belongs to my neighbor for 35 years. Can I now be considered the owner?
input: . Adverse possessory right to be deemed : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if any person has possessed any movable property or land owned by anyone else, since more than three years ago in the case of the movable property and thirty years ago in the case of the land as if the property or land were owned by himself or herself, that person shall be deemed to have adverse possessory right over such property or land. Provided that:
output:
According to Section 273(1)...
Rule: Possession of land as if owned by oneself for more than thirty years leads to being deemed to have an adverse possessory right.
Application/Conclusion: You have possessed the land for 35 years, which exceeds the thirty-year threshold, so you would be deemed to have an adverse possessory right over that land, subject to any applicable exceptions in the Chapter.

instruction: If someone acquires adverse possessory right, can they obtain formal ownership in their name?
input: Section no 273  part (2) : If any person acquires the adverse possessory right over any property pursuant to sub-section (1), the person may obtain ownership over such property in his or her name.
output:
According to Section 273 part (2)...
Rule: A person who acquires an adverse possessory right under subsection (1) may obtain ownership of that property in their name.
Application/Conclusion: If you meet the conditions for adverse possession under Section 273(1), you may proceed to obtain legal ownership in your name.

instruction: Can adverse possession be claimed over government land or community land?
input:
Section no 273  part (1) : No adverse possessory right may be acquired over
a government, public, community or trust land despite the length of the period
of possession.
output:
According to Section 273 part (1)...
Rule: Adverse possessory rights cannot be acquired over government, public, community or trust land regardless of how long possession continues.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot claim ownership by adverse possession if the land is government, public, community or trust land.

instruction: Someone took my house by force years ago and has been living there. Can they now claim adverse possession?
input:
Section no 273  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if a property or land is possessed without knowledge of its owner, secretly
or forcibly, this Section shall not apply.
output:
According to Section 273 part (3)...
Rule: The adverse possession rule in subsection (1) does not apply if the property was possessed without the owner's knowledge, secretly, or forcibly.
Application/Conclusion: Because the possession was forcible, the person cannot rely on adverse possession under Section 273(1) to claim ownership.

instruction: From what date is the period for adverse possession computed?
input:
Section no 273  part (4) : In computing the period pursuant to this Section,
it shall be computed from the date of the commencement of this Act.
output:
According to Section 273 part (4)...
Rule: Time periods for adverse possession under this Section are computed from the commencement date of the Act.
Application/Conclusion: When calculating whether the statutory period for adverse possession has run, you must count from the date this Act came into force.

instruction: I have had someone's movable goods in my possession for four years. Am I deemed to have adverse possessory right?
input: . Adverse possessory right to be deemed : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if any person has possessed any movable property or land owned by anyone else, since more than three years ago in the case of the movable property and thirty years ago in the case of the land as if the property or land were owned by himself or herself, that person shall be deemed to have adverse possessory right over such property or land. Provided that:
output:
According to Section 273(1)...
Rule: Possession of movable property as if owned by oneself for more than three years leads to being deemed to have an adverse possessory right.
Application/Conclusion: Having possessed the movable goods for four years (more than three), you would be deemed to have an adverse possessory right, unless an exception in the Chapter applies.

instruction: My neighbor forcibly occupied my field but claims he has owned it for decades. Can he rely on adverse possession?
input:
Section no 273  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if a property or land is possessed without knowledge of its owner, secretly
or forcibly, this Section shall not apply.
output:
According to Section 273 part (3)...
Rule: Adverse possession does not apply where the property was possessed without the owner's knowledge, secretly, or by force.
Application/Conclusion: Since the occupation was forcible, your neighbor cannot rely on Section 273(1) to claim adverse possession of your field.

instruction: I borrowed a vehicle and during possession I damaged it negligently. Am I liable for anything?
input:
Section no 274 . Compensation to be paid : (1) If any person possesses any
property forcibly, with mala fide intention or secretly, the person shall return
the benefits derived from that possession and such property to the concerned
person and pay a reasonable compensation for any loss caused to the property
due to his or her negligence in the course of possessing such property.
output:
According to Section 274(1)...
Rule: A person possessing property forcibly, with mala fide intention or secretly must return benefits and the property and pay reasonable compensation for losses caused by their negligence while possessing it.
Application/Conclusion: If your negligent handling damaged the vehicle while you were possessing it in circumstances covered by the Section, you are required to compensate for the loss and return benefits/property to the owner.

instruction: I was holding someone's goods and they were lost while in my care. Do I have to pay?
input:
Section no 274  part (2) : If any property owned by anyone else is lost or
damaged during the continuance of the possessory right of a person over the
property, the person shall pay compensation for such property to the concerned
person.
output:
According to Section 274 part (2)...
Rule: If property owned by another is lost or damaged while a person has possessory rights over it, that person must pay compensation to the owner.
Application/Conclusion: You are liable to pay compensation to the owner for the lost or damaged property that occurred during your possession.

instruction: I only found out today that someone built on my land ten years ago. How long do I have to sue?
input:
Section no 275 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any
act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit within
three months after the date of knowledge of commission of such act or action.
output:
According to Section 275...
Rule: A person aggrieved by acts under this Chapter must bring a lawsuit within three months from the date they become aware of the act.
Application/Conclusion: Since you learned about the construction today, you have three months from today to file a lawsuit under this Chapter.

instruction: Can I go into my neighbor's compound without asking to retrieve my dog?
input:
Section no 276  part (4) : No person shall enter other’s house and compound
without consent of any person except in accordance with law.
output:
According to Section 276 part (4)...
Rule: No person may enter another's house or compound without consent, except as permitted by law.
Application/Conclusion: You may not enter your neighbor's compound without their consent unless a legal exception applies; you should seek permission or use legal remedies rather than entering unilaterally.

instruction: My neighbor built a fence that closes off the only exit from my land. What section deals with this?
input:
Section no 276  part (2) : No person shall temper with other’s property by
closing the road or exit of the other person or doing any act or construction on
the border of his or her land or otherwise.
output:
According to Section 276 part (2)...
Rule: It is prohibited to tamper with another's property by closing their road or exit or by constructing on the border of their land.
Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor's fence that blocks your only exit is prohibited by Section 276(2); you have grounds to object and seek remedy under this provision.

instruction: Is it allowed to use someone else's property without their permission?
input:
Section no 276 .
Prohibition of use, temperance or acquisition of
other’s : property: (1) No person shall use other’s property without consent of
that other person.
output:
According to Section 276(1)...
Rule: Using another person's property without their consent is prohibited.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully use someone else's property unless you have their consent or another legal basis.

instruction: Can the government take my land for a road project?
input:
Section no 276  part (3) : No person shall acquire other’s property without consent of that person. Provided that the Government of Nepal may, in
accordance with law, acquire property of any person for public interest.
output:
According to Section 276 part (3)...
Rule: Private acquisition of another's property is prohibited without consent; however, the Government may acquire property for public interest in accordance with law.
Application/Conclusion: The government can acquire your land for a public-interest project (such as a road) if it follows the legal procedures set out by law; private persons cannot do so without your consent.

instruction: My neighbor's building overlaps my plot—does that count as encroachment?
input:
Section no 277 . Property to be inviolable : (1) No person shall encroach
or trespass other’s property by way of overlapping, pressing or otherwise.
 Section no 277  part (2) : If any person takes possession of other’s property
by way of any act referred to in sub-section (1), that person shall be deemed to
have encroached or trespassed such property.
output:
According to Section 277(1) and Section 277 part (2)...
Rule: Encroachment or trespass includes overlapping or pressing on another's property; a person taking possession by such acts is deemed to have encroached or trespassed.
Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor's building overlapping your plot is an encroachment under Section 277 and they would be deemed to have trespassed your property, giving you a basis to seek removal or remedy.

instruction: Under which section do I find rules about paying compensation if property in my possession gets damaged?
input:

property forcibly, with mala fide intention or secretly, the person shall return
the benefits derived from that possession and such property to the concerned
