According to Section 274(1) and Section 274 part (2)...
Rule: Section 274 requires return of benefits and payment of reasonable compensation where property is possessed forcibly, mala fide or secretly and makes the possessor liable for loss or damage during possessory right.
Application/Conclusion: Rules about paying compensation for damage or loss while possessing another's property are set out in Section 274(1) and (2).

instruction: My brother secretly sold my bicycle five years ago. Could the buyer now claim ownership because the bike was in their possession for more than three years?
input:
Section no 273  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if a property or land is possessed without knowledge of its owner, secretly
or forcibly, this Section shall not apply.
output:
According to Section 273 part (3)...
Rule: The adverse possession rule does not apply when property is possessed without the owner's knowledge, secretly, or forcibly.
Application/Conclusion: Because the sale and possession were secret (without your knowledge), the buyer cannot acquire ownership by adverse possession under Section 273(1), even if possession has lasted more than three years.

instruction: Can I build a house on someone else's land without their written consent?
input: Section no 279  part (1) : No person shall build a house in a land without obtaining written consent of the owner of that land.
output: According to Section 279(1), Rule: No person shall build a house in a land without obtaining written consent of the owner of that land. Application/Conclusion: You may not lawfully build a house on land owned by someone else unless you first obtain the owner's written consent. If you build without that consent, you will be acting contrary to this provision.

instruction: My neighbor constructed a house on my land without permission. Can I make them sell the house to me?
input: Section no 279  part (2) : If any person builds a house in a land without obtaining written consent of the owner of that land, the land-owner may, if he or she so desires, purchase the house on payment of the price that is less by up to twenty-five percent of the market price of that house.
output: According to Section 279(2), Rule: If a person builds a house on land without the owner's written consent, the land-owner may choose to purchase that house by paying a price up to 25% less than its market price. Application/Conclusion: As the land-owner you have the option to buy the unauthorized house by paying up to 25% below market value; you can exercise that choice instead of seeking demolition or other remedies.

instruction: I built a house on someone else's land without consent. Can I buy the land instead?
input: Section no 279  part (3) : If the land-owner does not purchase such house pursuant to sub-section (2), the house-owner may, if the owner so consents, purchase the land on payment of the price that is higher by up to twenty-five percent of the market price of the land where the house is located.
output: According to Section 279(3), Rule: If the land-owner does not buy the house, the person who built it may purchase the land — but only if the land-owner consents — by paying up to 25% more than the land's market price. Application/Conclusion: You can only buy the land where you built the house if the land-owner agrees; you would have to pay up to 25% above market price as permitted by this provision.

instruction: We can't agree on buying/selling after the illegal construction. What must the builder do?
input: Section no 279  part (4) : If both parties do not agree to purchase and sell the house or land pursuant to sub-section (2) or (3), the person who has built the house shall demolish the house and take away his or her materials within a period of three months of the date on which the house was so built.
output: According to Section 279(4), Rule: If neither party agrees to purchase or sell under the earlier subsections, the person who built the house must demolish it and remove the materials within three months of construction. Application/Conclusion: If you and the other party cannot reach an agreement, the builder is legally required to demolish the house and clear materials within three months from the date it was built.

instruction: What happens if the illegal house is not demolished within three months?
input: Section no 279  part (5) : If the house is not demolished within the period referred to in sub-section (4), such a house shall belong to the landowner.
output: According to Section 279(5), Rule: If the house is not demolished within the three-month period, the house becomes the property of the landowner. Application/Conclusion: If the builder fails to demolish and remove the house within the prescribed three months, ownership of that house vests in you as the landowner.

instruction: When I put a window facing my neighbor's land, do I have to leave any space?
input: Section no 280 . To leave land while putting window : If a person or government body has to build a house by putting a window or door towards the 155 neighbor’s land, the person or body shall leave the land according to the standards specified by the concerned body.
output: According to Section 280, Rule: A person or government body that builds a house with a window or door towards the neighbor’s land must leave land according to standards specified by the concerned body. Application/Conclusion: You must comply with the setback/space standards set by the relevant authority when placing a window or door facing a neighbor’s land; check those standards with the concerned body to know the exact required distance.

instruction: Can I direct my roof water to my neighbor's yard or to the public road?
input: Section no 281 . Prohibition of channeling water of house or roof : No person shall channel the water of his or her house or roof to other’s house or land or a public road.
output: According to Section 281, Rule: No person shall channel water from their house or roof to another person’s house or land or to a public road. Application/Conclusion: You are prohibited from diverting roof or household water onto a neighbor’s property or into a public road; you must arrange drainage so water does not flow onto others’ property or public ways.

instruction: Is it allowed to construct a safety tank adjoining my neighbor's land?
input: Section no 282  part (1) : No person shall construct a safety tank by adjoining it to the neighbor’s land.
output: According to Section 282(1), Rule: It is prohibited to construct a safety tank by adjoining it to a neighbor’s land. Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully build a safety tank directly adjoining your neighbor’s land; you must avoid placing the tank against their boundary.

instruction: If I need a safety tank on my plot, how much space must I leave from my neighbor's land?
input: Section no 282  part (2) : If a person has to construct a safety tank in his or her land, he or she shall leave at least the land according to the standards specified by the concerned body, except in cases where the neighbor’s consent is available.
output: According to Section 282(2), Rule: When constructing a safety tank, a person must leave land according to standards specified by the concerned body unless the neighbor’s consent is given. Application/Conclusion: You must follow the setback/spacing standards set by the relevant authority when siting a safety tank; only if the neighbor consents may you deviate from those standards.

instruction: How close to the boundary am I allowed to dig a well (Kuwa)?
input: Section no 283 . To leave land while digging well or Kuwa : In digging a well or a small ( Kuwa) in one’s land, one shall leave the land so that the distance of at least one meter can be maintained from the neighbor’s land.
output: According to Section 283, Rule: When digging a well or Kuwa, one must leave land so that at least one meter distance is maintained from the neighbor’s land. Application/Conclusion: You must keep a minimum one-meter distance from the neighboring boundary when digging a well or Kuwa on your land.

instruction: My neighbor's tree roots and branches are growing into my yard and affecting my property. What does the law say they should do?
input: Section no 284  part (2) : If any tree or plant planted by a person in one’s land cause any effect by expanding to other’s house, land or property, the person who has planted such tree or plants shall cut the branches or roots of the tree or plant in such manner as not to cause loss or damage to that person’s house, land or property.
output: According to Section 284(2), Rule: If a tree or plant planted by someone expands and affects another's house, land or property, the planter must cut branches or roots in a way that does not cause loss or damage to that other property. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor (the planter) is required to trim the offending branches or roots carefully so as not to cause damage; you can request they do so under this provision.

instruction: Am I allowed to plant a tree that will cause effects (shade/roots) to my neighbor's property?
input: Section no 284 . Prohibition of planting trees or plants causing effect : (1) No person shall plant a tree or plants in such a way so that it causes effects to other’s house, land or property.
output: According to Section 284(1), Rule: No person shall plant trees or plants in a manner that causes effects to another’s house, land or property. Application/Conclusion: You must not plant trees or plants so that they affect a neighbor’s property (for example by overhanging branches or invasive roots); planting in such a way is prohibited.

instruction: If my neighbor runs a business that makes strong smells and noise, can I still complain that it's damaging my property?
input: . Safety measures to be adopted : A person shall, while doing any work on his or her house or land, adopt safety measures in order to avoid any loss or damage or effect to the neighbor’s house or land in any manner. Provided that, except where a business transaction is carried on by any neighbor, matters such as gas, smell, smoke or noise of 154 general nature emitted or produced from the use by the neighbor of his or her house or land shall not be deemed to have caused a loss or damage or effect to the house or land.
output: According to Section 'Safety measures to be adopted', Rule: Generally a person must adopt safety measures to avoid causing loss or damage to a neighbor; however, matters such as gas, smell, smoke or general noise emitted from normal use of a neighbor’s house or land are not deemed to have caused loss or damage—except where a business transaction is carried on by the neighbor. Application/Conclusion: If your neighbor is simply living in their house, common smells/smoke/noise of general nature are generally not treated as damage. But if the neighbor is carrying on a business, those matters may not be excluded and you can more properly complain or seek remedies.

instruction: Under which section is the landowner's option to buy an unauthorized house stated? (I need the exact citation.)
input: Section no 279  part (2) : If any person builds a house in a land without obtaining written consent of the owner of that land, the land-owner may, if he or she so desires, purchase the house on payment of the price that is less by up to twenty-five percent of the market price of that house.
output: According to Section 279(2), Rule: This subsection sets out the land-owner’s option to purchase a house built without consent at a price up to 25% below market value. Application/Conclusion: The exact legal citation for the landowner’s purchase option is Section 279(2).

instruction: Ram built on my plot without telling me. I only found out today — how long do I have to make him demolish it?
input: Section no 279  part (4) : If both parties do not agree to purchase and sell the house or land pursuant to sub-section (2) or (3), the person who has built the house shall demolish the house and take away his or her materials within a period of three months of the date on which the house was so built.
output: According to Section 279(4), Rule: If the parties do not agree to purchase/sell under subsections (2) or (3), the builder must demolish and remove the house within three months from the date it was built. Application/Conclusion: The statutory period given to the builder for demolition is three months from the construction date; as landowner you can require demolition under this timeline if no purchase agreement is reached.

instruction: Can I register a government-owned plot of land in my own name?
input: Section no 305 . Prohibition of registration of government, public or community : properties: (1) No person shall register, or cause to be registered, any government, public or community property in his or her name.
output: According to Section 305 part (1): Rule: No person is allowed to register any government, public or community property in their own name. Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully register a government-owned plot in your name; any attempt to do so would contravene the prohibition in this provision.

instruction: What happens if someone nevertheless registers public land under their personal name?
input: Section no 305  part (2) : If a person registers, or causes to be registered, any government, public or community property in the name of any individual, such registration shall, ipso facto, be void.
output: According to Section 305 part (2): Rule: Any registration of government, public or community property in an individual's name is automatically void. Application/Conclusion: If someone registers public land in their name, that registration has no legal effect — it is void from the outset.

instruction: I suspect my neighbor registered community land in his name. If I file a complaint, how long will the Land Revenue Office take to decide?
input: Section no 305  part (3) : If a complaint is filed as to the registration of any government, public or community property in any individual’s name, the concerned Land Revenue Oﬀice shall summon the presence of the registrationholder also and inquire into the matter, as required, and make necessary decision within six months after the date of filing the complaint.
output: According to Section 305 part (3): Rule: Upon a complaint about registration, the Land Revenue Office must investigate, summon the registration-holder, and make a necessary decision within six months of filing. Application/Conclusion: After you file the complaint, expect the Land Revenue Office to conclude its inquiry and issue a decision within six months from your filing date.

instruction: If a registration of community land is annulled, what steps must the Land Revenue Officer take?
input: Section no 305  part (4) : If the registration of any government, public or community property in any individual’s name is annulled pursuant to this Section, the Land Revenue Oﬀicer shall make necessary entries in the records maintained in his or her oﬀice and give 165 information thereof to the concerned district level administrative oﬀice and Local Level.
output: According to Section 305 part (4): Rule: When such a registration is annulled, the Land Revenue Officer must update office records and inform the district level administrative office and Local Level. Application/Conclusion: If the registration is annulled in your case, the officer is legally required to correct the records and notify the relevant local and district authorities.

instruction: Is there a monetary penalty for illegally registering government or public property?
input: Section no 305  part (5) : The Land Revenue Oﬀice shall punish a person who registers, or causes to be registered, any government, public or community property in contravention of this Section with a fine of twenty-five thousand to one hundred thousand rupees.
output: According to Section 305 part (5): Rule: A person who registers government, public or community property in violation of this Section is liable to a fine between 25,000 and 100,000 rupees. Application/Conclusion: If someone registers such property illegally, they can be fined within that range by the Land Revenue Office.

instruction: If someone commits an offence by registering public land, can criminal proceedings still be taken even after civil annulment?
input: Section no 305  part (6) : The registration of government, public or community property in oneself or some individual’s name which in itself is offence as per prevailing laws, nothing written in this section shall be an obstacle to take action in offence related to it.
output: According to Section 305 part (6): Rule: This Section does not prevent taking action for offences under other prevailing laws relating to such registration. Application/Conclusion: Even if the registration is addressed civilly (annulled/fined), criminal or other offence-related proceedings permitted by other laws can still be initiated against the offender.

instruction: Who is responsible for protecting government, public or community properties?
input: Section no 304 . Obligation to protect government, public or community : properties: (1) The Government of Nepal, public organization or 164 community holding the right in, possession, custody of, and control over, the government, public or community properties shall itself protect such properties.
output: According to Section 304 part (1): Rule: The entity that holds the right, possession, custody and control — whether the Government of Nepal, a public organization, or a community — must itself protect those properties. Application/Conclusion: Responsibility to protect a property lies with whichever of those entities holds its rights and custody; they must take care of it themselves.

instruction: Is protecting government and public properties also a duty of district and local offices?
input: Section no 304  part (2) : To protect government and public properties shall be responsibility of the concerned district level administrative oﬀice and Local Level.
output: According to Section 304 part (2): Rule: The concerned district level administrative office and the Local Level are responsible for protecting government and public properties. Application/Conclusion: If the property is government or public property, the relevant district administrative office and Local Level bear the duty to ensure its protection.

instruction: Who protects community property?
input: Section no 304  part (3) : The concerned community and Local Level shall be responsible for the protection of the community property.
output: According to Section 304 part (3): Rule: The concerned community together with the Local Level are responsible for protecting community property. Application/Conclusion: For community-owned land or assets, the community itself and the Local Level must take responsibility for safeguarding them.

instruction: Can I possess or encroach on government or community land if no one complains?
input: Section no 306 . Prohibition of possession or cultivation of government, public : or community land: (1) No person shall possess any government, public or community land by way of overlapping, encroachment, surrounding or otherwise.
output: According to Section 306 part (1): Rule: No person may possess government, public or community land by overlapping, encroachment, surrounding or any other manner. Application/Conclusion: Even if there is no immediate complaint, you are not legally permitted to possess or encroach on such land — possession by encroachment is prohibited.

instruction: May I cultivate government land for farming if I start using it?
input: Section no 306  part (2) : No person shall, except with the permission of the Government of Nepal, concerned public organization or community, cultivate, or cause to be cultivated, any government, public or community land.
output: According to Section 306 part (2): Rule: Cultivation of government, public or community land is prohibited unless you have permission from the Government of Nepal, the concerned public organization, or the community. Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully cultivate that land unless you first obtain the appropriate permission from the authorized body.

instruction: Someone has been illegally cultivating community land. What can authorities do?
input: Section no 306  part (3) : If any person possesses or cultivates any government, public or community land in contravention of sub-section (1) or (2), the concerned Land Revenue Oﬀice, in the case of the government or public land, and the concerned Local Level, in the case of the community land, shall separate such land, recover the crops yielded in the land from that person and vacate the land.
output: According to Section 306 part (3): Rule: If a person possesses or cultivates such land unlawfully, the Land Revenue Office (for government/public land) or the Local Level (for community land) must separate the land, recover crops produced, and vacate the land. Application/Conclusion: Authorities can repossess the land, seize the harvest grown on it, and remove the unlawful possessor/cultivator.

instruction: Our community has been granted a piece of land under law. Will the Land Revenue Office register it in our community’s name?
input: part (2) : If any land is available to a community in accordance with law, the Land Revenue Oﬀice shall prepare the land ownership registration certificate of such land in the name of such community and provide it to that community.
output: According to Section (part 2) regarding community land registration: Rule: When land is available to a community in accordance with law, the Land Revenue Office must prepare and provide a land ownership registration certificate in the community's name. Application/Conclusion: If your community legally has the land, the Land Revenue Office is obliged to register it and give the registration certificate to the community.

instruction: If I file a complaint about an illegal registration, will the person who holds the registration be called in?
input: Section no 305  part (3) : If a complaint is filed as to the registration of any government, public or community property in any individual’s name, the concerned Land Revenue Oﬀice shall summon the presence of the registrationholder also and inquire into the matter, as required, and make necessary decision within six months after the date of filing the complaint.
output: According to Section 305 part (3): Rule: The Land Revenue Office must summon the registration-holder for inquiry when a complaint is filed and decide within six months. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the registration-holder will be summoned to appear and the office must investigate and reach a decision within six months of your complaint.

instruction: I bought a plot that the seller later admits was community land. Is my registered title valid?
input: Section no 305  part (2) : If a person registers, or causes to be registered, any government, public or community property in the name of any individual, such registration shall, ipso facto, be void.
output: According to Section 305 part (2): Rule: Registrations of government, public or community property in an individual's name are ipso facto void. Application/Conclusion: Your registered title is not valid if the land is government/public/community property; such a registration is automatically void and lacks legal effect.

instruction: Does the law define who 'protects' public property in simple terms?
input: Section no 304 . Obligation to protect government, public or community : properties: (1) The Government of Nepal, public organization or 164 community holding the right in, possession, custody of, and control over, the government, public or community properties shall itself protect such properties.
output: According to Section 304 part (1): Rule: The entity that holds rights, possession, custody and control — whether the Government, a public organization, or a community — must protect the property. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, whichever body legally owns or holds control of the property is responsible for protecting it.

instruction: My neighbour's tree branches hang over into my yard and he refuses to trim them. Can I cut them off myself?
input: part (3) : If a person who has planted such tree or plants fails to cut off the branches or roots of the tree or plants pursuant to sub 156 section (2), the person who is affected therefrom may cut off the branches or roots of such tree or plants on his or her own.
output: According to Section 156(3), the rule is that if the planter fails to remove branches or roots as required, the affected person may cut them off on their own. Applied to your situation: because your neighbour has failed to trim the overhanging branches as required, you are legally entitled to cut off those branches yourself (taking care to avoid unnecessary damage).

instruction: I cut off my neighbour's overhanging roots following the law, but he says I damaged his tree and wants money. Can he recover compensation?
input: Section no 285 . Compensation to be recovered : If any damage is caused to any person from any act done or action taken by any person under this Chapter, the damage sustaining person shall be entitled to recover a reasonable compensation from the person who has done such act.
output: According to Section 285, the rule is that if any damage is caused to a person by an act done under this Chapter, the injured party can recover reasonable compensation from the actor. Applied to your case: even though you cut roots under the authority given by the Chapter, if your act caused damage to your neighbour (for example serious harm to the tree), your neighbour may be entitled to seek reasonable compensation. You should document why you acted and that you acted under the Section allowing removal; that may limit or contextualize any compensation claim.

instruction: I just learned my neighbour removed a ditch that reduced my land's water. How long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 286 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date of knowledge of the commission of such act or action. 157
output: According to Section 286, the rule is that an aggrieved person must bring a lawsuit within six months from the date they learned of the act. Applied to your situation: you have six months from the date you became aware that the ditch removal reduced your water to start legal proceedings under this Chapter; if more than six months have passed, you risk being time-barred.

instruction: Can I cultivate a plot of land that someone else has the right and possession of, if they aren't using it?
input: Section no 287 . Prohibition of use of other’s land : No person shall cultivate or use, or cause to be cultivated or used, any land in which another person has right, possession and ownership, without consent of that person.
output: According to Section 287, the rule is that nobody may cultivate or use land in which another person has right, possession, or ownership without that person's consent. Applied to your question: even if the other person is not actively using the land, you cannot lawfully cultivate it without their consent.

instruction: A farmer says he needs to cut across my land to make a ditch to irrigate his field. Must I allow him to use part of my land for the ditch?
input: Section no 288 . Requirement to allow land to be used for ditch : (1) If a person who needs to construct a ditch through other’s land to cultivate land requests for land, the concerned owner of the land shall provide the land for the construction of the ditch through the place where the concerned landowner considers appropriate.
output: According to Section 288(1), the rule is that if someone requests land to construct a ditch for cultivation, the landowner must provide land for the ditch at a place the landowner considers appropriate. Applied here: you are required to allow the farmer to construct the ditch across your land when he requests it, but you have the right to specify the place on your land where the ditch will be constructed.

instruction: If my land is used for a ditch, what am I entitled to receive for that loss?
input: Section no 288  part (2) : In consideration for the land provided for construction of a ditch through it pursuant to sub-section (1), the person who constructs the ditch shall provide a substitute land, amount according to the prevailing price of the land used in the construction of the ditch or reasonable compensation to the concerned landowner.
output: According to Section 288(2), the rule is that the person who constructs the ditch must provide either substitute land, the market price of the land used, or reasonable compensation to the landowner. Applied to your case: when your land is used for a ditch, you are entitled to a substitute plot, payment equal to the prevailing land price for the portion used, or other reasonable compensation.

instruction: They built a ditch on land that belongs to the government, not to me. Do I get compensation?
input: Section no 288  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if a ditch is constructed in a public or government land, it is not required to provide a substitute land, price of land or compensation for the land used in construction of the ditch.
output: According to Section 288(3), the rule is that if a ditch is constructed on public or government land, no substitute land or compensation is required. Applied to your question: if the ditch sits entirely on public/government land, the constructor is not required to provide you substitute land or compensation for that public land use.

instruction: An upstream owner is taking all the stream water so my downstream field dries up. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 289 . Prohibition of using whole water of river or stream : No owner of a land shall so use the whole water of the river or stream which originates or flows from the land as to prevent the owner of downstream land from using the same or as to endanger the life of aquatic animals in the river or stream or as to adversely affect the ecological balance. 158
output: According to Section 289, the rule is that a landowner must not use the entire water of a river or stream originating/flowing from their land so as to prevent downstream owners from using it, endanger aquatic life, or harm ecological balance. Applied to your situation: the upstream owner cannot lawfully take all the water if doing so prevents you (a downstream owner) from using it, harms aquatic life, or disrupts ecology; you have grounds to object and seek remedy.

instruction: Someone wants to dig a new ditch above my irrigated field and I think it will reduce my water a lot. Can they do that?
input: Section no 290 . Prohibition of making new ditch affecting irrigated field : No person shall construct a new ditch above a land irrigated by a ditch already made and in operation in a manner to significantly lessen the volume of water in that land.
output: According to Section 290, the rule is that no one may construct a new upstream ditch in a way that significantly lessens the water volume reaching a land already irrigated by an existing ditch. Applied here: if the proposed new ditch would significantly reduce the water reaching your irrigated field, its construction is prohibited; you can challenge or stop the construction on that basis.

instruction: I paid and worked to build the village ditch. Do I get first use of its water?
input: Section no 291 . Use and allocation of ditch water : (1) A person who has spent labor or money in the construction of a ditch shall have the first priority to the ditch water for the cultivation of land.
output: According to Section 291(1), the rule is that whoever spent labor or money constructing a ditch has first priority to its water for cultivation. Applied to your situation: because you contributed labor or funds to build the ditch, you have first priority to use its water for cultivation before others.

instruction: Our village has a long-standing agreement on how to split ditch water. Does someone who paid to build the ditch get to override that?
input: Section no 291  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), in a place where people have been using the water according to agreed division between them from the time immemorial, all people shall be entitled to use the ditch water according to the division.
output: According to Section 291(2), the rule is that longstanding, time-immemorial agreements on water division prevail: everyone uses water according to that agreed division notwithstanding the priority rule for constructors. Applied here: if your village has an established customary division of the ditch water, that division continues to govern usage and cannot be overridden simply because someone paid to build the ditch.

instruction: If I paid to build the ditch but later don't need all the water, can my neighbour use the surplus?
input: Section no 291  part (3) : If the water is suﬀicient for or no longer required for a person who uses the water pursuant to sub-section (1), another person shall be entitled to use the ditch water for cultivating the land irrespective of the person whom the ditch belongs to.
output: According to Section 291(3), the rule is that if the constructor's water needs are met or they no longer require water, others may use the ditch water for cultivation regardless of ownership. Applied to your scenario: if you as the constructor have sufficient water or no longer need it, your neighbour may lawfully use the excess water for cultivation.

instruction: Can I refuse to let someone make a ditch across my land simply because I don't like them?
input: Section no 288 . Requirement to allow land to be used for ditch : (1) If a person who needs to construct a ditch through other’s land to cultivate land requests for land, the concerned owner of the land shall provide the land for the construction of the ditch through the place where the concerned landowner considers appropriate.
output: According to Section 288(1), the rule is that a landowner must provide land for a requested ditch intended for cultivation, though the owner chooses the place on their land. Applied to your question: you cannot refuse solely out of dislike; you must allow the ditch construction when properly requested, but you retain the right to select the exact location on your land.

instruction: Under which section does the law say I can get compensation if someone acting under this Chapter damages me?
input: Section no 285 . Compensation to be recovered : If any damage is caused to any person from any act done or action taken by any person under this Chapter, the damage sustaining person shall be entitled to recover a reasonable compensation from the person who has done such act.
output: According to Section 285, the rule is that anyone who suffers damage from an act taken under this Chapter is entitled to recover reasonable compensation from the actor. Applied to your need for citation: Section 285 is the provision that creates the right to claim compensation for damage caused by acts under the Chapter.

instruction: I discovered yesterday that a ditch was dug through my land six months ago without telling me. Am I out of time to sue?
input: Section no 286 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date of knowledge of the commission of such act or action. 157
output: According to Section 286, the rule is that an aggrieved person has six months from the date they learn of the act to bring a lawsuit. Applied to your fact: since you only learned about the ditch yesterday, the six-month clock starts from yesterday; you still have six months from that date to file suit under the Chapter.

instruction: A developer built a ditch on land that used to belong to the community (public land). Do private owners get compensation for loss of use?
input: Section no 288  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if a ditch is constructed in a public or government land, it is not required to provide a substitute land, price of land or compensation for the land used in construction of the ditch.
output: According to Section 288(3), the rule is that when a ditch is built on public/government land, there is no requirement to provide substitute land or compensation. Applied to your question: private owners are not entitled to compensation under this provision for a ditch constructed on public land; the constructor need not provide substitute land or pay compensation for that public land use.

instruction: Can I report someone who registered government land in their name? Will I get anything for reporting?
input:
. To reward complainant : (1) Any person whosoever may make a complaint with the concerned body on the matters of registration, or causing registration, of a government, public or community property, or possession, use or cultivation of a land under such property or construction work done in such land, in contravention of this Chapter.
Section no 310  part (2) : If, on inquiring into a complaint made pursuant to sub section (1), the complaint is held to be true, the concerned body shall provide the complainant with a reward in a sum that is half the fine imposed on the wrongdoer pursuant to this Chapter.
output: According to Section 310 (parts (1) and (2)): Rule: Any person may make a complaint about improper registration or use of government/public/community property, and if the complaint is found true the complainant is entitled to a reward equal to half the fine imposed on the wrongdoer. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can report such registration; if the inquiry finds your complaint true, you should receive a reward equal to half of the fine imposed on the offender.

instruction: If I file a complaint, can the authority keep my identity secret?
input: Section no 310  part (3) : The concerned body may keep confidential a complaint made pursuant to sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 310(3): Rule: The concerned body has the discretion to keep a complaint confidential. Application/Conclusion: The authority may, at its option, keep your complaint confidential — so you can request confidentiality and the body is empowered to maintain it.

instruction: What happens if a government employee knowingly registers public land in someone's name?
input:
Section no 311 . Action to be taken : (1) If any employee, either knowingly or negligently or recklessly registers, or causes to be registered, any government, public or community property in the name of any person or if any employee with the duty to render assistance pursuant to this Chapter does not render such assistance, such employee shall be liable to departmental action in accordance with the law of terms and conditions of his or her service.
Section no 311  part (2) : Nothing shall prevent the taking of action against an employee who commits an act referred to in sub-section (1) on a criminal offence, in addition to the action taken under sub-section
output: According to Section 311 (parts (1) and (2)): Rule: An employee who knowingly, negligently or recklessly registers government/public/community property in someone else's name, or fails to render required assistance, is liable to departmental (service) action; additionally, criminal proceedings may also be pursued. Application/Conclusion: Such an employee can face disciplinary action under service rules and may also be prosecuted criminally — you can expect both administrative and possible criminal remedies against them.

instruction: Who can file a case on behalf of the government if a decision harms public property?
input:
Section no 312 . Governmental attorney empowered to file or make case, : petition or appeal: (1) The concerned government attorney shall have power to file or make a case, petition or appeal against any 169 decision made by any body or authority, adversely affecting any government or public property.
Section no 312  part (2) : The concerned oﬀice or authority shall provide the government attorney with such documents and other assistance as may be necessary in relation to the filing or making of a case, petition or appeal pursuant to sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 312 (parts (1) and (2)): Rule: The concerned government attorney is empowered to file cases, petitions or appeals against decisions that adversely affect government or public property, and the relevant office must provide necessary documents and assistance. Application/Conclusion: The government attorney is the authorized person to take legal action for the government in such matters, and you can expect government offices to cooperate by supplying records and help for that legal action.

instruction: I found out today that my village commons were registered to someone else last month. How long do I have to sue?
input: Section no 313 . Statute of limitation : A person may make a lawsuit at any time in the cases of Sections 305, 306 and 307 of this Chapter, and a person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken referred to in other Sections of this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken.
output: According to Section 313: Rule: For matters other than Sections 305–307, an aggrieved person must file suit within six months from the date of the act or action. Application/Conclusion: Because your grievance concerns another section of this Chapter, you generally have six months from the date the registration occurred to file a lawsuit — act promptly to preserve your rights.

instruction: Can I sue at any time for issues under Sections 305–307?
input: Section no 313 . Statute of limitation : A person may make a lawsuit at any time in the cases of Sections 305, 306 and 307 of this Chapter, and a person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken referred to in other Sections of this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken.
output: According to Section 313: Rule: Lawsuits under Sections 305, 306 and 307 may be filed at any time (no time limit). Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your matter falls under Section 305, 306 or 307, there is no statute of limitation and you may file a suit at any time.

instruction: My father gave a plot to a committee to manage for the community. Is that a trust under the law?
input:
Section no 314 .
Trust deemed to be established : If a person makes necessary arrangements for the operation and management by another of a property in which the person has right, ownership and possession for the benefit of beneficiary, a trust shall be deemed to be established. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “beneficiary” means a person, group, general public, body whether incorporated or unincorporated, or community getting the benefit from the trust property.
output: According to Section 314: Rule: A trust is deemed established when a person arranges for another to operate and manage property he/she owns for the benefit of a beneficiary (broadly defined). Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your father made arrangements for another party to operate and manage the plot for the benefit of the community (a beneficiary), the arrangement is treated as a trust under this Chapter.

instruction: What does 'beneficiary' include here? Simple terms, please.
input:
Section no 314 .
Trust deemed to be established : If a person makes necessary arrangements for the operation and management by another of a property in which the person has right, ownership and possession for the benefit of beneficiary, a trust shall be deemed to be established. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “beneficiary” means a person, group, general public, body whether incorporated or unincorporated, or community getting the benefit from the trust property.
output: According to Section 314: Rule: The law defines "beneficiary" broadly to include an individual, a group, the general public, an incorporated or unincorporated body, or a community that benefits from the trust property. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, anyone or any organized group (including the general public or a community) who receives benefit from the property can be a beneficiary under this Chapter.

instruction: Can a trust be only private, or can it be public too?
input: Section no 315 . Trust may be public or private : (1) A trust may be either public or private.
output: According to Section 315(1): Rule: A trust may be either public or private. Application/Conclusion: The law recognizes both types — your trust can be established and classified as either private or public depending on its purpose and beneficiaries.

instruction: My local group wants to create a fund to build a road for the village. Would that make the trust a public trust?

Application/Conclusion: Yes — creating a fund to build a village road (infrastructure/development work) would qualify the trust as a public trust under this provision.

instruction: We want to run a training program and provide jobs for low-income people through a trust. Is that considered a public trust?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (b) : To establish and operate a fund necessary for the development of skills, creation of employment opportunities and development of the people with low income,
output: According to Section 315(2)(b): Rule: A trust established to fund skill development, create employment opportunities and develop low-income people is deemed a public trust. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a trust with those objectives would be treated as a public trust, because it aims to develop skills and employment for low-income persons.

instruction: Under which section does the law allow a complainant to be rewarded?
input: Section no 310  part (2) : If, on inquiring into a complaint made pursuant to sub section (1), the complaint is held to be true, the concerned body shall provide the complainant with a reward in a sum that is half the fine imposed on the wrongdoer pursuant to this Chapter.
output: According to Section 310(2): Rule: The concerned body shall provide the complainant a reward equal to half the fine imposed on the wrongdoer if the complaint is upheld. instruction: My neighbor owns the land where a ditch is built, but several of us use it. He altered the ditch without asking. What does the law say?
input:
Section no 292 . Prohibition of alteration in ditch without consent :
If any ditch is constructed only in the land of a person and other persons have
also been using the ditch, the owner of land where such ditch is situated shall
not be allowed to alter the ditch without consent of the other persons using it.
output: According to Section 292, the owner of the land where a ditch is situated shall not be allowed to alter the ditch without the consent of the other persons using it. Rule: An owner cannot change a ditch used by others unless those users consent. Application/Conclusion: Since you and others were using that ditch and your neighbor altered it without your consent, his alteration is prohibited under Section 292 — you can insist on consent before further changes or seek remedy for the unauthorized alteration.

instruction: I didn't join in repairing the irrigation ditch last season. Can I still use water from that ditch this year?
input:
Section no 293 . One who does not make labor or expenses in making
ditch not : allowed to use water: (1) While making a new ditch or repairing 159
an old ditch, all persons who use the water of such ditch shall make necessary
labor or expenses in proportion to their respective land.
 Section no 293  part (2) : A person who does not make labor or expenses in
making a new ditch or repairing an old one pursuant to sub-section
 Section no 293  part (1) : shall not be entitled to use the water of such a
ditch.
output: According to Section 293, persons who use a ditch must contribute labor or expenses proportionally when a new ditch is made or an old one repaired, and those who do not contribute pursuant to subsection (1) shall not be entitled to use the water. Rule: Non-contributors to construction/repair forfeit the right to use that ditch's water. Application/Conclusion: Because you did not participate in making or repairing the ditch as required, you are not entitled to use its water under Section 293 unless you now make the required contribution.

instruction: We among five landowners have a written agreement about building a ditch and sharing water. Does that agreement count, even if the general rules differ?
input:
Section no 294 . Construction of ditch or use of water with mutual
consent : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if
there is a separate agreement between the concerned land-owners or those who
make a ditch or who are users of water in relation to the construction of ditch
or using of water for the cultivation of land, the ditch may be made or water
used according to that agreement.
output: According to Section 294, if there is a separate agreement between concerned land-owners or users regarding construction of a ditch or use of water, the ditch may be made or water used according to that agreement. Rule: Parties’ mutual agreement overrides other Chapter provisions. Application/Conclusion: Your written agreement governs how the ditch is built and water is used among you, so long as it is between the concerned landowners/users, and you may follow that agreement.

instruction: A river changed course and left a strip of land on my side. Can I cultivate it?
input:
Section no 295 . Cultivation of land adjacent to river bank : If a river
or stream enters in a land and divides it or cuts a land, the land shall belong to
its owner and may be cultivated by the owner after the river or stream changes
its course and leaves the land.
output: According to Section 295, when a river or stream changes its course and leaves land, that land belongs to its owner and may be cultivated by the owner. Rule: Land exposed after the river changes course remains the owner's and can be cultivated. Application/Conclusion: If the strip left by the changed river course belonged to you before, you may cultivate it now under Section 295.

instruction: Can I register someone else's land under my name if they don't object right away?
input:
Section no 296 . Prohibition of registration : No person shall register, or
cause to be registered, other’s land in his or her name.
output: According to Section 296, no person shall register, or cause to be registered, other’s land in his or her name. Rule: Registering another person's land in your name is prohibited. Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully register land that belongs to someone else in your name, regardless of whether they object immediately.

instruction: My father (the registered holder) died last week. How long do I have to apply to transfer the land to my name?
input:
Section no 297  part (1) : If a person needs to have transfer of a land on
the death of its registration holder or to have registration and deregistration of
a land in which the person has got right in any manner, the concerned person
shall submit an application to the Land Revenue Oﬀice and obtain transmission
and registration and deregistration of the matter within thirty-five days of the
occurrence of such an event.
output: According to Section 297 part (1), the concerned person shall submit an application to the Land Revenue Office and obtain transmission and registration and deregistration of the matter within thirty-five days of the occurrence of such an event. Rule: A 35-day time limit applies to apply for transfer after death of the registered holder. Application/Conclusion: You must submit the application for transmission/registration to the Land Revenue Office within 35 days from your father's death to comply with Section 297(1).

instruction: I missed the 35-day period to register inherited land. Can I still get it registered, and will there be a penalty?
input:

and registration and deregistration of the matter after the expiry of the 160
time-limit referred to in sub-section (1), the Land Revenue Oﬀice shall execute
the transmission and registration of such land in the applicant’s name by collecting the fee of one hundred rupees irrespective of the length of time after such
expiration.
output: According to Section 297 part (2), if an application is submitted after the expiry of the time-limit referred to in subsection (1), the Land Revenue Office shall execute the transmission and registration by collecting the fee of one hundred rupees irrespective of the length of time after such expiration. Rule: Late applications are still accepted; a fixed fee of Rs.100 is collected regardless of delay. Application/Conclusion: Although you missed the 35-day deadline, you can still get the land transmitted and registered in your name by applying to the Land Revenue Office and paying the Rs.100 fee prescribed by Section 297(2).

instruction: I just noticed someone did something under this Chapter that harmed my rights. How long do I have to file a lawsuit?

act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six
months after the date of knowledge of commission of such an act or action.
output: According to Section 298, an aggrieved person may make a lawsuit within six months after the date of knowledge of commission of such an act or action. Rule: A six-month limitation period runs from knowledge of the act. Application/Conclusion: You have six months from the date you learned about the harmful act under this Chapter to file a lawsuit under Section 298.

instruction: In plain words, what kinds of things are 'government property' according to the law? Give examples.
input:
Section no 299 . Property deemed to be government property : The
following property title to which belongs to, or which is owned, controlled by,
or subject to, the Government of Nepal, Province Government and Local Government shall be deemed to be the government property:
 Section no 299  clause (a) : Government houses, buildings or lands,
 Section no 299  clause (b) : Roads, paths or railways,
 Section no 299  clause (c) : Forests, or trees or trees, bushes in forests,
 Section no 299
output: According to Section 299, property that belongs to, is owned, controlled by, or subject to the Government of Nepal, Province Government or Local Government is deemed government property; examples listed include government houses/buildings/lands (clause a), roads/paths/railways (clause b), and forests/trees/bushes in forests (clause c). Rule: The listed categories are treated as government property. Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, official buildings and lands, public roads and railways, and forests/trees/vegetation identified in Section 299 are government property.

instruction: Can I register the plot I bought if the seller's brother objects and claims it's his?
input:

output: According to Section 296, no person shall register, or cause to be registered, other’s land in his or her name. Rule: Registration of someone else's land in your name is prohibited. Application/Conclusion: If the seller's brother legitimately owns the plot, you cannot register it in your name. If you legitimately bought it from the true owner, you must ensure proper transmission/registration procedures are followed; but you may not register land that legally belongs to another person under Section 296.

instruction: He promised to let me use the ditch but stopped after altering it. Short and blunt: Can he do that?

instruction: I was promised registration as security for a loan but the owner hasn't registered it to me. Can I register it myself?

instruction: Can neighbors make their own arrangement about how to use irrigation water even if the statute says otherwise?

instruction: I just discovered today that someone registered my land wrongly five months ago. How long do I have to bring a suit?
