Application/Conclusion: If the separated part still belongs to you, you may cultivate it now that the stream changed course, under Section 295.

instruction: Can I set up a trust to run a school or college for the community?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (d) : To establish and operate such educational and academic institutes like schools, colleges and 171 universities as may be useful for the general public,
output: According to Section 315(2)(d), the law allows trusts to establish and operate educational and academic institutes like schools, colleges and universities for the general public. Rule: A trust may be created with the object of establishing and operating educational institutions that are useful for the general public. Application/Conclusion: If your trust’s purpose is to set up a school or college intended to benefit the general public, that objective is expressly permitted; you can proceed to establish such a trust under this provision.

instruction: I want to open a clinic through a trust. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (e) : To establish and operate clinics such as hospitals and health posts for public purposes,
output: According to Section 315(2)(e), trusts may be established to create and operate clinics, hospitals and health posts for public purposes. Rule: Establishing healthcare facilities for public purposes is a permitted object of a trust. Application/Conclusion: You may establish a trust whose object is to run a clinic or hospital intended for public benefit; this activity is explicitly recognized as a lawful trust purpose.

instruction: Can I form a trust to run social welfare programs?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (c) : To operate social welfare programs,
output: According to Section 315(2)(c), operating social welfare programs is a permitted object of a trust. Rule: Trusts can be established to operate social welfare programs. Application/Conclusion: If your proposed trust aims to run social welfare initiatives, that objective falls within the statutory list of permissible public purposes, so forming the trust for that purpose is allowed.

instruction: If I set up a trust only to benefit my cousin, is that a public trust?
input: Section no 315  part (3) : A trust which is established with object to render benefit, advantage or facility to any particular person or group shall be deemed to be a private trust.
output: According to Section 315(3), a trust established to benefit any particular person or group is deemed a private trust. Rule: Trusts whose objects confer benefit on specific individuals or groups are classified as private trusts (not public). Application/Conclusion: Because your trust is intended solely to benefit your cousin (a particular person), it would be treated as a private trust under this provision, not a public trust.

instruction: If my trust has both public projects and private beneficiaries, how is it classified?
input: Section no 315  part (4) : If a trust is established to accomplish both public and private objectives, such a trust shall be deemed to be a public trust. 172
output: According to Section 315(4), a trust established to accomplish both public and private objectives shall be deemed a public trust. Rule: Mixed-object trusts (both public and private aims) are classified as public trusts. Application/Conclusion: If your trust contains elements that benefit the general public alongside provisions that advantage particular individuals, the trust will be treated as a public trust under this rule.

instruction: What must I include in the application to establish a trust? (Short and direct)
input: Section no 316 . Application to be made for establishment of trust : (1) A person who intends to establish a trust shall make an application, setting out the following matters, to the Registrar:
output: According to Section 316(1), a person intending to establish a trust must make an application to the Registrar setting out specified matters. Rule: An application to establish a trust must be submitted to the Registrar and must set out the matters required by the section. Application/Conclusion: You must apply to the Registrar to establish the trust and include the required details (see the specific matters listed in subsections (a)–(d) of Section 316(1)).

instruction: What specific matters must be stated in that application?
input:
Section no 316  clause (a) : Value and details of the property held for the trust,
 Section no 316  clause (b) : Beneficiary, and benefit and facility to the beneficiary, the terms and limitation thereof,
 Section no 316  clause (c) : If the trust is to be established for any particular period, matter relating thereto,
 Section no 316  clause (d) : Other necessary details.
output: According to Section 316(1)(a)–(d), the application must state the value and details of trust property; the beneficiary and the nature, terms and limitations of benefits; any matters relating to a particular period if the trust is time-limited; and other necessary details. Rule: The application must comprehensively disclose the trust property, beneficiaries and their entitlements, duration (if any), and other necessary particulars. Application/Conclusion: When you prepare the application, include the property’s value and details, identify beneficiaries and describe their benefits and any limits, state duration-related matters if applicable, and add any other required details to satisfy the Registrar’s requirements.

instruction: Which documents do I need to submit along with my application to register a trust?
input:
Section no 316  part (2) : In making an application pursuant to sub-section (1), the following documents shall also be submitted with the application:
 Section no 316  part (2) (a) : Memorandum of incorporation of the trust,
 Section no 316  part (2) (b) : Trustee’s name and photocopy of the deed relating to his or her consent,
 Section no 316  part (2) (c) : Photocopy of the deed, if any, executed for the establishment of the trust,
 Section no 316  part (2) (d) : Photocopy of a reliable deed relating to the trust settler’s identity, and, in the case of the trust settler being a body corporate, certified copies of the documents relating to the incorporation of the body corporate and of the decision by such a body corporate in relation to the establishment of trust,
 Section no 316  part (2) (e) : Receipt of payment of the fees chargeable by law for the registration of trust. 173
output: According to Section 316(2)(a)–(e), you must submit the memorandum of incorporation of the trust; the trustee’s name and a photocopy of the deed showing their consent; a photocopy of any deed executed to establish the trust; a photocopy of a reliable identity deed for the settlor (and, where the settlor is a body corporate, certified incorporation documents and the corporate decision to establish the trust); and the receipt for payment of registration fees. Rule: These documents are mandatory attachments to the application for establishing a trust. Application/Conclusion: Prepare and attach all the listed documents—memorandum, trustee consent deed copy, establishment deed copy (if any), settlor identity proof (and corporate documents if applicable), and the fee receipt—when filing with the Registrar.

instruction: I'm a company wanting to be the settler of a trust. What specific documents will I need to attach regarding the company?
input: Section no 316  part (2) (d) : Photocopy of a reliable deed relating to the trust settler’s identity, and, in the case of the trust settler being a body corporate, certified copies of the documents relating to the incorporation of the body corporate and of the decision by such a body corporate in relation to the establishment of trust,
output: According to Section 316(2)(d), where the settlor is a body corporate you must submit certified copies of the incorporation documents and the corporate decision authorizing establishment of the trust, along with a reliable identity deed. Rule: Corporate settlors must provide certified incorporation documents and evidence of the corporate decision to establish the trust. Application/Conclusion: As a company settlor, include a reliable identity deed plus certified copies of your company’s incorporation papers and the corporate resolution/decision authorizing the trust when applying for registration.

instruction: Do I need to show the trustee's consent when registering the trust?
input: Section no 316  part (2) (b) : Trustee’s name and photocopy of the deed relating to his or her consent,
output: According to Section 316(2)(b), the application must include the trustee’s name and a photocopy of the deed showing his or her consent. Rule: Proof of the trustee’s consent is a required document for registration. Application/Conclusion: You must obtain and attach a deed evidencing the trustee’s consent (and include the trustee’s name) when submitting the trust registration application.

instruction: Is there a requirement to pay registration fees when applying for a trust?
input: Section no 316  part (2) (e) : Receipt of payment of the fees chargeable by law for the registration of trust. 173
output: According to Section 316(2)(e), you must submit the receipt of payment of the fees chargeable by law for registration of the trust. Rule: Payment of the prescribed registration fees and submission of the receipt is mandatory. Application/Conclusion: Before or when filing the application, pay the applicable registration fee and include the payment receipt with your documents; the Registrar requires that receipt.

instruction: If my trust will only run for a fixed period, do I need to mention that in the application?
input: Section no 316  clause (c) : If the trust is to be established for any particular period, matter relating thereto,
output: According to Section 316(1)(c), if the trust is to be established for any particular period, matters relating to that period must be set out in the application. Rule: The application must disclose duration-related matters when the trust is time-limited. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your trust is intended to operate for a specified period, you must state the relevant details about that period in the application to the Registrar.

instruction: Can a trust be created to protect wildlife and the environment?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (g) : To operate programs for the protection of wildlife, aquatic animals or environment,
output: According to Section 315(2)(g), trusts may operate programs to protect wildlife, aquatic animals or the environment. Rule: Environmental and wildlife protection programs are permissible trust objects. Application/Conclusion: You can validly form a trust with the object of protecting wildlife, aquatic animals, or the environment; such programs fall within the statutory list of public purposes for trusts.

instruction: Can I use a trust to promote cultural heritage or protect historical sites?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (f) : To protect natural, historical or cultural heritages or to promote such act,
output: According to Section 315(2)(f), trusts may be established to protect natural, historical or cultural heritages or to promote such acts. Rule: Protection and promotion of natural, historical or cultural heritage are permitted trust purposes. Application/Conclusion: If your trust’s objective is to protect or promote heritage or historical/cultural sites for public benefit, forming such a trust is expressly allowed by the statute.

instruction: I want to run rescue operations through a trust — is that covered?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (k) : To operate rescue works,
output: According to Section 315(2)(k), operating rescue works is a permitted object of a trust. Rule: Trusts can be formed to carry out rescue operations. Application/Conclusion: You may establish a trust with the objective of conducting rescue works; this purpose is specifically listed as allowable under the law.

instruction: Can a trust be used to run religious activities like temples or monasteries?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (l) : To establish shrines, temples, monasteries, domes, mosques, churches or carry out similar other religious activities,
output: According to Section 315(2)(l), trusts may establish shrines, temples, monasteries, domes, mosques, churches or carry out similar religious activities. Rule: Setting up and operating places of worship and similar religious activities are permitted trust objects. Application/Conclusion: If your trust’s purpose is to establish or operate religious institutions or carry out analogous religious activities for public benefit, it is permitted under this provision.

instruction: Is running sports programs a valid trust objective?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (i) : To operate programs relating to sports,
output: According to Section 315(2)(i), operating programs relating to sports is a permissible object for a trust. Rule: Trusts may be created to run sports-related programs. Application/Conclusion: You can form a trust whose objective is to operate sports programs; that purpose is explicitly allowed by the statute.

instruction: What does the law say about trusts that operate public programs generally — is there a catch-all provision?
input: Section no 315  part (2) (m) : To operate other public programs for the interest of public.
output: According to Section 315(2)(m), trusts may operate other public programs serving the public interest. Rule: Beyond the specifically listed objects, trusts are permitted to carry out other public programs that benefit the public. Application/Conclusion: If your proposed trust aims to run public-interest programs not expressly listed elsewhere in Section 315(2), this catch‑all provision supports such an objective so long as the programs serve the public interest.

instruction: Who is the 'Registrar' I need to apply to — what does the law define as Registrar?
input:
Explanation: For the purposes of this
 Chapter:
 Section no 316  part (1) : “Registrar” means the authority provided for by
 law for the registration, supervision and liquidation of trusts, and this term also
 includes the Land Revenue Oﬀicer in the concerned district if such authority is
 not so provided for.
output: According to Section 316(1) (Explanation), the term 'Registrar' means the authority provided by law for registration, supervision and liquidation of trusts, and includes the Land Revenue Officer in the district if no such authority is provided. Rule: The Registrar is the designated legal authority responsible for trust registration/supervision/liquidation; where no authority exists, the Land Revenue Officer stands in. Application/Conclusion: When preparing your application, submit it to the legally designated Registrar for trusts; if no such authority exists in your district, the Land Revenue Officer performs the Registrar’s functions.

instruction: How does the law define the word 'Trustee' for trust registration purposes?
input: Section no 316  part (2) : “Trustee” means the person who is responsible for the operation and management of a trust property.
output: According to Section 316(2) (Explanation), a 'Trustee' means the person responsible for the operation and management of a trust property. Rule: The trustee is the individual charged with operating and managing trust property. Application/Conclusion: In your application and documents, identify the trustee(s) who will manage the trust property because the law treats them as the persons responsible for the trust’s operation and management.

instruction: Can I sell the village pond that people have been using for generations?
input:
Section no 300  clause (b) : Wells, water conduits, shores, ponds and banks thereof, 162
Section no 300  part (2) : The ownership of the public property shall vest in the public body or the Government of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 300(1)(b) and Section 300 part (2).
Rule: Wells, water conduits, shores, ponds and their banks are listed as public property, and ownership of public property vests in the public body or the Government of Nepal.
Application/Conclusion: Because the pond and its banks are listed as public property, you cannot unilaterally sell it as private property. The title/ownership is vested in the public body or the Government, so any use, transfer or disposal would require action by the public body or the Government as per applicable public procedures.

instruction: Does the law mention rivers and streams anywhere?
input:
clause (d) : Rivers, rivulets, streams, lakes, ponds and banks thereof,
 Section no 299
output:
According to Section 299 clause (d).
Rule: Section 299 explicitly lists rivers, rivulets, streams, lakes, ponds and their banks among the items set out in that provision.
Application/Conclusion: The statute explicitly refers to rivers and streams in Section 299(d). To know the legal consequences (for example whether they are public or otherwise) you must read the related provisions that classify public or other types of property (such as Section 300).

instruction: In simple words, what does 'public property' include under this law?
input:
Section no 300 . Property deemed to be public property : (1) The
following property which is for public purpose shall be deemed to be the public
property:
 Section no 300  clause (a) : Houses, lands, sewerage or roads having been
used since ancient times,
 Section no 300  clause (b) : Wells, water conduits, shores, ponds and banks
thereof, 162
 Section no 300  clause (c) : Exits for chattels, pasture lands, Kharka, graveyards, Chihan, Samadhisthal, Kabristan and lands where these are located,
 Section no 300  clause (d) : Inns, Pauwas, Dewals, religious meditation sites,
memorials, temples, shrines, Chaitya, monasteries, Stupas, churches, Chowk,
Dawali, Chautari or lands where these are located,
 Section no 300  clause (e) : Lands where fairs, markets and public entertainment or sports sites are located,
 Section no 300  clause (f) : Private property provided by any person for
public purposes,
 Section no 300  clause (g) : Such other property as prescribed to be the
public property by the Government of Nepal, by a notification in the Nepal
Gazette.
output:
According to Section 300(1) clauses (a)–(g).
Rule: The statute lists specific types of property that are deemed public property when used for public purposes, including anciently used houses/lands/roads, wells and ponds, pastures and graveyards, religious and communal structures and lands for fairs and markets, privately donated public-use land, and any other property notified by the Government.
Application/Conclusion: In plain language, public property includes long-used public roads and lands, water sources and their banks, communal pastures and burial grounds, temples and public rest spots, market and fairgrounds, privately donated land for public use, and anything else the Government formally declares public. If your land matches one of these categories, it will be treated as public property.

instruction: My village community says the grazing field belongs to all of us. Is that considered community property under the law?
input:
Section no 301 . Property deemed to be community property : Any
land held by a community for its use, any structure built in such land or other
property owned by it shall be deemed to be the community property.
output:
According to Section 301.
Rule: Any land held by a community for its use, and structures or other property owned by that community, are deemed community property.
Application/Conclusion: If the grazing field is held by the community for communal use, it qualifies as community property under Section 301. The community collectively holds rights in that land rather than any single individual owning it outright.

instruction: What details must the Land Revenue Office prepare and update about government and public properties in the district?
input:
Section no 302 .
Details to be updated : (1) The Land Revenue Oﬀice
shall prepare and update the following details in relation to the government and
public properties situated within the district:
 Section no 302  clause (a) : The location where the government or public
properties are situated, plot number and area, in the case of a land, and situation
of the house, if any, 163
 Section no 302  clause (b) : If the government or public properties are possessed by, or subjected to, any body or organization, details thereof,
 Section no 302  clause (c) : Other necessary details.
output:
According to Section 302(1) clauses (a)–(c).
Rule: The Land Revenue Office must prepare and update location, plot number, area and house situation for government/public properties; details about possession or any body/organization occupying them; and other necessary details.
Application/Conclusion: The Land Revenue Office is legally required to record precise location and plot information, who possesses or uses the property (if any organization/body is involved), and any other relevant details. You can ask the Office for these recorded particulars for any government or public property in the district.

instruction: Is the Local Level obliged to help the Land Revenue Office with these updates?
input:
Section no 302  part (2) : The Local Level shall render necessary assistance
to the Land Revenue Oﬀice in preparing the details referred to in sub section
(1).
output:
According to Section 302 part (2).
Rule: The Local Level must render necessary assistance to the Land Revenue Office in preparing the property details described in subsection (1).
Application/Conclusion: Yes. The Local Level has a statutory duty to assist the Land Revenue Office in compiling and updating details of government and public properties. If the Land Revenue Office lacks information, the Local Level should provide support.

instruction: Once the Land Revenue Office prepares the property details, where must copies be sent?
input:
Section no 302  part (3) : After the preparation of the details pursuant to
sub section (1), the Land Revenue Oﬀice shall forward a copy thereof to the
concerned district level administrative oﬀice and Local Level.
output:
According to Section 302 part (3).
Rule: After preparing the details, the Land Revenue Office must forward a copy to the concerned district-level administrative office and the Local Level.
Application/Conclusion: Once the Land Revenue Office completes the property records, those records must be sent to both the district administrative office and the local authority. You can therefore request those offices for copies of the updated records.

instruction: Who is responsible for collecting and updating details of community properties?
input:
Section no 302  part (4) : The Local Level shall collect and update the details
referred to in sub-section (1) in relation to the community properties situated
within its jurisdiction and forward a copy thereof to the concerned Land Revenue
Oﬀice.
output:
According to Section 302 part (4).
Rule: The Local Level must collect and update the details for community properties within its jurisdiction and forward a copy to the Land Revenue Office.
Application/Conclusion: The Local Level is responsible for maintaining records of community properties in its area and must send those records to the Land Revenue Office. If community property information is missing, approach your Local Level to obtain or correct it.

instruction: If government land is held in the name of a public organization, can that organization get a land ownership registration certificate?
input:
Section no 303 . Land ownership registration certificate to be provided
: (1) If any government land is held in the name of a government body or
public organization, the Land Revenue Oﬀice shall prepare the land ownership
registration certificate of such land in the name of such body or organization
and provide it to such body or organization.
 Section no 303
output:
According to Section 303(1).
Rule: When government land is held in the name of a government body or public organization, the Land Revenue Office must prepare and provide a land ownership registration certificate in that body's or organization's name.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. If government land is recorded in the name of a government body or public organization, the Land Revenue Office is required to issue a land ownership registration certificate to that body/organization. The organization can request the certificate from the Office.

instruction: Are lands where fairs and markets happen treated specially by the law?
input: Section no 300  clause (e) : Lands where fairs, markets and public entertainment or sports sites are located,
output:
According to Section 300(1)(e).
Rule: Lands where fairs, markets and public entertainment or sports sites are located are listed among property deemed to be public property.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. Land used for fairs, markets, public entertainment or sports is classified as public property under Section 300(1)(e). Such lands are treated as public property and are subject to relevant public ownership and management rules.

instruction: Someone donated their private land so the whole village could use it. Does that make it public property?
input:
Section no 300  clause (f) : Private property provided by any person for
public purposes,
output:
According to Section 300(1)(f).
Rule: Private property provided by any person for public purposes is included among property deemed to be public property.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. If a private owner has provided land for public purposes, that land is treated as public property under Section 300(1)(f). The donation converts the property's status for legal purposes to public property, subject to applicable formalities and registration.

instruction: Are temples, Chaitya and monasteries considered public property?
input:
Section no 300  clause (d) : Inns, Pauwas, Dewals, religious meditation sites,
memorials, temples, shrines, Chaitya, monasteries, Stupas, churches, Chowk,
Dawali, Chautari or lands where these are located,
output:
According to Section 300(1)(d).
Rule: Religious structures and associated lands such as inns, temples, Chaitya, monasteries and similar places are listed as property deemed to be public property.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. Temples, Chaitya, monasteries and other listed religious or memorial sites and the lands where they are located are treated as public property under Section 300(1)(d). Their management and use are governed by the legal status conferred by that provision.

instruction: Does the law say the government can notify other kinds of property as public property?
input:
Section no 300  clause (g) : Such other property as prescribed to be the
public property by the Government of Nepal, by a notification in the Nepal
Gazette.
output:
According to Section 300(1)(g).
Rule: The Government of Nepal may, by notification in the Nepal Gazette, prescribe other property to be public property.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. Beyond the categories listed, the Government can formally declare additional property to be public property through an official Gazette notification. Therefore, a property not explicitly listed may still become public property if so notified.

instruction: Are mountains and sandy lands mentioned in the statute anywhere?
input:
clause (g) : Himalaya, mountains, rocks, sandy lands, public
gardens,
 Section no 299
output:
According to Section 299 clause (g).
Rule: Section 299 includes Himalaya, mountains, rocks, sandy lands and public gardens among the items listed in that provision.
Application/Conclusion: The statute explicitly mentions mountains, rocks and sandy lands in Section 299(g). For the precise legal effect (e.g., ownership classification), you should refer to related provisions that classify or declare property as public, community or otherwise.

instruction: If a property is being used by an organization, does the Land Revenue Office have to note who possesses it?
input: Section no 302  clause (b) : If the government or public properties are possessed by, or subjected to, any body or organization, details thereof,
output:
According to Section 302(1)(b).
Rule: The Land Revenue Office must record details if government or public properties are possessed by or subjected to any body or organization.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. The Office has to document and update who possesses or uses a government or public property, including organization names and relevant details. This information should appear in the official records.

instruction: My local authority prepared community property records — should they send them anywhere else?
input:
Section no 302  part (4) : The Local Level shall collect and update the details
referred to in sub-section (1) in relation to the community properties situated
within its jurisdiction and forward a copy thereof to the concerned Land Revenue
Oﬀice.
output:
According to Section 302 part (4).
Rule: The Local Level must forward the community property details it collects and updates to the concerned Land Revenue Office.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. After collecting and updating community property records, the Local Level is required to send a copy to the Land Revenue Office. If you need official records, both Local Level and the Land Revenue Office should hold copies.

instruction: What must the Land Revenue Office do when government land is held in the name of a government body?
input:
Section no 303 . Land ownership registration certificate to be provided
: (1) If any government land is held in the name of a government body or
public organization, the Land Revenue Oﬀice shall prepare the land ownership
registration certificate of such land in the name of such body or organization
and provide it to such body or organization.
 Section no 303
output:
According to Section 303(1).
Rule: The Land Revenue Office must prepare and provide a land ownership registration certificate in the name of the government body or public organization when government land is held in their name.
Application/Conclusion: The Office is obliged to issue the registration certificate to the relevant government body or public organization. If the certificate was not issued, the concerned body can request the Land Revenue Office to prepare and provide it as required by law.

instruction: Can I create a trust just by telling my friend to manage my house after I die?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if any person has, by way of his or her oral behavior, conduct or a testamen91tary gift or will, provided for the operation and management of a property in which he or she has right, ownership and possession as a trust, the trust shall be deemed to have been established by such behavior, conduct or will. Provided that in the case of a property requiring registration for the transfer of its title in accordance with law, a deed pertaining to such transfer has to be registered.
output: According to Section 316(3): Rule: A trust can be deemed established by oral behavior, conduct, testamentary gift or will. Application/Conclusion: If you orally or by conduct provided that your house be managed as a trust (including by will), that can create a trust. However, if the house requires title transfer under law, the transfer deed still must be registered — so for full legal effect on title you must register the deed.

instruction: Do I need to register a deed if I transfer a property into a trust?
input: Provided that in the case of a property requiring registration for the transfer of its title in accordance with law, a deed pertaining to such transfer has to be registered.
output: According to Section 316(3): Rule: Where a property requires registration to transfer title, the deed effecting that transfer must be registered. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your property's title transfer into the trust triggers statutory registration, you must register the deed for the transfer to be effective.

instruction: Can a foreigner be the founder of a trust in Nepal?
input: If a foreign person intends to establish a trust, the person shall make an application, upon fulfilling the procedures as referred to in sub-sections (1) and (2). A foreign person may be the founder of the trust to be so established. Provided that a foreign person is not allowed to establish a trust for the accomplishment of the object referred to in clause (l) of sub-section (2) of Section 315.
output: According to Section 316(4): Rule: A foreign person may apply and may serve as founder of a trust if they follow the prescribed procedures, but they are barred from establishing trusts for certain objects specified elsewhere (Section 315(2)(l)). Application/Conclusion: Yes, a foreigner can be a founder if they follow the procedures in subsections (1) and (2), but they cannot establish a trust for the specific prohibited object listed in Section 315(2)(l).

instruction: Are there any objects for which foreigners cannot establish trusts?
input: Provided that a foreign person is not allowed to establish a trust for the accomplishment of the object referred to in clause (l) of sub-section (2) of Section 315.
output: According to Section 316(4): Rule: Foreign persons are prohibited from establishing trusts aimed at accomplishing the object specified in clause (l) of Section 315(2). Application/Conclusion: You must check Section 315(2)(l) to see the specific prohibited object; if your intended trust purpose matches that clause, a foreign founder cannot lawfully establish it.

instruction: If a foreigner founds a trust, must some trustees be Nepali residents?
input: At least one-thirds of the trustees of a trust established pursuant to sub-section (4) shall be Nepali citizens having permanent residence in Nepal.
output: According to Section 316(5): Rule: For trusts established under the foreign-founder rule, at least one-third of trustees must be Nepali citizens with permanent residence in Nepal. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if a foreign person establishes the trust, at least one-third of the trustees must be Nepali citizens with permanent residence in Nepal.

instruction: What must I include in the memorandum about the trust's beneficiaries?
input: Details of the beneficiaries,
output: According to Section 317(d): Rule: The memorandum of incorporation must set out details of the beneficiaries. Application/Conclusion: You must list and describe who the beneficiaries are in the trust memorandum, providing sufficient detail about their identity or classification as required.

instruction: What information about trustees is required in the memorandum of incorporation?
input: Names, surnames and addresses of the trustees, details of the business to be performed by them, and, if a body corporate is a trustee, name, surname and address of the person designated by the body to act as the trustee,
output: According to Section 317(c): Rule: The memorandum must include trustees' names, surnames, addresses, the business they will perform, and, if a corporate trustee, the designated individual's name and address. Application/Conclusion: You must supply full personal/contact details for each trustee, state what duties they will perform, and, for any corporate trustee, name the designated natural person who will act.

instruction: Do I need to state the objects and nature of the trust in the memorandum?
input: Objects and nature of the trust,
output: According to Section 317(b): Rule: The memorandum must state the objects and nature of the trust. Application/Conclusion: Yes — your memorandum must explicitly set out what the trust is for (its objectives) and the nature/type of the trust.

instruction: What should I describe about how trust property will be used?
input: Method of use of the trust property,
output: According to Section 317(e): Rule: The memorandum must specify the method of use of the trust property. Application/Conclusion: You should describe in the memorandum how the trust property will be utilized — e.g., how income or capital will be applied, managed, or distributed.

instruction: If beneficiaries will get pay or benefits, what goes into the memorandum?
input: If the beneficiaries are entitled to remuneration or other facilities, details thereof and limitation,
output: According to Section 317(g): Rule: Where beneficiaries are entitled to remuneration or other facilities, the memorandum must include details and any limitations. Application/Conclusion: If beneficiaries will receive pay or benefits, the memorandum must set out what those are and any caps or conditions on them.

instruction: Can I operate a private trust without registering it?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, a private trust may be operated even without registration. Provided that if a person so operates a private trust, the person shall give information thereof to the concerned Registrar.
output: According to Section 318(3): Rule: A private trust may operate without formal registration, but the operator must inform the concerned Registrar. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can run a private trust without registration, but you must inform the relevant Registrar that the private trust is being operated.

instruction: If I run an unregistered private trust, do I need to inform anyone?
input: Provided that if a person so operates a private trust, the person shall give information thereof to the concerned Registrar.
output: According to Section 318(3): Rule: Operators of unregistered private trusts must give information to the concerned Registrar. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you operate a private trust without registering it, you are legally required to notify the concerned Registrar about it.

instruction: How long does the Registrar have to register a trust after I apply?
input: If an application is made for the establishment of a trust pursuant to Section 316, the Registrar shall make necessary inquiry into the objects of the trust and the details of the property proposed for the establishment of the trust, and, if it appears reasonable to register the trust, register the trust and issue the trust registration certificate, within a period of thirty-five days of the making of such application.
output: According to Section 318(1): Rule: The Registrar must conduct inquiries and, if registration is reasonable, register the trust and issue a certificate within 35 days of the application. Application/Conclusion: After you submit a proper application under Section 316, the Registrar has up to 35 days to complete inquiries and, if satisfied, register the trust and issue the registration certificate.

instruction: If the trust gets registered, is it automatically established?
input: If a trust is registered pursuant to sub-section (1), the trust is deemed to have been established.
output: According to Section 318(2): Rule: Registration pursuant to subsection (1) causes the trust to be deemed established. Application/Conclusion: Yes — once the Registrar registers the trust under Section 318(1), the law treats the trust as legally established.

instruction: What must the memorandum of incorporation contain (general)?
input: The following matters shall be set out in the memorandum of incorporation of a trust:
output: According to Section 317: Rule: The memorandum of incorporation must set out the listed matters (detailed in subsequent clauses). Application/Conclusion: In general, your memorandum must contain the prescribed matters — such as founders' and trustees' details, objects, beneficiaries, methods of use, tenure, termination consequences, and operational provisions — as specified in the clauses following this provision.

instruction: If a company is the founder, what founder details must go into the memorandum?
input: Names, surnames and addresses of the founders of the trust, and, if a body corporate is the founder, names, surnames and addresses of the directors of such body,
output: According to Section 317(a): Rule: The memorandum must list founders' names, surnames and addresses; if a corporate body is the founder, it must list the directors' names and addresses. Application/Conclusion: If a company is the founder, you must include the company's founding details and specifically the names and addresses of the company's directors in the memorandum.

instruction: If a company acts as trustee, what must be included about who will act for it?
input: Names, surnames and addresses of the trustees, details of the business to be performed by them, and, if a body corporate is a trustee, name, surname and address of the person designated by the body to act as the trustee,
output: According to Section 317(c): Rule: The memorandum must give trustees' names/addresses and duties; if a corporate trustee is appointed, it must name the natural person designated to act on its behalf and give that person's details. Application/Conclusion: When a corporate body is trustee, the memorandum must identify the individual designated by that body to act as trustee and provide their full name and address.

instruction: Can I build a shop on community land for my personal business?
input: Section no 307 . Prohibition of building structure : (1) No person shall build any structure in any government, public or community land, for any personal or public purpose. Provided that any structure may be constructed as considered appropriate by the Government of Nepal, in the case of a government or public land, and by the concerned community for public purpose, in the case of a community land.
output:
According to Section 307(1)...
Rule: No person shall build any structure in government, public or community land for any personal or public purpose, except that the Government of Nepal may authorize structures on government/public land and the concerned community may authorize structures on community land for public purpose.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully build a shop on community land for your personal business unless the concerned community expressly permits construction for a public purpose. If you do so without that permission, it would contravene Section 307(1).

instruction: Our community wants to build a public meeting hall on the communal field. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 307 . Prohibition of building structure : (1) No person shall build any structure in any government, public or community land, for any personal or public purpose. Provided that any structure may be constructed as considered appropriate by the Government of Nepal, in the case of a government or public land, and by the concerned community for public purpose, in the case of a community land.
output:
According to Section 307(1)...
Rule: Construction on community land is generally prohibited except when the concerned community considers it appropriate for public purpose.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—if the concerned community (not an individual) considers the meeting hall appropriate for a public purpose and authorizes it, construction is permitted under the proviso. Obtain the community's authorization before proceeding.

instruction: Someone just started building a house on the village pasture without permission. Who can stop them?
input: ( 2) If any person initiate to construct any structure in any government, public or community land in contravention of sub section (1), the concerned Chief District Oﬀicer or Local Level shall stop such work immediately.
output:
According to Section 307(2)...
Rule: If construction is initiated in contravention of subsection (1), the concerned Chief District Officer or Local Level must stop the work immediately.
Application/Conclusion: The Chief District Officer or the Local Level has the duty and authority to halt the unauthorized construction right away. You should inform the Local Level or CDO so they can intervene.

instruction: I already built a small shed on community land before I knew the rule. What can the authorities do?
input: Section no 307  part (3) : If any person has already constructed any structure in any government, public or community land in contravention of sub section (1), the concerned Chief District Oﬀicer shall give a time limit of fifteen days to the main person having constructed the structure to demolish such structure.
output:
According to Section 307(3)...
Rule: If a structure has already been constructed in contravention of subsection (1), the Chief District Officer shall give the main person who constructed it a time limit of fifteen days to demolish it.
Application/Conclusion: The CDO can require you to demolish the shed and must give you a 15-day notice to do so. You should act promptly within that period or seek to regularize the matter with the community/authority if possible.

instruction: If I'm ordered to take down the illegal structure, who pays for demolition?
input: Section no 307  part (4) : The main person having constructed such a structure shall demolish the structure at his or her own expense within the time-limit given pursuant to sub-section (3).
output:
According to Section 307(4)...
Rule: The main person who constructed the structure must demolish it at his or her own expense within the time limit given under subsection (3).
Application/Conclusion: You are legally required to demolish the structure yourself and bear the cost, within the 15-day period set by the CDO. Failure to do so will lead to further action.

instruction: They didn't demolish the illegal building after 15 days. Will the government remove it?
input: Section no 307  part (5) : If the main person having constructed such a structure fails to demolish the structure within the time-limit given pursuant to sub-section (3), the concerned Chief District Oﬀicer shall demolish such a structure. 167
output:
According to Section 307(5)...
Rule: If the constructor fails to demolish within the given time limit, the Chief District Officer shall demolish the structure.
Application/Conclusion: If the person ordered to demolish does not act within the 15 days, the CDO will carry out the demolition. Expect the authority to remove the structure and take any necessary steps.

instruction: If the CDO demolishes the building, can they make me pay? Will I also be fined?
input: Section no 307  part (6) : If the Chief District Oﬀicer demolishes any structure pursuant to sub-section (5), the Chief District Oﬀicer may recover the expenses incurred in such demolition from the main person having constructed the structure and punish him or her with a fine not exceeding twenty-five thousand rupees.
output:
According to Section 307(6)...
Rule: When the CDO demolishes under subsection (5), the CDO may recover demolition expenses from the constructor and may punish that person with a fine not exceeding twenty-five thousand rupees.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—the authority can recover the demolition costs from you and may impose a fine up to Rs. 25,000. If the CDO demolishes, be prepared to reimburse expenses and face a possible fine.

instruction: I'm old and can't physically demolish the illegal structure within 15 days. Will the police help the Local Level with enforcement?
input: Section no 307  part (7) : It shall be the duty of the concerned police oﬀice to render necessary assistance, if any, sought by the Local Level in stopping the construction of any structure or in demolishing any already built structure pursuant to this Section.
output:
According to Section 307(7)...
Rule: The concerned police office has a duty to render necessary assistance to the Local Level when requested for stopping construction or demolishing structures under this Section.
Application/Conclusion: The police can assist the Local Level with enforcement actions. If you cannot demolish yourself, the CDO/Local Level may arrange demolition with police assistance and then recover costs from you—so you should communicate your situation to the Local Level promptly.

instruction: Can the national government transfer a government-owned building from one agency to another?
input: Section no 308 . Power to transfer government property : The Government of Nepal may transfer any government property owned and possessed by, or subjected to, any body or organization to any other body or organization, with the permission of such an owner body or organization.
output:
According to Section 308...
Rule: The Government of Nepal may transfer government property from one body/organization to another, but such transfer requires the permission of the owner body or organization.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—the Government can transfer government-owned property between bodies, but it must obtain the permission of the owning body or organization before doing so.

instruction: Our community no longer uses the shared grazing land. Can we make it public land?
input:
Section no 309 . Conversion of community property into public property : (1) If any community holding a community property does not use it or submits an application bearing signature or thumb impression of each of the main persons of all families of such a community, setting out that it is not necessary to use such community property in its purpose, to the concerned
88
Land Revenue Oﬀice, the concerned Land Revenue Oﬀicer may make necessary
inquiry into the matter and convert such property into the public property.
output:
According to Section 309(1)...
Rule: If a community holding community property does not use it or submits an application signed/thumb-impressed by the main persons of all families stating the property is no longer needed, the Land Revenue Officer may inquire and convert the property into public property.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—if the entire community agrees and submits the required application (signatures/thumb impressions of main persons of all families) or the property is unused, the Land Revenue Officer can investigate and convert the community property into public property.

instruction: After conversion, will the office update records and inform local authorities?
input: Section no 309  part (2) : In the event of conversion of any community property into the public property pursuant to sub-section (1), the concerned Land Revenue Oﬀicer shall make necessary entries in the records maintained in his or her oﬀice and give information thereof to the concerned district level administrative oﬀice and Local Level. 168
output:
According to Section 309(2)...
Rule: When community property is converted into public property under subsection (1), the Land Revenue Officer must enter the change in office records and notify the concerned district administrative office and Local Level.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—the Land Revenue Office will update its records and must inform the district administrative office and the Local Level after conversion. Expect official record changes and formal notifications.

instruction: How long do I have to demolish an illegally built structure once ordered?
input: Section no 307  part (3) : If any person has already constructed any structure in any government, public or community land in contravention of sub section (1), the concerned Chief District Oﬀicer shall give a time limit of fifteen days to the main person having constructed the structure to demolish such structure.
output:
According to Section 307(3)...
Rule: The Chief District Officer must give the constructor a time limit of fifteen days to demolish the contravening structure.
Application/Conclusion: You have 15 days from the CDO's notice to demolish the structure yourself. Act within that timeframe to avoid forced demolition and additional penalties.

instruction: What is the maximum fine the CDO can impose if they demolish my illegal structure?
input: Section no 307  part (6) : If the Chief District Oﬀicer demolishes any structure pursuant to sub-section (5), the Chief District Oﬀicer may recover the expenses incurred in such demolition from the main person having constructed the structure and punish him or her with a fine not exceeding twenty-five thousand rupees.
output:
According to Section 307(6)...
Rule: If the CDO demolishes under subsection (5), the CDO may recover demolition expenses and may punish the constructor with a fine not exceeding Rs. 25,000.
Application/Conclusion: The maximum fine the CDO may impose in such a case is Rs. 25,000, in addition to recovering demolition costs.

instruction: My neighbour has been cultivating government land for years. Can the Land Revenue Office punish them, and how much is the fine?
input:

who possesses or cultivates any government, public or community land 166 in
contravention of this Section with a fine not exceeding ten thousand rupees.
output:
According to Section 306(4)...
Rule: The Land Revenue Office may punish any person who possesses or cultivates government, public or community land in contravention of the applicable provision with a fine not exceeding ten thousand rupees.
Application/Conclusion: If your neighbour is occupying or cultivating such land contrary to the law, the Land Revenue Office has authority to punish them and may impose a fine of up to Rs. 10,000. You may report the matter to the Land Revenue Office for investigation.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me a plot that turns out to be community land; he already built a house. What can the Local Level/authorities do?
input: Section no 307  part (5) : If the main person having constructed such a structure fails to demolish the structure within the time-limit given pursuant to sub-section (3), the concerned Chief District Oﬀicer shall demolish such a structure. 167
output:
According to Section 307(5)...
Rule: If the constructor fails to demolish within the time-limit, the Chief District Officer shall demolish the structure.
Application/Conclusion: If Ram built on community land and cannot validly show permission, the CDO can order demolition after giving notice. If he ignores the notice, the CDO will demolish the house. You should report the issue and cooperate with Local Level/CDO procedures.

instruction: Under which section is conversion of community property into public property provided?
input:
Section no 309 . Conversion of community property into public property : (1) If any community holding a community property does not use it or submits an application bearing signature or thumb impression of each of the main persons of all families of such a community, setting out that it is not necessary to use such community property in its purpose, to the concerned

inquiry into the matter and convert such property into the public property.
output:
According to Section 309(1)...
Rule: Section 309 provides that community property may be converted into public property where the community does not use it or has submitted an application (with required signatures/thumb impressions of main persons of all families) stating it is no longer necessary; the Land Revenue Officer may then inquire and convert the property.
Application/Conclusion: Conversion of community property into public property is provided under Section 309(1). Follow the application and inquiry process set out there if your community seeks conversion.

instruction: My Local Level asked the police to stop an illegal construction. Are the police obliged to help?
input: Section no 307  part (7) : It shall be the duty of the concerned police oﬀice to render necessary assistance, if any, sought by the Local Level in stopping the construction of any structure or in demolishing any already built structure pursuant to this Section.
output:
According to Section 307(7)...
Rule: The police office has a duty to provide necessary assistance to the Local Level when requested to stop construction or demolish structures under this Section.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—the police are legally obliged to assist the Local Level when asked to stop or demolish illegal construction. If they refuse, you can raise the issue with higher authorities or record the refusal.

instruction: Can my trust be refused registration if I forget to pay the fee?
input: Section no 319  clause (a) : If the details, documents or fees referred to in Section 316 are not mentioned or paid,
output: According to Section 319(a): Rule: The Registrar may refuse to register a trust where the details, documents or fees referred to in Section 316 are not mentioned or paid. Application/Conclusion: If you forget to pay the required fee (or omit required documents/details), the Registrar has statutory power to refuse registration. You must submit the missing fee and required documents to avoid refusal.

instruction: Someone else already has a very similar trust name — can my application be rejected?
input: Section no 319  clause (b) : If the name of the trust resembles with the name of any other trust already registered prior to the registration of the trust applied for,
output: According to Section 319(b): Rule: The Registrar may refuse registration where the proposed trust name resembles the name of an already-registered trust. Application/Conclusion: If your trust's name resembles a previously registered trust, the Registrar can refuse registration on that ground; you should choose a distinct name to proceed.

instruction: I want to set up a trust to do something a bit shady — how far can the Registrar refuse registration for public-order or decency reasons?
input: Section no 319  clause (c) : If the objects or terms of the trust appear to be inappropriate or undesirable for reasons of public interest, decency, courtesy or public order, are not 176 lawful or are not capable of being implemented owing to their uncertainty or vagueness.
output: According to Section 319(c): Rule: The Registrar may refuse registration if the trust's objects or terms are inappropriate or undesirable for public interest, decency, courtesy or public order, are unlawful, or are uncertain/vague and not capable of implementation. Application/Conclusion: If your proposed trust objectives are unlawful, offensive to public order/decency, or so vague they cannot be carried out, the Registrar can refuse registration. You must draft clear, lawful, and publicly appropriate objectives to succeed.

instruction: How long will the Registrar take to tell me if they refuse my trust application?
input: Section no 319  part (2) : If a trust is not capable of being registered pursuant to sub-section (1), the Registrar shall give information thereof, along with the reason for refusal, to the applicant within thirty-five days.
output: According to Section 319(2): Rule: The Registrar must inform the applicant, with reasons, within thirty-five days if a trust is not capable of being registered under subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: If your application is defective for any of the grounds in Section 319(1), you should receive formal notice and reasons from the Registrar within 35 days of submission.

instruction: If they refuse me and I fix the problems, how quickly will they register the trust after I apply again?
input: Section no 319  part (3) : If, upon receipt of information pursuant to sub-section Section no 319  part (2) : , the applicant makes necessary corrections and an application again for the registration of the trust, the Registrar shall register the trust and issue the registration certificate pursuant to sub-section (1) of Section 318, within fifteen days of the making of such an application.
output: According to Section 319(3): Rule: When an applicant corrects defects identified under Section 319(2) and reapplies, the Registrar must register the trust and issue the certificate within fifteen days of that application. Application/Conclusion: If you correct the stated deficiencies and re-submit, expect registration and the certificate to be issued within 15 days of your corrected application.

instruction: The trust was just created — how long do I have to transfer the settled property to the trustee?
input: Section no 320 . Transfer of property for incorporation of trust : (1) The trust founder shall transfer the property settled for the trust to the trustee within a period of three months of the establishment of the trust.
output: According to Section 320(1): Rule: The founder must transfer the property settled for the trust to the trustee within three months of establishing the trust. Application/Conclusion: You have a three-month deadline from the trust's establishment to transfer the settled property to the trustee; failing to do so can have legal consequences under the Act.

instruction: If the settled property is land, is there any special rule about transfer?
input: Section no 320  part (2) : If the property to be transferred pursuant to sub-section (1) : is an immovable property, such a property shall be deemed to have been duly transferred only when it is transferred in accordance 93 with law.
output: According to Section 320(2): Rule: An immovable property is deemed duly transferred only when it has been transferred in accordance with law. Application/Conclusion: For land or other immovable property, you must complete the legal transfer formalities under applicable law; informal handovers or internal acts alone will not constitute a valid transfer.

instruction: I'm a foreigner creating a trust in Nepal — is there any minimum funds requirement?
input: Section no 320  part (3) : A foreign person that establishes a trust in Nepal shall remit into Nepal a movable property equivalent to at least one million United States Dollars through regular banking channel and hand over the same to the trustee within a period of three months.
output: According to Section 320(3): Rule: A foreign person establishing a trust in Nepal must remit into Nepal, through regular banking channels, movable property equivalent to at least one million US dollars and hand it to the trustee within three months. Application/Conclusion: As a foreign founder, you must bring into Nepal at least US$1,000,000 (or equivalent movable property) via banking channels and deliver it to the trustee within 3 months of establishment to comply with the statute.

instruction: Do I need to tell the Registrar after I hand over the foreign funds to the trustee?
input: Section no 320  part (4) : The information of the hand-over of the movable property pursuant to sub-section (3) shall be given to the Registrar.
output: According to Section 320(4): Rule: Information about the hand-over of the movable property under subsection (3) must be given to the Registrar. Application/Conclusion: After remitting and handing over the required funds, you (or the trustee) must notify the Registrar of that hand-over to meet statutory requirements.

instruction: I failed to transfer the trust property within three months. Is my trust still valid?
input: Section no 321 . Dissolution of trust on failure of transfer of property : In the event of failure to transfer the property within the time-limit 177 referred to in Section 320, the registration of such a trust shall be deemed to be void ipso facto and the trust shall be deemed to have been dissolved.
output: According to Section 321: Rule: If the property is not transferred within the time-limit set in Section 320, the trust's registration is void ipso facto and the trust is deemed dissolved. Application/Conclusion: If you did not transfer the settled property within the 3-month period (or the required period under Section 320), the trust registration becomes void automatically and the trust is considered dissolved without further action.

instruction: As a trustee, must I follow the memorandum of incorporation when managing trust property?
input: Section no 322 . Operation and management of trust property according to : memorandum of incorporation: (1) The trustee shall, subject to the terms and restrictions set forth in the memorandum of incorporation, operate and manage the trust property.
output: According to Section 322(1): Rule: The trustee must operate and manage trust property subject to the terms and restrictions in the memorandum of incorporation. Application/Conclusion: You, as trustee, are bound to follow the memorandum's terms and restrictions when managing trust assets; you cannot act contrary to those provisions.

instruction: Can the trustee sell trust land without asking anyone?
input: Section no 322  part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, the trustee shall, in operating and managing the property pursuant to sub-section (1), not sell, mortgage, or otherwise transfer title to, the immovable property or any part thereof without prior permission of the concerned Registrar.
output: According to Section 322(2): Rule: Except where the memorandum provides otherwise, the trustee must not sell, mortgage, or transfer title to immovable property (or part of it) without prior permission of the concerned Registrar. Application/Conclusion: The trustee cannot unilaterally sell trust land; prior Registrar permission is required unless the memorandum explicitly allows such acts.

instruction: If the trustee wants to mortgage trust property, what must be included in the permission request?
input: Section no 322  part (3) : In asking for prior permission of the Registrar pursuant to sub-section (2), the reason for the sale, mortgage of, or transfer of title to, such property, and the reasons and grounds that it may result in more benefit to the beneficiary shall be set out.
output: According to Section 322(3): Rule: A request for prior permission must set out the reason for the sale, mortgage, or transfer, and explain why it will result in greater benefit to the beneficiary. Application/Conclusion: When applying to the Registrar for permission to mortgage or sell trust property, the trustee must provide clear reasons and show how the proposed transaction benefits beneficiaries; this information is required for the Registrar's consideration.

instruction: My trust's name is almost identical to an older registered trust. What should I expect?
input: Section no 319  clause (b) : If the name of the trust resembles with the name of any other trust already registered prior to the registration of the trust applied for,
output: According to Section 319(b): Rule: The Registrar may refuse registration where a trust's name resembles an earlier-registered trust. Application/Conclusion: Expect potential refusal on the ground of name resemblance. To avoid rejection, choose a clearly distinct name or be prepared to explain differences to the Registrar.

instruction: I corrected the application after refusal — do they have to issue the registration certificate fast?
input: Section no 319  part (3) : If, upon receipt of information pursuant to sub-section Section no 319  part (2) : , the applicant makes necessary corrections and an application again for the registration of the trust, the Registrar shall register the trust and issue the registration certificate pursuant to sub-section (1) of Section 318, within fifteen days of the making of such an application.
output: According to Section 319(3): Rule: After the applicant corrects defects and reapplies, the Registrar must register the trust and issue the registration certificate within fifteen days. Application/Conclusion: Once you've made the required corrections and resubmitted, the Registrar is obliged to complete registration and issue the certificate within 15 days of that corrected application.

instruction: Do trustees have any limits when managing trust property according to the law?
input: Section no 322 . Operation and management of trust property according to : memorandum of incorporation: (1) The trustee shall, subject to the terms and restrictions set forth in the memorandum of incorporation, operate and manage the trust property.
output: According to Section 322(1): Rule: Trustees must operate and manage trust property subject to the terms and restrictions in the memorandum of incorporation. Application/Conclusion: Trustees are legally constrained by the memorandum's provisions; any management decisions must align with those terms and restrictions.

instruction: If a foreign founder doesn't bring in the required money, what happens?
input: Section no 320  part (3) : A foreign person that establishes a trust in Nepal shall remit into Nepal a movable property equivalent to at least one million United States Dollars through regular banking channel and hand over the same to the trustee within a period of three months.
output: According to Section 320(3): Rule: A foreign founder must remit at least US$1,000,000 (equivalent movable property) into Nepal through banking channels and hand it to the trustee within three months. Application/Conclusion: If a foreign founder fails to remit and hand over the required amount within 3 months, they are not complying with the statutory requirement; such failure may lead to consequences under Sections 320 and 321 (including possible voiding/dissolution).

instruction: Can I be appointed trustee if I'm under 18?
input: Section no 325  clause (a) : A person who is not competent to make contract,
output: According to Section 325 clause (a)... Rule: A person who is not competent to make a contract is not qualified to be a trustee. Application/Conclusion: If you are under 18 and therefore not legally competent to make contracts, you are disqualified from being appointed a trustee.

instruction: I once took trust money to pay a debt but returned it later. Can I still be a trustee?
input: Section no 325  clause (b) : A person who has embezzled a property in his or her custody, 180
output: According to Section 325 clause (b)... Rule: A person who has embezzled property in their custody is not qualified to be a trustee. Application/Conclusion: Since embezzlement of trust property is an explicit disqualification, having embezzled—even if later returned—would make you ineligible to serve as trustee under this provision.

instruction: I was convicted years ago for corruption. Can I be a trustee now?
input: Section no 325  clause (c) : A person who has been convicted by a court of the offense of corruption,
output: According to Section 325 clause (c)... Rule: A person convicted by a court of the offense of corruption is disqualified from being a trustee. Application/Conclusion: Your prior corruption conviction disqualifies you from appointment as a trustee under this section.

instruction: I received a sentence for a crime involving moral turpitude. Does that bar me from being a trustee?
input: Section no 325  clause (d) : A person who has been sentenced for a criminal offense involving moral turpitude,
output: According to Section 325 clause (d)... Rule: Anyone sentenced for a criminal offense involving moral turpitude is not qualified to be a trustee. Application/Conclusion: Your sentence for such an offense prevents you from serving as a trustee according to this provision.

instruction: Can the only beneficiary of a trust also be the trustee?
input: Section no 325  clause (e) : A person who is the sole beneficiary of the trust property.
output: According to Section 325 clause (e)... Rule: A person who is the sole beneficiary of the trust property is not qualified to be a trustee. Application/Conclusion: If you are the sole beneficiary of the trust, you cannot be appointed as its trustee under this rule.

instruction: How many trustees can a trust have?
input: Section no 326 . Number of Trustees : Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, the number of trustees shall, subject to the other provisions of this Chapter, be one in minimum and seven in maximum.
output: According to Section 326... Rule: Unless the memorandum of incorporation says otherwise, trustees must number at least one and at most seven. Application/Conclusion: The trust must have between 1 and 7 trustees, unless the memorandum provides a different rule.

instruction: Can a company be named trustee?
input: Section no 327 . Body corporate being eligible to be trustee : (1) A body corporate which is established in accordance with law may be appointed as a trustee.
output: According to Section 327(1)... Rule: A body corporate legally established may be appointed as trustee. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a properly established company or corporation can be appointed trustee under this provision.

instruction: If a company is trustee, who represents it in trust matters?
input: Section no 327  part (2) : If the body corporate referred to in sub-section (1) is appointed as a trustee, the person working as the chief of such a body or a person to whom the power is delegated by a decision of the board of directors of such a body shall act on behalf of such a body. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “person working as the chief” means the chairperson, director, managing director, general manager, executive director of such body or a person empowered by such a body to work as its chief.
output: According to Section 327 part (2)... Rule: When a body corporate is trustee, its chief officer or a person authorized by the board acts on its behalf; chiefs include chairperson, director, MD, GM, executive director or an empowered person. Application/Conclusion: A company-appointed trustee must act through its chief officer (as defined) or someone the board delegates — that person will represent the corporate trustee in trust matters.

instruction: My trustee was found to be ineligible. Does the trustee's office become vacant automatically?
input: Section no 328  clause (a) : If the person is not qualified to be a trustee, 181
output: According to Section 328 clause (a)... Rule: The trustee's office falls vacant if the person is not qualified to be a trustee. Application/Conclusion: If the trustee is discovered to be ineligible, their office is treated as vacant under this clause.

instruction: The trustee wants to resign. What happens then?
input: Section no 328  clause (b) : If the person resigns from the oﬀice of a trustee,
output: According to Section 328 clause (b)... Rule: The trustee's office becomes vacant upon resignation. Application/Conclusion: If your trustee resigns, their office is vacant and vacancy-filling procedures must follow.

instruction: What if the trustee dies or goes bankrupt?
input: Section no 328  clause (c) : If the person dies or becomes insolvent,
output: According to Section 328 clause (c)... Rule: The trustee's office falls vacant if the trustee dies or becomes insolvent. Application/Conclusion: Death or insolvency of the trustee creates a vacancy in the trustee's office under this clause.

instruction: Our trustee is a company that just went into liquidation. Is the trustee's office affected?
input: Section no 328  clause (d) : If, in the case of a body corporate, it is dissolved, liquidated or becomes insolvent in accordance with law,
output: According to Section 328 clause (d)... Rule: If a corporate trustee is dissolved, liquidated, or becomes insolvent, the trustee's office becomes vacant. Application/Conclusion: The corporate trustee's liquidation or dissolution vacates its office; the vacancy must then be filled per applicable procedures.

instruction: The trust was set up for 10 years and that period ended. Does the trustee stay on?
input: Section no 328  clause (e) : If a trust is established for a certain period and such a period is completed,
output: According to Section 328 clause (e)... Rule: The trustee's office falls vacant when a trust established for a fixed period reaches the end of that period. Application/Conclusion: Once the trust term finishes, the trustee's office is vacated under this provision.

instruction: My trustee's fixed tenure expired last month. Are they still a trustee?
input: Section no 328  clause (f) : If the trustee is appointed for a certain tenure and such a tenure is completed,
output: According to Section 328 clause (f)... Rule: The trustee's office becomes vacant when their appointed tenure ends. Application/Conclusion: If the trustee's term has expired, they cease to hold office according to this clause.

instruction: Founder asked for trustee to be removed for mishandling funds. On what ground can a trustee be removed and does that create vacancy?
input: Section no 328  clause (g) : If the trustee is removed by the trust founder or court on the ground that he or she has embezzled the trust property or has not taken a reasonable care of (herchaha) such property.
output: According to Section 328 clause (g)... Rule: A trustee is removed (creating vacancy) if the founder or court finds embezzlement or failure to take reasonable care of trust property. Application/Conclusion: If the trustee is proven to have embezzled or negligently cared for trust assets, they can be removed by the founder or court and their office becomes vacant.

instruction: Our trust deed is silent on how to replace a trustee who left. What does the law say we must do next?
input: Section no 328  part (2) : If the oﬀice of the trustee is fallen vacant pursuant to sub-section (1), such an oﬀice shall be filled in accordance with the procedures set forth in the memorandum of incorporation.
output: According to Section 328 part (2)... Rule: Vacancies are to be filled following procedures in the memorandum of incorporation. Application/Conclusion: You must consult the trust's memorandum of incorporation and follow its prescribed procedure to fill the vacant trustee office; if silent, further steps (see next provisions) apply.

instruction: There is no procedure in our memorandum. Who can apply to appoint a new trustee?
input: Section no 328  part (3) : If the oﬀice of trustee cannot be fulfilled pursuant to sub-section (2), the beneficiary, if available, and the concerned Local Level, if there is no beneficiary or the beneficiary cannot be identified, shall make an application, accompanied by a list of possible candidates, to the concerned District Court for the appointment of a trustee.
output: According to Section 328 part (3)... Rule: If the memorandum procedure cannot be used, the beneficiary (or the Local Level if no/unknown beneficiary) must apply with candidate list to the District Court for trustee appointment. Application/Conclusion: Since your memorandum gives no procedure, the beneficiary (or local authority if no beneficiary) should apply to the District Court with candidate names to have a trustee appointed.

instruction: If the District Court receives an application with candidate names, how will it choose a trustee?
input: Section no 328  part (4) : If an application is made for the appointment of trustee pursuant to sub-section (3), the District Court shall appoint to the oﬀice of trustee an appropriate person from the list of candidates 182 provided by the applicant, in consonance with the spirit of the memorandum of incorporation.
output: According to Section 328 part (4)... Rule: The District Court must appoint an appropriate person from the applicant's list of candidates, consistent with the memorandum's spirit. Application/Conclusion: The court will select a suitable candidate from your submitted list, taking into account the memorandum of incorporation's intent, and appoint that person as trustee.

instruction: Can I file a lawsuit on behalf of our joint property if other owners are not available?
input: Section no 262  part (2) : If all owners are not available as referred to in sub section (1), any owner may, on behalf of him or her or the other owners, institute legal action against any person or defend any case. 147
output: According to Section 262(2): Rule: If all owners are not available, any one owner may institute legal action or defend a case on behalf of themselves and the other owners.
