Application/Conclusion: Since other owners are unavailable, you are legally permitted to file or defend a lawsuit on behalf of the joint-property owners.

instruction: Do all co-owners have to start a lawsuit together to protect joint property?
input: Section no 262 . Legal action or defense may be made by any owner of joint : property: (1) If it is necessary to institute a legal action against any person or defend a case in relation to the protection of a joint property, all owners shall make such institution or defense.
output: According to Section 262(1): Rule: When it is necessary to institute or defend a legal action concerning protection of joint property, all owners shall make such institution or defense. Application/Conclusion: The default rule is that all owners should join such proceedings; however, if some owners are unavailable, Section 262(2) allows one owner to act on their behalf.

instruction: I want to separate my share from a jointly owned house — can I do this anytime?
input: Section no 263 . Separation of one’s share from joint property : (1) Any owner of a joint property may separate his or her right or share therein from the other owners at any time.
output: According to Section 263(1): Rule: Any owner of a joint property may separate his or her right or share from the other owners at any time. Application/Conclusion: You have the statutory right to seek separation of your share at any time, subject to the other conditions in Section 263.

instruction: Do I need the consent of the other owners to separate my share from joint property?
input: Section no 263  part (2) : The separation of a joint property referred to in sub section (1) shall be effected in accordance with the consent of all the owners.
output: According to Section 263(2): Rule: The separation referred to in subsection (1) shall be effected with the consent of all owners. Application/Conclusion: Although subsection (1) allows separation at any time, subsection (2) requires the consent of all owners to effect that separation — so you need their agreement.

instruction: Can I force a separation if it will cause substantial loss or disorder to other co-owners?
input: Section no 263  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) or (2), if the separation of any joint property results either in a substantial loss to the other owners or in a disorder in the form of that property, such separation may not be made.
output: According to Section 263(3): Rule: Even if subsection (1) or (2) would allow separation, separation may not be made if it results in substantial loss to other owners or causes disorder in the form of the property. Application/Conclusion: If your proposed separation would substantially harm other owners or materially disorder the property, you cannot force the separation under this provision.

instruction: If the property can't be divided without damage, what should we do with the joint property?
input: Section no 263  part (4) : If any joint property cannot be separated owing to the circumstance referred to in sub-section (3), the owners of that property shall sell such property and divide the proceeds of sale between them in proportion to their respective right and share therein.
output: According to Section 263(4): Rule: Where joint property cannot be separated due to circumstances in subsection (3), owners must sell the property and divide proceeds in proportion to their rights and shares. Application/Conclusion: If separation would cause substantial loss or disorder, the property should be sold and the sale proceeds distributed proportionally among owners.

instruction: Some owners refuse to sell. Can I buy the joint property by paying the others?
input: Section no 263  part (5) : If any joint property cannot be sold in accordance with sub-section (4) or all the owners do not agree to sell it and any owner intends to buy such property, such an owner may exclusively own it by paying the price of that property to the other owners in the same proportion.
output: According to Section 263(5): Rule: If the property cannot be sold under subsection (4) or owners do not agree to sell, an owner who intends to buy may take exclusive ownership by paying the price to the other owners in proportion to their shares. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if others won't sell, you can buy out their shares by paying them their proportional price and thereby obtain exclusive ownership.

instruction: If two of us want to buy the same joint property, who gets it?
input: Section no 263  part (6) : If more than one owner intend to buy the joint property pursuant to sub-section (5), the owner who agrees to pay the highest price shall be entitled to purchase such property.
output: According to Section 263(6): Rule: When more than one owner intends to buy under subsection (5), the owner who agrees to pay the highest price is entitled to purchase. Application/Conclusion: If multiple owners bid to buy out the others, the highest bidder wins the right to purchase the joint property.

instruction: Are there separate rules for community or government-owned properties?
input: Section no 264 . Provisions relating to community, public, government and trust : properties: The provisions relating to, and ownership, use, management, and transfer of right in, and other provisions of, the 148 community, public, government and trust properties shall be as set forth in the other Chapters of this Act.
output: According to Section 264: Rule: Provisions about ownership, use, management and transfer of community, public, government and trust properties are set out in other Chapters of the Act. Application/Conclusion: This section indicates special rules exist elsewhere in the Act for such properties; you must refer to those other Chapters for detailed rules governing community/public/government/trust property.

instruction: I discovered an unlawful change to our joint property today. How long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 265 . Statute of limitation : A person aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken. 149 Chapter2 Provisions Relating to Ownership and Possession
output: According to Section 265: Rule: An aggrieved person may file a lawsuit within six months after the act was done or action taken. Application/Conclusion: You generally have six months from the date you discovered (or from the date of) the act or action to initiate a lawsuit under this Chapter.

instruction: If I acquire a property according to law, does that mean I'm the owner?
input: Section no 266 . Ownership to be deemed : If a person acquires the right in any property in accordance with law, his or her ownership in that property shall be deemed.
output: According to Section 266: Rule: If a person acquires rights in property in accordance with law, that person's ownership shall be deemed. Application/Conclusion: Once you legally acquire rights in a property, the law treats you as its owner.

instruction: As an owner, what rights do I have — can I use, sell or mortgage my property?
input:
Section no 288 . Right of owner : Any person, in capacity of the owner of any property, shall have the following right, subject to laws:
 Section no 288  clause (a) : To use the property,
 Section no 288  clause (b) : To sell or otherwise transfer the title to the property to any other person,
 Section no 288  clause (c) : To mortgage or pledge the property in any manner,
 Section no 288  clause (d) : To deal in the property,
 Section no 288  clause (e) : To take benefits of the property in any manner whatsoever,
output: According to Section 288: Rule: An owner has, subject to laws, rights to use the property; to sell or transfer title; to mortgage or pledge; to deal in the property; and to take benefits from it. Application/Conclusion: You, as owner, normally may use, sell or transfer, mortgage, deal with, and take benefits from your property, though these rights are subject to applicable laws and restrictions.

instruction: Can I mortgage or pledge my property if I'm the owner?
input: Section no 288  clause (c) : To mortgage or pledge the property in any manner,
output: According to Section 288(c): Rule: An owner has the right to mortgage or pledge the property in any manner, subject to laws. Application/Conclusion: Yes — as the owner you may mortgage or pledge the property, provided you comply with relevant legal requirements.

instruction: Am I allowed to 'take benefits' from my property — for example, collect rent or harvest crops?
input: Section no 288  clause (e) : To take benefits of the property in any manner whatsoever,
output: According to Section 288(e): Rule: An owner has the right to take benefits of the property in any manner whatsoever, subject to laws. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to derive benefits (such as rent or produce) from your property, though you must respect any statutory or contractual restrictions that apply.

instruction: Does 'to deal in the property' allow me to lease it out to tenants?
input: Section no 288  clause (d) : To deal in the property,
output: According to Section 288(d): Rule: An owner has the right to deal in the property (subject to laws). Application/Conclusion: The phrase permits dealings in the property — which would typically include leasing — but you should ensure there are no other statutory or contractual restrictions before leasing.

instruction: If the land cannot be partitioned and must be sold, how are sale proceeds shared?
input: Section no 263  part (4) : If any joint property cannot be separated owing to the circumstance referred to in sub-section (3), the owners of that property shall sell such property and divide the proceeds of sale between them in proportion to their respective right and share therein.
output: According to Section 263(4): Rule: When joint property cannot be separated as per subsection (3), the owners must sell it and divide the sale proceeds in proportion to their respective rights and shares. Application/Conclusion: The proceeds are distributed among owners according to each owner's proportional share in the property.

instruction: If not all owners agree to sell but I want to buy the property, how is the buyer chosen and purchase price handled?
input:
Section no 263  part (5) : If any joint property cannot be sold in accordance with sub-section (4) or all the owners do not agree to sell it and any owner intends to buy such property, such an owner may exclusively own it by paying the price of that property to the other owners in the same proportion.
 Section no 263  part (6) : If more than one owner intend to buy the joint property pursuant to sub-section (5), the owner who agrees to pay the highest price shall be entitled to purchase such property.
output: According to Section 263(5) and 263(6): Rule: Under (5), if owners don't agree to sell (or sale under (4) is not possible), an owner may acquire exclusive ownership by paying the price to other owners in proportion to their shares. Under (6), if multiple owners want to buy, the one who offers the highest price gets the property. Application/Conclusion: You can buy out the others by paying their proportional share; if another owner also bids, the highest bidder wins.

instruction: Who may institute or defend legal proceedings to protect a jointly owned property?
input:
Section no 262 . Legal action or defense may be made by any owner of joint : property: (1) If it is necessary to institute a legal action against any person or defend a case in relation to the protection of a joint property, all owners shall make such institution or defense.
 Section no 262  part (2) : If all owners are not available as referred to in sub section (1), any owner may, on behalf of him or her or the other owners, institute legal action against any person or defend any case. 147
output: According to Section 262(1) and 262(2): Rule: Section 262(1) requires all owners to institute or defend legal action when necessary; Section 262(2) allows a single owner to act on behalf of others if all owners are not available. Application/Conclusion: Protection of joint property normally requires all owners to participate, but if some are unavailable, a single owner may bring or defend proceedings on behalf of all.

instruction: Can I, as the founder of a trust, sell or mortgage trust property whenever I want?
input: Selling, disposing of, gifting, donating or pledging or mortgaging the trust property by the trust founder or 187 his or her offspring or heir, except for the residual property that can be possessed and used after making operation as set forth in the deeds including the Donative inscription, Shilapatra of the trust,
output: According to Section 338(7)(b): Rule: The trust founder, or his/her offspring or heir, selling, disposing, gifting, donating, pledging or mortgaging trust property is deemed a breach of trust, except for residual property allowed by the deeds/Donative inscription. Application/Conclusion: As the founder you cannot freely sell or mortgage trust property unless the trust deed (Donative inscription/Shilapatra) specifically allows that residual property to be possessed and used; otherwise such sale or mortgage would constitute a breach of trust.

instruction: I found that the trustee used benefits from one part of the trust while breaching another part. Can those benefits be applied to make good the trustee's liability?
input: If, in relation to one portion of any trust, the trust is breached, and, in relation to another portion of the trust, benefit is derived, the trustee shall not use such benefit in the fulfillment of his or her liability.
output: According to Section 338(5): Rule: If a trustee breaches the trust in one portion but derives benefit from another portion, the trustee is not allowed to use that benefit to discharge his/her liability. Application/Conclusion: The trustee cannot offset or apply benefits obtained from other parts of the trust to satisfy liabilities arising from the breach; beneficiaries or enforcement authorities can require separate remedy for the breach.

instruction: If the loss to the trust happened because of operation of law (like a court order), is the current trustee personally liable?
input: If the loss and damage is caused by operation of law,
output: According to Section 338(6)(a): Rule: Loss or damage caused by operation of law is a circumstance in which the trustee shall not bear liability for breach of trust. Application/Conclusion: If the loss was caused by an operation of law (for example a statutory levy or court order), the trustee will not be held personally liable for that loss under this provision.

instruction: We discovered damage that resulted from actions of a previous trustee. Is the present trustee responsible for that loss?
input: If the loss and damage is a result of the breach of trust by any act done by the previous trustee or the consequence thereof.
output: According to Section 338(6)(b): Rule: Loss or damage that results from acts or consequences of a previous trustee’s breach is a circumstance where the current trustee shall not bear liability. Application/Conclusion: If the damage stems from a previous trustee’s breach, the current trustee is not automatically personally liable for that loss under this clause; liability would instead relate to the previous trustee or other applicable law.

instruction: My trust was formed before this Act came into force. What acts will be deemed breaches of trust under the new law?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, any one who does any of the following acts in relation to a trust in operation upon being incorporated in accordance with law in force for the time 99 being prior to the commencement of this Act shall be deemed to have committed a breach of trust:
output: According to Section 338(7): Rule: For trusts already in operation before this Act, certain specified acts are deemed breaches of trust despite other provisions. Application/Conclusion: If your trust was incorporated and operating before this Act, the listed actions that follow this introductory clause (such as failing to follow the Donative inscription, improper disposal of trust property, embezzlement) will be treated as breaches under the new law.

instruction: What if a trustee doesn't follow instructions in the trust deed — is that a breach?
input: Failing to do acts set forth in the Donative inscription, Shilapatra of the trust or deed establishing such trust,
output: According to Section 338(7)(a): Rule: Failure to perform acts specified in the Donative inscription, Shilapatra, or trust deed is deemed a breach of trust. Application/Conclusion: If a trustee neglects duties or actions expressly required by the trust instrument (Donative inscription/Shilapatra/deed), that failure constitutes a breach and may give rise to legal action.

instruction: My trustee sold some movable items from the trust and kept the proceeds. Is that embezzlement?
input: Embezzling the movable trust property by the trustee, except for reasonable wear and tear while using it for the trust purpose.
output: According to Section 338(7)(c): Rule: Embezzling movable trust property by the trustee (excluding reasonable wear and tear in trust use) is a breach of trust. Application/Conclusion: Selling trust movable items and keeping proceeds would amount to embezzlement and thus a breach of trust unless the action falls within reasonable wear-and-tear permitted for trust purposes.

instruction: If someone commits a breach listed in subsection (7), what legal consequences do they face?
input: shall be liable to action in accordance with the law in force at the time of the commencement of this Act.
output: According to Section 338(7): Rule: A person who commits a breach under subsection (7) shall be liable to action according to the law in force at the commencement of this Act. Application/Conclusion: Those who commit the enumerated breaches can be sued or prosecuted under whatever legal remedies and procedures were in force when this Act commenced — the provision makes them legally liable to be acted against.

instruction: Where should the deeds and ownership documents of a trust be kept?
input: Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, the deeds, documents of the ownership and possession of the trust property and other proofs and evidences pertaining thereto shall all be in the custody of the trustee, and in the case of a public trust, the trustee shall submit copies of such deeds and documents to the registrar. Provided that in the case of any deed, document or evidence to be approved by the registrar, it is not required to submit the copies of such deeds, documents or evidence to the registrar.
output: According to Section 339(1): Rule: Trust deeds, ownership/possession documents and related proofs are to be kept in the custody of the trustee; for public trusts, copies must be submitted to the registrar, except where the deed/document requires approval by the registrar (in which case submission of copies is not required). Application/Conclusion: Generally, the trustee must hold the original deeds and documents. If the trust is public, the trustee must submit copies to the registrar unless the specific deed/document is one that must be approved by the registrar (then copies need not be submitted).

instruction: Do trustees need to hand over originals of documents to the registrar?
input: Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, the deeds, documents of the ownership and possession of the trust property and other proofs and evidences pertaining thereto shall all be in the custody of the trustee, and in the case of a public trust, the trustee shall submit copies of such deeds and documents to the registrar. Provided that in the case of any deed, document or evidence to be approved by the registrar, it is not required to submit the copies of such deeds, documents or evidence to the registrar.
output: According to Section 339(1): Rule: The trustee keeps custody of deeds/documents; for public trusts the trustee must submit copies (not originals) to the registrar, with a specified exception for items to be approved by the registrar. Application/Conclusion: Trustees should retain originals; they are generally required to submit copies (not originals) to the registrar for public trusts, unless the document itself is one that the registrar must approve — then submission of copies is not required.

instruction: Who is responsible for safely keeping trust deeds and evidences?
input: The trustee and the registrar shall safely retain the deeds, documents and evidences referred to in sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 339(2): Rule: Both the trustee and the registrar have responsibility to safely retain the deeds, documents and evidences mentioned in subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: The trustee must keep the original custody, and where applicable copies are with the registrar, both parties are legally required to ensure safe retention of those records.

instruction: I spent my own money fixing a trust building to stop further damage. Can I get reimbursed from trust funds?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if the trustee has used his or her personal property or other’s property in the course of the protection of the trust property, accomplishment 188 of the object of trust or protection of the benefit of the beneficiary, the trustee shall be entitled to reimburse the amount for such property from the trust property.
output: According to Section 340: Rule: If a trustee uses personal or another’s property to protect trust property, accomplish the trust object, or protect beneficiary benefit, the trustee is entitled to reimbursement from the trust property. Application/Conclusion: You (as trustee) can claim reimbursement from trust funds for the reasonable expenses or value of personal property used to protect the trust or its objects; keep receipts and records to support the reimbursement claim.

instruction: A trustee used someone else’s vehicle to move trust goods during an emergency. Can that cost be reclaimed from the trust?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if the trustee has used his or her personal property or other’s property in the course of the protection of the trust property, accomplishment 188 of the object of trust or protection of the benefit of the beneficiary, the trustee shall be entitled to reimburse the amount for such property from the trust property.
output: According to Section 340: Rule: Use of one's own or another’s property by the trustee for protection of trust property or accomplishment of trust objectives entitles the trustee to reimbursement from the trust. Application/Conclusion: The trustee may be reimbursed from trust assets for costs associated with using another person’s vehicle to protect or transport trust property in an emergency, subject to proper accounting and evidence.

instruction: I believe the previous trustee caused losses. Who should I file action against and where is that stated?
input: If the loss and damage is a result of the breach of trust by any act done by the previous trustee or the consequence thereof.
output: According to Section 338(6)(b): Rule: Loss or damage resulting from a previous trustee's breach is recognized as such and the current trustee is not held liable under this clause. Application/Conclusion: You should pursue action against the previous trustee (or those responsible for that prior breach) rather than the current trustee, because this provision exempts the current trustee from liability for losses that are the consequence of prior trustees' acts.

instruction: Under which section does the law say the trustee must not use benefits from another portion to cover liabilities?
input: If, in relation to one portion of any trust, the trust is breached, and, in relation to another portion of the trust, benefit is derived, the trustee shall not use such benefit in the fulfillment of his or her liability.
output: According to Section 338(5): Rule: Section 338(5) prohibits a trustee from using benefits derived from one portion of the trust to satisfy liabilities arising from breach in another portion. Application/Conclusion: The prohibition is explicitly located in Section 338(5), so any attempt by a trustee to offset liabilities using benefits from a different portion of the trust would be contrary to that section.

instruction: Short: Can the registrar keep copies of trust deeds?
input: and in the case of a public trust, the trustee shall submit copies of such deeds and documents to the registrar.
output: According to Section 339(1): Rule: For public trusts the trustee must submit copies of deeds and documents to the registrar. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the registrar will retain copies of the trust deeds/documents for public trusts as required by Section 339(1).

instruction: I want to sue someone for breach of trust — how does the Act treat breaches committed before the Act started?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, any one who does any of the following acts in relation to a trust in operation upon being incorporated in accordance with law in force for the time 99 being prior to the commencement of this Act shall be deemed to have committed a breach of trust:
output: According to Section 338(7): Rule: The Act treats certain acts committed by trusts already in operation before the Act’s commencement as breaches of trust under its provisions. Application/Conclusion: If the breach falls within the acts listed following this provision, it will be deemed a breach under the Act even though it occurred with a trust incorporated before the Act commenced; you can therefore pursue action based on those deemed breaches subject to applicable laws.

instruction: Can I use trust property for my own benefit?
input: Section no 335 . Prohibition of possession of trust property to prejudice benefit : of beneficiary: No trustee shall so possess or use the trust property for himself or herself or other person as may be prejudicial to the benefit of the beneficiary.
output: According to Section 335: Rule: A trustee is prohibited from possessing or using trust property in any way that is prejudicial to the beneficiary's benefit. Application/Conclusion: You may not use the trust property for your own benefit if doing so prejudices the beneficiary; such use would be unlawful under Section 335 and can be challenged by the beneficiary.

instruction: My co-trustee embezzled money from the trust. What can I do?
input:
Section no 336  part (2) : If the trust property is not managed properly or is made subject to cheating or fraud or is embezzled or used for other purposes, any trustee or beneficiary may, subject to the provisions 185 set forth in the memorandum of incorporation, file a complaint in the court for the prevention of such embezzlement. Provided that any one whosoever may file a complaint in the case of a public trust.

Section no 336  part (3) : If, upon a complaint filed pursuant to sub-section (2), it is held that the trust property has not been managed properly or has been made subject to cheating or fraud or embezzled or used for other purposes, the court shall recover the claimed amount from the embezzler and may also order compensation to be paid by a trustee if the trustee has committed such embezzlement.
output: According to Section 336(2)-(3): Rule: A trustee or beneficiary may file a complaint in court if trust property is embezzled, and if the court finds embezzlement it shall recover the claimed amount from the embezzler and may order compensation from a trustee who committed the embezzlement. Application/Conclusion: You (as trustee or beneficiary) can file a complaint in court to stop the embezzlement; the court can recover the stolen amount from the embezzler and may order the dishonest trustee to pay compensation.

instruction: What duties do I have to protect and maintain the trust property?
input:
Section no 334 . Protection of trust property : (1) The trustee shall protect and maintain the trust property, and may also make any kind of such legal action or complete any kind of such formality with any public authority as may be required for this purpose.

Section no 334  part (2) : In protecting or maintaining the trust property, the trustee shall take proper and reasonable care of (herbichar), and do act conducive to the enhancement of, the trustee property as if the property were his or her own.
output: According to Section 334(1)-(2): Rule: The trustee must protect and maintain trust property, may take necessary legal or formal actions with public authorities, and must take proper and reasonable care and act to enhance the property as if it were their own. Application/Conclusion: As trustee you are required to actively safeguard the trust assets, complete necessary formalities, and manage the property carefully and proactively to enhance its value.

instruction: I am a beneficiary — can I inspect the trust accounts?
input: Section no 337 . To maintain accounts of trust : (1) The trustee shall maintain accounts in a manner to reflect clearly and actually the accounts of the trust property, and provide statements thereof available to the registrar, and trust founder or beneficiary, identified, if any, intends to inspect the same.
output: According to Section 337(1): Rule: Trustees must maintain clear accounts of the trust property and provide statements available for inspection by the registrar, trust founder, or identified beneficiary. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you are an identified beneficiary, you have the right to inspect the trust accounts/statements that the trustee must make available.

instruction: Is an audit required for a public trust every year?
input: Section no 337  part (2) : In the case of a public trust, the trustee shall have its accounts audited by a recognized auditor each year and submit a copy of the audit report to the registrar.
output: According to Section 337(2): Rule: Public trusts must have their accounts audited annually by a recognized auditor and must submit the audit report to the registrar. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the trust is a public trust, an annual audit by a recognized auditor is required and the report must be filed with the registrar each year.

instruction: What is a 'breach of trust' and what follows if a trustee breaches duties?
input:
Section no 338 . Breach of trust : (1) If a trustee fails to fulfill the duties required to be fulfilled pursuant to this Chapter, the trustee shall be deemed to have committed a breach of trust.

Section no 338  part (1) : , the trustee so breaching trust shall be responsible for the loss and damage caused to the beneficiary and bear liability for the same.

Section no 338  part (3) : In bearing the liability pursuant to sub-section (2), the trustee breaching trust shall bear such profits as may be equal to the 186 income or profits which the trust or beneficiary would have made or earned if the trust had not been breached.
output: According to Section 338(1)-(3): Rule: A trustee who fails to fulfill duties under the Chapter is deemed to have committed a breach of trust, is responsible and liable for loss or damage to the beneficiary, and must disgorge profits equal to what the trust or beneficiary would have earned but for the breach. Application/Conclusion: If a trustee neglects duties or acts improperly, they will be held liable for losses and must compensate the beneficiary, potentially also surrendering profits equivalent to the trust's lost earnings.

instruction: There are two trustees and one mismanages funds. Who pays?
input: Section no 338  part (4) : If a trust has more than one trustee, all trustees who commit a breach of trust shall collectively bear the liability for the loss and damage caused from such breach of trust.
output: According to Section 338(4): Rule: Where multiple trustees commit a breach of trust, they are jointly liable to bear the loss and damage. Application/Conclusion: If more than one trustee is responsible for the breach, the trustees who committed the breach will be collectively liable to compensate for the loss.

instruction: Can anyone (not a trustee or beneficiary) file a complaint for a public trust?
input: Section no 336  part (2) : If the trust property is not managed properly or is made subject to cheating or fraud or is embezzled or used for other purposes, any trustee or beneficiary may, subject to the provisions 185 set forth in the memorandum of incorporation, file a complaint in the court for the prevention of such embezzlement. Provided that any one whosoever may file a complaint in the case of a public trust.
output: According to Section 336(2): Rule: For general trusts the trustee or beneficiary may file a complaint (subject to the trust memorandum); but in the case of a public trust, any person may file a complaint. Application/Conclusion: Yes — for a public trust, any person (not only trustees or beneficiaries) may file a complaint if the trust property is mismanaged or embezzled.

instruction: A trustee failed to register property formalities — am I allowed to complete those with authorities?
input: Section no 334 . Protection of trust property : (1) The trustee shall protect and maintain the trust property, and may also make any kind of such legal action or complete any kind of such formality with any public authority as may be required for this purpose.
output: According to Section 334(1): Rule: A trustee may take legal actions or complete necessary formalities with public authorities to protect and maintain the trust property. Application/Conclusion: Yes — as trustee you are empowered to complete required formalities with public authorities to protect the trust property.

instruction: If trust property is destroyed because trustee neglected it, can beneficiaries recover losses?
input: Section no 336 . Duty to prevent loss to trust property : (1) It shall be the duty of the trustee to prevent destruction, termination of, or otherwise loss to, the trust in a manner prejudicial to the benefit of the beneficiary or contrary to the object of the trust.
output: According to Section 336(1): Rule: Trustees have a duty to prevent destruction or loss of trust property that would prejudice beneficiaries or the trust's object. Application/Conclusion: If a trustee's neglect causes destruction or loss, beneficiaries can rely on this duty to seek remedies because the trustee was obligated to prevent such loss.

instruction: What counts as a breach of trust in simple terms? (Explain plainly.)
input: Section no 338 . Breach of trust : (1) If a trustee fails to fulfill the duties required to be fulfilled pursuant to this Chapter, the trustee shall be deemed to have committed a breach of trust.
output: According to Section 338(1): Rule: A breach of trust occurs when a trustee fails to carry out the duties required by the Chapter. Application/Conclusion: Plainly: if a trustee doesn't do what the law or trust requires (for example mismanages assets, doesn't protect property, or misuses funds), that trustee is considered to have committed a breach of trust and may be held responsible.

instruction: Can a trustee be ordered to pay profits the trust would have earned?
input: Section no 338  part (3) : In bearing the liability pursuant to sub-section (2), the trustee breaching trust shall bear such profits as may be equal to the 186 income or profits which the trust or beneficiary would have made or earned if the trust had not been breached.
output: According to Section 338(3): Rule: A breaching trustee must bear profits equal to the income or profits the trust or beneficiary would have earned but for the breach. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the trustee can be ordered to pay an amount reflecting the profits or income the trust lost because of the breach.

instruction: I found out about possible fraud today — how long do I have to file a complaint?
input: Section no 336  part (2) : If the trust property is not managed properly or is made subject to cheating or fraud or is embezzled or used for other purposes, any trustee or beneficiary may, subject to the provisions 185 set forth in the memorandum of incorporation, file a complaint in the court for the prevention of such embezzlement. Provided that any one whosoever may file a complaint in the case of a public trust.
output: According to Section 336(2): Rule: Trustees or beneficiaries may file a complaint in court in cases of cheating, fraud or embezzlement (and any person may do so for a public trust), subject to provisions in the trust memorandum. Application/Conclusion: The provision allows filing a complaint but does not specify a time limit in this text. Therefore, based solely on Section 336(2), no specific filing deadline is stated here; you should file promptly and check other applicable laws or the trust memorandum for any time limits.

instruction: Under which section is 'breach of trust' defined?
input: Section no 338 . Breach of trust : (1) If a trustee fails to fulfill the duties required to be fulfilled pursuant to this Chapter, the trustee shall be deemed to have committed a breach of trust.
output: According to Section 338(1): Rule: Section 338 defines 'breach of trust' by stating that a trustee who fails to fulfill required duties under the Chapter is deemed to have committed a breach. Application/Conclusion: Breach of trust is defined in Section 338(1).

instruction: My trustee refused to show accounts. Can I force an audit or inspection?
input:
Section no 337 . To maintain accounts of trust : (1) The trustee shall maintain accounts in a manner to reflect clearly and actually the accounts of the trust property, and provide statements thereof available to the registrar, and trust founder or beneficiary, identified, if any, intends to inspect the same.

Section no 337  part (2) : In the case of a public trust, the trustee shall have its accounts audited by a recognized auditor each year and submit a copy of the audit report to the registrar.
output: According to Section 337(1)-(2): Rule: Trustees must keep clear accounts and make statements available for inspection by registrar, trust founder, or identified beneficiaries; public trusts must also have annual audits and submit reports to the registrar. Application/Conclusion: You can ask for the trust statements for inspection as an identified beneficiary, and if the trust is public you can expect an annual audit report filed with the registrar; refusal to provide these may be challenged under these obligations.

instruction: Can a trustee who has been removed avoid liability for actions they took while in office?
input: part (5) : If any trustee is relieved of his or her oﬀice by virtue of the circumstance referred to in sub-section (1), he or she shall, as promptly as possible, hand over the trust property in his or her custody, control or use to other trustees, and he or she shall not get immunity from any kind of liability or legal action for any act done or action taken by him or her while in oﬀice of a trustee by the reason only that he or she has been so relieved of oﬀice. Provided that if all trustees are relieved of oﬀice, such property shall be transferred after the appointment of another trustee.
output: According to Section 327(5): Rule: A trustee who is relieved of office must hand over trust property promptly and does not obtain immunity from liability or legal action simply because they were relieved. Application/Conclusion: If you were removed as trustee, you must return any trust property in your custody promptly, and you remain potentially liable for acts taken while in office — you cannot claim automatic immunity just because you were relieved.

instruction: My trust had only one trustee and that trustee's office is now vacant. Do I need to tell anyone?
input: Section no 328  part (6) : If the oﬀice of a trustee of a public trust with only one trustee falls vacant or is fulfilled pursuant to this Section, information thereof shall be given to the registrar.
output: According to Section 328(6): Rule: If a public trust that has only one trustee becomes vacant, that fact must be reported to the registrar. Application/Conclusion: Yes — when the sole trustee's office becomes vacant you must inform the registrar about the vacancy as required by the law.

instruction: Who succeeds as trustee after a trustee dies if the trust deed doesn't say otherwise?
input: Section no 329 . To specify roll of succession of trustee : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in as to the roll of succession of trustees in the memorandum of incorporation, after the death of a trustee, his or her eldest son, daughter-in-law or daughter shall succeed the oﬀice of a trustee according to the roll of succession, and if there is no one out of them, his or her heir shall succeed the oﬀice of trustee.
output: According to Section 329(1): Rule: If the memorandum is silent, succession goes to the trustee's eldest son, daughter-in-law, or daughter in that order; if none of them exist, the trustee's heir succeeds. Application/Conclusion: If the trust deed doesn't specify succession, the eldest son (or daughter-in-law or daughter in that order) will take the trustee office; if none of those exist, the heir becomes trustee.

instruction: So my father's eldest daughter will become trustee automatically after his death?
input: Section no 329 . To specify roll of succession of trustee : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in as to the roll of succession of trustees in the memorandum of incorporation, after the death of a trustee, his or her eldest son, daughter-in-law or daughter shall succeed the oﬀice of a trustee according to the roll of succession, and if there is no one out of them, his or her heir shall succeed the oﬀice of trustee.
output: According to Section 329(1): Rule: Absent a different provision in the memorandum, succession follows eldest son, then daughter-in-law, then daughter. Application/Conclusion: Your father's eldest daughter will succeed only if she fits the order specified (i.e., eldest son has precedence; if there is no eldest son or daughter-in-law, then eldest daughter succeeds). Check the memorandum to see if it provides a different order.

instruction: The person who should become trustee is currently unqualified. Who carries out trustee duties meanwhile?
input: Section no 329  part (2) : If a person who becomes the trustee pursuant to sub section (1) is not qualified to be the trustee, his or her guardian or the person taking care of (herchaha) him or her shall perform the obligation of the trustee on his or her behalf until such a person becomes qualified. 183
output: According to Section 329(2): Rule: If the successor under subsection (1) is not qualified, that person's guardian or caregiver shall perform the trustee's obligations on their behalf until they become qualified. Application/Conclusion: If the named successor is unqualified (for example underage or otherwise ineligible), a guardian or caregiver must act as trustee in their stead until the successor attains qualification.

instruction: Our memorandum says descendants inherit the trustee role. Does general succession law still apply?
input: Section no 329  part (3) : Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, if there is a provision that one’s descendents are entitled to be the trustee, the descendents of such a person shall succeed the oﬀice of trustee according to the limit of their respective rights, and the provisions contained in Section 326 shall not apply to such case.
output: According to Section 329(3): Rule: Where the memorandum grants the right to descendants to be trustees, those descendants succeed according to their respective rights and Section 326 does not apply. Application/Conclusion: Because your memorandum expressly gives descendants the trustee right, succession follows that provision and the rules in Section 326 are excluded — follow the limits and order set out in the memorandum.

instruction: All trustees resigned at once and we can't immediately appoint replacements. Who runs the trust in the meantime?
input: Section no 330 . Requirement to perform obligation of trustee in special : circumstance: If there exists a situation that the oﬀice of trustee falls vacant in entirety and the oﬀice of trustee cannot be filled immediately pursuant to sub-section (2) of Section 328, the Local Level shall function as the trustee until the oﬀice is filled.
output: According to Section 330: Rule: When the office of trustee becomes entirely vacant and cannot be filled immediately under Section 328(2), the Local Level shall act as trustee until the office is filled. Application/Conclusion: If all trustees have vacated and you cannot appoint new trustees right away, the Local Level (local authority) will temporarily perform trustee functions until proper trustees are appointed.

instruction: How should trustees make decisions when there are multiple trustees — do they vote or must all agree?
input: Section no 331 . Requirement to operate trust by consensus : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, the trust with more than one trustee shall be operated by consensus decision of all the trustees as far as possible.
output: According to Section 331(1): Rule: Trusts with more than one trustee should be operated by consensus of all trustees as far as possible, unless the memorandum says otherwise. Application/Conclusion: You should try to reach consensus among all trustees on decisions; voting should be a last resort and the memorandum may provide a different procedure you need to follow.

instruction: We can't reach consensus. What's the next step? Who decides?
input: Section no 331  part (2) : In the event of failure to reach consensus pursuant to sub-section (1), the trust may be operated by a majority decision of the then existing trustees, and if that is not possible, by the decision of the eldest trustee.
output: According to Section 331(2): Rule: If consensus fails, decisions may be made by majority of existing trustees; if majority is not possible, the eldest trustee decides. Application/Conclusion: If you cannot reach unanimous agreement, conduct a majority decision among current trustees; if a majority cannot be formed (e.g., tie or only two trustees who disagree), the eldest trustee's decision governs.

instruction: I'm a trustee — am I obliged to follow the trust's stated purpose and any honesty standard?
input: Section no 332 . To carry out object of trust : The trustee shall carry out the object of trust as set forth in the memorandum of incorporation, and in so carrying out the object, the trustee shall discharge functions honestly and according to his or her capacity and diligence.
output: According to Section 332: Rule: A trustee must carry out the trust's object as set out in the memorandum and must act honestly and with appropriate capacity and diligence. Application/Conclusion: As trustee you are legally required to pursue the trust's stated objectives and to perform your duties honestly and diligently — failure to do so could expose you to consequences under the law or the trust terms.

instruction: Do trustees have to keep an inventory of trust assets and share it with anyone?
input: Section no 333 . To maintain records of trust property : (1) The trustee shall prepare an inventory of the trust property and update the records 184 thereof, and, in the case of a public trust, a copy of such records shall be submitted to the registrar each year.
output: According to Section 333(1): Rule: Trustees must prepare and update an inventory of trust property; for public trusts, a copy of those records must be submitted to the registrar annually. Application/Conclusion: You must maintain up-to-date records and an inventory of trust assets, and if the trust is public, file the inventory with the registrar every year.

instruction: How often do I need to file my public trust's inventory with the registrar?
input: Section no 333 . To maintain records of trust property : (1) The trustee shall prepare an inventory of the trust property and update the records 184 thereof, and, in the case of a public trust, a copy of such records shall be submitted to the registrar each year.
output: According to Section 333(1): Rule: For public trusts, a copy of the updated inventory/records must be submitted to the registrar each year. Application/Conclusion: You are required to submit the trust's inventory to the registrar annually — once every year.

instruction: If all trustees are relieved at the same time, when should the trust property be transferred?
input: part (5) : If any trustee is relieved of his or her oﬀice by virtue of the circumstance referred to in sub-section (1), he or she shall, as promptly as possible, hand over the trust property in his or her custody, control or use to other trustees, and he or she shall not get immunity from any kind of liability or legal action for any act done or action taken by him or her while in oﬀice of a trustee by the reason only that he or she has been so relieved of oﬀice. Provided that if all trustees are relieved of oﬀice, such property shall be transferred after the appointment of another trustee.
output: According to Section 327(5): Rule: A relieved trustee must hand over property promptly to other trustees, but if all trustees are relieved, the property shall be transferred only after another trustee is appointed. Application/Conclusion: If all trustees are removed simultaneously, the trust property should not be immediately transferred to others; it should be transferred after new trustee(s) are appointed.

instruction: I want to resign as trustee — what must I do with trust property before I go?
input: part (5) : If any trustee is relieved of his or her oﬀice by virtue of the circumstance referred to in sub-section (1), he or she shall, as promptly as possible, hand over the trust property in his or her custody, control or use to other trustees, and he or she shall not get immunity from any kind of liability or legal action for any act done or action taken by him or her while in oﬀice of a trustee by the reason only that he or she has been so relieved of oﬀice. Provided that if all trustees are relieved of oﬀice, such property shall be transferred after the appointment of another trustee.
output: According to Section 327(5): Rule: A trustee relieved of office must promptly hand over trust property in their custody or control to other trustees and remains liable for past acts. Application/Conclusion: Before resigning, you must promptly hand over any trust property you control to the other trustees; you should also be aware that resignation does not shield you from liability for actions taken while you were trustee.

instruction: Under which section is the roll of succession for trustees specified?
input: Section no 329 . To specify roll of succession of trustee : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in as to the roll of succession of trustees in the memorandum of incorporation, after the death of a trustee, his or her eldest son, daughter-in-law or daughter shall succeed the oﬀice of a trustee according to the roll of succession, and if there is no one out of them, his or her heir shall succeed the oﬀice of trustee.
output: According to Section 329(1): Rule: Section 329 specifies the roll of succession of trustees (eldest son, daughter-in-law, daughter, then heir if none). Application/Conclusion: The rules for trustee succession are set out in Section 329; consult Section 329 to determine who succeeds when a trustee dies, unless the memorandum states otherwise.

instruction: Can I put more than 25% of the trust's investable funds in a fixed deposit at a commercial bank?
input: Section no 323  part (4) (b) : Deposit of a maximum of twenty-five percent in a fixed account with a commercial bank,
output: According to Section 323(4)(b)... Rule: Deposit of a maximum of twenty-five percent in a fixed account with a commercial bank is allowed. Application/Conclusion: You may not place more than 25% of the total investable trust sum in a fixed account with a commercial bank; exceeding that would contradict the statutory limit.

instruction: Can the trust buy government bonds or treasury bills?
input: Section no 323  part (4) (a) : At lest twenty-five percent in the purchase of bonds or treasury bills issued by the Government of Nepal or Nepal Rastra 94 Bank or bonds guaranteed by the Government of Nepal,
output: According to Section 323(4)(a)... Rule: At least twenty-five percent of the investable sum may be placed in bonds or treasury bills issued by the Government of Nepal, Nepal Rastra Bank, or bonds guaranteed by the Government. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the trust can invest in such government-issued or government-guaranteed bonds/treasury bills and is in fact required to allocate at least 25% of the investable funds to them.

instruction: If the trust has spare income not needed right away for its object, can that income be invested?
input: Section no 323  part (3) : Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, in the operation and management of the trust property pursuant to sub-sections (1) and (2), income earned from 178 the trust property which is not required immediately to accomplish the objects of trust may be invested for the accomplishment of the objects of trust.
output: According to Section 323(3)... Rule: Income from the trust property that is not immediately required to accomplish the trust's objects may be invested to further those objects, unless the memorandum of incorporation says otherwise. Application/Conclusion: If the memorandum does not prohibit it, spare trust income may be invested, provided the investments are intended to help achieve the trust's purposes.

instruction: Who should appoint the trustee for a trust — me as the founder, or someone else?
input: Section no 324  part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, the founder of the trust shall appoint the trustee.
output: According to Section 324(2)... Rule: Unless the memorandum of incorporation provides otherwise, the founder of the trust is the person who shall appoint the trustee. Application/Conclusion: As the founder, you are the one who should appoint the trustee unless the trust's memorandum sets a different appointment procedure.

instruction: What happens if the founder never appoints a trustee or cannot appoint one?
input: Section no 324  part (3) : In the event of the failure to appoint or inability to appoint the trustee pursuant to sub-section (1) or (2), the founder of trust shall be deemed to be the trustee.
output: According to Section 324(3)... Rule: If a trustee is not appointed or cannot be appointed under the relevant provisions, the founder is deemed to be the trustee. Application/Conclusion: If no trustee is appointed, or appointment is impossible, the law treats the founder as the trustee by operation of this provision.

instruction: What duty does the trustee have to prevent damage or loss to trust property?
input: Section no 323  part (2) : In the operation and management of the trust property pursuant to sub-section (1), the trustee shall make arrangement to avoid any loss and damage to, and maintain sustainability of, such property.
output: According to Section 323(2)... Rule: The trustee must arrange to avoid loss and damage to trust property and must maintain the sustainability of that property. Application/Conclusion: The trustee is legally required to take steps to protect the trust assets from harm and to preserve their sustainability in managing the trust.

instruction: Can a trustee use trust property or accounts together with their personal property/accounts?
input: Section no 323  part (8) : The trustee shall maintain his or her personal property and the trust property separately and operate and mange the trust property accordingly, and in the event of a need to operate an account, separate accounts shall be maintained.
output: According to Section 323(8)... Rule: The trustee must keep personal property and trust property separate, and must maintain separate accounts when operating trust accounts. Application/Conclusion: A trustee may not commingle trust assets with personal assets; separate accounts and clear separation are required by the statute.

instruction: Can a trust subscribe to ordinary shares of a commercial bank? Any limit?
input: Section no 323  part (4) (d) : A maximum of five percent in the subscription of ordinary shares of a commercial bank,
output: According to Section 323(4)(d)... Rule: Subscription to ordinary shares of a commercial bank is permitted up to a maximum of five percent of the total investable sum. Application/Conclusion: The trust may subscribe to ordinary shares of a commercial bank but cannot allocate more than 5% of the investable funds to such subscriptions.

instruction: Is investment in publicly traded companies allowed? If so, how much?
input: Section no 323  part (4) (f) : A maximum of five percent in the subscription of such ordinary shares of an enlisted public limited company as are dealt publicly.
output: According to Section 323(4)(f)... Rule: Subscription to ordinary shares of publicly traded (enlisted) public limited companies is allowed up to a maximum of five percent of the investable sum. Application/Conclusion: The trust may invest in publicly dealt ordinary shares but must limit such subscriptions to 5% of the total investable funds.

instruction: My trustee noticed one sector giving low returns — do they have to act, and how quickly?
input: Section no 323  part (5) : The trustee shall, from time to time, carry out monitoring as to the investment made pursuant to sub-section (4), and if it appears from such monitoring that the returns of investment made in one sector be lesser, such investment shall be 179 withdrawn immediately and made in another sector yielding more returns, subject to the terms and restrictions of the investment.
output: According to Section 323(5)... Rule: Trustees must monitor investments periodically and, if monitoring shows a sector's returns are lower, the investment in that sector shall be withdrawn immediately and reallocated to a sector yielding better returns, subject to investment terms and restrictions. Application/Conclusion: The trustee must act without delay to withdraw underperforming investments and reallocate funds to better-yielding sectors, observing any contractual restrictions.

instruction: Can the trustee obtain expert advice before changing investments?
input: Section no 323  part (6) : In making monitoring or investment pursuant to sub section (5), opinion of an expert in the concerned sector may, as required, be obtained.
output: According to Section 323(6)... Rule: In carrying out monitoring or making investments under subsection (5), the trustee may obtain the opinion of a sector expert as required. Application/Conclusion: The trustee is permitted to seek expert opinions to inform monitoring and investment decisions when appropriate.

instruction: If an expert's opinion is obtained, can the trustee rely on it as the basis for decisions?
input: Section no 323  part (7) : An opinion obtained pursuant to sub-section (6) may be taken as the basis for monitoring or investment.
output: According to Section 323(7)... Rule: An expert opinion obtained under subsection (6) may be taken as the basis for monitoring or investment decisions. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a trustee may rely on an obtained expert opinion when deciding how to monitor or invest trust funds.

instruction: Is there a specified limit for deposits in development banks?
input: Section no 323  part (4) (c) : Deposit of a maximum of ten percent in a fixed account with a development bank,
output: According to Section 323(4)(c)... Rule: A maximum of ten percent of the investable sum may be deposited in a fixed account with a development bank. Application/Conclusion: The trust may place up to 10% of the investable funds in fixed accounts at development banks; it may not exceed that statutory cap.

instruction: How much can be deposited in a finance company from trust investments?
input: Section no 323  part (4) (e) : Deposit of a maximum of ten percent in a fixed account with a finance company,
output: According to Section 323(4)(e)... Rule: Deposit of a maximum of ten percent in a fixed account with a finance company is permitted. Application/Conclusion: You may allocate up to 10% of the investable trust funds to fixed deposits with a finance company; exceeding that would violate the provision.

instruction: Is there an overall prescribed scheme for how trust investments must be proportioned?
input: Section no 323  part (4) : Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, in making investment pursuant to sub-section (3), it may be invested as follows, in the following proportion of the total sum:
output: According to Section 323(4)... Rule: Except where the memorandum of incorporation provides otherwise, investments from investable trust income must follow the prescribed proportions laid out in the subsequent subparagraphs. Application/Conclusion: Yes — there is a statutory allocation scheme for investments that must be followed unless the trust's memorandum sets different rules.

instruction: What is the trustee's basic duty when operating and managing trust property?
input:
. Duty to operate and manage trust property properly
: (1) The trustee shall operate and manage the trust property properly, by
exercising his or her capacity and diligence honestly.
output: According to Section 323(1)... Rule: The trustee must operate and manage trust property properly, exercising capacity and diligence honestly. Application/Conclusion: The trustee is legally required to act with honest effort, competence, and care in managing the trust assets.

instruction: My trustee used trust funds for their personal expenses and mixed accounts. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 323  part (8) : The trustee shall maintain his or her personal property and the trust property separately and operate and mange the trust property accordingly, and in the event of a need to operate an account, separate accounts shall be maintained.
output: According to Section 323(8)... Rule: Trustees must keep personal property and trust property separate and maintain separate accounts where needed. Application/Conclusion: No — using trust funds for personal expenses or mixing accounts is contrary to the statutory requirement of separation; the trustee is required to maintain separate property and accounts.

instruction: If the memorandum of incorporation gives a different rule on investments, which rule applies?
input: Section no 323  part (3) : Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, in the operation and management of the trust property pursuant to sub-sections (1) and (2), income earned from 178 the trust property which is not required immediately to accomplish the objects of trust may be invested for the accomplishment of the objects of trust.
output: According to Section 323(3)... Rule: The statutory permission to invest spare trust income applies except where the memorandum of incorporation provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: If the memorandum of incorporation contains different investment rules, those written rules will control and the statutory default in Section 323(3) will not apply.

instruction: Can I give up my rights as a beneficiary of a private trust? What must I do?
input: Power to relinquish benefit of trust property : (1) In the case of a private trust, the beneficiary who is competent to make contract may, by a notice in writing to the trustee and the registrar, relinquish any or all of his or her right, benefit, facility or interest from the trust property.
output: According to Section 344(1): Rule: A beneficiary of a private trust who is competent to contract may relinquish any or all of their rights, benefits, facilities or interests in the trust property, but this must be done by a notice in writing to the trustee and the registrar. Application/Conclusion: If you are a competent beneficiary and want to give up your entitlement, you must submit a written notice addressed to the trustee and to the registrar. Once you do that, your specified rights/benefits will be relinquished as described.

instruction: If everyone gives up their interest in our private trust, does the trust end?
input: Section no 344  part (2) : If every beneficiary wholly relinquishes the right, benefit, facility or interest from the trust property pursuant to sub section (1), such a trust shall be deemed to have been dissolved.
output: According to Section 344(2): Rule: Where every beneficiary wholly relinquishes their rights/benefits under subsection (1), the private trust shall be deemed dissolved. Application/Conclusion: If all beneficiaries each submit the required written relinquishment, the trust will be legally considered dissolved.

instruction: In whose name should trust property be recorded in the trust records?
input: Section no 345 . Duty to maintain ownership of trust property : (1) The trust property shall be entered as such in the records of trust and held in the name of the person specified in the memorandum of incorporation and in the name of the beneficiary, if such a person is not specified in the memorandum of incorporation.
output: According to Section 345(1): Rule: Trust property must be entered in the trust records and held in the name of the person specified in the memorandum of incorporation; if no person is specified there, it shall be held in the name of the beneficiary. Application/Conclusion: You must record the trust property in the trust's records and title it to the person named in the memorandum. If the memorandum does not name anyone, hold it in the beneficiary's name.

instruction: We plan to set up a corporate body to run our public trust. In whose name will the property be held?
input: Section no 345  part (2) : If, in the case of a public trust, the memorandum of incorporation provides for the establishment of a separate body corporate for the operation and management of the trust property, such property shall be held in the name of the body corporate so established.
output: According to Section 345(2): Rule: For a public trust where the memorandum establishes a separate body corporate to operate/manage the trust property, the property shall be held in the name of that body corporate. Application/Conclusion: If your public trust's memorandum creates a corporate body to run the property, the trust property must be titled and held in the name of that corporate body.

instruction: I want to change the stated object of a trust I founded. What do I need to do?
input: Section no 346 . Alteration in the object of trust : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if the trust founder considers appropriate to make any amendment or alteration in the object set forth in the memorandum of incorporation at the time of the creation of trust, he or she may make an application, accompanied by the reason for such amendment or alteration, to the registrar.
output: According to Section 346(1): Rule: The trust founder may apply to the registrar to amend or alter the object in the memorandum, but the application must be accompanied by the reason for the amendment. Application/Conclusion: To change the object's memorandum you must file an application with the registrar explaining and giving reasons for the proposed amendment; the registrar will then consider the request.

instruction: If I apply to change the trust's object and give reasons, will the registrar automatically approve it?
input: Section no 346  part (2) : If, on an inquiry into an application made pursuant to sub-section (1), the reason for the amendment or alteration in the object set forth in the memorandum of incorporation seems to be reasonable, the registrar may issue an order to amend or alter such object, and, if an order is so made, the object set forth in the memorandum of incorporation shall be deemed to have been amended or altered accordingly.
output: According to Section 346(2): Rule: The registrar will inquire into the application and, if the reason appears reasonable, may issue an order amending the object; when the order is made, the memorandum's object is deemed amended. Application/Conclusion: Approval is not automatic — the registrar must find the reason reasonable after inquiry. If the registrar issues the order, the memorandum is legally amended as specified.

instruction: I manage trust property as trustee. Can tax authorities treat the trust assets as my personal property for tax assessment?
input: Section no 347 . Trust property not to be counted : Any trust property operated and managed by the trustee shall not be counted as the property of the trustee for the purpose of assessment of tax or for any other purpose.
output: According to Section 347 (first sentence): Rule: Trust property operated and managed by the trustee shall not be counted as the trustee's own property for tax assessment or other purposes. Application/Conclusion: Tax authorities should not treat or assess the trust assets as your personal property simply because you operate/manage them as trustee.

instruction: I used trust land and gained some benefits personally. Will those benefits be considered my property for tax?
input: Section no 347 . Trust property not to be counted : Any trust property operated and managed by the trustee shall not be counted as the property of the trustee for the purpose of assessment of tax or for any other purpose. Provided that in the case of a person who derives any benefit, facility or interest from such property, such benefit, facility or interest shall be counted.
output: According to Section 347 (full text): Rule: While the trust property itself is not counted as the trustee's property for tax or other purposes, any benefit, facility or interest a person derives from such property shall be counted. Application/Conclusion: The trust assets are not your personal property, but any personal benefits you obtained from using that trust property should be counted (for tax or other assessments) as your benefit or interest.

instruction: If a trust is voided, will actions already taken by the trust be undone?
input: Section no 348 . Consequence of voidance of trust : (1) If a trust once established is dissolved or voided for any reason, such dissolution or voidance shall not affect any act already done.
output: According to Section 348(1): Rule: Dissolution or voidance of an established trust does not affect any act already done. Application/Conclusion: Transactions or acts carried out by the trust before it was voided or dissolved remain valid and are not automatically undone by the dissolution.

instruction: Our public trust got dissolved. Where should the trustee hand over the trust property?
input: Section no 348  part (2) : In the event of dissolution or voidance of a trust for any reason pursuant to sub-section (1), in the case of a public trust, except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of its incorporation, the trustee may, by order of the registrar, hand over the trust property to any other trust with the identical object or to any public body with similar objects if such other trust is not available, and in the case of a private trust, the trustee shall hand over the trust property to the beneficiary, if identified, or to the nearest successor to the beneficiary if the beneficiary is not available or to the trust founder if even such successor is not available or to other successor if even the trust founder is not available.
output: According to Section 348(2): Rule: For a dissolved public trust (unless the memorandum says otherwise), the trustee may, by order of the registrar, hand over the trust property to another trust with an identical object or, failing that, to a public body with similar objects. Application/Conclusion: If your public trust is dissolved, the trustee should seek the registrar's order to transfer the property to another trust with the same object or to a suitable public body, unless your memorandum specifies a different arrangement.

instruction: A private trust I know has been voided. No beneficiary can be found. Who gets the property?
input: Section no 348  part (2) : In the event of dissolution or voidance of a trust for any reason pursuant to sub-section (1), in the case of a public trust, except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum of its incorporation, the trustee may, by order of the registrar, hand over the trust property to any other trust with the identical object or to any public body with similar objects if such other trust is not available, and in the case of a private trust, the trustee shall hand over the trust property to the beneficiary, if identified, or to the nearest successor to the beneficiary if the beneficiary is not available or to the trust founder if even such successor is not available or to other successor if even the trust founder is not available.
output: According to Section 348(2): Rule: When a private trust is dissolved, the trustee must hand over the property to the beneficiary if identified; if not, to the nearest successor to the beneficiary; if that successor is not available, to the trust founder; if the founder is not available, to another successor. Application/Conclusion: If no beneficiary can be located, the trustee should follow the succession order set out: nearest successor, then trust founder, then other successor — transferring the trust property accordingly.

instruction: What happens if no eligible person or body is available to receive property of a dissolved trust?
input: Section no 348  part (3) : If any body or person referred to in sub-section (2) is not available, the property of the dissolved or voided trust shall devolve on the Government of Nepal.
output: According to Section 348(3): Rule: If none of the bodies or persons listed in subsection (2) are available, the dissolved trust's property shall devolve on the Government of Nepal. Application/Conclusion: If the trustee cannot find any appropriate trust, public body, beneficiary, successor or founder to receive the property, the property will pass to the Government of Nepal.

instruction: I and my sibling are beneficiaries of a private trust. I want to relinquish my share but my sibling won't. If I relinquish alone, will the trust dissolve?
input:
Power to relinquish benefit of trust property : (1) In the case of a private trust, the beneficiary who is competent to make contract may, by a notice in writing to the trustee and the registrar, relinquish any or all of his or her right, benefit, facility or interest from the trust property.

 Section no 344  part (2) : If every beneficiary wholly relinquishes the right, benefit, facility or interest from the trust property pursuant to sub section (1), such a trust shall be deemed to have been dissolved.
output: According to Section 344(1) and Section 344(2): Rule: An individual beneficiary may relinquish rights by written notice to the trustee and registrar (344(1)). The trust is deemed dissolved only if every beneficiary wholly relinquishes their rights under subsection (1) (344(2)). Application/Conclusion: If you alone relinquish, your share will be relinquished once you follow the required written notice procedure, but the trust will not be dissolved unless all beneficiaries do the same.

instruction: I'm trying to amend the trust's object — do I need to say why in my application to the registrar?
input: Section no 346 . Alteration in the object of trust : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if the trust founder considers appropriate to make any amendment or alteration in the object set forth in the memorandum of incorporation at the time of the creation of trust, he or she may make an application, accompanied by the reason for such amendment or alteration, to the registrar.
output: According to Section 346(1): Rule: The founder's application to amend the object must be accompanied by the reason for the amendment or alteration. Application/Conclusion: Yes — when you apply to the registrar to change the object's memorandum you must include the reasons for the proposed amendment.

instruction: Under which section does the law state trust property operated by the trustee is not counted as the trustee's property for tax?
input: Section no 347 . Trust property not to be counted : Any trust property operated and managed by the trustee shall not be counted as the property of the trustee for the purpose of assessment of tax or for any other purpose.
output: According to Section 347: Rule: Section 347 provides that trust property operated and managed by the trustee shall not be counted as the trustee's own property for tax assessment or other purposes. Application/Conclusion: The legal provision you need is Section 347; it prevents trust property from being treated as the trustee's personal property for tax or similar assessments.

instruction: I used some trust facilities for my private work. Will those facilities be treated as my income or property?
input: Section no 347 . Trust property not to be counted : Any trust property operated and managed by the trustee shall not be counted as the property of the trustee for the purpose of assessment of tax or for any other purpose. Provided that in the case of a person who derives any benefit, facility or interest from such property, such benefit, facility or interest shall be counted.
output: According to Section 347 (full text): Rule: Trust assets themselves are not counted as the trustee's property, but any benefit, facility or interest a person derives from trust property shall be counted. Application/Conclusion: The trust assets won't be your personal property, but the facilities you used for private work are benefits that should be counted (for tax or other purposes) as your benefit or interest.

instruction: Can I use trust property to make money for myself?
output:
According to Section 342 clause (b):
Rule: A trustee must not use trust property in any act yielding profit to the trustee or anyone else except for accomplishing the object of the trust.
Application/Conclusion: If you use the trust property to make personal profit and that use is not for accomplishing the trust's object, it is prohibited. You would be acting contrary to Section 342(b) and could be required to account for or restore any benefit obtained.

instruction: Am I allowed to be paid for being a trustee?
input:
Section no 342  clause (e) : To obtain any remuneration, allowance or facility
in consideration for being a trustee, Provided that nothing shall bar the receiving
of reasonable remuneration, allowance or facility for any work done whole-time
or part-time after establishing the oﬀice or with the prior permission of the
registrar, without prejudicing the object of the trust or benefit of the beneficiary.
output:
According to Section 342 clause (e):
