Rule: Trustees are generally barred from obtaining remuneration for being a trustee, but reasonable remuneration for work (full- or part-time) is permitted after establishing the office or with prior permission of the registrar, provided it does not prejudice the trust's object or beneficiaries' benefit.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot simply claim payment for holding the trustee role. You may receive reasonable pay for actual work if the office is established or you have prior registrar permission and the payment does not harm the trust or beneficiaries.

instruction: Can a trustee buy the trust's property while still serving?
input:
Section no 342  clause (f) : To purchase or otherwise receive on pledge,
mortgage, lease or rent the property of the trust for which he or she is a trustee
during his or her tenure or before at least three years of his or her retirement
from the oﬀice of a trustee.
output:
According to Section 342 clause (f):
Rule: A trustee must not purchase or otherwise acquire (by pledge, mortgage, lease or rent) the trust property while serving as trustee or within three years before retirement from the trustee office.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot buy or take the trust's property while you are trustee, nor within three years before you leave the office. Any such acquisition in that period would be prohibited under Section 342(f).

instruction: My trustee mixed his land with trust land. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 342  part (3) : The trustee shall not merge his or her property
with the trust property.
output:
According to Section 342 part (3):
Rule: A trustee is prohibited from merging their personal property with trust property.
Application/Conclusion: The trustee's act of mixing their land with trust land is not allowed. The trustee must separate the properties and may be required to remedy any resulting harm to the trust.

instruction: Can a trustee do business between their private assets and the trust's assets?
input:
Section no 342  part (2) : The trustee shall not make any economic transaction between his or her private property and the trust property. He or she
shall make compensation for the loss, if any, to the trust property from such
transaction.
output:
According to Section 342 part (2):
Rule: Trustees must not enter into economic transactions between their private property and trust property; if such a transaction occurs and causes loss, the trustee must compensate the trust for the loss.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot lawfully transact between your private assets and the trust's assets. If you do and the trust suffers a loss, you are obligated to compensate the trust for that loss.

instruction: Can a trustee hand over their duties to someone else?
input:
Section no 342  clause (c) : To delegate or hand over the responsibility or
obligation of trustee to another trustee or a person, Provided that nothing shall
bar the appointing of his or her agent or attorney in the course of ordinary
transaction or assigning of any responsibility or obligation if such responsibility
or obligation is to be 189 assigned in view of the nature of such transaction
or assigning of any responsibility to another person with the consent of the
beneficiary, if any, identified.
output:
According to Section 342 clause (c):
Rule: Trustees must not delegate or hand over their responsibilities to another person, except they may appoint an agent or attorney for ordinary transactions or assign responsibilities appropriate to the transaction, and may assign responsibilities with the beneficiary's consent.
Application/Conclusion: You generally cannot transfer the trustee role or its obligations to someone else. However, you may appoint agents for ordinary business or assign specific tasks when appropriate, and you may assign responsibilities with the beneficiary's consent.

instruction: There are two trustees. Can one of them do something that goes against Section 329?
input:
Section no 342  clause (d) : To carry out any act relating to the trust solely
contrary to Section 329, if there are more than one trustee,
output:
According to Section 342 clause (d):
Rule: If there is more than one trustee, no trustee shall carry out any act relating to the trust that is solely contrary to Section 329.
Application/Conclusion: A single trustee cannot unilaterally take an action that conflicts with Section 329 when multiple trustees exist. They must act in accordance with Section 329 and with the other trustees as required.

instruction: What other responsibilities does a trustee have beyond what's listed in this chapter?
input:
Other powers, duties and liabilities deemed to be
vested with : trustee: Except as otherwise provided for in the memorandum
of incorporation, in addition to the powers, duties and liabilities clearly set
forth in this Chapter, such other powers and duties as may be required for the
implementation and accomplishment of the object of trust, care (herbichar)and
protection of the trust property and protection of the rights and benefits of the
beneficiary shall be deemed to be vested with the trustee.
output:
According to Section 342 (preamble to trustee duties):
Rule: Beyond the enumerated powers, duties and liabilities in the Chapter, trustees also hold any additional powers and duties necessary to implement and accomplish the trust's object, care for and protect trust property, and protect beneficiaries' rights and benefits, unless the memorandum of incorporation provides otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: Even if a specific duty isn't spelled out in the Chapter, you as trustee are responsible for any additional actions needed to fulfill the trust's purpose and safeguard trust property and beneficiary interests, unless the memorandum says otherwise.

instruction: If I'm the only beneficiary and I'm now old enough, can I demand the trust property?
input:
Section no 343 . To give direction to transfer trust property : Except as
otherwise provided for in the memorandum of incorporation, in the case of 190
only one beneficiary, after he or she becomes competent to make contract, and
in the case of more than one beneficiary, after all of them become competent to
make contract and reach consensus, such beneficiary or beneficiaries may direct
the trustee to hand over the trust property to him or her or them, and if any
direction is so given, it shall be the duty of the trustee to abide by such direction.
output:
According to Section 343:
Rule: When there is only one beneficiary who becomes legally competent to contract, that beneficiary may direct the trustee to hand over the trust property; the trustee must comply, except where the memorandum of incorporation provides otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: As the sole beneficiary who is competent to contract, you can direct the trustee to transfer the trust property to you, and the trustee has a duty to follow that direction unless the trust's memorandum says otherwise.

instruction: Does the rule allowing beneficiaries to demand transfer apply to public trusts?
input: Provided that this provision shall not apply to the public trust.
output:
According to Section 343 (proviso):
Rule: The provision allowing beneficiaries to direct transfer of trust property does not apply to public trusts.
Application/Conclusion: If the trust is a public trust, beneficiaries cannot use Section 343 to demand the transfer of trust property; the exception explicitly excludes public trusts.

instruction: If a trustee trades between his private house and the trust's house and the trust loses money, what happens?
input:
Section no 342  part (2) : The trustee shall not make any economic transaction between his or her private property and the trust property. He or she
shall make compensation for the loss, if any, to the trust property from such
transaction.
output:
According to Section 342 part (2):
Rule: Trustees are forbidden from economic transactions between private and trust property; if such a transaction causes loss, the trustee must compensate the trust for that loss.
Application/Conclusion: Because the trustee conducted a private-trust transaction and the trust suffered a loss, the trustee is required to compensate the trust for the loss under Section 342(2).

instruction: Can a trustee appoint an attorney to handle ordinary matters?
input:
Provided that nothing shall
bar the appointing of his or her agent or attorney in the course of ordinary
transaction or assigning of any responsibility or obligation if such responsibility
or obligation is to be 189 assigned in view of the nature of such transaction
or assigning of any responsibility to another person with the consent of the
beneficiary, if any, identified.
output:
According to Section 342 clause (c) (proviso):
Rule: Trustees may appoint an agent or attorney for ordinary transactions or assign responsibilities appropriate to the nature of the transaction, and may assign responsibilities with beneficiary consent.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — a trustee may appoint an attorney or agent to handle ordinary matters, provided the appointment fits the transaction's nature and, where required, the beneficiary's consent is obtained.

instruction: How long before leaving office is a trustee forbidden from buying trust assets?
input:
Section no 342  clause (f) : To purchase or otherwise receive on pledge,
mortgage, lease or rent the property of the trust for which he or she is a trustee
during his or her tenure or before at least three years of his or her retirement
from the oﬀice of a trustee.
output:
According to Section 342 clause (f):
Rule: A trustee is prohibited from purchasing or otherwise acquiring trust property during their tenure and also within at least three years prior to retirement from the trustee office.
Application/Conclusion: You are forbidden from acquiring the trust property while in office and for at least three years before you retire as trustee.

instruction: If there are several beneficiaries, when can they tell the trustee to hand over the property?
input:
in the case of more than one beneficiary, after all of them become competent to
make contract and reach consensus, such beneficiary or beneficiaries may direct
the trustee to hand over the trust property to him or her or them, and if any
direction is so given, it shall be the duty of the trustee to abide by such direction.
output:
According to Section 343:
Rule: When there are multiple beneficiaries, they may direct the trustee to hand over the trust property only after all beneficiaries are competent to contract and they reach consensus; the trustee must obey such a direction.
Application/Conclusion: The beneficiaries must all be legally competent and agree among themselves before they can validly direct the trustee to transfer the trust property. Once those conditions are met, the trustee is obliged to comply.

instruction: Is a trustee allowed to use trust property for anything other than the trust's goals?
input:
Section no 342  clause (a) : To use the trust property in any manner other
than in the accomplishment of the object of trust,
output:
According to Section 342 clause (a):
Rule: Trustees are prohibited from using trust property in any manner other than to accomplish the trust's object.
Application/Conclusion: Using trust property for purposes outside the trust's object is not permitted. If you plan to use trust assets for another purpose, that would violate Section 342(a).

instruction: My trustee rented trust land to his relative during his term. Is that legal?
input:
Section no 342  clause (f) : To purchase or otherwise receive on pledge,
mortgage, lease or rent the property of the trust for which he or she is a trustee
during his or her tenure or before at least three years of his or her retirement
from the oﬀice of a trustee.
output:
According to Section 342 clause (f):
Rule: A trustee must not receive (including by lease or rent) the property of the trust for which they are trustee during their tenure or within three years before retirement.
Application/Conclusion: If the trustee rented trust land to their relative for the trustee's own benefit during their tenure, that falls within the prohibition in Section 342(f) and would be impermissible. The trustee should not have taken that lease/rent arrangement.

instruction: How many days do I have to appeal a registrar's decision after I learn about it?
input: Section no 349 . Appeal may be made : A party who is not satisfied with any order or decision made by the registrar pursuant to this Chapter may make an appeal to the concerned District Court within thirty-five days after the date of knowledge of such order or decision.
output: According to Section 349... Rule: A party dissatisfied with any order/decision of the registrar may appeal to the concerned District Court. Application/Conclusion: You have thirty-five days from the date you learn of the registrar's order or decision to file that appeal.

instruction: I just got an order from the registrar today. Can I still appeal, and what's the deadline?
input: Section no 349 . Appeal may be made : A party who is not satisfied with any order or decision made by the registrar pursuant to this Chapter may make an appeal to the concerned District Court within thirty-five days after the date of knowledge of such order or decision.
output: According to Section 349... Rule: An appeal against the registrar's order/decision must be brought to the concerned District Court within thirty-five days of knowledge. Application/Conclusion: Since you learned of the order today, you generally have thirty-five days from today to file the appeal.

instruction: Does this Chapter affect trusts that were already operating before the Act started?
input: Section no 350 . Not to affect other trust : (1) Nothing contained in this Chapter shall affect any trust in operation upon being incorporated in accordance with law in force for the time being prior to the commencement of this Act, and such a trust may be operated in accordance with the Donative inscription (Danpatra), Shilapatra, memorandum of incorporation or other deed establishing such a trust or with the ritual, custom or practice. Provided that such a trust shall be registered under this Act or information of its operation shall be given to the registrar within three years of the commencement of this Act, and records thereof shall be maintained. 193
output: According to Section 350(1)... Rule: The Chapter does not affect trusts already in operation before the Act; they may continue to operate under their original deeds, inscriptions, rituals, customs, or memorandum. Application/Conclusion: Your pre-existing trust can keep operating as before under its founding documents or customs, but it must be registered under this Act or inform the registrar of its operation within three years of the Act's commencement and maintain records.

instruction: My family trust existed before this law. Do we have to register it now?
input: Section no 350 . Not to affect other trust : (1) Nothing contained in this Chapter shall affect any trust in operation upon being incorporated in accordance with law in force for the time being prior to the commencement of this Act, and such a trust may be operated in accordance with the Donative inscription (Danpatra), Shilapatra, memorandum of incorporation or other deed establishing such a trust or with the ritual, custom or practice. Provided that such a trust shall be registered under this Act or information of its operation shall be given to the registrar within three years of the commencement of this Act, and records thereof shall be maintained. 193
output: According to Section 350(1)... Rule: Pre-existing trusts must be either registered under this Act or provide information of their operation to the registrar within three years of the Act's commencement, and must maintain records. Application/Conclusion: Yes — your family trust should be registered or at least notify the registrar within that three-year window and keep records as required.

instruction: Can a trust that existed before the Act still follow its Donative inscription or customary practice instead of the new Act?
input: Section no 350 . Not to affect other trust : (1) Nothing contained in this Chapter shall affect any trust in operation upon being incorporated in accordance with law in force for the time being prior to the commencement of this Act, and such a trust may be operated in accordance with the Donative inscription (Danpatra), Shilapatra, memorandum of incorporation or other deed establishing such a trust or with the ritual, custom or practice. Provided that such a trust shall be registered under this Act or information of its operation shall be given to the registrar within three years of the commencement of this Act, and records thereof shall be maintained. 193
output: According to Section 350(1)... Rule: Pre-existing trusts may continue to operate in accordance with their Donative inscription (Danpatra), Shilapatra, memorandum of incorporation, other establishing deed, or with ritual, custom or practice. Application/Conclusion: Yes — such a trust may keep following its traditional or deed-based rules rather than immediately switching to new procedures, but must still register or inform the registrar within three years and keep records.

instruction: After the trust achieves its objective, can the remaining property be used or mortgaged?
input: Section no 350  part (2) : The trust referred to in sub-section (1) shall be managed and operated as previously for the object and purpose for which it was established, and the property or income that remains upon the accomplishment of that object and purpose may be possessed, used, pledged or mortgaged.
output: According to Section 350(2)... Rule: A pre-existing trust must be managed for its original object and purpose; any remaining property or income after accomplishing that purpose may be possessed, used, pledged, or mortgaged. Application/Conclusion: Once the trust's stated objective is fulfilled, the leftover property or income can legally be retained, used, pledged, or mortgaged in line with the trust's original purpose.

instruction: Is it allowed to buy or sell property that belongs to an old trust?
input: Section no 350  part (3) : The property of a trust established pursuant to sub section (1) may be purchased or sold in a manner without prejudice the object and purpose of the trust.
output: According to Section 350(3)... Rule: Property of a pre-existing trust may be purchased or sold provided such transactions do not prejudice the trust's object and purpose. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the trust's property can be bought or sold, but any sale or purchase must not undermine or defeat the trust's original intended object and purpose.

instruction: If someone buys trust land, can they use it for anything they like?
input: Section no 350  part (4) : The purchaser under sub-section (3) shall use the property for the object and purpose for which the trust was established.
output: According to Section 350(4)... Rule: A purchaser of trust property must use that property for the object and purpose for which the trust was established. Application/Conclusion: No — a buyer cannot use the purchased trust property for unrelated purposes; they are legally bound to use it in line with the trust's original object and purpose.

instruction: The trust was given government land for a school. Can the trustor or their children use that land personally?
input: Section no 350  part (5) : If a trust under sub-section (1) has been established or operated for any specific purpose by obtaining a government land, such a land shall be used for the accomplishment of the object and purpose for which the trust was established, and such a land shall not be used by the trustor or his or her offspring or successor.
output: According to Section 350(5)... Rule: Government land obtained for a trust must be used to accomplish the trust's object and purpose and shall not be used by the trustor or the trustor's offspring or successor. Application/Conclusion: The trustor and their descendants cannot personally use that government land; it must be used only for the trust's specified purpose (e.g., the school).

instruction: If the trustor fails to run the project on government land, who can possess the land?
input: Section no 350  part (6) : If the person referred to in sub-section (5) does not accomplish the object and purpose of such a trust, the person who accomplishes such object and purpose shall be entitled to possess and use such a land.
output: According to Section 350(6)... Rule: If the person who had been given government land for a trust fails to accomplish the trust's object and purpose, then the person who actually accomplishes that object and purpose is entitled to possess and use the land. Application/Conclusion: If the original trustee fails to run the project, someone else who completes the trust's purpose can lawfully possess and use the government land.

instruction: I've been operating a trust without any written deed for 20 years. Can I still possess the property?
input: Section no 350  part (7) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, if any person has continuously operated a trust referred to in sub-section (1) since last sixteen years or more than sixteen years ago without any deed to that effect, that person may possess and use such property upon the accomplishment of the object and purpose of such a trust. 194
output: According to Section 350(7)... Rule: A person who has continuously operated such a trust for sixteen years or more without any deed may possess and use the trust property upon accomplishment of the trust's object and purpose. Application/Conclusion: Yes — having continuously operated the trust for over sixteen years without a deed, you may possess and use the property's trust assets once the trust's object has been accomplished.

instruction: If something isn't mentioned in Section 350, which document controls the trust's operation?
input: Section no 350  part (8) : Matters other than those set forth in this Section shall be as set forth in the memorandum of incorporation of a trust, Sheelapatra, Donative Inscription or as per the custom and practice in relation to the operation of such a trust.
output: According to Section 350(8)... Rule: Matters not covered by Section 350 are governed by the trust's memorandum of incorporation, Sheelapatra, Donative Inscription, or applicable custom and practice. Application/Conclusion: If Section 350 is silent on a point, you should look to the trust's founding documents or customary practice to determine how to proceed.

instruction: Is embezzlement of trust property barred by any statute of limitation if I want to sue?
input:
Section no 351 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation in relation to the following matters if a person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter is to make a lawsuit:
 Section no 351  clause (a) : Embezzlement of the trust property,
output: According to Section 351(1) and clause (a)... Rule: There is no statute of limitation for embezzlement of trust property when bringing a lawsuit under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: You can file a lawsuit for embezzlement of trust property regardless of how much time has passed; the law sets no time limit for such claims.

instruction: I found out someone forged a trust document years ago. Can I still sue now?
input:
Section no 351 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation in relation to the following matters if a person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter is to make a lawsuit:
 Section no 351  clause (b) : Fraud or forgery of any document relating to the trust property,
output: According to Section 351(1) and clause (b)... Rule: There is no statute of limitation for fraud or forgery of any document related to trust property when bringing a lawsuit. Application/Conclusion: Yes — even if many years have passed since you discovered the forgery, you can still bring a lawsuit because no time limit applies to such claims under this Chapter.

instruction: A trustee took benefits contrary to our trust's memorandum. Is there a time limit to sue?
input:
Section no 351 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation in relation to the following matters if a person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter is to make a lawsuit:
 Section no 351  clause (d) : Derivation of benefit by the trustee contrary to the terms of the memorandum of incorporation of the trust,
output: According to Section 351(1) and clause (d)... Rule: There is no statute of limitation for claims concerning a trustee deriving benefits contrary to the trust's memorandum. Application/Conclusion: You can bring a lawsuit against the trustee for unauthorized personal benefit at any time; the law does not impose a time bar for such claims.

instruction: Someone misappropriated trust funds long ago. Can we still take legal action now?
input:
Section no 351 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation in relation to the following matters if a person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter is to make a lawsuit:
 Section no 351  clause (c) : Embezzlement or misappropriation of the trust property,
output: According to Section 351(1) and clause (c)... Rule: No statute of limitation applies to embezzlement or misappropriation of trust property for purposes of bringing a lawsuit. Application/Conclusion: You can still initiate legal proceedings for misappropriation of trust property regardless of the time elapsed; there is no time limit under this provision.

instruction: Under which section does the Act say there is no time limit for fraud, embezzlement, forgery, or trustee misconduct?
input:
Section no 351 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation in relation to the following matters if a person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter is to make a lawsuit:
 Section no 351  clause (a) : Embezzlement of the trust property,
 Section no 351  clause (b) : Fraud or forgery of any document relating to the trust property,
 Section no 351  clause (c) : Embezzlement or misappropriation of the trust property,
 Section no 351  clause (d) : Derivation of benefit by the trustee contrary to the terms of the memorandum of incorporation of the trust,
 Section no 351
output: According to Section 351... Rule: Section 351(1) lists specific matters (embezzlement, fraud/forgery, embezzlement/misappropriation, and trustee deriving improper benefits) for which there shall be no statute of limitation when an aggrieved person seeks to bring a lawsuit under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: The absence of time limits for these categories is set out in Section 351(1); for claims of embezzlement, forgery/fraud, misappropriation, or trustee misconduct, you are not barred by a statute of limitation.

instruction: Can a trust buy and then the buyer put the property to a different use than the trust's purpose?
input:
Section no 350  part (3) : The property of a trust established pursuant to sub section (1) may be purchased or sold in a manner without prejudice the object and purpose of the trust.
 Section no 350  part (4) : The purchaser under sub-section (3) shall use the property for the object and purpose for which the trust was established.
output: According to Section 350(3) and Section 350(4)... Rule: Trust property may be purchased or sold only in a way that does not prejudice the trust's object and purpose; purchasers must use the property for the trust's original object and purpose. Application/Conclusion: No — a buyer cannot repurpose the property contrary to the trust's object; any purchase must preserve the trust's purpose and the purchaser must use it for that purpose.

instruction: My village trust was operating but we missed the three-year registration window. What does the law say we should have done?
input: Section no 350 . Not to affect other trust : (1) Nothing contained in this Chapter shall affect any trust in operation upon being incorporated in accordance with law in force for the time being prior to the commencement of this Act, and such a trust may be operated in accordance with the Donative inscription (Danpatra), Shilapatra, memorandum of incorporation or other deed establishing such a trust or with the ritual, custom or practice. Provided that such a trust shall be registered under this Act or information of its operation shall be given to the registrar within three years of the commencement of this Act, and records thereof shall be maintained. 193
output: According to Section 350(1)... Rule: Pre-existing trusts must be registered under this Act or must give information of their operation to the registrar within three years of the Act's commencement, and must maintain records. Application/Conclusion: The law required your trust to be registered or to have notified the registrar within three years and to keep records. If that window was missed, the provision still reflects the requirement; you should now contact the registrar to regularize the trust's status and ensure records are maintained (the Section does not specify penalties in the quoted text).

instruction: Can I significantly alter the house I hold under usufruct without asking the owner?
input:
Prohibition of alteration in structure of property
without : consent: A usufructuary shall not be entitled to significantly alter
the substance or form of the property obtained under the provision of usufruct
or to destroy such property, except with the owner’s prior permission.
output:
According to Section 357... 
Rule: A usufructuary is not entitled to significantly alter the substance or form of the property obtained under usufruct or to destroy such property without the owner’s prior permission. 
Application/Conclusion: If you want to make significant structural changes or demolish the house, you must first get the owner’s prior permission. Without that permission, such alteration or destruction would be prohibited.

instruction: My landlord says I can tear down the old shed because otherwise I can't use the land. Is that allowed?
input:
Provided that if the enjoyment of the property given under the provision of
usufruct is not possible without an alteration in the form of or destruction of
the property, except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the property may
be enjoyed by altering its form or destroying it, on payment of the price that
may be set at the time of returning such property.
output:
According to Section 357... 
Rule: If enjoyment of the usufruct property is not possible without altering or destroying it (and the contract doesn't say otherwise), the usufructuary may alter or destroy it, but must pay a price that may be set when returning the property. 
Application/Conclusion: If the shed must be removed for you to reasonably use the property and the contract does not forbid it, you may remove it, but you should expect to pay compensation (a price set upon return of the property). Notify the owner and clarify the amount or method of valuation to avoid disputes.

instruction: Do I need a deed to rent out a usufruct property for 15,000 per month?
input:
Section no 358 .
Power to rent, lease or mortgage property under
provision of : usufruct: (1) The usufructuary may, if he or she so desires,
rent, lease or mortgage the property obtained under the provision of usufruct,
by executing a deed, subject to the contract referred to in sub-section (2) of
Section 352. Provided that:
 Section no 358  part (1) : It is not required to execute a deed for renting a
property for a monthly rent not exceeding twenty thousand rupees.
output:
According to Section 358(1)... 
Rule: Generally a usufructuary rents/leases/mortgages by executing a deed, but it is not required to execute a deed for renting a property when the monthly rent does not exceed twenty thousand rupees. 
Application/Conclusion: For a monthly rent of 15,000 rupees you are not required to execute a deed to rent the usufruct property. However, consider documenting the agreement in writing for clarity and to inform the owner (see other duties).

instruction: If I rent out the usufruct property, do I have to inform the owner?
input:
Section no 358  part (2) : If a property is so rented, leased or mortgaged, the
usufructuary shall give information thereof to the owner.
output:
According to Section 358(2)... 
Rule: When a usufructuary rents, leases or mortgages the property, they must give information of that transaction to the owner. 
Application/Conclusion: Yes — after renting, leasing or mortgaging the property you must inform the owner about the arrangement.

instruction: Can I lease the usufruct property for 10 years if my usufruct ends in 5 years?
input:
Section no 358  part (3) : The property obtained under the provision of
usufruct may not be rented, leased or mortgaged for a period that exceeds the
validity period of usufruct.
output:
According to Section 358(3)... 
Rule: Property under usufruct may not be rented, leased or mortgaged for a period that exceeds the validity period of the usufruct. 
Application/Conclusion: No — you cannot validly lease the property for 10 years if your usufruct expires in 5 years. Any agreement exceeding the usufruct term would violate this rule.

instruction: Do I have to mention that the property is under usufruct in the lease deed?
input:
Section no 358  part (2) : The usufructuary shall, in renting, leasing or mortgaging the property obtained under the provision of usufruct, mention in the
relevant deed that the property is under the provision of usufruct. 198
output:
According to Section 358(2)... 
Rule: When renting, leasing or mortgaging under usufruct, the usufructuary must state in the relevant deed that the property is under usufruct. 
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you execute a deed for rent, lease or mortgage, you must expressly mention in that deed that the property is under usufruct.

instruction: I executed a lease without telling the lessee or owner that the property was under usufruct. Is that lease valid?
input:
Section no 358  part (3) : If a rent, lease or mortgage of the property obtained
under the provision of usufruct is executed in contravention of sub sections (1)
and (2), such a transaction shall ipso facto be void.
output:
According to Section 358(3)... 
Rule: Any rent, lease or mortgage executed in contravention of sub-sections (1) and (2) (such as failing to follow deed requirement or mention of usufruct) is ipso facto void. 
Application/Conclusion: Because you executed the lease in contravention of the statutory requirements (failing to mention the usufruct), that transaction is void by operation of law.

instruction: If I rent the usufruct property to someone, can they use it like I do?
input:
Section no 358  part (4) : A person who obtains a property on rent, lease or
mortgage pursuant to sub-section (1) shall be entitled to enjoy the property as
if the person were the usufructuary.
output:
According to Section 358(4)... 
Rule: A person who obtains the property by rent, lease or mortgage under subsection (1) is entitled to enjoy the property as if they were the usufructuary. 
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the tenant/lessee/mortgagee who obtains the property per subsection (1) may enjoy it in the same manner as a usufructuary, subject to the same limitations.

instruction: What am I legally required to do to keep the usufruct property in good order?
input:
Section no 359 . Duty to maintain (marmat samhar) and care (herbichar) : property under the provision of usufruct: (1) The usufructuary shall
maintain (marmat samhar) and take care of (herbichar) the property which he
or she has obtained under the provision of usufruct properly and reasonably as
if it were his or her own property.
output:
According to Section 359(1)... 
Rule: The usufructuary must maintain and take care of the usufruct property properly and reasonably, as if it were their own. 
Application/Conclusion: You are legally required to perform ordinary maintenance and care — attend to repairs and keep the property in reasonable condition just as you would for your own property.

instruction: I took the property by lease from the usufructuary. Do I also have to take care of it?
input:
Section no 359  part (2) : If a person obtains a property under the provision
of usufruct by way of rent, lease or mortgage, the person shall take care of such
property properly and reasonably.
output:
According to Section 359(2)... 
Rule: A person who obtains the property by rent, lease or mortgage under usufruct must take care of it properly and reasonably. 
Application/Conclusion: Yes — as a lessee or mortgagee who obtained the property, you must take reasonable care of the property.

instruction: Who pays for ordinary upkeep and who pays for big repairs after a disaster?
input:
Section no 359  part (3) : The usufructuary shall maintain the property
obtained under the provision of usufruct at his or her cost. Provided that if
it is necessary to maintain such property by spending a substantial amount
in consequence of a disaster, the usufructuary shall obtain the owner’s prior
permission, and the owner shall bear such maintenance expenses.
output:
According to Section 359(3)... 
Rule: Ordinary maintenance costs are borne by the usufructuary. If substantial maintenance is necessary due to a disaster, the usufructuary must obtain the owner’s prior permission and the owner shall bear those substantial maintenance expenses. 
Application/Conclusion: Pay for routine upkeep yourself. For large, disaster-related repairs, get the owner’s prior permission — if obtained, the owner must pay those substantial expenses.

instruction: Can I mortgage the usufruct property to get a loan?
input:

Power to rent, lease or mortgage property under

Section 352.
output:
According to Section 358(1)... 
Rule: The usufructuary may rent, lease or mortgage the usufruct property by executing a deed, subject to any contract limitations referred to. 
Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can mortgage the usufruct property to obtain a loan, but normally this must be done by executing a deed and must comply with any contractual restrictions under the referenced contract.

instruction: I signed a mortgage for a longer term than my usufruct. The owner says it's invalid. Who's right?

output:
According to Section 358(3)... 
Rule: Usufruct property may not be rented, leased or mortgaged for a period exceeding the usufruct's validity. 
Application/Conclusion: The owner is right. A mortgage extending beyond the usufruct term would violate this rule and is not permitted.

instruction: I executed a rental deed but forgot to write 'under usufruct' in it. The other party now claims it's void. Is that true?
input:

According to Section 358(2) and Section 358(3)... 
Rule: A deed for rent/lease/mortgage must mention that the property is under usufruct; failure to comply with these requirements renders the transaction ipso facto void. 
Application/Conclusion: Yes — omitting the fact that the property is under usufruct from the deed contravenes the statutory requirement, and the transaction can be considered void by operation of law.

instruction: A third party I rented to is now damaging the land. Can I stop them? What does the law say about causing damage?
input:
Section no 360 . Prohibition of causing damage to property obtained under the : provision of usufruct: (1) The usufructuary shall not damage, or
cause to be damaged, the property obtained under the provision of usufruct.
output:
According to Section 360(1)... 
Rule: The usufructuary must not damage, or cause the property obtained under usufruct to be damaged. 
Application/Conclusion: You must prevent damage and are prohibited from causing it. If a third party you rented to is damaging the property, you should stop them and take steps to remedy the damage; as usufructuary you remain responsible for preventing damage and may be liable if you caused or permitted it.

instruction: I want to demolish the interior to repurpose it, but the owner objects. What does the law require?

without : consent: A usufructuary shall not be entitled to significantly alter

According to Section 357... 
Rule: Significant alteration or destruction of usufruct property requires the owner’s prior permission; an exception allows alteration/destruction only when necessary for enjoyment and not barred by contract, but then compensation must be paid when returning the property. 
Application/Conclusion: You cannot demolish the interior over the owner’s objection unless you obtain prior permission. If demolition is strictly necessary for reasonable enjoyment and the contract does not forbid it, you may do so but should expect to pay compensation when returning the property. Obtain the owner’s consent or document the necessity and compensation arrangement first.

instruction: Short: Who pays big repair costs after a flood — me or the owner?

Rule: Ordinary maintenance costs fall on the usufructuary; however, substantial maintenance required because of a disaster is borne by the owner if the usufructuary obtains the owner’s prior permission.

instruction: I want to sub-rent the usufruct property and let the sub-tenant enjoy it fully. Is that allowed?

output:
According to Section 358(4)... 
Rule: A person who obtains the property by rent, lease or mortgage under subsection (1) can enjoy it as if they were the usufructuary. 
Application/Conclusion: You may sub-rent and allow the sub-tenant to enjoy the property similarly to a usufructuary, provided the original rent/lease/mortgage complied with legal requirements (deed rules, term not exceeding usufruct, informing the owner, etc.).

instruction: I rented out the property for more than the usufruct term. The tenant refuses to leave after usufruct ends. What does law say?

Rule: Renting for a period beyond the usufruct's validity is not permitted; such transactions executed in contravention of requirements are ipso facto void.

instruction: Can I personally use a servitude that was made for public use?
input: Section no 369  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if there is a provision of servitude for public purpose, such a servitude may also be used for personal purpose.
output:
According to Section 369(2)...
Rule: If a servitude is provided for a public purpose, it may also be used for a personal purpose despite subsection (1).
Application/Conclusion: If the servitude over the land was created for public use, you are permitted to use that servitude for personal purposes as well. The law explicitly allows personal use of a public servitude.

instruction: My father says the servitude was created by operation of law — does that change how it can be used?
input: Section no 369  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, a servitude created by operation of law may be used in accordance with law.
output:
According to Section 369(3)...
Rule: A servitude that is created by operation of law must be used in accordance with the law (i.e., the legal rules governing such statutory or automatic servitudes).
Application/Conclusion: If the servitude on your property arose by operation of law (not by private agreement), its use is governed by the legal provisions applicable to such servitudes. You should follow the legal conditions for that type of servitude rather than private terms.

instruction: If I buy a plot that already has a servitude, can the seller’s transfer stop that servitude?
input: Section no 370 . Servitude not to be adversely affected by transfer of immovable : property: (1) A servitude in a servient immovable property shall continue to exist even if the owner of such a immovable property transfers all or any of such property to another person in any manner. 205
output:
According to Section 370(1)...
Rule: A servitude on a servient immovable property continues to exist despite any transfer of ownership of that property.
Application/Conclusion: Buying the plot does not remove the existing servitude — the servitude remains binding on the new owner. You cannot rely on the transfer alone to extinguish that servitude.

instruction: We partitioned our ancestral land. Do all siblings still have to provide the servitude?
input: Section no 370  part (2) : Even if the servient immovable property is partitioned, each coparcener shall be deemed to have provided such a servitude.
output:
According to Section 370(2)...
Rule: When a servient immovable property is partitioned, each coparcener (co-heir) is deemed to have provided the servitude.
Application/Conclusion: After partition, each sibling (coparcener) is treated as having granted the servitude, so the servitude continues to apply across the partitioned shares.

instruction: Can a servitude ever be extinguished when land is transferred or partitioned?
input: Section no 370  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) or (2), if in transferring or partitioning the servient immovable property, there is a provision of servitude elsewhere in such property and servitude is not thus required to be provided in the immovable property in which a person acquires right by way of such transfer or partition, the servitude shall be deemed to have been extinguished to that extent.
output:
According to Section 370(3)...
Rule: If, upon transfer or partition, a servitude exists elsewhere in the property so that it is no longer necessary to provide the servitude in the specific immovable acquired by a person, the servitude is deemed extinguished to that extent.
Application/Conclusion: A servitude can be extinguished partially when the reallocation of property (transfer/partition) places the servitude elsewhere and it is no longer required for the particular portion someone acquires. You must examine how the partition or transfer redistributed servitudes to see if your portion is freed from that servitude.

instruction: Someone blocked the path we've used for generations to reach the road. Can we still walk through?
input: Section no 371 . To allow enjoyment or use : (1) If any land, despite that a person has right, ownership or possession in it, has been in use since ancient time as a public or community road, cattle exit, pasture land, ditch, cannel, quay, pond, public road, sewage, track road or main road, public shelter, tomb, graveyard, shrine, temple, monastery, dome, mosque, Idgaha, Karbala, Kabristan or church, community school, hospital or similar other public monument or site, the land shall be allowed to be used by the concerned persons accordingly for the particular purpose.
output:
According to Section 371(1)...
Rule: Land that has been used since ancient times for public or community purposes (including public or community roads and similar sites) shall be allowed to be used by concerned persons for that particular purpose even if someone owns or possesses it.
Application/Conclusion: If the path you and the community have used since ancient times qualifies as a public or community road or similar, you and other concerned persons have the right to continue using it despite the owner's objection. Blocking the path would not legally prevent its traditional public use.

instruction: Can the owner build a fence across that old community path?
input: Section no 371  part (2) : The owner or possessor of the servient land shall not cultivate or use, make any structure in, or otherwise own or possess, it in such manner as to adversely affect the provision set forth in sub - section (1).
output:
According to Section 371(2)...
Rule: The owner or possessor of servient land must not cultivate, use, build structures, or otherwise possess the land in a way that adversely affects the ancient public/community uses listed in subsection (1).
Application/Conclusion: The owner cannot lawfully build a fence or structure that obstructs the community path if that would adversely affect the recognized public or community use. You can object and assert the right to continue the public use.

instruction: During a flood, can rescuers enter my neighbour’s house without my consent to save people?
input: Section no 372 . Use of neighbor’s house or land at time of disaster : If, at the time of disaster such as fire, earthquake, volcano and flood, it is not possible to rescue victims of such disaster without entering or using the house or land of a person, the victims may be rescued, or caused to be rescued, by entering the house or land with the consent of the 206 owner of the house or land if the owner is available, and even without consent of the owner of the house or land if the owner is not available for the time being or refuses to give consent.
output:
According to Section 372...
Rule: In disasters where rescue is impossible without entering someone’s house or land, rescuers may enter with the owner’s consent if available, and may enter even without consent if the owner is unavailable or refuses.
Application/Conclusion: During the flood, rescuers can lawfully enter your neighbour’s property to save people even if you refuse consent or are not present, provided entering is necessary to rescue victims.

instruction: Who counts as 'the owner of the house or land' in an emergency?
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “the owner of the house or land” means the person who is using, possessing or controlling the concerned house or land for the time being.
output:
According to Section 372 (Explanation)...
Rule: For the purposes of the disaster-entry rule, 'the owner of the house or land' is the person currently using, possessing, or controlling the house or land.
Application/Conclusion: In an emergency, the person actually occupying or controlling the property at that time is treated as the owner for consent purposes — rescuers should seek that person's consent if available.

instruction: The only footpath to my house was washed away in a landslide. Do I get a new right of way?
input: Section no 373 . Acquisition of servitude of passage : (1) If the passage originally available to have access to and from a house or land is destroyed subsequently due to a disaster, the person who has been using the passage to and from such house or land from the past shall have the servitude of a reasonable passage to the public road.
output:
According to Section 373(1)...
Rule: If the original passage providing access to a house or land is destroyed by a disaster, the person who used that passage historically acquires a servitude of a reasonable passage to the public road.
Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to a reasonable right of way to the public road after the landslide if you were the historical user of the destroyed passage. The law grants you a servitude of reasonable passage to maintain access.

instruction: Can the current owner refuse to let someone use a servitude that's been established under Section 368?
input: Section no 369 . Use of provision of servitude to be allowed : (1) If there is a provision of servitude pursuant to Section 368, the owner of the concerned immovable property shall allow another person to enjoy or use the immovable property in accordance with the provision of servitude.
output:
According to Section 369(1)...
Rule: Where a servitude exists pursuant to Section 368, the owner must allow the other person to enjoy or use the immovable property in accordance with the servitude.
Application/Conclusion: The current owner cannot lawfully refuse to permit use that the servitude allows. They are obligated to allow the servitude-holder to use the property as provided.

instruction: Someone says public servitude can't be used for private benefit. Is that true?
input: Section no 369  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if there is a provision of servitude for public purpose, such a servitude may also be used for personal purpose.
output:
According to Section 369(2)...
Rule: Despite subsection (1), a servitude created for public purposes may also be used for personal purposes.
Application/Conclusion: The claim is incorrect under this law: a public servitude can also be used personally. So personal use of a public servitude is permitted by statute.

instruction: Our field has been a community pasture and a pond for ages. What exactly does the law say we can do there?

According to Section 371(1)...
Rule: Land used since ancient times for public or community purposes listed (including pasture land and pond) must be allowed to be used by concerned persons for those specific purposes, regardless of private ownership.
Application/Conclusion: Your community may continue to use the field as pasture or pond for its traditional public purpose. Private ownership does not extinguish the community’s right to use it for those established purposes.

instruction: If after partition one plot already carries the servitude so another plot need not, does that mean the servitude is gone for the other plot?

output:
According to Section 370(3)...
Rule: Where, because of transfer or partition, a servitude is provided elsewhere and is not required for a particular immovable that someone acquires, the servitude is deemed extinguished to that extent.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if partitioning results in the servitude being satisfied elsewhere so it is unnecessary for your specific acquired plot, the servitude is extinguished for your plot to that extent. You must check the partition’s arrangement to determine whether the servitude still applies to your parcel.

instruction: I'm a rescuer and the house owner is refusing to let us in during an earthquake. Can we still enter?

Use of neighbor’s house or land at time of disaster : If, at the time of disaster such as fire, earthquake, volcano and flood, it is not possible to rescue victims of such disaster without entering or using the house or land of a person, the victims may be rescued, or caused to be rescued, by entering the house or land with the consent of the 206 owner of the house or land if the owner is available, and even without consent of the owner of the house or land if the owner is not available for the time being or refuses to give consent.
output:
According to Section 372...
Rule: Rescuers may enter with the owner's consent if available, and may enter even without consent if the owner is unavailable or actively refuses, when necessary to rescue disaster victims.
Application/Conclusion: As a rescuer during the earthquake, you may lawfully enter the house to save victims even if the owner refuses, because the law permits entry without consent in such emergency rescue situations.

instruction: I used a small trail for 30 years but the flood washed it away last week. How do I get back access? (Short answer.)
input: Section no 373 . output:
According to Section 373(1)...
Rule: When a previously used passage is destroyed by disaster, the historical user acquires a servitude of a reasonable passage to the public road.
Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to a reasonable right of way to the public road to restore access — the law grants you that servitude after the flood.

instruction: Could an owner stop people using an ancient shrine area on his land because he now owns it?
input: Section no 371 . To allow enjoyment or use : (1) If any land, despite that a person has right, ownership or possession in it, has been in use since ancient time as a public or community road, cattle exit, pasture land, ditch, cannel, quay, pond, public road, sewage, track road or main road, public shelter, tomb, graveyard, shrine, temple, monastery, dome, mosque, Idgaha, Karbala, Kabristan or church, community school, hospital or similar other public monument or site, the land shall be allowed to be used by the concerned persons accordingly for the particular purpose.
output:
According to Section 371(1)...
Rule: Land used since ancient times for public or community purposes (including shrines and similar sites) must be allowed to be used by concerned persons for that purpose despite private ownership.
Application/Conclusion: The owner cannot lawfully stop people from using the area as an ancient shrine if it falls within the listed public/community uses. The community retains the right to use it for that purpose.

instruction: Can I sublet my rented house? If I do, who does the sub-tenant pay rent to?
input: part (3) : A sub-tenant who rents the house pursuant to sub section (1) shall pay the rent of the house or its portion to the tenant who has so sublet.
output:
According to Section 395(3):
Rule: A sub-tenant who rents the house pursuant to subsection (1) must pay the rent (or its portion) to the tenant who sublet the premises.
Application/Conclusion: If you sublet your rented house lawfully under the cited subsection, any sub-tenant's rent obligation is toward you (the tenant who sublet), not directly to the original house-owner.

instruction: If I let someone into my flat as a sub-tenant, are they bound by the same rules I have to follow under the tenancy chapter?
input: Section no 395  part (4) : The sub-tenant who rents the house pursuant to sub section (1) shall, while dwelling in the rented house, abide by all such terms and provisions as required to be abided by the tenant pursuant to this Chapter.
output:
According to Section 395(4):
Rule: A sub-tenant must abide by all the terms and provisions the tenant is required to follow under this Chapter while dwelling in the rented house.
Application/Conclusion: Your sub-tenant is legally bound to follow the same obligations you have under the tenancy chapter (for example use, maintenance, conduct). You can rely on these rules to enforce standards against the sub-tenant.

instruction: My sub-tenant is making life miserable for neighbors and not keeping the place clean. Can I evict them immediately?
input: Section no 395  part (5) : If the sub-tenant who rents the house pursuant to sub section (1) fails to act in accordance with the terms while dwelling in the rented house or fails to maintain sanitation in, protect or safeguard, the house or carries out any act such as causing harassment, pain or unrest to the other dwellers of the house or neighbors, the tenant may evict the sub-tenant from the house at any time.
output:

Rule: If a sub-tenant fails to comply with terms, fails to maintain sanitation or safeguard the house, or causes harassment/unrest to other dwellers or neighbors, the tenant may evict the sub-tenant at any time.

instruction: Can I demolish part of the rented house or add a new structure without asking the owner in writing?

Prohibition of altering structure without consent : (1) Except as otherwise provided in the agreement, the tenant shall not demolish, remove or disorder any structure of, or add any structure to, the rented house or otherwise alter it without the house owner’s consent in writing. 217
output:

Rule: Except where the agreement allows otherwise, a tenant may not demolish, remove, disorder, add to, or otherwise alter the rented house without the house-owner's written consent.

instruction: If I alter the building without permission and the owner suffers loss, can they claim money from me?
input: Section no 396  part (2) : If the tenant does any act in contravention of sub section (1) and thereby causes any loss to the house-owner, the house-owner shall be entitled to recover compensation for the loss caused to him or her from the tenant.

instruction: Can I take out insurance on the land I hold as a usufructuary?

instruction: Who pays taxes on property given in usufruct — me or the owner?

Section no 366  part (2) : In the event of the extinguishment of the provision of usufruct pursuant to sub-section (1), the property given to any person in usufruct shall ipso facto devolve on the owner except in the circumstance set forth in clause (f) or (g).
output: According to Section 366(2)(g) and Section 366(2). Rule: Total loss of the property obtained in usufruct is a ground for extinguishment; the general rule of automatic devolution to the owner does not apply where clause (g) is the circumstance. Application/Conclusion: Because the property is totally lost, the usufruct is extinguished, but there is nothing to devolve back to the owner; clause (g) is an express exception to the ipso facto reversion rule.

instruction: If a usufruct is created to last until a person reaches a certain age, but that person dies before reaching that age, does the usufruct still continue?
input: Section no 366  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) or (2), if a property is given in usufruct on the condition that it shall remain valid until any person attains a certain age, the provision of usufruct shall remain valid until the date on which the person attains that age even if the person dies before the date of attainment of such age, as if he or she were surviving.
output: According to Section 366(3). Rule: If usufruct is conditioned to remain valid until a person attains a certain age, it continues until that date even if the named person dies before attaining it — the usufruct is treated as if the person survived. Application/Conclusion: If the usufruct was set to last until the beneficiary turns, say, 25, it remains in effect until that 25th birthday even if the beneficiary dies beforehand.

instruction: I just discovered someone acted under this Chapter to my detriment. How long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 367 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit 203 within six months after the date of knowledge of the commission of such an act or action. 204 Chapter-8 Provisions Relating to Servitudes
output: According to Section 367. Rule: A person aggrieved by any act or action under this Chapter may file a lawsuit within six months from the date they became aware of the act or action. Application/Conclusion: You have six months from the date you learned of the wrongful act under this Chapter to bring a suit; if you wait longer you risk losing the right to sue under this limitation.

instruction: My neighbor uses part of my immovable property by arrangement — does that create a servitude?
input: Section no 368 . Servitude to be deemed : (1) If there is a provision of enjoyment or use by the owner of another property of any immovable property or any part thereof in which another person has right, ownership or possession pursuant to this Chapter, provision of servitude shall be deemed to have been created.
output: According to Section 368(1). Rule: Where the owner of one property has provision of enjoyment or use of immovable property (or part of it) in which another person has rights, ownership, or possession under this Chapter, a servitude is deemed to be created. Application/Conclusion: If your neighbor (owner of another property) has been granted use or enjoyment of part of your immovable property as described, that factual arrangement amounts to a servitude under the law.

instruction: How is a servitude established — by contract or by old custom?
input: Section no 368  part (2) : A servitude shall be in existence in accordance with the contract, nature of the place where the immovable property is situated, custom or practice exercised since ancient time therein.
output: According to Section 368(2). Rule: A servitude may exist based on contract, the nature of the location, or longstanding custom/practice. Application/Conclusion: Servitudes can arise through express agreement, because the site's nature requires it, or through ancient/local custom — so you should check any contract, the property's situation, and historical practice to determine if a servitude exists.

instruction: Does the law allow returning a usufruct even if earlier sections (363, 364) seem to restrict it?
input: . Power to return property by usufructuary : Notwithstanding anything contained in Sections 363 and 364, if the usufructuary does not wish to enjoy the property obtained under the provision of usufruct, the usufructuary may return such a property to the owner at any time, by giving a notice of at least forty-five days.
output: According to Section 365 (Power to return property by usufructuary). Rule: The usufructuary may return the property at any time by giving at least 45 days' notice, notwithstanding any contrary provisions in Sections 363 and 364. Application/Conclusion: Even if Sections 363 or 364 appear to limit return, Section 365 expressly permits you to return the usufruct with 45 days' notice — the return right overrides conflicting provisions.

instruction: Which section in this chapter sets out the statute of limitation for actions related to this Chapter?
input: Section no 367 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit 203 within six months after the date of knowledge of the commission of such an act or action. 204 Chapter-8 Provisions Relating to Servitudes
output: According to Section 367. Rule: Section 367 provides the statute of limitation: an aggrieved person must sue within six months from knowledge of the act. Application/Conclusion: If you need to know where the limitation is set, it is in Section 367 and the time limit is six months from when you learned of the act.

instruction: If a usufruct is extinguished under subsection (1) of Section 366, what generally happens to the property?
input: Section no 366  part (2) : In the event of the extinguishment of the provision of usufruct pursuant to sub-section (1), the property given to any person in usufruct shall ipso facto devolve on the owner except in the circumstance set forth in clause (f) or (g).
output: According to Section 366(2). Rule: When usufruct is extinguished under subsection (1), the property given in usufruct ipso facto devolves to the owner, except where clauses (f) or (g) apply. Application/Conclusion: Generally the property returns automatically to the owner when the usufruct ends, but you must check whether clause (f) (transfer to usufructuary by law) or (g) (total loss) changes that outcome.

instruction: If the usufruct validity period simply expires under Section 363, is that a recognized ground for extinguishment?
input: Section no 366  clause (a) : In the event of expiration of the validity period of usufruct pursuant to Section 363, Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “expiration of the validity period” means:
output: According to Section 366(a). Rule: Expiration of the usufruct's validity period pursuant to Section 363 is a ground for extinguishment of the usufruct. Application/Conclusion: If the usufruct reaches the end of the period set under Section 363, it is extinguished by that expiration.

instruction: I want to challenge an act taken under this Chapter — what immediate procedural time limit should I be aware of?
input: Section no 367 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit 203 within six months after the date of knowledge of the commission of such an act or action. 204 Chapter-8 Provisions Relating to Servitudes
output: According to Section 367. Rule: The time limit to bring a lawsuit for acts under this Chapter is six months from knowledge of the act. Application/Conclusion: Prompt action is required — you must file within six months of discovering the act, otherwise you may be barred by the statute of limitation.

instruction: Can I pay my rent by cheque?
input: part (3) : The rent may be paid by way of cheque or cash pursuant to sub-section (2).
output: According to Section 391(3), the rent may be paid by way of cheque or cash pursuant to sub-section (2). Rule: The law permits payment of rent either by cheque or cash. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you are allowed to pay your rent by cheque (as an alternative to cash) under this provision.

instruction: If my landlord accepts cash, do I get any proof?
input: Section no 391  part (4) : If the owner receives the rent in cash pursuant to this Section, he or she shall give a receipt thereof to the tenant.
output: According to Section 391(4), if the owner receives the rent in cash pursuant to this Section, he or she shall give a receipt thereof to the tenant. Rule: When rent is received in cash, the landlord must provide a receipt. Application/Conclusion: If your landlord took cash rent and did not give a receipt, you can request the receipt — the landlord is legally obliged to provide it.

instruction: Who has to pay taxes on the rented house — tenant or owner?
input: Section no 392 . Obligation to pay tax and other charge : (1) Except as otherwise set forth in the agreement, it shall be the obligation of the house owner to pay the tax and other charge leviable by law in relation to the house rented.
output: According to Section 392(1), except as otherwise set forth in the agreement, it shall be the obligation of the house owner to pay the tax and other charge leviable by law in relation to the house rented. Rule: By default the house owner must pay taxes/charges related to the rented house, unless the rental agreement states otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Unless your lease says the tenant will pay, the owner is responsible for those taxes and charges.

instruction: My landlord didn't pay the property tax and I paid it to avoid penalty — can I deduct that from rent?
input:
Section no 392  part (2) : If it is the obligation of the land owner to pay tax or charge pursuant to sub-section (1) and the house owner fails to pay the tax or charge in time, the tenant may pay such tax or charge.
 Section no 392  part (3) : If the tenant pays the tax or charge pursuant to sub section (2), he or she shall be entitled to deduct such an amount from the rent payable to the house owner.
output: According to Section 392(2)-(3), if it is the obligation of the land owner to pay tax or charge pursuant to sub-section (1) and the house owner fails to pay the tax or charge in time, the tenant may pay such tax or charge; and if the tenant pays the tax or charge pursuant to sub section (2), he or she shall be entitled to deduct such an amount from the rent payable to the house owner. Rule: When the owner is obliged to pay but fails, the tenant can pay and then deduct that amount from rent. Application/Conclusion: You may deduct the tax amount you paid from future rent, since the owner failed to pay as required.

instruction: I want to run a small shop in the rented house. Do I need insurance? What counts as 'business purpose'?
input: Section no 393 . Insurance of house to be procured : (1) A tenant who rents a house for industrial or business purpose shall procure the insurance of the house for its security. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “industrial or business purpose” means the operation of any industry or carrying on a business or trade by having a departmental store or one or more than one shop.
output: According to Section 393(1), a tenant who rents a house for industrial or business purpose shall procure the insurance of the house for its security; and the Explanation defines “industrial or business purpose” as operation of any industry or carrying on business or trade by having a departmental store or one or more than one shop. Rule: Tenants using the premises for business/industrial activities must obtain insurance; department stores and shops fall within that meaning. Application/Conclusion: Since you plan to run a shop (which counts as a business purpose), you are obliged to procure insurance for the rented house.

instruction: A fire damaged the premises. Landlord says I'm responsible because I didn't insure — is that right?
input: Section no 393  part (2) : If the person obliged to procure insurance pursuant to sub-section (1) fails to procure insurance of the house and the house 215 is damaged by such cause as disaster, unrest, riot or fire, the tenant shall be liable for such damage.
output: According to Section 393(2), if the person obliged to procure insurance pursuant to sub-section (1) fails to procure insurance of the house and the house 215 is damaged by such cause as disaster, unrest, riot or fire, the tenant shall be liable for such damage. Rule: A tenant required to insure (per 393(1)) who fails to obtain insurance will be liable for damage caused by disaster, unrest, riot, or fire. Application/Conclusion: If you were obliged to insure (because you were renting for business/industrial use) and you did not procure insurance, you can be held liable for the fire damage.

instruction: As a residential tenant, am I supposed to do repairs myself?
input: Section no 394 . Repair and maintenance of house rented : (1) Except as otherwise set forth in the agreement, the tenant shall be obliged to repair and maintain the rented house, as required.
output: According to Section 394(1), except as otherwise set forth in the agreement, the tenant shall be obliged to repair and maintain the rented house, as required. Rule: By default the tenant is responsible for repair and maintenance unless the rental agreement says otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Unless your lease assigns repair duties to the owner, you are generally obliged to carry out necessary repairs and maintenance.

instruction: My lease says the owner will do repairs. What must I do before the owner fixes things?
input: Section no 394  part (2) : If the agreement provides that the house owner is obliged to repair and maintain the rented house and it is necessary to carry out any repair and maintenance of the house, the tenant shall give a notice in writing to the house owner in time.
output: According to Section 394(2), if the agreement provides that the house owner is obliged to repair and maintain the rented house and it is necessary to carry out any repair and maintenance of the house, the tenant shall give a notice in writing to the house owner in time. Rule: When the owner is contractually responsible, the tenant must provide timely written notice before repairs are carried out. Application/Conclusion: You should give the landlord a written notice promptly describing the needed repairs so the owner can perform them.

instruction: Landlord ignored my repair notice. Can I fix it and take the cost off rent?
input:
Section no 394  part (3) : If the land-owner fails to repair and maintain the rented house despite the notice given pursuant to sub-section (2), the tenant may repair and maintain such a house.
 Section no 394  part (4) : The tenant shall be entitled to deduct the billed amount of expenses incurred in the repair and maintenance of the house carried out pursuant to sub-section (3) from the rent payable to the house owner.
output: According to Section 394(3)-(4), if the land-owner fails to repair and maintain the rented house despite the notice given pursuant to sub-section (2), the tenant may repair and maintain such a house; and the tenant shall be entitled to deduct the billed amount of expenses incurred in the repair and maintenance of the house carried out pursuant to sub-section (3) from the rent payable to the house owner. Rule: After proper written notice and landlord's failure to act, a tenant may repair and then deduct the billed repair costs from rent. Application/Conclusion: If you gave written notice and the owner did not act, you may arrange repairs and deduct the reasonable billed expenses from rent.

instruction: Do I need to estimate repair costs before I hire someone?
input: Section no 394  part (5) : Except as otherwise agreed upon between the house owner and the tenant in respect of the repair and maintenance of the house, the tenant shall, prior to carrying out repair and maintenance under sub-section (4), prepare a cost estimate of the repair and maintenance and give its written information to the house owner in advance of fifteen days.
output: According to Section 394(5), except as otherwise agreed upon between the house owner and the tenant in respect of the repair and maintenance of the house, the tenant shall, prior to carrying out repair and maintenance under sub-section (4), prepare a cost estimate of the repair and maintenance and give its written information to the house owner in advance of fifteen days. Rule: Before carrying out repairs and deducting costs, the tenant must prepare a cost estimate and inform the owner in writing at least 15 days in advance (unless otherwise agreed). Application/Conclusion: You should produce a written cost estimate and notify the landlord 15 days before commencing repairs if you plan to later deduct the expenses from rent.

instruction: Can I sublet my flat to someone else?
input: Section no 395 . Subletting house rented to other person : (1) If the agreement entered into with the house owner provides that the tenant may sublet the whole or any portion of the house rented by him or her to 216 another person, the tenant may, subject to the agreement, sublet the whole or any portion of such a house to another person.
output: According to Section 395(1), if the agreement entered into with the house owner provides that the tenant may sublet the whole or any portion of the house rented by him or her to 216 another person, the tenant may, subject to the agreement, sublet the whole or any portion of such a house to another person. Rule: Subletting is permitted only if the rental agreement allows it; subject to that agreement, the tenant may sublet. Application/Conclusion: You can sublet only if your lease expressly permits subletting; otherwise you must obtain the owner's consent.

instruction: I already sublet a room — how soon must I tell the landlord the sub-tenant's name and address?
input: Section no 395  part (2) : If the tenant sublets the whole or any portion of the house rented to another person pursuant to sub-section (1), the tenant shall, no later than fifteen days, give information in writing indicating the name and address of the sub-tenant to the house owner.
output: According to Section 395(2), if the tenant sublets the whole or any portion of the house rented to another person pursuant to sub-section (1), the tenant shall, no later than fifteen days, give information in writing indicating the name and address of the sub-tenant to the house owner. Rule: The tenant must provide written notice of the sub-tenant's name and address to the owner within 15 days. Application/Conclusion: Since you sublet, you must inform the landlord in writing of the sub-tenant's name and address within 15 days.

instruction: Under which section does the law say who pays taxes on the house?
input: Section no 392 . Obligation to pay tax and other charge : (1) Except as otherwise set forth in the agreement, it shall be the obligation of the house owner to pay the tax and other charge leviable by law in relation to the house rented.
output: According to Section 392(1), except as otherwise set forth in the agreement, it shall be the obligation of the house owner to pay the tax and other charge leviable by law in relation to the house rented. Rule: Section 392 sets out the obligation to pay taxes and other charges. Application/Conclusion: The duty for taxes on the rented house is defined in Section 392 — generally the owner must pay unless the agreement says otherwise.
