instruction: My landlord says I can't deduct repair bills from rent even after I fixed the toilet because I didn't give him notice 15 days before — is that true?
input: Section no 394  part (5) : Except as otherwise agreed upon between the house owner and the tenant in respect of the repair and maintenance of the house, the tenant shall, prior to carrying out repair and maintenance under sub-section (4), prepare a cost estimate of the repair and maintenance and give its written information to the house owner in advance of fifteen days.
output: According to Section 394(5), except as otherwise agreed upon between the house owner and the tenant in respect of the repair and maintenance of the house, the tenant shall, prior to carrying out repair and maintenance under sub-section (4), prepare a cost estimate of the repair and maintenance and give its written information to the house owner in advance of fifteen days. Rule: The tenant must provide a written cost estimate and notify the owner 15 days beforehand unless the parties agreed differently. Application/Conclusion: If you did not provide the 15-day written cost estimate and there was no other agreement allowing shorter notice, the landlord may have grounds to dispute deduction of those repair costs.

instruction: I sublet one room without asking. The landlord demands the subtenant's details now — how long do I have to provide them?
input: Section no 395  part (2) : If the tenant sublets the whole or any portion of the house rented to another person pursuant to sub-section (1), the tenant shall, no later than fifteen days, give information in writing indicating the name and address of the sub-tenant to the house owner.
output: According to Section 395(2), the tenant shall, no later than fifteen days, give information in writing indicating the name and address of the sub-tenant to the house owner. Rule: The law requires written notice of sub-tenant details within 15 days of subletting. Application/Conclusion: You must provide the landlord with the subtenant's name and address in writing within 15 days — do so immediately if that period is still running or already passed (and be prepared to explain the delay).

instruction: I rented a shop but didn't buy insurance. A riot caused damage. Can the owner hold me responsible?
input: Section no 393  part (2) : If the person obliged to procure insurance pursuant to sub-section (1) fails to procure insurance of the house and the house 215 is damaged by such cause as disaster, unrest, riot or fire, the tenant shall be liable for such damage.
output: According to Section 393(2), if the person obliged to procure insurance pursuant to sub-section (1) fails to procure insurance of the house and the house 215 is damaged by such cause as disaster, unrest, riot or fire, the tenant shall be liable for such damage. Rule: A tenant who was required to insure but did not will be liable for damage caused by disasters, unrest, riot, or fire. Application/Conclusion: Because you rented a shop (business purpose) and did not procure the required insurance, you can be held liable for riot damage under this section.

instruction: My landlord took cash rent and refuses to give a receipt — how do I state my right simply?
input: Section no 391  part (4) : If the owner receives the rent in cash pursuant to this Section, he or she shall give a receipt thereof to the tenant.
output: According to Section 391(4), if the owner receives the rent in cash pursuant to this Section, he or she shall give a receipt thereof to the tenant. Rule: The owner is legally required to provide a receipt for cash rent. Application/Conclusion: You can tell your landlord: 'By law (Section 391(4)) you must give me a receipt for the cash rent you accepted.'

instruction: Can I force my neighbor to provide a passage through their land so my buffalo can reach my field?
input:
. Requirement to allow passage or exit for farming : (1)
If a person does not have a passage or exit for people or livestock to have access
to and from his or her farm land and needs such passage or exit, the owner of
the concerned land shall provide the facility of passage or exit to such a person.
Provided that no person shall be compelled to provide such a passage or exit
through the house and compound land.
output:
According to Section 380(1):
Rule: If someone lacks a passage or exit for people or livestock to access their farmland and needs it, the owner of the concerned land must provide such a passage or exit. However, no one can be compelled to give a passage through their house and compound land.
Application/Conclusion: You can ask your neighbor to provide a passage across their land for your buffalo if you genuinely lack access, and legally they are required to provide it. But you cannot force them to let the passage go through their house or the compound immediately surrounding their house.

instruction: If I use the passage and step on the crops, am I liable?
input:
Section no 380  part (2) : A person who uses the passage or exit pursuant to
sub section (1) shall so use it that no loss or damage is caused to the 209 crops
or other property of the person providing such a passage or exit.
output:
According to Section 380(2):
Rule: A person using the passage granted under subsection (1) must use it in a way that causes no loss or damage to the crops or other property of the landowner providing the passage.
Application/Conclusion: If you damage crops while using the passage, you are acting contrary to Section 380(2) and therefore liable for the loss; you must take care to avoid causing damage.

instruction: What happens if damage is caused while someone uses my land for passage under these rules?
input:
Section no 381 . Compensation to be paid : If, in using a house or land
belonging to another person, any kind of loss or damage is caused to any one
for the purposes set forth in Sections 372, 373, 375, 377 and 380, the person
using the passage or exit shall pay a reasonable compensation to the concerned
house or landowner.
output:
According to Section 381:
Rule: If using another's house or land for the purposes set out (including Section 380) causes any loss or damage, the person using the passage or exit must pay reasonable compensation to the owner of the house or land.
Application/Conclusion: If someone uses your land as a passage as permitted by Section 380 and causes damage, that user must pay you reasonable compensation for the loss.

instruction: I just learned today that someone used my land without paying for damages last year. How long do I have to sue?
input:
Section no 382 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any
act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit within
six months after the date of knowledge of such an act or action. 210 Chapter-9
Provisions Relating to House Rent
output:
According to Section 382:
Rule: A person aggrieved by any act or action under this Chapter must bring a lawsuit within six months from the date they became aware of the act or action.
Application/Conclusion: Since you learned about the use and alleged damage today, you have six months from today to file a lawsuit related to that act under this Chapter.

instruction: If I lend my house to someone and take rent, am I considered a landlord under the law?
input:
Section no 383 . House deemed to be rented : If a person who has right,
possession or ownership in a house lends, for a rent, the house to another person
to use it for a certain period of time, the person shall be deemed to rent the
house. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “house” means
any house, storey, unit or room of the house, or land or cartilage occupied by
such a house.
output:
According to Section 383:
Rule: If someone who has right, possession or ownership of a house lends it to another for rent for a certain period, that person is deemed to have rented the house (i.e., is a landlord for purposes of this Chapter).
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you lend your house to another for rent for a period, you are legally treated as renting the house under Section 383 and subject to the Chapter's rules.

instruction: Can a landlord rent out a house that's unsafe for living?
input:
Section no 384 .
Prohibition of renting unsafe house : (1) No person
shall rent or take on rent a house which is not safe for human habitation from
111
health and security perspectives.
output:
According to Section 384(1):
Rule: No person shall rent or take on rent a house that is unsafe for human habitation from health and security perspectives.
Application/Conclusion: A landlord cannot lawfully rent out a house that is unsafe to live in, and a tenant should not take such a house on rent. The rental would be prohibited under Section 384(1).

instruction: I want to use a rented building as a cold storage. Are different standards applied?
input:
Section no 384  part (2) : The quality standards of a house for non-residential
purpose such as a warehouse, livestock farming, storage and cold storage shall
be as specified in the house rent agreement.
output:
According to Section 384(2):
Rule: Quality standards for non-residential uses (like warehouse, livestock farming, storage, cold storage) are to be specified in the house rent agreement.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — for cold storage or other non-residential uses, the specific quality standards must be set out in the rent agreement; they are not automatically the same as residential standards.

instruction: What's the maximum period for a normal house rent under this law?
input:
Section no 385 . Period of house rent : (1) The period of house rent shall be
as set forth in the agreement, not exceeding five years. Provided that if a house
is rented for a commercial purpose, it shall be as set forth in the agreement.
output:
According to Section 385(1):
Rule: The rent period is as set in the agreement but shall not exceed five years. For commercial purposes, the period is as set in the agreement (no five-year cap mentioned for commercial use).
Application/Conclusion: For ordinary (non-commercial) house rents, the agreement can set the period but it cannot exceed five years. If the house is rented for commercial purposes, the agreement controls the period without that five-year limit stated here.

instruction: My lease expired. Can we extend it informally or does it require a new agreement?
input:
Section no 385  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), after the expiration of the period of house rent, the period may be extended
at times with the consent of the house owner and the tenant. 211
output:
According to Section 385(2):
Rule: After the rent period expires, it may be extended with the consent of both the house owner and the tenant.
Application/Conclusion: The lease can be extended after expiry, but it requires mutual consent between you and the owner. An extension should be agreed to by both parties (preferably documented).

instruction: Do I have to sign a written agreement when I rent a house?
input:
Section no 386 . Agreement to be concluded while renting : (1) While
renting a house, its owner shall enter into an agreement in writing with the
tenant, setting out the following matters:
output:
According to Section 386(1):
Rule: When renting a house, the owner must enter into a written agreement with the tenant that sets out specified matters.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the law requires the owner to conclude a written tenancy agreement with the tenant when renting a house.

instruction: What specific items must a written rent agreement include?
input:
Section no 386  clause (a) : Full name and address of the owner and of the
tenant, their citizenship number, and passport or identification certificate, in
the case of a foreigner,
 Section no 386  clause (b) : Place and plot number of the land where the
house is located,
 Section no 386  clause (c) : Purpose for rent,
 Section no 386  clause (d) : Date of commencement of rent,
 Section no 386  clause (e) : Validity period of rent,
 Section no 386  clause (f) : Monthly rent,
 Section no 386  clause (g) : Time and mode of payment of rent,
 Section no 386  clause (h) : Liability to pay tariffs of electricity, water supply,
telephone etc. used in the house,
 Section no 386  clause (i) : Matter on payment of house rent tax,
 Section no 386
output:
According to Section 386 (clauses a–i):
Rule: The written rent agreement must set out (a) full names/addresses and ID details, (b) place and plot number, (c) purpose of rent, (d) commencement date, (e) validity period, (f) monthly rent, (g) time and mode of payment, (h) liability for utility tariffs, and (i) matters concerning payment of house rent tax.
Application/Conclusion: Your written agreement should include all of these items (a–i). If any are missing, the agreement would not fully comply with the statutory requirements set out in Section 386.

instruction: What exactly does the law mean by 'house' here?
input:
Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “house” means
any house, storey, unit or room of the house, or land or cartilage occupied by
such a house.
output:
According to Section 383 (Explanation):
Rule: For this Chapter, 'house' includes any house, storey, unit or room of a house, or the land or cartilage occupied by such a house.
Application/Conclusion: 'House' is a broad term here — it covers whole houses, individual storeys or units/rooms, and the land occupied by them. The Chapter's rules apply to all those forms.

instruction: Can the owner include a clause that I must pay electricity and water bills in the agreement?
input:
Section no 386  clause (h) : Liability to pay tariffs of electricity, water supply,
telephone etc. used in the house,
output:
According to Section 386(h):
Rule: The rental agreement should specify the liability to pay tariffs for electricity, water supply, telephone, etc. used in the house.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the agreement may and should state who is liable for paying utilities. If the agreement includes such a clause assigning the liability to you, that is a recognized item under Section 386(h).

instruction: Is payment of house rent tax something that can be included in the lease terms?
input: Section no 386  clause (i) : Matter on payment of house rent tax,
output:
According to Section 386(i):
Rule: The agreement should include matters concerning payment of house rent tax.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the lease can and should include provisions about who pays house rent tax; it is one of the required matters in the written agreement.

instruction: What must be written about rent amount and how I pay it?
input:
Section no 386  clause (f) : Monthly rent,
 Section no 386  clause (g) : Time and mode of payment of rent,
output:
According to Section 386(f) and (g):
Rule: The agreement must state the monthly rent amount and the time and mode of payment.
Application/Conclusion: Your lease should clearly state the monthly rent figure and exactly when and how it is to be paid (e.g., monthly bank transfer, cash on a certain date), as required by the law.

instruction: Who specifically needs to be identified in the rent agreement — do I need to put citizenship numbers?
input:
Section no 386  clause (a) : Full name and address of the owner and of the
tenant, their citizenship number, and passport or identification certificate, in
the case of a foreigner,
output:
According to Section 386(a):
Rule: The agreement must include full name and address of owner and tenant, their citizenship number, and passport/identification for a foreigner.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — you should include both parties' full names and addresses and citizenship numbers. If the tenant is a foreigner, include passport or other identification details as required.

instruction: My neighbor says I must let my goats pass through his compound to get to my field. Can he force me to allow it?
input:
. Requirement to allow passage or exit for farming : (1)
If a person does not have a passage or exit for people or livestock to have access
to and from his or her farm land and needs such passage or exit, the owner of
the concerned land shall provide the facility of passage or exit to such a person.
Provided that no person shall be compelled to provide such a passage or exit
through the house and compound land.
output:
According to Section 380(1):
Rule: A landowner must provide a passage if another person needs access for people or livestock to reach their farmland, but no one can be forced to provide passage through their house and compound land.
Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor cannot force you to allow passage through your house or compound. If the required passage can be provided elsewhere on your land, you may be required to allow it; but not through living areas or the compound immediately around the house.

instruction: Can I sublet my rented house to someone else without asking the owner?
input:
Section no 386  clause (l) : Matter as to whether the rented house can be
sublet to another, and
output: According to Section 386 clause (l), Rule: Whether the rented house can be sublet to another person is a matter to be stated in the rental agreement. Application/Conclusion: You may sublet only if the agreement permits subletting (or you obtain the owner's consent). If the agreement expressly forbids subletting, you cannot sublet; check the agreement language.

instruction: My landlord says he'll evict me next week. What does the law say about eviction terms?
input:
Section no 386  clause (k) : Matter on leaving the rented house and eviction
of the tenant from it,
output: According to Section 386 clause (k), Rule: Matters concerning leaving the rented house and eviction of the tenant must be addressed in the rental agreement. Application/Conclusion: Eviction procedures, notice periods and conditions should be those specified in your agreement; if the agreement is silent, you should request the landlord to follow any agreed or statutory procedure and seek legal advice if wrongful eviction is threatened.

instruction: If the rented house is to be insured, who decides and how should it be handled?
input:
clause (j) : If the rented house is to be insured, matter
relating thereto,
output: According to Section 386 clause (j), Rule: Insurance-related matters for the rented house should be specified as part of the rental agreement. Application/Conclusion: Responsibility for insuring the property, who pays the premium, and what is covered should be written into the agreement; absent such provision, the parties should agree in writing to avoid disputes.

instruction: Do I need a written rent agreement if my monthly rent is Rs. 15,000?
input:
Section no 386  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), it is not necessary to enter into an agreement in writing with the tenant if
the monthly house rent does not exceed twenty thousand rupees.
output: According to Section 386 part (2), Rule: A written agreement is not necessary where the monthly house rent does not exceed twenty thousand rupees. Application/Conclusion: Because your rent is Rs. 15,000 (below Rs. 20,000), a written agreement is not legally required — although making one is still advisable for clarity and proof of terms.

instruction: Does the tenant's photograph have to be attached to the rent agreement?
input:
Section no 386  part (3) : The tenant’s photograph shall also be aﬀixed to
the agreement referred to in sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 386 part (3), Rule: The tenant's photograph must be affixed to the agreement referred to in sub-section (1). Application/Conclusion: If you enter into an agreement under sub-section (1), ensure your photograph is attached to that agreement to comply with the statute.

instruction: What witness signatures and copies are required when signing a rental agreement?
input:
Section no 386  part (4) : The agreement referred to in sub-section (1) shall
also be signed by at least two witnesses of each side, namely the house owner
and the tenant, and a copy thereof shall be retained each by the owner and the
tenant.
output: According to Section 386 part (4), Rule: The agreement must be signed by at least two witnesses for each side (owner and tenant), and each side shall retain a copy. Application/Conclusion: When you sign the agreement, obtain signatures of two witnesses for both parties and ensure both you and the owner keep a copy for your records.

instruction: When is a rental agreement legally considered to be entered into between owner and tenant?
input:
Section no 386  part (5) : After the completion of the procedures referred to
in sub-section (4), an agreement shall be deemed to be entered into between the
house owner and the tenant.
output: According to Section 386 part (5), Rule: Once the procedures in sub-section (4) (e.g., witness signatures and exchange of copies) are completed, the agreement is deemed entered into. Application/Conclusion: After you and the owner complete those formalities, the agreement is legally effective even if other actions remain.

instruction: Does the landlord need to tell me about cracks or other structural faults before I rent?
input:
Section no 387 . Details of house to be provided : In renting a house,
the owner shall, at the time of entering into agreement, disclose the weakness
or fault, if any, in the structure of the house to the tenant.
output: According to Section 387, Rule: The owner must disclose any structural weakness or fault in the house when entering into the agreement. Application/Conclusion: If the landlord knew of cracks or faults and did not disclose them at the time of agreement, you may have grounds to complain, seek repair, negotiation of terms, or other legal remedy depending on the impact of the defect.

instruction: The house is furnished. What must the owner do about the furniture list before rent starts?
input:
Section no 388 . Preparation of description of goods or chattels : (1)
The house owner shall, prior to renting his or her house, prepare a description
of the goods or chattels in the house to be rented.
output: According to Section 388(1), Rule: The owner must prepare a description of the goods or chattels in the house prior to renting. Application/Conclusion: Ask the owner for the written inventory of furniture/chattels before taking possession and ensure it is attached to the agreement to avoid later disputes over condition or missing items.

instruction: If I use the furniture listed in the inventory, do I need to acknowledge it somehow?
input:
Section no 388  part (2) : If the tenant is to use the goods or chattels set
forth in the description prepared pursuant to sub-section (1), he or she shall
receive such goods or chattels and give a receipt thereof to the house-owner.
output: According to Section 388 part (2), Rule: If the tenant uses the goods/chattels listed in the description, the tenant must receive them and give a receipt to the owner. Application/Conclusion: When you take possession of the listed items, issue a receipt acknowledging receipt (and ideally note condition) to protect both parties.

instruction: Is the landlord responsible for arranging water and electricity for the rented house?
input:
Section no 389  clause (b) : To arrange for such water and electricity supply,
sewerage and sanitation in the rented house as may be required, except as
otherwise provided for in the agreement,
output: According to Section 389 clause (b), Rule: The house owner must arrange necessary water, electricity, sewerage and sanitation unless the agreement provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: If your agreement does not shift these responsibilities to you, the landlord must ensure these services; if the agreement says you must arrange them, that clause controls.

instruction: Neighbors keep disturbing my peace. Does the landlord have to protect me from harassment by other occupants?
input:
Section no 389  clause (c) : To prevent the tenant from insecurity, harassment
or unrest from other persons dwelling in the house,
output: According to Section 389 clause (c), Rule: The owner is obliged to prevent the tenant from insecurity, harassment or unrest caused by other persons dwelling in the house. Application/Conclusion: Inform the landlord and request remedial action; the landlord has a duty to take reasonable steps to stop harassment by other occupants.

instruction: What are my main duties as a tenant — in plain terms?
input:
Section no 390 . Obligations of tenant : The obligations of the tenant shall
be as follows:
 Section no 390  clause (a) : To pay the rent to the house owner within the
specified period,
 Section no 390  clause (b) : To maintain sanitation in, take care of (herchaha),
protect and safeguard the rented house properly and reasonably, as if it were
his or her own,
 Section no 390  clause (c) : Not to do any act such as causing unrest, harassment or insecurity to the other dwellers in the house or neighbors,
 Section no 390  clause (d) : To abide by the other matters set forth in the
agreement.
output: According to Section 390, Rule: The tenant must (a) pay rent within the specified period, (b) keep the house sanitary and take reasonable care of it, (c) avoid causing unrest/harassment or insecurity to other dwellers or neighbors, and (d) follow other matters set out in the agreement. Application/Conclusion: Practically, you must pay rent on time, maintain cleanliness and repair due to your use, behave respectfully to others, and comply with any additional terms in your contract.

instruction: Our written agreement doesn't say how to pay rent. When exactly must I pay each month?
input:
Section no 391  part (2) : If the agreement does not provide for any mode and
procedure of the payment of rent pursuant to sub-section (1), the 214 tenant
shall pay the rent to the house owner within seven days of the expiry of each
month.
output: According to Section 391 part (2), Rule: If the agreement does not specify the mode and procedure of payment, the tenant must pay rent within seven days after the end of each month. Application/Conclusion: Since your agreement is silent, you should pay the monthly rent within seven days following each month's expiry and keep proof of payment.

instruction: Can the lease agreement require a specific method and timing for rent payments?
input:
Section no 391 . Mode and procedure of payment of rent : (1) The
tenant shall pay the rent to the house owner in accordance with the mode and
procedure set forth in the agreement.
output: According to Section 391(1), Rule: Rent must be paid according to the mode and procedure specified in the agreement. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the agreement can set a specific payment method and timing; you must follow whatever the signed agreement requires unless you mutually agree to change it in writing.

instruction: Can the owner stop me from using the house in ways allowed by the lease?
input:
Section no 389  clause (a) : To allow the tenant to use the house in accordance
with the agreement,
output: According to Section 389 clause (a), Rule: The owner must allow the tenant to use the house in accordance with the agreement. Application/Conclusion: The owner cannot arbitrarily prevent you from using the property in ways that the agreement permits; if they do, you may assert your rights under the agreement and the statute.

instruction: Can I demand a right of way from all surrounding owners to reach the public road?
input: part (2) : A person shall not be entitled to demand the servitude of passage from the owners of all surrounding houses or land pursuant to sub-section (1), and he or she may demand such a servitude from the owner of the house or land through which the distance to the public road is the shortest.
output: According to Section 373(2), Rule: A person cannot demand servitude of passage from all surrounding owners; instead the servitude may be demanded only from the owner whose house or land provides the shortest distance to the public road. Application/Conclusion: You cannot require access across every surrounding property. You may only demand a passage from the owner whose land lies on the shortest route to the public road.

instruction: If I sell a part of my land, do I have to provide exits for both buyer and seller?
input: Section no 374 . Prohibition of transfer of house or land without provision of : passage or exit: (1) In setting aside and transferring any part of the house or land with the provision of passage or exit, such a house or land shall not be transferred without making provision of passage or exit to both the purchaser and the seller.
output: According to Section 374(1), Rule: No part of a house or land may be transferred without providing a passage or exit for both the purchaser and the seller when such provision is necessary. Application/Conclusion: If you plan to transfer part of your land and access requires a passage or exit, you must ensure provision of that passage/exit for both parties before transfer proceeds.

instruction: Do I still need to create a passage when selling land if there is already another way out?
input: Section no 374  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if there is another passage or exit to and from such house or land, it is not required to make provision of passage or exit. 207
output: According to Section 374(2), Rule: The obligation in subsection (1) does not apply if there already exists another passage or exit to and from the house or land. Application/Conclusion: If there is an alternative existing exit, you are not required to provide an additional passage when transferring the property.

instruction: My neighbor can't get sewerage or electricity through his own land — can he lay pipes or lines across my property?
input: Section no 375 . Power to extend basic services : If it is not possible to provide basic services such as sewerage, water supply, electricity, gas and telephone service to the house of a person through his or her own land or public, government or community land, the person shall be entitled to lay pipe or line in the neighbor’s land in such manner as not to cause any loss or damage to the owner of such land.
output: According to Section 375, Rule: When basic services cannot be provided through a person's own or public land, that person is entitled to lay pipes or lines in a neighbor's land, but only in a manner that does not cause loss or damage to that neighbor. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor may lay the necessary utility lines across your land if no other route exists, but the work must be carried out so as not to cause you loss or damage.

instruction: Can I navigate or boat in a river that runs through someone else's property?
input: Section no 376 . Power to use river or stream or river or stream bank : Any person may carry out movement, navigation, boating or fishing in the river or stream which is situated in, or originated from, the personal property of any person or within the zone of a maximum of four meters in either side of such river or stream. Provided that such activity is not allowed in small rivulets that do not have perennial flow of water.
output: According to Section 376, Rule: Any person may navigate, boat, fish, or otherwise move in a river or stream situated in or originating from another's property or within up to four meters on either side, except in small rivulets without perennial flow. Application/Conclusion: You are generally allowed to navigate or boat in such rivers/streams even if they are on another's land, provided the watercourse is suitable (not a non-perennial small rivulet) and activities stay within the permitted zone.

instruction: Is fishing allowed in a stream that flows through my neighbor's land?
input: Section no 376 . Power to use river or stream or river or stream bank : Any person may carry out movement, navigation, boating or fishing in the river or stream which is situated in, or originated from, the personal property of any person or within the zone of a maximum of four meters in either side of such river or stream. Provided that such activity is not allowed in small rivulets that do not have perennial flow of water.
output: According to Section 376, Rule: Fishing is permitted in a river or stream situated in or originating from another's property, and within up to four meters on either bank, except where the watercourse is a small non-perennial rivulet. Application/Conclusion: You may fish in that stream as long as it is not a small seasonal rivulet and you remain within the allowed zone.

instruction: A reservoir was created on nearby land. Who must make an exit for the public and livestock?
input: Section no 377 . Power to use exit road : (1) If a river or stream is diverted or a reservoir is built or a dam is made for any reason in the river or stream, the owner of the concerned land shall provide a reasonable exit for the public and livestock to have access to and from such diversion, reservoir or dam.
output: According to Section 377(1), Rule: When a river is diverted or a reservoir/dam is built, the owner of the affected land must provide a reasonable exit for public and livestock access to and from the diversion, reservoir, or dam. Application/Conclusion: The landowner where the reservoir or dam sits is responsible for making reasonable access available for people and animals to reach and leave the site.

instruction: There are several possible routes to maintain the exit to the dam. Which land should be used?
input: Section no 377  part (2) : If, in maintaining the provision of exit passage referred to in sub-section (1), it is possible to maintain such exit passage through the land of more than one person, the exit passage shall, unless provided otherwise, be maintained through the nearest land that is technically feasible for the access to the diversion, reservoir or dam though that passage. 208
output: According to Section 377(2), Rule: Where multiple lands could serve as the exit route, the exit should be maintained through the nearest land that is technically feasible, unless an alternative has been provided. Application/Conclusion: If several properties could host the access route, the access must, by default, go through the closest property that is technically feasible for reaching the diversion, reservoir, or dam.

instruction: Can I divert my roof rainwater onto the neighbour's field to avoid puddles on my side?
input:
Section no 378 . Prohibition of preventing natural flow of water : (1) Every house or land owner shall himself or herself manage the rain water flow from his or her house or land.

Section no 378  part (2) : If there is no provision referred to in sub-section (1), the rain water shall be allowed to make its natural course. Provided that no water shall be let to so flow as to cause adverse effect on the downstream land by making a ditch, controlling floods or otherwise diverting the flow or through human intervention.
output: According to Section 378(1)-(2), Rule: Each owner must manage rainwater from their property; where they cannot, rainwater must follow its natural course, but no one may let water flow in a way that causes adverse effects on downstream land (for example by digging ditches or diverting flow). Application/Conclusion: You must manage your rainwater yourself; you cannot intentionally divert it onto your neighbour's land in a manner that causes harm or adverse effects. Natural flow is allowed only if it does not damage downstream properties.

instruction: Is it legal to make a ditch so that rainwater from my land floods the field below?
input: Section no 378  part (2) : If there is no provision referred to in sub-section (1), the rain water shall be allowed to make its natural course. Provided that no water shall be let to so flow as to cause adverse effect on the downstream land by making a ditch, controlling floods or otherwise diverting the flow or through human intervention.
output: According to Section 378(2), Rule: Even where rainwater follows its natural course, no water may be made to flow so as to cause adverse effects on downstream land by digging ditches, controlling floods, diverting the flow, or other human intervention. Application/Conclusion: Deliberately digging a ditch to send rainwater to flood downstream land is prohibited and not legally permitted.

instruction: If I need water for irrigation, can I use water from a neighbor's pond before they use it?
input: Section no 379 . Power to use stream, river or pond water : Any person may use the water of a stream, river or pond, which is originated from, flows through or situated in, the land of another person for the purpose of irrigation and drinking, after the use of such water by the concerned owner. Provided that in making such use, the adjoining neighbor shall have priority.
output: According to Section 379, Rule: A person may use water from a stream, river, or pond on another's land for irrigation or drinking only after the owner has used that water; adjoining neighbors have priority when making such use. Application/Conclusion: You cannot use the water before the landowner has taken their use; you may use it only afterward, and adjoining neighbors get priority over more distant users.

instruction: Who gets priority to use water from a shared stream or pond?
input: Section no 379 . Power to use stream, river or pond water : Any person may use the water of a stream, river or pond, which is originated from, flows through or situated in, the land of another person for the purpose of irrigation and drinking, after the use of such water by the concerned owner. Provided that in making such use, the adjoining neighbor shall have priority.
output: According to Section 379, Rule: When using water from another's stream, river, or pond (after the owner's use), adjoining neighbors have priority in making such use. Application/Conclusion: If you and another person both wish to use that water, the adjoining neighbor (closer neighbor) has the legal priority to use it.

instruction: If it's impossible to supply electricity through public land, can an owner lay a line through my plot even if it might slightly inconvenience me?
input: Section no 375 . Power to extend basic services : If it is not possible to provide basic services such as sewerage, water supply, electricity, gas and telephone service to the house of a person through his or her own land or public, government or community land, the person shall be entitled to lay pipe or line in the neighbor’s land in such manner as not to cause any loss or damage to the owner of such land.
output: According to Section 375, Rule: Where basic services cannot be provided through one's own land or public land, the person may lay pipes or lines across a neighbor's land, but only in a way that does not cause loss or damage to the neighbor. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor may run the electricity line across your plot if no alternative exists, but the installation must be carried out so it does not cause you loss or damage; mere minor inconvenience that does not amount to loss or damage should not justify refusal, but measurable harm would.

instruction: The buyer refused to provide an exit after buying my subdivided land. Is the sale valid?
input: Section no 374 . Prohibition of transfer of house or land without provision of : passage or exit: (1) In setting aside and transferring any part of the house or land with the provision of passage or exit, such a house or land shall not be transferred without making provision of passage or exit to both the purchaser and the seller.
output: According to Section 374(1), Rule: A parcel of house or land requiring a passage or exit shall not be transferred without making such provision for both purchaser and seller. Application/Conclusion: If the transfer occurred without providing the required passage/exit, that transfer runs counter to the statutory prohibition. The transaction is not compliant with Section 374(1) and you can assert that the transfer was not properly effected unless the required provision is made.

instruction: Are navigation and boating allowed in tiny seasonal streams?
input: Section no 376 . Power to use river or stream or river or stream bank : Any person may carry out movement, navigation, boating or fishing in the river or stream which is situated in, or originated from, the personal property of any person or within the zone of a maximum of four meters in either side of such river or stream. Provided that such activity is not allowed in small rivulets that do not have perennial flow of water.
output: According to Section 376, Rule: Navigation, boating and similar activities are not allowed in small rivulets that do not have perennial (year-round) flow. Application/Conclusion: You may not navigate or boat in tiny seasonal streams that lack perennial flow; the prohibition specifically excludes such small rivulets from allowed activities.

instruction: Can my landlord evict me if I fail to do what Section 390 requires of me?
input:
clause (a) : If the tenant fails to perform his or her obligations pursuant to Section 390,
 Section no 401
output: According to Section 401 clause (a): Rule: If a tenant fails to perform obligations under Section 390, that is a ground for eviction. Application/Conclusion: If you have not fulfilled the duties set out in Section 390, your landlord may seek eviction on this ground. You should check exactly which obligations in Section 390 are alleged to be breached and remedy them or contest the allegation to avoid eviction.

instruction: My tenant is running illegal activity in the rented flat. Can I evict them?
input: Section no 401  clause (b) : If the tenant commits in the rented house any offense related activity prohibited by law,
output: According to Section 401 clause (b): Rule: Commission of any law‑prohibited, offense‑related activity in the rented house is a valid ground for eviction. Application/Conclusion: If your tenant is engaging in illegal/offense‑related acts inside the property, you may evict them under this clause — you should document the conduct and follow the eviction procedure required by law.

instruction: I need my rented house back to live in myself. How much notice must I give the tenant?
input: Section no 401  part (2) : If it is necessary to evict the tenant from the house in the circumstance referred to in clause (c) of sub-section (1), the land-owner shall give a notice in writing to the tenant in advance of at least thirty-five days.
output: According to Section 401 part (2): Rule: When the house‑owner needs the house for personal use (clause (c)), the owner must give at least 35 days' written advance notice to the tenant. Application/Conclusion: You must serve the tenant a written notice at least 35 days before eviction if you are taking the house for your own use.

instruction: If I evict my tenant because I need the house for myself, can I immediately rent it to someone else?
input: Section no 401  part (3) : If the house owner evicts the tenant from the house pursuant to sub-section (2), the house-owner is not entitled to rent such a house to another person until three months, without using it on his or her own.
output: According to Section 401 part (3): Rule: After evicting a tenant because the owner needs the house for personal use, the owner cannot rent the house to another person for three months, unless the owner actually uses it themselves. Application/Conclusion: You cannot re-rent the property to a new tenant for three months following such an eviction; doing so would violate this restriction unless you have genuinely used the house yourself.

instruction: I was evicted because the owner needed the house but now they want to rent it out within two months. Do I have any priority?
input: Section no 401  part (4) : If the house-owner is to rent such house to another person within three months pursuant to sub-section (3) and the previous tenant intends to rent such a house, he or she shall get priority.
output: According to Section 401 part (4): Rule: If the owner intends to rent the house within three months and the previous tenant wishes to re‑rent, the previous tenant has priority. Application/Conclusion: If the landlord tries to rent the house within three months after evicting you for personal use and you want it back, you have a priority right to re‑rent before others.

instruction: I left the rented house. Does the rental agreement end automatically?
input:
Section no 402 . House rent agreement deemed to be terminated : A house rent agreement entered into pursuant to Section 386 shall be deemed to have been terminated in any of the following circumstances:
 Section no 402  clause (a) : If the tenant leaves the house,
output: According to Section 402 clause (a): Rule: A house rent agreement is deemed terminated if the tenant leaves the house. Application/Conclusion: If you (the tenant) have left the premises, the rental agreement is considered terminated under this clause — subject to any other legal or factual complications such as abandonment procedures or unpaid dues.

instruction: If the owner legally evicts me, does that also terminate the agreement?
input: Section no 402  clause (b) : If the house-owner evicts the tenant from the house,
output: According to Section 402 clause (b): Rule: A house rent agreement is deemed terminated where the house‑owner evicts the tenant. Application/Conclusion: If you are evicted lawfully by the owner, that eviction ends the rental agreement under this provision.

instruction: What must I do before handing the house back to the owner when I leave?
input: Section no 403 . Duty to hand over goods or chattels in good condition : (1) The tenant shall, while leaving the rented house, count the goods or chattels in his or her custody, clean or color the house, if required, and hand over the same in good condition to the house-owner.
output: According to Section 403(1): Rule: On leaving, the tenant must count goods/chattels in their custody, clean or repaint the house if required, and hand everything over in good condition. Application/Conclusion: Before you vacate, inventory the items you hold, clean or paint if asked, and return the property and chattels in good condition to avoid disputes or deductions.

instruction: I broke a piece of furniture that belonged to the owner — am I liable to pay?
input: Section no 403  part (2) : If the tenant looses or damages any goods or chattel in his or her custody, the tenant shall hand over similar goods or chattel or pay a sum of money as per the prevailing price of such goods or chattel to the house-owner.
output: According to Section 403 part (2): Rule: If a tenant loses or damages goods/chattels in their custody, they must replace them with similar items or pay their prevailing market price. Application/Conclusion: You are required to either provide a comparable replacement item or pay its current value to the owner for the damaged furniture.

instruction: Do I have to pay for wear-and-tear items like cutlery that get used daily?
input: Section no 403  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), the tenant shall not be bound to reimburse for any goods or chattel which is depreciable or destroyable in the course of daily use or to pay price for such goods or chattel.
output: According to Section 403 part (3): Rule: Tenants are not required to reimburse for goods or chattels that naturally depreciate or get destroyed through daily use. Application/Conclusion: You are not liable to pay for normal wear and tear on everyday items (e.g., utensils) that naturally depreciate through ordinary use.

instruction: My tenant vanished without paying three months' rent and we can't find them. What can I do?
input: Section no 404 . Power to vacate house : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a tenant disappears without paying the rent for three months or more without notice and the tenant is not found despite a public notice or correspondence with his or her address or the tenant or his or her successor or agent does not appear despite that he or she has been found, the house-owner shall submit an application with such statement to the concerned ward oﬀice of the Local Level.
output: According to Section 404(1): Rule: If a tenant disappears without paying rent for three months or more and cannot be located despite public notice or correspondence, the house‑owner may submit an application to the concerned ward office stating the facts. Application/Conclusion: You should publish the required public notice and, if the tenant remains unlocated, file the stated application to the local ward office to proceed with vacating the house.

instruction: Does the tenancy end automatically when the rent period is over?
input: Section no 402  clause (d) : If the period of house rent expires. 220
output: According to Section 402 clause (d): Rule: A house rent agreement is deemed terminated when the period of rent expires. Application/Conclusion: When the agreed rental period ends, the tenancy is treated as terminated under this provision, unless there is an extension agreement or other legal basis to continue occupancy.

instruction: My tenant keeps breaching the written rental agreement. Is that a ground for eviction?
input: Section no 401  clause (g) : If the tenant does any act in contravention of the agreement or this Chapter,
output: According to Section 401 clause (g): Rule: Acts by the tenant that contravene the rental agreement or the provisions of this Chapter constitute grounds for eviction. Application/Conclusion: Repeated or material breaches of the lease terms can justify eviction — document the breaches and follow due process to evict on this ground.

instruction: The house has serious damp and smells; is that a reason to end the lease?
input: Section no 401  clause (e) : If the rented house does not appear to be appropriate for human habitation from the technical and health perspectives,
output: According to Section 401 clause (e): Rule: If the rented house is not appropriate for human habitation on technical or health grounds, that is a ground relevant under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: If the property is uninhabitable for technical/health reasons, that condition can justify termination or eviction actions under this provision — you should obtain evidence (e.g., inspection report) and follow the legal process.

instruction: Can the owner remove tenants to repair the house?
input: Section no 401  clause (d) : If it is necessary to repair and maintain the house by removing inhabitants from the house,
output: According to Section 401 clause (d): Rule: Necessity to repair and maintain the house that requires removing inhabitants is a ground recognized under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: The owner may evict or require vacation to carry out necessary repairs/maintenance, provided they follow the applicable notice and procedural requirements.

instruction: The law mentions Section 395 subsection (5). If that circumstance exists, can the owner evict me?
input:
Section no 401  clause (h) : If there exists the circumstance under sub-section (5) of Section 395.
 Section no 401
output: According to Section 401 clause (h): Rule: If the circumstances described in Section 395(5) exist, those circumstances serve as a ground under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: If the specific scenario in Section 395(5) applies to your case, the owner may rely on this clause to seek eviction — you should review Section 395(5) to understand whether it actually applies and whether any defenses exist.

instruction: We mutually agreed to end the tenancy — is there a provision saying the agreement is terminated then?
input: Section no 402  clause (c) : If the house-owner and the tenant cancel the agreement with mutual consent,
output: According to Section 402 clause (c): Rule: A rent agreement is deemed terminated when the house‑owner and tenant cancel it by mutual consent. Application/Conclusion: If both parties have mutually agreed to cancel the tenancy, the agreement is considered terminated under this provision — ensure the mutual cancellation is documented in writing to avoid later disputes.

instruction: I plan to leave the flat tomorrow — do I need to count the things I had from the landlord?
input: Section no 403 . Duty to hand over goods or chattels in good condition : (1) The tenant shall, while leaving the rented house, count the goods or chattels in his or her custody, clean or color the house, if required, and hand over the same in good condition to the house-owner.
output: According to Section 403(1): Rule: The tenant must count goods/chattels in their custody on leaving, clean or paint if required, and hand them over in good condition. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you should inventory the landlord's items you possess and hand them back in good condition, and clean or repaint if requested, to comply with this duty.

instruction: Can I revoke a deed of gift with testament after I've signed it, or am I stuck?
input: Section no 410 . Power to amend or revoke deed of gift with testament : (1) The maker of gift with testament may, if he or she so wishes, amend the terms of, or revoke, the deed of gift with testament executed by him or her at any time, by making an application in person before the concerned authority.
output: According to Section 410(1): Rule: The maker of a gift with testament may amend or revoke the deed at any time by applying in person to the concerned authority. Application/Conclusion: You are not permanently stuck — you can revoke or change the deed of gift with testament whenever you wish, provided you personally apply before the concerned authority and follow the required procedure.

instruction: What exactly must I do to amend or revoke my testamentary gift? Do I just send a letter?
input:
Section no 410  part (2) : In amending or revoking the deed of gift with testament pursuant to sub-section (1), such a person shall appear before the concerned authority, execute a separate deed and then amend or revoke such a deed of gift with testament.
Section no 410  part (3) : The deed revoking or amending the deed of gift with testament pursuant to sub-section (2) shall be executed in fulfillment of the procedures applicable to the execution of the deed of gift with testament.
output: According to Section 410(2)-(3): Rule: To amend or revoke you must personally appear before the concerned authority, execute a separate deed of amendment or revocation, and follow the same formal procedures that apply to executing the original deed. Application/Conclusion: A simple letter is not enough — you must go in person, sign a distinct deed of amendment or revocation, and comply with the formal execution requirements (the same procedures used for the original deed).

instruction: Can I give the same property to two different people by making a new deed without revoking the old one?
input: Section no 410  part (4) : No person may grant a property once granted to any one by executing the deed of gift with testament to other person by executing such a deed, without revoking the earlier deed of gift with testament pursuant to this Section.
output: According to Section 410(4): Rule: You cannot grant a property already granted by a deed of gift with testament to another person by executing a new deed unless you first revoke the earlier deed in accordance with this Section. Application/Conclusion: You must revoke the earlier deed following the statutory procedure before granting the same property to someone else; otherwise the new attempt to grant is not permitted.

instruction: My parent executed a new deed transferring the same property to X without revoking the first deed. Which deed stands?
input: Section no 410  part (5) : If a deed of gift with testament is executed in contravention of sub-section (4), the deed of gift with testament executed earlier shall ipso facto be valid. 225
output: According to Section 410(5): Rule: If a later deed is executed in contravention of subsection (4) (i.e., without properly revoking the earlier deed), the earlier deed remains valid ipso facto. Application/Conclusion: The earlier deed (the first validly executed one) continues to be effective; the later deed executed without proper revocation does not displace it.

instruction: I donated property to an organization by testament but the organization was dissolved before I died. What happens to the gift?
input: clause (b) : If a property is donated or gifted to a person with entitlement after testament and the receiver of donation or gift dies before the person making such a donation or gift or the organization obtaining donation or gift is dissolved,
output: According to Section 408(b): Rule: A donation/gift intended to take effect after testament fails if the designated individual dies before the donor or if the organization intended to receive the gift is dissolved before it takes effect. Application/Conclusion: If the organization you named was dissolved before the testamentary gift became effective, that gift cannot take effect as intended; the donor should address an alternative disposition (or the property will be dealt with according to applicable succession rules).

instruction: I left property to an unborn child in my will. The child was stillborn. Is the gift valid?
input: Section no 408  clause (c) : If a property is donated or gifted to an unborn baby and the baby is not born alive,
output: According to Section 408(c): Rule: A donation or gift to an unborn baby does not take effect if the baby is not born alive. Application/Conclusion: If the unborn child named in your testament is not born alive, the gift to that unborn child fails and will not vest as intended.

instruction: I made a gift in my will but the property was destroyed before the gift became effective. What then?
input: Section no 408  clause (d) : If the donated or gifted property is so destroyed that its existence is extinct before the donation or gift becomes effective.
output: According to Section 408(d): Rule: If the donated or gifted property is destroyed to the point of non-existence before the gift becomes effective, the gift cannot take effect. Application/Conclusion: Because the subject matter no longer exists before the gift becomes effective, the intended donation fails with respect to that destroyed property.

instruction: I gifted a piece of land but it turns out someone else already had ownership rights over it. Can that gift be invalidated?
input: Section no 409  clause (a) : If a person donates or gifts a property in which another has right and ownership,
output: According to Section 409(a): Rule: A donation or gift is voidable if the donor gifts property in which another person has a right or ownership. Application/Conclusion: The gift can be voided because you donated property over which someone else holds rights or ownership; the other person's rights prevail and the donation is voidable on that ground.

instruction: My sibling was named as donee but our mother didn't get my father's consent where the law requires it. Is the gift fully valid?
input:
Section no 409  clause (b) : If any property is donated or gifted without obtaining the consent of another person where such consent is needed pursuant to law,

Section no 409  part (2) : In the case of a donation or gift made without the consent of another person pursuant to clause (b) of sub-section (1) where such
119
consent is required, the property shall be void to the extent of such consent not
taken.
output: According to Section 409(1)(b) and 409(2): Rule: A gift made without legally required consent is voidable; where such consent is required but not obtained, the property is void to the extent consent was not taken. Application/Conclusion: Because the required consent was not obtained, the gift is voidable — and it will be void to the extent that the missing consent affects the gift. Practically, portions or rights that require that consent will be invalid; you should seek rectification or legal steps to confirm the extent of voidness.

instruction: I doubt the person who made the gift was mentally competent. Can that make the donation void?
input: Section no 409  clause (c) : If the maker of the donation or gift is an incompetent or quasi-competent person, 224
output: According to Section 409(c): Rule: A donation or gift is voidable if the maker was incompetent or quasi-competent at the time of making it. Application/Conclusion: If you can show the donor lacked capacity (incompetent or quasi-competent), the donation can be voided; evidence of incapacity at the time of the gift will be central.

instruction: I signed a deed but didn't follow legal formalities. Can that be cancelled?
input: Section no 409  clause (d) : If the donation or gift is made without fulfilling the legal requirements.
output: According to Section 409(d): Rule: A donation or gift made without fulfilling legal requirements is voidable. Application/Conclusion: Failure to satisfy the required legal formalities makes the gift susceptible to being voided; you or an interested party can challenge it on that basis.

instruction: My brother was convicted of assaulting our father before the will becomes effective. Can he inherit the gifted property?
input: Section no 411 . Not to obtain property under deed of gift with testament : If the receiver of gift with testament is convicted to have committed any criminal offense against the maker of such a gift before the deed of gift with testament becomes effective, the receiver shall not be entitled to obtain the property under such a deed.
output: According to Section 411: Rule: A receiver of a testamentary gift who is convicted of a criminal offence against the maker before the deed becomes effective is not entitled to obtain the property. Application/Conclusion: If your brother was convicted of a criminal offence against your father before the testamentary gift took effect, he is barred from receiving the gifted property under that deed.

instruction: Is there a general list of circumstances where a gift can be voided?
input: Section no 409 . Donation or gift to be voidable : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Act, a donation or gift may be voided in any of the following circumstances:
output: According to Section 409(1): Rule: The law provides specific circumstances under which a donation or gift may be voided, notwithstanding other provisions. Application/Conclusion: Yes — Section 409(1) confirms there is an enumerated set of grounds (then listed in the following clauses) under which gifts can be voided; you should consult those specific clauses (e.g., lack of ownership, missing consent, incapacity, failure of legal requirements) to see which applies to your case.

instruction: If a donation lacked another person's consent, is the whole property lost or only part of it?
input:
Section no 409  part (2) : In the case of a donation or gift made without the consent of another person pursuant to clause (b) of sub-section (1) where such
119
consent is required, the property shall be void to the extent of such consent not
taken.
output: According to Section 409(2): Rule: When required consent is missing, the property is void only to the extent of the consent not taken. Application/Conclusion: The entire gift isn't necessarily void — only the portion or rights affected by the missing consent are void. Determine what specific part required consent to see how much is invalidated.

instruction: I want to know: where is the power to amend or revoke a deed of gift with testament stated in the law?
input: Section no 410 . Power to amend or revoke deed of gift with testament : (1) The maker of gift with testament may, if he or she so wishes, amend the terms of, or revoke, the deed of gift with testament executed by him or her at any time, by making an application in person before the concerned authority.
output: According to Section 410(1): Rule: Section 410 sets out the power to amend or revoke a deed of gift with testament. Application/Conclusion: The statutory authority for amending or revoking a deed of gift with testament is Section 410; it explicitly grants the maker the right to amend or revoke by personal application to the concerned authority.

instruction: Scenario: I donated land to a nephew who died before me. Does the gift take effect for his heirs?
input: clause (b) : If a property is donated or gifted to a person with entitlement after testament and the receiver of donation or gift dies before the person making such a donation or gift or the organization obtaining donation or gift is dissolved,
output: According to Section 408(b): Rule: A testamentary donation to a person fails if the designated recipient dies before the donor. Application/Conclusion: Because your nephew died before you (the donor), the testamentary gift to him cannot take effect as directed; it does not automatically vest in his heirs under this provision unless other provisions or alternative dispositions apply.

instruction: I made a will for an unborn grandchild. If they are born alive later, does the gift take effect only then?
input: Section no 408  clause (c) : If a property is donated or gifted to an unborn baby and the baby is not born alive,
output: According to Section 408(c): Rule: A gift to an unborn baby requires the baby to be born alive for the gift to be effective. Application/Conclusion: If the unborn grandchild is later born alive, the gift can take effect; if the baby is not born alive, the gift fails. Therefore the key condition is live birth for the testamentary gift to vest.

instruction: My father tried to transfer already-granted property to someone else without revoking the earlier deed; I want to challenge it. What does the law say about such conflicts?
input: Section no 410  part (5) : If a deed of gift with testament is executed in contravention of sub-section (4), the deed of gift with testament executed earlier shall ipso facto be valid. 225
output: According to Section 410(5): Rule: Where a later deed is executed in contravention of the rule that earlier grants must be revoked first, the earlier deed remains automatically valid. Application/Conclusion: You can challenge the later deed — the law preserves the validity of the earlier deed ipso facto, so the earlier beneficiary's rights prevail and the subsequent inconsistent deed is ineffective to supplant it.

instruction: Can I give my house in usufruct just by telling my neighbour? Do I need any paper?
input: Section no 354 . Deed to be executed : (1) In giving an immovable property in usufruct, its owner shall execute a deed to that effect in accordance with law.
output: According to Section 354(1), the rule is that when an immovable property is given in usufruct the owner must execute a deed in accordance with law. Applied to your situation, an oral grant to your neighbour would not satisfy this requirement — you need to execute the proper deed for the usufruct to be valid.

instruction: What does 'usufruct' actually mean in plain words? I'm confused.
input: Section no 352 . Usufruct deemed to be constituted : (1) When a person gives free a property in which he or she has title and ownership and fruits, benefit, income or facility to be yielded from that property to another person entitling that other person to enjoy such property and fruits, benefit, income or facility thereof, usufruct shall be deemed to be constituted.
output: According to Section 352(1), the rule is that usufruct is constituted when an owner gives another person the right to enjoy a property and the fruits/benefits/income it yields. Applied to your question, usufruct means the recipient can use and take the benefits of the property (like income or crops) even though ownership stays with the original owner.

instruction: If my uncle gave me land in usufruct, am I allowed to collect the crop income and live on it as if it were mine?
input: Section no 355 . Entitlement of usufructuary to enjoy property as if to him or her: (1) If a person gives another person his or her property in usufruct, the usufructuary of such property shall be entitled to enjoy the property, fruits, benefit, income or facility to be yielded or earned from the property and fruits, benefit, income or facility accrued from the property as if it were his or her own property.
output: According to Section 355(1), the rule is that a usufructuary is entitled to enjoy the property and its fruits/benefits/income as if it were their own. Applied to your case, you may collect crop income and live off the property in the same manner as an owner would, subject to any limits in the contract or law.

instruction: Can I cut down the mature trees on a plot given to me in usufruct and sell the timber?
input:
Section no 356 . Property which usufructuary cannot enjoy : Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 355, a usufructuary shall not be entitled to enjoy the following properties relating to the property obtained under the provision of usufruct:
 Section no 356  clause (b) : Grown trees. Provided that fruits, flowers or other products obtained from the trees may be enjoyed.
output: According to Section 356(b), the rule is that a usufructuary is not entitled to enjoy grown trees themselves, although they may enjoy fruits, flowers or other products from the trees. Applied to your question, you may not cut down and sell the grown trees (the trees themselves are not for the usufructuary), but you can harvest and use/sell fruits or other products produced by those trees.

instruction: My father gave our ancestral house in usufruct to my sister and she started using it. When did her right start?
input: Section no 353 . Usufruct to be effective : The provision of usufruct constituted by a contract shall become effective on the date of the commencement of the contract unless otherwise set forth in the contract.
output: According to Section 353, the rule is that usufruct becomes effective on the commencement date of the contract unless the contract provides a different date. Applied to your situation, your sister's right began on the contract's commencement date, unless the contract specifies some other start date.

instruction: If two cousins are both made usufructuaries of the same field, do they share it or each get separate parts?
input: Section no 355  part (2) : If there are more than one usufructuary obtaining a property pursuant to sub-section (1), every usufructuary shall be entitled to enjoy that property jointly or severally.
output: According to Section 355(2), the rule is that where there are multiple usufructuaries each is entitled to enjoy the property either jointly or severally. Applied to your cousins' case, they can enjoy the field together or separately as provided — both forms of enjoyment are recognized.

instruction: If a property given in usufruct gets partitioned among heirs, do usufruct rights disappear?
input: Section no 355  part (3) : If a property obtained under the provision of usufruct is partitioned, every coparcener who is entitled to enjoy the property in usufruct shall be entitled to enjoy the property pursuant to sub section (1).
output: According to Section 355(3), the rule is that even if the property is partitioned, each coparcener entitled to usufruct continues to enjoy the property as described in subsection (1). Applied here, partition does not extinguish the usufruct rights — the entitled coparceners retain the right to enjoy the property and its benefits.

instruction: My neighbour is stopping me from using land given to me in usufruct. Can I go to court?
input: Section no 355  part (4) : A usufructuary may make a lawsuit in the court, as required, for the protection or enjoyment of the property obtained under the provision of usufruct.
output: According to Section 355(4), the rule is that a usufructuary may bring a lawsuit to protect or enforce enjoyment of the usufruct property. Applied to your problem, you are entitled to approach the court to protect or enforce your usufruct rights against interference.

instruction: Can I mine minerals on land given to me in usufruct?
input: Section no 356  clause (a) : Mines and minerals related with the property, Provided that where the mines are the subject of usufruct, the mines may be enjoyed.
output: According to Section 356(a), the rule is that generally a usufructuary is not entitled to enjoy mines and minerals related to the property, except where the mines themselves are expressly the subject of the usufruct. Applied to your situation, you cannot extract minerals unless the usufruct agreement specifically includes the mines.

instruction: If I want the usufruct agreement to say something special about when it starts, can we set a later date?
input: Section no 353 . Usufruct to be effective : The provision of usufruct constituted by a contract shall become effective on the date of the commencement of the contract unless otherwise set forth in the contract.
output: According to Section 353, the rule is that the usufruct takes effect at the contract's commencement unless the contract itself states a different effective date. Applied to your plan, yes — the parties can set a different start date in the contract and that date will govern when the usufruct becomes effective.

instruction: Under which section is the rule that the terms of usufruct are controlled by contract?
input: Section no 352  part (2) : The provisions of usufruct shall be as set forth in a contract entered into between the concerned persons.
output: According to Section 352(2), the rule is that the provisions of usufruct are determined by the contract between the parties. Applied to your request for citation, Section 352(2) is the provision that states usufruct terms are governed by the contract.

instruction: My cousins, who live in a joint family, say our elder brother granted usufruct over common property without telling us. Is that valid?
input: Section no 354  part (2) : In giving a property in common in usufruct, consent of the coparceners living in a joint family shall be obtained.
output: According to Section 354(2), the rule is that when a common property in a joint family is given in usufruct, the consent of the coparceners living in the joint family must be obtained. Applied to your facts, the grant without the coparceners' consent would not comply with Section 354(2) — the consent of coparceners is required.

instruction: I found out today that someone misused funds from a trust. How long do I have to file a lawsuit for matters not covered elsewhere?
input: Section no 351  part (2) : A lawsuit may be made within six months after the date of the accrual of cause of action in relation to any matter other than that set forth in sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 351(2), the rule is that a lawsuit for matters (other than those in subsection (1)) must be made within six months from the date the cause of action accrued. Applied to your situation, you generally have six months from the date you discovered the misuse (the accrual of the cause of action) to file suit, unless a different provision applies.

instruction: If two people are made usufructuaries, can one of them act alone to use or sell the benefits?
input: Section no 355  part (2) : If there are more than one usufructuary obtaining a property pursuant to sub-section (1), every usufructuary shall be entitled to enjoy that property jointly or severally.
output: According to Section 355(2), the rule is that multiple usufructuaries may enjoy the property jointly or severally. Applied to your question, one usufructuary may enjoy the benefits separately (severally) if that form of enjoyment is applicable — the statute recognises both joint and several enjoyment. Note: enjoyment is allowed; whether one can independently transfer rights is not expressly addressed in this text.

instruction: Can a usufructuary treat the usufruct property exactly like owned property — for example, mortgage or sell it?
input: Section no 355 . Entitlement of usufructuary to enjoy property as if to him or her: (1) If a person gives another person his or her property in usufruct, the usufructuary of such property shall be entitled to enjoy the property, fruits, benefit, income or facility to be yielded or earned from the property and fruits, benefit, income or facility accrued from the property as if it were his or her own property.
output: According to Section 355(1), the rule is that a usufructuary is entitled to enjoy the property and its fruits/benefits/income as if it were their own. Applied to your query, the usufructuary can use and take benefits like an owner, but the text speaks only of enjoyment — it does not explicitly authorize alienation (sale or mortgage) of the underlying property. You should check the contract and other law for any limits on transfer or encumbrance.

instruction: My landlord says the usufruct contract they signed last year controls everything. Is that true?
input: Section no 352  part (2) : The provisions of usufruct shall be as set forth in a contract entered into between the concerned persons.
output: According to Section 352(2), the rule is that the provisions of usufruct are those set out in the contract between the parties. Applied to your situation, the terms of the usufruct contract the landlord signed will govern the rights and obligations of the parties, subject to mandatory legal provisions.

instruction: If the usufruct covers mines specifically, can the usufructuary enjoy them?
input: Section no 356  clause (a) : Mines and minerals related with the property, Provided that where the mines are the subject of usufruct, the mines may be enjoyed.
output: According to Section 356(a), the rule is that ordinarily mines and minerals related to the property are not enjoyed by the usufructuary, but if the mines are expressly made the subject of the usufruct, they may be enjoyed. Applied to your fact, only if the usufruct agreement explicitly includes the mines will the usufructuary be entitled to enjoy them.

instruction: Can I sell my private house to someone without asking anyone in my family?
input:
Power to transfer private property : A person may
transfer his or her private property to another person without any one’s consent.
output:
According to Section (Power to transfer private property)...
Rule: A person may transfer his or her private property to another person without anyone's consent.
Application/Conclusion: If the house is your private property (not joint or common), you may sell or transfer it without needing consent from family members.

instruction: If my sister refuses to sign, can I still sell my share of the family land?
input:
Section no 418  part (2) : Even though all the owners do not agree to transfer
the joint property pursuant to sub-section (1), any owner may transfer the
property of his or her right or portion.
output:
According to Section 418(2)...
Rule: Even if all owners do not agree to transfer the joint property, any owner may transfer the property of his or her right or portion.
Application/Conclusion: You can sell only your own right or portion in the family land without requiring all owners' agreement; you cannot validly transfer more than your share.

instruction: Do all co-owners have to agree before selling joint property?
input:
Section no 418 . Joint property may be sold by way of sale : (1) A joint
property may be sold and transferred with the consent of all of its owners.
output:
