According to Section 418(1)...
Rule: A joint property may be sold and transferred with the consent of all of its owners.
Application/Conclusion: To sell the whole joint property, you need the consent of all owners. Without unanimous consent, a full-sale is not permitted under this provision.

instruction: If my share can't be separated from the land but my brother wants to buy it, what happens?
input:
Section no 418  part (3) : If, in making a transfer pursuant to sub-section (1),
it is technically not possible to separate the right or portion of any owner from
the joint property, and another owner intends to acquire such property, that
other owner shall be entitled to obtain it at the price mutually agreed upon
between the owners.
output:
According to Section 418(3)...
Rule: When an owner's portion cannot be technically separated and another owner wishes to acquire it, that owner is entitled to obtain it at a price mutually agreed between the owners.
Application/Conclusion: If your share cannot be physically separated and your brother wants to acquire it, he may do so provided you both agree on a price; the property can be transferred to him at the mutually agreed price.

instruction: Two of us want the same share — who gets it?
input:
Section no 418  part (4) : If more than one owner intend to acquire the joint
property, the owner who agrees to pay the highest price shall be entitled to
obtain such property.
output:
According to Section 418(4)...
Rule: If more than one owner intends to acquire the joint property, the owner who agrees to pay the highest price is entitled to obtain it.
Application/Conclusion: When multiple co-owners wish to buy the same joint property, it goes to the one who offers the highest price.

instruction: What if nobody else wants to buy and the share can't be separated — must we sell the whole property?
input:
Section no 418  part (5) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(3), if the other owners do not intend to acquire the right or portion of any owner
and it is not possible technically to separate such property and, the whole of the
joint property shall be sold and the proceeds of sale shall be divided between
the owners according to their respective right or portion in that property.
output:
According to Section 418(5)...
Rule: If other owners do not intend to acquire the portion and separation is technically impossible, the whole joint property shall be sold and proceeds divided according to each owner's share.
Application/Conclusion: If no co-owner wants to buy your inseparable share, the only remedy under this section is to sell the entire property and divide the sale proceeds among owners according to their respective portions.

instruction: Someone sold joint property without getting consent from others — is that sale fully valid?
input:
Section no 418  part (6) : If any person transfers the joint property in contravention of sub-section (1), only the transfer of the extent of his or her right
or portion in such property shall be valid, and the concerned person shall be
entitled to get return of the property transferred in excess of the right or portion
of the transferor.
output:
According to Section 418(6)...
Rule: A transfer of joint property made contrary to subsection (1) is valid only to the extent of the transferor's own right or portion; any transfer beyond that is not valid and the excess can be reclaimed.
Application/Conclusion: If someone sold the joint property without full owner consent, the sale is only valid up to the seller's own share. Any part sold beyond that share can be reclaimed by the other owners.

instruction: Can I transfer property in common without written consent of the coparceners?
input:
Section no 419 . Prohibition of transferring property in common without : obtaining consent: (1) No person shall, without obtaining written 229 consent of the coparceners in common, transfer a property in common to another
person.
output:
According to Section 419(1)...
Rule: No person shall transfer a property in common to another without obtaining written consent of the coparceners in common.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot legally transfer a property held in common unless you have the written consent of the other coparceners.

instruction: My coparcener was a witness on the sale deed — does that count as consent?
input:
Section no 419  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if a coparcener of the joint family is a witness to the deed of transfer of a
property in common, consent of that coparcener shall be deemed to have been
obtained.
output:
According to Section 419(2)...
Rule: If a coparcener of the joint family is a witness to the deed of transfer of a property in common, that coparcener's consent is deemed to have been obtained.
Application/Conclusion: If your coparcener signed as a witness on the transfer deed, the law treats their consent as given; the transfer will be considered to have that coparcener's consent.

instruction: Someone transferred a common property without written consent — is the whole transfer valid?
input:
Section no 419  part (3) : If any person transfers a property in common in
contravention of sub-section (1), the transfer of title only to the extent of such
right or portion that person has in that property shall be valid. The concerned
coparcener shall be entitled to get back the property transferred in excess of
such right or portion.
output:
According to Section 419(3)...
Rule: A transfer of a common property made in contravention of subsection (1) is valid only to the extent of the transferor's own right or portion; any excess transferred can be reclaimed by the concerned coparcener.
Application/Conclusion: If someone transferred common property without the required written consent, only the part corresponding to their share is validly transferred; the rest can be recovered by other coparceners.

instruction: Can the head of the family sell common items for household needs without others' consent?
input:
Section no 420 . Property in common may be sold for household purpose : Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 419, the person acting
as the head of family may, for the household purpose, sell whole of the property
in common, in the case of a movable property, and the half of such property, in
the case of an immovable property, without consent of the others.
output:
According to Section 420...
Rule: The head of family may, for household purposes, sell the whole of a common movable property and half of a common immovable property without others' consent, notwithstanding Section 419.
Application/Conclusion: If you act as the head of family and need to sell common property for household purposes, you may sell an entire movable common property or half of an immovable common property without obtaining consent from the other owners.

instruction: Is it ever allowed to transfer someone else's property as if it's yours?
input:
Section no 421 . Prohibition of transferring other’s property : (1) No
person shall transfer a property to another person in which any one else has
right and ownership.
output:
According to Section 421(1)...
Rule: No person shall transfer a property to another person in which someone else has right and ownership.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot legally transfer property that belongs to someone else or in which another person has ownership rights.

instruction: If a person transfers another's property pretending it's theirs, is that deed valid?
input:
Section no 421  part (2) : If any person transfers a property in contravention
of sub-section (1), such a deed or transaction shall be void.
output:
According to Section 421(2)...
Rule: Any deed or transaction made in contravention of subsection (1) is void.
Application/Conclusion: A transfer made by someone of another person's property, in violation of the prohibition, is void and has no legal effect.

instruction: I bought land from someone who wasn't the real owner; can the real owner reclaim it?
input:
Section no 421  part (3) : If the real owner makes a claim in the property
transferred pursuant to sub-section (1), the transferee of such property shall
return it to the concerned owner.
output:
According to Section 421(3)...
Rule: If the real owner claims property that was transferred in contravention of subsection (1), the transferee must return it to the real owner.
Application/Conclusion: If the true owner asserts their right over the land you purchased from a non-owner, you are obliged to return the property to that real owner.

instruction: I sold more than my share of a joint property by mistake — can the others get back what was sold beyond my portion?
input:
Section no 418  part (6) : If any person transfers the joint property in contravention of sub-section (1), only the transfer of the extent of his or her right
or portion in such property shall be valid, and the concerned person shall be
entitled to get return of the property transferred in excess of the right or portion
of the transferor.
output:
According to Section 418(6)...
Rule: A transfer of joint property contrary to subsection (1) is valid only up to the transferor's own right or portion; any excess transferred can be reclaimed by the concerned persons.
Application/Conclusion: The co-owners can demand return of the part of the property that you transferred beyond your legal share; only the portion equal to your share remains validly transferred.

instruction: I purchased a common asset but later learned seller didn't have written consent. Am I partly safe?
input:
Section no 419  part (3) : If any person transfers a property in common in
contravention of sub-section (1), the transfer of title only to the extent of such
right or portion that person has in that property shall be valid. The concerned
coparcener shall be entitled to get back the property transferred in excess of
such right or portion.
output:
According to Section 419(3)...
Rule: A transfer of common property made without required written consent is valid only to the extent of the transferor's own right or portion; any excess can be reclaimed by coparceners.
Application/Conclusion: Your title is valid only up to the seller's actual share. Any portion transferred beyond that share is not valid, and the coparceners can claim that excess back from you.

instruction: If the head of family sells half of an immovable property for household needs, do others have a claim?
input:
Section no 420 . Property in common may be sold for household purpose : Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 419, the person acting
as the head of family may, for the household purpose, sell whole of the property
in common, in the case of a movable property, and the half of such property, in
the case of an immovable property, without consent of the others.
output:
According to Section 420...
Rule: The head of family may sell half of a common immovable property for household purposes without consent of others.
Application/Conclusion: If the sale is genuinely for household purpose and done by the person acting as head of family, selling half of the immovable common property is permitted and others cannot prevent it under Section 420.

instruction: My neighbor claims I transferred his plot though he was the owner. What does the law say about transferring another's property?
input:
Section no 421 . Prohibition of transferring other’s property : (1) No
person shall transfer a property to another person in which any one else has
right and ownership.
output:
According to Section 421(1)...
Rule: No one may transfer a property in which someone else has right and ownership.
Application/Conclusion: If your neighbor is the true owner, a transfer made by you of that plot would be prohibited and invalid under this provision.

instruction: Can I sell my property even if my brother objects?
input:
Section no 414 . Property may be transferred : (1) Any person, other
than a person who is not competent to make contract pursuant to this Act or
120
laws in force, may, subject to this Act, transfer a property in which he or she
has right and ownership to one or more than one person jointly or severally.
output:
According to Section 414(1):
Rule: Any person who is competent to make a contract may, subject to the Act, transfer property in which he or she has right and ownership.
Application/Conclusion: If you alone hold the ownership and you were competent at the time of transfer, you have the legal power to sell despite your brother's objection. If, however, your brother is a co-owner or has a legal right in the property, his interest must be respected (see Section 416 on multiple transferees), so you cannot unilaterally override another owner’s entitlement.

instruction: Ram promised to transfer land to me but never executed the deed. What does the law say?
input:
Section no 413 . Property deemed to be transferred : If a person sells,
donates, gifts or otherwise transfers a property in which he or she has right
and ownership to another person, the property shall be deemed to have been
transferred to that other person.
output:
According to Section 413:
Rule: Property is deemed transferred when a person sells, donates, gifts or otherwise transfers a property in which he or she has right and ownership to another person.
Application/Conclusion: A mere promise without an actual transfer does not satisfy Section 413. Only when Ram actually transfers (e.g., executes the deed or otherwise effects transfer) will the property be deemed transferred to you. If no transfer occurred, your remedy depends on evidence of completion or steps taken toward transfer; the statutory deeming rule does not apply until transfer is done.

instruction: What does 'property deemed to be transferred' mean in simple terms?
input:
Section no 413 . Property deemed to be transferred : If a person sells,
donates, gifts or otherwise transfers a property in which he or she has right
and ownership to another person, the property shall be deemed to have been
transferred to that other person.
output:
According to Section 413:
Rule: When someone actually sells, donates, gifts or otherwise transfers property they own to another person, the law treats that property as having been transferred to the recipient.
Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, once an owner completes a transfer (sale, gift, donation or similar act), the law will recognize the recipient as the new owner. The phrase simply clarifies that completed transfers result in legal ownership passing to the transferee.

instruction: Who is barred from transferring property under this law?
input:
Section no 414 . Property may be transferred : (1) Any person, other
than a person who is not competent to make contract pursuant to this Act or
120
laws in force, may, subject to this Act, transfer a property in which he or she
has right and ownership to one or more than one person jointly or severally.
output:
According to Section 414(1):
Rule: A person who is not competent to make a contract pursuant to this Act or laws in force cannot transfer property; otherwise competent persons may transfer property subject to the Act.
Application/Conclusion: Persons legally incompetent to contract (as defined elsewhere in law) are barred from transferring property. Competency is therefore a prerequisite for a valid transfer.

instruction: I discovered today that someone made a transfer affecting my rights years ago. How long do I have to sue?
input:
Statute of limitation : A lawsuit may be made within
the statute of limitation, if any, specified separately in this Chapter, within two
years after the date of maturation of one’s right in donation or gift received
by one and after the date of possession and enjoyment upon maturity of right
in a donation or gift incapable of being made, and, in relation to the other
cases, within one year after the date of knowledge of any act done or action
taken pursuant to this Chapter, by a person who is aggrieved from such an act
or action.
output:
According to Section (Statute of limitation):
Rule: Suits must be brought within the statute of limitation specified: generally within two years after maturation of rights in donations/gifts (or after possession/enjoyment when maturity occurs), and for other cases within one year after knowledge of the act or action that aggrieved the person.
Application/Conclusion: If your grievance relates to a donation or gift, you generally have two years from maturation/possession; for other kinds of acts under this Chapter you have one year from when you learned of the act. Calculate the relevant triggering date (maturation, possession, or date you gained knowledge) to determine whether your suit is time-barred.

instruction: Under which section is ownership passing to the buyer defined?
input:
Section no 416 . Ownership devolving on transferee of property : (1) If
any person transfers his or her property to another person pursuant to Section
414, his or her ownership in that property shall cease to exist from the date of
such transfer and the transferee shall have ownership in such property.
output:
According to Section 416(1):
Rule: When a person transfers property pursuant to Section 414, the transferor’s ownership ceases from the date of transfer and the transferee acquires ownership.
Application/Conclusion: Ownership passes to the transferee at the date of valid transfer under Section 414. For buyers or recipients, legal ownership exists from the effective transfer date specified by law.

instruction: Can a guardian sell property on behalf of a ward?
input:
Section no 415 . Power of guardian or curator to sell property : (1) A
guardian or curator may, subject to this Act, sell and transfer a property for
the rights, interests and protection of the person under his or her guardianship
or curatorship.
output:
According to Section 415(1):
Rule: A guardian or curator may, subject to the Act, sell and transfer property for the rights, interests and protection of the person under guardianship or curatorship.
Application/Conclusion: A guardian has statutory authority to sell or transfer property of the ward when acting in the ward's best interests and subject to the Act’s conditions. This allows guardians to manage property where necessary for protection of the ward’s rights and interests.

instruction: My guardian sold our house without getting court approval. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 415  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), except as otherwise provided in this Act, no immovable property may be
sold without permission of the court.
output:
According to Section 415(2):
Rule: Except as otherwise provided in the Act, no immovable property may be sold by a guardian without permission of the court.
Application/Conclusion: A sale of immovable property by a guardian without court permission is not permitted under Section 415(2). If your guardian sold the house without obtaining the court’s permission, that sale may be challengeable as unauthorized.

instruction: If someone transfers property with a will effect, when do they become owner?
input:
Section no 416  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if a person transfers the right in his or her property to be effective with
testament, the transferee shall have ownership in such property only after the
death of the transferor.
output:
According to Section 416(2):
Rule: If a transfer is made to be effective by testament, the transferee acquires ownership only after the death of the transferor.
Application/Conclusion: Where the transfer is testamentary (i.e., takes effect on death), the designated transferee does not obtain ownership while the transferor is alive; ownership vests only upon the transferor’s death.

instruction: If two or more people acquire the same property, how are shares determined?
input:
Section no 416  part (3) : If two or more persons acquire the same property,
they shall have that much entitlement to such property in proportion to their
respective portion.
output:
According to Section 416(3):
Rule: Multiple acquirers of the same property have entitlement in proportion to their respective portions.
Application/Conclusion: When multiple persons acquire the same property, each person’s share is determined proportionally according to the portions specified. Their entitlements are proportional to those portions.

instruction: If a deed is silent about how much each person gets, what happens?
input:
Section no 416  part (4) : If a deed does not indicate the portion to which a
person is entitled on the acquisition of a property, all the persons acquiring the
property shall be deemed to have acquired it equally.
output:
According to Section 416(4):
Rule: When a deed does not state each person’s portion on acquisition, all transferees are deemed to have acquired the property equally.
Application/Conclusion: If a transfer document omits the portion sizes, the law treats all transferees as having equal shares. You should assume equal division unless the deed or other evidence specifies otherwise.

instruction: Do I need to execute a deed to gift movable property worth Rs. 80,000?
input:
Section no 414  part (1) : It is not required to execute a deed to donate or gift
any movable property or cash amounting up to one hundred thousand rupees.
output:
According to Section 414(1) (Provided that):
Rule: It is not required to execute a deed to donate or gift any movable property or cash up to one hundred thousand rupees.
Application/Conclusion: For a movable gift or cash gift of Rs. 80,000, you do not need to execute a deed under this provision. The transfer can be effected without a formal deed for amounts up to Rs. 100,000.

instruction: Is sale of movable property governed differently? Do I need to follow other laws?
input:
Section no 414  part (2) : Sale or otherwise transfer of a movable property
shall be made in accordance with the laws in force.
output:
According to Section 414(2):
Rule: Sale or transfer of movable property must be carried out in accordance with the laws in force.
Application/Conclusion: Even if a deed is not required for small gifts, the sale or transfer of movable property must still comply with applicable laws and regulations. You should follow the relevant legal requirements for the specific movable property transaction.

instruction: If I transfer my property, when does my ownership end?
input:
Section no 416 . Ownership devolving on transferee of property : (1) If
any person transfers his or her property to another person pursuant to Section
414, his or her ownership in that property shall cease to exist from the date of
such transfer and the transferee shall have ownership in such property.
output:
According to Section 416(1):
Rule: The transferor’s ownership ceases from the date of the transfer under Section 414, and the transferee gains ownership.
Application/Conclusion: Your ownership ends on the effective date of a valid transfer. From that date the transferee is the owner.

instruction: Can I transfer property so that it takes effect immediately or only after my death?
input:
Section no 414  part (3) : A person may, pursuant to sub-section (1), transfer
a property in which he or she has right and ownership to another person with
immediate or testamentary effect.
output:
According to Section 414(3):
Rule: A person may transfer property with either immediate effect or testamentary (i.e., taking effect on death) effect.
Application/Conclusion: You may structure a transfer to take effect immediately (the transferee becomes owner upon transfer) or to be testamentary (ownership vests after your death). The law recognizes both forms of transfers.

instruction: If someone was mentally incompetent when they signed a transfer, does that matter?
input:
Section no 414  part (2) : The competency or incompetency referred to in sub
section (1) shall be determined on the basis of whether he or she was competent
or incompetent at the time of the transfer of property by him or her.
output:
According to Section 414(2):
Rule: Competency for transfer is judged based on whether the person was competent or incompetent at the time of the transfer.
Application/Conclusion: If a person lacked competency when the transfer was made, the transfer may be invalid. Competency is assessed at the exact time of transfer, so evidence of incompetency at that time is critical to challenge the transfer.

instruction: My neighbor says both of us acquired the same parcel — how do we split it?
input:
Section no 416  part (3) : If two or more persons acquire the same property,
they shall have that much entitlement to such property in proportion to their
respective portion.
output:
According to Section 416(3):
Rule: When two or more persons acquire the same property, their entitlements are in proportion to their respective portions.
Application/Conclusion: You and your neighbor’s shares depend on the proportions each of you acquired. If the portions are specified, split the property accordingly; if not specified, other provisions (e.g., Section 416(4)) may apply to determine equal division.

instruction: I inherited a house by my father's will. How long do I have to apply to register it in my name?
input: Section no 429  part (1) : If a person transfers his or her right in a property to another person with testamentary effect and such transferor of property dies, one who obtains the property shall submit an application, accompanied by the death registration certificate as well as other evidences, to the concerned oﬀice for the 234 transmission of the property to him or her, within six months after the date of the transferor’s death.
output:
According to Section 429(1)...
Rule: A person who obtains property by testament must submit an application to the concerned office, with the death registration certificate and other evidence, within six months of the transferor's death.
Application/Conclusion: Since you inherited the house by will, you must apply to have it transmitted to you within six months from your father's date of death, including the death registration certificate and other supporting evidence.

instruction: I found out about my uncle's death 9 months after he died. Can I still get the land he left me? Will I pay anything?
input:
Section no 429  part (1) : If a person transfers his or her right in a property to another person with testamentary effect and such transferor of property dies, one who obtains the property shall submit an application, accompanied by the death registration certificate as well as other evidences, to the concerned oﬀice for the 234 transmission of the property to him or her, within six months after the date of the transferor’s death.
 Section no 429  part (4) : If any person submits an application to the oﬀice for the transmission after the expiration of the time-limit referred to in sub-section (1), the oﬀice shall transmit such property to the applicant in accordance with such a deed, by collecting the fees by five hundred rupees for each year after the expiration of the time limit.
output:
According to Section 429(1) and Section 429(4)...
Rule: The general rule is you must apply within six months with required documents. If you apply after that time-limit, the office will still transmit the property but will collect fees of five hundred rupees for each year after the time-limit's expiration.
Application/Conclusion: Because you are applying 9 months after your uncle's death (i.e., after six months), you can still have the property transmitted to you, but the office will charge a fee of 500 rupees for each year (or part of a year) past the six-month deadline.

instruction: What does the registration office check when I submit my application for a testamentary transfer?
input: Section no 429  part (2) : If an application is submitted pursuant to subsection  Section no 429  part (1) : , the concerned oﬀice shall examine the deed maintained in it and make necessary inquiry as to whether the deed executor has died or not and the deed is void or not.
output:
According to Section 429(2)...
Rule: Upon an application, the concerned office must examine the deed on record and inquire whether the deed executor (transferor) has died and whether the deed has been voided.
Application/Conclusion: When you submit your application, expect the office to review the deed and investigate whether the transferor is indeed deceased and whether anyone has voided the deed before transmitting the property.

instruction: The office says my father died and didn't void the deed — will they give me the property?
input: Section no 429  part (3) : If, upon an inquiry made pursuant to sub-section (2), it appears that the transferor of the property has died and has not got the deed voided, such property shall be transmitted to the applicant.
output:
According to Section 429(3)...
Rule: If the office's inquiry shows the transferor has died and the deed has not been voided, the property must be transmitted to the applicant.
Application/Conclusion: Because their inquiry found your father died and did not void the deed, the office is required to transmit the property to you as the applicant.

instruction: I bought a shop last year. Now the seller says it was damaged before sale. Can I claim a refund?
input: Section no 430 . Not to claim for damage, destroy or low quality : A person who has once purchased a property from another person shall not be entitled to make a claim that such property is damaged, destroyed or of low quality. Provided that if the seller has sold the property by misrepresentation 125 or with deviation from the particulars set forth in the deed, the purchaser shall be entitled to compensation for the same.
output:
According to Section 430...
Rule: Generally a buyer cannot later claim that the purchased property is damaged, destroyed, or of low quality; however, if the seller sold the property by misrepresentation or deviated from the deed's particulars, the purchaser is entitled to compensation.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot claim a refund merely because the shop is damaged unless you can prove the seller misrepresented its condition or deviated from what was stated in the deed. If you can prove misrepresentation or deviation, you may seek compensation.

instruction: Can I exchange my plot for my cousin's plot and do I need any special papers?
input:
Section no 431 .Property may be exchanged : (1) Any person may exchange his or her property with another person with or without adding any amount. 235
 Section no 431  part (2) : A deed shall be executed in accordance with law in exchanging a property pursuant to this Act.
output:
According to Section 431(1) and Section 431(2)...
Rule: Any person may exchange property with another (with or without paying additional amount), and such an exchange must be effected by executing a deed in accordance with law.
Application/Conclusion: Yes, you can exchange your plot for your cousin's plot. You must execute a legally valid deed for the exchange, following the procedures required by law.

instruction: Can I sell my land to a foreign friend who wants it for a house?
input: Section no 432 . Restriction on transfer of immovable property to foreigner : (1) No person shall, without obtaining prior permission of the Government of Nepal, transfer any immovable property to a foreigner but for the person who has acquired the non-resident citizenship of Nepal, it will be according to prevailing law.
output:
According to Section 432(1)...
Rule: No person may transfer immovable property to a foreigner without prior permission of the Government of Nepal; an exception exists for persons who have acquired non-resident Nepali citizenship as per prevailing law.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot directly sell your land to your foreign friend unless you first obtain prior permission from the Government of Nepal (or the buyer holds non-resident Nepali citizenship and the prevailing law permits it).

instruction: What happens if someone transfers land to a foreigner without getting government permission?
input: Section no 432  part (2) : If any person transfers any immovable property to a foreigner in contravention of sub-section (1), the relevant deed shall ipso facto be void, and such property shall devolve on the Government of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 432(2)...
Rule: A transfer of immovable property to a foreigner made in contravention of the prior-permission requirement is ipso facto void, and the property shall devolve on the Government of Nepal.
Application/Conclusion: If someone transfers property to a foreigner without government permission, that deed is automatically void and the property will pass to the Government of Nepal rather than the foreigner.

instruction: I financed a foreign buyer so they could buy a house — what is my legal status over that investment?
input: Section no 432  part (3) : The amount invested by the creditor in the obtainment of an immovable property pursuant to sub-section (1) shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali).
output:
According to Section 432(3)...
Rule: Any amount invested by a creditor to help obtain immovable property under the subsection dealing with transfers to foreigners is treated as an unsecured bond (Kapali).
Application/Conclusion: Your investment will be treated as an unsecured claim (Kapali) against the person, not as a secured interest in the property. You would not have proprietary rights over the immovable property itself.

instruction: A foreigner got a share of land in partition in our family — can their name be registered and can they collect rent?
input: Section no 433 . Foreigner to transfer partition share or inheritance, if any : obtained: (1) If any foreigner obtains a partition share in or succeeds to any immovable property in Nepal, the property shall not be eligible to be transferred to or registered in his or her name nor shall he or she be entitled to enjoy the income of that property, except where so permitted by the Government of Nepal. Provided that this provision shall not apply to a person who has obtained non-resident Nepali citizenship.
output:
According to Section 433(1)...
Rule: A foreigner who obtains a partition share or succeeds to immovable property in Nepal cannot have that property transferred or registered in their name, nor enjoy its income, except if the Government of Nepal permits; this does not apply to those with non-resident Nepali citizenship.
Application/Conclusion: The foreigner cannot be registered as owner nor collect income from the property unless the Government of Nepal grants permission. If they hold non-resident Nepali citizenship, this restriction does not apply.

instruction: Under which section is the restriction on transferring immovable property to foreigners stated?
input: Section no 432 . Restriction on transfer of immovable property to foreigner : (1) No person shall, without obtaining prior permission of the Government of Nepal, transfer any immovable property to a foreigner but for the person who has acquired the non-resident citizenship of Nepal, it will be according to prevailing law.
output:
According to Section 432(1)...
Rule: Section 432 sets out the restriction: immovable property cannot be transferred to a foreigner without prior Government of Nepal permission (with the non-resident Nepali citizenship exception under prevailing law).
Application/Conclusion: The restriction you asked about is contained in Section 432 of the Act; it requires government permission before transferring immovable property to a foreigner.

instruction: Seller lied about the plot size in the deed. Can I get compensation?
input: Section no 430 . Not to claim for damage, destroy or low quality : A person who has once purchased a property from another person shall not be entitled to make a claim that such property is damaged, destroyed or of low quality. Provided that if the seller has sold the property by misrepresentation 125 or with deviation from the particulars set forth in the deed, the purchaser shall be entitled to compensation for the same.
output:
According to Section 430...
Rule: While purchasers generally cannot claim defects in quality, if the seller sold the property by misrepresentation or deviated from the particulars in the deed, the purchaser is entitled to compensation.
Application/Conclusion: Because the seller misrepresented the plot size (a deviation from deed particulars), you are entitled to claim compensation for that misrepresentation.

instruction: My relative drew up a deed leaving property to me when he dies. He told others later he revoked it before death. How will the office check that?
input: Section no 429  part (2) : If an application is submitted pursuant to subsection  Section no 429  part (1) : , the concerned oﬀice shall examine the deed maintained in it and make necessary inquiry as to whether the deed executor has died or not and the deed is void or not.
output:
According to Section 429(2)...
Rule: The office must examine the deed on record and make necessary inquiries as to whether the deed executor has died and whether the deed has been voided.
Application/Conclusion: When you apply, the office will review the deed and investigate claims that the deed was revoked before death; if the inquiry shows the deed was voided prior to death, that will affect transmission, but if not, the property may be transmitted to you.

instruction: I got a property via testamentary deed but my relative tried to void the deed before dying. If they didn't legally void it, do I still get it?
input: Section no 429  part (3) : If, upon an inquiry made pursuant to sub-section (2), it appears that the transferor of the property has died and has not got the deed voided, such property shall be transmitted to the applicant.
output:
According to Section 429(3)...
Rule: If the inquiry shows the transferor died and did not have the deed voided, the property shall be transmitted to the applicant.
Application/Conclusion: If the inquiry finds that your relative died without legally voiding the deed, then the office is obliged to transmit the property to you despite any attempted revocation that was not completed.

instruction: If I exchange my flat with someone else, do we need to formalize it somehow?
input: Section no 431  part (2) : A deed shall be executed in accordance with law in exchanging a property pursuant to this Act.
output:
According to Section 431(2)...
Rule: Any property exchange must be formalized by executing a deed in accordance with law.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — when you exchange flats, you must execute a legally valid deed that follows the statutory requirements to effect the exchange.

instruction: A buyer claims later the property I sold was low quality. Can they demand return unless I misrepresented?
input: Section no 430 . Not to claim for damage, destroy or low quality : A person who has once purchased a property from another person shall not be entitled to make a claim that such property is damaged, destroyed or of low quality. Provided that if the seller has sold the property by misrepresentation 125 or with deviation from the particulars set forth in the deed, the purchaser shall be entitled to compensation for the same.
output:
According to Section 430...
Rule: Purchasers generally cannot claim that a purchased property is damaged or of low quality after the sale; however, if the seller misrepresented the property or deviated from deed particulars, the purchaser can claim compensation.
Application/Conclusion: The buyer cannot demand a return or remedy solely on the ground of low quality unless you misrepresented the property's condition or deviated from what was stated in the deed. If misrepresentation is proven, the buyer may get compensation.

instruction: Can I open my rented house myself if the ward office ignores my application?
input: Section no 404  part (6) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, if the concerned ward oﬀice of the Local Level does not take any action even within one month of the application submitted to it, the concerned house-owner shall submit an application to the concerned ward oﬀice and the nearby police oﬀice, and execute a deed and open the house in witness of a police employee and at least two local persons, and hand over the custody of the tenant’s goods to the police.
output: According to Section 404(6): Rule: If the concerned ward office does not act within one month of your application, the house-owner may submit an application to the ward office and nearby police, execute a deed, open the house in the presence of a police employee and at least two local persons, and hand the tenant’s goods to the police. Application/Conclusion: If you have waited one month after filing the application and the ward took no action, you may follow this procedure — apply to the ward and nearby police, execute the deed in the stated witnesses, open the house in the presence of police and two locals, and place the tenant’s goods in police custody.

instruction: How many days must the ward office give a tenant to appear after a notice?
input: Section no 404  part (1) : , the concerned ward oﬀice shall make a public notice inviting the tenant to appear within a period of fifteen days.
output: According to Section 404(1): Rule: The concerned ward office shall make a public notice inviting the tenant to appear within a period of fifteen days. Application/Conclusion: The tenant must be given 15 days to appear from the public notice.

instruction: A notice was published under subsection (2). How long does the tenant have to appear?
input: Section no 404  part (3) : If a notice is published pursuant to sub-section (2), the tenant shall appear within such a period. 221
output: According to Section 404(3): Rule: If a notice is published pursuant to subsection (2), the tenant shall appear within the period specified in that notice. Application/Conclusion: The tenant must appear within the period stated in the published notice (i.e., the timeframe set by the notice under subsection (2)).

instruction: What can the ward office do if the tenant fails to appear in the time required?
input: Section no 404  part (4) : If such a person does not appear within the period referred to in sub-section (3), the concerned ward oﬀice may open and vacate the rented house, upon having the goods therein in its or any one’s custody.
output: According to Section 404(4): Rule: If the person does not appear within the period referred to in subsection (3), the ward office may open and vacate the rented house and take custody of the goods therein. Application/Conclusion: If the tenant fails to appear in time, the ward office is authorized to open and vacate the rented premises and place the tenant’s goods in its or another’s custody.

instruction: I disappeared from my rented house but want my belongings back. What are my rights if I return?
input: Section no 404  part (5) : If the person who has disappeared pursuant to sub section (3) returns or sends his or her agent within six months, the concerned ward oﬀice shall collect the due rent from, and return the goods to him or her.
output: According to Section 404(5): Rule: If the person who disappeared pursuant to subsection (3) returns or sends an agent within six months, the ward office shall collect the due rent and return the goods. Application/Conclusion: If you return (or send an agent) within six months, you must pay the due rent and the ward office is required to return your belongings.

instruction: I found out about this action today. How long do I have to file a lawsuit about acts under this Chapter?

instruction: Explain in simple words: what's the difference between a mortgage with possession and without possession?
input:
Section no 435  part (2) : If the deed provides that the creditor is entitled
to possess the property mortgaged pursuant to sub-section (1) with immediate
effect at the time of lending or after a certain period, such a mortgage shall
be deemed to be a mortgage with possession ( Bhogbandaki ), and if the deed
provides that the creditor is entitled to possess the property in the event of
the debtor’s default on repayment of the loan within the deadline set by the
creditor and the debtor for repayment, such a mortgage shall be deemed to be
a mortgage without possession ( Drishtibandhaki ).
output: According to Section 435(2), the rule is that a mortgage with possession (Bhogbandaki) arises when the deed gives the creditor the right to possess the property immediately or after a specified date; a mortgage without possession (Drishtibandhaki) arises when the creditor’s right to possess is triggered only upon the debtor’s default within the agreed repayment deadline. Applied to your situation: if your loan contract says the lender can take possession now or from a set date, it's a mortgage with possession; if the lender can only take possession if you default, it's a mortgage without possession.

instruction: My creditor says they can possess the house immediately after we sign the mortgage. Is that allowed?
input:

ownership or possession to a creditor in consideration for a loan which the debtor
borrows from the creditor, entitling the creditor to possess that property with
effect from the date of execution of the deed or after a certain period, such
property shall be deemed to have been given in mortgage.
output: According to Section 435(1), the rule is that if a debtor gives immovable property to a creditor as security for a loan and the creditor is entitled to possess the property from the date of the deed or after a certain period, that arrangement is a valid mortgage. Applied to your situation: yes — if you, as debtor, agreed in the deed that the creditor can possess the house from the execution date (and you had right/ownership/possession to mortgage), this is a recognized mortgage with possession under the law.

instruction: I bought a house but later found the sale was invalid. Can I get my money back and interest?

Application/Conclusion: Yes — when the owner claims the painting you must return it, but you may lawfully recover reasonable expenses you incurred to preserve or maintain it while it was in your custody.

instruction: I bought a stolen antique unknowingly at a public bidding. The original owner wants it back but I paid a lot. Am I protected?
input: Section no 421  part (6) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (4), if a person has acquired any stolen or lost property by way of purchase at a public market or auction or bidding made publicly by any person or body, the person shall not be bound to return such property to the real owner unless and until he or she obtains the real value of such property and the fees or amount, if any, paid by him or her in the acquisition of such property.
output: According to Section 421(6): Rule: Purchasers who acquire lost or stolen property through public market, auction, or public bidding are not required to return it to the real owner until they obtain the real value and the fees or amounts they paid to acquire it. Application/Conclusion: You are protected in that you need not surrender the antique immediately; you can keep it until you recover the amount you legitimately paid and any related fees. Only after that are you obliged to return it to the original owner under this provision.

instruction: My neighbour sold the same plot to two people and one sale was registered earlier. Who gets the plot?
input: Section no 422  part (2) : If any person transfers a property in contravention of sub-section (1), the deed of transfer registered at an earlier date shall get legal validity if the transfer of an immovable property has been made, and if the transfer of a movable property has been made, the transfer to the person who acquires the property earlier shall be valid.
output: According to Section 422(2): Rule: For immovable property, the earlier-registered deed obtains legal validity. Application/Conclusion: Since a plot is immovable property, the person whose deed was registered earlier has the legally valid transfer and thus the superior claim to the plot.

instruction: I paid for a land and lost possession because the transfer was void. Do I get interest on my money while deprived?
input: Section no 424 . Entitlement to amount or compensation in event of deprivation : of enjoyment of property: (1) If a person transfers a property by way of sale pursuant to this Chapter and the purchaser is deprived of enjoying the property wholly or partly because of such transfer being invalid for any reason, the purchaser shall be entitled to recover from the transferor the amount paid by him or her for the property to the extent that he or she is so deprived of enjoying, an interest to be set by yearly ten percent of the amount and the registration fee or other amount, if any, he or she has paid for the transfer of that property as if it were an unsecured bond ( Kapali ).
output: According to Section 424(1): Rule: The purchaser deprived of enjoyment due to an invalid transfer can recover the amount paid, plus yearly interest set at 10%, and registration or other paid amounts, treated like an unsecured bond. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you are entitled to recover your payment plus 10% annual interest and any registration fees or similar amounts you paid, to compensate for your deprivation.

instruction: After a sale was declared invalid, the buyer couldn't remove his shop within six months. Can he still claim compensation?
input: Section no 424  part (3) : If any person is aggrieved from the transfer of a property in contravention of Sections 419, 421 and 422 or the failure to demolish and take away any structure pursuant to sub section (2), such a person shall also be entitled to a reasonable compensation for actual loss and damage suffered by him or her from such transferor, in addition to the amount referred to in sub section (1).
output: According to Section 424(3): Rule: A person aggrieved by a transfer violating certain sections or by failure to remove structures under subsection (2) is entitled to reasonable compensation for actual loss and damage, in addition to amounts under subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: If the buyer could not demolish and remove the shop within six months and suffered loss, they can claim reasonable compensation for actual losses from the transferor, on top of the monetary recovery provided by subsection (1).

instruction: Under which section do I find the rule that a guardian cannot gift their ward's property?
input: Section no 423 . Donation or gift incapable of being effected by guardian or : curator: No guardian or curator may donate or gift any property 231 belonging to the person under his or her guardianship or curatorship to any person.
output: According to Section 423: Rule: A guardian or curator may not donate or gift any property belonging to the person under their guardianship or curatorship. Application/Conclusion: The prohibition on gifting a ward's property by a guardian is laid down in Section 423, so any such gift would be impermissible under that section.

instruction: I purchased furniture first; someone else later claimed they were sold to them earlier. Which transfer is valid for movable goods?
input: Section no 422  part (2) : If any person transfers a property in contravention of sub-section (1), the deed of transfer registered at an earlier date shall get legal validity if the transfer of an immovable property has been made, and if the transfer of a movable property has been made, the transfer to the person who acquires the property earlier shall be valid.
output: According to Section 422(2): Rule: For movable property, when duplicate transfers occur, the transfer to the person who acquires the property earlier is valid. Application/Conclusion: Because furniture is movable, whoever acquired it earlier has the valid transfer; your later purchase may be subordinate to the earlier acquirer's rights.

instruction: Can I get compensation if a donated property becomes unusable for me?
input:

output: According to Section 424(4): Rule: If a person who may be entitled to, or is entitled to, a donation or gift is aggrieved by being unable to use the property for any reason under this Chapter, that person is entitled to reasonable compensation from the donor, subject to other sections of the Chapter; however, compensation cannot be recovered where a testamentary gift is void. Application/Conclusion: If you were the intended donee (or entitled) and cannot use the donated property under the Chapter's rules, you can claim reasonable compensation from the person who made the donation, unless the gift was testamentary and is void.

Application/Conclusion: Because the buyer took the property knowing it was stolen/another's property, they are not entitled to recover compensation referred to in subsections (1), (3) and (4).

instruction: I bought a plot but it had already been transferred to someone else before—can I claim the compensation mentioned in the law?

Application/Conclusion: Since you obtained the property with knowledge that it had already been transferred to someone else, you are not entitled to recover compensation under those subsections.

instruction: My father is abroad and appointed my cousin to sell his house. Is that appointment valid so my cousin can sell and transfer the immovable property?
input:
Section no 425 . Right in property may be transferred by attorney
: (1) If a person appoints another person, who is competent to be an attorney
in accordance with law, as his or her authorized attorney indicating the reason
that he or she is not able to appear in person before the concerned oﬀice in order
to sell and transfer his or her immovable property, such an authorized attorney
may, on his or her behalf, sell and transfer his or her property to another person.
output: According to Section 425(1): Rule: A person may appoint another who is competent to be an attorney under law as an authorized attorney—if the appointing person cannot appear in person before the concerned office to sell and transfer immovable property— and that authorized attorney may sell and transfer the immovable property on behalf of the appointing person. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin is legally competent to act as an attorney and was validly appointed because your father cannot appear in person, your cousin may lawfully sell and transfer the immovable property on your father's behalf.

instruction: Can my agent sell my motorbike for me?
input:

through his or her attorney or agent.
output: According to Section 425(2): Rule: A person may sell movable property through an attorney or agent. Application/Conclusion: Yes — your agent may sell your motorbike on your behalf, provided the agency/authorization is valid under law.

instruction: Our board passed a resolution giving a director power to transfer a company building. Is that director empowered to transfer the immovable property on behalf of the company?
input:
Section no 426 . Procedure to be followed by body corporate while
purchasing : or transferring property: (1) If, in transferring an immovable
property held in the name of a body corporate established in accordance with
law, the board of directors of such a body gives power by a decision to any
member of the board of directors or 233 employee of such a body to transfer
the property, such a person may transfer the property on behalf of such a body.
output: According to Section 426(1): Rule: If the board of directors of a body corporate gives power by decision to any board member or employee to transfer immovable property held in the name of the corporate body, that person may transfer the property on behalf of the body. Application/Conclusion: Because the board passed the resolution conferring that power, the designated director is authorized to transfer the company building on behalf of the corporate body, subject to whatever internal or statutory formalities otherwise apply.

instruction: If the company's procedures are followed, can the company purchase land in its own name?
input:
Section no 426  part (2) : If the procedure referred to in sub-section (1) is
fulfilled while purchasing or otherwise obtaining an immovable property in the
name of a corporate body, the property may be purchased or obtained in the
name of such a body.
output: According to Section 426(2): Rule: If the procedure in subsection (1) (i.e., board decision granting authority) is fulfilled when purchasing or obtaining immovable property, the property may be purchased or obtained in the name of the corporate body. Application/Conclusion: If your company followed the procedure described (board decision etc.), the company may lawfully purchase and have the immovable property recorded in the company's name.

instruction: I live abroad and cannot appear to register my land purchase. If I give someone power of attorney and my citizenship certificate, can they complete the purchase for me?
input:
Section no 427 .
Property may be purchased or obtained by other
person on : one’s behalf: If, except the circumstance set forth in Section 426,
a person who purchases or obtains a property in accordance with this Chapter
is, for any reason, unable to appear in person before the concerned oﬀice and
gives a power of attorney, accompanied by his or her citizenship certificate, to
a person who is competent to be an attorney by law in relation to the purchase
or obtainment of the property, such an attorney may purchase or obtain the
property in the name of that person.
output: According to Section 427: Rule: Where a person (other than in the Section 426 corporate situation) is unable to appear in person, they may give a power of attorney accompanied by their citizenship certificate to a person competent to be an attorney by law, and that attorney may purchase or obtain the property in the name of the principal. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you provide a valid power of attorney accompanied by your citizenship certificate to a person competent to be an attorney, that person may complete the purchase and register the property in your name.

instruction: Can a guardian buy land for a minor or for a baby who is still in the womb?
input:
Section no 428 . Property may be purchased or obtained in the name
of : incompetent or quasi-competent person: A guardian or curator may acquire
any property by way of donation, gift, purchase or otherwise for incompetent,
quasi competent minor or a guardian or member of undivided family for the
baby in the womb under his or her guardianship or curatorship.
output: According to Section 428: Rule: A guardian or curator may acquire any property by donation, gift, purchase or otherwise for an incompetent or quasi-competent minor; and a guardian or member of an undivided family may acquire property for a baby in the womb under their guardianship or curatorship. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a guardian may lawfully acquire property on behalf of a minor or for an unborn baby under their guardianship, using donation, purchase, gift or other lawful means.

instruction: What exactly can an 'authorized attorney' do for immovable property — in plain terms?
input:
Section no 425 . Right in property may be transferred by attorney
: (1) If a person appoints another person, who is competent to be an attorney
in accordance with law, as his or her authorized attorney indicating the reason
that he or she is not able to appear in person before the concerned oﬀice in order
to sell and transfer his or her immovable property, such an authorized attorney
may, on his or her behalf, sell and transfer his or her property to another person.
output: According to Section 425(1): Rule: Where someone appoints a person competent to be an attorney because they cannot appear in person before the relevant office, that authorized attorney may sell and transfer the appointor's immovable property on their behalf. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, an authorized attorney (if legally competent and properly appointed) can act for you to sell and transfer your land or building when you cannot appear yourself.

instruction: Ram promised to donate his field to me but later allowed someone else to use it and I can't. What remedy does the law offer?

output: According to Section 424(4): Rule: A person entitled or potentially entitled to a donation/gift who is aggrieved by being unable to use the property under this Chapter is entitled to reasonable compensation from the donor, subject to other sections; but compensation is not recoverable for a void testamentary gift. Application/Conclusion: If Ram was the donor and you were entitled (or may be entitled) to the donated field but are now prevented from using it, you can seek reasonable compensation from Ram under Section 424(4), unless the donation was testamentary and void.

instruction: If someone obtained property under circumstances listed in subsection (5), can they recover the amounts referred to in subsections (1), (3) and (4)?

Application/Conclusion: If a person obtained the property while knowing it belonged to someone else or was stolen, they cannot recover the compensation or amounts set out in subsections (1), (3) or (4).

instruction: Is there a specific requirement that the power of attorney be accompanied by my citizenship certificate when I authorize someone to buy property for me?

is, for any reason, unable to appear in person before the concerned oﬀice and
gives a power of attorney, accompanied by his or her citizenship certificate, to
a person who is competent to be an attorney by law in relation to the purchase
or obtainment of the property, such an attorney may purchase or obtain the

output: According to Section 427: Rule: The provision requires that the power of attorney given for purchase/obtainment of property be accompanied by the principal's citizenship certificate and be given to a person competent to be an attorney by law; only then may the attorney act to purchase in the principal's name. Application/Conclusion: Yes — Section 427 prescribes that the power of attorney should be accompanied by your citizenship certificate; without that accompaniment (or without a competent attorney), the attorney would not have the statutory authorization described here.

instruction: Can a member of an undivided family buy property for a baby still in the mother's womb?

output: According to Section 428: Rule: A guardian or curator may acquire property for an incompetent or quasi-competent minor; likewise, a guardian or member of an undivided family may acquire property for a baby in the womb under their guardianship/curatorship. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a member of an undivided family (or guardian) may lawfully obtain property for an unborn baby under the stated guardianship/curatorship rules.

instruction: Under which section is the rule 'Right in property may be transferred by attorney' found?

output: According to Section 425: Rule: Section 425 sets out the right in property to be transferred by an attorney — allowing a competent authorized attorney (appointed when the principal cannot appear) to sell and transfer immovable property on the principal's behalf. Application/Conclusion: The rule 'Right in property may be transferred by attorney' is contained in Section 425; it explains when and how an authorized attorney may effect sale/transfer of immovable property.

instruction: The company board gave a power of decision to an employee to transfer land. Can that employee transfer the land on behalf of the company?

purchasing : or transferring property: (1) If, in transferring an immovable

law, the board of directors of such a body gives power by a decision to any
member of the board of directors or 233 employee of such a body to transfer
the property, such a person may transfer the property on behalf of such a body.
output: According to Section 426(1): Rule: If the board of directors gives power by decision to a board member or employee to transfer immovable property held in the corporate name, that person may transfer the property on behalf of the corporate body. Application/Conclusion: Yes — where the board properly conferred that power by decision, the named employee may lawfully transfer the land on the company's behalf, subject to compliance with any other legal/formal requirements.

instruction: Can I sue if the debtor refuses to let me (as creditor) possess the mortgaged property?
input: or if the debtor does not allow, by any means, the creditor to possess and enjoy it, the creditor may make a lawsuit in accordance with law for effecting the possession and enjoyment of such property.
output: According to Section 437(1): Rule: If the debtor prevents the creditor from possessing and enjoying the mortgaged property, the creditor may bring a lawsuit under law to obtain possession and enjoyment. Application/Conclusion: If you are the creditor and the debtor is actively obstructing your possession or enjoyment of the mortgaged property, you have the statutory right to file a lawsuit to enforce possession and enjoyment.

instruction: What happens if I (creditor) neither take possession nor sue to take possession of a mortgaged property?
input: If the creditor fails to possess and enjoy the property pursuant to sub-section (1) or to make a lawsuit for effecting its possession and enjoyment pursuant to sub-section (2), such a mortgage shall ipso facto be inoperative.
output: According to Section 437(3): Rule: If the creditor does not take possession or bring a lawsuit to obtain possession/enjoyment as required, the mortgage becomes ipso facto inoperative. Application/Conclusion: If you (as creditor) fail to possess the property and also fail to sue to obtain possession, the mortgage will automatically become inoperative and you lose the special effect of that mortgage.

instruction: If the mortgage deed becomes inoperative, what legal status does the deed have?
input: If the deed of a mortgage becomes inoperative pursuant to sub-section (3), the deed shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond ( Kapali ).
output: According to Section 437(4): Rule: An inoperative mortgage deed is treated as equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali). Application/Conclusion: If your mortgage becomes inoperative under subsection (3), the security is lost and the deed will be treated as an unsecured debt instrument, meaning you no longer have the advantages of a mortgage security.

instruction: From when does the creditor get possessory rights over mortgaged property?
input: If any person mortgages any property, the possessory right in such property shall be deemed to have been transferred to the creditor from the date of its possession and enjoyment by the creditor. 239
output: According to Section 438: Rule: Possessory right is deemed transferred to the creditor from the date the creditor takes possession and enjoyment of the mortgaged property. Application/Conclusion: You (as creditor) obtain possessory rights only from the date you actually possess and enjoy the mortgaged property; prior to that date, that deemed transfer has not occurred.

instruction: Can a creditor use the possession like it's their own — take fruits or benefits from it?
input: The creditor shall be entitled to possess and enjoy the property mortgaged to him or her and fruit, benefit and facility brought out from such property as if the same were his or her own property.
output: According to Section 439(1): Rule: A creditor is entitled to possess and enjoy the mortgaged property and to take fruits, benefits and facilities from it as if it were their own property. Application/Conclusion: If you have proper possession, you may use or take benefits from the mortgaged property in the same manner as an owner, subject to other law and the terms of the mortgage deed.

instruction: The debtor is blocking me from taking possession. Do I get compensation?
input: If the creditor is not able to possess and enjoy the property mortgaged to him or her because of its incapability of being transferred or of any hindrance or obstruction by the debtor, the debtor shall pay a reasonable compensation to the creditor for the same.
output: According to Section 439(2): Rule: If the creditor cannot possess/enjoy the mortgaged property due to transfer incapability or hindrance/obstruction by the debtor, the debtor must pay reasonable compensation to the creditor. Application/Conclusion: If the debtor's actions prevent you from possessing or enjoying the property, you are entitled to seek reasonable compensation from the debtor for the loss.

instruction: Once I take possession of the mortgaged property, what duties do I have regarding its care?
input: After acquiring possessory right in the mortgaged property, the creditor shall take a reasonable care and protection of that property as if it were his or her own.
output: According to Section 440(1): Rule: After obtaining possessory right, the creditor must take reasonable care and protection of the mortgaged property as if it were their own. Application/Conclusion: If you take possession, you must maintain and protect the property responsibly; neglect or damage could expose you to liability for failing this duty.

instruction: Who pays taxes and land revenue when a creditor possesses the mortgaged property?
input: The creditor himself or herself shall pay the tax or charge, if any, payable by law for the possession and enjoyment of the mortgaged property. Provided that the debtor shall pay the land revenue payable by law.
output: According to Section 440(2): Rule: The creditor must pay taxes/charges related to possession and enjoyment; the debtor remains responsible for land revenue. Application/Conclusion: If you as creditor are in possession, you must pay applicable possession/enjoyment taxes, while the debtor still must pay land revenue as required by law.

instruction: Someone other than the debtor is preventing my possession. Can I sue them?
input: If the creditor is not able to possess and enjoy the mortgaged property because of any hindrance or obstruction by any person other than the debtor, the creditor may make a lawsuit in accordance with law for its possession and enjoyment.
output: According to Section 440(3): Rule: If a third party (not the debtor) obstructs the creditor's possession/enjoyment, the creditor may sue that person to obtain possession/enjoyment. Application/Conclusion: You may file a lawsuit against the third-party obstructer to secure possession and enjoyment of the mortgaged property.

instruction: I gave a loan against mortgage with possession. Can I still charge interest from the debtor?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Act, no creditor who has lent money against the security of mortgage with possession in a 240 property shall collect any kind of interest, charge or fee in consideration of such loan from the debtor.
output: According to Section 441(1): Rule: A creditor who lent money against a mortgage with possession may not collect any interest, charge or fee from the debtor for that loan. Application/Conclusion: If you provided the loan secured by a mortgage where you have possession, you cannot legally collect interest or other charges from the debtor on that loan.

instruction: After I acquired possession though the mortgage was originally 'without possession', can I collect interest?
input: After the creditor has acquired possession in the property of mortgage without possession, the creditor shall not collect any kind of interest, charge or fee in consideration for such loan.
output: According to Section 441(2): Rule: Even if a creditor acquires possession later in a mortgage that was initially without possession, the creditor still may not collect interest, charges or fees for the loan. Application/Conclusion: If you later take possession of a property that was mortgaged without initial possession, you are still barred from charging interest or fees on that loan.

instruction: How long can a mortgage with possession last? Is there a maximum?
input: Except as otherwise provided in the deed of mortgage, no property in mortgage with possession may be possessed and enjoyed for a period exceeding ten years.
output: According to Section 442(1): Rule: Unless the mortgage deed says otherwise, possession and enjoyment of a mortgaged property with possession cannot exceed ten years. Application/Conclusion: By default, you cannot possess and enjoy a mortgaged property with possession for more than ten years unless the mortgage deed specifically provides a different term.

instruction: If the mortgaged property with possession is not redeemed within the allowed period, what happens to the mortgage deed?
input: If the property in mortgage with possession is not redeemed within the period referred to in sub-section (1), the deed of mortgage shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond.
output: According to Section 442(2): Rule: If a mortgage with possession is not redeemed within the ten-year period under subsection (1), the deed becomes equivalent to an unsecured bond. Application/Conclusion: If the mortgaged property with possession is not redeemed within the allowed period, your mortgage security is lost and the deed will be treated as an unsecured debt instrument.

instruction: What's the maximum duration for a mortgage without possession?
input: No period of a mortgage without possession in a property shall exceed five years.
output: According to Section 443(1): Rule: A mortgage without possession cannot have a period exceeding five years. Application/Conclusion: If you enter a mortgage without possession, its maximum lawful duration is five years; any longer term would exceed this statutory limit.

instruction: My creditor never took possession and never sued. Is my mortgage still enforceable or is it treated like a regular debt?
input: If the creditor fails to possess and enjoy the property pursuant to sub-section (1) or to make a lawsuit for effecting its possession and enjoyment pursuant to sub-section (2), such a mortgage shall ipso facto be inoperative.
output: According to Section 437(3): Rule: Failure by the creditor to possess or sue to obtain possession renders the mortgage ipso facto inoperative. Application/Conclusion: Since the creditor did neither, the mortgage would become inoperative and would no longer function as a secured mortgage; effectively it will be treated as not providing security.

instruction: I was told I can use produce from property I hold as a creditor — is that actually written anywhere?
input: The creditor shall be entitled to possess and enjoy the property mortgaged to him or her and fruit, benefit and facility brought out from such property as if the same were his or her own property.
output: According to Section 439(1): Rule: The creditor is entitled to possess and enjoy the mortgaged property and to take its fruits, benefits and facilities as if it were their own. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the law explicitly permits a creditor in possession to use or take produce/benefits from the property in the same way an owner would.

instruction: If a mortgage converts into an unsecured bond, where is that stated?
input: If the deed of a mortgage becomes inoperative pursuant to sub-section (3), the deed shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond ( Kapali ).
output: According to Section 437(4): Rule: When a mortgage deed becomes inoperative under subsection (3), it is equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali). Application/Conclusion: The statute explicitly provides that an inoperative mortgage deed is treated as an unsecured bond; this is the legal basis for conversion from secured to unsecured status.

instruction: Can a creditor immediately take possession of my mortgaged land if I haven't repaid yet?

possession in the property in mortgage without possession or having recovery of
the related loan from the debtor prior to the completion of the period referred

output: According to Section 443(2): Rule: A creditor may not take action to effect possession of mortgaged property (where mortgage was made without possession) or seek recovery of the loan from the debtor until the period in subsection (1) has completed. Application/Conclusion: If your mortgage was created without giving possession to the creditor, the creditor cannot lawfully take possession or enforce recovery against the property until the statutory period under subsection (1) has expired. Therefore, immediate possession by the creditor is not permitted.

instruction: How long can the creditor possess the property after the initial period expires?
input:
Section no 443  part (3) : After the expiry of the period referred to in subsection
Section no 443  part (1) : , the property may be possessed for a period not
