output: According to Section 443(3): Rule: Once the initial period under subsection (1) has expired, the mortgaged property may be possessed for a period not exceeding ten years. Application/Conclusion: The creditor's possessory right following the expiry of the initial statutory period is limited to a maximum of ten years. So the creditor cannot possess the property for more than ten years under that possession right.

instruction: If I don't redeem my mortgaged land within ten years after possession, what happens to the mortgage deed?
input:
Section no 443  part (4) : If the property given in mortgage without possession
is not redeemed within the period of ten years after the possession 241 pursuant
to sub-section (3), the relevant deed shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond.
output: According to Section 443(4): Rule: If a mortgaged property (mortgage without possession) is not redeemed within ten years after the creditor's possession under subsection (3), the mortgage deed becomes equivalent to an unsecured bond. Application/Conclusion: If you fail to redeem within ten years after the creditor took possession, the security effect of the mortgage is lost and the deed will rank as an unsecured obligation (Kapali). Practically, the creditor will no longer have the mortgage security over the property.

instruction: Can I redeem my property while it is mortgaged? What do I need to pay?
input:
Section no 444 .
Redemption of mortgaged property at any time :
The debtor may, at any time, redeem his or her property from the creditor by
repaying the loan, in the case of a property given in mortgage with possession,
and also the interest, if any, payable on the loan, in the case of a property given
in mortgage without possession, to the creditor.
output: According to Section 444: Rule: The debtor can redeem mortgaged property at any time by repaying the loan; if the mortgage was without possession, the debtor must also pay any interest payable on the loan. Application/Conclusion: You have the right to redeem your property at any time. If the mortgage was with possession, repay the loan amount; if it was without possession, repay the loan plus any interest due to the creditor.

instruction: I want to redeem my cultivable land, but the creditor already planted crops. Can I still take the crops when I redeem?
input:
Section no 444  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if the property in mortgage is a cultivable land and the creditor has already
planted crops in such a land at the time of redemption, the creditor shall be
entitled to possess and enjoy such crops except as otherwise agreed upon between
the creditor and the debtor.
output: According to Section 444(2): Rule: If the mortgaged property is cultivable land and the creditor has already planted crops at the time of redemption, the creditor is entitled to possess and enjoy those crops unless an agreement states otherwise. Application/Conclusion: If you redeem while crops planted by the creditor are present, the creditor keeps the right to those crops. You cannot claim those crops on redemption unless you and the creditor have a different agreement.

instruction: Can the person who holds my mortgage remortgage the same property to someone else?
input:
Section no 445 . Property in mortgage may be remortgaged : (1) A
person who has obtained a property in mortgage shall be entitled to remortgage
such property or any part thereof to another person in consideration for an
amount which is equal to, or lesser than, the amount specified in the deed of
mortgage, and in such a case, a re-mortgage is deemed to have been created. Provided that a mortgaged property shall not be the object of re-mortgage prior
to the existence of the possessory right in such property.
output: According to Section 445(1): Rule: A mortgagee may remortgage the mortgaged property (or part of it) to another person for an amount equal to or less than the amount in the original mortgage; however, remortgage is not permitted before the remortgagee has a possessory right. Application/Conclusion: Yes, the holder of your mortgage can remortgage the property, but only for an amount that is equal to or less than the original mortgage amount, and only after the remortgagee's possessory right exists. If those conditions aren't met, a lawful remortgage is not created.

instruction: Is there any restriction on remortgaging before possession exists?
input:
Section no 445 . Property in mortgage may be remortgaged : (1) A
person who has obtained a property in mortgage shall be entitled to remortgage
such property or any part thereof to another person in consideration for an
amount which is equal to, or lesser than, the amount specified in the deed of
mortgage, and in such a case, a re-mortgage is deemed to have been created. Provided that a mortgaged property shall not be the object of re-mortgage prior
to the existence of the possessory right in such property.
output: According to Section 445(1): Rule: A mortgaged property cannot be remortgaged before the remortgagee has a possessory right in that property. Application/Conclusion: If the mortgagee tries to remortgage the property before any possessory right exists, that remortgage would not be valid under this provision. You can challenge such an early remortgage as invalid.

instruction: How long can the person who gets the property by re-mortgage possess it?
input:
Section no 445  part (2) : The period of possession and enjoyment of the
re mortgage given pursuant to sub-section (1) shall not exceed the period of
possession and enjoyment under the mortgage. 242
output: According to Section 445(2): Rule: The period of possession and enjoyment under a re-mortgage cannot exceed the period of possession and enjoyment under the original mortgage. Application/Conclusion: A re-mortgagee's possessory rights are limited by the original mortgage's remaining period. They cannot possess longer than the original mortgage entitlement allows.

instruction: If I want to redeem property that a remortgagee sold for the same price as the original mortgage, from whom should I pay?
input:
Section no 445  part (3) : If the debtor who has right and ownership in the
property intends to redeem the property re-mortgaged pursuant to sub-section
(1), the debtor may redeem the property upon payment of the price directly
from the re-mortgagee if the price of the re mortgage is equal to the original
price and through the original mortgagee if such price is less than the original
price.
output: According to Section 445(3): Rule: If the remortgage price equals the original mortgage price, the debtor may redeem directly from the re-mortgagee; if the remortgage price is less than the original price, redemption must be through the original mortgagee. Application/Conclusion: If the remortgagee sold or holds the property at the same price as the original mortgage, you can pay that party directly to redeem. If the remortgage price is lower, you must go through the original mortgagee to redeem.

instruction: What happens to a remortgage that conflicts with terms of the original mortgage?
input:
Section no 445  part (4) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in
this Section, the transaction of remortgage made inconsistent with the terms of
the mortgage shall ipso facto be void to the extent of such inconsistency.
output: According to Section 445(4): Rule: Any remortgage transaction that is inconsistent with the terms of the original mortgage is automatically void to the extent of that inconsistency. Application/Conclusion: If a remortgage contains terms that conflict with the original mortgage, those conflicting parts are legally void. That protects the debtor's and original mortgagee's rights against inconsistent remortgage terms.

instruction: If the creditor who re-mortgaged the property wasn't entitled to possess it, does the re-mortgage have security value?
input:
Section no 445  part (5) : If the creditor is not entitled to possess the property
re mortgaged pursuant to this Chapter, the deed of such a re-mortgage shall be
equivalent to an unsecured bond ( Kapali ).
output: According to Section 445(5): Rule: Where the creditor who re-mortgaged the property was not entitled to possess it, the re-mortgage deed is equivalent to an unsecured bond. Application/Conclusion: If a creditor improperly re-mortgages property without possessory entitlement, that re-mortgage will not have security over the land; it will instead be treated as an unsecured obligation (Kapali). Thus the re-mortgagee lacks secured priority in the land.

instruction: Can a creditor remortgage only the crops or benefits of my land instead of the whole property?
input:
Section no 446 .
Fruits or benefits of property may be mortgaged
: Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 445, a creditor who has obtained a property in mortgage may, instead of remortgaging the whole property,
remortgage only the fruits, benefit or facility of such property, or, if such property is a cultivable land, only the crops, products, trees, bamboo trees, reaped
or to be reaped fruits, vegetables, flowers or any other kinds of products to be
yielded from such land.
output: According to Section 446: Rule: A mortgagee may remortgage only the fruits, benefits or facilities of the property — and for cultivable land specifically, only the crops, products, trees and other yields — instead of the whole property. Application/Conclusion: Yes. The creditor can remortgage just the crops or other produce/benefits of your land rather than the entire parcel, subject to this provision. That remortgage covers the specified fruits/benefits only.

instruction: My mortgagee says they can remortgage for more than what my original mortgage says. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 445 . Property in mortgage may be remortgaged : (1) A
person who has obtained a property in mortgage shall be entitled to remortgage
such property or any part thereof to another person in consideration for an
amount which is equal to, or lesser than, the amount specified in the deed of
mortgage, and in such a case, a re-mortgage is deemed to have been created. Provided that a mortgaged property shall not be the object of re-mortgage prior
to the existence of the possessory right in such property.
output: According to Section 445(1): Rule: A remortgage can only be made for an amount equal to or less than the amount specified in the original mortgage deed. Application/Conclusion: No — the mortgagee cannot validly remortgage the property for an amount greater than the original mortgage amount. Any remortgage must be equal to or less than the deed-specified amount.

instruction: If the remortgage price is less than the original mortgage price, who should I pay to redeem — the re-mortgagee or the original mortgagee?
input:
Section no 445  part (3) : If the debtor who has right and ownership in the
property intends to redeem the property re-mortgaged pursuant to sub-section
(1), the debtor may redeem the property upon payment of the price directly
from the re-mortgagee if the price of the re mortgage is equal to the original
price and through the original mortgagee if such price is less than the original
price.
output: According to Section 445(3): Rule: If the remortgage price is less than the original mortgage price, redemption must be effected through the original mortgagee. Application/Conclusion: You must pay the original mortgagee when redeeming a property where the remortgage price is lower than the original price; you cannot simply pay the re-mortgagee in that situation.

instruction: I'm worried the mortgage deed might become meaningless over time — when does that happen?
input:
Section no 443  part (4) : If the property given in mortgage without possession
is not redeemed within the period of ten years after the possession 241 pursuant
to sub-section (3), the relevant deed shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond.
output: According to Section 443(4): Rule: If a mortgage (made without possession) is not redeemed within ten years after the creditor's possession under subsection (3), the mortgage deed becomes equivalent to an unsecured bond. Application/Conclusion: The mortgage's secured character ceases if redemption does not occur within ten years after possession — at that point the deed is treated as an unsecured obligation and loses its priority as security over the property.

instruction: Can a creditor remortgage only the annual harvest (the 'fruits') of my land?
input:
Section no 446 .
Fruits or benefits of property may be mortgaged
: Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 445, a creditor who has obtained a property in mortgage may, instead of remortgaging the whole property,
remortgage only the fruits, benefit or facility of such property, or, if such property is a cultivable land, only the crops, products, trees, bamboo trees, reaped
or to be reaped fruits, vegetables, flowers or any other kinds of products to be
yielded from such land.
output: According to Section 446: Rule: The mortgagee may remortgage the fruits or benefits of the property — for cultivable land, that specifically includes crops, products, trees and other produce. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the creditor can validly remortgage just the harvest or other fruits of your land rather than the land itself, subject to the provision's scope.

instruction: My creditor claims they can possess my mortgaged property forever if I default — is there any time limit?
input:
Section no 443  part (3) : After the expiry of the period referred to in subsection
Section no 443  part (1) : , the property may be possessed for a period not
exceeding ten years.
output: According to Section 443(3): Rule: Possession after expiry of the initial period is limited to a maximum of ten years. Application/Conclusion: No — the creditor cannot possess your mortgaged property indefinitely. Their possessory right after the statutory period is capped at ten years.

instruction: Can I mortgage the same property to two different people?
input: (1) No property once mortgaged may be mortgaged or transferred again, in duplication, to other person.
output:
According to Section 452(1)...
Rule: No property once mortgaged may be mortgaged or transferred again in duplication to another person.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot validly mortgage the same property to two different people. A second mortgage or duplicate transfer on the same property is prohibited and will be treated as duplication under the law.

instruction: I registered a mortgage after someone else — whose deed stands?
input: If a person mortgages a property in duplication in contravention of sub-section (1), the deed registered at an earlier date shall be valid and the subsequent deed shall ipso facto be void.
output:
According to Section 452(2)...
Rule: Where duplicate mortgages/transfers occur, the earlier-registered deed is valid and the later deed is ipso facto void.
Application/Conclusion: Since your mortgage was registered after another, the earlier-registered deed has priority and your later deed is void by operation of law; you will not hold a valid mortgage against that property.

instruction: I knowingly executed a duplicate mortgage deed—do I lose my loan?
input: If a deed becomes void pursuant to sub-section (2), the amount of a creditor who knowingly executes the deed in duplication shall lapse, and that of a creditor who executes it without knowledge of duplication shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali).
output:
According to Section 452(3)...
Rule: If a deed is void under Section 452(2), a creditor who knowingly executed the duplicate deed loses (the amount shall lapse); a creditor who acted without knowledge becomes equivalent to an unsecured creditor (Kapali).
Application/Conclusion: Because you knowingly executed the duplicate deed, your claim to recover the loan secured by that duplicate deed will lapse — you lose the secured claim arising from that deed.

instruction: I lent money thinking the mortgage was valid but later found out it duplicated an earlier one. What am I entitled to?
input: If a deed becomes void pursuant to sub-section (2), the amount of a creditor who knowingly executes the deed in duplication shall lapse, and that of a creditor who executes it without knowledge of duplication shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali).
output:
According to Section 452(3)...
Rule: A creditor who executed a duplicate deed without knowledge of duplication is treated as an unsecured creditor (Kapali).
Application/Conclusion: Since you acted without knowing about the earlier mortgage, your claim is not secured — it is equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali). You can claim repayment but you will rank as an unsecured creditor rather than having priority over the property.

instruction: I bought a property that was later found to have an earlier mortgage. Can I get clear title?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), in the event of the execution of deeds in duplication, and the first deed providing for any kind of mortgage and the second deed providing for the transfer of title, the transferee shall be entitled to establish the title by making repayment of loan in accordance with the first deed of mortgage.
output:
According to Section 452(4)...
Rule: If the first deed is a mortgage and the second is a transfer of title, the transferee (buyer) may establish title by repaying the loan under the first mortgage deed.
Application/Conclusion: As the purchaser (transferee) you can clear your title by repaying the mortgage debt owed under the earlier deed. After repayment in accordance with that first deed, you are entitled to establish title.

instruction: What penalty applies to someone who executes a duplicate deed?
input: One who executes a deed in duplication as mentioned in this Section shall be liable to the punishment with a fine of a sum that is equal to the amount in controversy, if any, indicated in the second deed, to the amount indicated in the earlier deed, if such amount in controversy is not indicated in the second deed, and a sum not exceeding twenty-five thousand rupees if no such amount is indicated even in the earlier deed. Provided that a fine in excess of one hundred thousand rupees shall not be imposed irrespective of the sum of amount in controversy.
output:
According to Section 452(5)...
Rule: A person executing a duplicate deed is liable to a fine: equal to the amount shown in the second deed (if indicated), or equal to the amount in the earlier deed (if second deed omits it), or up to Rs 25,000 if neither deed shows an amount; but the fine cannot exceed Rs 100,000 in any case.
Application/Conclusion: The person who made the duplicate deed faces a monetary penalty calculated by the rules above, subject to the Rs 100,000 cap, depending on whether the deeds state the disputed amount.

instruction: I had possession under a mortgage deed. How long do I have to establish possessory right if someone made a duplicate deed?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, in the event of the execution of the deed of mortgage in duplication, possessory right shall be established within two years from the date of the first deed if it provides for mortgage with possession (Bhogbhandhaki) and within two years from the date of entitlement to the possessory right if the first deed provides for mortgage without possessory right (Drishtibandhaki).
output:
According to Section 452(6)...
Rule: When duplicate mortgage deeds exist, possessory right must be established within two years: (a) from the date of the first deed if that deed provides for mortgage with possession (Bhogbhandhaki); (b) from the date entitlement to possession arises if the first deed provides mortgage without possession (Drishtibandhaki).
Application/Conclusion: If your mortgage gave you possession, you have two years from the first deed's date to establish possessory right. If possession entitlement arises later because the first deed was without possession, you have two years from the date you became entitled to possession.

instruction: What happens if the creditor fails to establish possessory right within the allowed time?
input: In the event of a failure to establish the possessory right pursuant to sub-section (6), the creditor’s amount shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali).
output:
According to Section 452(7)...
Rule: Failure to establish possessory right under Section 452(6) converts the creditor's secured claim into an unsecured claim (Kapali).
Application/Conclusion: If you do not establish the possessory right within the applicable two-year period, your claim against the property loses secured status and becomes equivalent to an unsecured bond — you will not have priority over the property.

instruction: I discovered a duplicate mortgage deed today — how long do I have to file a lawsuit under this chapter?
input: A lawsuit may be made within the statute of limitation, if any, specified separately in this Chapter, and, in relation to the other cases, within a period of one year after the date on which any act was done or action was taken pursuant to this Chapter, by a person who is aggrieved from such an act or action.
output:
According to Section 453...
Rule: A suit must be brought within any specific limitation set in the Chapter, or otherwise within one year after the date of the act or action under this Chapter by an aggrieved person.
Application/Conclusion: If no special limitation applies, you generally have one year from the date the relevant act or action occurred to file a lawsuit under this Chapter. Act promptly to avoid losing the right to sue.

instruction: If my neighbour redeems a transferred property, does that count as pre-emption?
input: If a person transfers, in any manner, any immovable property in which that person has right, ownership and possession to another person and anyone who is in neighbor of such property redeems it in accordance with this Chapter, pre-emption shall be deemed to be made.
output:
According to Section 454...
Rule: When a property owner transfers immovable property and a neighbour redeems it under this Chapter, such a redemption is deemed to be pre-emption.
Application/Conclusion: If your neighbour redeems the transferred property following the Chapter's procedures, the law treats that act as a valid exercise of pre-emption — the neighbour’s redemption amounts to pre-emption.

instruction: What does 'in neighbor of' mean for pre-emption? Explain simply.
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “in neighbor of” includes a situation where a ditch, water supply, passage, exit etc. for one will be closed by the reason that one does not have other’s house or land that is bordering one’s house or land and has been transferred.
output:
According to Section 454 (Explanation)...
Rule: 'In neighbor of' includes cases where transfer of bordering land would close access — e.g., a ditch, water supply, passage or exit for one would be blocked because the bordering house or land has been transferred.
Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if a transfer of nearby land would cut off your access to a passage, water, or exit (because the bordering land is transferred), you count as a 'neighbour' and may have pre-emption rights under this Chapter.

instruction: I had a mortgage without possession. When does my two-year period to establish possessory right start?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, in the event of the execution of the deed of mortgage in duplication, possessory right shall be established within two years from the date of the first deed if it provides for mortgage with possession (Bhogbhandhaki) and within two years from the date of entitlement to the possessory right if the first deed provides for mortgage without possessory right (Drishtibandhaki).
output:
According to Section 452(6)...
Rule: For mortgages without possession (Drishtibhandhaki), the two-year period to establish possessory right runs from the date you become entitled to possession.
Application/Conclusion: Since your mortgage was without possession, your two-year window begins when you become entitled to possess the property, not from the date of the first deed.

instruction: Someone registered a transfer after a mortgage. I'm the later transferee — can I get title back?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), in the event of the execution of deeds in duplication, and the first deed providing for any kind of mortgage and the second deed providing for the transfer of title, the transferee shall be entitled to establish the title by making repayment of loan in accordance with the first deed of mortgage.
output:
According to Section 452(4)...
Rule: A transferee who acquires title by a later deed can establish that title by repaying the loan under the earlier mortgage deed.
Application/Conclusion: As the later transferee, you can secure clear title by repaying the outstanding mortgage debt as per the first (earlier) mortgage deed; repayment allows you to establish title despite the earlier mortgage.

instruction: If the second deed doesn't state an amount, how is the fine for duplication calculated?
input: One who executes a deed in duplication as mentioned in this Section shall be liable to the punishment with a fine of a sum that is equal to the amount in controversy, if any, indicated in the second deed, to the amount indicated in the earlier deed, if such amount in controversy is not indicated in the second deed, and a sum not exceeding twenty-five thousand rupees if no such amount is indicated even in the earlier deed. Provided that a fine in excess of one hundred thousand rupees shall not be imposed irrespective of the sum of amount in controversy.
output:
According to Section 452(5)...
Rule: If the second deed omits the amount, the fine equals the amount in the earlier deed; if neither deed states an amount, the fine is up to Rs 25,000; fines cannot exceed Rs 100,000 total.
Application/Conclusion: Where the second deed lacks an amount, the law looks to the earlier deed's stated amount to fix the fine; absent amounts in both, the fine may be up to Rs 25,000, subject to the overall Rs 100,000 cap.

instruction: What does 'Kapali' mean in this law — is it secure or not?
input: If a deed becomes void pursuant to sub-section (2), the amount of a creditor who knowingly executes the deed in duplication shall lapse, and that of a creditor who executes it without knowledge of duplication shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali).
output:
According to Section 452(3)...
Rule: 'Kapali' refers to an unsecured bond — a creditor treated as unsecured when a duplicate deed is void and the creditor acted without knowledge.
Application/Conclusion: 'Kapali' means your claim is unsecured; if your deed is void but you acted innocently, you become an unsecured creditor (Kapali) rather than holding a secured interest in the property.

instruction: I want a short blunt answer: Who wins if two deeds exist — mortgage then sale?
input: If a person mortgages a property in duplication in contravention of sub-section (1), the deed registered at an earlier date shall be valid and the subsequent deed shall ipso facto be void.
output:
According to Section 452(2)...
Rule: The earlier-registered deed prevails; the later deed is automatically void.
Application/Conclusion: The first (earlier) deed wins. The later deed (whether sale or another mortgage) is void unless the transferee clears the earlier mortgage by repayment under Section 452(4).

instruction: Can I pre-empt a neighbor's immovable property that was just sold to someone else?
input: Entitlement of heir to pre-emption : (1) If a person sells his or her immovable property, the heir in neighbor of such property may pre empt such property upon payment of the amount paid by the buyer of that property as well as the fees incurred in course of approval of deed to the buyer.
output: According to Section 455(1): Rule: When an immovable property is sold, an heir who is a neighbor may pre-empt (buy back) that property by paying the amount the buyer paid plus fees incurred in approving the deed. Application/Conclusion: If you are an heir who is a neighbor, you can still pre-empt the property after the sale by reimbursing the buyer the purchase price and the approval/registration fees; you therefore have a right to buy back under these terms.

instruction: There are three siblings who are heirs and all want to pre-empt the land. Who gets to do it first?
input: Section no 455  part (2) : If there are more than one heir who intend to make pre emption pursuant to sub-section (1), the nearest heir, and, if such heirs are also more than one, the heir who is the most immediate neighbor, and, if even such heirs are more than one, all the heirs may pre-empt such property in equal proportion.
output: According to Section 455(2): Rule: If multiple heirs intend to pre-empt, priority goes first to the nearest heir; if more than one nearest, then the most immediate neighbor; if still more than one, all may pre-empt in equal shares. Application/Conclusion: Determine who among the siblings is the nearest heir; if more than one equally nearest, check who is the immediate neighbor; if that does not resolve it, the siblings can exercise pre-emption by dividing the property equally.

instruction: My uncle (nearest heir) refuses to act. Can I pre-empt instead?
input: Section no 455  part (3) : If the nearest heir does not pre-empt such property pursuant to sub-section (2), the heir who is the nearest in the order of preference may pre-empt such property. 248
output: According to Section 455(3): Rule: If the nearest heir does not exercise pre-emption, the next heir in the order of preference may pre-empt. Application/Conclusion: If your uncle (the nearest heir) declines or fails to pre-empt, then you, as the next heir by order of preference, may step in and pre-empt the property.

instruction: I rent a house whose owner sold it and there are heirs but none want to act. As a tenant, do I have any right to buy it back?
input: Section no 456 . Pre-emption by tenant : If there is no heir in neighbor of the property pursuant to Section 455 or even if there is an heir, he or she does not intend to make pre-emption and if there is a tenant in accordance with law in such a property, the tenant may pre-empt such property. 132
output: According to Section 456: Rule: If there's no heir-neighbor or the heir declines to pre-empt, a lawful tenant of the property may pre-empt. Application/Conclusion: Since the heirs are not acting, you as a legally recognized tenant may exercise pre-emption and buy the property under the applicable terms.

instruction: My co-owner sold his part of a house to someone else. Can I pre-empt that sold portion?
input: Section no 457 . Pre-emption of sold house : (1) If there are different owners of the different parts of the same house and the owner of a part sells his or her part to another person, the owner of another part may, if he or she intends to pre-empt that part, preempt such a part of the house by paying the amount paid by the buyer and the fee incurred in the registration of the deed to the buyer.
output: According to Section 457(1): Rule: When different persons own different parts of a house and one owner sells his part, another part-owner may pre-empt that sold part by paying the buyer the purchase price and registration fees. Application/Conclusion: As a co-owner, you can buy back the sold part by reimbursing the buyer the amount they paid plus the deed registration fee; you therefore have a legal right to pre-empt that portion.

instruction: I'm an heir and my brother who owns part of the house sold his share. Do heirs get preference to pre-empt that part?
input: Section no 457  part (2) (a) : If the owner of the other part is the heir, such an heir, and if there are more than one heir, the nearest heir,
output: According to Section 457(2)(a): Rule: In pre-emption of a sold part of a house, if the other part-owner is an heir, that heir (and if multiple heirs, the nearest heir) has preference to pre-empt. Application/Conclusion: Because you are an heir, you (or the nearest heir among heirs) have priority to pre-empt your brother's sold share before non-heirs can; you should assert that preference to exercise pre-emption.

instruction: If the other owner of the adjoining part is not an heir, who has preference to pre-empt the sold part?
input: Section no 457  part (2) (b) : If the owner of the other part is a person other than the heir, the owner in neighbor of or the owner of the part adjoining such a part.
output: According to Section 457(2)(b): Rule: Where the co-owner of another part is not an heir, preference for pre-emption goes to the owner-neighbor or the owner of the adjoining part. Application/Conclusion: If the neighboring or adjoining part-owner wants to pre-empt, they get preference in buying the sold part; you should check whether an adjoining owner is asserting that right before others can.

instruction: My father gifted half the house to someone and that donee sold it to a third party. Can my father or his heir living nearby pre-empt that portion?
input: Section no 458 . Pre-emption of house donated or gifted : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 455,456 or 457, if any person relinquishes in any manner his or her right in and donates or gifts the half part of the same house or any portion thereof or the land occupied by or appurtenant to the house and the donee has transferred the right in the house or land in any manner to another person, the donor or his or her heir residing in the same place may, 249 if he or she so intends, pre-empt such a house or any portion thereof or the land occupied by or appurtenant to the house.
output: According to Section 458(1): Rule: Even if a half-part or portion of a house was donated or gifted and the donee then transferred it, the donor or the donor's heir residing in the same place may pre-empt that house/portion. Application/Conclusion: Your father (the donor) or his heir living locally can exercise pre-emption over the portion transferred by the donee by following the procedure and payment rules set out by law.

instruction: If I was the first donee of half a house and later the donor gives the remaining half to someone else, can I or my heir buy that remaining half back?
input: Section no 458  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if a person gets a donation or gift of the half part or any portion of the same house or the land occupied by or appurtenant to the house from a donor and the donor donates or gifts the remaining part of such a house or land to another person, the former donee or giftee or his or her heir may pre-empt such remaining part or portion.
output: According to Section 458(2): Rule: If someone received a donated half (or portion) and the donor later donates the remaining part to another, the initial donee (or their heir) may pre-empt the remaining portion. Application/Conclusion: As the first donee (or your heir), you have the right to pre-empt and acquire the remaining part gifted to a third person by paying the required amount.

instruction: What price must be paid when pre-empting a part of a house that was originally gifted?
input: Section no 458  part (3) : In making pre-emption pursuant to sub-section (1) or Section 458  part (2) : , the figure of price, if any, indicated in the instrument of donation or gift, and amount equal to the prevailing market price, if such figure is not so indicated, and the fees incurred in the registration of the deed shall be paid to the creditor. Section no 458
output: According to Section 458(3): Rule: For pre-emption under Sections 458(1) or 458(2), pay the price shown in the donation instrument (if any); if no price is indicated, pay an amount equal to the prevailing market price, plus deed registration fees, to the creditor. Application/Conclusion: When you pre-empt a gifted portion, check the gift instrument for a stated price; if none exists, you must pay market value and registration fees to the creditor to complete the pre-emption.

instruction: Do I need to reimburse the buyer's fees if I want to pre-empt a sold property, or just the purchase price?
input: Entitlement of heir to pre-emption : (1) If a person sells his or her immovable property, the heir in neighbor of such property may pre empt such property upon payment of the amount paid by the buyer of that property as well as the fees incurred in course of approval of deed to the buyer.
output: According to Section 455(1): Rule: Pre-emption requires payment of both the amount paid by the buyer and the fees incurred in approving the deed. Application/Conclusion: You must reimburse the buyer for the purchase price and also cover the fees charged during deed approval/registration to successfully pre-empt the property.

instruction: If several heirs are equally nearest and live next to the property, how is the property divided if they all pre-empt?
input: Section no 455  part (2) : If there are more than one heir who intend to make pre emption pursuant to sub-section (1), the nearest heir, and, if such heirs are also more than one, the heir who is the most immediate neighbor, and, if even such heirs are more than one, all the heirs may pre-empt such property in equal proportion.
output: According to Section 455(2): Rule: When multiple heirs are equally nearest and immediate neighbors, they may pre-empt the property in equal proportions. Application/Conclusion: If you and other heirs qualify as equally nearest/most immediate neighbors and all choose to pre-empt, the property should be divided equally among you for the purposes of pre-emption.

instruction: My landlord sold my rented house and the heirs are refusing to act. As a tenant, what exactly can I do according to the law?
input: Section no 456 . Pre-emption by tenant : If there is no heir in neighbor of the property pursuant to Section 455 or even if there is an heir, he or she does not intend to make pre-emption and if there is a tenant in accordance with law in such a property, the tenant may pre-empt such property. 132
output: According to Section 456: Rule: Where no heir-neighbor exists or the heir declines to pre-empt, a lawful tenant may exercise pre-emption. Application/Conclusion: You, as a lawful tenant, have the statutory right to pre-empt (buy) the rented property if heirs do not act; you should follow pre-emption procedures and make the required payments to the buyer.

instruction: My neighbor sold his share and the buyer already registered the deed. Can pre-emption still happen and what do I pay?
input: Section no 457 . Pre-emption of sold house : (1) If there are different owners of the different parts of the same house and the owner of a part sells his or her part to another person, the owner of another part may, if he or she intends to pre-empt that part, preempt such a part of the house by paying the amount paid by the buyer and the fee incurred in the registration of the deed to the buyer.
output: According to Section 457(1): Rule: Even after a sale and deed registration, another part-owner may pre-empt by paying the buyer the amount they paid plus registration fees. Application/Conclusion: Registration of the buyer's deed does not prevent pre-emption; you must reimburse the buyer for the purchase price and registration fees to pre-empt the sold share.

instruction: Someone donated half the house to A, who later transferred it. Can the donor's heir living nearby buy that half back?
input: Section no 458 . Pre-emption of house donated or gifted : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 455,456 or 457, if any person relinquishes in any manner his or her right in and donates or gifts the half part of the same house or any portion thereof or the land occupied by or appurtenant to the house and the donee has transferred the right in the house or land in any manner to another person, the donor or his or her heir residing in the same place may, 249 if he or she so intends, pre-empt such a house or any portion thereof or the land occupied by or appurtenant to the house.
output: According to Section 458(1): Rule: After donation/gift and subsequent transfer by the donee, the donor or the donor's heir living in the same place may pre-empt the donated portion. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the donor's heir residing locally can exercise pre-emption to reclaim that half by following the payment and registration requirements under the law.

instruction: A friend says 'You can pre-empt by paying market price' — where does that come from?
input: Section no 458  part (3) : In making pre-emption pursuant to sub-section (1) or Section 458  part (2) : , the figure of price, if any, indicated in the instrument of donation or gift, and amount equal to the prevailing market price, if such figure is not so indicated, and the fees incurred in the registration of the deed shall be paid to the creditor. Section no 458
output: According to Section 458(3): Rule: If a donation instrument lacks a stated price, the pre-emptor must pay an amount equal to the prevailing market price plus deed registration fees. Application/Conclusion: Your friend's statement is grounded in law: when no price is specified in the gift instrument, pre-emption requires payment of market value and registration fees.

instruction: Short question: Who may pre-empt a sold property if there are no neighbor-heirs?
input: Section no 456 . Pre-emption by tenant : If there is no heir in neighbor of the property pursuant to Section 455 or even if there is an heir, he or she does not intend to make pre-emption and if there is a tenant in accordance with law in such a property, the tenant may pre-empt such property. 132
output: According to Section 456: Rule: If no heir-neighbor exists or the heir declines, a lawful tenant may pre-empt. Application/Conclusion: The tenant has the right to pre-empt when there are no eligible/acting neighbor-heirs.

instruction: We have a messy family dispute: father gifted two halves to different people and one sold it. Which family members can try to buy back parts?
input: Section no 458  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if a person gets a donation or gift of the half part or any portion of the same house or the land occupied by or appurtenant to the house from a donor and the donor donates or gifts the remaining part of such a house or land to another person, the former donee or giftee or his or her heir may pre-empt such remaining part or portion.
output: According to Section 458(2): Rule: When the donor gives different parts to different donees, the first donee (or their heir) may pre-empt the remaining part given to another. Application/Conclusion: In your family case, the first doneee (or that doneee's heir) can seek to pre-empt the other donated half; family members who are heirs of the doneee may exercise that right on behalf of the doneee.

instruction: Explain simply: what does Section 455 allow an heir-neighbor to do?
input: Entitlement of heir to pre-emption : (1) If a person sells his or her immovable property, the heir in neighbor of such property may pre empt such property upon payment of the amount paid by the buyer of that property as well as the fees incurred in course of approval of deed to the buyer.
output: According to Section 455(1): Rule: An heir who is a neighbor can pre-empt (buy back) immovable property sold by paying the buyer's purchase price and the deed approval/registration fees. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if your relative sells land next door, as an heir-neighbor you have the legal option to step in and buy it by reimbursing what the buyer paid plus the related fees.

instruction: Can a third person mortgage his property on behalf of a debtor who borrowed money?
input:
. Mortgaging by third party on behalf of debtor : (1) A
third person may, in consideration for a loan borrowed by a debtor, mortgage a
property in which the third person has right and ownership to the creditor on
behalf of the debtor. 243
output:
According to Section 447(1):
Rule: A third person may, in consideration for a loan borrowed by a debtor, mortgage a property in which the third person has right and ownership to the creditor on behalf of the debtor.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you own or have a right in the property and you mortgage it because of a loan borrowed by the debtor, you are permitted to mortgage that property to the creditor on the debtor’s behalf.

instruction: If someone else mortgages their land for my loan, can the creditor possess it like it was my mortgage?
input:
Section no 447  part (2) : The creditor shall, pursuant to this Chapter, be
entitled to possess and enjoy the property mortgaged pursuant to sub section
(1) as if it were the property mortgaged by the debtor to the creditor.
output:
According to Section 447(2):
Rule: The creditor is entitled to possess and enjoy property mortgaged under subsection (1) as if the debtor had mortgaged it.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — once the third person mortgages their property under Section 447(1), the creditor can possess and enjoy that property in the same way as if the debtor had mortgaged it.

instruction: What is the legal relationship between me (debtor) and the third person who mortgaged their property for my loan if we didn't sign any agreement?
input:
Section no 447  part (3) : If a property is mortgaged by a third person
pursuant to sub-section (1), the relationship between the debtor and the third
person shall be governed by the deed of mortgage or other separate contract,
and in the default of such provision, such transaction shall be equivalent to an
unsecured bond (Kapali).
output:
According to Section 447(3):
Rule: The debtor–third person relationship is governed by the mortgage deed or other contract; if no such provision exists, the transaction is equivalent to an unsecured bond.
Application/Conclusion: If you and the third person did not record any deed or separate contract, your legal relationship will be treated as an unsecured bond — meaning the third person’s obligation to you is not secured by a specific mortgage-based claim.

instruction: I want to redeem just part of the mortgaged land though there are several creditors — is that allowed?
input:
Section no 448 . Property in mortgage to be indivisible : (1) A property
mortgaged by a debtor to a creditor shall remain indivisible notwithstanding
the creation of more than one creditor by virtue of the partition or succession
between the creditor’s coparceners or the division between creditor’s partners,
and the debtor shall not be entitled to redeem the whole or any portion of the
mortgaged property until the loan borrowed by him or her is repaid in full in
accordance with the deed of mortgage.
output:
According to Section 448(1):
Rule: A mortgaged property is indivisible even if there are multiple creditors; the debtor cannot redeem the whole or any portion until the loan is repaid in full as per the mortgage deed.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot redeem only a portion of the mortgaged land while any part of the loan remains unpaid — redemption is barred until the loan is fully repaid under the deed.

instruction: My brother and I are both debtors because of a family division. Can I redeem the mortgaged property by paying only my share of the loan?
input:
Section no 448  part (2) : If more than one debtor are maintained by virtue of
the partition, succession between the debtor’s coparceners or division between
the debtor’s partners, the mortgaged property shall not be liable to redemption
until each debtor repays his or her respective portion of the loan in full.
output:
According to Section 448(2):
Rule: Where there are multiple debtors (by partition, succession, or division), the mortgaged property cannot be redeemed until each debtor repays his or her respective portion in full.
Application/Conclusion: If you and your brother are co-debtors, the property cannot be redeemed unless each of you repays your own share of the loan completely.

instruction: Who is responsible if the mortgaged property gets damaged after the creditor takes possession?
input:
Section no 449 . Creditor to be liable for loss and damage to property
in : mortgage: (1) After the creation of the creditor’s possessory right in the
property in mortgage, the creditor shall be liable for any kind of loss or damage,
if any, caused to the property in mortgage. 244
output:
According to Section 449(1):
Rule: After the creditor obtains possessory rights in the mortgaged property, the creditor is liable for any loss or damage caused to that property.
Application/Conclusion: Once the creditor has possession under the mortgage, the creditor bears responsibility for loss or damage to the property (not the debtor).

instruction: If the creditor is liable for damage, do they have to restore the property at their own cost?
input:
Section no 449  part (2) : In the event of any loss or damage to the property in
130
mortgage pursuant to sub-section (1), the creditor shall so repair such property,
at his or her cost, as to restore it into its original form.
output:
According to Section 449(2):
Rule: Where loss or damage occurs under subsection (1), the creditor must repair the property at his or her own cost to restore it to its original form.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the creditor must pay for and carry out repairs to return the mortgaged property to its original condition.

instruction: The mortgaged house was hit by a flood. Is the creditor liable for that damage?
input:
Section no 449  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), the creditor shall not be liable for any loss or damage to the property in
mortgage caused by a disaster, and the creditor shall repair such loss or damage
with the debtor’s consent in writing.

Section no 449  part (4) : The debtor shall, while redeeming the property in
mortgage, pay also the expenses incurred in the maintenance under sub-section
(3), in addition to the loan borrowed from the creditor.
output:
According to Section 449(3) and (4):
Rule: The creditor is not liable for loss or damage caused by a disaster; the creditor may repair such damage only with the debtor’s written consent, and the debtor must pay the maintenance expenses (incurred under subsection (3)) when redeeming, in addition to repaying the loan.
Application/Conclusion: For flood or other disaster damage, the creditor does not automatically bear liability. If the creditor repairs the damage, it must be done with your written consent, and you will have to reimburse the maintenance expenses when you redeem the property, on top of repaying the loan.

instruction: If the creditor repairs disaster damage, will I have to pay those repair costs when I redeem the property?
input:
Section no 449  part (4) : The debtor shall, while redeeming the property in
mortgage, pay also the expenses incurred in the maintenance under sub-section
(3), in addition to the loan borrowed from the creditor.
output:
According to Section 449(4):
Rule: The debtor must, at the time of redeeming the mortgaged property, pay the expenses incurred under subsection (3) (maintenance after disaster repairs), in addition to repaying the loan.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the creditor incurred maintenance/repair expenses under subsection (3) (e.g., after a disaster), you must pay those expenses when redeeming the property, along with the loan amount.

instruction: After the creditor took possession of my mortgaged house, he keeps saying the property is unsuitable and harasses me. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 450 . Not to create trouble on property in mortgage : After
the creation of the possessory right in the property in mortgage, the creditor
shall not so trouble the debtor stating that such property is inappropriate or
inaccurate or less as to be inconsistent with the terms of the deed. Provided
that nothing shall bar the making of a claim for the repayment of a loan in
accordance with the deed of mortgage if the creditor is not entitled to possess
the property in mortgage for any reason or if the property is held to be defective
for any reason.
output:
According to Section 450:
Rule: After obtaining possessory rights, the creditor must not trouble or harass the debtor by claiming the property is inappropriate or inconsistent with the deed; however, this does not prevent the creditor from claiming repayment according to the mortgage deed if the creditor is not entitled to possession or if the property is defective.
Application/Conclusion: The creditor should not harass you by alleging the property is unsuitable once in possession. However, if there are legitimate grounds — e.g., the creditor isn't entitled to possession or the property is defective — the creditor may still pursue repayment under the deed.

instruction: Can I mortgage property to a foreigner living abroad?
input:
Section no 451 .
Mortgage not to be made to foreigner : No person
may mortgage an immovable property to a foreign person other than a person
having obtained the non-resident Nepali citizenship, without prior approval of
the Government of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 451:
Rule: No person may mortgage immovable property to a foreign person (except a person who has obtained non-resident Nepali citizenship) without prior approval of the Government of Nepal.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot mortgage your land to a foreigner unless that person holds non-resident Nepali citizenship or you obtain prior approval from the Government of Nepal.

instruction: Is a non-resident Nepali allowed to take a mortgage on my property, or are they treated as foreign?
input:
Section no 451 .
Mortgage not to be made to foreigner : No person
may mortgage an immovable property to a foreign person other than a person
having obtained the non-resident Nepali citizenship, without prior approval of
the Government of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 451:
Rule: A mortgage to a foreign person is prohibited without government approval, except where the person has obtained non-resident Nepali citizenship.
Application/Conclusion: A person with non-resident Nepali citizenship is an exception — they can receive a mortgage without the Government’s prior approval that would otherwise be required for a foreigner.

instruction: Short — can I redeem part of the mortgaged property while a creditor’s partners split into multiple creditors?
input:
Section no 448 . Property in mortgage to be indivisible : (1) A property
mortgaged by a debtor to a creditor shall remain indivisible notwithstanding
the creation of more than one creditor by virtue of the partition or succession
between the creditor’s coparceners or the division between creditor’s partners,
and the debtor shall not be entitled to redeem the whole or any portion of the
mortgaged property until the loan borrowed by him or her is repaid in full in
accordance with the deed of mortgage.
output:
According to Section 448(1):
Rule: Mortgaged property remains indivisible even if more than one creditor arises through partition or division; the debtor cannot redeem the whole or any portion until the loan is fully repaid per the deed.
Application/Conclusion: No — even if the creditor’s partners create multiple creditors, you cannot redeem any part of the mortgaged property until the loan is repaid in full under the mortgage deed.

instruction: I'm a creditor who took possession. Can I claim maintenance costs for disaster repairs from the debtor later?
input:
Section no 449  part (4) : The debtor shall, while redeeming the property in
mortgage, pay also the expenses incurred in the maintenance under sub-section
(3), in addition to the loan borrowed from the creditor.
output:
According to Section 449(4):
Rule: The debtor must pay expenses incurred under subsection (3) (disaster-related maintenance) when redeeming the property, in addition to repaying the loan.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you (the creditor) incur maintenance/repair expenses after a disaster under subsection (3), those expenses can be recovered from the debtor at the time the debtor redeems the property.

instruction: My friend mortgaged his house for my loan. If later there is no written agreement between us, what is my legal position vis-à-vis him?
input:
Section no 447  part (3) : If a property is mortgaged by a third person
pursuant to sub-section (1), the relationship between the debtor and the third
person shall be governed by the deed of mortgage or other separate contract,
and in the default of such provision, such transaction shall be equivalent to an
unsecured bond (Kapali).
output:
According to Section 447(3):
Rule: The relationship between debtor and third person is governed by the mortgage deed or a separate contract; absent such a provision, the transaction is equivalent to an unsecured bond.
Application/Conclusion: If you and your friend did not document any agreement, your claim against the friend will be treated as an unsecured bond — meaning you have an unsecured claim for repayment rather than a secured mortgage-based right against the friend’s property.

instruction: Who must pay the registration fee when a property is transferred or mortgaged?
input: Section no 469  clause (a) : In the case of a deed transferring a property or relating to mortgage, the transferee or mortgagee,
output: According to Section 469 clause (a)... Rule: In the case of a deed transferring property or relating to a mortgage, the transferee or the mortgagee is obligated to pay the registration fee. Application/Conclusion: If you are the buyer (transferee) or the mortgagee named in the deed, you are the person required to pay the fee when that deed is registered.

instruction: If my family is partitioning ancestral land, who is responsible for the registration fee?
input: Section no 469  clause (b) : In the case of a deed on partition or relinquishment of partition share, separation of board and bread or unification of board and bread, all coparceners in equal portion,
output: According to Section 469 clause (b)... Rule: For deeds concerning partition or relinquishment of partition shares (and similar family division matters), all coparceners share the registration fee equally. Application/Conclusion: In a partition of ancestral land, every coparcener must contribute an equal portion of the registration fee.

instruction: Two parties exchanged plots of land. Who pays the registration fee?
input: Section no 469  clause (c) : In the case of a deed on exchange of property, both parties to the deed,
output: According to Section 469 clause (c)... Rule: For a deed of exchange of property, both parties to the deed are liable to pay the registration fee. Application/Conclusion: If you exchanged land with another person, both you and the other party are each responsible for paying the fee as per the deed.

instruction: I received a gift under a will. Who pays the registration fee for that testamentary gift?
input: Section no 469  clause (d) : In the case of a deed of testamentary gift, the donor or testator,
output: According to Section 469 clause (d)... Rule: For a deed of testamentary gift, the donor or testator is the person obligated to pay the registration fee. Application/Conclusion: If the property was given by someone under a testamentary gift, the donor/testator (the person who made the gift) bears the fee — not the beneficiary.

instruction: I'm registering a house rent agreement — who must pay the registration fee?
input: Section no 469  clause (e) : In the case of a deed on house renting, the house lord,
output: According to Section 469 clause (e)... Rule: For a deed concerning house renting, the house lord (landlord) is required to pay the registration fee. Application/Conclusion: If you are the landlord entering a registered rent deed, you are the one responsible for paying the registration fee.

instruction: How is the fee calculated for a rent agreement registration?
input:
Section no 469  part (2) : In registering the deed referred to in clause (e) of sub section (1), the fee shall be determined considering the amount of rent of
137
the first month receivable for house rent as the price.
output: According to Section 469 part (2)... Rule: For registration of a house renting deed (clause (e)), the fee is calculated by considering the first month's rent as the price. Application/Conclusion: When determining the registration fee for a tenancy agreement, the office will treat the amount of the first month's rent as the transaction amount for fee calculation.

instruction: Who pays when a trust is being established and its memorandum is registered?
input: Section no 469  clause (f) : In case of a memorandum of establishment of trust, founder of a trust, 257
output: According to Section 469 clause (f)... Rule: For registration of a memorandum establishing a trust, the founder of the trust must pay the fee. Application/Conclusion: If you founded a trust and are registering its memorandum, you (the founder) are responsible for the registration fee.

instruction: For miscellaneous deeds not listed specifically, who is liable to pay registration fees?
input: Section no 469  clause (g) : In the case of any other deed, both parties to the deed.
output: According to Section 469 clause (g)... Rule: For any deed not otherwise specified, both parties to the deed are liable to pay the registration fee. Application/Conclusion: If your deed type isn't listed in clauses (a)–(f), expect that both parties named in the deed share responsibility for the fee.

instruction: How may parties make the payment that the deed requires at registration — can they use cheque?
input: Section no 470 . Provision relating to payment of amount : If any amount is to be paid and received between the parties to a deed according to the deed intended to be approved and registered, such payment may be effected either in household or in presence of the concerned employee of the oﬀice or by a good for payment cheque.
output: According to Section 470... Rule: Payments between parties under a deed may be made in the household, in the presence of the concerned office employee, or by a good-for-payment cheque. Application/Conclusion: You may pay the amount required by the deed in person at the house, before the office employee, or by a valid cheque — all three methods are permitted.

instruction: When a registered deed requires a transmission, how quickly must the office execute transmission and registration?
input: Section no 471  part (1) : If any transmission has to be effected in consequence of a deed registered, the concerned oﬀice shall execute transmission, and registration and deregistration of the matter on the day of registration of the deed, and on the following day if it is not possible to do so on that day.
output: According to Section 471 part (1)... Rule: The concerned office must execute transmission, registration, and deregistration on the day the deed is registered, or on the next day if same-day action is not possible. Application/Conclusion: After your deed is registered, expect the office to update transmission and registration records immediately that day or at the latest the following day.

instruction: My deed was registered at Office A but the property records are held in Office B in another district. What must Office A do?
input: Section no 471  part (2) : If any transmission and registration and deregistration of the matter have to be made in the records of another oﬀice according to the deed registered by one oﬀice, the latter shall give a time-limit of thirty-five days to the transferee, thereby informing him or her to go to the concerned oﬀice for the transmission, and registration and deregistration of the matter, and send also the deed to the concerned oﬀice.
output: According to Section 471 part (2)... Rule: When the deed requires action in another office's records, the registering office must (a) give the transferee 35 days to go to the concerned office for transmission/registration/deregistration and (b) send the deed to that concerned office. Application/Conclusion: Office A should notify you (the transferee) with a 35‑day period to visit Office B and must forward the deed to Office B for completion of transmission and registration.

instruction: Office B has just received a deed sent by another district for transmission and registration. What should Office B do next?
input: Section no 471  part (3) : On receipt of a deed sent by another district for the transmission, and registration and deregistration of the matter pursuant to subsection (2), the concerned oﬀice shall enter the 258 matter of such registration into its records and effect transmission and registration and deregistration of the matter according to the deed.
output: According to Section 471 part (3)... Rule: Upon receipt of a deed from another district, the concerned office must enter the registration into its records and effect the transmission, registration, and deregistration as per the deed. Application/Conclusion: When Office B receives the deed from Office A, it is required to record the matter in its registers and complete the transmission and related registration steps according to the deed.

instruction: Two different deeds were registered concerning the same piece of land on different days. Which one is valid?
input: Section no 472 . Deed registered at earlier date to be valid : In the event of approval and registration of more than one deed in relation to the same matter, the deed approved and registered on the earlier date shall be valid.
output: According to Section 472... Rule: If more than one deed is approved and registered regarding the same matter, the deed registered earlier in date is the valid one. Application/Conclusion: Between two conflicting registered deeds for the same land, the one with the earlier registration date prevails; the later-registered deed will not be valid against the earlier one.

instruction: I discovered an improper action taken under this Chapter today. How long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 473 . Statute of limitation : (1) A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken.
output: According to Section 473 part (1)... Rule: A person aggrieved by any act or action under this Chapter must file a lawsuit within six months from the date the act was done or the action taken. Application/Conclusion: Since you discovered the act today, you should check the date the act occurred; the legal window to file is six months from that date. If the act occurred recently, you must initiate legal proceedings within six months of that act.

instruction: Where is the obligation to pay registration fees set out in the law?
input: Section no 469 . Obligation to pay fees : (1) The following person shall pay the fee chargeable for the registration of the following deed:
output: According to Section 469... Rule: Section 469 sets out the obligation to pay registration fees and lists which persons are responsible for fees for different deed types. Application/Conclusion: If you want to know who must pay a registration fee for a particular deed, consult Section 469 which enumerates the liable persons for each deed category.

instruction: Can both parties be made to pay the fee for a deed not otherwise specified?
input: Section no 469  clause (g) : In the case of any other deed, both parties to the deed.
output: According to Section 469 clause (g)... Rule: For any deed not specifically covered in prior clauses, both parties to the deed are responsible for the registration fee. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the deed type is not listed elsewhere in Section 469, the law makes both parties share the obligation to pay the registration fee.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me his plot and we had a registered deed process started, but he backed out. What are my options and how long can I wait to sue?
input: Section no 473 . Statute of limitation : (1) A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken.
output: According to Section 473 part (1)... Rule: An aggrieved person must file a lawsuit within six months from the date of the act or action taken under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: If Ram's backing out involved an act or action governed by this Chapter (for example, a registration-related act), you have six months from the date of that act to sue. Act promptly to preserve your rights; if the matter involves registration steps, use the six-month limitation to initiate legal proceedings.

instruction: Is it acceptable to make payment in the presence of the office employee when registering a deed?
input: Section no 470 . Provision relating to payment of amount : If any amount is to be paid and received between the parties to a deed according to the deed intended to be approved and registered, such payment may be effected either in household or in presence of the concerned employee of the oﬀice or by a good for payment cheque.
output: According to Section 470... Rule: Payments required by a deed can lawfully be made in the household, in the presence of the concerned office employee, or by a valid cheque. Application/Conclusion: Yes — making the payment in the presence of the concerned office employee is an authorized method; you may also pay at the household or by cheque.

instruction: If the buyer and I disagree about the market price and the office approved the registration, can I go to court? What's the deadline?
input:
part (7) : If any party does not agree to the market price of
the property subject to pre-emption fixed pursuant to sub-section (6) or if the
person obliged to allow preemption appears within the time limit and shows the
reason why pre-emption is not to be made, and it is necessary to decide it upon
examination of evidence on the matter, the oﬀice that approves the registration
134
of the deed shall inform that the concerned person may make a lawsuit in the
court within thirty-five days; and in such a case, action shall be taken pursuant
to a decision of the court if a lawsuit has been filed within the time-limit, and
pursuant to a decision of the oﬀice if no such a lawsuit has been filed.
output:
According to Section 460(7):
Rule: If any party does not agree to the market price or a person entitled to object appears and shows cause, the office that approves the registration must inform that the concerned person may file a lawsuit in court within thirty-five days.
Application/Conclusion: You can go to court, but you must file the lawsuit within thirty-five days from when you were informed. If a suit is filed within that time, action will follow the court's decision; if not, the office's decision stands.

instruction: I petitioned for pre-emption but later I changed my mind and didn't show up. Will I lose my deposit?
input:
Section no 460  part (9) : If the person who has petitioned for pre-emption
does not subsequently intend, for any reason, to make pre-emption or 252 fails
to appear at the appointed dates, the oﬀice shall punish that person with a
fine of three percent of the amount of deposit furnished by him or her and the
amount that remains after deducting that fine from the amount of deposit shall
be returned to him or her.
output:
According to Section 460(9):
Rule: If a petitioner for pre-emption withdraws intent or fails to appear at appointed dates, the office will impose a fine equal to three percent of the deposit, and return the remaining deposit amount.
Application/Conclusion: If you changed your mind or did not show up, expect a 3% fine on your deposit; the rest will be returned to you.

instruction: They said pre-emption cannot be made and returned my deposit. Is any deduction allowed?

instruction: If the office or the court decides pre-emption is valid, do they update the land records?

output:

Rule: When the concerned office or court holds that pre-emption can be made, the office must enter and update the records of the pre-empted property accordingly.
Application/Conclusion: Yes. If pre-emption is held valid by the office or court, the office is obliged to update the land/property records to reflect the pre-emption.

instruction: How long do I have to file a lawsuit if I'm aggrieved by actions under this Chapter?
input:
Section no 462 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from
any act done or action taken pursuant to this Chapter may file a lawsuit within
thirty-five days after the date of knowledge thereof not later than six months
after the date of registration of the deed. Provided that a tenant may file a lawsuit within thirty-five days after the date of expiration of the date within which
the land owner may make pre-emption.
output:
According to Section 462:
Rule: An aggrieved person may file a lawsuit within thirty-five days of knowledge, but not later than six months after the date of registration of the deed; tenants have a specific thirty-five-day rule after the expiry of the owner's pre-emption period.
Application/Conclusion: You must act quickly: generally file within 35 days of learning of the act, and in any case no later than six months after deed registration. If you are a tenant, you have 35 days from the expiration of the owner's pre-emption period.

Application/Conclusion: Yes. Once the designated office approves your deed under this Chapter, it is legally treated as registered even before any further formalities.

instruction: I just received a copy of a deed that was registered in another district. How long do I have to file a lawsuit here?

instruction: Can a casual give-and-take under a condition be treated as a transaction? I gave goods to someone on a condition.
input: Section no 474 . Transaction deemed to be made : (1) If there is giveand-take of any amount or goods between two or more persons subject to any condition, transaction shall be deemed to have been made between them.
output: According to Section 474(1) the Rule: any give-and-take of amount or goods between people subject to a condition is legally deemed a transaction. Application/Conclusion: Your conditional giving of goods is treated as a transaction under the law, so legal rules on transactions will apply to your situation.

instruction: I accepted money from a friend under a condition, but now I want to return it. Do I have to?
input: Section no 474  part (2) : If a transaction is made pursuant to sub-section (1), the receiver of amount or goods shall return the same to the giver of amount or goods. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “amount” includes the price of a goods.
output: According to Section 474(2) the Rule: where a transaction exists under subsection (1), the receiver must return the amount or goods to the giver. Application/Conclusion: As the receiver, you are legally obliged to return the amount or goods to your friend (the giver) in accordance with this provision.

instruction: Someone says I borrowed goods from them but there was no formal loan—what does the law say about obligations like that?
input: Section no 475 .Loan deemed to be borrowed : If a person has an obligation to pay any amount or goods to another person in any manner, such 138 obligation shall be deemed to be a loan borrowed by that person, and such a person shall return such amount or goods to the concerned person, subject to the provisions of this Chapter.
output: According to Section 475 the Rule: any obligation to pay amount or goods to another is treated as a loan borrowed by the obliged person, who must return the amount or goods. Application/Conclusion: Even without a formal loan document, the law treats that obligation as a loan — the person with the obligation must return the money or goods to the other party under the Chapter's rules.

instruction: Can I carry out a sale or loan without writing anything down?
input: Section no 476 . Transaction not to be carried on without executing deed : No person shall carry on transaction without executing a deed in accordance with law. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “deed” means any document that substantiates a transaction including a cheque, bill, voucher and receipt.
output: According to Section 476 the Rule: transactions cannot be carried out without executing a deed as required by law; a deed includes documents like cheques, bills, vouchers, and receipts. Application/Conclusion: You cannot legally complete a transaction informally without a supporting deed — you must execute an appropriate written document (even a receipt or cheque may suffice) as evidence.

instruction: What details must I include in a deed when lending money to my cousin?
input: Section no 477  clause (a) : Name, surname, age and address of each person involved in transaction, and name of his or her father, mother, grand-father and grand-mother, Provided that in the case of a married person, the name of his or her husband or wife, as the case may be, shall also be mentioned.
output: According to Section 477(a) the Rule: the deed must state name, surname, age, address of each person involved, and names of their father, mother, grandfather and grandmother; for married persons, the spouse's name must also appear. Application/Conclusion: Your loan deed should include your cousin’s full personal details and family names (and your details) as listed, to satisfy the formal requirements.

instruction: Can I charge any interest on a loan stated in the deed?
input: Section no 478 . Entitlement of creditor to interest from debtor : (1) If a deed on transaction provides for the payment of interest, the creditor may collect the interest from the debtor as set forth in the deed.
output: According to Section 478(1) the Rule: if the deed provides for interest, the creditor may collect interest from the debtor as the deed specifies. Application/Conclusion: You may charge and collect interest only if the deed includes that provision and you must follow the terms set out in the deed.

instruction: Is there a legal limit on how much interest I can charge per year?
input: Section no 478  part (2) : The amount of interest which the creditor is entitled to collect from the debtor pursuant to sub-section (1) shall not exceed ten percent of the principal per annum.
output: According to Section 478(2) the Rule: interest charged under a deed cannot exceed ten percent of the principal per annum. Application/Conclusion: You cannot legally charge more than 10% per year on the principal, even if the deed states a higher rate — any higher rate would exceed the statutory cap.
