not appear within the time limit referred to in sub-section (2), and, after the
expiration of the time limit, if it appears from the received petition, registered
deed and records of the oﬀice that pre-emption is to be effected, the oﬀice shall
make decision to effect pre emption and give an execution slip to the person
entitled to pre 251 emption to enjoy the property to be pre-empted, and send
a notice to the person obliged to allow preemption to receive the amount of
deposit made pursuant to sub-section (1).
output:
According to Section 460(5):
Rule: Where the obliged person does not appear and the office finds pre-emption should be effected, the office will decide to effect pre-emption, issue an execution slip to the entitled person to enjoy the property, and send notice to the obliged person to collect the deposited amount.
Application/Conclusion: If the seller never appears and the office’s review supports pre-emption, you can receive an execution slip and legally enjoy the property; the office will also notify the seller to collect the deposit you made.

instruction: The seller appeared but says your market price is wrong. Who determines the market price?
input:
Section no 460  part (6) : If the person obliged to allow pre-emption appears
within the time-limit referred to in sub-section (2) but expresses his or her
disagreement with the market price of such property, the oﬀice that approves
the registration of the deed shall fix the market price of that property and effect
pre-emption by having the amount equal to that market price paid to the person
obliged to allow pre emption.
output:
According to Section 460(6):
Rule: If the obliged person appears and disputes the market price, the registration office shall fix the market price and effect pre-emption by paying that fixed amount to the obliged person.
Application/Conclusion: The office is the authority to determine the market price in case of dispute; once fixed, the office will pay that amount to the obliged person and complete the pre-emption.

instruction: Do I file the pre-emption petition at the same office where the deed is being registered?
input:
Section no 460 .
Procedures for making pre-emption : (1) A person
who intends to make pre-emption of any immovable property pursuant to this
Chapter shall make a petition to the oﬀice making registration of the relevant
deed, and such a petition has to be accompanied by a deposit of an amount
equal to the price of the property to be pre empted, if any, indicated in the
deed registered for the transfer of 250 such property, or an amount equal to the
prevailing market price if such price is not indicated in the deed, and the fees
charged in the approval of registration of such a deed.
output:
According to Section 460(1):
Rule: The petition must be made to the office making registration of the relevant deed.
Application/Conclusion: File your pre-emption petition at the same registration office where the relevant deed is being registered, and include the required deposit and fees.

instruction: What fees come with the petition — do I need to pay registration approval fees too?
input:
Section no 460 .
Procedures for making pre-emption : (1) A person
who intends to make pre-emption of any immovable property pursuant to this
Chapter shall make a petition to the oﬀice making registration of the relevant
deed, and such a petition has to be accompanied by a deposit of an amount
equal to the price of the property to be pre empted, if any, indicated in the
deed registered for the transfer of 250 such property, or an amount equal to the
prevailing market price if such price is not indicated in the deed, and the fees
charged in the approval of registration of such a deed.
output:
According to Section 460(1):
Rule: The petition must be accompanied by the deposit (price or market price) and the fees charged in the approval of registration of the deed.
Application/Conclusion: You must pay the registration approval fees along with the deposit when submitting the pre-emption petition.

instruction: My father died and left property. Several heirs want to pre-empt. If the nearest heirs are more than one, who can proceed?
input:
part (4) : If, there are more than one heir intending to
make pre emption pursuant to sub-section (1) or (2), the nearest heir, and the
most aggrieved heir, if even the nearest heirs are more than one, may make
pre-emption.
output:
According to Section 458(4):
Rule: The nearest heir may make pre-emption; if there are multiple nearest heirs, the most aggrieved heir among them may make pre-emption.
Application/Conclusion: Where several heirs are equally nearest, the heir who is most aggrieved among those nearest heirs has the right to exercise pre-emption on the inherited property.

instruction: Is it true that parts of joint housing are protected from pre-emption no matter what?
input:
Section no 459 . Where pre-emption is not permitted : Notwithstanding
anything contained in Sections 457 and 458, any part of or house built under
the provision of joint housing shall not be subject to pre-emption.
output:
According to Section 459:
Rule: Regardless of other provisions, any part or house built under joint housing is not subject to pre-emption.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — such units are excluded from pre-emption; joint-housing parts cannot be pre-empted even if other sections might allow it.

instruction: If I deposit the market price with the registration office and later the obliged person refuses to appear, can the office still give me the execution slip?
input:
Section no 460  part (5) : If the person obliged to allow pre-emption does
not appear within the time limit referred to in sub-section (2), and, after the
expiration of the time limit, if it appears from the received petition, registered
deed and records of the oﬀice that pre-emption is to be effected, the oﬀice shall
make decision to effect pre emption and give an execution slip to the person
entitled to pre 251 emption to enjoy the property to be pre-empted, and send
a notice to the person obliged to allow preemption to receive the amount of
deposit made pursuant to sub-section (1).
output:
According to Section 460(5):
Rule: If the obliged person does not appear and the office’s records support pre-emption, the office will decide to effect pre-emption, issue an execution slip to the entitled person, and notify the obliged person to collect the deposited amount.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — after you deposit the market price and the obliged person fails to appear, the office can issue an execution slip so you may enjoy the property; it will inform the obliged person to collect the deposit.

instruction: They say the market price I'm depositing is too low. Who finally sets the price and what happens next?
input:
Section no 460  part (6) : If the person obliged to allow pre-emption appears
within the time-limit referred to in sub-section (2) but expresses his or her
disagreement with the market price of such property, the oﬀice that approves
the registration of the deed shall fix the market price of that property and effect
pre-emption by having the amount equal to that market price paid to the person
obliged to allow pre emption.
output:
According to Section 460(6):
Rule: The registration office will fix the market price when the obliged person disputes it, and effect pre-emption by paying that fixed amount to the obliged person.
Application/Conclusion: The office resolves the dispute by determining the market price itself; once fixed, the office pays that sum to the obliged person and completes the pre-emption.

instruction: I submitted a petition. What immediate steps does the registration office take after receiving it?
input:
Section no 460  part (2) : If a petition is received pursuant to sub-section
(1), the oﬀice that approves the registration of the deed shall hold the petitioner
on recognizance and send a process of summon to the person obliged to allow
preemption to appear in the oﬀice, within a period of seven days excluding the
time required for journey.
output:
According to Section 460(2):
Rule: On receipt of the petition the registration office holds the petitioner on recognizance and summons the person obliged to allow pre-emption to appear within seven days (excluding travel time).
Application/Conclusion: After you file, expect the office to keep you on recognizance and to issue a summon to the obliged person to appear within the specified seven-day period.

instruction: If records show pre-emption should not be made, will the office tell me?
input:
Section no 460  part (4) : If, despite that the person obliged to allow preemption does not appear and consent to preemption within the time-limit referred
to in sub-section (2), it appears from the received petition, registered deed and
records of the oﬀice that pre-emption is to be effected, the oﬀice that approves
registration of the deed shall make decision to effect pre-emption, and if it appears that pre-emption is not to be made, that oﬀice shall make decision not to
effect pre emption and give according information to the petitioner.
output:
According to Section 460(4):
Rule: The office must decide based on petition, deed and records whether to effect pre-emption; if it finds pre-emption is not appropriate, it shall decide not to effect it and inform the petitioner.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the office concludes pre-emption should not be made, it will notify you of its decision rather than silently rejecting the petition.

instruction: Can the lender charge 15% interest if the deed only says 'interest' but gives no rate?
input:
part (3) : If the deed executed pursuant to sub-section (1)
does not provide for the rate of interest but only for the payment of interest,
the creditor may collect interest from the debtor at the rate of ten percent of
the principal per annum.
output: According to Section 478 part (3)... Rule: If a deed only provides for the payment of interest but does not state the rate, the creditor may collect interest at 10% per annum on the principal. Application/Conclusion: The lender cannot lawfully charge 15%; the default permitted rate is 10% per year.

instruction: My loan deed says 'profit' instead of 'interest' but doesn't state the amount. Can the creditor treat it like interest?
input:
Section no 478  part (4) : If the deed executed pursuant to sub-section (1)
provides for the payment of profit instead of interest but does not specify the
amount of such profit, the creditor may collect such profit from the debtor as if
it were interest.
output: According to Section 478 part (4)... Rule: Where a deed provides for payment of 'profit' (not interest) and the amount is unspecified, the creditor may collect that profit as if it were interest. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the deed says 'profit' but gives no amount, the creditor can claim it under the same rules as interest.

instruction: The loan agreement has no mention of interest. Can the creditor demand interest later?
input:
Section no 479 . Creditor not allowed to collect interest from debtor : If the deed on transaction does not provide for the payment of interest, the
creditor shall not collect interest from the debtor.
output: According to Section 479... Rule: If the deed does not provide for payment of interest, the creditor shall not collect interest. Application/Conclusion: If your deed is silent about interest, the creditor cannot lawfully demand interest later.

instruction: They added monthly compounding to my loan. Do I have to pay compound interest?
input:
Section no 480 . Compound interest not to be collected : (1) The
creditor shall not collect compound interest from the debtor.
output: According to Section 480(1)... Rule: Creditors are prohibited from collecting compound interest. Application/Conclusion: You are not required to pay compound interest; any attempt to charge it is contrary to law.

instruction: The lender already collected compound interest from me and kept the repayments. What remedies do I have?
input:
Section no 480  part (2) : If any creditor collects compound interest from a
debtor in contravention of sub-section (1), such interest shall be deducted from
the principal and refunded if the principal has already been repaid.
output: According to Section 480 part (2)... Rule: If a creditor unlawfully collects compound interest, that interest must be deducted from the principal, and if the principal has already been repaid, the compound interest must be refunded. Application/Conclusion: You can require the lender to deduct the compound interest from your outstanding principal; if you've already repaid the principal, you should get the collected compound interest refunded.

instruction: Can a creditor demand interest that ends up exceeding the original loan amount?
input:
Section no 481 . Interest in excess of principal not to be collected : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, the creditor
shall not collect interest in excess of the principal.
output: According to Section 481... Rule: A creditor shall not collect interest in excess of the principal. Application/Conclusion: Interest that would push total payments above the principal is unlawful; the creditor cannot collect interest exceeding the principal amount.

instruction: I repaid the full principal and interest — what must the creditor do with the deed?
input:
Section no 482  clause (a) : If the debtor repays the whole of the principal
and interest, the creditor shall sign and return the deed on transaction to the
debtor by tearing out the deed or indicating on its space or reverse side that
the loan has been repaid,
output: According to Section 482 clause (a)... Rule: When the debtor repays all principal and interest, the creditor must sign and return the deed by tearing it out or marking on it (or its reverse) that the loan has been repaid. Application/Conclusion: You should insist the creditor return the deed with a clear marking or tearing out to show the debt is discharged.

instruction: I repaid everything but the creditor says the written deed is lost. What should I ask for?
input:
Section no 482  clause (b) : If the deed is not found at the time of repayment
of the principal and interest pursuant to clause (a), the creditor shall give the
debtor a receipt indicating the receipt of the particular amount on the particular
date,
output: According to Section 482 clause (b)... Rule: If the deed cannot be found when repayment is made, the creditor must give the debtor a receipt stating the exact amount received and the date. Application/Conclusion: Request a dated receipt showing the amounts you paid; that receipt is the creditor's obligation and your proof of repayment.

instruction: I paid part of the loan today. What does the creditor have to record?
input:
Section no 482  clause (c) : In repaying some amount out of the principal and
interest, the creditor shall indicate on the reverse side of the deed how much he
or she has received from the debtor on which date, and get the debtor to sign
the deed and issue a separate receipt of amount accordingly if the deed is not
found immediately or it is not with the creditor for the time being.
output: According to Section 482 clause (c)... Rule: When only part of the principal/interest is repaid, the creditor must note on the reverse of the deed the amount received and the date, obtain the debtor's signature, and issue a receipt if the deed is not available. Application/Conclusion: Insist the creditor record the payment on the deed's reverse and sign it with your acknowledgment, or provide a separate receipt if the deed isn't present.

instruction: If a court gives a judgment in my favour, from what date can the creditor claim interest?
input:
Section no 483 . Interest accruable as of the date of recovery of amount : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if the court
passes a judgment on a lawsuit, if any, made within the period under Section
484 entitling the creditor to recover interest as well, the creditor shall be entitled
to the interest as of the date of recovery according to the judgment.
output: According to Section 483... Rule: If a court issues a judgment (from a suit filed within the period under Section 484) that entitles the creditor to interest, the creditor is entitled to interest as of the date of recovery stated in the judgment. Application/Conclusion: If the creditor sues within the allowable period and wins interest in judgment, interest will be recoverable from the judgment's recovery date, not earlier or later arbitrarily.

instruction: How long can a household deed be valid for? Short answer, please.
input:
Section no 484 . Period of deed executed in household : (1) The period
of a deed executed in household pursuant to this Chapter shall not exceed ten
years.
output: According to Section 484(1)... Rule: A household deed under this Chapter cannot have a period exceeding ten years. Application/Conclusion: The maximum lawful term for such a deed is 10 years.

instruction: We extended the loan term once and I repaid some interest during the first ten years. Does the ten-year limit restart?
input:
Section no 484  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if the debtor repays some of the principal or interest thereon to the creditor
or the term of a deed is extended for the repayment of principal or interest
within the period of ten years, another period of ten years shall be extended
from the date of such repayment of principal or interest or extension of the
period, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 484 part (2)... Rule: If within the initial ten-year period the debtor repays some principal/interest or the deed term is extended for repayment, a further ten-year period is extended from the date of that repayment or extension. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a repayment or an agreed extension made within the first ten years restarts a new ten-year period from that date.

instruction: Under which section is it stated that a creditor cannot collect interest exceeding the principal? I need to cite it.
input:
Section no 481 . Interest in excess of principal not to be collected : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, the creditor
shall not collect interest in excess of the principal.
output: According to Section 481... Rule: The law expressly prohibits collecting interest in excess of the principal. Application/Conclusion: Cite Section 481 — it is the provision that bars any creditor from collecting interest exceeding the principal.

instruction: I signed a household deed for 12 years. Is that term valid?
input:
Section no 484 . Period of deed executed in household : (1) The period
of a deed executed in household pursuant to this Chapter shall not exceed ten
years.
output: According to Section 484(1)... Rule: A household deed's period shall not exceed ten years. Application/Conclusion: A 12-year term exceeds the statutory maximum and is not valid as to the excess; the lawful maximum is ten years.

instruction: The creditor won't return or mark the deed after I repaid the loan. What does the law require them to do?
input:
Section no 482  clause (a) : If the debtor repays the whole of the principal
and interest, the creditor shall sign and return the deed on transaction to the
debtor by tearing out the deed or indicating on its space or reverse side that
the loan has been repaid,
output: According to Section 482 clause (a)... Rule: After full repayment, the creditor must sign and return the deed, either by tearing it out or marking on it that the loan is repaid. Application/Conclusion: You can demand the deed back with a signed marking or tearing out; the creditor is legally obliged to do so once you have repaid in full.

instruction: They collected a 'profit' sum but now want to apply a higher percentage they invented. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 478  part (4) : If the deed executed pursuant to sub-section (1)
provides for the payment of profit instead of interest but does not specify the
amount of such profit, the creditor may collect such profit from the debtor as if
it were interest.
output: According to Section 478 part (4)... Rule: Where a deed provides for 'profit' without specifying an amount, that profit is recoverable as if it were interest. Application/Conclusion: The creditor may claim 'profit' treated like interest, but cannot arbitrarily impose an unspecified higher rate beyond what interest rules permit; any claimed amount must conform to how interest would lawfully be calculated.

instruction: Rajan lent me money and now sues for interest, but our deed contains no interest clause. What's my position?
input:
Section no 479 . Creditor not allowed to collect interest from debtor : If the deed on transaction does not provide for the payment of interest, the
creditor shall not collect interest from the debtor.
output: According to Section 479... Rule: If the deed does not provide for payment of interest, the creditor shall not collect interest. Application/Conclusion: Rajan cannot lawfully recover interest under the deed if there is no clause providing for interest; his suit seeking interest would not be supported by this provision.

instruction: Explain in simple terms what 'compound interest not to be collected' means — I'm not a lawyer.
input:
Section no 480 . Compound interest not to be collected : (1) The
creditor shall not collect compound interest from the debtor.
output: According to Section 480(1)... Rule: Creditors are prohibited from charging compound interest. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, the lender cannot charge interest on top of previously charged interest (no 'interest on interest'); you only owe interest calculated on the principal as allowed by law, not compounded amounts.

instruction: Can I register a house rent agreement if the monthly rent is Rs. 120,000?
input:
clause (h) : A deed on house renting with a monthly rent of
more than one hundred thousand rupees,
 Section no 464  part (2) : If any person fails to have registered a deed required
to be registered pursuant to sub-section (1), such a deed shall not be legally
recognized.
output:
According to Section 464 (clauses h and part (2)).
Rule: A deed on house renting with a monthly rent of more than one hundred thousand rupees is included among the deeds set out in Section 464, and if a deed required to be registered under subsection (1) is not registered, it shall not be legally recognized.
Application/Conclusion: Because your rent is above the threshold, your renting deed falls within Section 464(h) and therefore must be registered; if it is not registered it will not be legally recognized.

instruction: Is a usufruct deed in land required to be registered?
input:
clause (i) : A deed on usufruct in an immovable property,
 Section no 464
output:
According to Section 464 (clause i).
Rule: A deed on usufruct in an immovable property is specifically listed under Section 464.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — a usufruct deed in immovable property is a deed contemplated by Section 464 and is among those that must be registered.

instruction: I made a sale deed but didn't register it. Is the deed valid?
input:
part (2) : If any person fails to have registered a deed required
to be registered pursuant to sub-section (1), such a deed shall not be legally
recognized.
output:
According to Section 464(2).
Rule: Any deed required to be registered under subsection (1) that is not registered shall not be legally recognized.
Application/Conclusion: If your sale deed is one of the deeds required by subsection (1) of Section 464 and you failed to register it, the deed will not be legally recognized.

instruction: Can I voluntarily register a deed that is NOT listed in Section 464?
input:
Section no 465 . Other deeds may be registered : (1) A person may, if
he or she so intends, have registered also any deed other than that set forth in
Section 464.
output:
According to Section 465(1).
Rule: A person may, by choice, have registered any deed other than those listed in Section 464.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — you may voluntarily register deeds not listed in Section 464 if you wish.

instruction: If I apply to register a deed that's not in Section 464, will the office have to register it?
input:
Section no 465  part (2) : If a person makes an application for the approval
of registration of a deed pursuant to sub-section (1), the concerned oﬀice shall
register such deed by fulfilling the legal requirements.
output:
According to Section 465(2).
Rule: Where a person applies for approval of registration under subsection (1), the concerned office shall register the deed after fulfilling the legal requirements.
Application/Conclusion: If you apply to register such an 'other' deed, the office is obliged to register it provided the legal requirements are met.

instruction: Can I ask the registration office to send someone to my place to register a deed? How long before they must visit?
input:
Section no 466 . Deed may be registered by commission : (1) If a person
makes an application to the concerned oﬀice for the approval of registration of
a deed by a commission deputed by the oﬀice and it appears that such a deed
can be registered by that oﬀice, the chief of oﬀice or other employee deputed
by him or her shall, on deposit with the oﬀice of the fees chargeable for such
registration, visit the location indicated by the applicant within five days and
register such a deed by fulfilling the legal requirements.
output:
According to Section 466(1).
Rule: If you apply for registration by a commission and it appears the office can register the deed, the chief or deputed employee shall, after you deposit the required fees, visit the location indicated by you within five days and register the deed by fulfilling legal requirements.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can request registration by a commission, and they are required to visit the location and carry out the registration within five days after you deposit the fees.

instruction: The commission visited but did not approve my deed. When must I get my deposit back?
input:
Section no 466  part (3) : If, for any reason, the deed is not approved and
registered by a commission deputed pursuant to sub-section (1), the applicant
shall get refund of the deposit within three months.
output:
According to Section 466(3).
Rule: If a deed is not approved and registered by the deputed commission, the applicant shall receive a refund of the deposit within three months.
Application/Conclusion: You must be refunded your deposit within three months if the commission did not approve and register your deed.

instruction: I applied for registration by commission but didn't get my refund after three months — what happens to my deposit?
input:
Section no 466  part (4) : If the applicant fails to get refund of the deposit
within the time-limit referred to in sub-section (3), the oﬀice shall credit such
deposit into revenue.
output:
According to Section 466(4).
Rule: If the applicant does not get a refund within the three-month period, the office shall credit the deposit into revenue.
Application/Conclusion: If you haven't received the refund within three months, the office is authorized to treat (credit) that deposit as revenue.

instruction: Can my parties register a deed in a district where none of us lives or where the property isn't located?
input:
Section no 467 . Deed may be approved and registered with oﬀice in
other : district: (1) If the parties to a deed intend to get the deed approved and
registered in a district other than the district in which either of them resides or
136
the property is situated, they shall make an application, setting out the matter,
to the concerned oﬀice of that district.
output:
According to Section 467(1).
Rule: Parties who wish to have a deed approved and registered in a district other than where they reside or where the property is situated must apply to the concerned office of that district, setting out the matter.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — the parties can seek registration in another district by making an application to that district's concerned office and explaining the matter.

instruction: If we apply to register in another district, will that other district office have to investigate and register it?
input:
Section no 467  part (2) : If an application is made for the registration of
a deed pursuant to sub-section (1), such an oﬀice shall make necessary inquiry
into the matter and approve and register such deed by fulfilling the legal requirements.
output:
According to Section 467(2).
Rule: When an application is made under subsection (1), the concerned office shall conduct necessary inquiry and, after fulfilling legal requirements, approve and register the deed.
Application/Conclusion: The other district's office must inquire into the application and, if legal requirements are satisfied, approve and register the deed.

instruction: If my property deed is registered in another district, will the original district's office be informed?
input:
Section no 467  part (3) : If a deed of immovable property is approved and
registered in other district pursuant to sub-section (2), the oﬀice shall send a
copy of the registered deed to the relevant oﬀice of the concerned district.
output:
According to Section 467(3).
Rule: When an immovable property deed is approved and registered in another district under subsection (2), the registering office shall send a copy of the registered deed to the relevant office of the concerned district.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your immovable property deed is registered in another district, a copy will be sent to the relevant office in the concerned district.

instruction: How is the fee for registering a deed determined?
input:
Section no 468 . Fee chargeable for registration of deed : (1) The fee
specified by law shall be charged for the approval and registration of a deed.
output:
According to Section 468(1).
Rule: The fee specified by law must be charged for the approval and registration of a deed.
Application/Conclusion: The registration fee is the fee set out in the applicable law; you will be charged whatever fee the law specifies for that deed's approval and registration.

instruction: What fee is charged if the law does not specify a registration fee? Also what if the declared price is below the government's minimum?
input:
Section no 468  part (2) : Except where the law provides for the fee of approval
and registration of a deed, fee shall be charged according to the amount set forth
in the deed dealing with transaction of money. 256 Provided that if the price of
the immovable property referred to in the deed is less than the minimum price
specified by the Government of Nepal, the fee shall be charged according to the
price specified by the Government of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 468(2).
Rule: If the law does not provide a specific fee, the fee is charged according to the amount stated in the deed concerning a money transaction; however, if the immovable property's price in the deed is less than the minimum price set by the Government of Nepal, the fee will be charged based on the government-specified price.
Application/Conclusion: If no statutory fee exists, the office will calculate the fee from the amount in your deed; but if that amount is below the government's minimum price for that property, the office will use the government-prescribed price to compute the fee.

instruction: Can the office's commission register any deed anywhere they like?
input:
Section no 466 . Deed may be registered by commission : (1) If a person
makes an application to the concerned oﬀice for the approval of registration of
a deed by a commission deputed by the oﬀice and it appears that such a deed
can be registered by that oﬀice, the chief of oﬀice or other employee deputed
by him or her shall, on deposit with the oﬀice of the fees chargeable for such
registration, visit the location indicated by the applicant within five days and
register such a deed by fulfilling the legal requirements.
output:
According to Section 466(1).
Rule: Registration by commission is available only where, upon application, it appears that the concerned office can register the deed; then the chief or a deputed employee will visit and register after fee deposit.
Application/Conclusion: No — the commission cannot register any deed anywhere at will. The office must first determine that the deed can be registered by that office; only then will the deputed official visit and register it.

instruction: Ram promised to register our agreement but didn't. If the agreement required registration and remains unregistered, can I enforce it?
input:
part (2) : If any person fails to have registered a deed required
to be registered pursuant to sub-section (1), such a deed shall not be legally
recognized.
output:
According to Section 464(2).
Rule: A deed that is required to be registered but is not registered shall not be legally recognized.
Application/Conclusion: If the agreement is of the kind required to be registered under Section 464 and Ram failed to register it, the agreement will not be legally recognized, which undermines your ability to enforce it as a registered deed.

instruction: If I want to register a deed in another district, what must my application include?
input:
Section no 467 . Deed may be approved and registered with oﬀice in
other : district: (1) If the parties to a deed intend to get the deed approved and
registered in a district other than the district in which either of them resides or
136
the property is situated, they shall make an application, setting out the matter,
to the concerned oﬀice of that district.
output:
According to Section 467(1).
Rule: Parties wishing to register in another district must make an application to that district's concerned office and set out the matter in the application.
Application/Conclusion: Your application should be made to the concerned office of the other district and must set out the details of the matter (i.e., explain why and what you seek to have registered).

instruction: If the commission approves my deed, what happens to the deposit I paid?
input:
Section no 466  part (2) : If the deed is approved by a commission deputed
pursuant to sub-section (1), the oﬀice shall credit into revenue the deposit made
pursuant to that sub-section. 255
output:
According to Section 466(2).
Rule: If the deed is approved by the deputed commission, the office shall credit the applicant's deposit into revenue.
Application/Conclusion: When the commission approves and registers the deed, the deposit you paid will be credited into the office's revenue (i.e., retained as revenue).

instruction: Under which section is the power to register deeds by commission laid out?
input:
Section no 466 . Deed may be registered by commission : (1) If a person

output:
According to Section 466.
Rule: Section 466 provides for registration of deeds by a commission deputed by the office, including the procedure and timing once application and fee deposit are made.
Application/Conclusion: The statutory basis for having a deed registered by commission is Section 466; you should rely on Section 466 when seeking registration by commission.

instruction: Can I sell a movable item that is part of our joint family property without the head of family's permission?
input: Section no 487 . Exchange of movable property not allowed without consent : (1) A person of majority age in a joint family is not allowed to exchange any movable property in common without consent of the person acting as the head of family. Provided that the consent of the person acting as the head of family shall not be required to exchange his or her private property.
output: According to Section 487(1). Rule: A majority-aged person in a joint family cannot exchange movable property in common without the head of family's consent; the head's consent is not required only for the person's private property. Application/Conclusion: If the movable item is common (household) property, you cannot lawfully sell or exchange it without the head's consent. If it is your clearly private property, you may exchange it without that consent.

instruction: My sister signed a sale deed but our head of family didn't sign. Can the buyer (creditor) recover money from our shared property?
input: Section no 486  part (1) : If any person carries on transaction with another person and the deed of such transaction does not bear the signature of the person acting as the head of family, the creditor shall not be entitled to recover his or her amount from such property until the debtor’s right in the property in common is established.
output: According to Section 486(1). Rule: A deed lacking the head of family's signature prevents a creditor from recovering against the common property until the debtor's right in that property is established. Application/Conclusion: The buyer cannot immediately recover money from the joint property; recovery is blocked until the debtor's individual right in the common property is legally established.

instruction: If the head of the family repays a loan that my brother took without the head's signature, can the creditor then recover the money?
input: Section no 486  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if the person acting as the head of family repays such amount, the creditor may recover the same.
output: According to Section 486(2). Rule: Even if a deed lacked the head's signature, if the head of family repays the amount, the creditor may recover it. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the head repays the loan, the creditor can lawfully recover that amount (against whoever repaid or as permitted by law).

instruction: I discovered today that a sale was done without the head's signature and I can't recover the debt. How long do I have to file a lawsuit?
input: Section no 486  part (3) : If any person is not able to recover the amount from the debtor on the occurrence of the circumstance referred to in sub section (1), the creditor shall make a lawsuit against the debtor and maintain his or her right within a period of ten years. 264
output: According to Section 486(3). Rule: Where recovery is prevented by the circumstance in subsection (1) (deed without head's signature), the creditor must file a lawsuit and preserve the right within ten years. Application/Conclusion: You have a ten-year period from the relevant occurrence to bring and maintain a lawsuit against the debtor to protect your right.

instruction: If I later establish that the debtor had a right in the common property, when does the limitation period to sue for recovery start?
input: Section no 486  part (5) : The statute of limitation for making a lawsuit shall, for the recovery of the amount pursuant to sub-section (4), commence from the date of establishment of the debtor’s right.
output: According to Section 486(5). Rule: The limitation period for a lawsuit to recover amounts under subsection (4) begins from the date the debtor's right in the property is established. Application/Conclusion: The clock for the statute of limitations to sue for recovery starts only when the debtor's right in the common property is legally established.

instruction: We couldn't recover money at first because the deed lacked the head's signature. After we maintained the right with the debtor, can we then recover from the debtor?
input: Section no 486  part (4) : In the event of the maintenance of the right with the debtor pursuant to sub-section (3), the creditor may recover his or her amount from the debtor in accordance with law after his or her right in the property in common has been established.
output: According to Section 486(4). Rule: If the creditor maintains the right with the debtor as per subsection (3), then after the debtor's right in the common property is established, the creditor may recover the amount from the debtor according to law. Application/Conclusion: Yes — once you have maintained your right (sued as required) and the debtor's right in the common property is established, you may recover the debt from the debtor as provided by law.

instruction: Someone exchanged a household movable item without getting our head of family's consent. Is that exchange valid?
input: Section no 487  part (2) : If a person exchanges a movable property in contravention of sub-section (1), the exchange of such property shall not be valid 141
output: According to Section 487(2). Rule: Exchanges made in contravention of subsection (1) (i.e., without the head's consent) are not valid. Application/Conclusion: The exchange is invalid if it was done without the required consent of the head of family.

instruction: They took a shared television and transferred it to another person without our head's consent. Can we get it back now? It's been 20 days.
input: Section no 487  part (3) : If there is no consent of the person acting as the head of family to the exchange of movable property made in contravention of sub-section (1), the property so exchanged may be taken back within thirty-five days.
output: According to Section 487(3). Rule: Property exchanged without the head's consent may be taken back within thirty-five days. Application/Conclusion: Yes — because it has been only 20 days (less than 35), you may take the property back under this provision.

instruction: They took the item without consent, but now it's been 40 days. Can we still repossess it?
input: Section no 487  part (3) : If there is no consent of the person acting as the head of family to the exchange of movable property made in contravention of sub-section (1), the property so exchanged may be taken back within thirty-five days.
output: According to Section 487(3). Rule: Property taken without the head's consent may be reclaimed only within thirty-five days. Application/Conclusion: No — after 40 days you have passed the thirty-five-day period, so this provision no longer permits taking the property back.

instruction: A transaction looks informal but the bank paid by cheque and there are voucher records. Can the court treat this as proof and order recovery?
input: Section no 488 . Recovery of amount if transaction appears to have been carried : Even though any person does not execute a deed by fulfilling the procedures referred to in this Chapter, if it appears from any deed, banking transaction, negotiable instrument, cheque, voucher or book of account that transaction has been carried on with any 265 person, the court may, based on such deed, banking transaction, negotiable instrument, cheque, voucher or book of account, order the recovery of such amount from the debtor to the lawsuit maker.
output: According to Section 488. Rule: Even if formal deed procedures were not followed, if evidence (deed, bank transaction, cheque, voucher, book of account, etc.) shows a transaction took place, the court may order recovery based on that evidence. Application/Conclusion: Yes — bank cheques and vouchers can support a court order for recovery; the court can rely on those records to order repayment.

instruction: If a deed executed in our household was destroyed by flood, what must I do first and by when?
input: Section no 489 . Procedure to be followed if deed executed on household is lost : or destroyed due to force majeure event: (1) If a deed executed in household is lost or destroyed due to a force majeure event, the creditor shall make an application, setting out the matter, to the concerned Local Level within fifteen days from the date of loss or occurrence of the force majeure event.
output: According to Section 489(1). Rule: When a household deed is lost/destroyed due to a force majeure event, the creditor must apply to the concerned Local Level, setting out the matter, within fifteen days of the loss/event. Application/Conclusion: You should submit an application to the Local Level describing the loss within 15 days of the flood/event to comply with the procedure.

instruction: I filed the application about the lost deed at the Local Level. Will they give me anything as proof?
input: Section no 489  part (2) : If an application is made pursuant to sub-section (1), the concerned Local Level shall draw up a receipt setting out the matter and issue the receipt, sealed with the stamp of the oﬀice, to the applicant.
output: According to Section 489(2). Rule: The Local Level must draw up and issue a stamped receipt describing the matter when an application under subsection (1) is made. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the Local Level should give you a stamped receipt documenting your application about the lost deed.

instruction: If I transacted with someone who is legally incompetent or quasi-competent, will that transaction be recognized?
input: . Transaction carried on with incompetent or quasicompetent : person not to be recognized: A transaction carried on by a person with an incompetent or quasi-competent person shall not get legal recognition.
output: According to Section 486 (general provision). Rule: Transactions carried out with an incompetent or quasi-competent person do not receive legal recognition. Application/Conclusion: Such a transaction is not legally recognized and would not be enforceable unless other legal conditions change that status.

instruction: Can I get a new deed prepared if the original is lost but the deed executor is alive?

instruction: My executor won't agree to recreate a lost deed. What can I do and how long do I have?

instruction: I suspect my seller delivered defective goods. How long do I have to notify them?
input:
Section no 490 . To return goods transacted in the event of imperfection : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the deed, if the receiver of any
goods transacted with specification of price is not able to possess the goods due
to the fact that the goods do not correspond to that set forth in the deed or
are imperfect for any reason, he or she shall give a notice thereof to the giver of
goods within thirty-five days of such transaction.
output: According to Section 490(1): Rule: The receiver of goods must give notice to the giver within thirty-five days of the transaction if the goods do not match the deed or are imperfect. Application/Conclusion: You must notify the seller within 35 days from the transaction date if the goods are defective or do not conform to the deed.

instruction: If I notify the seller about imperfect goods and my claim is reasonable, what should happen next?
input:

pursuant to sub-section (1) and his or her statement appears to be reasonable,

if the giver does not have such goods, he or she shall get back his or her goods
and cancel the deed executed in relation to such transaction.
output: According to Section 490(2): Rule: Upon a reasonable notice by the receiver, the giver must exchange the goods if similar goods are available; if not, the giver must take back the goods and the deed related to the transaction shall be cancelled. Application/Conclusion: If your notice is reasonable and the seller has similar goods, they must exchange them; if they have no similar goods, they must take the goods back and the sale deed can be cancelled.

instruction: Seller refuses to exchange or take back imperfect goods. What remedies do I have?
input:

the concerned person or get such transaction to be void.
output: According to Section 490(3): Rule: If the giver refuses to exchange or take back goods, the receiver may sue for recovery of the price and reasonable compensation for loss/damage, or seek to have the transaction declared void. Application/Conclusion: If the seller refuses, you can file a lawsuit to recover the price plus compensation for damages or ask the court to void the transaction.

instruction: I borrowed equipment for a job. Do I need to return it the same way?
input:
Section no 491 . To return goods in original condition : (1) If any person
obtains or borrows for any specific purpose any goods owned or possessed by
another person whether for rent or not or for borrowing or not or on any other
terms and conditions, the person shall, after the completion of the purpose,
return the goods that are the same in kind, quantity and quality as have been
so acquired or borrowed, to the owner or possessor. 267
output: According to Section 491(1): Rule: A person who obtains or borrows goods for a specific purpose must, after the purpose is complete, return goods that are the same in kind, quantity and quality to the owner. Application/Conclusion: You must return the equipment in the same kind, quantity and quality as you received it once your job is finished.

instruction: What if the item I borrowed got lost or damaged while I had it — do I have to replace it?
input:
Section no 491  part (2) : If the goods obtained pursuant to sub-section
(1) are lost, broken, destroyed, out of order or otherwise damaged, except as
otherwise provided for in the deed, the person obtaining such goods shall return
similar other goods to the owner or possessor or pay to the owner or possessor
an amount equivalent to the prevailing market price of such goods if similar
other goods are not available.
output: According to Section 491(2): Rule: If borrowed goods are lost/damaged (unless deed says otherwise), the borrower must return similar goods or, if unavailable, pay the prevailing market price. Application/Conclusion: If the item you borrowed was lost or damaged, you must either replace it with a similar item or pay its market value to the owner unless the deed provides otherwise.

instruction: By when must I return borrowed goods or pay rent after completing the purpose?
input:
Section no 491  part (3) : Except as otherwise provided for in the deed in
relation to the return of, or payment of rent or amount for, the goods pursuant
to sub-section (1) or (2), such goods or rent shall be returned or paid to the
owner or possessor within fifteen days after the completion of the purpose for
which the goods were obtained.
output: According to Section 491(3): Rule: Unless the deed states otherwise, goods or rent must be returned or paid within fifteen days after the completion of the purpose. Application/Conclusion: You must return the goods or pay the agreed rent/amount within 15 days after finishing the purpose for which you obtained them, unless your agreement says otherwise.
