instruction: Can I sell my house even if my brother objects? I'm an adult — does his objection matter?
input: Section no 506 .Persons competent to concluded contract : (1) Every person other than the following persons shall be competent to conclude a contract:
output: According to Section 506... Rule: Every person, except those listed as excluded, is competent to conclude a contract. Application/Conclusion: If you are not among the excluded categories listed in Section 506 (for example, a minor or person of unsound mind), you are competent to sell your house even if your brother objects. His objection does not by itself make the contract invalid unless he falls into an excluded category.

instruction: Is my 17-year-old sister allowed to sign a lease agreement by law?
input: Section no 506  clause (a) : One who is a minor,
output: According to Section 506... Rule: Minors are listed as persons excluded from competence to conclude a contract. Application/Conclusion: Because your sister is a minor (17 years old), she is among the persons who are not competent to conclude a contract under Section 506(a), so she generally cannot validly sign a lease on her own.

instruction: My cousin has bipolar disorder and is 'sometimes fine, sometimes not.' Can he make contracts?
input: Section no 506  part (1) : A person who is usually of unsound mind, but occasionally of sound mind, may conclude a contract when he or she is of sound mind.
output: According to Section 506... Rule: A person usually of unsound mind but occasionally of sound mind may conclude a contract when he or she is of sound mind. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin is usually of unsound mind but presently is in a period of sound mind, he may validly conclude a contract during that lucid interval; otherwise, he may lack competence.

instruction: If someone is normally sane but has episodes of unsoundness, can they sign during an episode?
input: Section no 506  part (2) : A person who is usually of sound mind, but occasionally of unsound mind, may not conclude a contract when he or she is of unsound mind.
output: According to Section 506... Rule: A person usually of sound mind but occasionally unsound may not conclude a contract while they are in an unsound state. Application/Conclusion: If the person is currently experiencing an unsound episode, any contract they attempt to conclude during that time would not be valid because they lack competence at that moment.

instruction: If a law elsewhere says someone can't contract for a particular matter, does Section 506 allow them to anyway?
input: Section no 506  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), any person who is deemed incompetent to conclude a particular contract under the law shall not be deemed to be a competent to conclude such a contract.
output: According to Section 506... Rule: Even if subsection (1) might suggest competence, if another law deems a person incompetent for a particular contract, they remain incompetent for that contract. Application/Conclusion: If another statute or rule specifically declares a person incompetent to enter a particular kind of contract, Section 506 does not override that — the person cannot validly conclude that particular contract.

instruction: Can my guardian sign contracts for me if I'm found incompetent?
input: Section no 506  part (3) : In concluding a contract on behalf of a person who is incompetent or quasi-competent, his or her guardian or curator may conclude such a contract.
output: According to Section 506... Rule: A guardian or curator may conclude a contract on behalf of a person who is incompetent or quasi-competent. Application/Conclusion: If you are legally found incompetent or quasi-competent, your guardian or curator has authority to enter into contracts on your behalf under Section 506(3).

instruction: Who can sign contracts for a company? Do they need board approval?
input: Section no 506  part (4) : In concluding a contract on behalf of a legal person, it shall be conclude by a decision of the director or directors authorized for the management and operation of such a person or by a person authorized by such a director or directors.
output: According to Section 506... Rule: Contracts on behalf of a legal person (company) must be concluded by a decision of the authorized director(s) or by a person authorized by those directors. Application/Conclusion: A company contract needs to be entered by its authorized directors or by someone they have authorized; board or director authorization is required for validity under Section 506(4).

instruction: If another law says a supposedly incompetent person is competent for a certain matter, which rule applies?
input: Section no 506  part (5) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, if a person deemed to be incompetent to conclude a contract under this Chapter on any particular matter is competent by other law to conclude a contract on such a matter, such a person shall be deemed to be competent to conclude a contract on that matter.
output: According to Section 506... Rule: If other law grants competence for a particular matter despite being deemed incompetent by this Chapter, that person is treated as competent for that matter. Application/Conclusion: Where a separate law specifically allows a person otherwise deemed incompetent to conclude a particular contract, that specific legal permission supersedes Section 506's general rule and the person is competent for that matter.

instruction: Are parties free to choose the contents and dispute resolution methods in their contract?
input: Section no 507 . Parties to be autonomous : The parties to a contract shall, subject to this Act, be autonomous to choose the form and contents of the contract, to determine terms and conditions of the contact and the nature of the remedy for its breach as well as to determine the measures for resolving disputes arising out of it.
output: According to Section 507... Rule: Parties to a contract are, subject to the Act, autonomous to decide the form, content, terms, remedies and dispute resolution measures. Application/Conclusion: You and the other party may agree on contract form, terms, remedies for breach, and how to resolve disputes (e.g., arbitration), provided your choices do not violate applicable provisions of the Act.

instruction: Ram offered to sell land to Sita and she accepted but didn't tell him — she just started making payments. Is acceptance valid?
input: Section no 508  part (3) : Even though there is no expression of acceptance to the offer directly, if the offeree abides by any terms mentioned in the offer by way of his or her conduct or accepts the advantage or service mentioned in the offer or indicates acceptance in any other manner, the offeree shall be deemed to have accepted the offer.
output: According to Section 508... Rule: Acceptance may be inferred by conduct — if the offeree acts in accordance with the offer's terms or accepts the advantage/service, they are deemed to have accepted. Application/Conclusion: Sita's conduct in making payments or otherwise acting on the offer can be treated as acceptance under Section 508(3), so a contract may be formed even without explicit verbal or written acceptance.

instruction: When is an offer considered completed—does it require the offeree to actually know about it?
input: Section no 508 . Offer and acceptance deemed to be completed : (1) Once the offeree comes to the knowledge of an offer, the act of making the offer shall be deemed to have been completed.
output: According to Section 508... Rule: The act of making an offer is complete when the offeree comes to know of the offer. Application/Conclusion: An offer is only considered made (completed) at the moment the offeree learns of it; prior to that, there is no completed offer capable of acceptance by that offeree.

instruction: I sent acceptance by mail. When is the acceptance considered completed for the offerer and offeree?
input: Section no 508  part (2) : The act of giving acceptance shall be deemed to be completed, in case of the offerer, if the offerer receives the acceptance forwarded by the offeree to the offerer having indicated his or her acceptance to the offer, and in case of the offeree, if the offerer comes to know that the offeree has accepted the offer.
output: According to Section 508... Rule: Acceptance is deemed completed for the offerer when the offerer receives the forwarded acceptance; for the offeree it is completed when the offerer comes to know of the offeree's acceptance. Application/Conclusion: If you mailed acceptance, the act is completed for the offerer once the offerer actually receives your acceptance; for you as offeree, it is completed when the offerer learns that you accepted.

instruction: If someone stays silent on an offer that said 'silence = acceptance unless you reject within 7 days,' is silence valid acceptance?
input: Section no 508  part (4) : If the offerer makes an offer having stipulated certain time and specifies that the offer is regarded as accepted if a notice of its rejection is not sent within such time, and if the offeree does not send a notice of acceptance of the offer within such time, the offer shall not be deemed to have been accepted.
output: According to Section 508... Rule: An offer cannot be deemed accepted merely because the offeree fails to send a notice of rejection within a stipulated time when the offeree also does not send a notice of acceptance within that time. Application/Conclusion: If the offer said 'silence = acceptance unless you reject within 7 days' but the offeree neither rejects nor sends an acceptance, the offer is not deemed accepted under Section 508(4). Silence alone in that setup does not create acceptance.

instruction: Ram made me a clear offer and I later accepted but sent the acceptance by courier; when exactly was the acceptance effective?
input: Section no 508  part (2) : The act of giving acceptance shall be deemed to be completed, in case of the offerer, if the offerer receives the acceptance forwarded by the offeree to the offerer having indicated his or her acceptance to the offer, and in case of the offeree, if the offerer comes to know that the offeree has accepted the offer.
output: According to Section 508... Rule: Acceptance is completed for the offerer when the offerer receives the forwarded acceptance; for the offeree when the offerer becomes aware of the acceptance. Application/Conclusion: Your acceptance by courier becomes effective with respect to the offerer on the date the offerer actually receives the couriered acceptance. For you, it is effective when the offerer comes to know you have accepted.

instruction: I promised to buy a car and started using it before signing — is that acceptance?
input: Section no 508  part (3) : Even though there is no expression of acceptance to the offer directly, if the offeree abides by any terms mentioned in the offer by way of his or her conduct or accepts the advantage or service mentioned in the offer or indicates acceptance in any other manner, the offeree shall be deemed to have accepted the offer.
output: According to Section 508... Rule: Conduct that abides by the offer's terms or acceptance of the offered advantage/service constitutes acceptance. Application/Conclusion: By using the car and acting in accordance with the offer, you may be deemed to have accepted the offer under Section 508(3), and a contract could be treated as formed even without formal signature.

instruction: Which section in the Act explains 'offer and acceptance deemed to be completed'?
input: Section no 508 . Offer and acceptance deemed to be completed : (1) Once the offeree comes to the knowledge of an offer, the act of making the offer shall be deemed to have been completed.
output: According to Section 508... Rule: Section 508 is the provision that governs when offers and acceptances are deemed completed. Application/Conclusion: For questions about timing of offers and acceptances, refer to Section 508 of the Act (titled 'Offer and acceptance deemed to be completed').

instruction: My uncle is declared incompetent by a court to sell his ancestral jewelry under a guardianship law. Can he still sell it under general contract rules?
input: Section no 506  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), any person who is deemed incompetent to conclude a particular contract under the law shall not be deemed to be a competent to conclude such a contract.
output: According to Section 506... Rule: If a person is deemed incompetent under any law to conclude a particular contract, they are not competent to conclude that contract despite subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: Since your uncle has been legally declared incompetent to sell that jewelry under guardianship law, Section 506(2) prevents him from validly selling it under general contract rules; the declaration of incompetence controls.

instruction: Can I revoke my offer by sending a notice before they accept?
input: . Offer or acceptance may be revoked : (1) The offerer may revoke his or her offer through a notice. Provided that, if the offerer has received from the offeree a notice to the effect that he or she has accepted the offer before receiving a notice of revocation of the offer, such an offer shall not be revoked.
output: According to Section 509(1): Rule: The offerer may revoke his or her offer by sending a notice, but not if the offerer has already received from the offeree a notice of acceptance before receiving the revocation. Application/Conclusion: You can generally revoke by notice — however, if you had already received the offeree's acceptance before your revocation reached them, you cannot revoke and the contract stands.

instruction: I sent acceptance but now want to withdraw it. Can I revoke my acceptance?
input: Section no 509  part (2) : The offeree may revoke his or her acceptance by a notice. Provided that if the offerer has already received the notice of acceptance before receiving the notice of its revocation, such an acceptance shall not be revoked
output: According to Section 509(2): Rule: The offeree may revoke his or her acceptance by sending a notice of revocation, except where the offerer has already received the original notice of acceptance before receiving the revocation. Application/Conclusion: You may withdraw your acceptance by notice unless the offerer already received your acceptance first — if the offerer received your acceptance before the revocation, the acceptance cannot be revoked.

instruction: I told them 'No' then changed my mind and sent an acceptance. Which one counts?
input: Section no 509  part (3) : The person who has sent a notice expressing his or her refusal of the offer may again send a notice expressing his or her acceptance to the offer. Provided that, if the notice of refusal out of the notices of refusal or acceptance reaches first, the contract shall not be deemed to have been concluded, and if the notice of acceptance reaches first, 278 the contract shall be deemed to be concluded.
output: According to Section 509(3): Rule: A person who has sent a refusal may later send acceptance; which notice governs depends on which notice reaches first — if refusal reaches first there is no contract, if acceptance reaches first the contract is concluded. Application/Conclusion: Whether your later acceptance binds depends on timing — if your acceptance reaches the offerer before your refusal does, the contract is formed; if the refusal reaches first, there is no contract.

instruction: What happens if a revocation and an acceptance arrive at the same time?
input: Section no 509  part (4) : If the notice under sub-section (1) has been sent after sending the offer, the notice under sub-section (2) has been sent after sending acceptance or the notice under sub-section (3) has been sent after sending a notice of refusal and the concerned person receives such notices at the same time, the contract shall not be deemed to have been concluded.
output: According to Section 509(4): Rule: If the relevant notices (revocation, revocation of acceptance, or changed acceptance after refusal) are received at the same time by the concerned person, no contract is deemed to have been concluded. Application/Conclusion: If your revocation and the other party's acceptance (or similar paired notices) arrive simultaneously, there is no contract — neither side's notice takes precedence.

instruction: I accepted but added a condition and changed the price. Is that acceptance?
input: Section no 509  part (5) : If the offeree sends an acceptance with condition or with alteration to the offer sent by the offerer, the offeree shall be deemed to after a counter offer.
output: According to Section 509(5): Rule: An acceptance that includes a condition or alteration is treated as a counter-offer. Application/Conclusion: Your conditional acceptance (e.g., changed price) does not amount to an unconditional acceptance of the original offer — it operates as a counter-offer and the original offer is not accepted unless the offerer agrees to your terms.

instruction: If the offer states acceptance must be within a set time but I miss it, is the offer revoked?
input: Section no 510  clause (a) : If the offerer makes an offer with a condition that a notice of acceptance to the offer be given within any certain time, and the offerer does not receive a notice of acceptance by the offeree within that time,
output: According to Section 510(a): Rule: An offer requiring acceptance within a specified time is deemed revoked if the offerer does not receive acceptance within that time. Application/Conclusion: If the offer set a deadline for acceptance and you fail to accept within that period, the offer is treated as revoked and you cannot later accept under that same offer.

instruction: I didn't get a time limit in the offer — how long do I have to accept?
input: Section no 510  clause (b) : If the time for sending a notice of acceptance is not specified pursuant to clause (a) and the offeree does not give a notice of acceptance to the offerer within a reasonable time,
output: According to Section 510(b): Rule: Where no time for acceptance is specified, the offer is deemed revoked if the offeree does not accept within a reasonable time. Application/Conclusion: You must accept within a reasonable time judged by the nature of the offer and circumstances — if you delay beyond what is reasonable, the offer will be treated as revoked.

instruction: What if the person who made the offer dies before I accept?
input: Section no 510  clause (c) : If the offerer, after making the offer, dies or becomes insane before receiving the acceptance,
output: According to Section 510(c): Rule: An offer is deemed revoked if the offerer dies or becomes insane after making the offer but before receiving acceptance. Application/Conclusion: If the offerer dies or becomes legally insane before your acceptance reaches them, the offer is revoked and you cannot form a contract by accepting thereafter.

instruction: I accepted but then the offeree died before I received the acceptance — is there a contract?
input: Section no 510  clause (e) : Even if the acceptance was given by the offeree, the offeree dies or becomes insane before the offerer receives the acceptance, 279
output: According to Section 510(e): Rule: Even if acceptance was given, if the offeree dies or becomes insane before the offerer receives the acceptance, the offer is deemed revoked. Application/Conclusion: If the offeree dies or becomes insane before you receive their acceptance, no contract arises despite their having sent acceptance.

instruction: Does sending a counter-offer cancel the original offer?
input: Section no 510  clause (f) : If the offeree sends a counter offer pursuant to sub section (5) of Section 509,
output: According to Section 510(f): Rule: An offer is deemed revoked if the offeree sends a counter-offer under Section 509(5). Application/Conclusion: By making a counter-offer (i.e., conditional acceptance or altered terms), the original offer is revoked — the original terms are no longer on the table unless the offerer accepts the counter-offer.

instruction: The offer required I perform a task before accepting, but I accepted without doing it. Is my acceptance valid?
input: Section no 510  clause (g) : If the offerer makes an offer on a condition that the offeree has to do any act or fulfill any condition before accepting the offer, and acceptance is made without doing such an act or fulfilling such a condition.
output: According to Section 510(g): Rule: An offer is deemed revoked where acceptance is made without performing a condition or act that the offer required to be done before acceptance. Application/Conclusion: If the offer required you to do something before accepting and you accepted without doing that act or fulfilling the condition, your acceptance does not make a valid contract under that offer.

instruction: Someone put an advertisement offering payment for returning lost goods. I found the goods and returned them — can I claim the payment?
input: Section no 511 . Contract according to offer made before the public : (1) If a person makes an offer publicly by means of an advertisement that he or she will pay certain remuneration to any person for doing any act specified in the advertisement, and if any person does such an act, the advertiser shall pay remuneration specified in the advertisement to such a person.
output: According to Section 511(1): Rule: A public offer by advertisement promising remuneration for a specified act creates an obligation to pay anyone who performs that act. Application/Conclusion: If you performed the specific act described in the advertisement (e.g., returned lost goods), the advertiser must pay the stated remuneration to you.

instruction: I performed the advertised act but I didn't know about the advertisement. Am I entitled to the reward?
input: Provided that if a person does the act specified in the advertisement without knowing such advertisement, such a person shall not be entitled to the remuneration.
output: According to Section 511(1) proviso: Rule: A person who performs the act specified in an advertisement without knowing of the advertisement is not entitled to the promised remuneration. Application/Conclusion: Because you did the act unaware of the advertisement, you cannot claim the reward under that public offer.

instruction: Which section says acceptance with a condition becomes a counter-offer?
input: Section no 509  part (5) : If the offeree sends an acceptance with condition or with alteration to the offer sent by the offerer, the offeree shall be deemed to after a counter offer.
output: According to Section 509(5): Rule: Acceptance that includes a condition or alteration is to be treated as a counter-offer. Application/Conclusion: Section 509(5) is the provision you rely on — your conditional acceptance is legally a counter-offer, not an acceptance of the original terms.

instruction: I sent a refusal, then later sent acceptance; the other party says there was no contract because my refusal reached them first. Is that right?
input: Section no 509  part (3) : The person who has sent a notice expressing his or her refusal of the offer may again send a notice expressing his or her acceptance to the offer. Provided that, if the notice of refusal out of the notices of refusal or acceptance reaches first, the contract shall not be deemed to have been concluded, and if the notice of acceptance reaches first, 278 the contract shall be deemed to be concluded.
output: According to Section 509(3): Rule: Where a refusal and later acceptance are both sent, whichever notice reaches the offerer first determines whether a contract exists — refusal first means no contract, acceptance first means contract. Application/Conclusion: If your refusal reached the offerer before your later acceptance, there is no contract; if your acceptance reached first, a contract was formed.

instruction: Short question: Can an offer be revoked if time runs out?
input: Section no 510  clause (a) : If the offerer makes an offer with a condition that a notice of acceptance to the offer be given within any certain time, and the offerer does not receive a notice of acceptance by the offeree within that time,
output: According to Section 510(a): Rule: Yes — an offer with a specified acceptance time is deemed revoked if acceptance is not received within that time. Application/Conclusion: If the deadline in the offer passes without acceptance being received, the offer is revoked.

instruction: My friend published an ad promising payment to anyone who locates his missing dog. I found the dog but I only learned of the ad later. Can I claim the money?
input: Provided that if a person does the act specified in the advertisement without knowing such advertisement, such a person shall not be entitled to the remuneration.
output: According to Section 511(1) proviso: Rule: A person who performs the advertised act without knowledge of the advertisement is not entitled to the payment. Application/Conclusion: Because you located the dog before knowing about the ad, you are not entitled to the advertised remuneration under Section 511.

instruction: I changed the price in my reply to an offer — did I accept or counter-offer? (Be blunt.)
input: Section no 509  part (5) : If the offeree sends an acceptance with condition or with alteration to the offer sent by the offerer, the offeree shall be deemed to after a counter offer.
output: According to Section 509(5): Rule: Any acceptance with a condition or alteration is treated as a counter-offer. Application/Conclusion: Bluntly — changing the price in your reply is not acceptance; it is a counter-offer.

instruction: My business partner lied and didn't deliver the goods. Can I get compensation?
input: If a person bound to fulfill any obligation does not fulfill it by fraud or does any act knowingly or recklessly, thereby any loss or damage is caused in any manner, such a person shall bear compensation for the loss or damage so caused.
output: According to Section 500(2): Rule: A person who fails to fulfill an obligation by fraud or by knowingly/recklessly acting and thereby causes loss must bear compensation for that loss. Application/Conclusion: If your partner’s non‑performance was due to fraud or knowingly reckless conduct and you can show loss resulted, you are entitled to seek compensation for the loss caused.

instruction: Can I be forced to perform a promise that asks me to do something illegal?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if the fulfillment of any obligation would be contrary to law, public order or public morality, it shall not be required to fulfill such an obligation. 273
output: According to Section 501: Rule: An obligation whose performance would be contrary to law, public order, or public morality is not required to be fulfilled. Application/Conclusion: You cannot be legally compelled to perform a promise that would involve illegal acts or violate public order or morality; such an obligation is not enforceable.

instruction: I promised to sell a painting that didn't exist when we agreed. Do I have to deliver it?
input: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if, at the time of its creation, any obligation of such nature as is impossible for fulfillment has been created, such an obligation shall not be required to be fulfilled.
output: According to Section 502(1): Rule: If an obligation was impossible to fulfill at the time it was created, it is not required to be fulfilled. Application/Conclusion: Because the painting did not exist when you made the promise (making performance impossible at creation), you are not required to fulfill that obligation.

instruction: We had a valid contract, but later a fire made performance impossible. What happens now?
input: If any obligation which was possible for fulfillment at the time of its creation subsequently becomes impossible for fulfillment, the consequence of such obligation shall be determined according to the law.
output: According to Section 502(2): Rule: If an obligation that was originally possible later becomes impossible, the legal consequences are to be determined according to law. Application/Conclusion: Since performance became impossible after formation (e.g., fire), the court will determine the consequences (such as discharge, adjustment, or compensation) under applicable law; you should seek legal advice to apply the law to your facts.

instruction: Half my order was lost in transit; I can deliver part but not the rest. Am I still liable for the undelivered portion?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) or (2), if a portion of any obligation can be fulfilled and the rest portion cannot be fulfilled, the obligation shall be fulfilled to the extent that it can be fulfilled.
output: According to Section 502(3): Rule: If part of an obligation can be fulfilled while another part cannot, the obligation must be performed to the extent it can be. Application/Conclusion: You should perform the portion you can deliver. The undelivered portion is excused by impossibility, but there may be separate consequences (e.g., adjustment or compensation) for the shortfall under the law.

instruction: I found out about the fraud today. How long do I have to go to court?
input: A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years from the date of the accrual of the cause of action. 274 Chapter-2 Provisions Relating to Formation of Contracts
output: According to Section 503: Rule: A person aggrieved under this Chapter must file a lawsuit within two years from the date the cause of action arose. Application/Conclusion: You generally have two years from when the cause of action accrued (for example, discovery of the fraud or when loss occurred) to file suit. Act promptly to preserve your rights.

instruction: When is an agreement considered a contract under the law?
input: If an agreement enforceable by law is concluded between two or more persons to do or abstain from doing any act, a contract shall be deemed to be concluded.
output: According to Section 504(1): Rule: When an agreement enforceable by law is concluded between two or more persons to do or abstain from doing an act, it is deemed a contract. Application/Conclusion: If the parties reached an enforceable agreement (meeting legal requirements), that agreement is a contract and gives rise to contractual rights and obligations.

instruction: Is a contract formed the moment the other party accepts my offer?
input: For the purposes of sub-section (1), a contract shall be deemed to have been concluded once the person to whom an offer has been made by another person communicates his or her acceptance thereto.
output: According to Section 504(2): Rule: A contract is deemed concluded once the offeree communicates acceptance of the offer. Application/Conclusion: Yes — when the person to whom you made the offer communicates acceptance, a contract is formed and both parties are bound.

instruction: If we have a contract, does that create a legal relationship I can enforce?
input: Once a contract is concluded, a binding legal relationship shall be created between the parties to it. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter,
output: According to Section 504(3): Rule: A concluded contract creates a binding legal relationship between the parties. Application/Conclusion: Once you have a valid contract, you can enforce the parties' obligations in law; a breach gives you legal remedies.

instruction: In simple words, what is an 'offer'?
input: “Offer” means an offer made by one person to another person with the intent of obtaining his or her acceptance to do or abstain from doing any act.
output: According to Section 504 Explanation (1): Rule: An 'Offer' is a proposal by one person to another intended to obtain acceptance to do or abstain from doing an act. Application/Conclusion: In everyday terms, an offer is a clear proposal to enter into an agreement, made with the expectation that the other person will accept or reject it.

instruction: What exactly is 'acceptance' of an offer?
input: “Acceptance” means the acceptance given by the person to whom the offer has been made in the same meaning in which the offer is made.
output: According to Section 504 Explanation (2): Rule: 'Acceptance' is the acceptance given by the offeree in the same terms as the offer. Application/Conclusion: Acceptance must match the offer’s terms; if the offeree accepts as offered, a contract is formed.

instruction: What are the basic conditions that make a contract enforceable by law?
input:
(1) A contract concluded in fulfillment of the following conditions shall be deemed to be a contract enforceable by law:

Section no 505 clause (a) : The consent expressed by a person to a contract to bind himself or herself,

Section no 505 clause (b) : Capacity or qualification of a person to a contract to conclude the contract, 275

Section no 505 clause (c) : Certain matter for the creation of an obligation,

Section no 505 clause (d) : Lawful obligation.
output: According to Section 505(1): Rule: A contract is enforceable if it fulfills the listed conditions: (a) genuine consent to be bound, (b) capacity/qualification to contract, (c) a lawful matter giving rise to an obligation, and (d) the obligation is lawful. Application/Conclusion: To have an enforceable contract, ensure the parties consented, had legal capacity, the subject matter creates an obligation, and the obligation is lawful; lacking any of these may make the contract unenforceable.

instruction: Can a promise made verbally be enforced, or does it have to be written?
input: A contract may be made in written or verbal form or even by conduct of the parties to it.
output: According to Section 505(2): Rule: Contracts can be made in written form, verbally, or by the parties' conduct. Application/Conclusion: Verbal agreements can be legally binding; however, certain contracts may require specific formalities (see Section 505(3)), so check whether your particular contract must be in writing.

instruction: Someone told me some contracts must follow special procedures. Is that true?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if there is a requirement that a particular contract be concluded in fulfillment of any particular procedure or formality, such a contract may not be enforceable unless such procedure or formality is completed.
output: According to Section 505(3): Rule: If a particular contract is required by law to follow a specific procedure or formality, it may not be enforceable unless that procedure is completed. Application/Conclusion: Yes — certain contracts must meet prescribed formalities (e.g., registration, written form). If those are not completed, the contract may not be enforceable.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me his land and I accepted, but now he refuses. What are my options?
input: Once a contract is concluded, a binding legal relationship shall be created between the parties to it. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter,
output: According to Section 504(3): Rule: A concluded contract creates a binding legal relationship between the parties. Application/Conclusion: If Ram’s promise and your acceptance together formed a concluded contract, that creates enforceable rights — you can seek remedies for breach (specific performance or damages) depending on the facts. If you suspect fraud, Section 500(2) may also be relevant for compensation.

instruction: Which section sets the time limit to file a lawsuit under this Chapter?
input: A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years from the date of the accrual of the cause of action. 274 Chapter-2 Provisions Relating to Formation of Contracts
output: According to Section 503: Rule: The statute of limitation for actions under this Chapter is two years from accrual of the cause of action. Application/Conclusion: The time limit is set out in Section 503 — you must generally commence legal proceedings within two years of the cause of action arising.

instruction: If only part of my contractual duty is possible to perform after an event, do I still have to do that part?
input: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) or (2), if a portion of any obligation can be fulfilled and the rest portion cannot be fulfilled, the obligation shall be fulfilled to the extent that it can be fulfilled.
output: According to Section 502(3): Rule: When part of an obligation remains possible while other parts are impossible, the possible portion must be performed. Application/Conclusion: You are required to fulfill that portion of the obligation that is still possible; the impossible portion is excused, though further legal consequences for the partial performance may follow.

instruction: If someone tricked me into signing, and I only discovered it later, can I still claim compensation?
input: If a person bound to fulfill any obligation does not fulfill it by fraud or does any act knowingly or recklessly, thereby any loss or damage is caused in any manner, such a person shall bear compensation for the loss or damage so caused.
output: According to Section 500(2): Rule: A person who fails to fulfill an obligation by fraud or acts knowingly/recklessly and causes loss must bear compensation. Application/Conclusion: If you were induced by fraud and suffered loss, you have the right to claim compensation. Note the two‑year limitation under Section 503 to bring a lawsuit from accrual of the cause of action.

instruction: Can my father's heir be forced to pay his debts after he dies?
input:
Section no 495  part (2) : If such a person dies or becomes of unsound
mind prior to the fulfillment of the obligation pursuant to sub-section (1), the
heir succeeding to his or her property or his or her guardian or curator or
the guarantor in the case of a contract relating to guarantee shall fulfill such
obligation. 271
output: According to Section 495: Rule: If a person dies or becomes of unsound mind before fulfilling an obligation, the heir who succeeds to the property (or guardian/curator/guarantor where applicable) shall fulfill that obligation. Application/Conclusion: Your father's heir can be required to fulfill his outstanding debts to the extent they attach to the inherited property; the heir is legally obliged to satisfy those obligations.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me land but backed out. Can I claim compensation for my loss?
input:
Section no 500 . To bear compensation for failure to fulfill obligation
: (1) If a person bound to fulfill any obligation fails to fulfill it or delays its
fulfillment, and thereby a loss or damage is caused to any other person in any
manner, such a person shall bear compensation for the actual loss or damage
so caused.
output: According to Section 500: Rule: A person who fails to fulfill or delays fulfilling an obligation and thereby causes loss or damage must bear compensation for the actual loss or damage caused. Application/Conclusion: You can seek compensation for the actual loss you suffered because Ram failed to complete the sale; the law allows recovery of actual damages caused by his failure or delay.

instruction: What does 'if no period is specified' mean — how long do I have to perform an obligation?
input:
Section no 496  part (3) : If no period, day or time has been specified under
sub section (1) or (2), the period, day or time for fulfilling the obligation shall
be determined having regard to the nature of obligation and the obligation shall
be fulfilled within a reasonable period.
output: According to Section 496: Rule: Where no specific period, day, or time is stipulated, the time for performance is determined by the nature of the obligation and must be within a reasonable period. Application/Conclusion: If your contract doesn't set a deadline, you must perform within a reasonable time judged by the obligation's character (trade custom, urgency, and circumstances); neither party can unreasonably delay.

instruction: My contract says delivery must be on a specific day. Can the buyer accept delivery earlier?
input:
Section no 496  part (2) : If a certain day or time has been specified for
fulfilling any obligation, the concerned person shall fulfill such obligation on that
day or at that time. Provided that if there is a stipulation that the obligation
shall be fulfilled within certain day or time, the obligation may be fulfilled even
prior to such day or time.
output: According to Section 496: Rule: If a specific day or time is fixed, performance must occur on that day/time; however, if the obligation is to be fulfilled within a certain day or time period, it may be fulfilled earlier. Application/Conclusion: If your contract requires delivery 'on' a particular day, performance should be on that day; but if it requires performance 'within' a period, early delivery is allowed. Check the exact wording ('on' vs 'within') to see if earlier delivery is permitted.

instruction: When is an obligation officially treated as 'not fulfilled'?
input:
Section no 496  part (4) : If any obligation is not fulfilled pursuant to subsection
 Section no 496  part (1) : , (2) or (3), the person who is bound to fulfill the
obligation shall be deemed to have not been fulfilled, or to have been unable to fulfill, the obligation.
output: According to Section 496: Rule: If an obligation is not fulfilled in accordance with subsections (1), (2) or (3) (i.e., within a specified period/day/time or within a reasonable period when none is specified), the obligor is deemed to have not fulfilled or to have been unable to fulfill the obligation. Application/Conclusion: If you miss the specified deadline or fail to perform within a reasonable time when no deadline exists, the law treats you as having not fulfilled the obligation — this status can trigger remedies like compensation or other enforcement measures.

instruction: Two friends promised jointly to deliver goods. If one refuses, are both equally liable?
input:
Section no 497 . Each person to fulfill obligation : (1) If more than one
person have undertaken to fulfill an obligation or such an obligation has been
created in relation to them, every person shall, except as otherwise provided for
in the contract, fulfill such an obligation equally.
output: According to Section 497: Rule: Where more than one person has undertaken an obligation, each person shall, unless the contract says otherwise, fulfill the obligation equally. Application/Conclusion: Both friends are equally liable to perform the delivery (or to be responsible for non-performance) unless your agreement specifies different shares; you can demand equal performance or hold both accountable.

instruction: I'm one of two creditors of a debtor. Must the debtor fulfill obligations to us equally?
input:
Section no 497  part (2) : If any person is bound to fulfill any obligation
vis-à-vis more than one person, he or she shall, except as otherwise provided for
in the contract, fulfill the obligation vis-à-vis every person equally. 272
output: According to Section 497: Rule: If a person owes obligations to more than one person, they must, unless the contract provides otherwise, fulfill the obligation to each person equally. Application/Conclusion: The debtor should divide performance equally among the creditors (or otherwise as contract specifies); you and the other creditor are entitled to equal treatment absent a contractual allocation.

instruction: Can an obligation be split among several people, or must it be performed in whole?
input:
Section no 498 . Obligation may be divisible : (1) If any obligation has
to be fulfilled vis-à-vis or by more than one person and the obligation vis-à-vis
or by such persons is capable of being divided or fragmented, having regard to
its nature, such obligation may be divided and shall be fulfilled by or vis-à-vis
every person accordingly.
145
output: According to Section 498: Rule: If an obligation relates to or is to be performed by/for more than one person and by its nature can be divided or fragmented, it may be divided and performed by or for each person accordingly. Application/Conclusion: Where the obligation is naturally divisible (e.g., delivery of multiple units), it can be apportioned among the parties; indivisible obligations (e.g., handing over a single unique item) cannot be split.

instruction: If an obligation is divisible, can any one of the obligated persons be asked to fulfill the whole thing?
input:
Section no 498  part (2) : In the circumstance referred to in sub-section (1),
every person or all persons may demand for the fulfillment of the obligation by
every person or all persons bound to fulfill such obligation.
output: According to Section 498: Rule: When an obligation is divisible as described in subsection (1), every person or all persons have the right to demand fulfillment from every person or all persons bound to fulfill that obligation. Application/Conclusion: You may require performance from any of the obligated parties (or all of them) with respect to their share; co-obligors cannot hide behind divisibility to avoid being called upon to perform their part.

instruction: Does the law require obligations created under Section 494 to be performed honestly?
input:
Section no 499 . Obligation to be fulfilled in good faith : The person
who is bound to fulfill the obligation created pursuant to Section 494 shall fulfill
it in good faith.
output: According to Section 499: Rule: Obligations created under Section 494 must be fulfilled in good faith by the person bound to perform them. Application/Conclusion: If your duty arises under Section 494, you are legally required to perform it honestly and reasonably; failure to act in good faith could affect remedies or lead to liability.

instruction: Who must personally perform an obligation they undertook? Can someone else do it?
input:
Section no 495 .
Obligation to be fulfilled : (1) A person shall himself
or herself fulfill the obligation of any matter which has been so maintained or
created as to be fulfilled by him or her or which he or she has undertaken to
fulfill.
output: According to Section 495: Rule: A person who has undertaken or is required to fulfill an obligation must personally fulfill it when it has been created or maintained to be fulfilled by that person. Application/Conclusion: Generally the obligor must perform personally unless the agreement or law allows delegation; you cannot simply refuse performance and force someone else to step in unless permitted.

instruction: If a contract specifies a period for performance, must it be completed within that period?
input:
Section no 496 . Obligation to be fulfilled within the prescribed time
: (1) If a certain period has been specified for fulfilling any obligation, the
concerned person shall fulfill such an obligation within that period.
output: According to Section 496: Rule: When a specific period is fixed for performance, the person concerned must fulfill the obligation within that period. Application/Conclusion: You must complete performance within the contractual period; missing it would constitute non-fulfillment and may give the other party remedies such as damages.

instruction: What can I claim if the builder delays and I suffer a loss?
input:
Section no 500 . To bear compensation for failure to fulfill obligation
: (1) If a person bound to fulfill any obligation fails to fulfill it or delays its
fulfillment, and thereby a loss or damage is caused to any other person in any
manner, such a person shall bear compensation for the actual loss or damage
so caused.
output: According to Section 500: Rule: A person who fails or delays in performing an obligation and causes loss to another must compensate for the actual loss or damage caused. Application/Conclusion: You can claim compensation from the builder for the actual loss you suffered because of the delay (e.g., extra housing costs, loss of rental income), provided you can prove the loss was caused by the delay.

instruction: I acted as guarantor for a loan. If the borrower becomes of unsound mind, will I be liable?
input:
Section no 495  part (2) : If such a person dies or becomes of unsound
mind prior to the fulfillment of the obligation pursuant to sub-section (1), the
heir succeeding to his or her property or his or her guardian or curator or
the guarantor in the case of a contract relating to guarantee shall fulfill such
obligation. 271
output: According to Section 495: Rule: If the primary obligor dies or becomes of unsound mind before performance, the heir, guardian/curator, or the guarantor (in guarantee contracts) shall fulfill the obligation. Application/Conclusion: As guarantor, you can be required to perform the obligation if the principal debtor becomes of unsound mind; the guarantor's liability is triggered by the principal's inability to fulfill.

instruction: Under which section is 'To bear compensation for failure to fulfill obligation' provided?
input:
Section no 500 . To bear compensation for failure to fulfill obligation
: (1) If a person bound to fulfill any obligation fails to fulfill it or delays its
fulfillment, and thereby a loss or damage is caused to any other person in any
manner, such a person shall bear compensation for the actual loss or damage
so caused.
output: According to Section 500: Rule: Section 500 sets out that a person who fails or delays in fulfilling an obligation and causes loss must bear compensation for the actual loss or damage. Application/Conclusion: The remedy for loss caused by non-performance or delay is found in Section 500 — you should rely on this section when claiming actual damages.

instruction: Can I claim the reward if I completed the act first and someone else did it later?
input: part (2) : If more than one person do the act specified in the offer under sub-section (1), only the person who does the act first shall be entitled to the remuneration. Provided that if two or more persons do the act specified in the offer at the same time, all of such persons shall be entitled to the equal share of the remuneration, and if the remuneration is incapable of being shared, the proceeds of the sale of the remuneration shall be equally divided among them.
output: According to Section 511(2): Rule: If more than one person does the act specified in the offer, only the person who does it first is entitled to the remuneration; if two or more do it at the same time they share equally, and if the remuneration cannot be divided its sale proceeds are equally divided. Application/Conclusion: Since you completed the act before others, you are entitled to the remuneration as the first performer.

instruction: Me and my friend finished the task exactly at the same time. How do we split the reward?
input: part (2) : If more than one person do the act specified in the offer under sub-section (1), only the person who does the act first shall be entitled to the remuneration. Provided that if two or more persons do the act specified in the offer at the same time, all of such persons shall be entitled to the equal share of the remuneration, and if the remuneration is incapable of being shared, the proceeds of the sale of the remuneration shall be equally divided among them.
output: According to Section 511(2): Rule: When two or more persons do the act at the same time they are entitled to equal shares of the remuneration; if the remuneration cannot be physically divided, its sale proceeds must be equally divided. Application/Conclusion: You and your friend should split the reward equally; if the reward cannot be split, sell it and divide the proceeds equally.

instruction: The advertisement gave a deadline. After the deadline, can the advertiser still accept somebody's performance?
input: Section no 511  part (3) : If a specific period is prescribed for doing the act according to the advertisement published pursuant to sub-section Section no 511  part (1) : , the offer made according to the advertisement shall be deemed 280 to have been revoked immediately after the expiry of that period.
output: According to Section 511(3): Rule: If the advertisement prescribes a specific period for doing the act, the offer is deemed revoked immediately after that period expires. Application/Conclusion: Once the deadline in the advertisement has passed, the offer is automatically revoked and the advertiser cannot accept a later performance under that offer.

instruction: How can an offer made by advertisement be revoked?
input: Section no 511  part (4) : An offer made pursuant to sub-section (1) may be revoked through the same medium through which it was published.
output: According to Section 511(4): Rule: An offer made by advertisement may be revoked by using the same medium in which it was published. Application/Conclusion: The advertiser must publish the revocation in the same medium (e.g., the same newspaper or website) to validly revoke the offer.

instruction: I completed the task before the advertiser published a revocation notice. Do I still get the reward?
input: Section no 511  part (5) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (4), if anyone has already done the act specified in the advertisement under subsection (1) before the publication of the notice of revocation of the offer, the remuneration specified in the advertisement shall be provided. Provided that the person who does the act specified in the advertisement shall notify the advertiser of the completion of the act as soon as possible.
output: According to Section 511(5): Rule: Even if the offer is later revoked via the same medium, a person who completed the specified act before publication of the revocation is still entitled to the advertised remuneration, provided they notify the advertiser as soon as possible. Application/Conclusion: Because you completed the act before the revocation was published, you are entitled to the reward; make sure to notify the advertiser promptly about your performance.

instruction: I started the work and told the advertiser I was doing it, then they revoked the offer. Do I get paid for the part I already did?
input: Section no 511  part (6) : If any person begins to do the act specified in the advertisement under sub-section (1) by giving its notice to the advertiser, appropriate remuneration shall be paid to such a person for the act done until the revocation of the advertisement.
output: According to Section 511(6): Rule: If a person begins the act and notifies the advertiser, they are entitled to appropriate remuneration for the work done up to the point the advertisement is revoked. Application/Conclusion: Since you notified the advertiser and began work, you should be paid proportionately for what you completed before the revocation.

instruction: Where is a contract formed when the offerer sends an offer expecting acceptance?
input: Section no 512 . Place of formation of contract : (1) The place where the offerer sends an offer expecting to receive its acceptance shall be deemed to be the place of formation of the contract.
output: According to Section 512(1): Rule: The place where the offeror sends an offer expecting acceptance is deemed the place of formation of the contract. Application/Conclusion: The contract is formed at the location from which the offeror sent the offer expecting acceptance, even if acceptance occurs elsewhere.

instruction: What if the offer's place isn't specified — where is the contract formed?
input: Section no 512  part (2) : If the place is not specified pursuant to sub-section (1), the place where the offerer receives acceptance shall be deemed to be the place of formation of the contract.
output: According to Section 512(2): Rule: If the place cannot be determined under subsection (1), the place where the offeror receives acceptance is the place of contract formation. Application/Conclusion: If you cannot identify the sending place, the contract is formed where the offeror actually receives the acceptance.

instruction: We wrote in the contract that the contract will be formed in Pokhara. Does that control the place of formation?
input: Section no 512  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-sections (1) and (2), if the parties specify the place of its formation in the contract, such a place shall be deemed to be the place of formation of the contract.
output: According to Section 512(3): Rule: If parties explicitly specify the place of formation in their contract, that specified place governs regardless of subsections (1) and (2). Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the contract states Pokhara as the place of formation, Pokhara will be deemed the place of formation.

instruction: In plain words, what is a contingent contract?
input: Section no 513 . Contingent contract : (1) If a contract is concluded to do or not to do any act if some event happens in the future, such a contract shall create no obligation until such an event happens.
output: According to Section 513(1): Rule: A contingent contract depending on a future event creates no obligation until that event occurs. Application/Conclusion: Simply put, if your agreement is conditional on a future event, neither party has to perform until that event actually happens.

instruction: We agreed to pay my cousin if she passes the exam. She made it impossible for herself to take the exam. Is the contract still binding?
input: Section no 513  part (2) : If a contract is so concluded as to be deemed to be concluded if any person does a particular act in the future, such a contract shall create no obligation if such a person does anything by which he or she becomes unable or it becomes impossible for him or her to do such an act.
output: According to Section 513(2): Rule: If a contract is conditional on a particular person doing an act later, and that person does something making it impossible for them to do the act, the contract creates no obligation. Application/Conclusion: Since your cousin made herself unable to take the exam (the condition), the contingent obligation does not arise and the contract is not enforceable.

instruction: We promised to pay if a certain uncertain event does NOT happen. When does payment become due?
input: Section no 513  part (3) : If a contract is concluded to do or not to do any act if any uncertain event does not happen in the future, the obligation under such a contract shall arise only after such an event becomes impossible to happen.
output: According to Section 513(3): Rule: Where performance depends on an uncertain event not happening, the obligation arises only when that event becomes impossible. Application/Conclusion: Payment becomes due only once it is impossible for the uncertain event to occur — not merely when it is unlikely.

instruction: We agreed that I'll get paid if the building is completed within 1 year; the work cannot be finished and the year expired. Is the contract still valid?
input: Section no 513  part (4) : If a contract is concluded to do or not to do any act if any event happens within any fixed time in the future, the contract shall be deemed to be void after such an event becomes impossible to happen within, or after the expiry of, the fixed time.
output: According to Section 513(4): Rule: If performance depends on an event happening within a fixed time, the contract becomes void after the event becomes impossible within that time or after the fixed time expires. Application/Conclusion: Since the event (completion within one year) became impossible or the year expired, the contingent contract is void and no obligation remains.

instruction: The reward is a single painting and two people claim it, what if it can't be split?
input: part (2) : If more than one person do the act specified in the offer under sub-section (1), only the person who does the act first shall be entitled to the remuneration. Provided that if two or more persons do the act specified in the offer at the same time, all of such persons shall be entitled to the equal share of the remuneration, and if the remuneration is incapable of being shared, the proceeds of the sale of the remuneration shall be equally divided among them.
output: According to Section 511(2): Rule: If multiple persons perform at the same time they share equally; if the remuneration cannot be divided, it must be sold and the sale proceeds equally divided. Application/Conclusion: For the single painting, if both performed simultaneously, sell the painting and split the sale proceeds equally between them.

instruction: Can an advertiser revoke a newspaper reward by posting online if they originally used the newspaper?
input: Section no 511  part (4) : An offer made pursuant to sub-section (1) may be revoked through the same medium through which it was published.
output: According to Section 511(4): Rule: Revocation must be made through the same medium used for the original publication. Application/Conclusion: If the original offer appeared in a newspaper, the advertiser should revoke via that same newspaper; revoking online instead would not satisfy this requirement.

instruction: I sent an offer from my home in Lalitpur expecting acceptance. Where was the contract formed when they accepted?
input: Section no 512 . Place of formation of contract : (1) The place where the offerer sends an offer expecting to receive its acceptance shall be deemed to be the place of formation of the contract.
output: According to Section 512(1): Rule: The place where the offeror sends an offer expecting acceptance is deemed the place of formation. Application/Conclusion: Because you sent the offer from Lalitpur expecting acceptance, the contract is formed in Lalitpur.

instruction: Quick: Under which section is 'Contingent contract' defined?
input: Section no 513 . Contingent contract : (1) If a contract is concluded to do or not to do any act if some event happens in the future, such a contract shall create no obligation until such an event happens.
output: According to Section 513: Rule: Section 513 deals with contingent contracts — contracts conditioned on future events which create no obligation until the event occurs. Application/Conclusion: 'Contingent contract' is defined and governed by Section 513.

instruction: Can a contract stop me from running my shop if it's not illegal to do so?
input: Section no 517  part (2) (a) : A contract that restraints anyone from exercising any profession, trade or business which is not prohibited by law, Provided that a contract shall not be deemed to be made in restraint of any profession, trade or business in any of the following circumstances:
output:
According to Section 517(2)(a)...
Rule: A contract that restrains anyone from exercising any profession, trade or business that is not prohibited by law is a void contract (i.e., it is not valid).
Application/Conclusion: If your shop is a lawful business, a contractual clause that simply bars you from running it would be void and unenforceable. You should therefore not be legally prevented from operating your shop on the basis of such a restraint clause.

instruction: I promised to pay someone only if their license is not issued by a specified date. When does my obligation kick in?
input:
part (5) : If a contract is concluded to do or not to do any act
if any event does not happen within any fixed time in the future, the obligation
under such a contract shall arise if such an event does not happen or it becomes
certain that such an event will not happen within the fixed time.
output:
According to Section (part 5)...
Rule: Where a contract conditions performance on an event not happening within a fixed future time, the contractual obligation arises when the event does not occur or it becomes certain the event will not occur within that fixed time.
Application/Conclusion: In your case, your obligation to pay arises once the license is not issued by the specified date, or it becomes clear it will not be issued by that date. Until then, the obligation has not yet arisen.

instruction: How should a contract be interpreted if both parties intended the same thing?
input: Section no 515 .Interpretation of contract : (1) A contract shall be interpreted according to the common intention of its parties.
output:
According to Section 515(1)...
Rule: A contract must be interpreted according to the common intention of its parties.
Application/Conclusion: If both parties share a clear common intention about the meaning of the contract terms, that shared intention governs how the contract is interpreted and will be given effect.

instruction: If the parties' real intention can't be proved, what standard is used to interpret a contract?
input: Section no 515  part (2) : If the intention cannot be established pursuant to sub section (1), a contract shall be interpreted according to the meaning of general understanding that a reasonable person of the same prudence as a party to the contract would give to it in normal circumstances.
output:
According to Section 515(2)...
Rule: When the parties' common intention cannot be established, the contract is interpreted by the meaning a reasonable person of the same prudence as a party would give to it in normal circumstances.
Application/Conclusion: If you and the other party cannot show a shared subjective intention, the objective reasonable-person standard applies. A court or tribunal will interpret ambiguous terms as a prudent, reasonable person in the parties' position would.

instruction: I relied on the other party's words and conduct. If there's ambiguity, whose intention matters?
input: Section no 515  part (3) : If one party to a contract knows or is deemed to know a statement and conduct of the other party, the contract shall be interpreted according to the intention of such a party.
output:
According to Section 515(3)...
Rule: If one party knows (or is deemed to know) the statement and conduct of the other party, the contract is interpreted according to the intention of the party whose statement/conduct was known.
Application/Conclusion: If you reasonably relied on the other party's words or conduct and they knew you understood them a certain way, interpretation will favor your understanding. The contract will be read according to your intention in that situation.

instruction: Can I interpret a clause in isolation, or must I look at the whole contract?
input: Section no 515  part (4) : The terms and expressions used in a contract shall be interpreted in the light of the entire contract or the context in which such terms and expressions are used.
output:
According to Section 515(4)...
Rule: Terms and expressions in a contract must be interpreted in light of the entire contract and the context in which they are used.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot fairly interpret a clause in isolation. The meaning must be derived from the whole contract and its context, so surrounding clauses and the contract's purpose should guide interpretation.

instruction: One clause seems to cancel another. How should a judge deal with conflicting terms?
input: Section no 515  part (5) : A contract shall be interpreted in a manner so that all the terms used in the contract are given effect without separating some terms from others.
output:
According to Section 515(5)...
Rule: A contract must be interpreted so that all terms are given effect, avoiding separation or nullifying some terms against others.
Application/Conclusion: A court will try to harmonize conflicting clauses so each has effect. If possible, your contract should be read to give meaning to both clauses rather than striking one down, unless reconciliation is impossible.

instruction: I discovered fraud today. How long do I have to file a lawsuit under this Chapter?
input:
Section no 516 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from
any act done or action taken under this Chapter may file a lawsuit within two
151
years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action. 283 Chapter-3 Validity
of Contracts
output:
According to Section 516...
Rule: An aggrieved person may file a lawsuit within two years after the date the cause of action accrues.
Application/Conclusion: Since you discovered the fraud today, you generally have two years from the date your cause of action arose (or from discovery if that is when accrual occurred under the facts) to file suit. Act promptly to preserve your rights.

instruction: Which section says general contract provisions apply to other contracts under this Act?
input:
Section no 514 . Application of general provisions of contract : The
provisions contained in this Chapter and Chapters 3, 4 and 5 of this Part shall,
generally, be applicable, to the other contracts to be concluded according to this
Act or law. 282
output:
According to Section 514...
Rule: The general provisions contained in this Chapter and Chapters 3, 4 and 5 generally apply to other contracts concluded under this Act or law.
Application/Conclusion: If you are dealing with a contract governed by this Act or related law, the general contract rules in the cited chapters will normally apply to your contract as well.

instruction: Are non-compete clauses always unenforceable? What about when goodwill is sold?
input:
Section no 517  part (2) (a) : A contract that restraints anyone from exercising any profession, trade or business which is not prohibited by law, Provided
that a contract shall not be deemed to be made in restraint of any profession,
trade or business in any of the following circumstances:
 Section no 517  part (1) : Where a contract is concluded between a buyer and
a seller on the sale and purchase of the goodwill of any trade or business, the
contract restraining the seller from carrying on similar trade or business under
such goodwill for the time and at the place specified in such contract,
output:
According to Section 517(2)(a) and its first proviso...
Rule: Generally, contracts restraining lawful professions, trades, or businesses are void. However, an exception exists where such a restraint is part of the sale of goodwill: a seller may be restrained from carrying on a similar trade under that goodwill for the time and place specified.
Application/Conclusion: Non-compete clauses are not universally enforceable, but a limited restraint tied to the sale of goodwill (with specified duration and place) is permitted. If your restraint is part of a goodwill sale and is reasonable in time/place as agreed in the contract, it may be valid.

instruction: I left my partnership. Can my old partners stop me from doing the same trade after separation?
output:
According to Section 517(3)...
Rule: A contract between partners that restrains them from engaging in the partnership's trade for a certain reasonable period or within a certain place after separation is recognized (i.e., not treated as an unlawful restraint generally).
Application/Conclusion: After you leave the partnership, a properly limited post-separation restraint (reasonable duration and geographic scope) agreed among partners can be enforceable. Whether a specific restraint is reasonable will depend on its time and place limits.

instruction: My partner agreement bars partners from competing while the partnership exists. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 517  part (2) : A contract concluded between the partners to
restrain them from doing the same profession, trade or business as that of the
partnership firm or any other profession, trade or business together with other
persons who are competitors of the 284 profession, trade or business of the same
nature other than the profession, trade or business of the partnership firm until
the partnership exists,
output:
According to Section 517(2) (partner-related provision)...
Rule: A contract among partners restraining them from doing the same profession/trade/business as that of the partnership (or from joining competitors) is permitted for the duration of the partnership.
Application/Conclusion: A clause preventing partners from competing while the partnership exists is valid under this provision. Such restraints are acceptable so long as they relate to protecting the partnership during its existence.

instruction: What does it mean when a contract is 'void' according to the law?
input:
Section no 517 . Void contracts : (1) A contract which is not valid according
to law shall be deemed to be a void contract.
output:
According to Section 517(1)...
Rule: Any contract that is not valid according to law is deemed a void contract.
Application/Conclusion: If a contract violates legal requirements or is otherwise invalid under the law, it has no legal effect (is void). You cannot enforce a void contract and remedies based on it will be limited or unavailable.

instruction: If someone knew how I understood a promise, will a court favor my interpretation?
input:
Section no 515  part (3) : If one party to a contract knows or is deemed
to know a statement and conduct of the other party, the contract shall be
interpreted according to the intention of such a party.
output:
According to Section 515(3)...
Rule: Where one party knows (or is deemed to know) the other party's statements and conduct, contractual interpretation is governed by the known party's intention.
Application/Conclusion: If the other party was aware of or should have been aware of your understanding, the court will interpret the contract according to your intention. This benefits the party whose communicated intention was known to the other.

instruction: Short: Where do the general interpretation rules appear?
input:
Section no 515 .Interpretation of contract : (1) A contract shall be
interpreted according to the common intention of its parties.
output:
According to Section 515(1)...
Rule: General interpretation rules are stated in Section 515: contracts are to be interpreted according to the parties' common intention.
Application/Conclusion: For questions about interpreting contracts, start with Section 515 which sets out the primary rule (common intention) and related interpretive principles.

instruction: I'm reading a contract and some expressions are unclear. Are they judged by context?
input:
Section no 515  part (4) : The terms and expressions used in a contract shall
be interpreted in the light of the entire contract or the context in which such
terms and expressions are used.
output:
According to Section 515(4)...
Rule: Ambiguous terms and expressions must be interpreted by reference to the whole contract and the relevant context.
Application/Conclusion: You should read unclear expressions in context—consider surrounding clauses, purpose, and the contract as a whole—to determine their meaning rather than isolating single words or phrases.

instruction: I want to know: which provision says all contract terms must be given effect?
input:
Section no 515  part (5) : A contract shall be interpreted in a manner so
that all the terms used in the contract are given effect without separating some
terms from others.
output:
According to Section 515(5)...
Rule: Contracts must be interpreted so that all terms are given effect and no term is arbitrarily separated or ignored.
Application/Conclusion: When construing your contract, aim to reconcile clauses and give meaning to each provision if possible. Courts will prefer an interpretation that preserves the effect of all terms.

instruction: Real-world: Ram promised to sell me his business if he didn't get a permit by June. He now says he won't sell. Do I have any claim?

if any event does not happen within any fixed time in the future, the obligation
under such a contract shall arise if such an event does not happen or it becomes
certain that such an event will not happen within the fixed time.
output:
According to Section (part 5)...
Rule: When a contract conditions performance on an event not happening within a fixed future time, the obligation arises if the event indeed does not happen or it becomes certain it will not happen within that time.
Application/Conclusion: If Ram's obligation to sell was conditioned on the permit not being issued by June, his obligation to sell arose when the permit was not issued by that date (or it became certain it would not be issued). You can therefore insist on his contractual obligation or pursue remedies for breach.

instruction: Are the general chapters' rules automatically applied to other contracts under this Act?
input:

provisions contained in this Chapter and Chapters 3, 4 and 5 of this Part shall,
generally, be applicable, to the other contracts to be concluded according to this
