According to Section 514...
Rule: The general provisions in this Chapter and Chapters 3–5 generally apply to other contracts concluded under this Act or law.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — unless a specific provision says otherwise, the general contract rules in the cited chapters will typically govern other contracts formed under the Act or related laws. Apply those general principles when interpreting or enforcing such contracts.

instruction: Can I sue if someone misappropriated property of a person who is mentally incompetent? I only found out now — is there a time limit?
input: Section no 492 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation for making a lawsuit in the matter of transaction carried on with intent to take rights to, misappropriate, cause loss to, or disorder, the property of an incompetent and quasi-competent person or in the matter of collection of compound interest or collection of interest in excess of ten percent.
output:
According to Section 492(1):
Rule: There is no statute of limitation for lawsuits about transactions intended to misappropriate or cause loss to the property of an incompetent or quasi-competent person (and for collection of compound interest or interest in excess of ten percent).
Application/Conclusion: Because the alleged misappropriation concerns an incompetent or quasi-competent person's property, you are not time-barred — you may bring a lawsuit at any time.

instruction: A lender charged me 12% interest and compound interest. Can I file suit now or am I out of time?
input: Section no 492 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation for making a lawsuit in the matter of transaction carried on with intent to take rights to, misappropriate, cause loss to, or disorder, the property of an incompetent and quasi-competent person or in the matter of collection of compound interest or collection of interest in excess of ten percent.
output:
According to Section 492(1):
Rule: There is no statute of limitation for actions concerning collection of compound interest or collection of interest in excess of ten percent.
Application/Conclusion: Because your claim involves compound interest or interest over 10%, you may bring a suit at any time — there is no time limit under this provision.

instruction: I discovered a fraud today that doesn't involve an incompetent person or excessive interest. How long do I have to file a case?
input: Section no 492  part (2) (b) : Within a period of one year from the date of expiration of the period, if any, specified in any deed, and failing such a deed, 143 or in the other cases, from the date of accrual of the cause of action. 269
output:
According to Section 492(2)(b):
Rule: Except where subsection (1) applies, a person must sue within one year from the date of expiration of any period specified in a deed, or if there is no deed, within one year from the date the cause of action accrues.
Application/Conclusion: Since your situation does not fall under subsection (1), you generally have one year from the date your cause of action arose (or from the deed's expiry if a deed applies) to file suit.

instruction: If this Chapter gives its own specific time limit for a claim, which deadline should I follow?
input: Section no 492  part (2) (a) : Where this Chapter provides for a separate statute of limitation for making a lawsuit, within such limitation,
output:
According to Section 492(2)(a):
Rule: Where this Chapter provides a separate statute of limitation for a specific matter, the lawsuit must be made within that separate limitation.
Application/Conclusion: If the Chapter includes a special limitation for your type of claim, you must follow that specific deadline rather than the general one-year rule.

instruction: Under which section does the law say 'unjust enrichment' gives rise to obligations?
input: Section no 494  clause (d) : By an unjust enrichment,
output:
According to Section 494(d):
Rule: One of the listed circumstances that creates an obligation is 'by an unjust enrichment.'
Application/Conclusion: Obligations can arise when someone is unjustly enriched; see this provision as the basis for such claims and consult Chapter-16 (per related parts) for the detailed definition and rules.

instruction: What actually creates an obligation under the statute? Tell me simply.
input:
Section no 493 . Obligation to be created : (1) If there is a legal compulsion for one to do or to abstain from doing any act, an obligation is created if one omits to do or does such an act.

Section no 493  part (2) : The obligation to be created pursuant to sub-section (1) shall be maintained and determined pursuant to this Chapter.
output:
According to Section 493:
Rule: An obligation is created when there is a legal compulsion to act or refrain, and a person either omits or performs the act; such obligations are maintained and determined under this Chapter.
Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if the law requires or forbids an action and someone fails to follow that requirement (by doing or not doing the act), an obligation arises and is resolved under the rules of this Chapter.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me his land but later backed out. Can I enforce that promise?
input:
Section no 494  clause (b) : By a contract,

Section no 494  part (2) (b) : The obligation referred to in clause (b) shall be created under a contact entered into between the parties. 270
output:
According to Section 494(b) and 494(2)(b):
Rule: Obligations are created by contract; such obligations arise from a contract entered into between the parties.
Application/Conclusion: Ram's promise, if it constitutes a valid contract between you and him, gives rise to enforceable obligations. You may seek enforcement or remedies under the contract, subject to proving the contract's existence and terms.

instruction: Someone gained money at my expense without justification. Which provision points me to the rules I should use?
input:
Section no 494  clause (d) : By an unjust enrichment,

Section no 494  part (2) (d) : The obligation referred to in clause (d) shall be created under an unjust enrichment as defined in Chapter-16 of this Part.
output:
According to Section 494(d) and 494(2)(d):
Rule: Obligations arising from unjust enrichment are recognized, and such unjust enrichment is defined and governed by Chapter-16 of this Part.
Application/Conclusion: If someone was unjustly enriched at your expense, you have an obligation-based remedy; you should refer to Chapter-16 for the detailed definition and applicable rules to pursue recovery.

instruction: If a person unilaterally promises to assume a debt, does the law treat that as creating an obligation?
input:
Section no 494  clause (e) : By an unilateral commitment of any person to assume obligation,

Section no 494  part (2) (e) : The obligation referred to in clause (e) shall be determined under provision for creating obligation under law through an unilateral commitment.
output:
According to Section 494(e) and 494(2)(e):
Rule: A unilateral commitment by a person to assume an obligation can create an obligation, and such obligations are determined under the provisions for creating obligations through unilateral commitments.
Application/Conclusion: A unilateral promise may be binding if it meets the legal requirements for creating obligations by unilateral commitment; examine the relevant provisions to see if the promise you have satisfies those requirements and can be enforced.

instruction: Can damage caused by someone's wrongful act create an obligation to compensate?
input:
Section no 494  clause (f) : By an act to be treated as tort under law,

Section no 494  part (2) (f) : The obligation referred to in clause (f) shall be created under torts as defined in Chapter-17 of this Part.
output:
According to Section 494(f) and 494(2)(f):
Rule: Obligations arise from acts treated as torts under law; those obligations are created under the tort rules defined in Chapter-17.
Application/Conclusion: If you suffered loss from another's tortious act, that act can create an obligation to compensate you under the tort provisions set out in Chapter-17 — you should look to those rules to pursue a claim.

instruction: How about quasi-torts — do they create obligations too?
input:
Section no 494  clause (g) : By an act to be treated as a quasi-tort under law.

Section no 494  part (2) (g) : The obligation referred to in clause (g) shall be created under an quasi-tort as defined in Chapter-18 of this Part.
output:
According to Section 494(g) and 494(2)(g):
Rule: Acts treated as quasi-torts create obligations; such obligations are governed by the definition and rules for quasi-torts in Chapter-18.
Application/Conclusion: If the conduct falls within the category of quasi-tort, an obligation to remedy the harm can arise and you should consult Chapter-18 for the precise standards and remedies.

instruction: Does the law say obligations created by statute are governed here?
input:
Section no 494  clause (a) : By a law,

Section no 494  part (2) (a) : The obligation referred to in clause (a) shall be created under this Act or other law.
output:
According to Section 494(a) and 494(2)(a):
Rule: Obligations created by law arise under this Act or other laws.
Application/Conclusion: If a statute imposes a duty, that duty is an obligation under this framework and will be governed by this Act or the other relevant law specified.

instruction: Where are obligations from indirect or quasi-contracts explained?
input:
Section no 494  clause (c) : By an indirect or quasi-contract,

Section no 494  part (2) (c) : The obligation referred to in clause (c) shall be created under an indirect or quasi-contact as defined in Chapter 15: of this Part.
output:
According to Section 494(c) and 494(2)(c):
Rule: Obligations arising from indirect or quasi-contracts are recognized and are created under the definitions and rules set out in Chapter-15 of this Part.
Application/Conclusion: If your situation involves an indirect or quasi-contract, consult Chapter-15 for the specific conditions and remedies that will establish and enforce the obligation.

instruction: I have a deed with an expiry date. When does the one-year limitation in the Chapter start running?
input: Section no 492  part (2) (b) : Within a period of one year from the date of expiration of the period, if any, specified in any deed, and failing such a deed, 143 or in the other cases, from the date of accrual of the cause of action. 269
output:
According to Section 492(2)(b):
Rule: The one-year limitation runs from the date of expiration of any period specified in a deed; if there is no deed, it runs from the date the cause of action accrues.
Application/Conclusion: For a claim tied to a deed, your one-year filing period begins on the deed's specified expiry date. If no deed governs the period, it begins when your cause of action accrued.

instruction: Short and blunt: where does the statute say special chapter limits override the general rule?
input: Section no 492  part (2) (a) : Where this Chapter provides for a separate statute of limitation for making a lawsuit, within such limitation,
output:
According to Section 492(2)(a):
Rule: If the Chapter provides a separate statute of limitation for a matter, that separate limitation must be followed.
Application/Conclusion: In short, follow the specific limitation in the Chapter for that matter — it overrides the general rule.

instruction: The bank charged me compound interest unfairly. Which provision allows me to sue even after many years?
input: Section no 492 . Statute of limitation : (1) There shall be no statute of limitation for making a lawsuit in the matter of transaction carried on with intent to take rights to, misappropriate, cause loss to, or disorder, the property of an incompetent and quasi-competent person or in the matter of collection of compound interest or collection of interest in excess of ten percent.
output:
According to Section 492(1):
Rule: There is no statute of limitation for actions concerning collection of compound interest (and interest over ten percent) or for misappropriation affecting incompetent persons.
Application/Conclusion: Because your claim involves compound interest, you are not barred by time and may bring a lawsuit regardless of how many years have passed.

instruction: Can my employer stop me from joining a competitor after I leave?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (a) : A contract so concluded between a person and any person, firm, company or body that the person is restrained from accepting the service of another person, firm, company or body who is the competitor of such other person, firm, company or body until the person is in the service of, or for a specified period after retirement from the service of, such other person, firm, company or body.
output: According to Section 517(4)(a): Rule: Contracts that expressly restrain a person from accepting service with a competitor — either while in service or for a specified period after retirement — are identified in the statute as contracts of that type. Application/Conclusion: If your employment contract contains such a restraint, the rule in Section 517(4)(a) applies to that clause. Whether the clause is void or enforceable depends on the legal classification in the Act (Section 517 lists such restraints among types of contracts described there). Practically, you should check whether the restraint fits this description and seek court guidance on enforceability, because the statute singles out this precise form of contractual restraint.

instruction: I entered into an agreement that forbids me from marrying anyone for life. Is that agreement valid?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (b) : A contract in restraint of a marriage other than one prohibited by the law,
output: According to Section 517(4)(b): Rule: A contract in restraint of a marriage (except where the marriage itself is prohibited by law) is identified in the statute as that type of contractual restraint. Application/Conclusion: If your agreement stops you from marrying someone and that marriage is not one already prohibited by law, the clause is of the kind described in Section 517(4)(b). Under the statute, such restraints are treated as the specified category and cannot be relied upon — you would not be legally bound by a contractual restriction preventing you from marrying in those circumstances.

instruction: Someone put a clause saying I can't use the public park anymore if I criticize their business. What does law say about stopping people from using public facilities?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (c) : A contract restraining any one from enjoying the facilities being enjoyed by the public, 285
output: According to Section 517(4)(c): Rule: A contract that restrains a person from enjoying facilities enjoyed by the public is identified in the statute as that kind of contract. Application/Conclusion: A clause that seeks to bar you from using a public facility (like a park) falls squarely under Section 517(4)(c). Such a contractual restraint is of the type the law calls out; therefore it cannot lawfully prevent a person from enjoying public facilities and would not be enforceable against you.

instruction: Can someone contract to stop me from going to court to enforce my rights?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (d) : A contract restraining legal right of any person from being enforced by a court,
output: According to Section 517(4)(d): Rule: A contract that restrains a person from enforcing their legal rights in court is identified in the statute as that type of restraint. Application/Conclusion: If a contract attempts to prevent you from suing or otherwise enforcing your legal rights before a court, it falls under Section 517(4)(d). Such a contractual term is the kind the statute addresses and cannot be used to bar you from seeking judicial enforcement of your rights.

instruction: I signed a deal that seems illegal — it asks me to do something the law forbids. Is that contract okay?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (e) : A contract concluded contrary to law or on a matter prohibited by the law in force,
output: According to Section 517(4)(e): Rule: A contract made contrary to law or on a matter prohibited by the law in force is identified in the statute as that kind of contract. Application/Conclusion: A contract that requires you to perform something illegal or deals with a subject matter forbidden by law is of the type mentioned in Section 517(4)(e). Such a contract is not valid — you cannot be bound to perform obligations that are contrary to law.

instruction: Someone made me promise to do something immoral and against public interest — is that enforceable?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (f) : A contract made for an immoral purpose or against public order or public interest,
output: According to Section 517(4)(f): Rule: Contracts made for an immoral purpose or against public order or public interest are identified in the statute as that category. Application/Conclusion: If your agreement’s object is immoral or contrary to public order/public interest, it falls under Section 517(4)(f) and cannot be enforced. You would not be legally required to perform obligations arising from such an immoral or contrary-to-public-order contract.

instruction: We made an agreement but both of us were unclear about what exactly we were contracting for. Can that be enforced?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (g) : A contract which cannot be performed because the parties thereto do not exactly ascertain or know about the matter in relation to which it has been concluded,
output: According to Section 517(4)(g): Rule: A contract that cannot be performed because the parties did not exactly ascertain or know the subject matter at the time of conclusion is identified in the statute as that type. Application/Conclusion: If neither party knew or had clearly ascertained the matter forming the contract’s basis, Section 517(4)(g) applies and the contract is of a kind that the law treats as incapable of performance. Such an agreement would not be enforceable in its present uncertain form.

instruction: I signed a contract that was impossible to carry out from day one. What does the law say?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (h) : A contract the performance of which is impossible at the time of its conclusion or a fictitious contract,
output: According to Section 517(4)(h): Rule: Contracts whose performance is impossible at the time of conclusion, or which are fictitious, are identified in the statute as that type. Application/Conclusion: If the agreement you signed could not possibly be performed when you entered into it (or is fictitious), it falls under Section 517(4)(h) and is not a valid enforceable contract.

instruction: I think the contract I signed is too vague to mean anything. Does that matter?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (i) : A contract which is vague because of its subject matter being incapable of giving a reasonable meaning,
output: According to Section 517(4)(i): Rule: A contract is of the described type if it is vague because its subject matter is incapable of giving reasonable meaning. Application/Conclusion: If the subject matter of your contract is so unclear that it cannot reasonably be given meaning, Section 517(4)(i) applies and the contract (or that vague part) will not be enforceable as written.

instruction: My cousin signed a contract but he’s a minor. Can that agreement be enforced against him?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (j) : A contract concluded by a person not competent to make contract,
output: According to Section 517(4)(j): Rule: A contract concluded by a person not competent to make a contract is identified in the statute as that kind of contract. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin lacked legal competence to contract (for example being a minor or otherwise not competent), the agreement falls under Section 517(4)(j) and would not be validly concluded against him.

instruction: I was told to sign a contract to commit an illegal act. Is that binding?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (k) : A contract with an illegal purpose,
output: According to Section 517(4)(k): Rule: Contracts that have an illegal purpose are identified in the statute as that type. Application/Conclusion: A contract whose purpose is illegal is covered by Section 517(4)(k). Such a contract is not enforceable and you are not legally bound to fulfill obligations that have an illegal purpose.

instruction: We both agreed on something but later found out we were mistaken about the essential fact. Is the contract void?
input: Section no 517  part (4) (l) : A contract concluded by mistake of both parties as to the essential fact of the contract at the time of its conclusion. 286
output: According to Section 517(4)(l): Rule: A contract concluded by mistake of both parties as to an essential fact at the time of its conclusion is identified in the statute as that type. Application/Conclusion: If both parties were mistaken about an essential fact when the contract was made, Section 517(4)(l) applies and the contract is of the kind the law treats as affected by that mutual mistake — meaning it would not stand as a valid enforceable contract in its mistaken form.

instruction: If a contract is void, do I have any rights or obligations under it?
input: Section no 517  part (3) : A void contract is invalid ab initio and it shall create neither any legal consequence nor any right and obligation of its parties.
output: According to Section 517(3): Rule: A void contract is invalid from the beginning (ab initio) and creates neither legal consequences nor rights or obligations for the parties. Application/Conclusion: If your agreement is legally void under the statute, it never produced enforceable rights or duties between the parties. You would not have obligations arising solely from a contract that the law classifies as void.

instruction: Part of our contract is illegal, but the rest seems fine. Can the rest be enforced?
input: Section no 517  part (4) : Even if any part of a contract becomes void, its remaining parts shall be enforceable according to law.
output: According to Section 517(4): Rule: If any part of a contract becomes void, the remaining parts of that contract shall be enforceable according to law. Application/Conclusion: Where one clause of your agreement is void (for example because illegal) but other clauses are separable and lawful, Section 517(4) allows the enforceable parts to survive. You can seek enforcement of the remaining lawful portions rather than losing the whole contract, subject to judicial determination of severability.

instruction: Can I ask a court to cancel a contract I entered into because I want to get out of it?
input: Section no 518 . Voidable contracts : (1) A contract which, at the initiation of its party, may be declared void by the court shall be deemed to be a voidable contract.
output: According to Section 518(1): Rule: A contract that may, at the initiative of one party, be declared void by a court is defined as a voidable contract. Application/Conclusion: If your contract falls into circumstances that render it voidable (for example coercion or undue influence listed elsewhere in Section 518), you may apply to the court to have it declared void at your initiative. The statute recognises this remedy, though specific grounds must exist for voidability.

instruction: Someone forced me to sign a contract by threatening to destroy my property — is that coercion?
input: Section no 518  part (2) (a) : A contract concluded by coercion, Explanation: If a person detains or threatens to detain any property of another person or threatens to put that other person’s body, life or prestige in peril or commits or threatens to commit any other act forbidden by law, with the intention of causing that other person to enter into a contract against his or her will, the person is said to commit coercion.
output: According to Section 518(2)(a): Rule: A contract concluded by coercion is voidable; coercion includes detaining or threatening to detain another’s property, threatening bodily harm, life, or reputation, or committing/threatening any other unlawful act to force someone into a contract. Application/Conclusion: Because you were threatened with destruction of your property to force you to sign, that conduct fits the statutory definition of coercion. You are an aggrieved party under Section 518 and can ask a court to void the contract on the ground of coercion.

instruction: What does 'undue influence' actually mean? I'm dealing with a relative who pressured me into signing.
input: Section no 518  part (1) : Undue influence means an influence exercised by a person over another person who is under his or her influence or who may be employed according to his or her will with the intention of 287 taking any unfair advantage for his or her interest or concern.
output: According to Section 518(1): Rule: Undue influence is an influence by a person over another who is under that influence or may be employed according to their will, used with the intention of taking unfair advantage for the influencer's interest. Application/Conclusion: If your relative used their dominant position or control over you to pressure you into signing so they could gain unfairly, that meets the statutory description of undue influence. You may seek to have the contract voided on that ground under Section 518.

instruction: My guardian made me sign a contract. Am I considered under influence automatically?
input: Section no 518  part (2) (a) : A person who is under his or her guardianship, curatorship or custody,
output: According to Section 518(2)(a): Rule: The statute deems certain persons to be under influence, including a person who is under guardianship, curatorship or custody. Application/Conclusion: Because you signed a contract while under the guardianship or custody of another, the law treats you as being in a position of influence. That makes it possible to challenge the contract for undue influence and ask the court to void it if the guardian took unfair advantage.

instruction: Can I sell my elderly mother's house even though my brother says she's too old to understand and disagrees?
input: Section no 518  part (2) (b) : A person who is incapable of representing his or her interest for the time being or forever by reason of age, illness or physical or mental distress,
output: According to Section 518(2)(b). Rule: A person who is incapable of representing his or her interest because of age, illness or physical or mental distress is recognized as lacking capacity. Application/Conclusion: If your mother truly cannot represent her own interests due to age or illness, transactions affecting her property may be vulnerable; you should verify her capacity (medical evidence) and consider court guidance or a guardian appointment before proceeding to avoid the contract being set aside.

instruction: My uncle pressured my cousin into signing a sale. He had financial leverage over her. Is that a problem?
input: Section no 518  part (2) (c) : A person who may be subjected to financial or positional influence of that other person.
output: According to Section 518(2)(c). Rule: A person who may be subjected to financial or positional influence of another is identified as being under possible undue influence. Application/Conclusion: If your cousin signed while subject to another's financial or positional influence, the contract may be voidable for undue influence; she can challenge it in court and may obtain rescission if undue influence is proved.

instruction: Someone lied to me about the land quality to get me to buy it. What does the law call that?
input: Section no 518  part (2) (c) : A contract concluded by fraud, Explanation: A party to a contract or his or her agent is said to commit fraud when he or she, with intent to deceive another party thereto or his or her agent, makes the suggestion, as to a fact, of that which is not true which he or she does not believe it to be true or does any act that is likely to make the other party or his or her agent believe it, or knowingly conceals a fact which is in his or her knowledge or does any such act as the law declares to be fraudulent. 288
output: According to Section 518(2)(c). Rule: A contract concluded by fraud involves intentional deception—making false suggestions, acts likely to induce belief, or knowingly concealing facts. Application/Conclusion: Your situation fits fraud if the seller knowingly misrepresented the land quality to induce your purchase; you can seek to void the contract and possibly claim remedies if you prove the seller's intent to deceive.

instruction: They described the house with false details and I relied on that. Is that misrepresentation?
input: Section no 518  part (2) : Misleading any party to his or her detriment,
output: According to Section 518(2)(d) (as explained). Rule: Misrepresentation includes acts that mislead any party to their detriment. Application/Conclusion: If the description misled you and caused detriment, it qualifies as misrepresentation; you may ask the court to void the contract or seek restoration under the remedies the law provides.

instruction: What exactly counts as presenting a false description in a contract?
input: Section no 518  part (1) : Presenting a false description of any matter or fact on without reasonable basis,
output: According to Section 518(2)(d) part (1). Rule: Presenting a false description without a reasonable basis is a form of misrepresentation. Application/Conclusion: If a party gives a factual description that is false and lacks reasonable basis, that act is misrepresentation and can be grounds to void the contract or seek restoration.

instruction: They promised the sale was for a car but actually made me sign for a motorbike. Can I challenge it?
input: Section no 518  part (4) : Making assurance to have concluded a contract in one subject and but causing to enter into it in another subject.
output: According to Section 518(2)(d) part (4). Rule: Assuring a party they concluded a contract in one subject while actually causing them to enter into another is misrepresentation. Application/Conclusion: You can challenge and seek to void the contract because you were induced into a different subject than assured; the court may restore your position if misrepresentation is proven.

instruction: I entered a contract because I mistakenly believed an important fact. What does the law say about mistakes caused by the other party?
input: Section no 518  part (3) : Causing a mistake as to any matter of the contract,
output: According to Section 518(2)(d) part (3). Rule: Causing a mistake about any matter of the contract is a form of misrepresentation/defect that can make a contract voidable. Application/Conclusion: If the other party's actions caused your mistake about a contractual matter, you may seek rescission or restoration under the voidable contract provisions.

instruction: If I was induced into a contract, can I ask the court to just restore my position instead of cancelling it?
input: Section no 518  part (3) (a) : The party caused to enter into a contract may, instead of having the contract voided, demand that his or her position be restored into the position that would have been had the contract not been concluded.
output: According to Section 518(3)(a). Rule: A party induced into a contract may choose restoration of their prior position instead of voiding the contract. Application/Conclusion: You can request the court to restore you to the position you would have been in absent the contract (rather than simply voiding it), and the court may order restoration as an alternative remedy.

instruction: My employer says the contract was fair though I was under pressure. Who has to prove there was no undue influence?
input: Section no 518  part (3) (b) : If a contract is made with the person who is under his or her influence and whose will can be dominated by him or her, the party who claims that he or she has not exercised such undue influence shall have the onus to prove that the contract has not been caused by undue influence. 289
output: According to Section 518(3)(b). Rule: When a contract is with someone under another's influence, the party claiming they did not exercise undue influence bears the onus of proof. Application/Conclusion: Your employer (or the influencer) must prove that no undue influence was exercised; if they cannot, the contract may be set aside for undue influence.

instruction: Is a contract I signed still valid while a court considers voiding it?
input: Section no 518  part (4) : A voidable contract shall, before it is voided, be enforceable as if it were a lawful contract.
output: According to Section 518(4). Rule: A voidable contract remains enforceable as if lawful until it is voided. Application/Conclusion: Until a court voids the contract, it is enforceable; parties should be cautious because obligations under the contract may still be binding until judicial voidance.

instruction: If the court voids the contract later, what happens to actions already taken under that contract?
input: Section no 518  part (5) : If a voidable contract under this Section is voided by the court, it shall not affect the act done under such contract before the voidance.
output: According to Section 518(5). Rule: Voidance of a voidable contract does not affect acts done under it before voidance. Application/Conclusion: Acts performed under the contract prior to court voidance remain valid; you cannot automatically unwind past actions simply because the contract is later voided.

instruction: If a contract is voided, can an innocent third party lose their legal interest?
input: Section no 518  part (6) : If any contract is voided pursuant to this Section, the legal right or interest of a bona fide third party shall not be prejudiced merely by the reason of such voidance.
output: According to Section 518(6). Rule: Voiding a contract does not, by itself, prejudice the legal rights or interests of a bona fide third party. Application/Conclusion: If a third party acquired rights in good faith, their legal interests are protected even if the original contract is later voided.

instruction: When is a contract considered 'unenforceable' by the court?
input: Section no 519 . Unenforceable contracts : (1) A contract that is not enforceable by the court shall be regarded as an unenforceable contract.
output: According to Section 519(1). Rule: A contract which the court will not enforce is defined as an unenforceable contract. Application/Conclusion: If the court lacks ability or jurisdiction to enforce a particular contract, it is treated as unenforceable under this provision.

instruction: We made an agreement orally but the law requires it to be in writing. Can I enforce it?
input: Section no 519  part (2) (a) : A contract required to be made in written form according to law is not concluded in written form,
output: According to Section 519(2)(a). Rule: A contract that the law requires to be in writing but is not concluded in writing is not enforceable by the court. Application/Conclusion: Your oral agreement will generally be unenforceable if the law requires a written form for that type of contract; you should redo the contract in the required written form to obtain enforceability.

instruction: We didn't register the sale even though registration is required. Is that enforceable?
input: Section no 519  part (2) (b) : A contract required to be made in fulfillment of any particular formality or procedure or to be registered with any body according to law is not so made in fulfillment of such formality or procedure or is not so registered,
output: According to Section 519(2)(b). Rule: Contracts that require certain formalities or registration and are not made or registered as required are not enforceable by the court. Application/Conclusion: Because the required formality/registration was not completed, the contract is likely unenforceable until the required procedure or registration is properly fulfilled.

instruction: My agent agreed to sell my land but did so for a plot I never authorized. Is that binding on me?
input: Section no 519  part (2) (c) : Where a contract is concluded on behalf of another person, the contract is concluded on a matter not authorized by, or concluded beyond the authority given by, that other person. 290
output: According to Section 519(2)(c). Rule: A contract concluded on behalf of someone that is beyond the authority given to the agent is not enforceable by the court. Application/Conclusion: If your agent acted outside their authority in contracting for a matter you didn't authorize, the contract is likely unenforceable against you; you may disavow it and the other party may not enforce it.

instruction: Under which section is the concept of 'unenforceable contracts' explained?
input: Section no 519 . Unenforceable contracts : (1) A contract that is not enforceable by the court shall be regarded as an unenforceable contract.
output: According to Section 519. Rule: Section 519 defines and governs unenforceable contracts. Application/Conclusion: The law's treatment of unenforceable contracts is set out in Section 519; refer to its subsections for specific grounds rendering contracts unenforceable.

instruction: Can I stop performing the contract if the thing I was supposed to deliver was destroyed in a fire?
input: Section no 531  part (2) (c) : If the subject matter essential for the performance of the contract is destroyed or damaged, or exists no longer, or such a subject matter could not be obtained,
output: According to Section 531(2)(c). Rule: If the subject matter essential for performance is destroyed, damaged, no longer exists, or cannot be obtained, that circumstance is deemed a fundamental change in the circumstances. Application/Conclusion: If the fire destroyed the essential subject matter for your contract, performance need not be made under the contract because the statutory condition for discharge (destruction of essential subject matter) is met.

instruction: My buyer paid me before the flood made delivery impossible. Do I have to return the money?
input: Section no 531  part (5) (a) : A party who has received any amount paid by the other party in consideration of the contract, prior to the occurrence of such a change in the circumstance, shall refund it to the other party,
output: According to Section 531(5)(a). Rule: If performance becomes impossible due to a fundamental change in circumstances, a party who received payment prior to that change must refund it. Application/Conclusion: Because the flood made performance impossible (a qualifying fundamental change), you must refund the amount you received from the buyer that was paid before the flood occurred.

instruction: Is war considered a reason to not perform a contract?
input: Section no 531  part (2) (b) : If it becomes impossible to perform the contract due to emergence of situations beyond human control such as war, flood, landslide, fire, earthquake and volcanic eruption,
output: According to Section 531(2)(b). Rule: Situations beyond human control — explicitly including war — that make performance impossible are deemed fundamental changes allowing discharge. Application/Conclusion: Yes. If war makes performance impossible, the contract need not be performed under this provision.

instruction: Performance has become much harder and more costly. Can I stop performing the contract?
input: Section no 531  part (3) (a) : If the performance of the contract has become diﬀicult,
output: According to Section 531(3)(a). Rule: Mere difficulty in performance is not a fundamental change in circumstances. Application/Conclusion: No. Simply becoming able to perform only with greater difficulty does not discharge you; you cannot stop performing on that ground alone under this section.

instruction: I now make less profit than expected if I complete the work. Is that a reason to be excused?
input: Section no 531  part (3) (b) : If the performance of the contract results in less profit or in loss,
output: According to Section 531(3)(b). Rule: A reduction in profit or incurring a loss does not constitute a fundamental change in circumstances. Application/Conclusion: No. Financial loss or reduced profit by itself does not excuse performance under this provision.

instruction: Our supplier (not a party) failed to deliver raw material. Can I treat that as a fundamental change and stop my contract?
input: Section no 531  part (3) (c) : If any party to the contract is dependent upon any third party who is not a party to the contract for its performance, and the third party makes a default or becomes incompetent,
output: According to Section 531(3)(c). Rule: Dependence on a non‑party who defaults or becomes incompetent is not a fundamental change in circumstances. Application/Conclusion: You cannot automatically treat that third‑party default as a ground to be discharged under this section; the law excludes such situations from being fundamental changes.

instruction: There’s a strike at the factory—can that discharge our contract?
input: Section no 531  part (3) (d) : In the event of a strike or lockout,
output: According to Section 531(3)(d). Rule: A strike or lockout is explicitly excluded from being deemed a fundamental change in circumstances. Application/Conclusion: No. A strike or lockout does not by itself allow discharge under this Section; the parties are not automatically excused on that ground.

instruction: The government imposed an extra tax after we signed. Am I relieved from performing?
input: Section no 531  part (3) (e) : If additional tax, fee or other revenue is required to be paid,
output: According to Section 531(3)(e). Rule: Imposition of additional tax, fee or revenue is not a fundamental change in circumstances. Application/Conclusion: No. You are not discharged from the contract merely because new taxes or fees were imposed after contracting under this provision.

instruction: We contracted for several goods. Only some can’t be supplied. Can I cancel the whole contract?
input: Section no 531  part (3) (f) : If a contract is concluded with more than one object and some of the objects cannot be fulfilled.
output: According to Section 531(3)(f). Rule: When a multi‑object contract has some objects that cannot be fulfilled, that situation is not a fundamental change in circumstances. Application/Conclusion: You cannot treat the partial inability to fulfill some objects as a fundamental change discharging the entire contract under this section.

instruction: If performance becomes difficult because of one of the excluded situations, can we renegotiate the contract terms?
input: Section no 531  part (4) : In the case of emergence of any of the circumstances referred to in sub-section (3), the parties may, except as otherwise provided for in the contract, negotiate to review or alter the terms and conditions of the contract.
output: According to Section 531(4). Rule: When circumstances listed in subsection (3) arise (those not deemed fundamental), parties may negotiate to review or alter contract terms unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Yes. Although those circumstances do not discharge performance, you and the other party are permitted to renegotiate the contract terms unless your contract forbids such negotiation.

instruction: What happens to amounts still due after a fundamental change makes performance impossible?
input: Section no 531  part (5) (b) : Payment to be made or due from one party to the other party in consideration of the contract shall not be payable after such a change in the circumstance.
output: According to Section 531(5)(b). Rule: If a fundamental change makes performance impossible, payments that were to be made or are due under the contract are not payable after that change. Application/Conclusion: After such a qualifying fundamental change, you are not obligated to make payments that would otherwise have been due under the contract.

instruction: The contract I signed later turned out to be illegal. Do I still have to perform?
input: Section no 531  part (2) (a) : If the contract becomes illegal and thereby it cannot be performed,
output: According to Section 531(2)(a). Rule: If a contract becomes illegal and thereby cannot be performed, this is a fundamental change in circumstances allowing discharge. Application/Conclusion: If the contract has become illegal and performance is impossible for that reason, you need not perform under the contract according to this provision.

instruction: Our performer died after signing a personal‑skills contract. Can the obligation be discharged?
input: Section no 531  part (2) (d) : If the contract is so concluded that its performance depends on the personal ability, skill or talent of a person, and the performance of the contract becomes impossible by the reason that such a person dies or becomes insane or is incapable of performing the contract because of physical or mental disability.
output: According to Section 531(2)(d). Rule: When performance depends on a specific person's personal ability, skill or talent, death, insanity, or incapacity of that person making performance impossible is a fundamental change. Application/Conclusion: Yes. If the contract required that particular person's personal services and they died or became incapable, performance is impossible and the obligation is discharged under this subsection.

instruction: The contract became impossible to carry out after a landslide. Do I still owe the balance payment?
input: Section no 531  part (2) (b) : If it becomes impossible to perform the contract due to emergence of situations beyond human control such as war, flood, landslide, fire, earthquake and volcanic eruption,
output: According to Section 531(2)(b). Rule: Natural disasters like a landslide that make performance impossible are fundamental changes discharging obligations. Application/Conclusion: If the landslide made performance impossible, then under Section 531 those obligations are discharged; per Section 531(5)(b) payments due after that change are not payable.

instruction: Quick: does the law say that a contract need not be performed if circumstances fundamentally change?
input: Section no 531  part (1) : If it becomes impossible to perform a contract as a result of fundamental change in the circumstance existed at the time of conclusion of the contract, the act according to the contract need not be performed.
output: According to Section 531(1). Rule: If performance becomes impossible because of a fundamental change in circumstances existing at the time of contracting, the contractual act need not be performed. Application/Conclusion: Yes. The provision expressly allows non‑performance when such a qualifying fundamental change makes performance impossible.

instruction: Which things are listed by the law as examples of fundamental changes?
input: Section no 531  part (2) : Without prejudice to the generality of sub-section (1), emergence of any of the following circumstances shall be deemed to constitute a fundamental change in the circumstance existed at the time of conclusion of a contract:
output: According to Section 531(2). Rule: The subsection introduces specific examples (in parts (a)–(d)) that are deemed fundamental changes, without limiting the general rule in subsection (1). Application/Conclusion: The law signals that the following listed circumstances (see parts (a)–(d) in the statute) are deemed fundamental changes and can discharge performance; these examples are illustrative of the broader rule in subsection (1).

instruction: My contract specified personal performance by a singer. She lost her voice. Can I claim impossibility?
input: Section no 531  part (2) (d) : If the contract is so concluded that its performance depends on the personal ability, skill or talent of a person, and the performance of the contract becomes impossible by the reason that such a person dies or becomes insane or is incapable of performing the contract because of physical or mental disability.
output: According to Section 531(2)(d). Rule: When performance depends on a person's unique ability, and that person becomes incapable (e.g., through disability), such incapacity that makes performance impossible is a fundamental change. Application/Conclusion: Loss of the singer's voice that makes performance impossible would fit this provision; you would be discharged from the obligation to have that specific performance fulfilled.

instruction: If the contract becomes illegal after signing, what happens to payments that were already made?
input: Section no 531  part (5) (a) : A party who has received any amount paid by the other party in consideration of the contract, prior to the occurrence of such a change in the circumstance, shall refund it to the other party,
output: According to Section 531(5)(a). Rule: When performance becomes impossible due to a fundamental change (including illegality), any amounts received before the change must be refunded. Application/Conclusion: If the contract became illegal and thus performance impossible, amounts you received before that illegality arose must be refunded to the payer under this provision.

instruction: Can I claim expenses if the contract changed circumstances and I already paid something?
input:
part (5) (c) : The amount payable to each other shall be
determined in consideration the act or amount already performed or paid, if
any, by one party to the other party before such a change in the circumstance,
and one party shall be entitled to recover reasonable expenses incurred by that
party in consideration of the contract from the other party.
output:
According to Section 530(5)(c)...
Rule: When circumstances change, amounts payable are determined by considering acts or payments already performed or made, and a party is entitled to recover reasonable expenses incurred in relation to the contract from the other party.
Application/Conclusion: If a change in circumstance occurred and you had already performed acts or paid money, the payable amount will take that into account, and you may recover reasonable expenses you incurred in performing or preparing to perform the contract from the other party.

instruction: If the exceptional circumstance ends, can we just keep performing the contract?
input:
Section no 531  part (6) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in
this Section, the contracting parties may agree to fulfill their respective obligations by continuing the performance of the contract after the end of the
circumstance under clause (b) of sub-section (2).
output:
According to Section 531(6)...
Rule: Parties may, by agreement, continue to fulfill their contractual obligations by resuming performance after the special circumstance ends.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if both parties agree, you can continue performing the contract after the specified circumstance ends; such continuation depends on mutual agreement.

instruction: My supplier didn't give the equipment we needed so the contract couldn't be performed. Are they liable?
input:
Section no 532  part (2) : If the contract cannot be performed due to the
failure to provide such facilities, the party in default of the performance shall
not be held liable responsible.
output:
According to Section 532(2)...
Rule: If failure to provide necessary facilities prevents performance, the party who failed to provide those facilities is not held liable for non-performance.
Application/Conclusion: Under this provision, if your supplier's failure to provide required facilities made performance impossible, that supplier (the party in default of providing facilities) is not automatically liable for the contract's non-performance.

instruction: Am I required to give the other side the facilities they need to perform our contract?
input:
Section no 532 . Facilities to be provided : (1) The parties to a contract
shall provide to each other such facilities as may be needed to perform the
contract from their respective sides.
output:
According to Section 532(1)...
Rule: Contracting parties must provide each other with facilities needed to perform the contract from their respective sides.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — both parties are obliged to supply whatever facilities are reasonably necessary on their side to enable performance of the contract.

instruction: Can we change terms, delay deadlines, or substitute work under the contract if we both agree?
input:
Section no 533 . Contract may be suspended or altered : (1) The parties
to a contract may, if they so agree, change or alter all or any of the portions of the
act to be performed under the contract, extend the time for the performance of
any act under the contract, suspend the contract by not making it obligatory to
perform any act to be performed under the contract for some time, substitute
any act for 300 the act specified in the contract or make a new contract in
substitution for the original contract.
output:
According to Section 533(1)...
Rule: Parties may, by mutual agreement, alter contract terms, extend performance time, suspend obligations temporarily, substitute acts, or make a new contract replacing the original.
Application/Conclusion: If both of you agree, you can modify the contract in those ways — change tasks, extend deadlines, suspend performance for a time, substitute different acts, or replace the original contract with a new one.

instruction: If we change the contract, does that create a new contract automatically?
input:
Section no 533  part (2) : If any change or alteration is made to a contract
pursuant to sub-section (1), a new contract shall be deemed to be made, and
the new contract shall become effective accordingly.
output:
According to Section 533(2)...
Rule: Any change or alteration made under the power to modify constitutes a new contract, which becomes effective accordingly.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — when you alter the contract as allowed, the alteration is treated as creating a new contract that takes effect in place of (or alongside) the original as specified.

instruction: If we make a new contract after altering the original, do we still have to honor the old one?
input:
Section no 533  part (3) : If a new contract is made pursuant to sub-section
(2), the obligation under the original contract need not be borne except as
otherwise provided for in the new contract.
output:
According to Section 533(3)...
Rule: When a new contract is made pursuant to the alteration rules, obligations under the original contract are not required to be performed, except to the extent the new contract provides otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: Generally, you are not bound by the old contract once a new contract replaces it, unless the new contract specifically preserves certain obligations from the original.

instruction: I just discovered someone breached the contract months ago. How long do I have to sue?
input:
Section no 534 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from
any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within
two years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action.
output:
According to Section 534...
Rule: An aggrieved person must file a lawsuit within two years from the date the cause of action accrued.
Application/Conclusion: You have two years from when your cause of action arose to bring a lawsuit under this Chapter; if more than two years have passed since accrual, you may be time-barred.

instruction: If the other party says they won't perform, is that automatically a breach?
input:
Section no 535 . Breach of contract deemed to occur : (1) If any party
to a contract fails to fulfill the obligation under the contract or gives a notice to
the other party that he or she will not perform the act to be performed by him
or her under the contract or his or her action and conduct demonstrate that he
or she is incapable of performing the act under the contract, the party shall be
deemed to have breached the contract.
output:
According to Section 535(1)...
Rule: A party who fails to fulfill obligations, notifies the other that they will not perform, or whose actions show incapacity to perform is deemed to have breached the contract.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the other party explicitly says they won't perform or their conduct shows they cannot perform, that constitutes a breach under this provision.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me land but now says he won't. Can I rescind the contract?
input:
Section no 535  part (2) : If one party commits a breach of the contract
pursuant to sub-section (1) or action or conduct of that party demonstrates nonperformance of the contract in a material respect or demonstrates a material
breach of the contract by the conduct or action of a party, the other party may
rescind the contract by giving a notice to such a party.
output:
According to Section 535(2)...
Rule: Where a party commits a breach as described (including indicating non-performance or material non-performance by conduct), the other party may rescind the contract by giving notice.
Application/Conclusion: If Ram's refusal or conduct amounts to the breach described, you may rescind the contract by notifying him, thereby treating the contract as terminated due to his material breach.

instruction: If I rescind, must I still perform anything under the contract?
input:
Section no 535  part (3) : In the case of the rescission of the contract pursuant
to sub-section (2), the party rescinding the contract shall not be bound to
perform the contract.
output:
According to Section 535(3)...
Rule: A party who rescinds under the rescission provision is not bound to perform the contract.
Application/Conclusion: After valid rescission, you are released from performing your obligations under the contract.

instruction: If the contract is between three people on one side, can one of them alone rescind?
input:
Section no 536 . Indivisible nature of the authority to rescind contract
: If either party of a contract consists of two or more persons, the contract may
be rescinded only if all of such persons rescind it or if the rescission is applicable
to all of them.
output:
According to Section 536...
Rule: When a contractual party comprises multiple persons, rescission is effective only if all of them rescind, or if the rescission applies to all of them.
Application/Conclusion: No — a single person among several cannot unilaterally rescind the contract; all co-parties must join the rescission or it must apply to all.

instruction: I paid part of the fee and then the contractor stopped. Can I get back what I paid and expenses?
input:
part (5) (c) : The amount payable to each other shall be
determined in consideration the act or amount already performed or paid, if
any, by one party to the other party before such a change in the circumstance,
and one party shall be entitled to recover reasonable expenses incurred by that
party in consideration of the contract from the other party.
output:
According to Section 530(5)(c)...
Rule: Payments and performed acts before a change in circumstance are considered when determining amounts payable; a party may recover reasonable expenses incurred in relation to the contract from the other party.
Application/Conclusion: Given you paid some fee before the contractor stopped, the final payable amount will account for what you paid, and you can claim reasonable expenses you incurred from the contractor, subject to specifics of the situation.

instruction: We want to substitute a different task instead of what the contract says — is that allowed?
input:
Section no 533 . Contract may be suspended or altered : (1) The parties
to a contract may, if they so agree, change or alter all or any of the portions of the
act to be performed under the contract, extend the time for the performance of
any act under the contract, suspend the contract by not making it obligatory to
perform any act to be performed under the contract for some time, substitute
any act for 300 the act specified in the contract or make a new contract in
substitution for the original contract.
output:
According to Section 533(1)...
Rule: Parties may, by mutual agreement, substitute any act for the act specified in the contract.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if both parties agree, you can substitute a different act for the one originally specified.

instruction: What happens legally when a party's actions show they can't perform the contract?
input:
Section no 535 . Breach of contract deemed to occur : (1) If any party
to a contract fails to fulfill the obligation under the contract or gives a notice to
the other party that he or she will not perform the act to be performed by him
or her under the contract or his or her action and conduct demonstrate that he
or she is incapable of performing the act under the contract, the party shall be
deemed to have breached the contract.
output:
According to Section 535(1)...
Rule: Conduct that demonstrates incapacity to perform counts as a breach of contract.
Application/Conclusion: If a party's actions make it clear they cannot perform, that party is deemed to have breached the contract, giving the other party remedies such as rescission as provided elsewhere in the Chapter.

instruction: How do I know which section sets the time limit to sue?
input:
Section no 534 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from
any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within
two years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action.
output:
According to Section 534...
Rule: The statute of limitation for actions under this Chapter is two years from accrual.
Application/Conclusion: Section 534 defines the time limit: you must bring suit within two years after your cause of action accrues.

instruction: If one party materially breaches by conduct, what can the other party do?
input:
Section no 535  part (2) : If one party commits a breach of the contract
pursuant to sub-section (1) or action or conduct of that party demonstrates nonperformance of the contract in a material respect or demonstrates a material
breach of the contract by the conduct or action of a party, the other party may
rescind the contract by giving a notice to such a party.
output:
According to Section 535(2)...
Rule: Material non-performance or conduct showing material breach allows the other party to rescind the contract by notice.
Application/Conclusion: If the breach is material as described, the innocent party may rescind the contract by serving notice, thereby terminating their obligation to continue performance.

instruction: Short: Can I stop performing if I gave notice to rescind?
input:
Section no 535  part (3) : In the case of the rescission of the contract pursuant
to sub-section (2), the party rescinding the contract shall not be bound to
perform the contract.
output:
According to Section 535(3)...
Rule: A party who rescinds under the stated provision is not bound to perform.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — once you validly rescind under subsection (2), you are no longer obliged to perform the contract.

instruction: We altered our contract — does that automatically replace the old one for all obligations?
input:
Section no 533  part (2) : If any change or alteration is made to a contract
pursuant to sub-section (1), a new contract shall be deemed to be made, and
the new contract shall become effective accordingly.

Section no 533  part (3) : If a new contract is made pursuant to sub-section
(2), the obligation under the original contract need not be borne except as
otherwise provided for in the new contract.
output:
According to Section 533(2) and 533(3)...
Rule: An alteration made under the permitted rules is treated as making a new contract (533(2)), and obligations under the original contract need not be borne except where the new contract provides otherwise (533(3)).
Application/Conclusion: When you alter the contract following subsection (1), a new contract arises and generally replaces the old obligations; however, any obligations the new contract expressly preserves from the original must still be honored.

instruction: Can I demand that an act be performed at a specific place if the contract is silent but the task obviously must be done at one location?
input:
part (3) : If a contract does not specify a particular place for
the performance of an act but the act can be performed only at a particular place
or has to be performed in any particular place 293 having regard to practice
or usage or nature of the act, the contract shall be deemed to have been so
concluded that the act has to be performed at that place.
output: According to Section 524(3), the rule is that when a contract does not name a place but the act can only be done at, or should be done at, a particular place (because of practice, usage or the nature of the act), the contract is treated as if it required performance at that place. Applied to your case: if the task objectively requires one specific location, you can insist performance at that place because the law deems the contract concluded on that basis.

instruction: My contract doesn't say where delivery should happen and it's not the kind of act that must happen in one place. Who decides the place?
input:
Section no 524  part (4) : In any case other than those referred to in subsections
 Section no 524  part (2) : and (3), if a contract does not specify the place for
the performance of an act, the party performing the act according to the contract
shall notify the other party to specify a reasonable place for the performance of
the act, and the other party shall specify a reasonable place for the performance
of the act.
output: According to Section 524(4), the rule is that where the contract does not fix a place (and the special cases of subsections (2) and (3) do not apply), the performing party must notify the other party to specify a reasonable place, and the other party must then specify a reasonable place. Applied to your situation: the performing party should request a reasonable place in writing/notice; the counterparty must then specify a reasonable place for performance.

instruction: I was supposed to get work done by a certain date but it didn't happen on time. Is that considered a delay under the law?
input:
Section no 525 . Performance of contract deemed to be delayed : (1) If
a contract so made as to be performed at a particular time is not performed at
or within such time, the performance of contract shall be deemed to have been
be delayed.
output: According to Section 525(1), the rule is that if a contract is to be performed at a particular time and it is not done at or within that time, the performance is deemed delayed. Applied to your situation: because the work was not completed by the contractual time, the law treats that as a delay, triggering the delay remedies in the statute.

instruction: The other side missed the deadline but says they can still do it later. Do I have to accept late performance immediately?
input:
Section no 525  part (2) : If the contract under sub-section (1) can be performed even after such time, one party of the contract may notify the other
party to perform the contract, having given a reasonable time.
output: According to Section 525(2), the rule is that where performance is possible after the agreed time, one party may notify the other to perform but must give a reasonable time for that performance. Applied to your case: you are not obliged to accept immediate late performance without notice — you should notify the other party and give them a reasonable additional period to perform.

instruction: If I give them extra time to perform after a delay, can I still claim damages for losses caused by the delay?
input:
Section no 525  part (3) : If a notice is given pursuant to sub-section (2), the other party shall perform the contract accordingly, and may claim for compen156
sation for any loss or damage caused in consequence of the delayed performance
of the contract.
output: According to Section 525(3), the rule is that after a notice under subsection (2) the other party must perform and may claim compensation for any loss or damage caused by the delayed performance. Applied to your situation: even if you grant extra time and they then perform, you can still seek compensation for losses suffered because of their delay.

instruction: I gave notice and extra time but they still didn't perform. Can I cancel the contract?
input:
Section no 525  part (4) : If a contract is not performed pursuant to subsection
 Section no 525  part (3) : , the party giving such a notice may rescind the
contract.
output: According to Section 525(4), the rule is that if the contract is not performed after the notice and reasonable time provided under subsection (3), the party who gave the notice may rescind (cancel) the contract. Applied to your scenario: since you gave notice and a reasonable additional period and performance still did not occur, you are entitled to rescind the contract.

instruction: What does it mean when they say 'time is of the essence' — when can I treat a contract as breached immediately for late performance?
input:
Section no 526 . Time to be considered as essence of contract : (1)
If the the purpose or objective of a contract cannot be achieved, in case of
non-performance of the contract within a particular day, time or period, having
regard to the nature of the contract or intention 294 shown by the parties at
time of its conclusion , the time for the performance of such a contract shall be
considered to be the essence of the contract.
output: According to Section 526(1), the rule is that where, because of the contract's nature or the parties' intention, failing to perform within a specified day, time or period would defeat the contract's purpose, time is to be treated as the essence of the contract. Applied to your question: if timely performance is essential to achieve the contract's object (as shown by the contract terms or circumstances), then failure to perform within that time means time is of the essence and late performance undermines the contract.

instruction: Delivery was late on a time‑sensitive sale — can I cancel straight away?
input:
Section no 526  part (2) : If either party of a contract does not perform the
contract under sub-section (1) within such a day, time or period, such a contract
shall be deemed to have been breached and the other party may rescind the
contract immediately.
output: According to Section 526(2), the rule is that if time is of the essence (per subsection (1)) and a party fails to perform within the specified time, the contract is deemed breached and the other party may immediately rescind it. Applied to your case: because delivery was late on a time-sensitive sale where time was essential, you may treat the contract as breached and rescind immediately.

instruction: My counterparty says I don't have to perform a part of the contract anymore. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 527  clause (a) : If either party to a contract waives the other
party from fulfilling the obligation under the contract,
output: According to Section 527(a), the rule is that when one party waives the other party's obligation under the contract, it is not necessary to perform that obligation. Applied to your situation: if the counterparty validly and clearly waives your obligation, you are excused from performing that part of the contract.

instruction: We had a contract that's voidable and the entitled party annulled it. Do I still need to perform?
input:
Section no 527  clause (b) : If a voidable contract is voided by the party
entitled to do so,
output: According to Section 527(b), the rule is that if a voidable contract is voided by the party entitled to void it, performance is not necessary. Applied to your situation: once the entitled party properly voids the voidable contract, neither party needs to perform obligations under that contract.

instruction: The other party breached the contract so the job became impossible. Do I still have to perform my part?
input:
Section no 527  clause (c) : If the contract cannot be performed for the reason
of its breach by the other party,
output: According to Section 527(c), the rule is that where the contract cannot be performed because the other party breached it, performance is not required. Applied to your case: if the breach by the other side makes your performance impossible, you are excused from performing under the contract.

instruction: Is there a situation where a statutory provision in this Part frees me from performance?
input:
Section no 527  clause (d) : If it is not necessary to perform the act under
the contract by operation of any provision of this Part,
output: According to Section 527(d), the rule is that if some provision of this Part makes performance unnecessary, you are not required to perform. Applied to your question: if another provision in the same Part of the law operates to excuse performance, that provision governs and you need not perform.

instruction: Can a contract be left unperformed if it turns out to be unenforceable under another section?
input:
Section no 527  clause (e) : If a contract which is unenforceable according to
Section 531.
output: According to Section 527(e), the rule is that a contract need not be performed if it is unenforceable under Section 531. Applied to your situation: if the contract is found to be unenforceable by operation of Section 531, then performance is not required — you would need to consult Section 531 for the grounds of unenforceability.

instruction: Ram promised to sell me land by June 1. He missed it. I gave notice and extra time but he still didn't transfer. What can I do?
input:
Section no 525 . Performance of contract deemed to be delayed : (1) If
a contract so made as to be performed at a particular time is not performed at
or within such time, the performance of contract shall be deemed to have been
be delayed.
 Section no 525  part (2) : If the contract under sub-section (1) can be performed even after such time, one party of the contract may notify the other
party to perform the contract, having given a reasonable time.
 Section no 525  part (3) : If a notice is given pursuant to sub-section (2), the other party shall perform the contract accordingly, and may claim for compen156
sation for any loss or damage caused in consequence of the delayed performance
of the contract.
 Section no 525  part (4) : If a contract is not performed pursuant to subsection
 Section no 525  part (3) : , the party giving such a notice may rescind the
