output: According to Section 525(1)–(4), the rule is that late performance when a time was fixed is a deemed delay; if performance is still possible a party may give notice and a reasonable time to perform; after such notice the performing party must perform but the other may claim compensation for losses from the delay; and if performance still does not occur the notifying party may rescind the contract. Applied to Ram's case: his failure by June 1 is a delay. You should notify him, give a reasonable additional period to effect transfer; you can claim compensation for losses caused by the delay; and if he still doesn't transfer after that reasonable time you may rescind the sale contract.

instruction: Under which section is 'Time to be considered as essence of contract' set out?
input:
Section no 526 . Time to be considered as essence of contract : (1)
If the the purpose or objective of a contract cannot be achieved, in case of
non-performance of the contract within a particular day, time or period, having
regard to the nature of the contract or intention 294 shown by the parties at
time of its conclusion , the time for the performance of such a contract shall be
considered to be the essence of the contract.
output: According to Section 526(1), the rule is that the provision titled 'Time to be considered as essence of contract' is set out in Section 526 and it states that where non-performance within a specified time defeats the contract's purpose (given the nature or parties' intention), time is to be treated as the essence of the contract. Applied to your need to cite it: you should refer to Section 526 where this rule is established.

instruction: They say I must give a 'reasonable time' after a missed deadline — how many days do I have to give?
input:
Section no 525  part (2) : If the contract under sub-section (1) can be performed even after such time, one party of the contract may notify the other
party to perform the contract, having given a reasonable time.
output: According to Section 525(2), the rule is that when performance is possible after the agreed time, the notifying party must give a 'reasonable time' for performance. Applied to your question: the statute requires a reasonable time but does not fix a specific number of days — what is 'reasonable' depends on the contract, the nature of the act, and the surrounding circumstances.

instruction: Short: If time was essential and they missed it, can I rescind immediately or must I give notice?
input:
Section no 526  part (2) : If either party of a contract does not perform the
contract under sub-section (1) within such a day, time or period, such a contract
shall be deemed to have been breached and the other party may rescind the
contract immediately.
output: According to Section 526(2), the rule is that where time is of the essence and performance is not made within the specified period, the contract is deemed breached and the other party may rescind immediately. Applied to your short question: you do not have to give additional notice — you may rescind immediately if the time was essential and the other party failed to perform in time.

instruction: I'm confused — if I give notice after a delay and they perform, can I still get money for my losses?
input:
Section no 525  part (3) : If a notice is given pursuant to sub-section (2), the other party shall perform the contract accordingly, and may claim for compen156
sation for any loss or damage caused in consequence of the delayed performance
of the contract.
output: According to Section 525(3), the rule is that after notice under subsection (2) the other party must perform and may claim compensation for losses due to delay. Applied to your confusion: yes — even if you give notice and the party eventually performs, you may claim compensation for loss or damage that resulted from the delay.

instruction: If my father dies leaving a contract, do I automatically inherit both the benefit and the burden of that contract?
input: . Assignment of rights and liabilities under a contract : If any party to a contract dies or becomes insane, the rights accruing from the contract shall devolve on to the heir succeeding the property of such a party to the contract, and the heir himself or herself shall also bear the obligations to the extent of the property succeeded by him or her. 295 Provided that the rights and obligations accruing on the basis of personal skill and qualification shall not devolve on to such an heir.
output: According to Section 528... Rule: If a party to a contract dies, the rights from the contract pass to the heir who succeeds the deceased's property, and that heir bears the obligations only to the extent of the property he or she has succeeded; however rights and obligations based on personal skill or qualification do not devolve on the heir. Application/Conclusion: If you inherit your father's property, you will inherit contractual rights and must bear related obligations only up to the value/extent of the inherited property. You will not be required to perform duties that depend on your father's personal skill or qualification.

instruction: Can I appoint someone else or an agent to perform my contractual duties?
input:
Section no 529 . Party who must perform contract : (1) Except in cases where a contract specifies that it must be performed by its party only, the contract may be performed by his or her agent or by a person appointed by him or her or by any other person on his or her behalf or the rights and obligations
157
under the contract may be transferred. Provided that no party to a contract
may transfer his or her obligations under the contract to another person without
consent of the other party.
output: According to Section 529(1)... Rule: Unless the contract specifies exclusive personal performance, the contract may be performed by an agent or another person on the party's behalf, and rights and obligations may be transferred; but obligations cannot be transferred to another person without the other party's consent. Application/Conclusion: You can have an agent perform the contract unless the contract requires personal performance. However, you cannot shift your obligations to someone else without the other party agreeing.

instruction: I want to transfer my contractual rights — do I need anything in writing?
input: Section no 529  part (2) (a) : Unless the contract otherwise provides for, the transfer shall be in written form,
output: According to Section 529(2)(a)... Rule: Unless the contract provides otherwise, transfers of rights and obligations must be in writing. Application/Conclusion: You should put the transfer in writing unless your contract explicitly allows a different form; otherwise the transfer may not meet the statutory requirement.

instruction: Can I make the transfer subject to some conditions?
input: Section no 529  part (2) (b) : The transfer shall be unconditional,
output: According to Section 529(2)(b)... Rule: The transfer of rights and obligations must be unconditional. Application/Conclusion: You cannot validly transfer contractual rights or obligations on a conditional basis under this provision; the transfer should be unconditional.

instruction: Is there any legal prohibition that could block a transfer of rights or obligations?
input: Section no 529  part (2) (c) : The transfer of rights or obligations is not prohibited by law or the contract,
output: According to Section 529(2)(c)... Rule: A transfer is valid only if it is not prohibited by law or by the contract. Application/Conclusion: Before transferring, you must confirm neither the law nor the contract forbids such transfer; if prohibited, you cannot transfer the rights or obligations.

instruction: Do I need to inform the other party when I transfer my rights or obligations? If so, how?
input: Section no 529  part (2) (d) : In the case of the transfer of rights and obligations, a notice along with its time limit shall be given to the other party.
output: According to Section 529(2)(d)... Rule: When rights and obligations are transferred, the other party must be given a notice that includes a time limit. Application/Conclusion: You must notify the counterparty about the transfer and provide the specified time limit as part of that notice; failure to do so would not comply with the statutory condition.

instruction: I accepted work done by a substitute. Later I wanted the original contractor to do it. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 529  part (3) : Once any party to a contract accepts any act done by a third person, that party shall not be entitled to claim subsequently that the act must be done by the party to the contract himself or herself, except as otherwise provided for in the contract. 296
output: According to Section 529(3)... Rule: If a party accepts an act performed by a third person, that party cannot later insist that the original contracting party must perform the act, unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Because you accepted the substitute's work, you generally cannot later demand that the original contractor perform it—unless your contract specifically reserves that right.

instruction: Three of us entered a contract together. Does each of us have to perform the whole obligation if one person defaults?
input:
Section no 529  part (4) : If two or more persons jointly enter into a contract
with another party, any or all of such joint promisors shall fulfill, or cause to be
fulfilled, the obligations under the contract, except as otherwise provided for in
the contract.
output: According to Section 529(4)... Rule: Where two or more persons jointly enter into a contract, any or all of the joint promisors must fulfill or cause the obligations to be fulfilled, unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you and others are joint promisors, any one or more of you may be required to perform the obligation (subject to the contract's terms).

instruction: If I (as one joint promisor) perform the obligation because another joint promisor defaulted, can I get money back from the others?
input:
Section no 529  part (5) : The joint promisor who fulfills the obligation shall
be entitled to recover damages or loss on a pro rata basis from the other joint
promisors, in consideration for the default of any other joint promisor in the
fulfillment of the obligation under sub-section
output: According to Section 529(5)... Rule: A joint promisor who fulfills the obligation is entitled to recover damages or loss on a pro rata basis from the other joint promisors to account for their default. Application/Conclusion: If you perform the obligation because another joint promisor failed, you can claim contribution (pro rata) from the other joint promisors for the loss or expense you incurred.

instruction: If the other party releases one of the joint promisors from obligation, does that free the rest?
input:
Section no 529  part (6) : Even if one party releases one joint promisor of
the other party to the contract concluded pursuant to in sub-section (4) from
the obligation on his or her part, such release shall not discharge the other joint
promisors from the obligation under that contract.
output: According to Section 529(6)... Rule: A release of one joint promisor by the opposing party does not discharge the remaining joint promisors from their obligations. Application/Conclusion: No — if the other party releases one joint promisor, the remaining joint promisors remain liable under the contract.

instruction: I am not a party to a contract but it was made for my benefit. Can I demand performance?
input:
Section no 530 .
Only the parties to contract can demand its performance : (1) Only the person who is a party to a contract can demand
the performance of the contract by the other party. Provided that if a contract is concluded for the benefit of any person, such a person can demand the
performance of that contract even if he or she is not a party to such a contract.
output: According to Section 530(1)... Rule: Generally only a party to a contract can demand performance, but if the contract was concluded for the benefit of a third person, that beneficiary can demand performance even if not a party. Application/Conclusion: Because the contract was made for your benefit, you may demand its performance even though you are not a contracting party.

instruction: If two of us jointly enter into a contract to do something, can we together enforce it?
input:
Section no 530  part (2) : If two or more persons jointly enter into contract to
do or not to do any act, all such a persons can jointly demand the performance
of that contract, except as otherwise provided for in the contract.
output: According to Section 530(2)... Rule: When two or more persons jointly enter into a contract to do or not to do an act, they can jointly demand performance of that contract, unless the contract says otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you and the others who jointly entered the contract can jointly require the other party to perform, unless the contract limits that right.

instruction: I agreed to work done by a subcontractor. Later I want the main contractor to finish. Can I force them?
input: Section no 529  part (3) : Once any party to a contract accepts any act done by a third person, that party shall not be entitled to claim subsequently that the act must be done by the party to the contract himself or herself, except as otherwise provided for in the contract. 296
output: According to Section 529(3)... Rule: Acceptance of an act by a third person prevents the accepting party from later insisting the original contracting party must perform, unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Because you accepted the subcontractor's act, you generally cannot later force the main contractor to do that act—unless the contract reserves that right.

instruction: My sibling inherited part of the property and with it some contracts. To what extent must they satisfy those contracts?
input: . Assignment of rights and liabilities under a contract : If any party to a contract dies or becomes insane, the rights accruing from the contract shall devolve on to the heir succeeding the property of such a party to the contract, and the heir himself or herself shall also bear the obligations to the extent of the property succeeded by him or her. 295 Provided that the rights and obligations accruing on the basis of personal skill and qualification shall not devolve on to such an heir.
output: According to Section 528... Rule: On death, contractual rights devolve to the heir who succeeds the property, and the heir bears obligations only to the extent of the property succeeded; obligations based on personal skill/qualification do not devolve. Application/Conclusion: Your sibling must meet contractual obligations only up to the value/extent of the inherited property and is not required to perform duties that depend on the deceased's personal skill or qualifications.

instruction: Can I transfer my contract rights even if the contract is silent about transfers?
input:
Section no 529 . Party who must perform contract : (1) Except in cases where a contract specifies that it must be performed by its party only, the contract may be performed by his or her agent or by a person appointed by him or her or by any other person on his or her behalf or the rights and obligations
157
under the contract may be transferred. Provided that no party to a contract
may transfer his or her obligations under the contract to another person without
consent of the other party.
output: According to Section 529(1)... Rule: If a contract does not require exclusive personal performance, rights and obligations may be transferred; however obligations cannot be transferred without the other party's consent. Application/Conclusion: If the contract is silent and does not require personal performance, you may transfer rights and have performance done by an agent. But you cannot transfer your obligations to someone else unless the other party consents.

instruction: One of our group paid to fulfill a joint obligation. How will that person get compensated by the rest?
input:

be entitled to recover damages or loss on a pro rata basis from the other joint
promisors, in consideration for the default of any other joint promisor in the
fulfillment of the obligation under sub-section
output: According to Section 529(5)... Rule: A joint promisor who fulfills the obligation may recover damages or loss pro rata from the other joint promisors for their default. Application/Conclusion: The person who paid can demand contribution from the other joint promisors calculated on a pro rata basis to reflect each one's share of liability.

instruction: I discovered my contract was void only 14 months after the problem. Can I still sue?
input: Section no 520 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit at any time, in the case of a void contract, within one year after the date of accrual of the cause of action for voidance, in the case of a voidable contract, and within two years after the date of accrual of the cause of action, in the case of other contracts.
output: According to Section 520... Rule: For a void contract a suit must be made within one year after the date the cause of action accrued. Application/Conclusion: Because your contract is described as void and you discovered the issue 14 months after accrual, that is beyond the one-year period specified for void contracts, so your right to sue is likely time-barred under this provision.

instruction: I learned about misrepresentation 18 months after signing. How long do I have to sue for a voidable contract?
input: Section no 520 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit at any time, in the case of a void contract, within one year after the date of accrual of the cause of action for voidance, in the case of a voidable contract, and within two years after the date of accrual of the cause of action, in the case of other contracts.
output: According to Section 520... Rule: The statute of limitation provides that actions concerning voidable contracts must be brought within the period indicated in the section (the text sets a longer period than for void contracts, applying a two-year period for the other contract categories referenced). Application/Conclusion: Since you discovered the misrepresentation 18 months after signing and the section indicates a two-year period for voidable/other contracts, you are still within the limitation period and may bring a suit within the remaining time.

instruction: What does the law expect each party to do under a contract? Explain simply.
input: Section no 521 . Obligation under contract to be fulfilled : Each party to a contract shall fulfill his or her obligation under the contract.
output: According to Section 521... Rule: Each contracting party is required to perform the obligations they agreed to in the contract. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, both you and the other party must carry out what the contract requires; failure by either side to do so means that party is not meeting the legal duty set out by the agreement.

instruction: Our contract didn't say who goes first. I think I should pay first — is that right?
input: Section no 521 part (2) : If the contract fixes the order of priority for the fulfillment of any promise, the promise shall be fulfilled in that order, and failing the fixation of such an order, the party who is liable to perform the promise first according to the nature of the contract shall perform it first.
output: According to Section 521(2)... Rule: If the contract specifies the order of performance, that order must be followed; if it does not, the party who, by the nature of the contract, is obliged to perform first must do so. Application/Conclusion: Because your contract does not fix the order, whoever is naturally required to perform first (for example, the buyer often pays before delivery, or the seller delivers goods before receiving payment depending on the contract's nature) should perform first.

instruction: He promised to hand over goods at the same time I'll pay, but now he shows he won't. Do I have to pay?
input: 522 . Reciprocal performance of contract : (1) If a contract is so concluded that the parties to the contract shall fulfill their respective obligations simultaneously and one party demonstrates such conduct or intention that he or she is not willing to fulfill his or her obligation materially, the other party need not perform his or her promise.
output: According to Section 522(1)... Rule: When obligations are to be performed simultaneously, and one party shows by conduct or intention that they will not perform, the other party is not required to perform their promise. Application/Conclusion: Since the other party has indicated unwillingness to perform his simultaneous obligation, you are entitled to withhold your payment and need not perform your promise.

instruction: My contractual obligation depends on the other side doing their part. They failed. Can I recover my losses?
input: Section no 521 part (3) : If, in the case of a contract containing reciprocal promises, and performance of one promise depends on the performance of the other promise, one party cannot perform the contract because of the failure of the other party to perform his or her promise may recover the loss or damage caused by the failure of the other party to perform the contract.
output: According to Section 521(3)... Rule: Where reciprocal promises exist and one party cannot perform because the other party failed to perform, the non-defaulting party may recover loss or damage caused by that failure. Application/Conclusion: Because your performance was frustrated by the other party's failure to perform, you are entitled to claim compensation for losses or damages resulting from their breach.

instruction: They actively prevented me from doing my part of a simultaneous contract. Can I cancel it and get damages?
input: Section no 521 part (4) : If a contract concluded for reciprocal promises to be simultaneously performed pursuant to sub-section (1) and one party prevents the other party from performing such a contract, the other party so prevented is entitled to rescind the contract and also to 292 recover the loss or damage, if any, caused to him or her in consequence of such termination of the contract.
output: According to Section 521(4)... Rule: If one party prevents the other from performing a contract of simultaneous reciprocal promises, the prevented party may rescind the contract and recover any loss or damage caused by that termination. Application/Conclusion: Since you were prevented from performing by the other party, you can rescind the contract and seek compensation for losses stemming from that prevention and termination.

instruction: Our agreement says delivery must be 'on June 1st' — do they have to deliver on that exact day and that manner?
input: Section no 523 . Time and manner for performance of contract : (1) If a contract specifies the time and manner for its performance, the contract shall be performed within the specified time and in the specified manner.
output: According to Section 523(1)... Rule: Where a contract specifies a time and manner for performance, the parties must perform within that time and in that manner. Application/Conclusion: Because your contract specifies June 1st, the other party is required to deliver on that date and in the specified way; failure to do so would be a breach of the contractual terms.

instruction: The contract never set a date, but the act can only be done during the monsoon. When must it be done?
input: Section no 523 part (2) : If a contract does not specify the time or manner for the performance of an act under the contract but the act can be performed only at any specific time or only in a specific manner, the contract shall be deemed to have been so concluded that the act has to be performed at that time and in that manner.
output: According to Section 523(2)... Rule: If no time or manner is specified but the act can only be performed at a specific time or in a specific manner, the contract is deemed to require performance at that specific time and in that manner. Application/Conclusion: As the act is only possible during the monsoon, you must perform (or can require performance) during the monsoon season even though the contract did not state a date.

instruction: We didn't say when or how to perform. How soon must we do it?
input: Section no 523 part (3) : If, except in the circumstance under sub-section (2), a contract does not specify the time or manner for its performance, the contract shall be performed within a reasonable time and in a reasonable manner.
output: According to Section 523(3)... Rule: Where a contract does not specify time or manner (and sub-section (2) does not apply), performance must occur within a reasonable time and in a reasonable manner. Application/Conclusion: You and the other party must act within what is reasonable under the circumstances; if a dispute arises, reasonableness will be assessed based on the contract context and industry norms.

instruction: If the contract gives a specific place to perform, can they make me come somewhere else?
input: Section no 524 . Place for performance of contract : (1) If a contract specifies any particular place for the performance of any act, that act shall be performed at such a place.
output: According to Section 524(1)... Rule: When a contract specifies a particular place for performance, the act must be performed at that place. Application/Conclusion: No — the obligor must perform at the contractually specified place unless the parties agree to change it; unilateral relocation would be a breach of that term.

instruction: We agreed I would hand over goods but the contract doesn't say where. Where must I hand them over?
input: Section no 524 part (2) : If, any party is required by a contract to hand over or deliver any goods to the other party and the contract does not specify the place for such hand-over or delivery of the goods, the contract shall be deemed to have been so concluded that the goods have to be delivered or handed over at the place where such goods are located.
output: According to Section 524(2)... Rule: If the contract requires delivery but does not specify the place, the goods must be delivered at the place where the goods are located. Application/Conclusion: You should hand over the goods at their current location; unless the parties agree otherwise, the law treats that location as the contractual place of delivery.

instruction: Which section sets out how long I have to sue for contract disputes? I need the exact reference.
input: Section no 520 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit at any time, in the case of a void contract, within one year after the date of accrual of the cause of action for voidance, in the case of a voidable contract, and within two years after the date of accrual of the cause of action, in the case of other contracts.
output: According to Section 520... Rule: Section 520 is the statute of limitation provision dealing with time limits for bringing lawsuits under this Chapter, specifying different limitation periods for void, voidable and other contract types. Application/Conclusion: Use Section 520 to determine the applicable limitation period for your contract claim (one year for void contracts; the provision indicates a longer—two year—period for voidable/other contract categories).

instruction: My buyer said he won't accept delivery and therefore I couldn't hand over goods simultaneously. Can I claim damages?
input: Section no 521 part (4) : If a contract concluded for reciprocal promises to be simultaneously performed pursuant to sub-section (1) and one party prevents the other party from performing such a contract, the other party so prevented is entitled to rescind the contract and also to 292 recover the loss or damage, if any, caused to him or her in consequence of such termination of the contract.
output: According to Section 521(4)... Rule: If one party prevents the other from performing simultaneous reciprocal promises, the prevented party can rescind the contract and recover resulting loss or damage. Application/Conclusion: Because your buyer prevented delivery, you may rescind the contract and claim compensation for losses caused by that prevention and termination.

instruction: Short: If one party clearly won't do their part, must I still perform?
input: 522 . Reciprocal performance of contract : (1) If a contract is so concluded that the parties to the contract shall fulfill their respective obligations simultaneously and one party demonstrates such conduct or intention that he or she is not willing to fulfill his or her obligation materially, the other party need not perform his or her promise.
output: According to Section 522(1)... Rule: Where obligations are to be performed simultaneously and one party demonstrates unwillingness to perform, the other party need not perform. Application/Conclusion: No — you are not required to perform if the other party has shown by conduct or intention that they will not perform their simultaneous obligation.

instruction: I have a sale contract but it never set a delivery method. The goods can only be moved by refrigerated transport. What does the law say about the manner?
input: Section no 523 part (2) : If a contract does not specify the time or manner for the performance of an act under the contract but the act can be performed only at any specific time or only in a specific manner, the contract shall be deemed to have been so concluded that the act has to be performed at that time and in that manner.
output: According to Section 523(2)... Rule: If no manner is specified but the act can only be performed in a specific manner, the contract is deemed to require performance in that manner. Application/Conclusion: The delivery must be made using refrigerated transport because the act (transport of those goods) can only be performed in that specific manner.

instruction: The contract lists several promises to be completed in order. Who must act first?
input: Section no 521 part (2) : If the contract fixes the order of priority for the fulfillment of any promise, the promise shall be fulfilled in that order, and failing the fixation of such an order, the party who is liable to perform the promise first according to the nature of the contract shall perform it first.
output: According to Section 521(2)... Rule: When the contract fixes the order of priority, performance must follow that order; where no order is fixed, the party who, by the nature of the contract, must perform first shall do so. Application/Conclusion: The party named first in the contract must perform first; if no order is specified, determine who naturally should act first based on the contract's nature and that party should perform.

instruction: I want to know: if place isn't mentioned, where is delivery presumed to take place?
input: Section no 524 part (2) : If, any party is required by a contract to hand over or deliver any goods to the other party and the contract does not specify the place for such hand-over or delivery of the goods, the contract shall be deemed to have been so concluded that the goods have to be delivered or handed over at the place where such goods are located.
output: According to Section 524(2)... Rule: Where a contract requires delivery but does not specify the place, the goods are to be delivered at the location where the goods are situated. Application/Conclusion: Delivery is presumed to occur at the current location of the goods; arrange hand-over there unless both parties agree otherwise.

instruction: Can I ask the court to force the other party to perform the contract instead of taking money?
input:
. Specific performance of contract : (1) If monetary compensation is not reasonable and adequate for the actual loss or damage suffered
by the aggrieved party because of the breach of contract, 304 the aggrieved party
may claim for the specific performance of the contract instead of compensation.
output: According to Section 540(1): Rule: If monetary compensation is not reasonable and adequate for the actual loss suffered from a breach, the aggrieved party may claim specific performance instead of compensation. Application/Conclusion: If money would not fairly make you whole for the breach, you can ask the court to order the other party to perform the contract rather than accept damages.

instruction: When is asking for specific performance not allowed?
input:
Section no 540 part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), specific performance may not be claimed in any of the following circumstances:
output: According to Section 540(2): Rule: Despite the general right in subsection (1), there are specified circumstances in which specific performance cannot be claimed. Application/Conclusion: You should check the listed exceptions (the following sub-clauses) because even if money is inadequate, a court still may refuse specific performance where those exceptions apply.

instruction: Can I get specific performance if I could be fully compensated by money?
input:
Section no 540 part (2) (a) : If monetary compensation is an adequate
remedy for the breach of contract,
output: According to Section 540(2)(a): Rule: If monetary compensation is an adequate remedy for the breach, specific performance cannot be claimed. Application/Conclusion: If the court finds that damages would adequately compensate you, your request for specific performance will likely be denied and you should pursue monetary damages instead.

instruction: The seller says they can't be supervised — can I still force them to deliver goods?
input:
Section no 540 part (2) (b) : If the court cannot supervise the performance
of the act under the contract,
output: According to Section 540(2)(b): Rule: Specific performance is not available where the court cannot properly supervise the contract's performance. Application/Conclusion: If enforcing the contract would require ongoing court supervision that is impractical, the court will refuse specific performance and you should seek damages or other remedies.

instruction: I hired a painter for their unique style. If they refuse, can I force them to paint?
input:
Section no 540 part (2) (c) : If the contract is for providing services of
personal ability, skill or knowledge,
output: According to Section 540(2)(c): Rule: Contracts for personal services, based on individual ability, skill or knowledge, cannot be specifically enforced. Application/Conclusion: You generally cannot force a particular person to perform personal services (like unique artistic work); the remedy will normally be damages, not specific performance.

instruction: Is specific performance possible if the contract simply can't be performed exactly?
input: Section no 540 part (2) (d) : If the contract cannot specifically be performed,
output: According to Section 540(2)(d): Rule: Specific performance is barred where the contract cannot be specifically performed. Application/Conclusion: If the subject matter or circumstances make exact performance impossible, the court will deny specific performance and you must seek monetary compensation or other relief.

instruction: What if the party who breached asks for specific performance — can they get it?
input:
Section no 540 part (2) (e) : If the party in breach of the contract claims
for its specific performance.
output: According to Section 540(2)(e): Rule: A party who is in breach cannot claim specific performance of the contract. Application/Conclusion: If the breaching party tries to force performance, the court will generally refuse that remedy in their favour; they cannot rely on specific performance while they remain in breach.

instruction: Ram is about to do something that would make performance impossible. Can I stop him by going to court?
input:
Section no 541 . Power of court to make order : (1) If the performance of
a contract is not possible because any party to the contract is about to perform any act or conduct which is contrary to the nature of the contract, the party
aggrieved by such an action or a conduct may file a complaint in the court to
prevent such an act or conduct.
output: According to Section 541(1): Rule: If a party is about to act in a way that makes contract performance impossible, the aggrieved party may file a complaint to prevent that act. Application/Conclusion: You can go to court to seek an order preventing Ram from taking actions that would frustrate or destroy your contractual rights.

instruction: If I file a complaint to stop the other party's conduct, can the court immediately order them to stop?
input: Section no 541 part (2) : If a complaint is filed pursuant to sub-section (1), the court may issue an appropriate order to any party to immediately stop his or her particular action or conduct, subject to the settlement of the dispute arising out of that contract in accordance with such a contract or law. 305
output: According to Section 541(2): Rule: After a complaint under subsection (1), the court may issue an immediate order stopping the particular action or conduct, subject to dispute settlement. Application/Conclusion: The court has the power to grant an immediate injunction to halt the other party's wrongful conduct while the contractual dispute is resolved according to law or the contract.

instruction: They disobeyed the court order I got to stop them. Can I get compensation for that extra harm?
input: Section no 541 part (3) : If an order is issued pursuant to sub-section (1), the aggrieved party shall be entitled to also recover additional loss or damage caused from the failure of the other party to comply with the order so issued.
output: According to Section 541(3): Rule: If an order is issued and the other party fails to comply, the aggrieved party may recover additional loss or damage caused by that failure. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the other side breaches the court's order, you can claim further compensation for losses that resulted from their non-compliance.

instruction: If my contract doesn't say otherwise, how will the court calculate compensation for breach?
input:
Section no 542 . Compensation to be ascertained in monetary value : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, assessment of compensation for any loss or damage as referred to in this Chapter shall be ascertained in
monetary value. Provided that Section 540 shall apply to the remedy under
that Section.
output: According to Section 542: Rule: Unless the contract provides otherwise, compensation for loss or damage is to be assessed in monetary value; Section 540 (on specific performance) still applies to remedies. Application/Conclusion: If your contract is silent, the court will quantify your loss in money, though you may still seek specific performance under Section 540 where appropriate.

instruction: What factors will the court consider when fixing damages for a breach?
input:
Section no 543 . Power of court to consider matters : While determining
compensation arising from the breach of a contract, the court shall consider
matters including whether the party has breached the contract intentionally or
whether the non-performance has occurred due to recklessness and how much
money or benefit might have been received by the innocent party to the contract
had the contract not been breached.
output: According to Section 543: Rule: The court must consider factors such as whether the breach was intentional or reckless and what money or benefit the innocent party would have received but for the breach. Application/Conclusion: When arguing for damages, highlight whether the breach was deliberate or reckless and present evidence of the loss of expected money or benefits, as these affect the compensation awarded.

instruction: I just found out about the breach — how long do I have to sue?
input:
Section no 544 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from
an act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within
two years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action. 306 Chapter-6
Provisions Relating to Contract of Sale of Goods
output: According to Section 544: Rule: A lawsuit under this Chapter must be brought within two years from the date the cause of action accrued. Application/Conclusion: You generally have two years from the date you knew (or should have known) the cause of action arose to file suit — act promptly to avoid losing your right to sue.

instruction: Ram promised to transfer movable goods to me later but now refuses. Is that a valid sale?
input:
Section no 545 . Contract of sale of goods : (1) A contract of sale of goods shall be deemed to have been made if any seller agrees to transfer the property
in goods immediately or in the future to the buyer for a price. Explanation:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “goods” means any kind of movable
property capable of being purchased or sold other than currency in circulation
for the time being, security or actionable claim.
output: According to Section 545(1): Rule: A sale is made when a seller agrees to transfer property in goods immediately or in the future to a buyer for a price; 'goods' means movable property (excluding currency in circulation, securities or actionable claims). Application/Conclusion: If Ram agreed to transfer movable goods to you for a price (now or later), that agreement qualifies as a contract of sale of goods and you have the legal protections under this Chapter.

instruction: We signed a sale agreement but it's conditional on a bank loan. Is that allowed?
input:
Section no 545 part (2) : A contract of sale of goods may be conditional or
unconditional.
output: According to Section 545(2): Rule: Contracts of sale of goods can be conditional or unconditional. Application/Conclusion: Yes — a sale can validly be conditional (for example, subject to obtaining a bank loan); the contract will be treated as conditional and the conditions must be analyzed when enforcing rights.

instruction: Can the court supervise and force day-to-day acts under my sales contract?
input:
Section no 540 part (2) (b) : If the court cannot supervise the performance
of the act under the contract,
output: According to Section 540(2)(b): Rule: Specific performance is barred where the court cannot supervise performance of the contract. Application/Conclusion: If enforcing your sales contract would require ongoing judicial supervision of daily acts, the court is unlikely to order specific performance and will instead consider monetary compensation or other remedies.

instruction: My buyer is trying to force me to accept specific performance though they failed themselves — can they do that?
input:
Section no 540 part (2) (e) : If the party in breach of the contract claims
for its specific performance.
output: According to Section 540(2)(e): Rule: A party who is in breach of the contract cannot successfully claim specific performance. Application/Conclusion: If the buyer (or other party) is the one in breach, their attempt to compel specific performance will generally fail; you can resist such a claim and seek damages or other appropriate relief.

instruction: Can ownership of goods pass to the buyer as soon as we sign the sales contract, even if I haven't paid yet?
input:
part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
if a contract is concluded for the sale of any specific goods in a deliverable state,
the parties shall be deemed to have the intention of transferring them when the
contract is concluded or upon payment of the price of the goods.
output: According to Section 554(2): Rule: Where a contract is for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the parties are deemed to intend transfer of those goods either when the contract is concluded or upon payment of the price, unless the contract says otherwise. Application/Conclusion: If your contract concerns specific goods that are in a deliverable state, ownership can pass at the moment the contract is concluded (or when the price is paid) depending on the agreed terms. Check the contract for any clause that alters this default timing; if none exists, signing the contract can transfer ownership even before payment.

instruction: I need to measure and weigh a bulk of grain before taking it. Can the seller demand transfer before I complete measurement?
input:
Section no 554  part (3) : If a contract is concluded for the sale of any specific
goods in a deliverable state and the buyer has to take measurement, weight,
make examination of the goods or to perform some acts to determine the price
of such goods, such goods shall not be 311 transferred until the buyer performs
such acts and gives information thereof to the buyer within a reasonable time.
output: According to Section 554(3): Rule: When transfer depends on the buyer performing acts like measurement, weighing or examination to determine price, the goods are not transferred until the buyer performs those acts and notifies the seller within a reasonable time. Application/Conclusion: Because you must measure and weigh the grain to fix the price, the law prevents transfer before you complete those acts and inform the seller promptly. The seller cannot force transfer until you have carried out those necessary checks and given notice within a reasonable time.

instruction: Where does the law say the goods are considered to be transferred — at buyer's place or seller's place?
input:
Section no 554  part (4) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
a contract shall be deemed to have been concluded so that the goods sold or to
be sold shall be transferred in the place where such goods are situated.
output: According to Section 554(4): Rule: Unless the contract provides otherwise, a contract is deemed concluded so that the goods are transferred at the place where the goods are situated. Application/Conclusion: If your contract is silent about place of transfer, the default rule is that ownership passes where the goods are located. So if the goods are at the seller's warehouse, transfer occurs there unless the contract sets a different place.

instruction: When exactly does the buyer get title to the goods?
input:
Section no 554  part (5) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
the buyer shall be deemed to have the title or ownership of the goods at the
time of the transfer of the goods to the buyer.
output: According to Section 554(5): Rule: Except where the contract says otherwise, the buyer is deemed to have title to the goods at the time they are transferred to the buyer. Application/Conclusion: Ownership vests in the buyer at the moment of transfer. Therefore, check when the transfer occurs under the contract (or under the default rules); that is when title passes to you.

instruction: Who bears the risk of loss if goods are damaged before I get them?
input:
Section no 555 . To bear risks : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the
contract, the seller shall bear the risk of any loss or damage to the goods until
such goods are transferred to the buyer.
output: According to Section 555(1): Rule: Unless contractually provided otherwise, the seller bears the risk of loss or damage to the goods until they are transferred to the buyer. Application/Conclusion: If goods are lost or damaged before transfer and your contract contains no different risk allocation, the seller must bear that loss. You would not be responsible until transfer has occurred.

instruction: I asked the seller to deliver goods to my shop; who bears the risk during delivery?
input:
Section no 555  part (3) : If the seller agrees to deliver the goods from the
place of purchase to the place specified by the buyer, the seller shall bear the
risk of any loss or damage to the goods, except as otherwise provided for in the
contract.
output: According to Section 555(3): Rule: If the seller agrees to deliver goods from their location to the place the buyer specifies, the seller bears the risk of loss or damage during that delivery, unless the contract says otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Since the seller agreed to deliver to your shop, the seller bears the risk while goods are in transit (unless your contract shifts that risk to you). You should hold the seller responsible for any loss or damage occurring before you receive the goods.

instruction: What if delivery is delayed because the buyer failed to pick up goods? Who is responsible for risk?
input:
Section no 555  part (2) : If the transfer of goods has been delayed due to
the fault of either the buyer or the seller, the party who has caused such delay
shall bear the risk of loss or damage under sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 555(2): Rule: When transfer is delayed due to the fault of either party, the party who caused the delay bears the risk of loss or damage. Application/Conclusion: If you (the buyer) caused the delay by not picking up goods, you bear the risk of loss or damage during the delay. Conversely, if the seller caused the delay, the seller bears that risk.

instruction: Am I allowed to examine the goods when delivery is tendered before accepting them?
input:
Section no 556 .
Right of buyer to ascertain goods : If the delivery
of the goods sold is tendered to the buyer, the buyer shall have a reasonable
opportunity to examine and ascertain whether or not the goods conform to the
contract and the buyer shall not be deemed to have been accepted the delivery
of the goods until the buyer so ascertains.
output: According to Section 556: Rule: When delivery is tendered, the buyer has a reasonable opportunity to examine and ascertain conformity, and is not deemed to have accepted delivery until the buyer does so. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to inspect the goods upon tender of delivery to see if they match the contract. Until you have examined and confirmed conformity (or failed to do so within a reasonable time), you are not treated as having accepted them.

instruction: If I or my agent physically receives the goods, does that count as acceptance?
input:
Section no 557  clause (a) : If the buyer or his or her agent receives the
goods,
output: According to Section 557(a): Rule: Acceptance is deemed to have occurred if the buyer or the buyer's agent receives the goods. Application/Conclusion: If you or your authorized agent takes delivery and receives the goods, the law treats that as acceptance. You may lose certain post-delivery rights unless other clauses apply (e.g., inspection rights).

instruction: Does signing a delivery slip mean I've accepted the goods?
input:
Section no 557  clause (b) : If a receipt or slip is issued having acknowledged
the delivery of the goods,
output: According to Section 557(b): Rule: If a receipt or slip is issued acknowledging delivery, the buyer is deemed to have accepted the goods. Application/Conclusion: Signing or issuing a delivery receipt that acknowledges delivery will normally be treated as acceptance. Avoid acknowledging delivery if you intend to reserve your right to reject goods until inspection, unless the contract allows it.

instruction: I examined the goods and then put them in my warehouse. Have I accepted them?
input:
Section no 557  clause (c) : If the buyer stores the goods having ascertained,
pursuant to Section 556, that the goods conform to the contract,
output: According to Section 557(c): Rule: If the buyer stores the goods after ascertaining (under Section 556) that they conform to the contract, the buyer is deemed to have accepted them. Application/Conclusion: Since you examined the goods, confirmed conformity, and then stored them, the law treats that conduct as acceptance. You would generally no longer be able to reject the goods after such acceptance.

instruction: The goods reached me but I didn't tell the seller I rejected them and I kept them. Am I considered to have accepted them?
input:
Section no 557  clause (d) : If the goods reach the buyer and the buyer does
not inform the seller within reasonable time that he or she has rejected the
goods and retains the goods with him or her.
output: According to Section 557(d): Rule: If goods reach the buyer and the buyer does not inform the seller within a reasonable time of rejection, and retains the goods, the buyer is deemed to have accepted them. Application/Conclusion: By keeping the goods without timely notifying the seller of rejection, you will be treated as having accepted them. If you intend to reject, you must communicate rejection within a reasonable time and not retain the goods.

instruction: I started using the machinery after delivery — does that count as acceptance?
input:
Section no 557  clause (e) : If the buyer does any act proving that he or she
has ownership in and control over such goods.
output: According to Section 557(e): Rule: If the buyer does any act proving ownership and control over the goods, the buyer is deemed to have accepted them. Application/Conclusion: Starting to use the machinery or otherwise acting in a way that shows ownership and control will be treated as acceptance. Such conduct may foreclose your ability to reject the goods later.

instruction: Our contract said goods must be delivered by June 1. What happens if seller doesn't deliver on time?
input:
Section no 558 . Time for delivery of goods : (1) If the contract provides
that goods have to be delivered at any specific time or within any specified
period, the seller shall deliver the goods to the buyer at that time or within
that period.
output: According to Section 558(1): Rule: If the contract specifies a delivery time or period, the seller must deliver at that time or within that period. Application/Conclusion: Because your contract sets June 1 as the delivery date, the seller is obliged to deliver by then. If the seller fails to deliver on time, they are in breach of that contractual obligation and you may pursue remedies under the contract or law.

instruction: The seller delivered earlier than the agreed date and I accepted. Is that valid delivery?
input:
Section no 558  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if the buyer accepts the goods delivered by the seller before or after the time
or period specified in the contract, the seller shall be deemed to have delivered
the goods.
output: According to Section 558(2): Rule: Even if delivery occurs before or after the specified contractual time, if the buyer accepts the goods, the seller is deemed to have delivered them. Application/Conclusion: Since you accepted the early delivery, the law treats the seller as having properly delivered. If you accepted, you generally cannot later complain that delivery timing breached the contract, unless other contract terms give you remedies for early/late delivery.

instruction: Can you point me to the exact section that says the buyer can examine goods before accepting?
input:
Section no 556 .
Right of buyer to ascertain goods : If the delivery
of the goods sold is tendered to the buyer, the buyer shall have a reasonable
opportunity to examine and ascertain whether or not the goods conform to the
contract and the buyer shall not be deemed to have been accepted the delivery
of the goods until the buyer so ascertains.
output: According to Section 556: Rule: The buyer has a reasonable opportunity to examine goods tendered for delivery and is not deemed to have accepted until they ascertain conformity. Application/Conclusion: The provision you asked about is Section 556. It gives the buyer the explicit right to inspect goods on tender and prevents automatic acceptance prior to that inspection.

instruction: I signed a delivery note and later found defects. Can I still reject the goods?
input:
Section no 557  clause (b) : If a receipt or slip is issued having acknowledged
the delivery of the goods,
output: According to Section 557(b): Rule: Issuance of a receipt or slip acknowledging delivery is one of the acts that deem the buyer to have accepted the goods. Application/Conclusion: By signing a delivery note that acknowledges delivery, you may be deemed to have accepted the goods and thus face limits on rejecting them later. You should check whether you signed under protest or whether other contract terms preserve inspection rights, but the statutory default is acceptance upon issuance of such acknowledgement.

instruction: Can I treat goods as satisfactory if they serve the particular purpose I bought them for?
input:
part (2) : If any goods sold or to be sold for any particular
purpose are fit for that purpose, the goods sold or to be sold shall be considered
to be of satisfactory quality.
output: According to Section 551(2): Rule: If goods sold (or to be sold) for any particular purpose are fit for that purpose, they shall be considered to be of satisfactory quality. Application/Conclusion: If you bought goods for a particular purpose and they perform that purpose, the law treats them as of satisfactory quality — so you generally cannot claim they are unsatisfactory on that ground alone.

instruction: I inspected a batch and knew about some defects before buying. Can I later claim the goods are of unsatisfactory quality?
input:
Section no 551  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(2), if the contract itself specifies any defects of such goods or if the buyer
has already knew such defects before the conclusion of the contract or while
inspecting the goods, such goods shall not be deemed to be of unsatisfactory
quality.
output: According to Section 551(3): Rule: Even if goods would otherwise be of unsatisfactory quality, they are not so deemed where the contract specifies the defects or the buyer knew of the defects before concluding the contract or while inspecting the goods. Application/Conclusion: Because you knew of the defects at inspection or before the contract, you cannot later successfully claim the goods are of unsatisfactory quality on that basis.

instruction: If our contract states a certain quality for the goods, what standard applies?
input:
Section no 551  part (4) : If the quality of any particular goods is specified
in the contract, the goods shall correspond to that quality, and if no 309 quality
is so specified, the goods shall be of the quality according to the prevalent
standards.
output: According to Section 551(4): Rule: Where the contract specifies the quality of particular goods, the goods must correspond to that specified quality; if no quality is specified, the goods must be of the quality according to prevalent standards. Application/Conclusion: Your seller must deliver goods matching the contractually specified quality. If the contract does not specify quality, the goods must meet prevailing market/industry standards.

instruction: Can the seller be taken to have warranted a particular quality unless the contract says so?
input:
Section no 551  part (5) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
the seller shall not be deemed to have warranted that the goods sold or to be
sold are of a particular quality.
output: According to Section 551(5): Rule: Except where the contract provides otherwise, the seller is not deemed to have warranted that the goods are of a particular quality. Application/Conclusion: Unless your contract expressly contains a warranty about a specific quality, the law will not imply such a warranty — so check the contract wording for any express quality warranty.

instruction: The seller delivered goods of a different quality than we agreed. What can I do — accept, reject, or partly accept?
input:
Section no 552 . Right to accept or reject goods of different quantity : (1) If the seller tenders to deliver to the buyer the goods of different quality
than that specified in the contract, the buyer has the right to accept and take
delivery of the goods in whole, to reject the whole or to accept any part and
reject the rest of the goods.
output: According to Section 552(1): Rule: Where goods tendered are of a different quality than specified, the buyer may (a) accept and take delivery of all, (b) reject all, or (c) accept part and reject the remainder. Application/Conclusion: You may choose any of those options — accept the entire delivery, reject it entirely, or accept some items and reject others — depending on what is reasonable for your situation.

instruction: I rejected part of a delivery. Can I ask the seller to replace or improve the goods?
input:
Section no 552  part (2) : If any goods are rejected in whole or in part
pursuant to sub-section (1), the buyer may give a notice to the seller to either
deliver other goods instead of such goods or where the quality of such goods
could be improved, to improve the quality of such goods.
output: According to Section 552(2): Rule: After rejecting goods in whole or in part under subsection (1), the buyer may notify the seller to either deliver other goods in their place or improve the quality where improvement is possible. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to notify the seller to replace the rejected goods with conforming goods or to fix/improve their quality if that is feasible.

instruction: If I give notice to replace defective goods, is the seller obligated to comply?
input:
Section no 552 part (3) : If a notice is given pursuant to sub-section (2), the
seller shall deliver the other goods instead of such goods or improve the quality
thereof, according to the notice given by the buyer or mutual understanding
reached between them.
output: According to Section 552(3): Rule: Where the buyer gives notice under subsection (2), the seller must either deliver replacement goods or improve the goods' quality as per the buyer's notice or mutual agreement. Application/Conclusion: Yes — once you notify the seller to replace or improve the goods, the seller is obliged to comply as specified in your notice or as agreed between you.

instruction: We made the purchase after inspecting a sample. Does that create any special rules?
input:
Section no 553 . Deemed to be contract for sale by sample : (1) If a
provision has been made in a contract to sell goods upon inspection of their
165
samples directly or indirectly a contract of sale of goods is deemed to be a
contract for the sale of goods upon inspecting sample.
output: According to Section 553(1): Rule: If the contract provides for sale upon inspection of samples (directly or indirectly), the contract is deemed to be a sale by sample. Application/Conclusion: Because you bought after inspecting a sample, the law treats the sale as a sale by sample, which brings into play the further protections and conditions applicable to sales by sample.

instruction: I bought bulk goods by sample. What conditions does the contract include by law?
input:
Section no 553  part (2) : If a contract is concluded for the sale of goods by
sample, the contract shall be deemed to contain the following conditions, except
as otherwise provided for in the contract: 310

Section no 553  part (2) (a) : The bulk of the goods shall correspond to the
sample in quality,

Section no 553  part (2) (b) : The buyer shall have a reasonable opportunity
of comparing the quality of the bulk of the goods with the sample,

Section no 553  part (2) (c) : The goods sold or to be sold shall be free from
any defect, and such goods appear to be of satisfactory quality, apparent on
comparing them with the sample.
output: According to Section 553(2) (and subparts a–c): Rule: A sale by sample is deemed to include (a) the bulk must correspond to the sample in quality; (b) the buyer must have a reasonable opportunity to compare the bulk with the sample; and (c) the goods must be free from defects and appear of satisfactory quality when compared with the sample. Application/Conclusion: When you purchase by sample, you are entitled to expect the bulk to match the sample, to be allowed to compare bulk with sample, and to receive defect-free goods that appear satisfactory by that comparison. If these conditions are not met, you have grounds to seek remedies.

instruction: Can the seller refuse responsibility because our contract said 'sold as is'?
input:
Section no 551  part (5) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
the seller shall not be deemed to have warranted that the goods sold or to be
sold are of a particular quality.
output: According to Section 551(5): Rule: Except where the contract otherwise provides, no implied warranty of particular quality is deemed to exist. Application/Conclusion: A contractual clause can affect implied warranties. If your contract explicitly disclaims a warranty of particular quality, the seller may not be taken to have warranted quality — so 'sold as is' or similar clauses can limit implied warranty claims unless the contract provides otherwise.

instruction: Short: If the seller gives me different goods, can I accept part and reject part?
input: Section no 552 . Right to accept or reject goods of different quantity : (1) If the seller tenders to deliver to the buyer the goods of different quality than that specified in the contract, the buyer has the right to accept and take delivery of the goods in whole, to reject the whole or to accept any part and reject the rest of the goods.
output: According to Section 552(1): Rule: Where delivered goods differ in quality from the contract, the buyer may accept all, reject all, or accept some and reject the rest. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you are explicitly allowed to accept part of the delivery and reject the remaining part.

instruction: I bought specific goods. When does ownership transfer according to the law?
input: Section no 554 . Provisions relating to transfer of ownership of goods : (1) If there is a contract for the sale of any specific or certain goods, the transfer of such goods shall be made as provided for in the contract, and failing such provision in the contract, the transfer shall be made according to the terms and conditions of the contract, intention of the parties, ascertained by having regard the conduct of the parties, and the relevant circumstances.
output: According to Section 554(1): Rule: For a contract to sell specific or certain goods, transfer of ownership occurs as provided in the contract; if the contract is silent, transfer is determined by the contract terms, the parties' intentions (ascertained from their conduct) and relevant circumstances. Application/Conclusion: Ownership of your specific goods will pass according to any express contractual provision. If none exists, the timing and circumstances of transfer are evaluated from the contract terms and the parties' conduct to determine when ownership passed.

instruction: Ram sold me goods after I inspected the sample but the delivered bulk differs. What does the law say I should have been able to do at purchase time?
input:
Section no 553  part (2) (b) : The buyer shall have a reasonable opportunity
of comparing the quality of the bulk of the goods with the sample,
output: According to Section 553(2)(b): Rule: In a sale by sample, the buyer must have a reasonable opportunity to compare the bulk with the sample. Application/Conclusion: You should have been given a fair chance to compare the delivered bulk with the sample before accepting. If you were not allowed a reasonable opportunity and the bulk differs, that supports your claim that the sale conditions were breached.

instruction: Do goods sold by sample have to be free from defects when compared to the sample?
input:
Section no 553  part (2) (c) : The goods sold or to be sold shall be free from
any defect, and such goods appear to be of satisfactory quality, apparent on
comparing them with the sample.
output: According to Section 553(2)(c): Rule: Goods sold by sample shall be free from any defect and shall appear of satisfactory quality when compared with the sample. Application/Conclusion: If the bulk shows defects or does not appear of satisfactory quality by comparison with the sample, you can treat that as a breach of the implied conditions of a sale by sample.

instruction: Seller points to a clause mentioning known defects in the contract. Can I still claim non-conformity?
input:
Section no 551  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(2), if the contract itself specifies any defects of such goods or if the buyer
has already knew such defects before the conclusion of the contract or while
inspecting the goods, such goods shall not be deemed to be of unsatisfactory
quality.
output: According to Section 551(3): Rule: If the contract specifies defects or the buyer knew of the defects before contracting or while inspecting, the goods are not deemed unsatisfactory. Application/Conclusion: If the contract expressly lists the defects or you knew about them at inspection, you generally cannot claim the goods are non-conforming on that basis.

instruction: I received goods of different quality and wrote to the seller asking for replacements. Do they have to follow my notice or can they propose something else?
input:
Section no 552 part (3) : If a notice is given pursuant to sub-section (2), the
seller shall deliver the other goods instead of such goods or improve the quality
thereof, according to the notice given by the buyer or mutual understanding
reached between them.
output: According to Section 552(3): Rule: After the buyer gives notice under subsection (2), the seller must deliver replacement goods or improve their quality according to the buyer's notice or a mutual understanding. Application/Conclusion: The seller is required to follow your notice (deliver replacements or improve quality) or otherwise act in accordance with a mutually agreed solution — they cannot ignore the notice and substitute an unrelated remedy unilaterally.

instruction: I'm confused: if the contract doesn't specify quality, what default applies?
input:
Section no 551  part (4) : If the quality of any particular goods is specified
in the contract, the goods shall correspond to that quality, and if no 309 quality
is so specified, the goods shall be of the quality according to the prevalent
standards.
output: According to Section 551(4): Rule: Where no particular quality is specified in the contract, the goods must be of quality according to prevalent standards. Application/Conclusion: If your contract is silent on quality, the goods must meet prevailing market or industry standards; failure to do so may give you remedies for non-conformity.

instruction: I bought by sample and the seller refuses to allow me to compare bulk with sample — what legal right do I have?
input:
Section no 553  part (2) (b) : The buyer shall have a reasonable opportunity
of comparing the quality of the bulk of the goods with the sample,
output: According to Section 553(2)(b): Rule: In a sale by sample, the buyer has a right to a reasonable opportunity to compare bulk with the sample. Application/Conclusion: You have a statutory right to compare; refusal to permit comparison undermines the sale-by-sample condition and supports a claim that the seller has not complied with the implied terms.

instruction: Can I contract to sell goods that I will only produce next season?
input:
part (3) : A contract may be concluded to sell the goods
owned or possessed by the seller for the time being or those to be produced or
acquired by the seller in the future.
output: According to Section 545(3): Rule: A contract may be concluded to sell goods that the seller owns or possesses now or those that the seller will produce or acquire in the future. Application/Conclusion: You can validly enter into a contract to sell goods you will produce later — such future goods can be the subject of a sale provided the contract does not state otherwise and the seller can obtain title as required when performance becomes due.

instruction: I signed to buy a particular batch but later found out they were already spoiled when we signed. Seller said he didn’t know. Is the contract valid?
input:
Section no 546 . Contract of sale of goods to be void : If a contract is
concluded to sell any specific type of goods, which have already become damaged
at the time of or before making of the contract, and the seller is not aware
about that at the time of making of the contract, the contract shall be void.
output: According to Section 546: Rule: If a contract is for a specific type of goods that were already damaged at or before the contract was made and the seller was unaware of that when making the contract, the contract is void. Application/Conclusion: Because the goods were already damaged when you contracted and the seller was unaware, the contract is void under Section 546 — you are not bound to accept or pay for those goods and should be able to rescind the sale.

instruction: What does 'specific type of goods' mean in this law? Explain simply.
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “specific type of goods” means the specific goods mentioned in the contract at the time of making of the contract.
output: According to Section 546 (Explanation): Rule: "Specific type of goods" means the particular goods actually named in the contract at the time it was made. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if the contract points to exact goods (e.g., a named batch, a particular consignment), those are "specific goods" for applying the rule that a sale is void if those exact goods were already damaged when the contract was made.

instruction: How is price fixed when the contract doesn’t say anything about price?
input:
Section no 547 . Determining price of goods : (1) Except as otherwise
provided for in the contract, the price of goods shall be determined in the manner
307 agreed upon in the contract under the terms and conditions of the contract,
or by the course of dealing between the parties.
output: According to Section 547(1): Rule: Absent a contrary contract term, the price is determined by the manner agreed in the contract or by the parties' prior course of dealing. Application/Conclusion: If your contract is silent, look to any agreed method elsewhere or how you and the seller have dealt with pricing before — that determines the price; if neither exists, other rules in Section 547 apply.

instruction: Seller told me price will be by weight. Can he charge for the packaging too?
input:
Section no 547  part (2) : If the price of goods is determined according to
their weight and measurement, the price of goods shall be determined on the
basis of the net weight and measurement of such goods, except as otherwise
provided for in the contract.
output: According to Section 547(2): Rule: When price is determined by weight or measurement, it is based on net weight/measurement unless the contract says otherwise. Application/Conclusion: The seller should not charge you for packaging or container weight — the price must be based on net weight unless your contract explicitly provides that gross weight (including packing) is used.

instruction: We have no pricing clause and no past dealings. How much must I pay?
input:
Section no 547  part (3) : If the price of goods cannot be determined under
sub section (1) or (2), the buyer shall pay the seller a reasonable price, taking
into account the relevant circumstances.
output: According to Section 547(3): Rule: If price cannot be determined under subsections (1) or (2), the buyer must pay a reasonable price considering relevant circumstances. Application/Conclusion: In your case, with no agreed method and no weight basis, you must pay a reasonable market-based price — what a sensible person would pay in those circumstances; evidence such as prevailing market rates will be relevant.

instruction: When exactly must the buyer pay — immediately on purchase or later on delivery?
input:
Section no 548 .Payment of price of goods : (1) Except as otherwise
provided for in the contract, the price of goods shall be paid as follows in any
of the following circumstances: Section no 548  clause (a) : The price of goods to be paid by the buyer to
the seller, at the time of the purchase of goods by the buyer, Section no 548  clause (b) : At the time of the transfer of the goods.
output: According to Section 548(1): Rule: Except where the contract provides otherwise, the price must be paid in the circumstances listed — either at the time of purchase or at the time of transfer of the goods. Application/Conclusion: If your contract does not change this, you must pay either when you purchase (if that applies) or when the goods are transferred — determine which circumstance applies to your transaction and pay accordingly.

instruction: Can I pay by cheque or online transfer, or must I pay physical cash?
input:
Section no 548  part (2) : While making payment of the price of goods
pursuant to sub-section (1), it shall be paid in cash.
Explanation: For the
purposes of this Section, the term “cash” includes a cheque, traveler’s cheque,
promissory note, bill of exchange, letter of credit, bank draft, credit card and
telegraphic transfer, payable through bank.
output: According to Section 548(2): Rule: Payment under subsection (1) must be paid in "cash," and "cash" expressly includes instruments like cheque, traveler’s cheque, promissory note, bill of exchange, letter of credit, bank draft, credit card and telegraphic transfer (through bank). Application/Conclusion: You may pay by cheque or bank transfer — physical currency is not the only acceptable form; the listed banking instruments and cards are valid.

instruction: If the contract names a particular brand, can the seller supply a different brand?
input:
Section no 549 . Description of goods : (1) If a contract specifies the name,
brand, trademark or specification of any goods to be sold, the contract shall be
deemed to have been concluded for the sale of the goods corresponding to that
name, brand, trademark or specification.
output: According to Section 549(1): Rule: Where the contract specifies the name, brand, trademark or specification, the sale is deemed to be of goods corresponding to that name/brand/trademark/specification. Application/Conclusion: The seller must supply goods matching the named brand/specification. Supplying a different brand would not meet the contract terms and you could insist on compliance or seek remedies.

instruction: I agreed on a sample and the brand in the contract. The bulk delivered looks like the sample but the brand label is different. What then?
input:
Section no 549  part (2) : If a contract specifies the name, brand, trademark
or specification and the sample of goods to be sold, the bulk of such goods shall
correspond not only to the sample but also to the name, brand, trademark or
specification specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 549(2): Rule: If contract specifies both a name/brand/trademark/specification and a sample, the bulk must correspond to both the sample and the specified name/brand/trademark/specification. Application/Conclusion: Because the bulk must match both the sample and the brand specified, delivery with a different brand label violates the contract; you can reject the goods or require the seller to supply the correct branded goods.
