instruction: I bought someone’s goods — how far does the law assume the seller actually owns them?
input:
Section no 550 . Condition as to title to goods to be sold : (1) Except
as otherwise provided for in the contract, it shall be deemed that, in the case
of a sale of goods, the seller has the title to the goods sold or, in the case of an
agreement to sell the goods in the future, the seller has or will have the title
to the goods to be sold, and that such goods are free from custody, control or
possession by any other person.
output: According to Section 550(1): Rule: Except as the contract provides otherwise, it is presumed that the seller has title to the goods sold (or will have title for future goods) and that the goods are free from custody or control of others. Application/Conclusion: The law assumes your seller owns and can sell the goods. If it turns out someone else had custody/control or superior title, that presumption may be rebutted, and you may have remedies against the seller for breach of this implied condition.

instruction: If an agreement to sell is made, does the seller automatically have a right to sell?
input:
Section no 550  part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
the seller shall be deemed to have the right to sell the goods sold or to be sold.
output: According to Section 550(2): Rule: Absent a contrary contract term, the seller is deemed to have the right to sell the goods sold or to be sold. Application/Conclusion: You can assume the seller has the legal right to sell; if it later appears the seller lacked that right, the seller may be liable for breach and you may seek remedies.

instruction: Do the goods have to be of any particular quality when I buy them?
input:
Section no 551 . Condition as to quality of goods : (1) Except as otherwise
provided for in the contract, the goods sold or to be sold shall be deemed to be
of satisfactory quality.
output: According to Section 551(1): Rule: Unless the contract provides otherwise, goods sold or to be sold are deemed to be of satisfactory quality. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to expect satisfactory quality by default; if the goods are defective or unsatisfactory contrary to that presumption, you may have grounds to reject them or claim remedies, unless your contract validly excludes that condition.

instruction: I agreed to pay when goods are transferred, but seller is demanding payment on purchase. Who’s right?
input:
Section no 548 .Payment of price of goods : (1) Except as otherwise
provided for in the contract, the price of goods shall be paid as follows in any
of the following circumstances: Section no 548  clause (a) : The price of goods to be paid by the buyer to
the seller, at the time of the purchase of goods by the buyer, Section no 548  clause (b) : At the time of the transfer of the goods.
output: According to Section 548(1): Rule: Absent a contrary contractual term, payment is required in the listed circumstances — at time of purchase or at time of transfer — depending which circumstance applies. Application/Conclusion: If your agreement specifies payment at transfer, Section 548 supports paying at transfer; the seller cannot insist on payment at purchase unless the contract or a relevant circumstance makes clause (a) applicable.

instruction: Seller weighed my grain with the sack on and charged me more. Can I dispute the bill?
input:
Section no 547  part (2) : If the price of goods is determined according to
their weight and measurement, the price of goods shall be determined on the
basis of the net weight and measurement of such goods, except as otherwise
provided for in the contract.
output: According to Section 547(2): Rule: When price is by weight/measurement, it must be based on net weight/measurement unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: You can dispute the extra charge for the sack; the seller should have charged on net weight. Unless your contract explicitly allowed charging for gross weight, you have grounds to demand correction or refund.

instruction: The contract named a particular consignment and yet the seller gave something else. Can I cancel?
input:
Section no 546 . Contract of sale of goods to be void : If a contract is
concluded to sell any specific type of goods, which have already become damaged
at the time of or before making of the contract, and the seller is not aware
about that at the time of making of the contract, the contract shall be void.
Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “specific type of goods”
means the specific goods mentioned in the contract at the time of making of the
contract.
output: According to Section 546: Rule: Contracts for specific goods that had become damaged at or before contracting (and of which the seller was unaware) are void; specific goods are those expressly mentioned in the contract. Application/Conclusion: If your contract specifically named a particular consignment and those exact goods are not as agreed (for example damaged or substituted), Section 546 and its explanation support voiding the contract when the specified goods are defective or not the contracted ones — you may rescind and seek return of payments.

instruction: Can I claim damages if the other party broke our contract?
input: Compensation for breach of contract : (1) In the case of breach of a contract under Section 535, the party aggrieved by it shall be entitled to recover from the party in breach of the contract damages for the actual loss or damage caused by the breach or such loss or 302 damage which the contracting parties knew when they made the contract to be likely result from the breach.
output: According to Section 537(1): Rule: The aggrieved party is entitled to recover damages for actual loss caused by the breach or for loss which the parties knew when making the contract to be a likely result of the breach. Application/Conclusion: If the other party breached, you may claim damages that compensate your real losses and losses that were foreseeable to both parties at contract formation; compile evidence of actual loss and any facts showing the loss was foreseeable.

instruction: We put a fixed sum for breach in the contract. Can I recover more than that amount from the breaching party?
input: Section no 537  part (2) : If the parties to a contract, in anticipation, at the time of its formation specify a sum in the contract, which becomes payable for breach of the contract, the aggrieved party shall be entitled to recover a reasonable amount not in excess of that sum from the other party, pursuant to sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 537(2): Rule: When a contract specifies a sum payable for breach, the aggrieved party may recover a reasonable amount but not an amount exceeding the agreed sum. Application/Conclusion: You cannot claim more than the stipulated sum; the recovery is limited to a reasonable amount up to that sum (subject to subsection (1)'s rules on actual/foreseeable loss).

instruction: My contract didn’t include a penalty clause. How much compensation can I claim if they breach?
input: Section no 537  part (3) : If the contract does not provide for compensation referred to in sub-section (2), the party claiming such compensation shall be entitled to recover a reasonable amount for the direct and actual loss or damage resulted from the breach of contract or for the breach of contract or for compensation. Provided that no compensation may be recovered for any indirect or remote loss or damage.
output: According to Section 537(3): Rule: Where no pre‑fixed sum exists, the claimant may recover a reasonable amount for direct and actual loss caused by the breach; indirect or remote losses are excluded. Application/Conclusion: You should claim reasonable compensation limited to losses that are direct and actual (not consequential or remote); document direct expenses or loss of value tied to the breach.

instruction: I already paid the contractual compensation because the work couldn't be finished in time — can I ask for more time to complete the job?
input: Section no 537  part (4) : If a contract, which is concluded for the completion of any act within a fixed period, contains a provision that compensation as referred to in sub-section (2) is payable if such an act cannot be completed 161 within that period, the party paying such compensation may request for the extension of the period for the completion of the contract in proportion to the amount of compensation paid by him or her.
output: According to Section 537(4): Rule: When a contract fixes compensation for failure to complete an act within a fixed period, the party who pays that compensation may request an extension of the completion period proportionate to the compensation paid. Application/Conclusion: Since you paid compensation under such a clause, you may request the other party (or the court) to extend the time to finish the work in proportion to what you paid.

instruction: If I accept the compensation stated in the contract, can the other party still sue me later?
input: Section no 537  part (5) : The right of a party to a contract to seek other legal remedies for the breach of a contract shall not be deemed adversely affected merely by the reason that the amount of compensation has been paid pursuant to this Section. 303
output: According to Section 537(5): Rule: Payment of compensation under this Section does not, by itself, prevent a party from seeking other legal remedies for breach. Application/Conclusion: Accepting or paying the stated compensation does not automatically bar additional legal actions; the party may still pursue other remedies if justified.

instruction: We mutually rescinded the contract after partial performance. Do I have to return what I received?
input: Section no 538 . Consequences of rescission or voidance of contract : (1) If, after a party to a contract has already received some cash or kind or any other benefit from the other party or after the fulfillment of the obligations under the contract partially, the contract is rescinded by mutual consent of the parties and the performance of the contract is not required under this Part or other law, the contract is voided or declared to be void according to law or the contract becomes invalid or is rescinded under this Part, such cash, kind or service so received shall be returned upon having settled the accounts of the cash or kind given until the date of the contract being in force.
output: According to Section 538(1): Rule: When a contract is rescinded or declared void after one party has received cash, goods or benefits (or partial performance has occurred), those received must be returned after settling accounts up to the date the contract was in force. Application/Conclusion: You are required to return the cash/goods/services you received, subject to accounting for values exchanged up to rescission; calculate and settle accounts, then restore the received items or their value.

instruction: I got services instead of money and the contract was rescinded. Do I have to pay anything back?
input: Section no 538  part (2) : If any service or advantage other than cash or kind has been given pursuant to sub-section (1), the party receiving such service or advantage shall pay a reasonable amount to the other party in consideration for such service or benefit.
output: According to Section 538(2): Rule: If a rescinded/void contract involved services or other advantages (not cash/goods), the recipient must pay a reasonable amount in consideration for that service/benefit. Application/Conclusion: You should pay a reasonable sum to the other party for the benefit you received (rather than returning cash/goods); assess the fair value of the service and settle accordingly.

instruction: They refuse to return money I gave after we rescinded the agreement. Can I recover legal costs for suing them to get it back?
input: Section no 538  part (3) : If it becomes necessary to institute legal action by the reason of failure to return the cash or kind or to pay the amount as referred to in sub-section (1), a reasonable expense incurred for that purpose may also be recovered.
output: According to Section 538(3): Rule: If legal action is necessary because the other party fails to return cash/goods or pay as required by subsection (1), reasonable expenses incurred to obtain recovery may also be recovered. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you must sue to recover what was not returned, you can also claim reasonable legal expenses incurred in that action; keep records of those costs.

instruction: The other party breached and we rescinded the contract. I already did some work — can I still get paid for that portion?
input: Section no 539 . Amount to be recovered in proportion to performed contract : (quantum meruit): If a contract is rescinded by the reason of its breach by any party or for any other reason, the aggrieved party may claim for the payment by the other party of amount under the contract in proportion to the work done or the performance of contract made by that party.
output: According to Section 539: Rule: When a contract is rescinded due to breach (or other reasons), the aggrieved party may claim payment in proportion to the work performed (quantum meruit). Application/Conclusion: You can claim payment for the portion of work you completed; calculate the reasonable proportion of the contract price corresponding to the performance rendered and seek that amount.

instruction: Ram promised to build my shop, I paid advance, he backed out and refuses to return the advance. What does the law say I can do?
input: Section no 538 . Consequences of rescission or voidance of contract : (1) If, after a party to a contract has already received some cash or kind or any other benefit from the other party or after the fulfillment of the obligations under the contract partially, the contract is rescinded by mutual consent of the parties and the performance of the contract is not required under this Part or other law, the contract is voided or declared to be void according to law or the contract becomes invalid or is rescinded under this Part, such cash, kind or service so received shall be returned upon having settled the accounts of the cash or kind given until the date of the contract being in force.
output: According to Section 538(1): Rule: When a contract is rescinded or declared void after one party has received cash, the received amount must be returned after settling accounts up to the date the contract was in force. Application/Conclusion: You can demand return of the advance; insist on settling accounts (deducting any legitimate value for services already rendered) and require the remaining cash be returned—if they refuse, you may pursue legal action to enforce this.

instruction: Can I claim compensation for lost future profits or remote damages after a breach?
input: Section no 537  part (3) : If the contract does not provide for compensation referred to in sub-section (2), the party claiming such compensation shall be entitled to recover a reasonable amount for the direct and actual loss or damage resulted from the breach of contract or for the breach of contract or for compensation. Provided that no compensation may be recovered for any indirect or remote loss or damage.
output: According to Section 537(3): Rule: Compensation is limited to direct and actual loss; indirect or remote losses (such as remote future profits) are not recoverable. Application/Conclusion: You cannot claim remote or speculative future profits; focus your claim on provable direct losses caused by the breach and provide supporting evidence.

instruction: I paid a penalty when I failed to finish on time. Does paying that penalty stop me from taking other legal steps later?
input: Section no 537  part (5) : The right of a party to a contract to seek other legal remedies for the breach of a contract shall not be deemed adversely affected merely by the reason that the amount of compensation has been paid pursuant to this Section. 303
output: According to Section 537(5): Rule: Payment of compensation under this Section does not, by itself, prevent the payer or payee from seeking other legal remedies. Application/Conclusion: Paying the penalty does not automatically bar you from pursuing additional remedies or defenses later; rights to other legal remedies remain available unless otherwise agreed or ordered.

instruction: If the contract set a liquidated sum but my actual loss is small, can the court award less than the fixed sum?
input: Section no 537  part (2) : If the parties to a contract, in anticipation, at the time of its formation specify a sum in the contract, which becomes payable for breach of the contract, the aggrieved party shall be entitled to recover a reasonable amount not in excess of that sum from the other party, pursuant to sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 537(2): Rule: The aggrieved party is entitled to recover a reasonable amount not exceeding the stipulated sum. Application/Conclusion: Yes — recovery is limited to a reasonable amount up to the fixed sum; if actual loss is smaller, the amount awarded may be less than the stipulated sum so long as it is reasonable under subsection (1).

instruction: If my contract was declared void and I received a non‑cash advantage, how is restitution handled?
input: Section no 538  part (2) : If any service or advantage other than cash or kind has been given pursuant to sub-section (1), the party receiving such service or advantage shall pay a reasonable amount to the other party in consideration for such service or benefit.
output: According to Section 538(2): Rule: For services or advantages (not cash/goods) received under a rescinded/void contract, the recipient must pay a reasonable amount to the other party. Application/Conclusion: Restitution is by paying a reasonable sum reflecting the value of the service or benefit you received; determine fair market value and compensate the counterparty accordingly.

instruction: What does 'quantum meruit' mean here — in plain language?
input: Section no 539 . Amount to be recovered in proportion to performed contract : (quantum meruit): If a contract is rescinded by the reason of its breach by any party or for any other reason, the aggrieved party may claim for the payment by the other party of amount under the contract in proportion to the work done or the performance of contract made by that party.
output: According to Section 539: Rule: When a contract is rescinded (for breach or other reasons), the aggrieved party may claim payment proportionate to the work actually done (quantum meruit). Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, quantum meruit lets you be paid fairly for the part of the job you completed even if the whole contract is cancelled—claim the share of the contract price that matches your performed work.

instruction: They paid me compensation under the contract — can I still seek other remedies like specific performance or damages?
input: Section no 537  part (5) : The right of a party to a contract to seek other legal remedies for the breach of a contract shall not be deemed adversely affected merely by the reason that the amount of compensation has been paid pursuant to this Section. 303
output: According to Section 537(5): Rule: Acceptance or payment of compensation under this Section does not automatically deprive a party of other legal remedies. Application/Conclusion: Yes — payment of compensation does not necessarily prevent you from pursuing other remedies (e.g., further damages or equitable relief) if legally justified; consult specifics since remedies may be affected by other facts or agreements.

instruction: If I must sue to get back goods after rescission, can I also recover my court costs from them?
input: Section no 538  part (3) : If it becomes necessary to institute legal action by the reason of failure to return the cash or kind or to pay the amount as referred to in sub-section (1), a reasonable expense incurred for that purpose may also be recovered.
output: According to Section 538(3): Rule: Reasonable expenses incurred to institute legal action for failure to return cash/goods or pay amounts due under subsection (1) may be recovered. Application/Conclusion: You may claim reasonable legal costs/expenses incurred in suing to recover the goods or money; keep receipts and records to support the claim for recovery of those expenses.

instruction: I performed half the job, the other side breached and declared contract void — can I demand half the contract price?
input: Section no 539 . Amount to be recovered in proportion to performed contract : (quantum meruit): If a contract is rescinded by the reason of its breach by any party or for any other reason, the aggrieved party may claim for the payment by the other party of amount under the contract in proportion to the work done or the performance of contract made by that party.
output: According to Section 539: Rule: On rescission for breach, the aggrieved party may claim payment proportionate to the work performed. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can claim the portion of the contract price commensurate with the work you completed (e.g., roughly half if half the work was done), subject to precise valuation of the performed work and any offsets for losses or benefits received.

instruction: Can I be considered the owner if the seller delivered the goods but didn't give me any ownership papers?
input: Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the goods are delivered but such basic documents as are related to the ownership of the goods or required for their use are not handed over, the ownership of the goods shall not be deemed to have been transferred.
output: According to Section 560... Rule: If the goods are delivered but the basic documents related to ownership or required for use are not handed over, ownership is not deemed to have been transferred. Application/Conclusion: Even though you have physical possession, you are not legally the owner until those ownership/use documents are handed over (unless your contract says otherwise).

instruction: Seller gave me fewer items than we agreed. Can I reject them?
input: If the seller delivers to the buyer a quantity of goods less than the quantity specified in the contract, the buyer may reject the goods. Provided that if the buyer accepts the goods even in such quantity, the buyer shall pay the price of that quantity at the rate specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 559(1)... Rule: When the seller delivers a quantity less than that specified, the buyer may reject the goods; if the buyer accepts the smaller quantity, they must pay for that accepted quantity at the contract rate. Application/Conclusion: You may lawfully reject the delivery. If you instead keep the fewer items, you will only owe the seller for the quantity you accepted at the agreed rate.

instruction: I accepted fewer goods because I needed them fast. Do I still have to pay full contract price?
input: If the seller delivers to the buyer a quantity of goods less than the quantity specified in the contract, the buyer may reject the goods. Provided that if the buyer accepts the goods even in such quantity, the buyer shall pay the price of that quantity at the rate specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 559(1)... Rule: Acceptance of a smaller quantity binds the buyer to pay only for that accepted quantity at the contract rate. Application/Conclusion: Since you accepted the lesser quantity, you must pay for those items only — not the full original contract quantity.

instruction: The seller sent me more goods than we agreed. Can I refuse the extra boxes?
input: If the seller delivers to the buyer a quantity of goods larger than the quantity specified in the contract, the buyer may accept the goods only in the quantity specified in the contract, and reject the rest or the whole quantity of goods. Provided that if the buyer accepts the whole quantity of goods so delivered, the buyer shall pay for the whole at the rate specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 559(2)... Rule: If the seller delivers more than the contract quantity, the buyer may accept only the contracted quantity and reject the surplus (or reject all). If the buyer accepts the entire excess delivery, they must pay for the whole amount at the contract rate. Application/Conclusion: You can lawfully keep only the agreed quantity and reject the extra boxes. If you keep everything, you'll be obliged to pay for all delivered items at the contract price.

instruction: I ended up keeping all the extra goods the seller sent. Do I owe for all of them?
input: If the seller delivers to the buyer a quantity of goods larger than the quantity specified in the contract, the buyer may accept the goods only in the quantity specified in the contract, and reject the rest or the whole quantity of goods. Provided that if the buyer accepts the whole quantity of goods so delivered, the buyer shall pay for the whole at the rate specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 559(2)... Rule: Accepting the entire larger delivery binds the buyer to pay for the whole quantity at the contract rate. Application/Conclusion: Yes — by accepting the whole excess delivery you are required to pay for all items at the agreed contract rate.

instruction: I received goods mixed with other items that aren't what I ordered. What are my options?
input: If the seller delivers to the buyer the goods mixed with goods of a description different than specified in the contract, the buyer may accept the goods specified in the contract and reject the rest or the goods in whole.
output: According to Section 559(3)... Rule: When delivered goods are mixed with differently described goods, the buyer may accept only the goods that match the contract and reject the rest or reject the entire delivery. Application/Conclusion: You can keep only the contract-compliant items and reject the mismatched goods, or reject everything if you prefer.

instruction: Am I forced to accept deliveries in installments if the seller wants to split shipments?
input: Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the buyer shall not be bound to accept the delivery of goods in installments.
output: According to Section 559(4)... Rule: Unless the contract provides otherwise, the buyer is not obligated to accept deliveries made in installments. Application/Conclusion: You are not required to accept split deliveries unless your contract expressly allows or requires installment delivery.

instruction: If I reject the delivery, do I have to send the goods back to the seller?
input: Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, if the buyer rejects the goods tendered by the seller for delivery, the buyer shall not be bound to return them to the seller. 314 Provided that the buyer shall give a notice of rejection, along with the reason for the same, to the seller through fastest means of communication.
output: According to Section 559(5)... Rule: Except where the contract says otherwise, a buyer who rejects goods is not obliged to return them; however, the buyer must notify the seller of the rejection and the reason by the fastest means of communication. Application/Conclusion: You don't have to ship the goods back, but you must promptly inform the seller of your rejection and why, using the quickest available communication.

instruction: How should I tell the seller I reject their delivery? Any special requirement?
input: Provided that the buyer shall give a notice of rejection, along with the reason for the same, to the seller through fastest means of communication.
output: According to Section 559(5)... Rule: The buyer must give notice of rejection and state the reason, and must do so by the fastest means of communication. Application/Conclusion: Inform the seller immediately (for example by phone, fax, email or instant messaging if appropriate) stating you reject the goods and why — prioritize the quickest available method so there's no dispute about timeliness.

instruction: The buyer refused to accept my goods after we contracted. Can I sue for compensation?
input: If the buyer does not accept or rejects the goods or refuses to pay the price of the goods after the making of a contract of the sale of goods, the seller may, subject to the contract, claim compensation from the buyer in consideration of the buyer’s failure to accept or refusal to accept the goods,
output: According to Section 561(a)... Rule: If a buyer refuses to accept goods or refuses to pay after a contract, the seller may (subject to the contract) claim compensation for the buyer's failure to accept. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you may claim compensation from the buyer, provided your contract and other legal requirements are met.

instruction: If a buyer refuses the goods but those goods are easily sold on the market, how is compensation calculated?
input: While determining compensation under clause (a), if the goods which the buyer has not accepted or has refused to accept are available in the market, compensation shall be determined on the basis of the difference between the price of the goods specified in the contract and the market or prevalent price of the goods,
output: According to Section 561(b)... Rule: Where a buyer refuses goods and those goods are available in the market, compensation is the difference between the contract price and the market/prevalent price. Application/Conclusion: If you can resell the goods in the market, compensation you can claim equals the contract price minus the market price (i.e., the loss due to the buyer's refusal).

instruction: The seller failed to deliver as promised. Can I get compensation?

output: According to Section 561(c)... Rule: If the seller fails or refuses to deliver as per contract, the buyer may claim compensation from the seller for that failure. Application/Conclusion: You can seek compensation from the seller for not delivering — pursue remedies provided by the contract and law for recovery.

instruction: If the seller fails to deliver but the goods can be bought on the market, how is my compensation worked out?

output: According to Section 561(d)... Rule: Where the seller fails to deliver and the goods are available in the market, compensation equals the difference between the contract price and the market/prevalent price. Application/Conclusion: Your compensation would be the extra cost you incur to buy replacement goods in the market — the contract price minus the market price (reflecting your loss).

instruction: Which section lists special rules about compensation when there's a breach in a sale contract?

Application/Conclusion: For questions about compensation when either party fails to perform a sale contract, you should refer to Section 561 and its clauses (a)–(d) because they prescribe how compensation claims and calculations should be handled.

instruction: Ram agreed to sell me machinery but then refused to deliver. What can I do?

instruction: When exactly does a surety's obligation arise?
input:
Section no 564  clause (a) : Obligation of the surety shall arise at the time
when the debtor fails to discharge the obligation to be discharged by him or her.
output: According to Section 564... Rule: The surety's obligation arises when the principal debtor fails to discharge the obligation. Application/Conclusion: The guarantor is not initially liable; their obligation begins only once the debtor defaults on the obligation.

instruction: Is a guarantor's obligation the same as the borrower's, or is it limited?

Application/Conclusion: A guarantor can be held to the same extent as the debtor and remains liable until the debtor's obligations are fully discharged.

instruction: If the principal debtor becomes free from the obligation by operation of law (e.g., insolvency), does that free the guarantor too?

instruction: Our loan had both mortgage security and a guarantee. Can the bank still pursue the guarantor for the whole debt?

instruction: Can the creditor immediately call the guarantor to pay once the debtor breaches?

instruction: My bank demanded payment from me (as guarantor) without notifying the borrower. Is that allowed?

instruction: What does the law mean by 'terms and conditions of guarantee' — can they be whatever the parties write?

instruction: Who counts as a 'creditor' under these guarantee provisions?

Application/Conclusion: The party entitled to the loan repayment or related benefit counts as creditor and may enforce the guarantee under these rules.

instruction: I worry the main borrower changed the contract terms later without telling me. Would that free me from my guarantee?

Application/Conclusion: If the borrower materially changes the agreement without your consent, you may be released from liability for subsequent transactions caused by that alteration.

instruction: Under which section is a contract of guarantee defined or deemed to be made?
input: Section no 563 . instruction: I signed as guarantor. If the borrower breaches, can the creditor straightaway sue me or do they need to follow any steps?

instruction: Can a guarantor be held liable for an obligation if the creditor already has security covering it?

instruction: A creditor is trying to make me pay even though the borrower was discharged in bankruptcy. Am I still on the hook?
input:

instruction: The bank claims both the security and my guarantee immediately. Which should they exhaust first?

instruction: A friend told me 'the guarantee becomes effective as soon as the borrower defaults.' Is that true?

instruction: Can I get someone to promise to save me from losses caused by their employees?
input:
Section no 571  part (1) : If
a contract is concluded by which one party to the contract promises to save the
other from loss or damage caused to him or her by the conduct of the promisor
himself or herself or by the conduct of any other person working under the
direction of such a party or loss or damage caused to such a party or third party
by his or her conduct, the contract shall deemed to be a contract of indemnity.
output: According to Section 571(1): Rule: A contract is a contract of indemnity when one party promises to save the other from loss or damage caused by the promisor's conduct or by any person working under the promisor's direction, or loss caused to a third party by their conduct. Application/Conclusion: If you and the other party sign a contract where they promise to protect you from losses caused by them or their employees acting under their direction, that agreement qualifies as a contract of indemnity and you would have the protections afforded by indemnity law.

instruction: Will my legal costs in defending a suit be recoverable under an indemnity?

instruction: If the person under whose direction someone acted did the act knowingly to cause loss, can indemnity protect that person?

output: According to Section 571(3): Rule: If a person acting under another's direction commits an act knowingly or recklessly with the intention of causing loss or damage, that person is personally liable despite any indemnity. Application/Conclusion: If the employee or agent intentionally or recklessly caused harm intending the loss, the agent/employee themselves (not just the indemnifier) can be held personally liable — the indemnity cannot shield them from personal liability in that scenario.

instruction: I paid compensation for loss caused to my property by a third party under an insurance-like contract. Can I recover that amount from the person who caused the loss?

output: According to Section 572(3): Rule: A person who pays compensation under the subrogation provisions is deemed subrogated to the rights of the person who suffered the loss and is entitled to recover the paid amount from the person who caused the loss. Application/Conclusion: Since you paid the compensation, you step into the victim's shoes and can pursue recovery of that amount from the third party who caused the loss.

instruction: Who should be paid when a contract specifies an indemnity amount for loss to property — me or my heir if I die?

Application/Conclusion: Payment under such a contract should be made to you if you live; if you have died, payment should go to your successor/heir.

instruction: If a contract says it is meant to recover loss from another person, must the payer recover from that other person?

irrespective of the person causing such loss or damage. 324 Provided that if a

output: According to Section 572(1): Rule: The person who concludes such a contract is liable for the loss regardless of who caused it; however, if the contract provides for recovery from another person, the loss shall be recovered from that other person. Application/Conclusion: If your contract expressly provides that loss be recovered from a specific other person, then the contract requires recovery from that other person; otherwise liability remains with the contracting party regardless of the actual wrongdoer.

instruction: Does subrogation mean I get the victim's rights after I pay compensation under the contract?

section (1), the person paying the amount or compensation referred to in sub-section (2) shall be deemed to have subrogated the person who has sustained

causing such loss or damage.

Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, after you pay the compensation, you acquire the victim's right to pursue the person who caused the loss to recover the amount you paid.

instruction: What's the practical effect of subrogator rights? Am I limited to what's written in the contract?

instruction: If I paid the injured person's claim, do I get their contractual rights under the indemnity?

Application/Conclusion: After you pay the injured person's claim and are subrogated, you acquire all the contractual rights that the injured party had under the contract — meaning you can enforce those contract rights to recover what you paid.

instruction: I took out a contract to cover possible business losses from third parties. Am I liable even if someone else caused the damage?

output: According to Section 572(1): Rule: The person concluding such a contract is liable for the loss irrespective of who actually caused it. Application/Conclusion: If you enter such a contract, you will be liable to cover the loss under the contract even if a third party was the actual cause — the contract places liability on the contracting party regardless of the wrongdoer.

instruction: If the indemnity contract doesn't specify an amount, what should I expect to be paid?

Application/Conclusion: When no specific indemnity sum is written in the contract, you are entitled to a reasonable compensation determined under the circumstances, payable promptly to you or your successor.

instruction: If the bank and borrower sign a new agreement that releases the borrower from the loan I guaranteed, am I freed as the surety?
input: Section no 565  clause (b) : If a contract is concluded to discharge the principal debtor from the obligation for which the guarantee was given,
output:
According to Section 565(b):
Rule: If a new contract is concluded that discharges the principal debtor from the obligation for which a guarantee was given, this is a ground affecting the surety's position.
Application/Conclusion: Here the bank and borrower have concluded a contract discharging the borrower; therefore, under Section 565(b) the surety’s obligation is affected — the surety would be discharged to the extent that the principal debtor’s obligation has been discharged by that contract.

instruction: The bank wrote off the loan last month. Does that release me from my guarantee?
input: Section no 565  clause (c) : If the principal debtor is discharged from the obligation by an act or action of the creditor or the loan is written off,
output:
According to Section 565(c):
Rule: If the principal debtor is discharged by an act of the creditor or the loan is written off, that affects the surety’s liability.
Application/Conclusion: Since the bank has written off the loan (an act of the creditor discharging the debtor), under Section 565(c) you are discharged to the extent the principal debtor’s obligation has been discharged by that write-off.

instruction: The creditor agreed to accept a smaller amount from the borrower and gave extra time for repayment. Does that free me from the guarantee?
input: Section no 565  clause (d) : If the creditor agrees to discharge the debtor from the liability by recovering a sum less than that is due or to give additional time for repaying the loan or not to institute a lawsuit,
output:
According to Section 565(d):
Rule: Where the creditor agrees to discharge the debtor by recovering less than due, giving additional time, or refraining from suing, this affects the surety’s liability.
Application/Conclusion: Because the creditor accepted less or granted more time, Section 565(d) applies and your liability as surety is reduced or discharged to the extent the creditor has altered the debtor’s obligation in those ways.

instruction: The creditor did something that stopped me from suing the principal debtor. Can that relieve me from my obligation as surety?
input: Section no 565  clause (e) : If any act or action by the creditor causes an adverse impact to the surety’s right to legal remedy against the principal debtor,
output:
According to Section 565(e):
Rule: If the creditor’s acts adversely impact the surety’s right to legal remedy against the principal debtor, that affects the surety’s obligation.
Application/Conclusion: Since the creditor’s conduct has impeded your ability to seek legal remedy against the principal debtor, Section 565(e) means your obligation can be affected — you may be discharged or relieved to the extent your remedy has been impaired.

instruction: The creditor returned the collateral back to the borrower and even damaged some security while holding it. Does that reduce my liability?
input: Section no 565  clause (f) : If the creditor loses, damages any security obtained by him or her from the principal debtor or returns it to the principal debtor, to the extent of the value of such security, 319
output:
According to Section 565(f):
Rule: If the creditor loses, damages, or returns security obtained from the principal debtor, the surety’s liability is reduced to the extent of the value of that security.
Application/Conclusion: Because the creditor returned or damaged the collateral, your liability as surety is reduced by the value of that security under Section 565(f).

instruction: The borrower has repaid part of the loan. How much of my guarantee remains?
input: Section no 565  clause (g) : To the extent to which the principal debtor has repaid the loan or discharged the obligation to the creditor according to the contract.
output:
According to Section 565(g):
Rule: The surety’s obligation is reduced to the extent the principal debtor has repaid the loan or discharged the obligation according to the contract.
Application/Conclusion: Since the borrower repaid part of the loan, your liability is correspondingly reduced to that extent under Section 565(g); you are only liable for the remaining unpaid portion.

instruction: The creditor didn't sue me or try to recover the debt for a very long time. Am I automatically discharged because of that delay?
input: Section no 565  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), the surety shall not be deemed to be in discharge of obligation, except as otherwise provided in the contract, merely because the creditor fails to institute legal action against the surety or attempt to recover the amount to be recovered by him or her in time.
output:
According to Section 565(2):
Rule: Mere failure by the creditor to institute legal action or attempt timely recovery does not by itself discharge the surety, except where the contract says otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: The creditor’s delay in suing you does not automatically discharge your guarantee; you remain liable unless the guarantee contract provides otherwise.

instruction: There are three co-sureties and the bank discharged one of them. Does that release the other two from their parts?
input: Section no 565  part (3) : If there are two or more sureties and the creditor discharges one co-surety from obligation, the other co-sureties shall not be discharged from their respective part of obligation.
output:
According to Section 565(3):
Rule: If a creditor discharges one co-surety, the other co-sureties are not discharged from their respective shares.
Application/Conclusion: The bank discharging one co-surety does not free the other two; they remain liable for their respective parts under Section 565(3).

instruction: My co-sureties and I guaranteed a loan and our obligations cannot be separated. The creditor discharged one co-surety — are we all still bound?
input: Section no 565  part (4) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (3), if the part of the co-sureties’ obligation cannot be separated, no co surety shall be deemed to be in discharge of his or her obligation even though the creditor has discharged him or her from the obligation.
output:
According to Section 565(4):
Rule: Where co-sureties’ obligations are inseparable, discharge of one co-surety does not discharge any other co-surety.
Application/Conclusion: Because your obligations are inseparable, the discharge of one co-surety does not free you — all co-sureties remain liable under Section 565(4).

instruction: A dispute has started between the creditor and the borrower over the loan. Does that automatically discharge me as surety?
input: Section no 565  part (5) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the surety shall not be in discharge of obligation under the contract of guarantee merely because there arises a dispute between the parties in relation to the contract creating the obligation for the discharge of which the contract of guarantee is made.
output:
According to Section 565(5):
Rule: A mere dispute between the parties about the underlying contract does not by itself discharge the surety, unless the guarantee contract provides otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: The existence of a dispute between creditor and borrower does not automatically free you; you remain bound as surety unless the guarantee contract says otherwise.

instruction: What responsibilities do I have toward the borrower as a surety? Can I be expected to make the debtor repay?
input: Section no 566 . Relation between the surety and the principal debtor : (1) The surety shall cause the principal debtor to repay the loan or discharge the obligation according to the contract. 320
output:
According to Section 566(1):
Rule: The surety must cause (i.e., procure or ensure) that the principal debtor repays the loan or discharges the obligation according to the contract.
Application/Conclusion: You have a positive duty to make the principal debtor repay or discharge the obligation; your role includes taking steps to ensure the debtor fulfills the contractual obligation under Section 566(1).

instruction: The borrower handed me a piece of land as security when I became surety. Can I mortgage or sell that land without his permission?
input: Section no 566  part (2) : If the principal debtor has given any property or security to the surety for the guarantee given by him or her while borrowing a loan or promising the obligation, the surety shall not pledge, mortgage, sell or otherwise transfer the title to such property or security without the consent of the principal debtor.
output:
According to Section 566(2):
Rule: Where the principal debtor gives property or security to the surety, the surety cannot pledge, mortgage, sell or transfer that property without the principal debtor’s consent.
Application/Conclusion: You may not sell, mortgage, pledge or otherwise transfer the land given by the borrower as security unless the borrower consents; doing so without consent would violate Section 566(2).

instruction: I guaranteed a loan that was to be used for buying equipment, but the creditor changed the loan’s purpose without telling me. Do I have to remain bound?
input: Section no 566  part (3) : If a guarantee is given for any loan or obligation borrowed or promised for any specific purpose, the object, nature or terms and conditions of that loan or obligation shall not be altered without the consent of the surety.
output:
According to Section 566(3):
Rule: If a guarantee is for a loan borrowed for a specific purpose, the object, nature or terms of that loan cannot be altered without the surety’s consent.
Application/Conclusion: Because your guarantee was for a specific purpose, the creditor cannot change the loan’s purpose or terms without your consent; you need not remain bound to obligations resulting from such unilateral alterations under Section 566(3).

instruction: Our guarantee contract says something different from the statute. Which provision governs our relationship — the contract or the section?
input: Section no 566  part (4) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, if the contract otherwise provides in relation to the surety and the principal debtor, such provision shall be applicable.
output:
According to Section 566(4):
Rule: If the contract provides otherwise in relation to the surety and the principal debtor, the contractual provision will apply even if it differs from other parts of this Section.
Application/Conclusion: The express terms of your contract with the creditor/principal debtor will govern your relationship where the contract provides differently; the contractual provision applies under Section 566(4).

instruction: Short and blunt: Can the creditor’s inaction in suing me after many months cancel my guarantee?
input: Section no 565  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), the surety shall not be deemed to be in discharge of obligation, except as otherwise provided in the contract, merely because the creditor fails to institute legal action against the surety or attempt to recover the amount to be recovered by him or her in time.
output:
According to Section 565(2):
Rule: Creditor’s mere failure to sue or attempt recovery in time does not by itself discharge the surety, except where the contract provides otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: No — mere inaction by the creditor does not cancel your guarantee; you remain liable unless the guarantee contract specifically says otherwise.

instruction: I am a co-surety. The creditor discharged one co-surety but kept the security that co-surety provided. Am I still liable for my share?
input: Section no 565  part (3) : If there are two or more sureties and the creditor discharges one co-surety from obligation, the other co-sureties shall not be discharged from their respective part of obligation.
output:
According to Section 565(3):
Rule: Discharging one co-surety does not discharge other co-sureties from their respective obligations.
Application/Conclusion: You remain liable for your share despite the creditor discharging the other co-surety; Section 565(3) keeps your obligation intact unless other conditions apply.

instruction: The creditor lost the collateral they were holding from the borrower. Will that affect what I owe as a guarantor?
input: Section no 565  clause (f) : If the creditor loses, damages any security obtained by him or her from the principal debtor or returns it to the principal debtor, to the extent of the value of such security, 319
output:
According to Section 565(f):
Rule: If the creditor loses, damages or returns security obtained from the principal debtor, the surety’s liability is reduced to the extent of the value of that security.
Application/Conclusion: Because the creditor lost the collateral, your liability is reduced by the value of that security under Section 565(f); you are liable only for the remainder after accounting for that value.

instruction: The borrower repaid part of the debt directly to the lender but the lender still demands full payment from me. Is that valid?
input: Section no 565  clause (g) : To the extent to which the principal debtor has repaid the loan or discharged the obligation to the creditor according to the contract.
output:
According to Section 565(g):
Rule: The surety’s obligation is reduced to the extent the principal debtor has repaid the loan or discharged the obligation according to the contract.
Application/Conclusion: The lender cannot demand the full amount from you for sums already repaid by the debtor; your liability is reduced by the amount the debtor has repaid under Section 565(g).

instruction: I guaranteed a loan only for a specific purchase. Later the lender changed the loan’s conditions without asking me. Do I have to accept the change?
input: Section no 566  part (3) : If a guarantee is given for any loan or obligation borrowed or promised for any specific purpose, the object, nature or terms and conditions of that loan or obligation shall not be altered without the consent of the surety.
output:
According to Section 566(3):
Rule: A guarantee for a loan taken for a specific purpose cannot have its object, nature or terms altered without the surety’s consent.
Application/Conclusion: You do not have to accept the altered terms if the loan’s purpose or terms were changed without your consent; such changes are not valid against you under Section 566(3).

instruction: I paid compensation to a person whose goods were damaged by my employee. Can I recover that money from the person who actually caused the damage?
input:

the person who has caused the loss or damage, or from the party to a contract
concluded in that respect, if any, the 325 amount or reasonable compensation
paid by him or her to the person who has suffered the loss or damage, as well
as the costs incurred in having recourse to legal remedies, if any.
output: According to Section 573(b): Rule: A subrogator who has paid compensation may recover from the person who caused the loss or damage (or from the relevant contracting party) the amount or reasonable compensation paid, plus costs of legal remedies. Application/Conclusion: Since you paid compensation to the injured person, you (as subrogator) can seek recovery from the person who actually caused the damage (or from any party to a relevant contract), including the compensation amount and legal costs.

instruction: How long do I have to file a lawsuit if I'm aggrieved by an action under this Chapter?
input:
Section no 574 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any
act done or action taken under this Chapter may file a lawsuit within two years
after the date of the accrual of the cause of action. 326 Chapter-8 Provisions
Relating to Contracts of Bailment
output: According to Section 574: Rule: A person aggrieved under this Chapter must file a lawsuit within two years from the date the cause of action accrued. Application/Conclusion: You have a two-year limitation period from when the cause of action arose to file your suit under this Chapter.

instruction: What exactly counts as a 'contract of bailment' in simple terms?
input:
Section no 575 . Contract of bailment : (1) If a person so delivers any goods
to another person that the goods shall be returned to him or her or handed over
or sold to any other person according his or her direction, a contract of bailment
shall be deemed to have been concluded.
Explanation: For the purposes of
this Chapter, the term “goods” means any movable property and right in such
property, other than currency in circulation.
output: According to Section 575(1): Rule: A contract of bailment exists when one person delivers goods to another with the understanding those goods will be returned, handed over, or sold per the deliverer's directions. 'Goods' means movable property or rights in such property (excluding currency in circulation). Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if you hand over movable property to someone to keep, return, or sell for you, that arrangement is a bailment under this Section.

instruction: Do I have to make a written deed if I bail property worth more than twenty-five thousand rupees?
input: Section no 575  part (2) : In concluding a contract pursuant to sub-section (1), a deed shall be executed while bailing any property the price of which exceeds twenty-five thousand rupees.
output: According to Section 575(2): Rule: When concluding a bailment under subsection (1), a deed must be executed if the property's price exceeds twenty-five thousand rupees. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if the property you bail has a value over Rs. 25,000, you are required to execute a deed for that bailment.

instruction: When is the bailment considered completed? Short answer.
input:
Section no 576 . Bailment deemed to be completed : (1) The process of
bailment shall be deemed to be completed once the bailee takes the delivery of
the goods under bailment.
output: According to Section 576(1): Rule: Bailment is deemed completed when the bailee takes delivery of the goods. Application/Conclusion: The moment the bailee receives the goods, the bailment process is considered complete.

instruction: I already had custody of certain items that belong to someone else. Does that count as bailment?
input:
Section no 576  part (2) : If any person or any one authorized by him or
her has already taken any goods in custody or possession, such goods shall be
deemed to have been held as bailment.
output: According to Section 576(2): Rule: If a person or an authorized person has already taken goods into custody or possession, those goods are deemed to be held as bailment. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you already have control or custody of goods belonging to another, the law treats that situation as a bailment.

instruction: I lent my scooter to someone. Do I need to tell them about a known engine fault that could cause an accident?
input:
Section no 577 . To disclose faults in goods bailed : (1) The bailor shall
disclose to the bailee any fault in the goods bailed of which the bailor is aware
and which interferes with the use of them or can cause any loss or damage to
the bailee or warrants separate provision or arrangement for their protection.
output: According to Section 577(1): Rule: The bailor must disclose to the bailee any faults in the bailed goods of which the bailor is aware that interfere with use or could cause loss or damage, or else arrange protections. Application/Conclusion: You must inform the person you lent the scooter to about the known engine fault (or provide separate protective arrangements), because failing to disclose such a fault that can cause harm violates this obligation.

instruction: I forgot to tell the bailee about a defect, but I didn't know about it. Am I liable if damage occurs?
input:
Section no 577  part (2) : If the bailor does not make such disclosure knowingly as required to be made pursuant to sub-section (1), to the bailee the 327
bailor shall be liable for any loss or damage arising from such goods or such
non-disclosure.
output: According to Section 577(2): Rule: If the bailor does not make the required disclosure knowingly under subsection (1), the bailor is liable for any loss or damage arising from the goods or such non-disclosure. Application/Conclusion: If you knowingly failed to disclose a fault, you are liable for resulting loss. If you truly did not know the fault, this clause still ties liability to a failure to make the required disclosure knowingly — meaning liability arises when nondisclosure was knowing; factual determination will matter in your case.

instruction: I hired out my lawn mower and didn't know it had a manufacturing defect. Am I responsible for damage to the hirer?
input:
Section no 577  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(2), if the goods are bailed for hire , the bailor shall be responsible for any loss or damage resulted from any faults in such goods even if the bailor was not aware
of the existence of such faults in such goods.
output: According to Section 577(3): Rule: When goods are bailed for hire, the bailor is responsible for any loss or damage from faults in the goods even if the bailor was not aware of those faults. Application/Conclusion: Because you bailed the lawn mower for hire, you are liable for damage caused by its defect even if you didn’t know about the defect.

instruction: What standard of care is expected from the bailee?
input:
Section no 578 . Obligations of bailee : (1) The bailee shall, take care of
(herbichar) and protect the goods bailed to him or her in accordance with the
terms and conditions specified in the contract and, reasonable care of goods, as
his or her own in the absence of such terms and conditions.
output: According to Section 578(1): Rule: The bailee must take care of and protect bailed goods according to the contractual terms, or otherwise exercise reasonable care as if the goods were their own. Application/Conclusion: The bailee must follow any contract terms; if none exist, they must take reasonable care. If the bailee fails to meet this standard, they can be held liable for resulting loss.

instruction: A storm destroyed goods I was keeping despite my reasonable care. Am I liable to the owner?
input:
Section no 578  part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
if any goods bailed are lost, stolen, damaged, depreciated, deteriorated or destroyed because of a disaster in spite of the reasonable care and protection
pursuant to sub-section (1), the bailee shall not be liable to return such goods.
output: According to Section 578(2): Rule: Except as the contract provides otherwise, if goods are lost/stolen/damaged/etc. due to a disaster despite the bailee exercising reasonable care under subsection (1), the bailee is not liable to return such goods. Application/Conclusion: Since the goods were destroyed by a storm (a disaster) despite your reasonable care, you are not liable to return or compensate for those goods unless the contract states otherwise.

instruction: If the bailee was reckless and the goods were stolen, what can the owner demand?
input:
Section no 578  part (2) : Provided that if the goods are lost, stolen, damaged, depreciated, deteriorated or destroyed because of recklessness or mala fide intention of the bailee or of his
174
or her failure to take care of or protect the goods according to the terms and
conditions of the contract, the bailee shall be liable to return the goods or pay
an amount equivalent to the price thereof to the bailor.
output: According to Section 578(2) (proviso): Rule: If goods are lost/stolen/damaged due to the bailee's recklessness, mala fide intention, or failure to take care per the contract, the bailee must return the goods or pay an amount equivalent to their price to the bailor. Application/Conclusion: Because the bailee acted recklessly and the goods were stolen as a result, the owner can require the bailee to return the goods or compensate the owner by paying the goods’ price.

instruction: Can I sue someone for my costs if I paid compensation to an injured person and had to go to court?
input:
clause (b) : The subrogator under clause (a) may recover from
the person who has caused the loss or damage, or from the party to a contract
concluded in that respect, if any, the 325 amount or reasonable compensation
paid by him or her to the person who has suffered the loss or damage, as well
as the costs incurred in having recourse to legal remedies, if any.
output: According to Section 573(b): Rule: A subrogator may recover the compensation paid and also the costs incurred in pursuing legal remedies from the person who caused the loss or the relevant contracting party. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you acted as a subrogator (paid compensation to the injured party), you may recover both the compensation amount and the legal costs from the person who caused the damage or from a relevant contracting party.

instruction: I discovered the problem only last week but damage happened three years ago — can I still file under this Chapter?
input:
Section no 574 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any
act done or action taken under this Chapter may file a lawsuit within two years
after the date of the accrual of the cause of action. 326 Chapter-8 Provisions
Relating to Contracts of Bailment
output: According to Section 574: Rule: The limitation period is two years from the date the cause of action accrued. Application/Conclusion: If the damage occurred three years ago and the cause of action accrued at that time, you are outside the two-year limitation period and generally cannot file now; exceptions would depend on whether accrual was delayed for legal reasons, but under this Section the basic deadline is two years.

instruction: If I hand goods to someone to sell on my instructions, is that a bailment?
input:
Section no 575 . Contract of bailment : (1) If a person so delivers any goods
to another person that the goods shall be returned to him or her or handed over
or sold to any other person according his or her direction, a contract of bailment
shall be deemed to have been concluded.
output: According to Section 575(1): Rule: Delivering goods to another so that they will be returned, handed over, or sold according to the deliverer's direction constitutes a bailment. Application/Conclusion: Yes — giving goods to someone to sell on your directions qualifies as a bailment under this Section.

instruction: Do I have to execute a deed if the price is exactly twenty-five thousand rupees?
input:
Section no 575  part (2) : In concluding a contract pursuant to sub-section (1), a deed shall be executed while bailing any property the price of which exceeds
twenty-five thousand rupees.
output: According to Section 575(2): Rule: A deed is required when bailing property whose price exceeds twenty-five thousand rupees. Application/Conclusion: No — the obligation to execute a deed applies only where the property's price exceeds Rs. 25,000. If the price is exactly Rs. 25,000, this clause does not mandate a deed.

instruction: Someone authorized on my behalf already took possession of goods. Is that treated as bailment even if I didn't hand them over personally?
input:
Section no 576  part (2) : If any person or any one authorized by him or
her has already taken any goods in custody or possession, such goods shall be
deemed to have been held as bailment.
output: According to Section 576(2): Rule: Goods taken into custody or possession by a person or someone authorized by them are deemed to be held as bailment. Application/Conclusion: Yes — possession by an authorized person counts as bailment; the law treats those goods as bailed even if you did not deliver them personally.

instruction: A bailee followed the contract terms but goods got ruined in an earthquake. Can the bailee be forced to pay?
input:
Section no 578  part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract,
if any goods bailed are lost, stolen, damaged, depreciated, deteriorated or destroyed because of a disaster in spite of the reasonable care and protection
pursuant to sub-section (1), the bailee shall not be liable to return such goods.
output: According to Section 578(2): Rule: If goods are destroyed by a disaster despite the bailee's reasonable care, the bailee is not liable to return such goods, unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Since the destruction was due to an earthquake (a disaster) and the bailee exercised reasonable care per the contract, the bailee cannot be forced to pay or return the goods under this Section, unless the contract states a different responsibility.

instruction: If a bailee fails to follow the contract and goods deteriorate, what can the bailor demand?
input:
Section no 578  part (2) : Provided that if the goods are lost, stolen, damaged, depreciated, deteriorated or destroyed because of recklessness or mala fide intention of the bailee or of his
