or her failure to take care of or protect the goods according to the terms and
conditions of the contract, the bailee shall be liable to return the goods or pay
an amount equivalent to the price thereof to the bailor.
output: According to Section 578(2) (proviso): Rule: If loss/damage/deterioration results from the bailee’s recklessness, mala fide intention, or failure to take care per contract, the bailee must return the goods or pay their price to the bailor. Application/Conclusion: If the bailee did not follow contractual care obligations and the goods deteriorated as a result, you (the bailor) can demand return of the goods or monetary compensation equal to their price.

instruction: I paid my creditor as a surety. Can I now sue the principal debtor to get my money back?
input: . Surety to substitute creditor : (1) After the surety has, on behalf of the principal debtor, repaid the loan to be repaid or discharged the obligation to be discharged to the creditor under the contract, the surety shall substitute the creditor in relation to such loan or obligation, and, as the creditor, be entitled to recover the loan from, or institute legal action against, the principal debtor.
output: According to Section 567(1): Rule: Once a surety has repaid the loan or discharged the obligation on behalf of the principal debtor, the surety substitutes the creditor and acquires the creditor's rights. Application/Conclusion: Since you repaid the creditor as surety, you step into the creditor's position and are entitled to recover the loan from the principal debtor or to institute legal action against them.

instruction: If I paid off the debt as a guarantor, is the principal debtor obliged to reimburse me including interest or other charges?
input: Section no 567  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, the principal debtor shall pay to the surety the sum of loan repaid by the surety or all amounts in consideration for the obligation performed by the surety on behalf of the principal debtor, as well as interest or any other fee or amount chargeable thereon.
output: According to Section 567(2): Rule: The principal debtor must repay the surety the sum the surety paid or amounts paid for the debtor's obligation, including interest and any other applicable fees. Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to reimbursement from the principal debtor for the loan amount you repaid and for interest or other fees chargeable on that amount.

instruction: I had to sue the debtor because they defaulted after I paid. Can I recover my legal costs from them?
input: Section no 567  part (3) : If it becomes necessary to institute legal action because of the default of the principal debtor to pay the amount payable by 321 him or her under sub-section (2) or if any other expenses need to be incurred in this regard, the surety shall be entitled to recover also such expenses from the principal debtor.
output: According to Section 567(3): Rule: If legal action or other expenses are necessary because the principal debtor defaults on amounts payable under subsection (2), the surety may recover those expenses from the principal debtor. Application/Conclusion: You can claim the legal costs and related expenses you incurred in suing the debtor from the principal debtor.

instruction: The creditor lied to me about the transaction to make me sign as surety. Can I void the guarantee?
input: Section no 568  clause (a) : If the guarantee is obtained by the creditor or by any other person with his or her consent by supplying misleading or false notice or information to the surety about the matter of the transaction for which the guarantee is given,
output: According to Section 568(a): Rule: A surety may have the guarantee voided if it was obtained by supplying misleading or false information about the transaction. Application/Conclusion: Because the creditor obtained your guarantee by misleading or false statements, you may seek to have the contract of guarantee voided.

instruction: The creditor hid material facts when getting my guarantee. Does that allow me to cancel the guarantee?
input: Section no 568  clause (b) : If the matter of guarantee, property or fact is concealed or not disclosed,
output: According to Section 568(b): Rule: The surety can void the guarantee if a matter of the guarantee, property or fact was concealed or not disclosed. Application/Conclusion: If important facts were concealed from you when you gave the guarantee, you may have the contract of guarantee voided.

instruction: I agreed to guarantee subject to a friend also becoming surety, but that friend never consented. Can I void the contract?
input: Section no 568  clause (c) : If the contract is concluded on the condition that a third person will also become the surety but the third person does not consent to give the guarantee.
output: According to Section 568(c): Rule: Where a guarantee was concluded on the condition that a third person would also become surety but that third person did not consent, the surety may have the guarantee voided. Application/Conclusion: Since the third person never consented, you can seek to void the contract of guarantee.

instruction: There are two of us as co-sureties and the debtor defaulted. Do we both pay everything or split equally?
input: Section no 569 . Obligation of sureties to be equal : (1) If two or more persons give the guarantee jointly or severally for any loan or obligation and the principal debtor fails to repay the loan or discharge the obligation, the cosureties shall repay the loan or discharge the obligation or perform the contract on an equal basis, except as otherwise provided for in the contract.
output: According to Section 569(1): Rule: When two or more persons guarantee jointly or severally, they are required to repay or discharge the obligation on an equal basis unless the contract states otherwise. Application/Conclusion: You and the other co-surety must share the liability equally, unless your guarantee contract specifies a different arrangement.

instruction: Me and two others guaranteed different portions of a loan. Am I liable for the whole loan if debtor defaults?
input: Section no 569  part (2) : If, while giving the guarantee jointly pursuant to sub section (1), the co-sureties guarantee different parts, every surety 322 shall be liable to pay or bear the obligation only to the extent of the respective part guaranteed by him or her.
output: According to Section 569(2): Rule: If co-sureties guarantee different parts, each surety is liable only for the part they specifically guaranteed. Application/Conclusion: You are responsible only for the percentage/part you guaranteed, not for the whole loan.

instruction: What does 'continuous guarantee' mean in simple words?
input: Section no 570 . Continuous guarantee : (1) A guarantee which is so given as to extend to a series of transactions shall be deemed to be a continuous guarantee.
output: According to Section 570(1): Rule: A guarantee that covers a series of transactions is called a continuous guarantee. Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, if your guarantee applies to multiple deals over time (not just one loan), it's a continuous guarantee.

instruction: If my guarantee covers many transactions, how much can I be held liable for in total?
input: Section no 570  part (2) : If the provision of a guarantee referred to in sub section (1) is made, the surety shall be liable to the extent of the amount of guarantee that could not be recovered in the entire period of the contract of guarantee irrespective of the number of transactions made thereunder.
output: According to Section 570(2): Rule: For a continuous guarantee, the surety's liability is measured by the amount that cannot be recovered during the entire period of the guarantee, regardless of how many transactions occurred. Application/Conclusion: Your total liability equals the unrecovered guarantee amount across the whole guarantee term; it is not reset or limited per individual transaction.

instruction: I want to stop being liable for future transactions under a continuous guarantee — how and how long before it stops?
input: Section no 570  part (3) : The surety may, by giving a notice to the creditor at least three months in advance, revoke the continuous guarantee as to the future transactions.
output: According to Section 570(3): Rule: The surety can revoke a continuous guarantee for future transactions by giving the creditor at least three months' advance notice. Application/Conclusion: To stop future liability, serve a written notice to the creditor and allow a minimum three months before the revocation takes effect.

instruction: If I die, does my continuous guarantee keep binding my estate or is it automatically cancelled?
input: Section no 570  part (4) : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, if the surety dies, the continuous guarantee shall be deemed to be ipso facto revoked.
output: According to Section 570(4): Rule: Unless the contract specifies otherwise, a continuous guarantee is ipso facto revoked on the surety's death. Application/Conclusion: If you die, the continuous guarantee will automatically cease to operate (unless the guarantee contract explicitly states a different outcome).

instruction: I repaid a loan and was told I 'substitute the creditor' — what does that legally mean for my ability to collect?
input: . Surety to substitute creditor : (1) After the surety has, on behalf of the principal debtor, repaid the loan to be repaid or discharged the obligation to be discharged to the creditor under the contract, the surety shall substitute the creditor in relation to such loan or obligation, and, as the creditor, be entitled to recover the loan from, or institute legal action against, the principal debtor.
output: According to Section 567(1): Rule: A surety who pays or discharges the debtor's obligation substitutes the creditor and acquires the creditor's rights regarding that loan or obligation. Application/Conclusion: Substituting the creditor means you now hold the creditor's position and can demand repayment from the principal debtor or commence legal proceedings to recover the amount.

instruction: After covering the debtor's debt, can I charge them for interest and fees when I demand reimbursement?
input: Section no 567  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, the principal debtor shall pay to the surety the sum of loan repaid by the surety or all amounts in consideration for the obligation performed by the surety on behalf of the principal debtor, as well as interest or any other fee or amount chargeable thereon.
output: According to Section 567(2): Rule: The principal debtor must pay the surety the repaid sum and any interest or other fees chargeable on it. Application/Conclusion: Yes — when you demand reimbursement from the principal debtor you may include the amount you repaid plus interest and other applicable fees.

instruction: Which section says I can recover expenses incurred to enforce repayment after the debtor defaults?
input: Section no 567  part (3) : If it becomes necessary to institute legal action because of the default of the principal debtor to pay the amount payable by 321 him or her under sub-section (2) or if any other expenses need to be incurred in this regard, the surety shall be entitled to recover also such expenses from the principal debtor.
output: According to Section 567(3): Rule: The surety may recover expenses incurred for instituting legal action or other necessary expenses caused by the principal debtor's default under subsection (2). Application/Conclusion: Section 567(3) specifically permits you to claim those enforcement or litigation expenses from the principal debtor.

instruction: Two of us guaranteed jointly and I ended up paying more than my share. Can I force the other co-surety to contribute equally?
input: Section no 569 . Obligation of sureties to be equal : (1) If two or more persons give the guarantee jointly or severally for any loan or obligation and the principal debtor fails to repay the loan or discharge the obligation, the cosureties shall repay the loan or discharge the obligation or perform the contract on an equal basis, except as otherwise provided for in the contract.
output: According to Section 569(1): Rule: Co-sureties who gave guarantee jointly are liable to repay or perform on an equal basis unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: You can seek contribution from the other co-surety so that the total burden is shared equally, unless your guarantee agreement states a different split.

instruction: My guarantee covered many credit transactions over time. The bank says I'm liable for each; is there a cap per transaction?
input: Section no 570  part (2) : If the provision of a guarantee referred to in sub section (1) is made, the surety shall be liable to the extent of the amount of guarantee that could not be recovered in the entire period of the contract of guarantee irrespective of the number of transactions made thereunder.
output: According to Section 570(2): Rule: For a continuous guarantee covering many transactions, the surety's liability is measured by the unrecovered guarantee amount over the entire guarantee period and is not reset per transaction. Application/Conclusion: There is no per-transaction cap under this provision; your liability is tied to the total unrecovered amount across the whole contract period, not separately for each transaction.

instruction: Can I sell goods that I only partially own if they are pledged as collateral?
input:
Section no 588  part (3) : If the pledger has a partial or limited title to, or
ownership of, the goods pledged as the collateral or deposit, the 334 pledgee
also shall have right and title to such goods to that extent only.
output: According to Section 588(3)... Rule: If the pledger has only partial or limited title or ownership in goods pledged as collateral, the pledgee's right and title extend only to that same limited extent. Application/Conclusion: If you only partially own the goods, you may not freely sell the full interest; the pledgee retains rights up to the extent of your partial ownership, so any sale must respect the pledgee's limited right in the pledged portion.

instruction: I pledged my motorcycle to two lenders and it's not enough to pay both. How will they share the motorcycle's value?
input:
Section no 589 . Creditors to be on equal footing ( pari pasu) : (1) If a
person has borrowed debt from two or more creditors at a time or several times
by pledging any of his or her goods as a collateral and the goods so pledged
as the collateral are not suﬀicient to pay the debt of all the creditors, except
as otherwise provided for in the contract, all the creditors who have taken the
goods as collateral shall be deemed to be in pari pasu in respect of the debt
outstanding and shall have the right to make a proportionate claim on the
goods accordingly.
output: According to Section 589(1)... Rule: When multiple creditors hold the same pledged goods and the collateral can't satisfy all debts, those creditors are deemed pari passu and may proportionately claim the goods. Application/Conclusion: Your two lenders will be treated equally and can claim a proportionate share of the motorcycle's value relative to their outstanding debts, unless your contract explicitly provides otherwise.

instruction: Can I sign a contract that gives one creditor future priority over other creditors on goods already pledged?
input:
Section no 589  part (2) : A contract entered into giving priority right in
the future to a creditor on the goods already pledged as collateral pursuant to
sub-section (1) shall be void. If a creditor has already recovered his or her debt
from such a collateral before the contract becomes void in spite of knowing that
there are also other creditors in respect of the security, such a creditor shall
return the amount to other creditors and recover his or her debt from other
assets of the pledger.
output: According to Section 589(2)... Rule: Any contract granting future priority to one creditor over others regarding goods already pledged under subsection (1) is void. Application/Conclusion: You cannot validly create a later contract that gives one creditor ahead-of-others priority on already-pledged goods; such a clause will be void and cannot override the pari pasu position of existing creditors.

instruction: If a creditor knew there were other creditors but still recovered the whole debt from the collateral, do they have to return money?
input:
Section no 589  part (2) : A contract entered into giving priority right in
the future to a creditor on the goods already pledged as collateral pursuant to
sub-section (1) shall be void. If a creditor has already recovered his or her debt
from such a collateral before the contract becomes void in spite of knowing that
there are also other creditors in respect of the security, such a creditor shall
return the amount to other creditors and recover his or her debt from other
assets of the pledger.
output: According to Section 589(2)... Rule: A creditor who recovers debt from collateral while knowing other creditors exist must return the recovered amount to those other creditors and seek recovery from the pledger's other assets. Application/Conclusion: If the creditor took the full amount from the collateral despite knowledge of co-creditors, they are required to reimburse the other creditors their share and then pursue the pledger's other assets for any remaining balance.

instruction: I discovered today's that an act under this Chapter harmed me. How long do I have to sue?
input:
Section no 590 . Statute of limitation : A person
who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make
a lawsuit within two years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action.
output: According to Section 590... Rule: A person aggrieved by acts under this Chapter must initiate a lawsuit within two years from the date the cause of action accrued. Application/Conclusion: You generally have two years from the date you became entitled to sue (the accrual date) to file a lawsuit under this Chapter; act promptly to avoid losing your right to litigate.

instruction: Can I appoint someone to act for me in business transactions?
input:
Section no 591 . Contract of agency deemed to be made : Any person
may appoint any other person as his or her agent to do any act on his or her
behalf, except on the matter of his or her personal ability, to conduct business
as his or her agent or carry on any transaction with a third person on his or her
behalf or to represent him or her to such a person or to establish any type of
legal relation with the person appointing an agent (the principal) and a third
person, and if an agent is so appointed, a contract of agency shall be deemed to
have been concluded.
output: According to Section 591... Rule: Any person may appoint another as their agent to perform acts, conduct business, enter transactions, or establish legal relations with third parties on their behalf, except for matters requiring the principal's personal ability; such appointment creates a contract of agency. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you can appoint an agent to carry out business and legal transactions for you, but not for acts that must be performed in your personal capacity; upon appointment, an agency contract is considered concluded.

instruction: What does it mean that a transaction through my agent is recognized as mine?
input: Section no 592  part (2) : A contract concluded through an agent appointed pursuant to Section 591 or act done by the agent shall be deemed to have been carried out by the concerned person and the obligation arising out of such an act shall be performed as if the contract were concluded or act done by the principal. Provided that if the agent has done any act beyond his or her authority, the principal shall not be liable for such an act other than that accepted by him or her.
output: According to Section 592(2)... Rule: Contracts or acts done through a properly appointed agent are treated as carried out by the principal, and resulting obligations bind the principal; however, the principal is not liable for acts beyond the agent's authority except for those acts the principal accepts. Application/Conclusion: If your agent lawfully concludes a contract for you, you are bound by it as if you did it yourself. But if the agent exceeded authority, you will only be liable for those excess acts if you expressly or implicitly accept them.

instruction: My agent went beyond what I allowed. Am I automatically responsible?
input: Section no 592  part (2) : A contract concluded through an agent appointed pursuant to Section 591 or act done by the agent shall be deemed to have been carried out by the concerned person and the obligation arising out of such an act shall be performed as if the contract were concluded or act done by the principal. Provided that if the agent has done any act beyond his or her authority, the principal shall not be liable for such an act other than that accepted by him or her.
output: According to Section 592(2)... Rule: The principal is not liable for acts the agent performs beyond authority, except for those acts the principal accepts. Application/Conclusion: You are not automatically responsible for unauthorized acts of your agent; you become liable only if you accept (expressly or implicitly) those acts.

instruction: Some acts my agent did were within authority and some were not. Am I liable for any part?
input:
Section no 592  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if, out of the acts done beyond authority, some acts are within his or her authority and some are beyond it and the part done within his or her authority can be separated, the principal shall be liable to the extent of the acts done within authority.
output: According to Section 592(3)... Rule: If acts done include separable parts within and beyond the agent's authority, the principal is liable to the extent of the acts that were within authority. Application/Conclusion: You will be liable for those portions of the agent's conduct that fall within the agent's authority and can be separated from the unauthorized parts, but not for the separable unauthorized actions.

instruction: Can someone be my agent to do something that requires me to be physically present?
input: Section no 592 . Recognition of transaction carried out by agent : (1) Whatever a person can do on his or her own, the person may get the same done, or cause to be done, through an agent, subject to the law. Provided that no act may be done through an agent for which one has to be present in person.
output: According to Section 592(1)... Rule: A person may have an agent perform actions they could do themselves, except where the act legally requires the principal's personal presence. Application/Conclusion: You cannot use an agent for acts that require your personal presence; for all other lawful acts, an agent may act on your behalf.

instruction: Under which section is a contract of agency deemed to be concluded when I appoint someone?

behalf, except on the matter of his or her personal ability, to conduct business

output: According to Section 591... Rule: Section 591 provides that appointment of an agent to act on a person's behalf (except for matters requiring personal ability) results in a deemed contract of agency. Application/Conclusion: The legal basis for saying a contract of agency is concluded upon appointment is Section 591; appointing an agent creates the agency relationship as described there.

instruction: If creditors are "pari pasu," what practical right do they have over the collateral?
input:

person has borrowed debt from two or more creditors at a time or several times

as otherwise provided for in the contract, all the creditors who have taken the
goods as collateral shall be deemed to be in pari pasu in respect of the debt
outstanding and shall have the right to make a proportionate claim on the
goods accordingly.
output: According to Section 589(1)... Rule: Creditors deemed pari passu have equal footing and can make proportionate claims on insufficient collateral. Application/Conclusion: Practically, each creditor can claim a share of the collateral proportionate to their outstanding debt, rather than any single creditor taking priority.

instruction: I want to prioritise my friend later for a pledged asset. Can I sign a later agreement to do that?
input:

output: According to Section 589(2)... Rule: Any future-priority contract regarding already-pledged goods under subsection (1) is void. instruction: I found out about a wrongful act under this Chapter after a year and a half. Is it too late to sue?
input:
Section no 590 . Statute of limitation : A person
who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make
a lawsuit within two years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action.
output: According to Section 590... Rule: The limitation period is two years from accrual of the cause of action. Application/Conclusion: Since you discovered the act 1.5 years (eighteen months) after accrual, you still have six months left to file a lawsuit within the two-year limitation period, unless other legal exceptions apply.

instruction: Plainly: what can't an agent do for me?

Section no 591 . Contract of agency deemed to be made : Any person

behalf, except on the matter of his or her personal ability, to conduct business
as his or her agent or carry on any transaction with a third person on his or her
behalf or to represent him or her to such a person or to establish any type of

person, and if an agent is so appointed, a contract of agency shall be deemed to
have been concluded.
output: According to Section 591... Rule: An agent may perform acts for the principal except those that relate to the principal's personal ability. Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, an agent cannot do acts that the law requires the principal to perform personally (personal-capacity matters); otherwise the agent can act on your behalf.

instruction: I appointed an agent. They made a deal, but part of it was clearly beyond their authority and inseparable. Am I liable?
input:

output: According to Section 592(3)... Rule: When acts contain separable parts within and beyond authority, the principal is liable only for the separable parts done within authority. Application/Conclusion: If the within-authority parts can be separated, you are liable for those; but if the unauthorized parts are inseparable, Section 592(3) suggests liability is limited to what can be separated — you should assess whether separation is possible and seek legal advice if uncertain.

instruction: Short: who bears obligations if my agent signs a contract for me?
input: Section no 592  part (2) : A contract concluded through an agent appointed pursuant to Section 591 or act done by the agent shall be deemed to have been carried out by the concerned person and the obligation arising out of such an act shall be performed as if the contract were concluded or act done by the principal. output: According to Section 592(2)... Rule: Contracts by an appointed agent are treated as performed by the principal, who bears resulting obligations, except for unauthorized acts not accepted by the principal. Application/Conclusion: You generally bear the obligations of contracts your agent lawfully signs for you; unauthorized acts bind you only if you accept them.

instruction: My creditor already took full payment from the pledged goods while I had other creditors listed. Do they have to compensate others?
input:
Section no 589  part (2) : A contract entered into giving priority right in
the future to a creditor on the goods already pledged as collateral pursuant to
sub-section (1) shall be void. If a creditor has already recovered his or her debt
from such a collateral before the contract becomes void in spite of knowing that
there are also other creditors in respect of the security, such a creditor shall

Rule: A creditor who recovers debt from collateral knowing there are other creditors must return amounts to those other creditors and then recover from the pledger's other assets. Application/Conclusion: The creditor must reimburse the co-creditors their shares from what was taken and can only pursue the pledger's other assets afterward to satisfy the remainder of their claim.

instruction: Can the repair shop keep my phone until I pay the repair bill?
input: Section no 581  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), the person who repairs, improves or renovates the goods shall have the right to retain them until the payment of the costs incurred in the repair, improvement or renovation of such goods or the service charge if paid, and if such costs or service fee are not paid within a reasonable period, that person may recover the costs or service fee by selling the goods.
output: According to Section no 581 part (2): Rule: A person who repairs, improves or renovates goods has the right to retain those goods until the repair costs or service charge are paid, and if not paid within a reasonable period, may recover the costs by selling the goods. Application/Conclusion: The repair shop may lawfully keep your phone until you pay the bill. If you do not pay within a reasonable time, the shop may be entitled to sell the phone to recover the unpaid costs, subject to any additional legal safeguards or contract terms.

instruction: If I refuse to pay right away, can they sell my repaired laptop straight away?
input: Section no 581  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), the person who repairs, improves or renovates the goods shall have the right to retain them until the payment of the costs incurred in the repair, improvement or renovation of such goods or the service charge if paid, and if such costs or service fee are not paid within a reasonable period, that person may recover the costs or service fee by selling the goods.
output: According to Section no 581 part (2): Rule: The repairer can retain goods until payment and may sell them to recover costs only if the costs or service fee are not paid within a reasonable period. Application/Conclusion: They cannot immediately sell your laptop the moment you refuse to pay; they must first allow a reasonable period for payment. Only after that reasonable period has passed may they sell to recover unpaid costs, unless the contract says otherwise.

instruction: Who must pay the storage and security expenses for goods left in bailment?
input: Section no 582 . Costs incurred in taking care of (herbichar) bailed goods : Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the bailor shall bear the expenses incurred in the bailment of goods and in the care or security of the bailed goods.
output: According to Section no 582: Rule: Unless the contract provides otherwise, the bailor (the person who delivered the goods) must bear expenses for bailment and care or security of the bailed goods. Application/Conclusion: If you left items with someone as bailee and your contract is silent, you (the bailor) are responsible for costs of taking care of or securing those goods. If the contract allocates expenses differently, that contract term governs.

instruction: Someone bailed my ancestral plot to hide it from creditors — is that valid?
input: Section no 583 . Contract of bailment to be void : If it is proved that any goods are bailed with the intention of disentitling partition share, abstaining from paying any payable government fee or amount payable to any one or for any other illegal purpose, such a contract of bailment shall be void.
output: According to Section no 583: Rule: A contract of bailment is void if goods were bailed with the intention to disentitle a partition share, avoid paying government fees or amounts, or for any other illegal purpose. Application/Conclusion: If you can prove the bailment of the ancestral plot was intended to defeat partition rights or to avoid creditor/government obligations (or another illegal purpose), that bailment contract is void and can be challenged in court.

instruction: How long do I have to file a lawsuit about something done under this Chapter?
input: Section no 584 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from an act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action.
output: According to Section no 584: Rule: The statute of limitation for actions arising under this Chapter is two years from the date the cause of action accrues. Application/Conclusion: You have two years from when your legal grievance arose to file a lawsuit under this Chapter. If you wait longer, you may be barred from bringing the claim.

instruction: If someone took delivery of my watch as security for a loan I gave them, what kind of contract is that?
input: Section no 585 . Contract of pledge or deposit deemed to be made : (1) If a person takes delivery of goods as security for payment of a debt lent to another person, a contract of collateral is deemed to have been concluded and if a person takes delivery of goods as a security for the performance of a promise by another person, a contract of deposit shall be deemed to have been concluded. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “goods” means any property and includes title to or an instrument establishing title to that property.
output: According to Section no 585: Rule: Delivery of goods as security for repayment of a debt constitutes a contract of collateral (pledge); delivery as security for performance of a promise constitutes a contract of deposit. Application/Conclusion: If you gave a watch to someone as security for a loan you made, the law treats that arrangement as a contract of collateral (pledge). The legal rules for collateral will apply to that watch.

instruction: Can the lender charge interest and also demand extra expenses related to the promise when goods are taken as collateral?
input: Section no 585  part (2) : A contract of collateral or deposit may be made pursuant to sub-section (1) in relation to the debt for the payment of which security is taken and interest of the debt, and if a deposit is taken as a security for the performance of a promise, other expenses related to that promise and expenses incurred in the care of (herchaha)collateraled or deposited goods.
output: According to Section no 585 part (2): Rule: A collateral or deposit may cover the debt and its interest; when a deposit secures performance of a promise, related expenses and expenses for caring for the collateraled/deposited goods may also be covered. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the lender may look to the collateral to cover the principal debt and interest. If the deposit secures performance of a promise, additional related expenses and care costs for the goods can also be claimed against the security, subject to the contract terms.

instruction: After I pay the loan, when must the pledged item be returned?
input: Section no 586 . To return goods collateraled or deposited : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, after the payment of the debt for which the collater has been taken or after the performance of the promise for which person deposit has been taken shall be returned to the concerned.
output: According to Section no 586: Rule: Except where the contract provides otherwise, collateraled (pledged) or deposited goods must be returned after payment of the debt or performance of the promise for which the goods were taken. Application/Conclusion: Once you repay the debt or fulfil the obligation secured by the pledged/deposited item, the holder must return the goods to you unless your contract specifies a different arrangement.

instruction: I paid back the money but the lender still holds my title deed. What does the law require?
input: Section no 586 . To return goods collateraled or deposited : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, after the payment of the debt for which the collater has been taken or after the performance of the promise for which person deposit has been taken shall be returned to the concerned.
output: According to Section no 586: Rule: Except where the contract states otherwise, collateral or deposited goods must be returned after the debt is paid or the promise performed. Application/Conclusion: Because you repaid the debt, the lender is required to return your title deed unless the contract explicitly provides another arrangement. You can demand return and, if refused, consider legal action within applicable time limits.

instruction: Can a bailment be declared void if done to avoid paying taxes?

output: According to Section no 583: Rule: A bailment is void if goods were bailed to abstain from paying any payable government fee (or for other illegal purposes). Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you can prove the bailment was made to avoid paying government fees (taxes), the contract is void and can be challenged; the arrangement will not be legally enforceable.

instruction: Who is responsible for expenses in caring for pledged goods — the lender or the depositor?
input: Section no 585  part (2) : A contract of collateral or deposit may be made pursuant to sub-section (1) in relation to the debt for the payment of which security is taken and interest of the debt, and if a deposit is taken as a security for the performance of a promise, other expenses related to that promise and expenses incurred in the care of (herchaha)collateraled or deposited goods.
output: According to Section no 585 part (2): Rule: When a deposit is taken as security, the contract may include not only the debt and interest but also other expenses related to the promise and expenses incurred in caring for the collateraled/deposited goods. Application/Conclusion: The costs of caring for pledged goods can be treated as recoverable expenses under the collateral/deposit arrangement. Whether the lender actually bears or recovers these costs depends on the contract and applicable claims against the security.

instruction: Under which section is a pledge or deposit deemed to exist when goods are taken as security?

If goods were taken as security, Section no 585 deems a collateral or deposit contract to exist.

instruction: My borrower sold my car I had given as collateral after a month of non-payment. Is that allowed?

output: According to Section no 581 part (2): Rule: The person holding goods (in this clause, the repairer) may retain them until payment and, if not paid within a reasonable period, may sell to recover costs. instruction: I paid for care charges on my bailed goods. Can I recover those from the bailee?

output: According to Section no 582: Rule: Unless the contract states otherwise, the bailor (the one who handed over the goods) bears the expenses incurred in bailment and care/security of the bailed goods. instruction: My neighbour mixed my sacks of rice with his without telling me. They can be separated. Who owns what and who pays?
input:

the goods of the bailor with his or her own goods, and the goods so mixed

respectively, but the bailee shall be bound to bear the expenses for separation

output: According to Section 578(5): Rule: If the bailee mixes the bailor's goods with his own without consent and the goods can be separated, each party retains title to their respective goods; the bailee must bear the separation expenses and any damage to the bailor. Your neighbour (the bailee) must pay the costs to separate the sacks and compensate you for any damage caused by the mixing.

instruction: If my bailee mixed my oil with theirs and it can't be separated, do I lose rights to my oil?
input:
Section no 578  part (6) : If the bailee, without consent of the bailor, mixes
the goods of the bailor with his or her own goods, and the goods so mixed
cannot be separated pursuant to sub-section (5), the bailor shall have right in

output: According to Section 578(6): Rule: If the bailee mixes the bailor's goods without consent and the mixed goods cannot be separated, the bailor shall have a right in such goods. Application/Conclusion: You do not lose your rights. Even though the oil cannot be separated, the law gives you a right in the mixed goods, meaning you can assert ownership interests or seek remedies as a bailor.

instruction: I told the storekeeper he could mix my grain with his for a better price. Later we profited. Who gets the income?
input:

that if the bailee, with the consent of the bailor, mixes the goods of the bailor

instruction: Can I sue the principal if my agent committed fraud in a sale and I couldn't recover from the agent?

instruction: My agent lied in the deal and committed fraud. Who is personally liable?

instruction: The principal told the buyer the agent could act for them; the agent made a bad deal. Is the principal liable?

Application/Conclusion: Because the principal represented that the agent had authority and the third party had no reason to suspect otherwise, the principal may be held liable for the agent's actions in that deal.

instruction: Even if the agent exceeded authority, can I still hold the principal responsible if the buyer reasonably believed the agent had power?
input: Section no 596  part (2) : In the cases referred to in sub-section (1), the principal may be liable even for the act done by the agent beyond the authority if there is a reasonable ground for the third party to believe that the agent has authority. 340

instruction: Can I terminate my agency immediately if I give notice and renounce it?

instruction: What happens if the principal revokes my authority and tells me performance is impossible?

Application/Conclusion: If the principal revokes your authority or informs you that performance is impossible, the agency is automatically terminated unless the contract says otherwise.

instruction: I was appointed to sell a house and finished the sale. Does my agency end automatically?

instruction: Can I sell the collateral if the borrower doesn't pay?

Application/Conclusion: If your borrower has defaulted within the specified period, you may start legal action to sell or auction the collateral at market price; if sale is impossible, you may pursue transfer of ownership under legal process.

instruction: My creditor sold my pledged goods but the sale fetched less than what's owed. Can they come after my other assets?

Application/Conclusion: Since the creditor didn't know the stereo wasn't your sister's, they can require your sister to provide collateral she actually owns of equal value; if she cannot, the creditor may move to void the contract.

instruction: What if the creditor knew the pledged goods didn't belong to the pledger — can they keep those goods?

Application/Conclusion: If the creditor knew (or the contract was already void) that the pledged goods weren't owned by the pledger, the creditor cannot keep those goods; they must seek recovery from the pledger's other assets.

Application/Conclusion: If you were given a receipt/bill by the transport business when you handed over the goods, you can rely on that document as evidence of the contract with the carrier; however, it does not apply if the person carrying the goods was merely your wage-employed worker or agent as explained.

instruction: My goods arrived broken. Is the transporter responsible?
input: Section no 603  part (2) : If the goods received from the owner of the goods for carriage are lost, destroyed, broken, defaced or damaged or the 344 goods do not reach to the specified destination in proper condition in any other manner, the carrier shall be liable for that.
output: According to Section 603(2): Rule: The carrier is liable if goods received for carriage are lost, destroyed, broken, defaced, damaged, or do not arrive at the specified destination in proper condition. Application/Conclusion: Because your goods arrived broken, the carrier is liable under this section and you can seek compensation from the carrier for the damage.

instruction: They handed my shipment to another truck and now it's missing. Who is liable?
input: Section no 604 . Carrier to be liable : (1) If more than one carrier or mode of transport is involved in the carriage of any goods, except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the carrier to whom the owner of the goods has been handed over the goods shall be liable.
output: According to Section 604(1): Rule: When more than one carrier or mode of transport is involved, the carrier who received the goods from the owner (i.e., to whom the owner handed over the goods) is liable, unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: The carrier who originally took the goods from you (the owner) is generally responsible for the loss, so you should hold that carrier liable unless your contract specifically shifts liability to another carrier.

instruction: If the carrier doesn't deliver on time and there's no delivery date in the contract, what law applies?
input: Section no 603  part (3) : The carrier shall carry the goods within the time specified in the contract, and within a reasonable time, if no period for transporting the goods is specified in the contract, and deliver the goods to the owner of the goods or his or her agent or a person designated by him or her.
output: According to Section 603(3): Rule: The carrier must transport goods within the time specified in the contract; if no time is specified, the carrier must deliver within a reasonable time. Application/Conclusion: If your contract has no delivery period, the carrier is required to deliver within a reasonable time — you can claim breach if they unreasonably delay beyond what would be considered reasonable for that shipment.

instruction: Can the carrier sell perishable food I sent if transport is delayed by an accident?
input: Section no 605 . Right to sell goods without consent of owner : (1) If the carrier fails to carry any goods to the destination within the specified time due to a disaster or accident in the course of carriage of the goods and such goods are perishable or their price or quality is susceptible to decrease significantly, the carrier may sell such goods even without the consent of the owner.
output: According to Section 605(1): Rule: If the carrier cannot carry goods to destination within the specified time due to a disaster or accident, and the goods are perishable or likely to suffer significant price/quality decline, the carrier may sell the goods without the owner's consent. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your perishable food could spoil or lose value because of a disaster/accident-caused delay, the carrier is permitted to sell it without your consent to prevent further loss.

instruction: They sold my perishable shipment after an accident — do I get the money?

Application/Conclusion: You are entitled to the proceeds from the sale; the carrier must pay you the amount obtained when they sold your perishable goods following the accident or disaster.

instruction: If my goods were stolen before delivery, is the carrier responsible? What if it was a flood?

output: According to Section 604(2): Rule: The carrier is liable if goods are stolen, lost, damaged or destroyed prior to carriage/delivery by the carrier, but the carrier is not liable if such loss/damage results from a disaster or accident. Application/Conclusion: If your goods were stolen or lost for reasons not caused by a disaster/accident, the carrier is liable. If the loss was due to a disaster or accident (e.g., flood), the carrier is not liable under this provision.

output: According to Section 606(1): Rule: Compensation for loss or damage is limited to one hundred thousand rupees unless the owner or agent clearly declared a higher value when the contract was made, or the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: The carrier can limit liability to 100,000 rupees by default. To claim more, you must have declared the higher value at contract time (or have a contract clause providing otherwise); if you didn't, recovery is capped at that amount.

instruction: What exactly makes a contract a lease?
input: A contract of lease deemed to be made : (1) If a contract is concluded under which a person gives any goods in which he or she has right and possession to another person for use and possession and enjoy the benefits accrued therefrom in consideration for a rent payable regularly for a certain period, a contract of lease shall be deemed to be concluded. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “goods” means any property from which benefit may be acquired through consumption, possession or use without diminishing them.
output: According to Section 610(1). Rule: A lease is deemed concluded when a person who has right and possession gives goods to another for use and possession and to enjoy benefits in return for regularly payable rent for a set period. Application/Conclusion: If your agreement gives the other party possession and use of goods you own, they enjoy benefits, and you receive regular rent for a period, that agreement qualifies as a lease under this Section.

instruction: What does the law mean by 'goods' in lease law? Explain in plain terms.

instruction: Can I change the structure of the rented shop interior without asking the landlord?

output: According to Section 611. Rule: The lessee must not change the original form of leased goods without the owner's consent, but repairs, maintenance, improvements or renovation are permitted. Application/Conclusion: You cannot alter the shop's original structure without the landlord's consent, though carrying out repairs or improvements (with care) is allowed.

instruction: Can I use the leased motorcycle as if it were mine? Any limits?

Section no 612 . To use the leased goods in good faith : (1) The lessee shall have the right to possess and use the leased goods in good faith and in a prudential manner as if the goods were owned by himself or herself.
 Section no 612  part (2) : While possessing and using the leased goods pursuant to sub-section (1), the lessee shall possess and use them in consonance with the object of the contract of lease.
output: According to Section 612(1)-(2). Rule: The lessee may possess and use leased goods in good faith and prudently, similar to an owner, but must use them in line with the lease's purpose. Application/Conclusion: You can use the motorcycle responsibly as if it were yours, but only for uses consistent with the lease (e.g., personal transport if that is the lease's object); uses outside the agreed purpose could breach the lease.

instruction: I used the rented laptop for a business the owner didn't agree to. Can the owner cancel the lease?

instruction: Who is responsible for general repairs to a rented generator?

output: According to Section 613(1). Rule: Unless the lease says otherwise, the lessor is responsible for repairing and maintaining leased goods. Application/Conclusion: Generally the owner (lessor) must take care of repairs for the generator unless your contract shifts that duty to you.

instruction: Do I have to tell the owner if someone is claiming the leased equipment?

Lessor to be informed if goods are not usable : (1) If the leased goods or any part thereof are lost, damaged or destroyed in any manner, are not capable of being possessed or used for any reason, any person makes a claim or dispute of any kind in relation to such goods or any part thereof or any person creates hindrance or disturbance in any manner while possessing or using the goods, the lessee shall give information thereof to the lessor immediately.
output: According to Section 614(1). Rule: The lessee must immediately inform the lessor if the goods are lost, damaged, unusable, subject to claims/disputes, or if anyone creates hindrance while using them. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if someone is claiming the leased equipment, you must inform the owner immediately.

instruction: If I improve the leased apartment, do I lose the right to do so because it changes form?

instruction: I rented a copier and later discovered it's consumable (uses cartridges). Can it be leased at all?
input:

instruction: Can a sublease last longer than the original lease?

instruction: If the lessor sues the lessee, can the sub-lessee be held liable?
input: Section no 618  part (6) : If the lessor makes recourse to any legal remedy or a claim against the lessee under this Chapter, the sub-lessee shall not be liable therefor except in the case referred to in sub-section (4).

Rule: A sub-lessee is not liable for the lessor's legal remedies or claims against the lessee, except as provided in subsection (4).
Application/Conclusion: Generally you (as sub-lessee) are protected from suits the lessor brings against the lessee — you are not liable unless the specific exception described in subsection (4) applies to your situation.

instruction: Does applying these rules affect the lessor's contractual rights?
input: Section no 618  part (7) : Nothing shall be deemed to have been prejudiced in any manner the right which the lessor may exercise under the contract of lease based on anything contained in this Section,.
output:
According to Section 618(7)...
Rule: The provisions of this Section do not prejudice or limit any rights the lessor may exercise under the lease contract.
Application/Conclusion: Even where these sub-lease rules apply, the lessor retains any contractual rights from the main lease — nothing here strips away the lessor's lease-based rights.

instruction: How long after lease termination must I return leased goods? I have an immovable property lease — any difference?
input: Section no 619 . output:
According to Section 619(1)...
Rule: Upon termination the lessee must return leased goods within thirty-five days; for immovable property the lessor is automatically entitled to possess the property after thirty-five days.
Application/Conclusion: You must return movable leased items within 35 days of termination. For immovable property, if you don't vacate or return within 35 days the lessor is deemed entitled to possession automatically.

instruction: Do I have to return the leased items in the same condition I received them?
input: Section no 619  part (2) : The lessee shall return the goods leased pursuant to sub-section (1) to the lessor on the same condition as they were received at the time of lease. Provided that the lessee shall not be liable for any natural decay or depreciation caused from the possession and use of the goods.
output:
According to Section 619(2)...
Rule: The lessee must return leased goods in the same condition as received, except they are not liable for natural decay or depreciation from normal possession and use.
Application/Conclusion: You must take reasonable care and return items in their original condition, but you are not responsible for ordinary wear-and-tear or natural deterioration from legitimate use.

instruction: I rented equipment and kept a parts list. Must I return all spare parts?
input: Section no 619  part (3) : If a record of the goods or accessories and spare parts thereof has been maintained at the time of leasing the goods, the goods and accessories and spare parts thereof according to such record shall also be returned, while returning the leased goods pursuant to sub-section (1) or (2). Application/Conclusion: You must return accessories and spare parts listed in the inventory provided at lease, except for those which were destroyed or naturally lost during proper use — you won't be held to return those.

instruction: Must leases of land or buildings be written down?
input: Section no 620 . Special provision relating to the contract of lease of immovable : property: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, a contract of lease of any immovable property shall be concluded in writing.

Rule: Any contract of lease for immovable property must be concluded in writing.
Application/Conclusion: An oral lease of land or a building would not comply — you need a written lease agreement for immovable property.

instruction: Do I have to register a lease that lasts more than ten years? Where is that stated?

instruction: Can someone who is not allowed to own land in Nepal lease it for farming or building without government permission?
input: Section no 620  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, no immovable property can, without consent of the Government of Nepal, be leased to a person who cannot acquire ownership in any immovable property in Nepal according to law, for the purpose of farming, constructing a building or housing and land development.
output:

Rule: Immovable property cannot be leased for farming, construction, housing or land development to a person who is legally barred from owning immovable property in Nepal, unless the Government of Nepal consents.
Application/Conclusion: If you are a person who cannot lawfully acquire ownership of land in Nepal (for example due to nationality restrictions), you cannot be leased land for those purposes unless the government gives consent.

instruction: I built a shed and planted trees on rented land. At lease end, can I leave them and claim ownership?
input: Section no 620  part (4) : In returning any building, shed or other structure built by the lessee, or the garden, forest or trees located, in the land leased under the contract of lease to the lessor upon the expiry of the validity period of the contract of lease, except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the lessee shall be deemed to have right and ownership in such building, shed or other structure or garden, forest or trees located therein, and the lessee shall accordingly remove such building, shed, structure, garden, forest or trees from such land.

According to Section 620(4)...
Rule: When returning leased land, structures or plantations created by the lessee are treated as the lessee's property, and the lessee must remove them unless the contract provides otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: You cannot simply leave structures or trees for the lessor and claim they become the lessor's property — you are deemed to own them and therefore must remove them at lease end unless the lease says otherwise.

instruction: What counts as a 'force majeure event'? Give examples in plain terms.

instruction: If the leased goods are partly destroyed by a storm and cannot be restored, who reduces the rent?

instruction: Under which section is the lessee required to take safety measures for leased goods?

instruction: Is fire always treated as force majeure so I won't be liable?

of a movable property, within fifteen days of the end of every fiscal year, in the
case of farmland, servitude, land leased for industrial or infrastructure building
or housing, and within a week of the end of every month, in the case of other
goods.
output: According to Section 616(2)... Rule: Where the lease does not specify payment terms, rent is payable: the next day after month-end for movable property; within 15 days after fiscal year-end for farmland, servitude, land leased for industrial/infrastructure building or housing; and within a week after month-end for other goods. Application/Conclusion: For land leased for a shop (land for industrial/infrastructure/building or housing category), if the contract is silent you must pay within 15 days after the fiscal year's end.

instruction: Do I have to pay rent exactly as the lease says or is there a general rule?
input:
Section no 616 . To pay lease rent : (1) The lessee shall pay to the lessor
the lease rent according to the terms and conditions of the contract of lease. 352
output: According to Section 616(1)... Rule: The lessee must pay lease rent according to the contract's terms and conditions. Application/Conclusion: You are bound to pay rent exactly as agreed in the lease. Only if the contract lacks payment terms does Section 616(2) supply default timings.

instruction: A dispute prevents me from using the leased machine. Can I pay less rent?
input:
Section no 614  part (3) : In the case of failure to restore the leased goods into their original condition within the period referred to in sub-section
Section no 614  part (2) : , the lease rent shall be subject to reduction in
proportion to the extent to which such goods have been lost, damaged or destroyed or become incapable of being used or possessed or such claim, hindrance
or dispute has been made.
output: According to Section 614(3)... Rule: If the lessor fails to restore goods within the prescribed period, the rent must be reduced proportionally in cases where goods are lost, damaged, destroyed or become unusable, or where a claim/hindrance/dispute exists. Application/Conclusion: If a dispute prevents your use of the leased machine and the lessor hasn’t restored it within the timeframe, you are entitled to a proportional reduction of the rent.

instruction: Can the lessor take legal action to restore goods, or must they do physical repair only?
input:
Section no 614  part (2) : Upon receipt of information pursuant to sub-section
(1), the lessor shall carry out such repair, maintenance or renovation or obtain
such legal remedies as may be necessary to restore the goods into their original
condition according to the nature of the goods within fifteen days.
output: According to Section 614(2)... Rule: The lessor must either carry out repair/maintenance/renovation or obtain necessary legal remedies to restore the goods within fifteen days. Application/Conclusion: The lessor is permitted — and required — to pursue legal remedies (not just physical repair) if necessary to restore the goods. So they may file legal action when appropriate to restore your right or the goods' condition.

instruction: I found that the leased vehicle’s value decreased during lease because my relative borrowed it and damaged it. Who pays?
input:
Section no 615  part (2) : If the leased goods are lost or destroyed for any
reason or the price of the goods decreases due to loss or destruction thereof in
any manner or due to loss because of negligence on the part of the lessee, any
member of his or her family, his or her agent or the third party, during the
validity of the contract of lease, the lessee 351 shall be liable therefor, and the
lessee shall restore such goods into their original condition, and if the lessee fails
to do so, he or she shall be liable to pay compensation therefor.
output: According to Section 615(2)... Rule: Loss, destruction or decrease in price due to negligence by the lessee or their family/agent/third party during the lease makes the lessee liable to restore the goods or pay compensation. Application/Conclusion: Because your relative (a family member) damaged the vehicle through negligence, you as the lessee are liable to restore it or compensate the lessor.

instruction: If there's a civil riot and the leased shop is damaged, is that considered force majeure?
input: Section no 615  part (4) (d) : Act of terrorism, civil riot, civil war,
output: According to Section 615(4)(d)... Rule: Acts of terrorism, civil riot and civil war are expressly listed as force majeure events. Application/Conclusion: Damage from a civil riot qualifies as force majeure under this provision; therefore the lessee would not be liable for loss caused by that event, and related rent adjustments under Section 615(4) may apply.

instruction: My landlord never fixed the leased equipment and I can't use it — can I stop paying full rent straight away?
input:
Section no 614  part (3) : In the case of failure to restore the leased goods into their original condition within the period referred to in sub-section
Section no 614  part (2) : , the lease rent shall be subject to reduction in
proportion to the extent to which such goods have been lost, damaged or destroyed or become incapable of being used or possessed or such claim, hindrance
or dispute has been made.
output: According to Section 614(3)... Rule: If the lessor fails to restore goods within the period set in subsection (2), the rent must be reduced proportionally to the extent of loss, damage, destruction or loss of use. Application/Conclusion: You should not unilaterally stop paying all rent; rather, the rent is to be reduced proportionally. Practically, you should calculate a proportional reduction and notify the lessor, or seek legal remedy if they dispute the reduction.

instruction: When is the 15‑day deadline mentioned in the lease law applicable?
input:
Section no 614  part (2) : Upon receipt of information pursuant to sub-section
(1), the lessor shall carry out such repair, maintenance or renovation or obtain
such legal remedies as may be necessary to restore the goods into their original
condition according to the nature of the goods within fifteen days.
output: According to Section 614(2)... Rule: The 15-day deadline applies from the time the lessor receives the information required under sub-section (1) for carrying out necessary restoration/repairs or obtaining legal remedies. Application/Conclusion: The 15 days begin when the lessor receives the requisite notice/information; the lessor must act within that period to restore the goods or pursue remedies.

instruction: I want to know: If the contract is silent, when do I pay rent for a regular appliance I leased?
input:
Section no 616  part (2) : If the terms and conditions of payment of the lease
rent are not specified in the contract pursuant to sub-section (1), the lessee
shall pay the lease rent on the next day of the end of each month, in the case
of a movable property, within fifteen days of the end of every fiscal year, in the
case of farmland, servitude, land leased for industrial or infrastructure building
or housing, and within a week of the end of every month, in the case of other
goods.
output: According to Section 616(2)... Rule: Where payment terms are not specified, rent for movable property is payable the next day after month-end; other goods require payment within a week after month-end. Application/Conclusion: For a regular appliance (movable property), if the lease is silent you must pay on the next day after the end of each month.

instruction: Can I lease housing land for 40 years to build a house?
input: Section no 617  clause (a) : Thirty-five years in the case of housing land leased for the construction of a building or housing land in use after construction of a building therein,
output: According to Section 617(1)(a), the rule is that a contract of lease for housing land for construction or housing land in use after construction cannot be valid for more than thirty-five years. Applied to your case, a 40-year lease would exceed that maximum and therefore is not valid for the full 40 years; the lawful maximum is 35 years.

instruction: Can I sign a lease for servitude land that lasts 50 years?
input: Section no 617  clause (b) : Thirty-five years in the case of the land leased for the purpose of servitude,
output: According to Section 617(1)(b), the rule is that land leased for the purpose of servitude may not have a contract valid for more than thirty-five years. Applied to your situation, a 50-year servitude lease would exceed the statutory maximum and thus cannot be valid for that full duration; the cap is 35 years.

instruction: I want to lease land for a road and small hydropower. How long can the lease be?
input: Section no 617  clause (c) : Forty years in the case of the land leased for the purpose of construction, development and 353 operation of the infrastructures such as industrial structure, roads, canals, electricity generation,
output: According to Section 617(1)(c), the rule is that land leased for construction, development and operation of infrastructure (including roads and electricity generation) may be valid for up to forty years. Applied to your plan to use land for a road and hydropower, the contract can be valid for a maximum of 40 years.

instruction: What's the maximum term I can get if I lease farmland?
input: Section no 617  clause (d) : Twenty years in the case of land for farming;
output: According to Section 617(1)(d), the rule is that land leased for farming purposes shall not be valid for more than twenty years. Applied to your situation, any farming lease cannot exceed a 20-year validity period.

instruction: My landlord offers a 25-year lease for my house to be used as a shop. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 617  clause (e) : Nineteen years in the case of house and land leased for the purposes other than that referred to in clause (a), (b), (c) or (d),
output: According to Section 617(1)(e), the rule is that when a house and land are leased for purposes not covered by clauses (a)–(d), the contract shall not be valid for more than nineteen years. Applied here, a 25-year lease for your house used as a shop would exceed the statutory maximum; the lawful maximum is 19 years.

instruction: Can I lease a car under a contract valid for 20 years?
input: Section no 617  clause (f) : Fifteen years in the case of a motor vehicle,
output: According to Section 617(1)(f), the rule is that a contract of lease for a motor vehicle cannot be valid for more than fifteen years. Applied to your question, a 20-year vehicle lease would exceed this limit and thus is not valid for that full period; the maximum is 15 years.

instruction: How long can machinery (not a car) be leased for?
input: Section no 617  clause (g) : Fifteen years in the case of machinery equipment other than a motor vehicle,
output: According to Section 617(1)(g), the rule is that machinery equipment other than motor vehicles may be leased for up to fifteen years. Applied to your case, such machinery cannot be the subject of a lease valid for more than 15 years.

instruction: What's the difference between clause (g) and clause (h) on machinery lease terms?
input:
Section no 617  clause (g) : Fifteen years in the case of machinery equipment other than a motor vehicle,
Section no 617  clause (h) : Fifteen years in the case of machinery equipment other than that referred to in clause (f) or (g),
output: According to Section 617(1)(g) and (h), the rule is that machinery equipment (both machinery other than motor vehicles and machinery not covered by clauses (f) or (g)) are subject to a maximum lease validity of fifteen years. Applied practically, both clauses set a 15-year cap for different categories of machinery; in effect the maximum for such machinery leases is 15 years.

instruction: How long can I lease a cow under a written lease?
input: Section no 617  clause (i) : Ten years in the case of a domestic animal,
output: According to Section 617(1)(i), the rule is that a contract of lease for a domestic animal may not be valid for more than ten years. Applied to your situation, a lease for a cow cannot exceed a 10-year validity period.

instruction: If an item is not listed in the lease-period table, how long can its lease be?
input: Section no 617  clause (j) : Ten years in the case of goods other than that set forth in this Section having regard to their life and nature.
output: According to Section 617(1)(j), the rule is that for goods not specifically listed, the lease may be valid for up to ten years, taking into account the life and nature of the goods. Applied to an unlisted item, you should consider its lifespan and nature, but the statutory cap is ten years unless otherwise addressed by agreement within that reasoning.

instruction: If my lease is about to expire, can the parties extend it?
input: Section no 617  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), the parties may extend the validity period of the contract of lease, subject to the validity period of the contract, before expiry of the period referred to in such a sub-section.
output: According to Section 617(2), the rule is that parties may extend the lease's validity period, but any such extension must be made before the original period expires and remain subject to the contract's validity limits. Applied to your case, the parties can extend the lease, but they must do so before expiry and within the statutory limits on lease duration.

instruction: Can we decide whether to extend our lease based on where the property is and what we're leasing?
input: Section no 617  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), the parties to a contract of lease may decide whether to extend the period of the contract of lease having regard to the place where the leased house and land are situated and the nature of the goods.
output: According to Section 617(3), the rule is that parties may take into account the location of the leased house and land and the nature of the goods when deciding whether to extend the lease period. Applied to your situation, you and the other party are permitted to consider those factors and mutually decide on extension, subject to other statutory limits and timing requirements.

instruction: Can I sub-lease my rented shop to someone else without telling the landlord?
input: Section no 618 . Leased goods may be sub-leased : (1) The lessee may, with the prior consent of the lessor, sub-lease to any person the goods or any 354 part thereof leased under the contract of lease, by concluding another contract of lease to that effect.
output: According to Section 618(1), the rule is that a lessee may sub-lease leased goods only with the prior consent of the lessor. Applied here, you cannot validly sub-lease your shop without obtaining the lessor's prior consent; you should get that consent before concluding any sub-lease.

instruction: If I sub-lease, does that free me from obligations to my landlord?
input: Section no 618  part (2) : The lessee shall not be free from his or her obligation towards the lessor for the reason that he or she has made a sub-lease pursuant to sub-section (1).
output: According to Section 618(2), the rule is that making a sub-lease does not relieve the lessee of obligations toward the lessor. Applied to your case, even after you sub-lease, you remain responsible to the lessor for the lease obligations (rent, care of goods, etc.).

instruction: Can a sub-lease include terms that conflict with the original lease?
input: Section no 618  part (3) : The terms and conditions of such a sub-lease contract concluded pursuant to sub-section (1) in relation to the goods on sublease shall not be different than the terms and conditions of the first contract of lease.
output: According to Section 618(3), the rule is that the terms and conditions of a sub-lease must not differ from those of the original lease with respect to the sub-leased goods. Applied to your situation, the sub-lease cannot lawfully impose terms that conflict with the original lease; it must align with the first contract's terms.

instruction: My sub-lease contract says the sub-lessee deals directly with the landlord — can that make the sub-lessee liable to the landlord?
input: Section no 618  part (4) : While determining the terms and conditions of the contract of lease pursuant to sub-section (3), provision may be so made that the sub-lessee shall be directly liable to the lessor in respect of the leased goods, and if such provision is made, the sub lessee shall be liable to the lessor to the extent of the sub-lease contract.
output: According to Section 618(4), the rule is that the parties may include a provision making the sub-lessee directly liable to the lessor; if such a provision exists, the sub-lessee is liable to the lessor to the extent of the sub-lease contract. Applied here, if your sub-lease contract expressly makes the sub-lessee directly liable to the landlord, that provision is effective and the sub-lessee will have direct liability up to the scope agreed in the sub-lease.

instruction: Conflict: I got my landlord's consent to sub-lease, but the sub-lessee agreed to higher rent and different use — which terms control?
input:
Section no 618  part (2) : The lessee shall not be free from his or her obligation towards the lessor for the reason that he or she has made a sub-lease pursuant to sub-section (1).
Section no 618  part (3) : The terms and conditions of such a sub-lease contract concluded pursuant to sub-section (1) in relation to the goods on sublease shall not be different than the terms and conditions of the first contract of lease.
output: According to Section 618(2) and (3), the rule is that (1) making a sub-lease does not free the lessee from obligations to the lessor, and (2) the sub-lease's terms must not differ from the original lease's terms regarding the subleased goods. Applied to your conflict, even if the sub-lessee agreed to higher rent or a different permitted use, those terms cannot lawfully contradict the original lease; the original lease's terms govern, and you remain responsible to the lessor for compliance.

instruction: My landlord says he wants to take the small shed and trees on the rented land 'as is'. Can he do that without paying me?
input: part (5) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (4), if the lessor desires to take such building, shed or other structure or garden, forest or trees located in such land on the as is where is basis, the lessor shall pay the mutually agreed price for the same.
output: According to Section 620(5), the rule is that if the lessor wants to take buildings, sheds, other structures, gardens, forests or trees on the land on an "as is where is" basis, the lessor must pay a mutually agreed price. Applying this to your situation: the landlord cannot simply take the shed and trees without payment — he must pay you the price you both agree on (or negotiate one).

instruction: My tenant hasn't paid rent for over three months. Can I terminate the lease?
input: Section no 621  clause (a) : Except as otherwise permitted by the lessor, if the lessee fails to pay the lease amount until ninety days after the due date for the payment of the lease rent has expired,
output: According to Section 621(a), the rule is that the lessor may terminate the lease if the lessee fails to pay the lease amount for ninety days after the due date (unless the lessor has permitted otherwise). Applying this to your case: since the tenant hasn't paid rent for over 90 days, you are entitled to terminate the contract of lease unless you previously allowed them more time.

instruction: I caught the tenant using the leased machine for a purpose we didn't agree to. Can I end the lease?
input: Section no 621  clause (b) : If the lessee possesses or uses the leased goods taken contrary to Section 612,
output: According to Section 621(b), the rule is that the lessor may terminate the contract if the lessee possesses or uses the leased goods in a manner contrary to Section 612. Applying this to your situation: if the tenant's use breaches the restrictions set out in Section 612 (i.e., they are using the goods contrary to permitted terms), you have grounds to terminate the lease.

instruction: What if the tenant never told me about a problem with the item I leased them? Can I terminate?
input: Section no 621  clause (c) : If the lessee fails to give information to the lessor or keep him or her informed about the matters referred to in sub-section (1) of Section 614,
