output: According to Section 621(c), the rule is that failure by the lessee to give information or keep the lessor informed about matters referred to in Section 614(1) is grounds for termination by the lessor. Applying this: if the lessee neglected obligations to inform you about matters required under Section 614(1), you may terminate the lease.

instruction: I leased equipment out and the renter returned it damaged and not restored. Can I terminate?
input: Section no 621  clause (d) : If the lessee fails to restore the leased goods into their original condition having regard to the nature of the goods pursuant to sub-section (2) of Section 615,
output: According to Section 621(d), the rule is that the lessor may terminate the lease if the lessee fails to restore the leased goods to their original condition as required by Section 615(2). Applying this: because the renter returned the equipment damaged and did not restore it as required, you have the right to terminate the contract.

instruction: Someone sub‑leased my rented property without asking me. Can I cancel the lease?
input: Section no 621  clause (e) : If the goods leased are sub-leased without the prior consent of the lessor.
output: According to Section 621(e), the rule is that sub-leasing the leased goods without the lessor's prior consent is a ground for termination. Applying this to your case: if the lessee sub-let the property without your prior permission, you can terminate the lease.

instruction: I paid for repairs out of pocket; the owner promised he would reimburse but hasn't. Can I end the lease?
input: Section no 621  part (2) (b) : If the lessor fails to reimburse the repair and maintenance costs or make its adjustment to the lease rent pursuant to sub-section (3) of Section 613,
output: According to Section 621(2)(b), the rule is that the lessee may terminate the lease if the lessor fails to reimburse repair and maintenance costs or adjust the lease rent as required by Section 613(3). Applying this: since the lessor didn't reimburse you as promised and Section 613(3) requires such reimbursement/adjustment, you are entitled to terminate the contract.

instruction: The rented shop can't be used for my business anymore because of a new regulation. Can I terminate the lease?
input: Section no 621  part (2) (a) : If the leased goods cannot be possessed or used for the purpose or object for which the goods have been leased,
output: According to Section 621(2)(a), the rule is that the lessee may terminate the lease if the leased goods cannot be possessed or used for the purpose for which they were leased. Applying this: if the new regulation makes the shop unusable for the intended business purpose, you may terminate the lease.

instruction: The lessor won't reduce the rent even though the leased item is in worse condition. Can I end things?
input: Section no 621  part (2) (c) : If the lessor does not reduce or agree to reduce the lease rent amount pursuant to sub-section (3) of Section 614 or sub-section (4) of Section 615.
output: According to Section 621(2)(c), the rule is that the lessee may terminate the contract if the lessor does not reduce or agree to reduce the lease rent as required under Section 614(3) or Section 615(4). Applying this: if you requested a rent reduction under those provisions and the lessor refused, you can terminate the lease.

instruction: Do the house‑rent rules apply to tenancy disputes in this chapter?
input: Section no 622 . Provisions relating to house rent to apply : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, in matters concerning house rent the provisions of Chapter-9 of Part 4 shall apply.
output: According to Section 622, the rule is that for matters concerning house rent, the provisions of Chapter-9 of Part 4 take precedence notwithstanding other provisions in this Chapter. Applying this: if your issue is specifically about house rent, you should look to and follow Chapter-9 of Part 4 rather than the general rules in this Chapter.

instruction: I just discovered the landlord took action that harmed me two years and one month ago. How long do I have to sue?
input: Section no 623 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years after the date of the accrual of the cause of action. 359 Chapter-13
output: According to Section 623, the rule is that a person aggrieved by an act under this Chapter must file a lawsuit within two years from the date the cause of action accrued. Applying this: because the harmful act occurred more than two years ago (two years and one month), you are likely time-barred from suing under this Chapter.

instruction: What exactly is a hire-purchase — in plain terms?
input:
Section no 624 . Hire-purchase contract deemed to be made : (1) If a person lets any goods to another person for hire on the following terms and conditions, a hire-purchase contract shall be deemed to be concluded:
 Section no 624  clause (a) : The hirer has the right of possession and use of the goods let by the owner of the goods, on the condition of payment of the rent amount by installments in periodic basis for that goods,
 Section no 624  clause (b) : The hirer has the right to purchase the goods on hire according to the terms and conditions of the contract,
 Section no 624  clause (c) : The ownership of such goods would be transferred to the hirer upon payment of the last installment,
 Section no 624  clause (d) : The hirer may terminate the contract at any time prior to the transfer of ownership pursuant to clause (c).
output: According to Section 624, the rule is that a hire-purchase exists where goods are let on hire with (a) the hirer having possession and use while paying periodic installments, (b) the hirer having the right to purchase under the contract, (c) ownership transferring when the last installment is paid, and (d) the hirer being able to terminate before ownership transfers. Applying this in plain terms: hire-purchase means you use and pay in installments, you can buy the item per the contract, ownership passes after the final payment, and you can cancel before that final payment and transfer.

instruction: Under which section is hire-purchase defined?
input: Section no 624 . Hire-purchase contract deemed to be made : (1) If a person lets any goods to another person for hire on the following terms and conditions, a hire-purchase contract shall be deemed to be concluded:
output: According to Section 624, the rule is that the law sets out when a hire-purchase contract is deemed to be concluded by listing the required terms and conditions. Applying this: hire-purchase is defined and governed by Section 624.

instruction: I want to stop my hire-purchase before buying the item — is that allowed?
input: Section no 624  clause (d) : The hirer may terminate the contract at any time prior to the transfer of ownership pursuant to clause (c).
output: According to Section 624(d), the rule is that the hirer may terminate the hire-purchase contract at any time before ownership transfers under clause (c). Applying this: you are allowed to terminate your hire-purchase agreement at any point before you pay the final installment and ownership passes to you.

instruction: When does ownership of a hire-purchased item pass to the hirer?
input: Section no 624  clause (c) : The ownership of such goods would be transferred to the hirer upon payment of the last installment,
output: According to Section 624(c), the rule is that ownership transfers to the hirer when the last installment is paid. Applying this: you only become the legal owner of the item after you have paid the final installment.

instruction: Does a hire-purchase agreement have to be written down?
input: Section no 624  part (2) : The contract referred to in sub-section (1) shall be concluded in writing.
output: According to Section 624(2), the rule is that a hire-purchase contract as described in subsection (1) must be concluded in writing. Applying this: for a hire-purchase to be valid under this provision, the agreement should be in writing.

instruction: The lessee used the leased goods in a way explicitly forbidden under Section 612. What can the lessor do?
input: Section no 621  clause (b) : If the lessee possesses or uses the leased goods taken contrary to Section 612,
output: According to Section 621(b), the rule is that using or possessing leased goods contrary to Section 612 is grounds for the lessor to terminate the lease. Applying this: since the lessee breached the restrictions of Section 612, the lessor may terminate the contract.

instruction: I was told in plain words: if the lessor doesn't reimburse repairs I can quit. Is that true?
input: Section no 621  part (2) (b) : If the lessor fails to reimburse the repair and maintenance costs or make its adjustment to the lease rent pursuant to sub-section (3) of Section 613,
output: According to Section 621(2)(b), the rule is that a lessee may terminate the lease if the lessor fails to reimburse repair/maintenance costs or adjust the rent as required by Section 613(3). Applying this simply: yes — if the lessor does not reimburse you or adjust rent as Section 613(3) provides, you can terminate the lease.

instruction: Ram sub‑leased my rented generator without asking and now denies it—what remedy do I have?
input: Section no 621  clause (e) : If the goods leased are sub-leased without the prior consent of the lessor.
output: According to Section 621(e), the rule is that sub-leasing the leased goods without the lessor's prior consent is a ground for termination by the lessor. Applying this to your conflict: if Ram sub‑let your generator without your prior consent, you have the right to terminate the lease and enforce remedies available under the contract or law.

instruction: Can I keep using the hired tractor without interruption until I finish paying?
input: The hirer has the right of uninterrupted possession and use of the hired goods,
output: According to Section 627(1)(a). Rule: The hirer has the right of uninterrupted possession and use of the hired goods. Application/Conclusion: Because you are the hirer, you are legally entitled to possess and use the tractor without interruption during the hire period unless the contract or a lawful order says otherwise; the owner cannot lawfully interfere with your possession simply because payments are pending.

instruction: The seller handed me a TV but I later found out it was already under a bank charge. What does the law say?
input: The goods are free from any type of charge or claim of any one at the time of transfer of the goods by the owner to the hirer,
output: According to Section 627(1)(b). Rule: At the time of transfer, the goods must be free of any charge or claim by anyone. Application/Conclusion: Because the TV had a bank charge when it was transferred to you, the owner violated this implied condition; you may have remedies against the owner for breach (for example claim for defect in title or rescission/compensation), since the law presumes transfer should be free of third-party claims.

instruction: I only saw a sample of the goods before hiring. Can I expect the delivered items to be like that sample?
input: If the hirer takes any goods on hire on the basis of a sample, the owner of the goods shall be deemed to have assured of the fact that all of such goods match with the sample.
output: According to Section 627(3). Rule: Where hire is based on a sample, the owner is deemed to assure that all goods match the sample. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you hired the goods on the basis of the sample, the owner is treated as assuring that the whole delivery will match that sample; if the delivered goods differ, you can treat that as a failure of the implied assurance.

instruction: If the contract describes the goods in detail and also shows a sample, which one matters?
input: If the description of any goods or quality thereof is specified in a contract concluded under this Chapter, the owner of the goods shall be deemed to have assured of the fact that such goods or quality thereof shall be as specified in the contract. Provided that if the sample is also specified in the contract, the matching of the quality of such goods with that of the sample shall not suﬀice, and it shall be matched with the description of the contract at the time of transferring the whole of the goods.
output: According to Section 627(4). Rule: The owner is deemed to assure that goods conform to the contract description; if a sample is also in the contract, conformity to the sample alone is insufficient — the goods must match the contractual description. Application/Conclusion: The contract description prevails as the standard at transfer; even if the sample appears correct, the owner must ensure the actual goods match the written description.

instruction: If I told the seller I need the machine for a special purpose and it fails, can I hold the owner responsible?
input: If the hirer has informed the owner of the goods that he or she is hiring the goods for any particular purpose, the owner of the goods guarantees that such goods or quality thereof will be appropriate for that purpose.
output: According to Section 627(1)(f). Rule: When the hirer informs the owner of a particular purpose, the owner guarantees the goods will be suitable for that purpose. Application/Conclusion: Since you told the owner about the special use, the owner gave an implied guarantee of fitness; if the machine is not appropriate for that purpose, you can hold the owner responsible for breach of that guarantee.

instruction: When is the owner NOT liable for the quality of goods?
input:
Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (e) of sub-section (1), the owner of the goods shall not be liable for the quality of the goods in any of the following circumstances:

(a) The owner of the goods was not aware of the defect in the goods, for which the hire-purchase 363 contract has been made at the time of conclusion of such contract,

(b) The hire-purchase contract itself has a stipulation about the defect in the quality of the goods,

(c) If the hirer has collected and examined a sample of the goods and the quality of the goods matches with such a sample,

(d) The hire-purchase contract is concluded with regard to any second-hand goods and that matter is specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 627(2)(a)-(d). Rule: Sub-section (2) lists circumstances where the owner is not liable for quality despite clause (e): (a) owner unaware of defect at contract time, (b) contract expressly stipulates the defect, (c) hirer inspected a sample and goods match it, (d) contract concerns second-hand goods and that is stated. Application/Conclusion: If any of these apply in your case (for example you examined the sample, or the contract discloses the defect, or the goods are sold as specified second‑hand), the owner may not be held liable for quality issues; otherwise the owner remains liable.

instruction: I examined the sample and it matched, later the bulk goods turned out defective. Can I still claim?
input: If the hirer has collected and examined a sample of the goods and the quality of the goods matches with such a sample,
output: According to Section 627(2)(c). Rule: If the hirer collected and examined a sample and the goods match that sample, the owner is not liable for quality defects. Application/Conclusion: Because you inspected and the delivered goods matched the sample, the law treats the owner as not liable for subsequent quality complaints tied to that sample conformity; your ability to claim is therefore limited unless other protections apply.

instruction: I bought second-hand tools under a hire-purchase agreement and did not notice problems. Does the owner guarantee quality?
input: The hire-purchase contract is concluded with regard to any second-hand goods and that matter is specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 627(2)(d). Rule: When the hire-purchase contract expressly states the goods are second-hand, the owner will not be liable for quality under clause (e). Application/Conclusion: Because the contract specifies the goods are second-hand, the owner may not be held to the same implied quality guarantee; you should check the contract wording but statutory protection for quality is limited in that scenario.

instruction: The owner told me he had the right to sell the goods before transfer. Is that allowed?
input: The owner of the goods has the right to sell the hired goods at the time of the transfer of such goods by him to the hirer,
output: According to Section 627(1)(d). Rule: The owner is regarded as having had the right to sell the hired goods at the time of transfer to the hirer. Application/Conclusion: The statute treats the owner as having legitimate title/sale-right when transferring goods under a hire-purchase contract; however, that does not override third-party claims (see clause (b)) — the owner must still transfer free of charges or claims.

instruction: Is there an implied promise that goods are of satisfactory quality when they are handed over?
input: The goods referred to in clause (a) are of satisfactory quality at the time of the transfer of goods,
output: According to Section 627(1)(e). Rule: The goods must be of satisfactory quality at the time of transfer. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the law implies satisfactory quality at transfer; if the goods are not of satisfactory quality when given to you, the owner may be in breach unless an exception in subsection (2) applies.

instruction: I asked whether 'completion of the purchase' means paying the last installment. Is that in law?
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “completion of the purchase” means the payment of the last installment of the hire-purchase price.
output: According to Section 628 (Explanation). Rule: 'Completion of the purchase' is defined as payment of the last installment of the hire-purchase price. Application/Conclusion: Legally, you only become owner when you pay the final installment; until then your ownership is not complete even though you may possess and use the goods.

instruction: When does ownership of hired goods actually pass to me?
input: The ownership of the goods related to a hire-purchase contract shall be transferred to the hirer upon completion of the purchase according to the hire-purchase price determined in accordance with the contract concluded under this Chapter.
output: According to Section 628. Rule: Ownership transfers to the hirer upon completion of the purchase as per the hire-purchase price determined by the contract. Application/Conclusion: You obtain legal ownership only when the purchase is completed (i.e., the price under the contract is fully paid); before that moment you have possession but not ownership.

instruction: I received the goods but haven't paid the last installment yet. Do I at least have a right to use them?
input: Provided that the right to possession and use shall be deemed to be created at the time of receiving such goods by him or her.
output: According to Section 628 (proviso). Rule: The right to possession and use is created at the time the hirer receives the goods. Application/Conclusion: Even though ownership passes only after full payment, you have the legal right to possess and use the goods from the moment you receive them under the hire-purchase agreement.

instruction: Are there certain terms that automatically apply to every hire-purchase contract even if the written contract says otherwise?
input:
. Consequences of formation of hire-purchase contract :
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in the contract, the following 362 terms and conditions shall be deemed to be inherent in the hire purchase contract concluded between the parties:
output: According to Section 627(1) preface. Rule: Certain terms and conditions are deemed inherent in every hire-purchase contract notwithstanding anything in the contract to the contrary. Application/Conclusion: You cannot fully contract out of statutory implied terms — the listed implied terms (such as possession rights, freedom from charge, satisfactory quality, etc.) automatically apply unless specific statutory exceptions apply.

instruction: If the contract itself notes a defect in the goods, can I still complain later about that defect?
input: The hire-purchase contract itself has a stipulation about the defect in the quality of the goods,
output: According to Section 627(2)(b). Rule: If the hire-purchase contract expressly stipulates the defect, the owner is not liable for that quality defect. Application/Conclusion: If the defect was expressly disclosed in the contract, you are generally precluded from later claiming against the owner for that specific defect; the contract's disclosure limits the owner's liability.

instruction: I was promised after-sales sale transfer to me. Does that mean I already own the item?
input: The ownership of the goods related to a hire-purchase contract shall be transferred to the hirer upon completion of the purchase according to the hire-purchase price determined in accordance with the contract concluded under this Chapter.
output: According to Section 628. Rule: Ownership transfers only upon completion of purchase as determined by the contract (i.e., full payment). Application/Conclusion: A mere promise of eventual transfer does not create ownership until the contract's condition (completion of purchase, usually payment of last installment) is met; until then you have the right to possession and use but not ownership.

instruction: I saw a sample and it matched, but the contract description differed. Which controls?
input: Provided that if the sample is also specified in the contract, the matching of the quality of such goods with that of the sample shall not suﬀice, and it shall be matched with the description of the contract at the time of transferring the whole of the goods.
output: According to Section 627(4) proviso. Rule: If both sample and description are in the contract, matching the sample alone is insufficient; goods must match the contractual description at transfer. Application/Conclusion: The contract description controls — if the delivered goods match the sample but not the written description in the contract, the owner may still be in breach because the goods must conform to the contract's description at transfer.

instruction: Can I transfer my hire-purchase right to someone else if the owner doesn't reply to my written request?
input:
part (1) : , give or refuse to give consent within fifteen days
of the date of the written request made by the hirer with the intention of getting
consent from the owner to transfer his or her right, interest or liability to another
person, and if consent cannot be obtained within such a period, the owner shall
be deemed to have refused the consent.
output: According to Section 633(1). Rule: If the owner does not give or refuse consent within fifteen days of the hirer's written request to transfer rights, the owner is deemed to have refused. Application/Conclusion: Because the owner failed to respond within 15 days, the law treats that as a refusal of consent — you cannot treat it as approval and must follow the procedure for a refusal (e.g., challenge it in court).

instruction: The owner refused to allow me to transfer my hire-purchase interest. What can I do next?
input:
Section no 633  part (3) : If the owner of goods makes a refusal pursuant to
sub section (2), the hirer shall, within thirty-five days, make a lawsuit in the
court to have the refusal voided, and if the court issues an order to the effect
that the refusal is not reasonable, the consent shall be deemed to have been
obtained from the owner of goods.
output: According to Section 633(3). Rule: When an owner refuses consent, the hirer must file a lawsuit within thirty-five days to have that refusal set aside; if the court finds the refusal unreasonable, consent is deemed obtained. Application/Conclusion: You should file a suit within 35 days challenging the owner's refusal. If the court agrees the refusal was unreasonable, the court will treat the owner's consent as given.

instruction: If my hire-purchase right is transferred by operation of law (e.g., inheritance), can the owner still stop that transfer under this Section?
input:
Section no 633  part (4) : If the right, interest or liability of the hirer is
transferred to another person by operation of law, nothing contained in this
Section shall be deemed to bar the exercise or performance of such right, interest
or liability.
output: According to Section 633(4). Rule: Transfers of the hirer's rights, interests or liabilities that occur by operation of law are not barred by this Section. Application/Conclusion: If your right transfers automatically by law (for example, by inheritance or merger), the owner cannot use the consent rule in Section 633 to prevent that transfer — the transferred rights or liabilities can be exercised or performed.

instruction: I used the hired equipment in a way that breaks the hire-purchase terms. Will I be held responsible?
input:
Section no 634 . To be liable for use of goods contrary to terms and
conditions : If the hirer uses the goods under the hire-purchase contract contrary to the terms and conditions of such a contract, the hirer shall be liable
therefor.
output: According to Section 634. Rule: A hirer is liable if they use the goods contrary to the contract's terms and conditions. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you used the equipment in a way that breaches the hire-purchase agreement, you are legally liable for that misuse and may face remedies from the owner.

instruction: The owner asked me where the hired goods are and how much benefit I got from them. Do I have to reply?
input:
Section no 635 . Information of actual condition of goods to be given :
If the owner of goods demands the hirer using the goods under the hire purchase
contract to give information as to the place where the concerned goods are
situated and the state of benefits accrued from 367 such goods, the hirer shall
give information thereof to the owner within fifteen days.
output: According to Section 635. Rule: The hirer must provide information about the goods' location and benefits derived when demanded by the owner, within fifteen days. Application/Conclusion: You are required to respond and give that information within 15 days of the owner's demand — failing to do so would breach the provision.

instruction: I missed more than one weekly installment. How much advance notice must the owner give before terminating the hire-purchase contract?
input:
Section no 636  clause (a) : If the installment is to be paid within or less
than an interval of one week, a period of one week.
output: According to Section 636(a). Rule: When installments are due at intervals of one week or less, the owner must give one week's advance notice to terminate. Application/Conclusion: For weekly (or more frequent) instalments, the owner must provide at least one week's notice before terminating the contract.

instruction: If my installments are monthly, what advance notice does the owner need to terminate the contract for default?
input:
Section no 636  clause (b) : In the cases other than that referred to in clause
(a), a period of fifteen days.
output: According to Section 636(b). Rule: For installments with intervals longer than one week (i.e., cases other than clause (a)), the owner must give fifteen days' advance notice. Application/Conclusion: If your installments are not weekly (for example, monthly), the owner must give at least 15 days' notice before terminating the hire-purchase contract for default.

instruction: I paid the missed installment and interest before the owner's notice period ended. Can the owner still terminate the contract?
input:
Section no 636  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if the hirer makes payment of the installment and the interest, if any, to
be accrued thereon according to the hire-purchase contract before the expiry of
the period for giving an advance notice pursuant to the said sub-section, the
hire-purchase contract cannot be terminated.
output: According to Section 636(2). Rule: If the hirer pays the due installment and any accrued interest before the notice period expires, the owner cannot terminate the contract. Application/Conclusion: Because you paid the overdue installment and interest before the advance notice period ended, the owner may not terminate the hire-purchase contract.

instruction: The owner says I breached Section 629 or didn't answer Section 635 requests and wants to end the contract — how much notice must they give?
input:
Section no 636  part (3) : If the hirer fails to perform the hire-purchase
contract or the terms and conditions referred to in Section 629 or 635, the
concerned owner of goods may terminate the hire-purchase contract, by giving
a notice of at least fifteen days.
output: According to Section 636(3). Rule: If the hirer fails to perform the contract or terms in Section 629 or 635, the owner may terminate the contract but must give at least fifteen days' notice. Application/Conclusion: The owner can terminate for those breaches, but they must provide you with at least 15 days' notice before doing so.

instruction: If the owner terminates the contract, can they come take the goods from wherever they are?
input:
Section no 636  part (4) (a) : To take back the goods wherever and in
whatever situation they may be, and if the goods cannot be so taken back, to
forfeit them,
output: According to Section 636(4)(a). Rule: Upon termination under the relevant subsections, the owner may repossess the goods wherever they are; if repossession is impossible, the owner may forfeit them. Application/Conclusion: Yes — after proper termination, the owner has the right to retake the goods wherever they are, and if they cannot be reclaimed, the owner may forfeit them.

instruction: After termination, the owner says they will keep some of the money I've already paid. Can they do that and must they tell me the remainder?
input:
Section no 636  part (4) (b) : To determine the amount of rent that he or
she can recover out of the amount paid in lieu of such goods, and inform the
hirer to take back of the exceeding amount,
output: According to Section 636(4)(b). Rule: The owner may determine rent recoverable from amounts already paid and must inform the hirer to take back any excess. Application/Conclusion: The owner can deduct rent they consider recoverable from payments you've made, but they must tell you the amount and return any surplus to you.

instruction: Can the owner keep my deposit if they terminate the hire-purchase contract?
input:
Section no 636  part (4) (c) : To forfeit the amount, if any, taken as a deposit
from the hirer at the time of hiring the goods,
output: According to Section 636(4)(c). Rule: Upon termination, the owner may forfeit any deposit taken from the hirer when hiring the goods. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the owner has the statutory power to forfeit the deposit paid at the time of hiring if they validly terminate the contract.

instruction: I only found out the owner refused my transfer today. How many days do I have to file a court challenge?
input:
Section no 633  part (3) : If the owner of goods makes a refusal pursuant to
sub section (2), the hirer shall, within thirty-five days, make a lawsuit in the
court to have the refusal voided, and if the court issues an order to the effect
that the refusal is not reasonable, the consent shall be deemed to have been
obtained from the owner of goods.
output: According to Section 633(3). Rule: The hirer must file a lawsuit within thirty-five days after the owner's refusal to have that refusal declared void. Application/Conclusion: You must begin court proceedings within 35 days of the owner's refusal if you want the refusal set aside — missing that period risks losing the challenge.

instruction: When is an owner's silence treated as a refusal to give consent to transfer?
input:
part (1) : , give or refuse to give consent within fifteen days
of the date of the written request made by the hirer with the intention of getting
consent from the owner to transfer his or her right, interest or liability to another
person, and if consent cannot be obtained within such a period, the owner shall
be deemed to have refused the consent.
output: According to Section 633(1). Rule: If the owner does not give or refuse consent within 15 days of the hirer's written request, the owner is deemed to have refused. Application/Conclusion: Silence after 15 days counts as a refusal — you should treat it as such and consider the 35-day court remedy in Section 633(3).

instruction: If goods cannot be physically taken back after termination, what can the owner do?
input:
Section no 636  part (4) (a) : To take back the goods wherever and in
whatever situation they may be, and if the goods cannot be so taken back, to
forfeit them,
output: According to Section 636(4)(a). Rule: The owner may repossess goods wherever they are; if repossession is not possible, the owner may forfeit the goods. Application/Conclusion: If the goods cannot be retrieved after termination, the owner is entitled to forfeit them under this provision.

instruction: What exactly is meant by 'liable for use of goods contrary to terms' in the hire-purchase context?
input:
Section no 634 . To be liable for use of goods contrary to terms and
conditions : If the hirer uses the goods under the hire-purchase contract contrary to the terms and conditions of such a contract, the hirer shall be liable
therefor.
output: According to Section 634. Rule: The hirer becomes legally liable when they use the hired goods in ways that breach the contract's terms and conditions. Application/Conclusion: In practical terms, any use of the goods that violates the hire-purchase agreement (as written) makes the hirer legally responsible for resulting consequences or losses.

instruction: In simple words, what counts as 'goods' under these rules?
input: Section no 624 part (1) : “Goods” means any movable property that may be let for hire for the purpose of its possession and use.
output: According to Section 624(1), the rule is that 'goods' are any movable property that can be let for hire for possession and use. Applied to your situation, everyday movable items such as vehicles, machinery, appliances or equipment that can be hired for someone to possess and use fall within 'goods' — so those are covered by the hire‑purchase rules.

instruction: Who exactly is a 'hirer' under this law? Short answer.
input: Section no 624 part (2) : “Hirer” means a person who takes any goods on hire for possession and use according to the hire-purchase contract and also includes his or her successor in the event of his or her death or other third person to receive such goods under the contract.
output: According to Section 624(2), the rule is that a 'hirer' is the person who takes goods on hire for possession and use under a hire‑purchase contract, and this term also covers the hirer's successor (after death) or any third person entitled to receive the goods under the contract. Applied: if you sign a hire‑purchase agreement you are the 'hirer' and your legal successors who inherit that right are treated as hirers too.

instruction: What specific items must be written into a hire‑purchase contract? (List the essentials.)
input:
Section no 625 clause (a) : The goods and short description thereof,
Section no 625 clause (b) : Hire-purchase price of the goods,
Section no 625 clause (c) : Cash price of the goods,
Section no 625 clause (d) : The date of commencement of the contract,
Section no 625 clause (e) : The amount of installment payable by the hirer to the owner of goods and the number of installments,
Section no 625 clause (f) : The due date for payment of each installment and the mode of payment,
Section no 625 clause (g) : The person and place for the payment of amount pursuant to clause (f).
output: According to Section 625(1)(a)-(g), the rule is that a hire‑purchase contract must specify: (a) the goods and a short description; (b) the hire‑purchase price; (c) the cash price; (d) the contract commencement date; (e) installment amount and number; (f) due dates and mode of payment; and (g) the person and place for payment. Applied: before you sign, check the contract contains each of these items — if any are missing you may have grounds for relief under Section 625(3).

instruction: If the seller allows payment by bank transfer instead of cash, does the contract need to say that?
input: Section no 625 part (2) : If an installment can be paid by any mode other than cash pursuant to clause (f) of sub-section (1), a brief description thereof shall be specified in the hire-purchase contract.
output: According to Section 625(2), the rule is that if installments may be paid by a mode other than cash (per clause (f)), the contract must give a brief description of that alternative mode. Applied to your case, yes — if the owner accepts bank transfer, cheque or any non‑cash method, the hire‑purchase contract should briefly state that method (e.g., 'bank transfer to account X').

instruction: They left out the cash price when we signed. Can I ask the court to cancel the contract?
input: Section no 625 part (3) : If a hire-purchase contract has been made without specifying any of the terms and conditions referred to in this 361 Section, the hirer may sue for the rescission of such contract, and if the court thinks that nonspecification of any of such terms and conditions in the contract is detrimental to the hirer, the court may rescind such contract or issue any such other order as it thinks fit.
output: According to Section 625(3), the rule is that if a hire‑purchase contract omits any of the required terms, the hirer may sue for rescission; the court, if it finds the omission detrimental to the hirer, may rescind the contract or make other appropriate orders. Applied: because the cash price was omitted, you can sue to have the contract rescinded or seek another remedy — the court will decide if the omission is detrimental and what to order.

instruction: Does the hire‑purchase price include the deposit or down payment?
input: Section no 625 part (1) : “Hire purchase price” means the total amount to be paid by the hirer to purchase or acquire the goods upon payment of the full price of the goods, and also includes an amount to be paid as deposit or down payment.
output: According to Section 625(1), the rule is that 'hire purchase price' means the total amount payable to acquire the goods on full payment and explicitly includes any deposit or down payment. Applied: any deposit or down payment you paid counts toward the hire‑purchase price and should be reflected in the total sum the contract states.

instruction: What does 'cash price' mean here? One-line please.
input: Section no 625 part (2) : “Cash price” means the price to be paid in cash by which the hirer may purchase any goods.
output: According to Section 625(2), the rule is that 'cash price' is the price payable in cash by which the hirer may purchase the goods. Applied: this is the lump‑sum cash purchase price you could pay instead of buying by installments.

instruction: We signed several documents with owner, investor and a surety. Are these treated separately or together?
input: Section no 626 . Conclusion of more than one contract to be deemed as : conclusion of single contract: (1) If several contracts are concluded in connection with the making of a hire-purchase contract, namely a contract between the hirer and the owner of any goods, a contract between a surety guaranteeing the payment of installments of the hire-purchase price of such goods or investor and the owner of such goods on the condition of entering into a hire-purchase contract, or in the case of any bailed or pledged goods, a contract between the bailor and the bailee of such goods, the contracts shall be deemed to be a single contract for the purposes of this Chapter.
output: According to Section 626(1), the rule is that several contracts connected with a hire‑purchase (e.g., hirer‑owner, surety‑owner, investor‑owner, or bailor‑bailee for pledged goods) shall be treated as a single contract for the Chapter's purposes. Applied: even if you signed multiple documents with different parties, the law may treat them all as one integrated hire‑purchase contract — meaning rights and obligations can be read together.

instruction: If the related contracts were signed on different days, which date matters?
input: Section no 626 part (2) : If the contracts referred to in sub-section (1) are concluded at different dates, the latest date shall be regarded as the date of the formation of the contract.
output: According to Section 626(2), the rule is that when the several connected contracts are concluded on different dates, the latest date is regarded as the contract formation date. Applied: if you signed the owner‑hirer agreement on Jan 1 and a surety agreement on Jan 10, Jan 10 would be treated as the formation date for purposes under this Chapter.

instruction: My relative inherits my hire‑purchase contract when I die — is that covered?
input: Section no 624 part (2) : “Hirer” means a person who takes any goods on hire for possession and use according to the hire-purchase contract and also includes his or her successor in the event of his or her death or other third person to receive such goods under the contract.
output: According to Section 624(2), the rule is that the definition of 'hirer' includes a successor on the hirer's death or any third person entitled to receive the goods under the contract. Applied: yes — your relative (successor) who is entitled under the contract steps into the position of 'hirer' and the hire‑purchase rules continue to apply to them.

instruction: Does the contract have to state who and where payments are made? I'm worried they didn't put that in.
input: Section no 625 clause (g) : The person and place for the payment of amount pursuant to clause (f).
output: According to Section 625(1)(g), the rule is that the hire‑purchase contract must specify the person and place for payment of amounts due under clause (f). Applied: if the contract omits the person/place for payment you can object — omission of required terms may allow you to seek rescission or other relief under Section 625(3).

instruction: Must the contract show when the hire starts, or can they leave that blank?
input: Section no 625 clause (d) : The date of commencement of the contract,
output: According to Section 625(1)(d), the rule is that the contract must state the date of commencement. Applied: the start date cannot be left blank without risking invalidity or a court ordering relief if that omission is detrimental to the hirer.

instruction: They didn't write how many installments there will be. Is that a problem?
input: Section no 625 clause (e) : The amount of installment payable by the hirer to the owner of goods and the number of installments,
output: According to Section 625(1)(e), the rule is that the contract must specify both the installment amount and the number of installments. Applied: omission of the number or amount of installments is a required‑term failure — you may sue for rescission or other remedies under Section 625(3) if that omission is detrimental.

instruction: When should due dates and mode of payment be written down? I'm asking because seller only told me verbally.
input: Section no 625 clause (f) : The due date for payment of each installment and the mode of payment,
output: According to Section 625(1)(f), the rule is that the contract must specify the due date for each installment and the mode of payment. Applied: verbal statements alone are insufficient — the due dates and payment mode should be in the written contract; otherwise you may have remedies if that omission harms you.

instruction: If goods were pledged and there is a separate bailor‑bailee contract, does that count as part of the hire‑purchase deal?
input: Section no 626 . Conclusion of more than one contract to be deemed as : conclusion of single contract: (1) If several contracts are concluded in connection with the making of a hire-purchase contract, namely a contract between the hirer and the owner of any goods, a contract between a surety guaranteeing the payment of installments of the hire-purchase price of such goods or investor and the owner of such goods on the condition of entering into a hire-purchase contract, or in the case of any bailed or pledged goods, a contract between the bailor and the bailee of such goods, the contracts shall be deemed to be a single contract for the purposes of this Chapter.
output: According to Section 626(1), the rule is that agreements connected with a hire‑purchase — including bailor‑bailee contracts for bailed or pledged goods — are to be treated as a single contract. Applied: yes — a separate bailor‑bailee agreement tied to the hire‑purchase will be regarded as part of the overall hire‑purchase contract for legal purposes.

instruction: They made a hire‑purchase agreement but didn't describe the non‑cash payment method. Can I get help from the court?
input: Section no 625 part (2) : If an installment can be paid by any mode other than cash pursuant to clause (f) of sub-section (1), a brief description thereof shall be specified in the hire-purchase contract.
output: According to Section 625(2), the rule is that if installments may be paid by a non‑cash mode, the contract must briefly specify that mode. Applied: if the contract fails to describe the agreed non‑cash mode, you can point to this requirement — and if the omission is detrimental, you may seek rescission or relief under Section 625(3).

instruction: Do I get a copy of the hire‑purchase contract after signing, free of charge?
input: part (3) : The owner of the goods shall provide one copy of the contract concluded pursuant to this Section to the hirer free of cost as soon as the contract is so concluded.
output: According to Section 624(3), the rule is that the owner must provide one copy of the concluded contract to the hirer free of cost as soon as the contract is concluded. Applied: you are entitled to receive a free copy immediately after signing — if the owner refuses, you can insist on receiving it and may have grounds to complain to the appropriate authority.

instruction: If I signed a hire-purchase and the hirer goes bankrupt, what happens to the goods?
input: Status of hired goods in case of hirer becoming bankrupt : (1) If the court holds, during the currency of a hire-purchase contract, that the hirer has become a bankrupt or is likely to be a bankrupt according to the laws in force, and as a consequence thereof, the liquidator or any other equally competent person taking control of the property of such a person shall exercise and fulfill the same rights and obligations as the successor has with regard to the goods under the hire-purchase contract.
output:
According to Section 638(1):
Rule: If a court determines during a hire-purchase contract that the hirer is bankrupt or likely to be bankrupt, the liquidator (or equivalent person taking control) shall exercise and fulfill the same rights and obligations as the successor regarding the goods under the hire-purchase contract.
Application/Conclusion: In your case, once bankruptcy is determined by the court, the liquidator steps into the position of the hirer/successor for purposes of the hire-purchase goods — they have the same rights and duties over those goods as the successor would.

instruction: Can the liquidator transfer my hired goods to someone else while bankruptcy is pending?
input: Section no 638  part (2) : If the hirer becomes bankrupt and the bankruptcy proceedings are under consideration in any court, the liquidator or 371 the person exercising the right equal to that of the liquidator pursuant to subsection (1) may, having obtained permission of such a court, transfer the goods under the hire-purchase contract to another person in any manner, and if such 197 goods are transferred in such a manner, the transferee of the goods shall exercise and fulfill the rights and obligations under the hire-purchase contract as if the transferee were the hirer.
output:
According to Section 638(2):
Rule: When bankruptcy proceedings are under consideration, the liquidator (or equivalent) may transfer the hire-purchase goods to another person only after obtaining the court's permission; the transferee then assumes the rights and obligations as if they were the hirer.
Application/Conclusion: The liquidator cannot lawfully transfer your hired goods to someone else without first getting court permission. If the transfer occurs with court permission, the new owner takes on the contract rights and duties as if they were the hirer.

instruction: How long do I have to sue if I'm harmed by an action under this Chapter?
input: Section no 639 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years after the date of accrual of the cause of action.
output:
According to Section 639:
Rule: A person aggrieved by any act or action under this Chapter must file a lawsuit within two years from the date the cause of action accrues.
Application/Conclusion: You have two years from when you first discovered (or when the cause accrued) to bring a lawsuit under this Chapter. If you delay beyond two years, you risk being time-barred.

instruction: Can I employ a 15-year-old at my shop?
input: Section no 640 . Employment in work : (1) Any person who has attained at least fourteen years of age may be employed in a work with his or her consent. Provided that a person who has not attained sixteen years of age shall not be employed in a hazardous business or work.
output:
According to Section 640(1):
Rule: Persons aged 14 or older may be employed with their consent; however, anyone under 16 must not be employed in hazardous businesses or work.
Application/Conclusion: You may employ a 15-year-old in your shop provided they consent and the work is not hazardous. If the job involves dangerous tasks, you cannot lawfully employ them.

instruction: Do I have to follow any other rules when hiring someone under 14–16 years?
input: Section no 640  part (2) : While employing any one pursuant to sub-section (1), the provisions of this Chapter shall be complied with, or caused to be complied with.
output:
According to Section 640(2):
Rule: When employing someone under subsection (1), the employer must comply with the provisions of this Chapter.
Application/Conclusion: If you hire someone aged 14 or older, you must ensure all relevant protections and requirements set out in this Chapter (wages, safety, working hours, etc.) are satisfied.

instruction: I asked my helper to work and I didn't pay. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 641 . Wages to be paid : (1) While employing any one in any work pursuant to Section 640, the employer shall have to pay the wages in proportion to the work except in cases where the employee voluntarily agrees to work without wages.
output:
According to Section 641(1):
Rule: Employers must pay wages in proportion to the work when employing under Section 640, except where the employee voluntarily agrees to work without wages.
Application/Conclusion: You generally must pay your helper proportionally for their work. The only exception is if the helper truly and voluntarily agreed to work without wages — such agreements are the exception, not the rule.

instruction: We agreed a wage rate when hiring — does the employer have to pay that exact rate?
input: Section no 641  part (2) : While paying the wages pursuant to sub-section (1), if any particular rate of wages is specified with the consent of the employer and the employee, the wages shall be paid accordingly and if no such rate is specified, the wages for the work shall be paid according to the rate prevailing in the place of work.
output:
According to Section 641(2):
Rule: If employer and employee agree a specific wage rate, the employer must pay that rate; if no rate is agreed, wages are to follow the prevailing rate at the place of work.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you and the employee agreed on a wage, you must pay that agreed rate. If there was no agreement, you must pay the local prevailing wage.

instruction: Can I delay paying wages until later, or must I pay immediately after they work?
input: Section no 641  part (3) : Except as otherwise agreed upon between the employer and the employee pursuant to sub-section (1) or (2), the wages shall be paid upon completion of the work.
output:
According to Section 641(3):
Rule: Unless the employer and employee have otherwise agreed under subsections (1) or (2), wages must be paid upon completion of the work.
Application/Conclusion: In absence of a different agreement, you must pay the worker when the work is completed. If you agreed a different payment timing with the employee, that agreement controls.

instruction: Are wages calculated daily or some other way?
input: Section no 641  part (4) : While determining the wages according to this Section, the wages shall be determined on the basis of each day of work except as otherwise agreed upon between the employer and the employee.
output:
According to Section 641(4):
Rule: Wages are to be determined on the basis of each day of work unless the employer and employee agree otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: By default calculate wages per day of work. If you and the employee agree to a different basis (e.g., piece rate, monthly), that agreement is permitted.

instruction: What must an employer do to protect workers from risks on the job?
input: Section no 642 . Provisions of safety measures to be made : A person shall employ another person in a work only after making provisions of adequate safety measures to prevent possible risks or danger in view of the nature of work.
output:
According to Section 642:
Rule: An employer must provide adequate safety measures, taking into account the nature of the work, before employing another person.
Application/Conclusion: You are required to put in place appropriate safety protections (equipment, procedures, training) to prevent foreseeable risks or danger before hiring someone for that work.

instruction: How many hours per day can I lawfully make a worker work under this Chapter?
input: Section no 643 . Prohibition of employing for more than eight hours : (1) A person may not employ another person in a work under this Chapter normally for more than eight hours a day.
output:
According to Section 643(1):
Rule: Under this Chapter, an employer may not normally require a person to work more than eight hours per day.
Application/Conclusion: You should not schedule or require workers covered by this Chapter to work more than eight hours a day under normal circumstances.

instruction: Can a liquidator be treated exactly like the successor regarding goods in a hire-purchase contract?
input: Status of hired goods in case of hirer becoming bankrupt : (1) If the court holds, during the currency of a hire-purchase contract, that the hirer has become a bankrupt or is likely to be a bankrupt according to the laws in force, and as a consequence thereof, the liquidator or any other equally competent person taking control of the property of such a person shall exercise and fulfill the same rights and obligations as the successor has with regard to the goods under the hire-purchase contract.
output:
According to Section 638(1):
Rule: Where a court finds the hirer bankrupt or likely to be bankrupt during a hire-purchase contract, the liquidator (or equivalent person) shall exercise and fulfill the same rights and obligations as the successor concerning the goods.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — once the court so rules, the liquidator is placed in the same legal position as the successor with respect to the hire-purchase goods and must exercise the same rights and duties.

instruction: If the transferee gets the hire-purchase goods from the liquidator, do they take over the contract?
input: Section no 638  part (2) : If the hirer becomes bankrupt and the bankruptcy proceedings are under consideration in any court, the liquidator or 371 the person exercising the right equal to that of the liquidator pursuant to subsection (1) may, having obtained permission of such a court, transfer the goods under the hire-purchase contract to another person in any manner, and if such 197 goods are transferred in such a manner, the transferee of the goods shall exercise and fulfill the rights and obligations under the hire-purchase contract as if the transferee were the hirer.
output:
According to Section 638(2):
Rule: With court permission, the liquidator may transfer hire-purchase goods to another; the transferee must then exercise and fulfill the contract's rights and obligations as if they were the hirer.
Application/Conclusion: If a transferee acquires the goods with the court's permission, they step into the hirer's shoes and must honor the rights and duties under the hire-purchase contract.

instruction: I just found out this week my employer withheld my wages last month. How many years do I have to take legal action?
input: Section no 639 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years after the date of accrual of the cause of action.
output:
According to Section 639:
Rule: An aggrieved person must file suit within two years from the date the cause of action accrues.
Application/Conclusion: You generally have two years from when the unpaid wage claim accrued (when payment was due or you discovered non-payment) to file a lawsuit under this Chapter. Act promptly to preserve your rights.

instruction: Under which section is the 'statute of limitation' for actions under this Chapter stated?
input: Section no 639 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years after the date of accrual of the cause of action.
output:
According to Section 639:
Rule: Section 639 sets a two-year limitation period for bringing causes of action under this Chapter.
Application/Conclusion: The statute of limitation for aggrieved persons under this Chapter is explicitly provided in Section 639 — two years from accrual.

instruction: My friend is 14 and wants to work in a factory. Is that permitted?
input: Section no 640 . Employment in work : (1) Any person who has attained at least fourteen years of age may be employed in a work with his or her consent. Provided that a person who has not attained sixteen years of age shall not be employed in a hazardous business or work.
output:
According to Section 640(1):
Rule: Persons aged 14 or older may be employed with consent, but those under 16 must not be employed in hazardous work.
Application/Conclusion: Your 14-year-old friend may work in a factory only if the work is not hazardous and they consent. If the factory tasks are dangerous, employment would be prohibited until at least age 16 (for hazardous work).

instruction: I and my worker agreed to a monthly lump sum. Does the law allow not calculating daily wages?
input: Section no 641  part (4) : While determining the wages according to this Section, the wages shall be determined on the basis of each day of work except as otherwise agreed upon between the employer and the employee.
output:
According to Section 641(4):
Rule: Wages are to be determined daily unless the employer and employee agree otherwise.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you and the worker mutually agreed to a monthly lump sum, that agreement is permitted and you need not calculate wages strictly on a daily basis.

instruction: Can I transfer my hire-purchase rights to my cousin if I need to leave the country?
input: Section no 633 . Right of hirer to transfer his or her right and interest : (1) The hirer may, with the consent of the owner of the hired goods, transfer to another person the right, interest or liability in the goods hired by him or her according to the hire-purchase contract and such other 366 right, interest or liability as may be accrued to him or her under such a contract.
output: According to Section 633(1)... Rule: The hirer may transfer the right, interest or liability in the hired goods to another person only with the consent of the owner. Application/Conclusion: You can transfer your hire-purchase rights to your cousin, but only if the owner of the goods expressly consents. Without the owner’s consent the transfer is not permitted under this provision.

instruction: If I decide to pay off the remaining price now and end the contract, am I entitled to any discount?
input: Section no 631  part (2) : While terminating the contract pursuant to sub-section (1), the hirer shall also be entitled to the discount of any kind, if any.
output: According to Section 631(2)... Rule: When the hirer terminates the contract by paying the hire-purchase price or outstanding installment (as per subsection (1)), the hirer is entitled to any discount that may apply. Application/Conclusion: If you pay off the remaining price to terminate the contract, you are entitled to receive whatever discount the contract provides (if any). Check the contract for available discounts; they must be applied when you terminate under subsection (1).

instruction: My hired motorcycle was damaged while I was using it — who is responsible if I didn't take care?
input: Section no 628  part (3) : If such goods are lost or damaged because of the failure to take care of (herbichar) and maintain them pursuant to sub-section (2), the hirer shall be liable therefor.
output: According to Section 628(3)... Rule: If the hired goods are lost or damaged due to the hirer’s failure to take reasonable care and maintain them as required, the hirer is liable for that loss or damage. Application/Conclusion: Because the damage occurred from a failure to take care, you (the hirer) would be legally liable to the owner for the loss or damage under this provision.

instruction: What exactly does the hirer need to do to 'take reasonable care' of hired goods?
input: Section no 628  part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the hirepurchase contract, the hirer shall take reasonable care of (herbichar) and maintain the goods related to such a contract as if the goods were those owned by himself or herself.
output: According to Section 628(2)... Rule: Unless the contract says otherwise, the hirer must take reasonable care of and maintain the hired goods as if they were his or her own property. Application/Conclusion: In practice this means you must look after, service, and not misuse the goods to the standard you would follow for your own property. If your contract has special terms, follow those; otherwise the default is care equivalent to ownership.

instruction: I want to end the hire-purchase by paying off the outstanding amount — how much notice must I give?
input: Section no 631 . Termination of contract by paying installment : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the hire-purchase contract, the hirer may, during the currency of the contract, terminate the contract by making payment of the hire-purchase price of the goods or outstanding installment, and giving an advance written notice of at least fifteen days to the owner of the goods. 365
output: According to Section 631(1)... Rule: The hirer may terminate the contract by paying the hire-purchase price or outstanding installments, provided the hirer gives at least fifteen days' advance written notice to the owner, unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: You must give a written notice at least 15 days before termination when ending the contract by paying off the amount, unless your hire-purchase contract sets a different notice requirement.

instruction: How and when do I have to pay installments under a hire-purchase agreement?
input: Section no 630 . Installment to be paid : The hirer shall pay the amount of installment as determined in the hire-purchase contract in consideration for the hired goods, within such period and according to such mode as specified in the contract.
output: According to Section 630... Rule: The hirer must pay installments as determined by the hire-purchase contract, within the time periods and by the methods specified in that contract. Application/Conclusion: Your payment obligations follow whatever schedule and payment method are written in your specific hire-purchase agreement. Check the contract to know exact due dates and modes of payment.

instruction: I returned goods early and I had paid only 40% of the price. The owner demands full remaining balance. Is that correct?
input: Section no 632  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if the hirer has already paid more than half of the hire purchase price on or before the termination of the hire-purchase contract, the hirer shall not be required to pay any more amount, and if the hirer has paid less than half the amount, the hirer shall pay up to the half of the amount.
output: According to Section 632(3)... Rule: If the hirer has paid more than half of the hire-purchase price at or before termination, no further payment is required; if the hirer has paid less than half, the hirer must pay up to half of the hire-purchase price. Application/Conclusion: Since you paid only 40% (less than half), you are required to pay up to half of the total hire-purchase price. The owner cannot demand the entire remaining balance beyond that requirement under this subsection.

instruction: I’ve already paid 60% of the hire-purchase price and want to return the goods — do I have to pay anything more?
input: Section no 632  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), if the hirer has already paid more than half of the hire purchase price on or before the termination of the hire-purchase contract, the hirer shall not be required to pay any more amount, and if the hirer has paid less than half the amount, the hirer shall pay up to the half of the amount.
output: According to Section 632(3)... Rule: If the hirer has paid more than half the hire-purchase price at or before termination, the hirer is not required to pay any further amount. Application/Conclusion: Because you have paid 60%, which is more than half, you are not required to pay any additional hire-purchase price when returning the goods under this provision.

instruction: If I want to terminate by returning the goods, what must I do before termination?
input: Section no 632  part (2) : Prior to terminating the contract pursuant to sub section (1), the hirer shall deliver or return the hired goods to the owner according to the hire-purchase contract and also pay the amount, if any, due and payable by the hirer to the owner under the contract on or before the termination of the contract.
output: According to Section 632(2)... Rule: Before terminating by returning the goods, the hirer must return the hired goods as required by the contract and pay any amounts due to the owner on or before termination. Application/Conclusion: You must physically deliver the goods back to the owner in the manner the contract specifies and settle any outstanding amounts due before the termination is effective.

instruction: Do I need to give advance written notice to the owner if I plan to return the goods to end the hire-purchase?
input: Section no 632 .Termination of contract by returning goods : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the hirer may, at any time prior to the payment of the last installment as determined according to the hire-purchase contract for the goods, terminate the contract by giving a written notice to the owner of goods at least fifteen days in advance.
output: According to Section 632(1)... Rule: The hirer may terminate the contract by returning the goods at any time before the last installment, but must give at least fifteen days' written notice to the owner unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Yes — you must give at least 15 days' advance written notice to the owner before terminating by returning the goods, unless your contract states a different rule.

instruction: I paid 55% and want to return the item — does that free me from other contractual charges like late fees?
input: Section no 632  part (4) : Nothing contained in sub-section (3) shall be deemed to release the hirer from payment of such other amount, charge or due as may be payable according to the hire-purchase contract.
output: According to Section 632(4)... Rule: Even if subsection (3) limits further hire-purchase price payments, that limitation does not release the hirer from paying other amounts, charges or dues that the hire-purchase contract requires. Application/Conclusion: Although paying more than half may prevent further hire-purchase price liability, you remain responsible for any other contractual charges (e.g., fees, damages, arrears) that your contract requires you to pay.

instruction: Are hired goods considered a bailment until ownership changes?
input: Section no 628  part (1) : The status of the goods hired under a hire-purchase contract shall be as of the bailment until the transfer of their ownership pursuant to Section
output: According to Section 628(1)... Rule: The goods hired under a hire-purchase contract have the status of bailment until ownership is transferred. Application/Conclusion: This means that, in legal treatment, the hired goods remain in bailment (not yet owned by the hirer) until the ownership transfer occurs as provided by the relevant section.

instruction: My contract says I cannot terminate early. Can I still return the goods before the last installment?
input: Section no 632 .Termination of contract by returning goods : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the hirer may, at any time prior to the payment of the last installment as determined according to the hire-purchase contract for the goods, terminate the contract by giving a written notice to the owner of goods at least fifteen days in advance.
output: According to Section 632(1)... Rule: The hirer may terminate by returning goods prior to the last installment except where the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: If your hire-purchase contract specifically prohibits early termination or sets different terms, those contractual provisions will control. You can only terminate early under this statutory rule when your contract does not otherwise restrict that right.

instruction: I sent back the hired item without giving 15 days' notice. Is my termination effective immediately?
input: Section no 632 .Termination of contract by returning goods : (1) Except as otherwise provided for in the contract, the hirer may, at any time prior to the payment of the last installment as determined according to the hire-purchase contract for the goods, terminate the contract by giving a written notice to the owner of goods at least fifteen days in advance.
output: According to Section 632(1)... Rule: Termination by returning goods requires at least fifteen days' written notice unless the contract provides otherwise. Application/Conclusion: Returning the item without giving the required 15 days' written notice would not meet the statutory requirement here (unless your contract allows immediate return), so the termination may not be effective according to this provision.

instruction: Who is supposed to maintain the hired refrigerator — me or the owner?
input: Section no 628  part (2) : Except as otherwise provided for in the hirepurchase contract, the hirer shall take reasonable care of (herbichar) and maintain the goods related to such a contract as if the goods were those owned by himself or herself.
output: According to Section 628(2)... Rule: The hirer is required to take reasonable care of and maintain the hired goods as if they were the hirer’s own, unless the contract specifies otherwise. Application/Conclusion: You (the hirer) are responsible for normal care and maintenance of the refrigerator, unless your hire-purchase contract assigns maintenance duties differently.

instruction: Can the owner refuse my proposed transfer of the hire-purchase contract to someone else?
input: Section no 633 . Right of hirer to transfer his or her right and interest : (1) The hirer may, with the consent of the owner of the hired goods, transfer to another person the right, interest or liability in the goods hired by him or her according to the hire-purchase contract and such other 366 right, interest or liability as may be accrued to him or her under such a contract.
output: According to Section 633(1)... Rule: The hirer may transfer rights or liabilities only with the consent of the owner. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the owner can refuse the transfer, because the statutory permission to transfer depends on the owner's consent.

instruction: Can the owner enter my house to seize hired goods? They want to come with police — is that allowed?
input: part (4) (d) : To enter the house where the goods are located with the assistance of police in the course of seizing the hired goods,
output: According to Section 636(4)(d): Rule: The owner is authorised to enter the house where the hired goods are located with the assistance of police for the purpose of seizing the hired goods. Application/Conclusion: If the owner seeks to seize hired goods and they come with police assistance, that entry is authorised by the statute. If they attempt entry without police assistance, this specific clause does not authorise such entry.

instruction: Can the owner recover loss from the money I've paid if I didn't return hired goods on time?
input: Section no 636  part (4) (e) : To recover compensation from the amount paid or make a claim for the loss or damage caused from the failure to return the hired goods in time or failure to perform the contract or the terms and conditions referred to in Section 629 or 635.
output: According to Section 636(4)(e): Rule: The owner may recover compensation from the amount already paid or make a claim for loss or damage caused by failure to return the hired goods on time or failure to perform contractual terms (including those in Sections 629 or 635). Application/Conclusion: If you failed to return goods on time or breached terms, the owner can deduct compensation from amounts you have paid and may also claim for any other loss or damage.

instruction: I already paid most of the price. Can the owner still terminate the hire-purchase contract?
input: Section no 636  part (5) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, if the hirer, surety or investor has already paid at least the basic price of the hired goods, the owner of the goods shall not entitled to terminate the hire-purchase contract under this Section. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “basic price” means three-fourths of the amount if the hire-price amounts to up to fifty thousand rupees and at least half the price if the hire-purchase price is more than that amount. 369
output: According to Section 636(5): Rule: If the hirer, surety or investor has already paid at least the "basic price," the owner is not entitled to terminate the hire-purchase contract under this Section. The "basic price" is defined as three-fourths of the amount where hire-price is up to Rs.50,000 and at least half where the hire-purchase price is more than that. Application/Conclusion: Calculate whether what you've paid reaches the statutory "basic price." If it does (e.g., ≥75% for contracts ≤Rs.50,000; ≥50% for contracts >Rs.50,000), the owner cannot lawfully terminate the contract under this Section.

instruction: The owner terminated my contract even though I had paid the basic price. What can I do? Do I get my money back?
input: Section no 636  part (6) : If the owner of goods terminates the hire-purchase contract in contravention of sub-section (5), the hirer or surety shall be in discharge of all liabilities to be fulfilled according to the hire purchase contract and shall be entitled to refund the entire amount paid for the goods hired by him or her. Provided that the hirer shall return the hired goods to the concerned owner of goods.
output: According to Section 636(6): Rule: If the owner terminates the hire-purchase contract contrary to sub-section (5), the hirer (or surety) is discharged from all liabilities under the contract and is entitled to a refund of the entire amount paid for the hired goods, provided the hirer returns the goods to the owner. Application/Conclusion: Since the owner terminated in violation of Section 636(5), you are relieved of further obligations and may demand a full refund of payments made, but you must return the hired goods to the owner.

instruction: Even if the owner can't terminate due to the basic price rule, can they still claim the remaining hire-purchase price from me?
input: Section no 636  part (7) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (5), a restriction to terminate the hire-purchase contract shall not be deemed to 196 bar in any manner the right to make a claim for the hire purchase price to be received from the hirer according to the contract.
output: According to Section 636(7): Rule: The restriction on termination in sub-section (5) does not prevent the owner from claiming the hire-purchase price due from the hirer under the contract. Application/Conclusion: Even if the owner cannot terminate the contract because you paid the basic price, the owner still retains the right to pursue recovery of the hire-purchase price owed under the contract.

instruction: They say I didn't give certain information under Section 635. Can the owner still end the contract and claim for damage?
input: Section no 636  part (8) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, the owner of goods may terminate the hire-purchase contract entered into with the person who does not give information referred to in Section 635 and, if any loss or damage is caused to such goods, make claim for the same as well.
output: According to Section 636(8): Rule: The owner may terminate the hire-purchase contract with a person who fails to provide information required by Section 635, and may claim for any loss or damage to the goods. Application/Conclusion: If you failed to provide the information mandated by Section 635, the owner may lawfully terminate the contract and seek compensation for any loss or damage to the goods.

instruction: I want to know what I'm entitled to if my hired goods are forfeited. What does the law say?
input: Section no 637 . Rights of hirer in case of forfeiture of goods : (1) If the owner of the goods hired pursuant to clause (a) of sub-section (4) of Section 636 forfeits the goods, the hirer shall be entitled to refund the amount paid in relation to the hire-purchase price up to the day of forfeiture and the amount equal to the price of the goods on the day of forfeiture from the owner. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “price of the goods on the day of forfeiture” means a sum that 370 remains after making deduction of the following amount or expense from the proceeds of sale of the forfeited goods:
