output: According to Section 637(1): Rule: If the owner forfeits the goods (under clause (a) of s.636(4)), the hirer is entitled to (a) a refund of the amount paid up to the day of forfeiture and (b) an amount equal to the price of the goods on the day of forfeiture (calculated after specified deductions from sale proceeds). Application/Conclusion: If your goods are forfeited under the cited power, you should receive refund of payments up to forfeiture day plus the net proceeds amount defined as the price on that day, after permitted deductions.

instruction: What expenses can be deducted from the sale proceeds when they calculate "price of the goods on the day of forfeiture"?
input: Section no 637 part (1) : Reasonable expenses incurred in course of the forfeiture of the goods,
output: According to Section 637(1) (first listed deduction): Rule: Reasonable expenses incurred in the course of the forfeiture of the goods may be deducted from the proceeds of sale when calculating the price of the goods on the day of forfeiture. Application/Conclusion: The owner may deduct reasonable costs directly related to effecting the forfeiture (e.g., seizure actions) from sale proceeds before paying you the "price on the day of forfeiture."

instruction: Are storage and repair costs taken out from the sale proceeds before I get paid after forfeiture?
input: Section no 637 part (2) : Reasonable expenses incurred in the storage and repair and maintenance of the goods until the sale of the goods,
output: According to Section 637(1) (second listed deduction): Rule: Reasonable expenses for storage, repair and maintenance of the goods until their sale may be deducted from the proceeds when calculating the price on the day of forfeiture. Application/Conclusion: Yes — costs reasonably incurred to store, repair or maintain the goods between forfeiture and sale can be deducted from sale proceeds before the owner pays you the net amount.

instruction: Can costs of selling or transferring the goods be taken out from what I'm owed after forfeiture?
input: Section no 637 part (3) : Reasonable expenses incurred in the sale or otherwise transfer of the goods,
output: According to Section 637(1) (third listed deduction): Rule: Reasonable expenses incurred in selling or otherwise transferring the goods may be deducted from sale proceeds when determining the price on the day of forfeiture. Application/Conclusion: Costs directly related to selling/transferring the forfeited goods may be deducted before you receive your share; expect deductions for usual, reasonable sale-related expenses.

instruction: Will outstanding taxes or fees I owe on the goods be deducted from the forfeiture sale proceeds?
input: Section no 637 part (4) : The amount paid for the taxes, charges, fees or dues, if any, outstanding and payable by the hirer for the goods according to the laws in force,
output: According to Section 637(1) (fourth listed deduction): Rule: Any taxes, charges, fees or dues outstanding and payable by the hirer for the goods under law may be deducted from the proceeds when calculating the price on the day of forfeiture. Application/Conclusion: If you have unpaid taxes/fees related to the goods, those amounts can be taken out of sale proceeds before the owner pays you the net amount after forfeiture.

instruction: How soon must the owner pay me the amount after forfeiture? Is there interest if they delay?
input: Section no 637 part (2) : The amount referred to in sub-section (1) shall be paid to the hirer within thirty days after the date of forfeiture of the goods, and while making payment thereafter, an interest at the rate of ten percent per year shall also be paid.
output: According to Section 637(2): Rule: The amount due to the hirer under sub-section (1) must be paid within thirty days after the date of forfeiture; if payment is made after thirty days, interest at ten percent per year must also be paid. Application/Conclusion: The owner must pay you within 30 days of forfeiture. If they pay later, you are entitled to 10% annual interest on the overdue amount.

instruction: If the owner terminates wrongly under s.636(5), do I still owe any obligations under the hire-purchase?
input: Section no 636  part (6) : If the owner of goods terminates the hire-purchase contract in contravention of sub-section (5), the hirer or surety shall be in discharge of all liabilities to be fulfilled according to the hire purchase contract and shall be entitled to refund the entire amount paid for the goods hired by him or her. Provided that the hirer shall return the hired goods to the concerned owner of goods.
output: According to Section 636(6): Rule: Termination by the owner in contravention of sub-section (5) discharges the hirer or surety from all liabilities under the hire-purchase contract; the hirer is entitled to refund of the entire amount paid, subject to returning the goods. Application/Conclusion: If the owner unlawfully terminated despite your having paid the basic price, you are freed from contractual liabilities and can claim a full refund, but must return the goods.

Application/Conclusion: Cite Section 637 for statutory rights of a hirer when goods are forfeited.

instruction: What interest rate applies if they pay me late after forfeiture? I want a clear number.
input: Section no 637 part (2) : The amount referred to in sub-section (1) shall be paid to the hirer within thirty days after the date of forfeiture of the goods, and while making payment thereafter, an interest at the rate of ten percent per year shall also be paid.
output: According to Section 637(2): Rule: If payment under sub-section (1) is made after thirty days from the date of forfeiture, interest at the rate of ten percent per year is payable. Application/Conclusion: The statutory interest rate for late payment after the 30-day period is 10% per annum.

output: According to Section 636(4)(e): Rule: The owner may recover compensation from the amount already paid or make a separate claim for loss or damage caused by failure to return the goods on time or failure to comply with contractual terms (including provisions in Sections 629 or 635). Application/Conclusion: If you defaulted in return or performance, the owner can apply sums you've paid toward compensation and may also pursue claims for additional loss or damage.

input: Section no 636 part (8) : Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Section, the owner of goods may terminate the hire-purchase contract entered into with the person who does not give information referred to in Section 635 and, if any loss or damage is caused to such goods, make claim for the same as well.
output: According to Section 636(8): Rule: The owner may terminate the hire-purchase contract where a person fails to provide information required by Section 635, and may claim for any loss or damage to the goods. Application/Conclusion: Failure to supply the Section 635 information permits the owner to terminate the contract and seek compensation for resulting loss or damage.

instruction: If goods are forfeited, what exactly must the owner pay me and when? I want the full immediate payment rules.
input: Section no 637 . Rights of hirer in case of forfeiture of goods : (1) If the owner of the goods hired pursuant to clause (a) of sub-section (4) of Section 636 forfeits the goods, the hirer shall be entitled to refund the amount paid in relation to the hire-purchase price up to the day of forfeiture and the amount equal to the price of the goods on the day of forfeiture from the owner. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “price of the goods on the day of forfeiture” means a sum that 370 remains after making deduction of the following amount or expense from the proceeds of sale of the forfeited goods: Section no 637 part (1) : Reasonable expenses incurred in course of the forfeiture of the goods, Section no 637 part (2) : Reasonable expenses incurred in the storage and repair and maintenance of the goods until the sale of the goods, Section no 637 part (3) : Reasonable expenses incurred in the sale or otherwise transfer of the goods, Section no 637 part (4) : The amount paid for the taxes, charges, fees or dues, if any, outstanding and payable by the hirer for the goods according to the laws in force, Section no 637 part (2) : The amount referred to in sub-section (1) shall be paid to the hirer within thirty days after the date of forfeiture of the goods, and while making payment thereafter, an interest at the rate of ten percent per year shall also be paid.
output: According to Section 637(1) and (2): Rule: Upon forfeiture under s.636(4)(a), the hirer is entitled to a refund of amounts paid up to forfeiture and an amount equal to the "price of the goods on the day of forfeiture" (i.e., proceeds remaining after deductions for reasonable forfeiture, storage/repair/maintenance, sale/transfer expenses, and any taxes/dues payable by the hirer). The amount due must be paid to the hirer within thirty days of forfeiture; late payment carries 10% per annum interest. Application/Conclusion: After forfeiture, the owner must calculate net proceeds after the listed deductions, refund amounts paid up to forfeiture plus that net amount, and pay within 30 days — otherwise you are entitled to 10% annual interest on the overdue sum.

instruction: What exactly counts as a "domestic helper"?

Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term

instruction: Where in the law can I find the rules specifically about domestic helpers?

instruction: I'm under 18 and working as a domestic helper — do I have a right to study?

instruction: Can my employer make me work while I'm sick?

Rule: Employers must not employ a domestic helper while the helper is sick, nor assign work the helper cannot do because of age, ability, or condition.

instruction: If a domestic helper dies, who pays for the funeral?

Application/Conclusion: If a domestic helper dies, the employer is legally obligated to pay for the normal funeral and related rites.

instruction: My employer shouts at me and humiliates me daily — is that allowed?

instruction: If I fall sick, can my employer take treatment costs out of my pay?

Rule: Employers must arrange treatment for a domestic helper who falls sick, and the expenses for that treatment may not be deducted from the helper's monthly or yearly wages.
Application/Conclusion: Your employer must arrange and cover your medical treatment and cannot recoup those costs by reducing your wages.

instruction: I hired a domestic helper last month — do I need to tell anyone about it?

instruction: I started a contracted job but left it halfway without a good reason. What does the law say?
input:

instruction: Can my employer pay my wages to my brother if I ask them to?

instruction: Can I recover payment if I supplied goods to my mentally incapacitated cousin but he can't contract?
input: Right to recover price of goods or services : If a person has supplies any goods or service to another person who is incapable of conclusion of a contract under law or any one whom such incapable 381 person is legally responsible to support, the person may recover the price of such goods or service from the person receiving such goods or service.
output: According to Section 661, the rule is: If someone supplies goods or services to a person who is incapable of concluding a contract (or to a person whom that incapable person is legally responsible to support), the supplier may recover the price from the person who received the goods or services. Application/Conclusion: Since you supplied goods to your mentally incapacitated cousin, you can seek to recover the price of those goods from the cousin (the person who received them).

instruction: My sister asked me to look after her jewelry while she's abroad. Can I treat it as my own?
input: Section no 662 . Property in custody to be kept as bailed property : If a person keeps in any manner in his or her custody property owned by another as may be retained according to law, such a person shall keep such property as a property under bailment.
output: According to Section 662, the rule is: A person who keeps property owned by another in their custody must keep it as property under bailment. Application/Conclusion: You cannot treat your sister's jewelry as your own — you must hold and care for it as a bailee and return it according to the terms of the bailment or the law.

instruction: I just discovered someone unjustly used my land and gained money from it. How long do I have to file a suit?
input: Section no 663 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two years after the date of accrual of the cause of action. 382 Chapter-16 Provisions Relating to Unjust Enrichment
output: According to Section 663, the rule is: An aggrieved person must bring a lawsuit under this Chapter within two years from the date the cause of action accrued. Application/Conclusion: You have two years from the date you discovered (or when the cause arose) the unjust use of your land/money gain to file a suit seeking remedy under the Chapter relating to unjust enrichment.

instruction: What exactly is 'unjust enrichment' in simple terms?
input: Section no 664 . Unjust enrichment to be deemed : (1) If any person gets any benefit or advantage from another person, without for the reason of doing any lawful act or fulfilling any obligation, the person who so gets the benefit or advantage shall be deemed to have got an unjust enrichment.
output: According to Section 664(1), the rule is: A person is deemed to have obtained unjust enrichment if they get a benefit or advantage from another without doing a lawful act or fulfilling an obligation. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if someone receives benefits from you without legal reason or an obligation to do so, the law treats that as unjust enrichment and they may be required to compensate you.

instruction: My neighbor used my tractor for his harvest and profited. Is that unjust enrichment?
input: Section no 664  part (2) (b) : If he or she receives a service from another or causes another to do a work,
output: According to Section 664(2)(b), the rule is: Receiving a service from another or causing another to do work can constitute unjust enrichment. Application/Conclusion: Because your neighbor used your tractor (a service/work done using your property) and profited, this fits the rule — the neighbor likely has unjustly enriched himself and may be obliged to compensate you.

instruction: If someone's assets increased because of me, can they be ordered to return the gain?
input: Section no 664  part (2) (a) : If there is an increment in his or her property or decrease in his or her liability,
output: According to Section 664(2)(a), the rule is: An increase in a person's property or a decrease in their liability is a circumstance in which that person is deemed to have obtained unjust enrichment. Application/Conclusion: If the other person's assets increased or liabilities decreased at your expense without lawful basis, the law treats that as unjust enrichment and they can be required to restore or compensate the gain.

instruction: They used my woodpile to build a shed and won't pay. Does the law cover using someone's property for another's benefit?
input: Section no 664  part (2) (c) : If other’s property is used for him or her.
output: According to Section 664(2)(c), the rule is: Using another person's property for one's benefit is a circumstance of unjust enrichment. Application/Conclusion: Since your wood (another's property) was used to build a shed that benefited them, this falls under unjust enrichment and you can seek restitution or compensation.

instruction: Is it always unjust enrichment whenever someone benefits from someone else?
input: Section no 664  part (3) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1) or (2), even if any person gets any goods, service, benefit or advantage in any manner, except in any of the following circumstances, he or she shall be deemed to have got an unjust enrichment:
output: According to Section 664(3), the rule is: Even if someone gets benefit under the situations in sub-sections (1) or (2), they are deemed unjustly enriched except where specified exceptions apply. Application/Conclusion: Not every benefit automatically avoids being unjust enrichment — the statute presumes unjust enrichment unless one of the stated exceptions (in the following clauses) applies.

instruction: They claim they were entitled by contract to get the goods. Does that stop my claim for unjust enrichment?
input: Section no 664  part (3) (a) : If any goods, service, benefit or advantage can be obtained from any person under a law or contract,
output: According to Section 664(3)(a), the rule is: If the goods, service, benefit or advantage can be obtained under a law or contract, it is an exception to unjust enrichment. Application/Conclusion: If the other party had a lawful or contractual right to receive those goods/services, then it is not unjust enrichment and you cannot claim restitution on that basis.

instruction: I gave money but the person says I told them not to return it. Can they keep it?
input: Section no 664  part (3) (b) : If the person, from whom any goods, service, benefit or advantage have been obtained, has agreed with free consent not to take back or reimburse the same. 383
output: According to Section 664(3)(b), the rule is: If the person who provided the goods/service agreed freely not to reclaim or be reimbursed, then the recipient is not deemed unjustly enriched. Application/Conclusion: If you freely and voluntarily agreed that the recipient need not return or reimburse the money, you generally cannot later claim unjust enrichment to demand it back.

instruction: Can the fact that I later lost money reduce what someone must repay for unjust enrichment?
input: Section no 664  part (4) : In determining whether or not and to what extent any person has got an unjust enrichment under this Chapter, no consideration shall be granted to any disadvantage or loss or damage caused thereby to him or her after he or she has got the unjust enrichment.
output: According to Section 664(4), the rule is: When determining unjust enrichment and its extent, losses or disadvantages that occurred to the enriched person after they acquired the enrichment are not considered. Application/Conclusion: If the recipient suffered losses after obtaining the benefit, those later losses do not reduce their obligation to compensate you for the unjust enrichment.

instruction: If someone is found to have been unjustly enriched, are they obligated to do anything?
input: Section no 664  part (5) : If a person gets an unjust enrichment pursuant to this Section, the person shall bear the obligation under this Chapter.
output: According to Section 664(5), the rule is: A person who obtains unjust enrichment bears the obligations set out in this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: If the court finds the person unjustly enriched, they will have the legal obligation (e.g., restitution) to remedy that enrichment under the Chapter.

instruction: I accidentally took my neighbor's fertilizer bag. Do I have to return it?
input: Section no 665 . Thing taken by mistake to be returned ( solutio indebiti ) : If any person takes or receives by mistake any goods which he or she is not entitled to take or receive, he or she shall return the goods to the person from whom he or she has taken or received them.
output: According to Section 665, the rule is: If a person takes or receives goods by mistake which they are not entitled to, they must return those goods to the person they took them from. Application/Conclusion: Since you took the fertilizer bag by mistake and were not entitled to it, you are required to return it to your neighbor.

instruction: I mistakenly paid someone thinking I owed them money but I didn't. Can I get that money back?
input: Section no 666 . To pay back debt paid by mistake : If a person pays a debt to another person by mistake because the person thinks that he or she is bound to do so and proves that he or she is not bound to pay such debt, that other person who receives such amount shall return it to him or her.
output: According to Section 666, the rule is: If a person pays a debt by mistake and proves they were not bound to pay, the recipient must return the amount. Application/Conclusion: Since you paid under a mistaken belief that you owed the debt and can prove you were not obligated, you can require the recipient to repay the mistaken payment.

instruction: Ram promised to do work on my house and accepted materials, then refused. What section talks about unjust enrichment where someone gets benefit and doesn't have legal right?

Application/Conclusion: If Ram got materials or benefited from your provision without performing the agreed work and had no lawful right to those benefits, he may be considered unjustly enriched and you can seek restitution.

input: Section no 664  part (3) (b) : If the person, from whom any goods, service, benefit or advantage have been obtained, has agreed with free consent not to take back or reimburse the same. 383

Application/Conclusion: Because you voluntarily agreed not to seek reimbursement, that agreement generally prevents you from later claiming the benefit as unjust enrichment.
