instruction: My neighbor entered my yard and damaged plants. Are they liable for damage?
input:
Section no 680 . To bear liability for trespass : A person who commits
trespass to other’s property shall be liable for any loss or damage resulted from
the trespass. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “trespass”
means an unlawful entry into, taking possession of products of, unauthorized
damage to, interference in, or unlawful encroachment on, a property that is
under entitlement, possession or ownership of another person, in the case of an
immovable property, and forcibly taking into custody, taking away, taking the
advantage arising out of, or causing obstruction or hindrance in the use of, the
property under entitlement, possession or ownership of another person, in the
case of a movable property, and also includes an act of taking control of any
type of property in an unauthorized manner.
output:
According to Section 680:
Rule: A person committing trespass to another's property is liable for any loss or damage resulting from that trespass; "trespass" is defined broadly to include unlawful entry, unauthorized damage, interference, encroachment, forcible taking, obstruction, and unauthorized control of property.
Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor's entry and damage to your plants qualify as trespass under this definition, so they are liable for the loss or damage caused and you can seek compensation for that damage.

instruction: In simple terms, what exactly counts as 'trespass' under this law?
input:
Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the term “trespass”
means an unlawful entry into, taking possession of products of, unauthorized
damage to, interference in, or unlawful encroachment on, a property that is
under entitlement, possession or ownership of another person, in the case of an
immovable property, and forcibly taking into custody, taking away, taking the
advantage arising out of, or causing obstruction or hindrance in the use of, the
property under entitlement, possession or ownership of another person, in the
case of a movable property, and also includes an act of taking control of any
type of property in an unauthorized manner.
output:
According to Section 680 (Explanation):
Rule: "Trespass" includes unlawful entry, taking possession of another's products, unauthorized damage, interference or encroachment for immovable property; and forcible taking, taking away, exploiting benefits from, or obstructing the use of movable property; it also covers unauthorized control of any property.
Application/Conclusion: In plain language, any unauthorized entry, damage, encroachment, seizure, or obstruction of someone else's property — whether land, a building, or movable items — is treated as trespass under this law.

instruction: If three people together break a fence and damage my crops, are they all responsible?
input:
Section no 681 . To bear liability jointly : (1) If more than one person
commit any act to be deemed a tort under this Chapter, each of such persons
shall, except as otherwise proved, be jointly and severally liable for any damage
caused by that act, in proportion to the culpability of the tort committed by
each person.
output:
According to Section 681(1):
Rule: When multiple persons commit an act that is a tort under this Chapter, each person is, unless proven otherwise, jointly and severally liable for the damage caused, in proportion to their culpability.
Application/Conclusion: The three people who broke the fence and damaged your crops are jointly and severally liable; each can be held responsible, and liability should be apportioned according to each person's culpability unless evidence shows otherwise.

instruction: Two friends damaged my vehicle, but I can tell one was much more responsible. How is liability split?
input:
Section no 681  part (2) : If separate liability can be determined in proportion
to the culpability of tort pursuant to sub-section (1), liability shall be borne
accordingly, and if such determination cannot be made, all persons responsible
for the tort shall bear liability on an equal basis. 390
output:
According to Section 681(2):
Rule: If separate liability can be determined proportionately to each person's culpability, liability is borne accordingly; if such proportional determination cannot be made, all responsible persons bear liability equally.
Application/Conclusion: Since you can tell one friend was more responsible, liability should be apportioned in proportion to each person's culpability. If, however, proportional culpability cannot be established in court, the law treats all responsible persons as equally liable.

instruction: Do I have to pay compensation if I commit a tort listed in this chapter?
input:
Section no 682 . Compensation to be paid for liability : (1) While bearing
liability for a tort committed under this Chapter, the person who commits the
tort shall pay compensation.
output:
According to Section 682(1):
Rule: A person who bears liability for a tort under this Chapter must pay compensation.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if you are found liable for a tort under this Chapter, you are legally required to pay compensation to the injured party.

instruction: I was injured partly because I was careless. Can that reduce my compensation?
input:
Section no 682  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), if any tort is committed under this Chapter as a result of any omission,
fault, recklessness or negligence of the injured person also, the quantum of such
compensation shall be lesser.
output:
According to Section 682(2):
Rule: If the tort occurred partly due to the injured person's own omission, fault, recklessness, or negligence, the amount of compensation shall be reduced.
Application/Conclusion: Because you were partly careless, the compensation you can recover will be reduced proportionately under this provision.

instruction: Can I claim for emotional distress or speculative future losses in a trespass case?
input:
Section no 682  part (3) : The compensation referred to in sub-section (1)
shall be limited to the actual loss or damage, and remote or unactual compensation shall not be recoverable.
output:
According to Section 682(3):
Rule: Compensation is limited to actual loss or damage; remote or speculative (unactual) compensation is not recoverable.
Application/Conclusion: Claims for purely emotional distress or speculative future losses that cannot be shown as actual, concrete loss are unlikely to be recoverable under this provision; compensation will be confined to proven actual damages.

instruction: Can compensation be paid in things other than money?
input:
Section no 682  part (4) : The compensation may be of any type, in the form
of either cash or kind or service.
output:
According to Section 682(4):
Rule: Compensation may take any form — cash, kind, or service.
Application/Conclusion: The injured party can accept compensation in money, in-kind (replacement goods or repair), or as services, depending on what the parties or the court decide is reasonable.

instruction: If I suffer loss from someone else's tort, am I entitled to make a claim?
input:
Section no 682  part (5) : If any loss or damage is caused under this Chapter,
a person who suffers shall be entitled to claim for compensation, subject to this
Chapter.
output:
According to Section 682(5):
Rule: A person who suffers loss or damage under this Chapter is entitled to claim compensation, subject to the provisions of the Chapter.
Application/Conclusion: You have the right to claim compensation for losses caused by a tort under this Chapter, provided you follow the procedures and limits set out in the Chapter.

instruction: Will a court order compensation if I file a claim?
input:
Section no 682  part (6) : If a claim is made for compensation pursuant to
sub section (5), the court may order reasonable compensation to be paid.
output:
According to Section 682(6):
Rule: When a compensation claim is made under subsection (5), the court may order reasonable compensation.
Application/Conclusion: If you file a valid claim, the court has the authority to order that reasonable compensation be paid to you based on the facts and evidence.

instruction: If an action is also a crime under another law, can I still sue under this Chapter?
input:
Section no 683 . Not to bear liability if separate provision is made :
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if a tort for
which liability is to be borne under this Chapter is treated as a criminal offence
under a law, or this Act or other law contains a separate provision or provides
for a separate legal remedy in relation to such a tort, no liability under this
Chapter may be borne.
output:
According to Section 683(1):
Rule: If a tort under this Chapter is treated as a criminal offence elsewhere, or another law/this Act provides a separate provision or remedy for it, no liability under this Chapter may be borne.
Application/Conclusion: If the same act is covered by criminal law or another statutory remedy exists, you generally cannot seek liability under this Chapter; instead, the other criminal or statutory remedy will take precedence.

instruction: Two people broke into my house and one stole items while the other only held the door. How will liability be allocated?
input:
Section no 681 . To bear liability jointly : (1) If more than one person
commit any act to be deemed a tort under this Chapter, each of such persons
shall, except as otherwise proved, be jointly and severally liable for any damage
caused by that act, in proportion to the culpability of the tort committed by
each person.

Section no 681  part (2) : If separate liability can be determined in proportion
to the culpability of tort pursuant to sub-section (1), liability shall be borne
accordingly, and if such determination cannot be made, all persons responsible
for the tort shall bear liability on an equal basis. 390
output:
According to Section 681(1)-(2):
Rule: Multiple perpetrators are jointly and severally liable, with liability apportioned according to each person's culpability; if proportional culpability cannot be determined, liability is shared equally among those responsible.
Application/Conclusion: The person who stole items will bear greater culpability and should therefore bear a larger share of liability; if the court can quantify each person's culpability it will apportion liability accordingly—otherwise it will split liability equally between them.

instruction: I'm renting a house; can my landlord treat me as the 'house-head' for legal notices?
input:
Section no 679  part (2) : “House-head” means a person who acts as the chief
of family, and also includes, in the case of a tenant renting other’s house, the
person who acts as the chief of the tenant’s family.
output:
According to Section 679(2):
Rule: For a tenant renting another's house, the "house-head" includes the person who acts as chief of the tenant's family.
Application/Conclusion: Your landlord can treat the tenant who acts as the family chief as the "house-head" for legal purposes; whether that is you depends on who actually performs the role of family head in the rented household.

instruction: Is there a time limit in these provisions for filing a compensation claim after trespass?
input:
Section no 682  part (5) : If any loss or damage is caused under this Chapter,
a person who suffers shall be entitled to claim for compensation, subject to this
Chapter.

Section no 682  part (6) : If a claim is made for compensation pursuant to
sub section (5), the court may order reasonable compensation to be paid.
output:
According to Section 682(5)-(6):
Rule: A person suffering loss under this Chapter is entitled to claim compensation and the court may order reasonable compensation when such a claim is made.
Application/Conclusion: These provisions establish entitlement to claim and the court's power to order compensation but do not specify any time limit for filing a claim. Therefore, no filing deadline is set in these subsections themselves — you would need to consult other procedural or limitation laws for any time limits.

instruction: Can I be held liable for a tort my 12-year-old child committed while living with me?
input:
Parents to bear liability : The father and mother jointly
living with a minor below fourteen years of age, or if there is no father or mother,
the person who exercises paternal authority over him or her shall be liable for
a tort committed by such a minor.
output: According to Section 673... Rule: Parents (father and mother) jointly living with a minor below fourteen years are liable for a tort committed by that minor (or, if no parents exist, the person exercising paternal authority). Application/Conclusion: Because your child is 12 (below 14) and you live with them, you (and the other parent, if living with the child) would be held liable for the tort committed by the child.

instruction: My mentally ill relative injured someone. Who pays for damages?
input:
Section no 674 . Guardian or curator to bear liability : The guardian
or curator of a person of unsound mind shall be responsible for and accordingly
bear liability for any loss or damage caused by such a person.
output: According to Section 674... Rule: The guardian or curator of a person of unsound mind is responsible for and must bear liability for any loss or damage caused by that person. Application/Conclusion: If your relative is of unsound mind and has a guardian or curator, that guardian/curator would be legally responsible for compensating losses caused by the relative.

instruction: Our household helper accidentally broke a visitor's expensive vase while carrying goods in the house. Is my employer liable?
input:
Section no 675 . Employer to bear liability : (1) Any person, firm, company
or organization who employs a domestic helper, other worker or 387 employee in
a work shall be liable for the loss or damage to another person, if any, resulted
from any act done in good faith by such a helper, worker or employee in the
course of doing such a work.
output: According to Section 675(1)... Rule: An employer who employs a domestic helper/worker is liable for loss or damage to another person caused by any act done in good faith by that helper/worker in the course of their work. Application/Conclusion: Because the helper accidentally broke the vase while performing their work in good faith, you (the employer) would be liable to compensate the visitor for the damaged vase.

instruction: But what if the helper intentionally smashed the vase or acted dishonestly—does liability change?
input:
Section no 675  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), the worker or employee shall be personally liable for any act which he or
she has done negligently or dishonestly.
output: According to Section 675(2)... Rule: Regardless of employer liability under subsection (1), the worker or employee is personally liable for acts done negligently or dishonestly. Application/Conclusion: If the helper intentionally or dishonestly smashed the vase (or acted negligently), the helper can be held personally liable for the damage; the employer may still face liability under (1) depending on facts, but the helper has direct personal liability.

instruction: Someone's cow escaped from my neighbour's field and trampled my crops. Who is liable?
input:
Section no 676 . Owner of animal to bear liability for loss or damage
caused by : animal: The owner of an animal which is kept by or under the
control of him or her shall be liable for any loss or damage caused by the animal
to any one. Provided that the owner of animal shall not be liable for any loss
or damage caused by the animal while being appropriately controlled by the
owner by taking adequate safety measures according to its behavior or caused
as a result of any act, default or negligence of the loss or damage sustaining
person himself or herself. Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the
term “animal” means a domestic animal or wildlife or avian of any type under
one’s control, and also includes a domestic, reptile or wild avian as well.
output: According to Section 676... Rule: The owner of an animal kept by or under their control is liable for any loss or damage caused by that animal, except where the owner proves the animal was appropriately controlled with adequate safety measures, or the damage was caused by the act/default/neglect of the injured person. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbour, as the owner of the cow, is generally liable for the trampling of your crops unless they can show they had adequate safety measures in place or that your own act or negligence caused the loss.

instruction: What does the law mean by 'animal' in this context? I'm not sure if a pet bird counts.
input:
Explanation: For the purposes of this Section, the
term “animal” means a domestic animal or wildlife or avian of any type under
one’s control, and also includes a domestic, reptile or wild avian as well.
output: According to Section 676... Rule: 'Animal' expressly includes domestic animals, wildlife, and any avian (including domestic, reptile, or wild avian) under a person's control. Application/Conclusion: A pet bird is covered by the definition of 'animal' for this section, so its owner can be liable for damage caused by the bird while it is under their control.

instruction: A part of my neighbour's house collapsed and injured me. Can I demand compensation and does it matter if the house was still under construction?
input:
Section no 677 .House-owner to bear liability for loss or damage
caused by its : collapse: The concerned house-owner shall be liable for any
kind of loss or damage, if any, caused to any one as a result of the collapse of
the house, in whole or in part, or by any part of the house, whether during, or
after the completion of, its construction.
output: According to Section 677... Rule: The house-owner is liable for any loss or damage caused by the collapse of the house (in whole or in part), or by any part of the house, whether the collapse occurs during construction or after completion. Application/Conclusion: You can demand compensation from the house-owner; it makes no legal difference whether the collapse happened during construction or after—the owner is liable.

instruction: My factory had an explosion due to lack of safety measures in its machinery. Is the property owner legally responsible?
input:
Section no 678  clause (a) : An explosion owing to a failure to adopt safety
measures properly according to the nature of a machine, equipment or engine,
output: According to Section 678(a)... Rule: A property owner is liable for loss or damage resulting from an explosion caused by failure to adopt proper safety measures according to the nature of a machine, equipment, or engine. Application/Conclusion: The property owner of the factory would be legally responsible for damages caused by the explosion if it occurred due to inadequate safety measures for the machinery.

instruction: A neighbour stored inflammable material and a fire caused damage next door. Is that the owner's fault?
input:
Section no 678  clause (b) : A fire or explosion owing to a failure to adopt
safety measures properly according to the nature of any inflammable or explosive
substance,
output: According to Section 678(b)... Rule: An owner is liable for loss or damage caused by a fire or explosion that occurred due to failure to adopt proper safety measures appropriate to inflammable or explosive substances. Application/Conclusion: If your neighbour failed to take necessary safety measures while storing inflammable material, they (as property owner) would be liable for the resulting fire damage to others.

instruction: Our nearby factory emits very loud noise and thick smoke beyond standards. Can the owner be held liable?
input: Section no 678  clause (c) : Emission of excessive smoke, noise by any industrial enterprise in contravention of the specified standards,
output: According to Section 678(c)... Rule: A property owner is liable for loss or damage caused by emission of excessive smoke or noise by any industrial enterprise when such emissions contravene specified standards. Application/Conclusion: If the factory's smoke or noise exceed specified standards and cause loss or damage, the owner of that industrial enterprise can be held liable.

instruction: A big tree from my neighbour's property fell across the public road and damaged my car. Is my neighbour responsible?
input:
Section no 678  clause (d) : A tree lying down or laid down on any highway,
road, street or way except due to a disaster or an act by any third person,
output: According to Section 678(d)... Rule: The property owner is liable for loss or damage resulting from a tree lying or laid down on a highway, road, street, or way, unless the cause was a disaster or an act by a third person. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbour (the property owner) is generally responsible for damage caused by their tree on the road unless it fell because of a disaster or someone else's act.

instruction: Sewage from a nearby plant was discharged through an open pipe and people got sick. Who bears liability?
input:
Section no 678  clause (e) : Discharge of any infected or toxic substance or
communicable disease carrying substance openly through a canal, ditch, pipe or
sewerage, without adopting precautionary measures properly, in contravention
of the specified standards.
output: According to Section 678(e)... Rule: A property owner is liable for loss or damage caused by openly discharging infected, toxic, or communicable disease-carrying substances through canals/ditches/pipes/sewerage without proper precautions and in contravention of standards. Application/Conclusion: The plant owner would be liable for resulting illness or damage if they discharged such substances openly without proper precautions and breached standards.

instruction: Someone threw garbage from their balcony and it injured a passerby. Is the head of that household responsible?
input:
Section no 679 . House-head to bear liability : The concerned house-head
shall be liable for the loss or damage, if any, caused to any one as a result of
any kind of solid waste or goods thrown from the house. Explanation: For the
purposes of this Section,
output: According to Section 679... Rule: The house-head is liable for loss or damage caused to anyone by any solid waste or goods thrown from the house. Application/Conclusion: The head of the household from whose house the garbage was thrown would be legally liable for injuries to the passerby caused by that act.

instruction: If an animal caused damage but the victim's own negligence contributed, can the owner avoid liability?
input:
Provided that the owner of animal shall not be liable for any loss
or damage caused by the animal while being appropriately controlled by the
owner by taking adequate safety measures according to its behavior or caused
as a result of any act, default or negligence of the loss or damage sustaining
person himself or herself.
output: According to Section 676... Rule: The animal owner is not liable where the animal was appropriately controlled with adequate safety measures, or where the loss/damage resulted from the act, default, or negligence of the person who suffered the loss. Application/Conclusion: If the injured person’s own negligent conduct substantially caused the damage, the owner may avoid liability (or liability may be reduced), provided the owner had taken appropriate safety measures.

instruction: We had a helper spill hot oil on a customer while delivering food in good faith. The customer wants compensation. Who pays — me or the helper?
input:
Section no 675 . Employer to bear liability : (1) Any person, firm, company
or organization who employs a domestic helper, other worker or 387 employee in
a work shall be liable for the loss or damage to another person, if any, resulted
from any act done in good faith by such a helper, worker or employee in the
course of doing such a work.
Section no 675  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section
(1), the worker or employee shall be personally liable for any act which he or
she has done negligently or dishonestly.
output: According to Section 675(1) and 675(2)... Rule: (1) Employers are liable for loss/damage caused by a helper/worker's acts done in good faith during work; (2) workers are personally liable for acts done negligently or dishonestly. Application/Conclusion: Because the spill occurred in the course of delivering food (an act done in good faith), you (as employer) would be liable to compensate the customer. If the helper's conduct was negligent or dishonest beyond mere accident, the helper could also bear personal liability.

instruction: Under which section does the law say who is liable for damage caused by a person of unsound mind?
input:
Section no 674 . Guardian or curator to bear liability : The guardian
or curator of a person of unsound mind shall be responsible for and accordingly
bear liability for any loss or damage caused by such a person.
output: According to Section 674... Rule: Section 674 states that the guardian or curator of a person of unsound mind is responsible for and must bear liability for any loss or damage caused by that person. Application/Conclusion: You should rely on Section 674 when addressing liability for actions of a person of unsound mind—the guardian/curator is the liable party.

instruction: My neighbour removed scaffolding and a portion of his wall fell during renovation and hit my car. He says it was during construction so he's not liable. Is he right?
input:
Section no 677 .House-owner to bear liability for loss or damage
caused by its : collapse: The concerned house-owner shall be liable for any
kind of loss or damage, if any, caused to any one as a result of the collapse of
the house, in whole or in part, or by any part of the house, whether during, or
after the completion of, its construction.
output: According to Section 677... Rule: The house-owner is liable for loss or damage caused by collapse of the house or any part of it whether the collapse occurs during construction or after completion. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbour is incorrect—because the damage occurred due to collapse during renovation/construction, the house-owner remains liable for damage to your car.

instruction: Can a producer reduce their liability if the consumer also caused the injury?
input:
Section no 688 . Quantum of liability may be reduced : Notwithstanding
anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if it is proved that the injury has
been caused due to both the producer and the consumer of a defective product,
the producer’s liability may be reduced proportionately. Provided that if such
injury has resulted in a loss or damage to a third party, the quantum of liability
may not be reduced in the case of such a party.
output: According to Section 688, Quantum of liability may be reduced. Rule: If injury is proved to have been caused due to both the producer and the consumer, the producer's liability may be reduced proportionately. Application/Conclusion: If you can show the consumer’s conduct also caused the harm, the court may reduce the producer’s share of liability in proportion to the consumer’s fault — but this reduction cannot be applied where the injured person is a third party who suffered loss or damage.

instruction: My child ate a product without following the warning and got hurt. Is the producer fully liable?
input: clause (g) : Information was given at the time of sale of the product, from which the injury has been caused that it might cause injury if not consumed properly,
output: According to Section 687 (clause (g)). Rule: If information/warning was given at the time of sale indicating the product might cause injury if not consumed properly, that fact is relevant. Application/Conclusion: Because a warning was provided, the producer may use that to show the consumer did not follow instructions; this can reduce or negate the producer's liability depending on the circumstances and other applicable provisions (for example, reduction under Section 688).

instruction: I ignored the label and used the chemical wrong and got burned—can I claim it's a defective product?
input:
clause (d) : The injury has been caused due to the consumer’s
failure to comply with the directions to be complied with while consuming the
produced goods or service,
output: According to Section 687 (clause (d)). Rule: Injury caused by the consumer’s failure to comply with directions while using the product is a recognized factor. Application/Conclusion: If your injury resulted from not following the product’s directions, the law treats that as a defense for the producer — it may bar or reduce your claim against the producer.

instruction: We bought lower-quality soap but a better brand exists—does that mean the soap is defective?
input:
Section no 689 . Product not deemed to be defective : Goods or service
consumed by a person shall not be considered to be a defective product merely
395 by the reason that any goods or service of quality higher than that of such
goods or service is available in the market.
output: According to Section 689. Rule: A product is not defective simply because higher-quality alternatives exist in the market. Application/Conclusion: You cannot call the soap defective just because better brands are available; defectiveness requires something other than relative quality compared to other products.

instruction: Can a person still sue under other laws if they are harmed by a defective product?
input:
Section no 690 .
Not to prejudice other right : Nothing contained in
this Chapter shall prejudice the right, interest or claim available under a law or
contract to any person whose body, life or property has been affected from a
defective product.
output: According to Section 690. Rule: The Chapter's provisions do not prejudice other rights, interests, or claims available under law or contract. Application/Conclusion: Yes — being governed by this Chapter does not prevent you from pursuing other legal or contractual remedies available for harm caused by a defective product.

instruction: How long do I have to file a lawsuit if harmed by a defective product? I just found out today.
input: Section no 691 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within one year from the date on which such an act was done or action taken.
output: According to Section 691. Rule: A lawsuit must be made within one year from the date of the act or action under this Chapter. Application/Conclusion: You generally have one year from the date the relevant act or action occurred to file suit. Act quickly — if you are close to or past that one-year period you may lose the right to sue.

instruction: I used a product differently than intended and got sick. Does the law consider that?
input: clause (e) : The injury has been caused because the consumer has not properly consumed the product or has consumed it otherwise,
output: According to Section 687 (clause (e)). Rule: Injury caused because the consumer did not properly consume the product or consumed it otherwise is recognized. Application/Conclusion: If you consumed the product in an improper way, that fact can defeat or reduce a claim against the producer; the producer can rely on that clause in their defense.

instruction: Under what condition would a producer be excused because they lacked technical knowledge about a defect?
input: clause (f) : One had no scientific or technical knowledge at the time of production or distribution of the goods or service that such goods or service was defective,
output: According to Section 687 (clause (f)). Rule: Lack of scientific or technical knowledge at the time of production/distribution that a product was defective is a recognized matter. Application/Conclusion: If the producer genuinely lacked the scientific or technical knowledge to know of the defect at the time, this can be used to argue they should not be held liable — though the court will consider evidence of what they reasonably should have known.

instruction: If I knew a product might harm me but still used it, can I sue later?
input:
clause (h) : The goods or service has been consumed despite
knowing or having a reasonable reason to know that it might cause loss or
damage.
output: According to Section 687 (clause (h)). Rule: Consumption of goods or services despite knowing, or having reasonable grounds to know, they might cause loss or damage is relevant. Application/Conclusion: If you knew (or should have reasonably known) about the risk and still used the product, that can bar or reduce your claim against the producer.

instruction: I was injured by a product bought abroad. Do Nepali private international law rules apply?
input:
Section no 692 . Provisions of this Part to apply : (1) The provisions of
this Part shall apply to any matter relating to private legal relationship involving
a foreigner, foreign object or any act done in a foreign country.
output: According to Section 692(1). Rule: This Part applies to private legal matters involving a foreigner, foreign object, or acts done in a foreign country. Application/Conclusion: If your case involves a foreign element (e.g., product bought abroad or a foreign manufacturer), the private international law provisions in this Part will apply to determine legal questions such as jurisdiction, applicable law, or capacity.

instruction: My spouse is a foreign national. Which section deals with family matters involving foreigners?
input:
Section no 692  part (2) (b) : Matters relating to matrimonial relationship,
paternal and maternal and other family relationship or partition or succession,
with at least one of the related parties whereof being a foreigner, or the place
of execution of any act or action related thereto being situated outside Nepal,
output: According to Section 692(2)(b). Rule: Matters relating to matrimonial, parental, family relationships, partition, or succession are covered where at least one related party is a foreigner or the act is executed outside Nepal. Application/Conclusion: Family-law disputes involving your foreign spouse fall under Section 692(2)(b), so private international law rules in this Part will guide how the matter is handled.

instruction: Is a contract made in another country covered by these private international law provisions?
input:
Section no 692  part (2) (e) : Matter relating to a contract made in a foreign
country.
output: According to Section 692(2)(e). Rule: Matters relating to contracts made in a foreign country are governed by this Part. Application/Conclusion: Yes — contracts formed in another country are specifically within the scope of these private international law provisions, so those rules will apply to disputes over such contracts.

instruction: Which clause tells me about property located abroad when one party is foreign?
input:
Section no 692  part (2) (c) : Matter relating to a property situated in a
foreign country, with at least one of the concerned parties being a foreigner,
output: According to Section 692(2)(c). Rule: Matters relating to property situated in a foreign country are covered when at least one concerned party is a foreigner. Application/Conclusion: If the dispute concerns property outside Nepal and one party is a foreigner, Section 692(2)(c) makes the private international law rules here applicable.

instruction: Does this Part cover contractual or non-contractual obligations involving a foreigner?
input: Section no 692  part (2) (d) : Matter relating to a contractual or noncontractual right or obligation, with at least one party being a foreigner,
output: According to Section 692(2)(d). Rule: Matters relating to contractual or non-contractual rights or obligations with at least one foreign party are included. Application/Conclusion: Yes — disputes over contracts or torts involving a foreign party are governed by these private international law provisions.

instruction: What does the law mean by 'foreigner' in this Part? Simple answer.
input: Explanation: For the purposes of this Part, the term “foreigner” means a foreign natural person or body corporate, and also includes a foreign state.
output: According to Section 692 (Explanation). Rule: 'Foreigner' includes a foreign natural person, a foreign body corporate, and a foreign state. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, a foreign individual, foreign company, or even a foreign government counts as a 'foreigner' under these rules.

instruction: I want to sue a foreign company for a defective product sold in Nepal. Which provision says this Part applies?
input:
Section no 692 . Provisions of this Part to apply : (1) The provisions of
this Part shall apply to any matter relating to private legal relationship involving
a foreigner, foreign object or any act done in a foreign country.
output: According to Section 692(1). Rule: The Part applies to private legal relationships involving foreigners or acts done abroad. Application/Conclusion: Suing a foreign company for a product issue falls within Section 692(1); the private international law provisions will therefore guide jurisdiction, applicable law, and related procedural questions.

instruction: My friend consumed a product in a way the manufacturer warned against and was injured. Can manufacturer argue reduced liability?
input: clause (g) : Information was given at the time of sale of the product, from which the injury has been caused that it might cause injury if not consumed properly,
output: According to Section 687 (clause (g)). Rule: If information/warnings were given at sale indicating injury may result if not consumed properly, that is relevant to liability. Application/Conclusion: Since the manufacturer provided a warning, they can argue that the consumer ignored it and therefore the manufacturer's liability should be reduced or excluded, subject to court assessment and Section 688 on proportional reduction.

instruction: If both I and the producer are partly at fault and a third party was injured, can the producer shift liability for that third party?
input:
Section no 688 . Quantum of liability may be reduced : Notwithstanding
anything contained elsewhere in this Chapter, if it is proved that the injury has
been caused due to both the producer and the consumer of a defective product,
the producer’s liability may be reduced proportionately. Provided that if such
injury has resulted in a loss or damage to a third party, the quantum of liability
may not be reduced in the case of such a party.
output: According to Section 688. Rule: Producer's liability may be reduced proportionately when both producer and consumer caused injury; however, if the injury resulted in loss to a third party, the quantum of liability may not be reduced for that third party. Application/Conclusion: Even if you and the producer share fault, the producer cannot reduce their liability to a third party injured by the product — the third party's recovery is unaffected by apportionment between producer and consumer.

instruction: I rushed to save my neighbour's house during a fire without telling them. Can I get my expenses back?
input: Section no 652 . Reasonable costs to be paid for saving property in times of : disaster: If any person saves or protects any property in times of disaster such as fire, flood, landslide, storm and earthquake without giving information to its owner, the owner of property shall reimburse the reasonable expenses incurred in saving or protecting such property to such a person.
output: According to Section 652... Rule: If a person saves or protects another's property in a disaster (fire, flood, landslide, storm, earthquake) without informing the owner, the owner must reimburse reasonable expenses incurred. Application/Conclusion: Because you saved your neighbour's house in a fire without informing them, you are entitled to claim reimbursement of reasonable expenses from the owner.

instruction: I paid a tax that the municipality was supposed to pay and the municipality benefited. Can I claim back the money?
input: Section no 653 . Right to claim reimbursement : (1) If a person, in spite of being compelled by law to fulfill any obligation, fulfills such obligation at his or her own expense and another person gets anything or benefit due to the fulfillment of such an obligation or for any other reason, the person fulfilling such an obligation may claim reimbursement of the amount incurred therein from the person who so gets such thing or benefit.
output: According to Section 653(1)... Rule: If you, though compelled by law, fulfill an obligation at your own expense and another person gains a benefit from that fulfillment, you may claim reimbursement from that person. Application/Conclusion: Since you paid the tax and the municipality (or another) benefitted, you can claim reimbursement of the amount you incurred from the beneficiary.

instruction: Can I stop managing my uncle's shop that I started running without his permission and just walk away?
input: Section no 649 . If other’s property managed voluntarily, not to be abandoned : ( negotiorum gestio ): If a person manages or operates a business or property of another person on his or her own without information to, or authority from, that other person, the person shall, so long as such business or property continues to exist, not abandon such business or property without handing it over to that other person, his or her successor or agent or until that other person removes him or her.
output: According to Section 649... Rule: A person who voluntarily manages another's business/property without authority must not abandon it while it continues to exist; they must hand it over to the owner, successor, or agent, or remain until removed. Application/Conclusion: You cannot simply walk away. You must hand the shop over to your uncle (or his successor/agent) or remain until he removes you.

instruction: My neighbour started farming my land without permission and now refuses to return control. What does the law say?
input: Section no 649 . If other’s property managed voluntarily, not to be abandoned : ( negotiorum gestio ): If a person manages or operates a business or property of another person on his or her own without information to, or authority from, that other person, the person shall, so long as such business or property continues to exist, not abandon such business or property without handing it over to that other person, his or her successor or agent or until that other person removes him or her.
output: According to Section 649... Rule: Someone who manages another's property without authority must not abandon it and must hand it back to the owner, successor, or agent, or remain until removed. Application/Conclusion: Your neighbour cannot lawfully refuse to return control; they are required to hand the property back to you (or your successor/agent), or you can remove them as provided by the law.

instruction: What exactly is an 'indirect or quasi-contract'? Explain simply.
input: Section no 648 . Indirect or quasi-contract deemed to be made : (1)Notwithstanding anything contained in Chapter-2 of this Part, if any person does any certain, lawful, voluntary or unilateral act that may give rise to a juridical relationship, an indirect or quasi-contract shall be deemed to be made.
output: According to Section 648(1)... Rule: When a person does a lawful, voluntary, or unilateral act that can create a legal relationship, the law treats that act as if an indirect or quasi-contract has been made. Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, if you do something on your own that legally affects someone else (for example, managing their property or saving their goods), the law may treat it like a contract arose even without explicit agreement.

instruction: I fixed my friend's gate to stop a trespass, but later I found out he asked me to do it to commit something illegal. Can I still get reimbursed?
input: Section no 653  part (2) : Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), if a person fulfills any obligation for any illegal purpose, the person shall not be entitled to claim reimbursement from the same.
output: According to Section 653(2)... Rule: If a person fulfills an obligation for an illegal purpose, they are not entitled to claim reimbursement even if subsection (1) would otherwise allow it. Application/Conclusion: Because you fulfilled the obligation for an illegal purpose (you were asked to commit something illegal), you cannot claim reimbursement for your expenses.

instruction: How long do I have to file a lawsuit under this Chapter if I discover a violation today?
input: Section no 647 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved in relation to any of the matters under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within three months after the date of accrual of the cause of action in the case of 376 Section 644, and within thirty-five days in the case of the other matters. 377
output: According to Section 647... Rule: The time limit to sue under this Chapter is three months after accrual of the cause of action in cases falling under Section 644, and thirty-five days for the other matters. Application/Conclusion: You must file within the applicable period: if your claim comes under Section 644, file within three months of the cause arising; for other claims under this Chapter, file within thirty-five days.

instruction: Under which section is the concept of 'indirect or quasi-contract' stated?
input: Section no 648 . Indirect or quasi-contract deemed to be made : (1)Notwithstanding anything contained in Chapter-2 of this Part, if any person does any certain, lawful, voluntary or unilateral act that may give rise to a juridical relationship, an indirect or quasi-contract shall be deemed to be made.
output: According to Section 648... Rule: Section 648(1) states that an indirect or quasi-contract is deemed to be made when a lawful, voluntary or unilateral act gives rise to a juridical relationship. Application/Conclusion: The law recognises indirect or quasi-contracts under Section 648.

instruction: I took custody of my neighbour's unattended tools to look after them. Am I required to care for them in any particular way?
input: Section no 650 . To care (herbichar) or manage property taken in custody : (1) If a person takes the custody of a property belonging to another person for its care or management, the person shall take care of and manage the property in good faith as if that were his or her own property.
output: According to Section 650(1)... Rule: A person who takes custody of another's property for care or management must take care of and manage it in good faith as if it were their own. Application/Conclusion: You are required to look after the tools in good faith and with the same care you would apply to your own property.

instruction: I was guarding a friend's boat I took into custody, but I negligently damaged it. Am I liable?
input: Section no 650  part (2) : If a person who takes the custody of a property pursuant to sub-section (1) causes loss or damage to the property 378 with malafide intention or recklessly, the person shall pay compensation therefor.
output: According to Section 650(2)... Rule: If a person who took custody of another's property causes loss or damage with malafide intention or recklessly, they must pay compensation. Application/Conclusion: Because you negligently damaged the boat (recklessly), you are liable to pay compensation for the loss or damage.

instruction: If I delegate the work someone entrusted me with to another person and things go wrong, am I still responsible?
input: Section no 651 . Not absolved from obligation by delegation of authority : If a person, who is entrusted by another person with a responsibility to do any act, delegates any or all of his or her powers to another person to do that act in a manner not to be prejudicial to the obligation vis-à-vis that other 200 person, the person shall not be free from his or her own obligation by the reason of such delegation.
output: According to Section 651... Rule: A person entrusted with a responsibility who delegates powers is not freed from their own obligation by reason of that delegation, provided the delegation is not prejudicial to the obligation. Application/Conclusion: You remain responsible; delegating the task does not absolve you of liability if something goes wrong.

instruction: Someone got benefit because I paid a debt they owed. Can I require them to reimburse me?
input: Section no 653 . Right to claim reimbursement : (1) If a person, in spite of being compelled by law to fulfill any obligation, fulfills such obligation at his or her own expense and another person gets anything or benefit due to the fulfillment of such an obligation or for any other reason, the person fulfilling such an obligation may claim reimbursement of the amount incurred therein from the person who so gets such thing or benefit.
output: According to Section 653(1)... Rule: If you fulfill an obligation at your own expense and another person gains a benefit from that fulfillment, you may claim reimbursement from the beneficiary. Application/Conclusion: Since someone benefited from your payment of their debt, you can demand reimbursement of the expenses from that person.

instruction: If an indirect or quasi-contract happens because of my unilateral action, does that create obligations under this Chapter?
input: Section no 648  part (2) : If an indirect or quasi-contract is made pursuant to sub section (1), an obligation under this Chapter shall be created from the same fact.
output: According to Section 648(2)... Rule: When an indirect or quasi-contract is deemed to be made under subsection (1), an obligation under this Chapter is created from that fact. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your unilateral lawful act gives rise to an indirect/quasi-contract per 648(1), that act creates obligations under this Chapter as provided by 648(2).

instruction: My friend started running my cafe without telling me and now wants to leave it as it is. Can they abandon it?
input: Section no 649 . If other’s property managed voluntarily, not to be abandoned : ( negotiorum gestio ): If a person manages or operates a business or property of another person on his or her own without information to, or authority from, that other person, the person shall, so long as such business or property continues to exist, not abandon such business or property without handing it over to that other person, his or her successor or agent or until that other person removes him or her.
output: According to Section 649... Rule: A voluntary manager of another's business/property without authority must not abandon it and must hand it over to the owner, successor, or agent, or remain until removed. Application/Conclusion: Your friend cannot simply abandon the cafe; they must hand it back to you (or your successor/agent) or remain until you remove them.

instruction: I delegated a duty but the delegate acted prejudicially and harmed the beneficiary. Am I still on the hook?
input: Section no 651 . Not absolved from obligation by delegation of authority : If a person, who is entrusted by another person with a responsibility to do any act, delegates any or all of his or her powers to another person to do that act in a manner not to be prejudicial to the obligation vis-à-vis that other 200 person, the person shall not be free from his or her own obligation by the reason of such delegation.
output: According to Section 651... Rule: Delegating powers does not free the entrusted person from their obligation, particularly where the delegation must not be prejudicial to the obligation. Application/Conclusion: You remain liable — delegation does not absolve you, and if the delegate harmed the beneficiary, you can still be held responsible.

instruction: I removed stones from a flooded road to save passing cars without telling the municipality. Do I have a right to be paid?
input: Section no 652 . Reasonable costs to be paid for saving property in times of : disaster: If any person saves or protects any property in times of disaster such as fire, flood, landslide, storm and earthquake without giving information to its owner, the owner of property shall reimburse the reasonable expenses incurred in saving or protecting such property to such a person.
output: According to Section 652... Rule: A person who saves or protects property in disasters (fire, flood, landslide, storm, earthquake) without informing the owner is entitled to reimbursement of reasonable expenses from the owner. Application/Conclusion: You can claim reasonable expenses from the owner (e.g., the municipality or relevant owner) for removing the stones to protect passing cars during the flood.

instruction: Can I sue the maker if I was harmed after consuming a product I bought?
input: Section no 685  part (2) : The producer of a defective product referred to in sub section (1) shall bear liability under this Chapter for the loss or damage, if any, caused to the body, life or property of any person as a result of the consumption of such product sold or distributed by any one. Explanation : For the purposes of this Chapter,
output:
According to Section 685(2):
Rule: The producer of a defective product shall bear liability for loss or damage to body, life or property caused by consumption of such product.
Application/Conclusion: If you were harmed by consuming the product and it qualifies as a defective product under the Chapter, you can sue the producer because Section 685(2) makes the producer liable for such harms.

instruction: How much time do I have to file a lawsuit for harm caused by a defective good?
input: Section no 684 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within six months after the date on which such an act was done or action was taken. 392
output:
According to Section 684:
Rule: A person aggrieved under this Chapter must file a lawsuit within six months from the date of the act or action complained of.
Application/Conclusion: You have six months from the date the act or action occurred to start legal proceedings under this Chapter; waiting longer risks your case being barred by the statute of limitations.

instruction: What exactly counts as a 'defective product' in plain terms?
input: Section no 685  part (1) : “Defective product” means any goods or service which, for any of the following reasons, lack the minimum safety measures that a person of general prudence reasonably expects while consuming any product:
output:
According to Section 685(1):
Rule: A 'defective product' is any good or service that lacks the minimum safety measures reasonably expected by a prudent consumer.
Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, a product is 'defective' if it doesn't meet basic safety expectations a normal consumer would have when using it.

instruction: What kinds of defects are listed by the law?
input:
Section no 685  part (1) (a) : Defective design, manufacturing, processing or installation,

Section no 685  part (1) (b) : Defective packing, safety or storage,

Section no 685  part (1) (c) : Defective presentation,

Section no 685  part (1) (d) : Lacking adequate measures or precautions to control the potential risk or danger according to the nature of the produced good or service.
output:
According to Section 685(1)(a)-(d):
Rule: The law identifies defective design/manufacture/processing/installation; defective packing/safety/storage; defective presentation; and lack of adequate precautions to control foreseeable risks as types of defects.
Application/Conclusion: If a product suffers from any of these listed problems, it can be treated as a defective product under the statute and may give rise to liability.

instruction: If the product only became dangerous after I bought it, can I still hold the producer responsible?
input: Section no 687  clause (b) : The goods or service that he or she produced, imported, sold or distributed was not defective at the time of production, import, sale or distribution or it became defective after the sale or distribution,
output:
According to Section 687(b):
Rule: A producer is not liable if the goods or service were not defective at the time of production/import/sale/distribution or if they became defective after sale or distribution.
Application/Conclusion: If the product became defective only after you bought it (i.e., it was not defective when sold), the producer can use Section 687(b) as a defense and you may not be able to hold them liable under this Chapter.

instruction: I can't find the original manufacturer — who can I sue for a defective imported product?
input:
Section no 685  part (2) (a) : The distributor or seller if the producer cannot be traced out,

Section no 685  part (2) (b) : In the case of any imported product, the importer of the defective product or the distributor or seller of such product.
output:
According to Section 685(2)(a)-(b):
Rule: If the producer cannot be traced, the distributor or seller is included as a 'producer' for liability; for imported products, the importer or the distributor/seller may be liable.
Application/Conclusion: If you cannot locate the manufacturer, you can pursue the distributor/seller; for imported goods you can also sue the importer or the local distributor/seller under the statutory scheme.

instruction: Am I protected if the seller never marketed or distributed the product?
input: Section no 687  clause (c) : The goods or service that he or she produced has not been marketed, sold or distributed, 394
output:
According to Section 687(c):
Rule: The producer shall not be liable if the goods or service he or she produced have not been marketed, sold or distributed.
Application/Conclusion: If a producer can prove the product was never marketed, sold or distributed, Section 687(c) provides a defense and the producer may be discharged from liability.

instruction: What must I prove when I claim a product injured me?
input: Section no 686 . Claimant to prove that product is defective : If any person makes a claim that any good or service is a defective product and he or she has suffered injury to his or her body, life or property from the consumption thereof, he or she shall prove that there is the relationship between such defective product and the injury, and that such injury has resulted solely from the consumption of such product.
output:
According to Section 686:
Rule: The claimant must prove the causal relationship between the defective product and the injury and that the injury resulted solely from consumption of that product.
Application/Conclusion: To succeed you must show both (1) the product caused your injury and (2) the injury resulted solely from using that product; lacking either element weakens the claim.

instruction: Does the law outright ban selling defective products?
input: Section no 685 . To be liable for defective product : (1) No person shall produce any defective product and sell or distribute, or cause to be sold or distributed, any defective goods or service.
output:
According to Section 685(1):
Rule: No person shall produce a defective product and sell, distribute, or cause it to be sold or distributed.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—the statute prohibits producing and selling or distributing defective goods or services; doing so can lead to liability under the Chapter.

instruction: If I imported a product that hurt someone, can I be held liable even if I didn't make it?
input: Section no 685  part (2) (b) : In the case of any imported product, the importer of the defective product or the distributor or seller of such product.
output:
According to Section 685(2)(b):
Rule: For imported products, the importer or the distributor or seller of such product is included as a producer and can bear liability.
Application/Conclusion: Yes—if an imported product causes harm, the importer (or distributor/seller) can be held liable under this provision even if they did not manufacture the item.

instruction: What happens if a seller is sued but the actual producer can be found?
input: Section no 685  part (2) (a) : The distributor or seller if the producer cannot be traced out,
output:
According to Section 685(2)(a):
Rule: The distributor or seller is treated as a producer only if the actual producer cannot be traced out.
Application/Conclusion: If the actual producer can be traced, the distributor or seller would not automatically be treated as the 'producer' under this clause; you should generally pursue the actual producer first.

instruction: Does the statute define what a 'Good' is?
input: Section no 685  part (3) : “Good” means any industrial product for consumption by the public.
output:
According to Section 685(3):
Rule: 'Good' is defined as any industrial product for consumption by the public.
Application/Conclusion: The law's protections apply to industrial products intended for public consumption; if the item falls into that category it is a 'good' under the Chapter.

instruction: If someone claims a product was defective, can the producer prove they never produced it to avoid liability?
input: Section no 687  clause (a) : He or she has not produced, sold or distributed the defective product,
output:
According to Section 687(a):
Rule: A producer is not liable if he or she proves they did not produce, sell or distribute the defective product.
Application/Conclusion: If a producer can prove they had no role in producing, selling or distributing the product, Section 687(a) provides a valid defense and they may be released from liability.

instruction: Short: Can a product's poor presentation be a legal defect?
input: Section no 685  part (1) (c) : Defective presentation,
output:
According to Section 685(1)(c):
Rule: Defective presentation is listed as a type of defect in the definition of 'defective product.'
Application/Conclusion: Yes—poor or misleading presentation can constitute a legal defect under the statute and support a claim if it causes harm.

instruction: I run a small shop. Am I responsible if I sell a defective product but I didn't manufacture it and I can find the maker?
input: Section no 685  part (2) (a) : The distributor or seller if the producer cannot be traced out,
output:
According to Section 685(2)(a):
Rule: The distributor or seller is included as a producer only if the actual producer cannot be traced.
Application/Conclusion: If you can trace and sue the actual manufacturer, Section 685(2)(a) generally won't make you liable as the 'producer'; your liability as a seller depends on whether the producer can be traced and other facts.

instruction: I was injured but the product was altered after sale — can I still hold the original producer liable?
input: Section no 687  clause (b) : The goods or service that he or she produced, imported, sold or distributed was not defective at the time of production, import, sale or distribution or it became defective after the sale or distribution,
output:
According to Section 687(b):
Rule: The producer is not liable if the goods were not defective when produced/imported/sold/distributed or if they became defective after sale/distribution.
Application/Conclusion: If the product was altered or became defective after you bought it, the original producer can rely on Section 687(b) to avoid liability; this makes it harder to hold the producer responsible for post-sale alterations.

instruction: I want to sue — what exact connection do I need to show between the product and my injury?
input: Section no 686 . Claimant to prove that product is defective : If any person makes a claim that any good or service is a defective product and he or she has suffered injury to his or her body, life or property from the consumption thereof, he or she shall prove that there is the relationship between such defective product and the injury, and that such injury has resulted solely from the consumption of such product.
output:
According to Section 686:
Rule: The claimant must prove a relationship (causal link) between the defective product and the injury, and that the injury resulted solely from consuming the product.
Application/Conclusion: You must demonstrate both causation and exclusive causation by the product—showing the product caused the injury and that no other cause produced the injury—to meet the claimant's burden under the law.

instruction: I accidentally received my cousin's money that was sent to me by mistake — do I have to return it and pay interest?
input:
To return goods or amount taken with malafide
intention and : benefits accrued therefrom: (1) If any person receives from
another person with malafide intention any amount or goods in which he or
she has no claim, he or she shall return to that other person such amount or
goods and the interest to be chargeable on such amount under the law or the
advantage or return accrued from such goods, from the date of receipt of such

output:
According to Section 667(1)...

Application/Conclusion: Even if the transfer was a mistake, if it qualifies as receipt in which you have no claim, you should return the money and be prepared to account for interest or benefits that accrued while you held it.

instruction: Someone took my watch in bad faith and sold it. What happens if the watch is lost while in their possession?
input: Section no 667 part (2) : If the amount or goods received pursuant to subsection Section no 667 part (1) : are lost or damaged for any reason, he or she shall also pay the compensation therefor.
output:
According to Section 667(2)...
Rule: If goods received under Section 667(1) are lost or damaged for any reason while held by the recipient, that person must pay compensation for the loss or damage.
Application/Conclusion: The person who took and later lost your watch must compensate you for the loss, even if the loss occurred after they received it in bad faith.

instruction: A friend paid off my loan without telling me. Do I need to repay them?
input: Section no 668 . To pay debt paid by third person : If a debt payable by a person is paid by a third person without the debtor’s knowledge, the debtor shall pay the debt to the person who has so paid it. 203
output:
According to Section 668...
Rule: If a third person pays a debt payable by someone else without the debtor’s knowledge, the debtor must repay the third person.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — you are obligated to repay your friend who paid your loan even if you did not know about the payment at the time.

instruction: If my neighbour paid my property tax for me, can they force me to reimburse them?
input: Section no 669 . Right to claim reimbursement if payable tax paid by another : person: If a tax payable by a person is paid by another person, that other person who has so paid the tax may claim reimbursement therefor from the person who is obliged to pay it. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “tax” means any type of government fee, charge, tariff, duty and fine, and also includes a local tax.
output:
According to Section 669...
Rule: A person who pays another person's tax may claim reimbursement from the person who was obliged to pay that tax.
Application/Conclusion: Your neighbour can legally demand reimbursement from you for the property tax they paid on your behalf.

instruction: I found a smartphone on the street. Can I keep it until someone claims it?
input:
Section no 670 . Goods found may be kept upon giving information to
police : (1) If any person finds any goods in any manner, he or she may, having given a notice thereof, along with actual description thereof, to the police, safely retain such goods with him or her until the concerned owner is found.
output:
According to Section 670(1)...
Rule: A finder of goods may, after giving notice and an actual description to the police, safely retain the goods until the owner is found.
Application/Conclusion: You may keep the smartphone temporarily, but you must first notify the police with an accurate description and hold it until the true owner is located.

instruction: I spent money to advertise a lost ring I found. Can I demand that the owner repay me for my expenses before returning the ring?
input:
Section no 670  part (2) : The concerned owner shall bear the expenses
incurred in finding the owner of goods referred to in sub-section (1) and retaining
such goods, and the finder of goods may retain the goods until the payment of
such expenses.
output:
According to Section 670(2)...
Rule: The owner must bear expenses incurred in finding and retaining the found goods, and the finder may retain the goods until those expenses are paid.
Application/Conclusion: You can require the owner to repay your advertising and retention expenses and may keep the ring until they reimburse you.

instruction: No one claimed the bicycle I found. After how long does it become mine?
input: Section no 670  part (3) : If no person appears to claim the goods retained pursuant to sub-section (1) until three years, the goods shall belong to the finder. 385
output:
According to Section 670(3)...
Rule: If no one claims found goods retained under subsection (1) within three years, ownership vests in the finder.
Application/Conclusion: If nobody claims the bicycle within three years from when you reported and held it as required, the bicycle becomes yours.

instruction: I discovered today that someone used my savings without permission last month. How long do I have to sue?
input:
Section no 671 . Statute of limitation : A person who is aggrieved from
any act done or action taken under this Chapter may make a lawsuit within two
years after the date of accrual of the cause of action. 386
output:
According to Section 671...
Rule: A person aggrieved by any act under this Chapter must bring a lawsuit within two years from the date the cause of action accrued.
Application/Conclusion: You generally have two years from the date you discovered (or from the date the cause arose, depending on accrual) to file suit regarding the unauthorized use of your savings — act promptly.

instruction: Someone caused damage to my shop by reckless driving; there's no contract between us. Is this a tort?
input: Section no 672  part (2) : If the parties do not have any prior contractual relationship in relation to any commission or omission referred to in sub-section (1), the loss or damage resulted from such a commission or recklessness shall be deemed to be a tort. Explanation: For the purposes of this Chapter, the term “omission” means the state of failure of a person to do any act which the person is bound to do.
output:
According to Section 672(2)...
Rule: Where there is no prior contractual relationship, loss or damage from a commission or recklessness is deemed a tort.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — because there’s no contract between you and the driver, the damage to your shop caused by reckless driving qualifies as a tort, giving you a right to seek remedy under this Chapter.

instruction: What exactly counts as a tort in simple terms?
input:
Section no 672 . Tort deemed to be committed : (1) No person shall
cause loss or damage, in any manner, to another person’s body, life or property
or legally protected right or interest by the reason of commission or omission
done, whether by any default, negligence or recklessness on the part of himself
or herself or of any one else to whom he or she must bear obligation according
to this Chapter.
output:
According to Section 672(1)...
Rule: A tort occurs when someone causes loss or damage to another’s body, life, property, or legally protected rights by an act or failure to act, through default, negligence, or recklessness.
Application/Conclusion: In plain terms, harming another person or their property through careless or wrongful behavior — even without a contract — is a tort and can make the wrongdoer liable.

instruction: I was negligent at my shop and someone got hurt. Am I automatically liable?
input: Section no 672  part (3) : A person who commits a tort pursuant to subsection Section no 672 part (1) : shall bear liability under this Chapter.
output:
According to Section 672(3)...
Rule: A person who commits a tort under subsection (1) bears liability under this Chapter.
Application/Conclusion: If your negligence caused injury and that conduct falls within subsection (1), you are liable and may be required to compensate the injured person under the Chapter.

instruction: Under which section is the rule that someone who pays another's tax can seek reimbursement found?

Application/Conclusion: The right to reimbursement for payment of another’s tax is specifically set out in Section 669, so anyone in that situation may rely on this provision to recover their payment.

instruction: Can I legally hold on to found goods until I get my storage and advertisement costs reimbursed?
input:
Section no 670  part (2) : The concerned owner shall bear the expenses
incurred in finding the owner of goods referred to in sub-section (1) and retaining

such expenses.
output:
According to Section 670(2)...
Rule: The owner must cover expenses incurred in finding and retaining found goods, and the finder may retain the goods until such expenses are paid.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — you may lawfully retain the goods until the owner reimburses your legitimate costs for finding and holding the item.

instruction: My cousin borrowed money and then lied to me. He used the money to buy things. Must he return benefits too?

instruction: I found a valuable painting and told police. If after two years no one claims it, do I own it?
input: Section no 670  part (3) : If no person appears to claim the goods retained pursuant to sub-section (1) until three years, the goods shall belong to the finder. 385
output:

instruction: Someone received money they had no right to. Can they escape liability by saying they were careless and not malicious?

done, whether by any default, negligence or recklessness on the part of himself
or herself or of any one else to whom he or she must bear obligation according
to this Chapter.
output:
According to Section 672(1)...
Rule: Causing loss or damage to another’s property by commission or omission through default, negligence or recklessness is prohibited and actionable under this Chapter.
Application/Conclusion: You can sue for the damage to your fence as the driver’s reckless act caused property loss; the driver (or the person responsible) will be liable under tort law even without any prior contract.

instruction: I found a laptop and notified police. The owner says they will pay my costs but hasn't paid yet — can I still hold it?
input:
Section no 670  part (2) : The concerned owner shall bear the expenses
incurred in finding the owner of goods referred to in sub-section (1) and retaining
such goods, and the finder of goods may retain the goods until the payment of
such expenses.
output:
According to Section 670(2)...
Rule: The owner must bear expenses for finding and retaining found goods, and the finder may keep the goods until those expenses are paid.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — until the owner actually pays your lawful expenses, you may retain the laptop in accordance with the section.

instruction: My neighbor paid for my father's funeral because no one told him we were the heirs. Can I make him pay me back?
input: Section no 655 . Successor to reimburse expenses incurred in obsequies of : deceased: If any person performs the funeral and obsequies acts of a deceased in accordance with his or her rites, tradition and culture, without giving information to the successor to or close relative of the deceased and claims the expenses incurred in the performance of such funeral and obsequies acts, the closest heir to, and, in the absence of the heir, the relative of, the deceased shall reimburse that person for the expenses.
output:
According to Section 655...
Rule: If someone performs funeral/obsequies acts without informing the deceased’s successor or close relative and claims expenses, the closest heir (or if no heir, the relative) must reimburse those expenses.
Application/Conclusion: Your neighbor performed the funeral without informing you as the heir and now claims expenses. Under Section 655 you, as the closest heir, are obliged to reimburse the expenses he incurred.

instruction: A distant relative organized my uncle's obsequies and wants us to pay. Do we have to if we are the heirs but were not informed?
input: Section no 655 . Successor to reimburse expenses incurred in obsequies of : deceased: If any person performs the funeral and obsequies acts of a deceased in accordance with his or her rites, tradition and culture, without giving information to the successor to or close relative of the deceased and claims the expenses incurred in the performance of such funeral and obsequies acts, the closest heir to, and, in the absence of the heir, the relative of, the deceased shall reimburse that person for the expenses.
output:
According to Section 655...
Rule: When funeral acts are performed without informing the successor or close relative and expenses are claimed, the closest heir (or if none, a relative) must reimburse the person who performed them.
Application/Conclusion: As the closest heirs you must reimburse the distant relative who paid for the obsequies because he performed them without informing you and is claiming the expenses.

instruction: Someone performed obsequies as an act of compassion and says we need not pay. Are they entitled to reimbursement?
input: Section no 655 . Successor to reimburse expenses incurred in obsequies of : deceased: If any person performs the funeral and obsequies acts of a deceased in accordance with his or her rites, tradition and culture, without giving information to the successor to or close relative of the deceased and claims the expenses incurred in the performance of such funeral and obsequies acts, the closest heir to, and, in the absence of the heir, the relative of, the deceased shall reimburse that person for the expenses.
output:
According to Section 655...
Rule: A person who performed funeral/obsequies without informing successors and claims expenses is to be reimbursed by the closest heir (or, absent an heir, by a relative).
Application/Conclusion: If the person voluntarily performed the rites and claims expenses, the heir must reimburse them. If, however, they expressly performed the rites gratuitously (i.e., with clear intention of no charge), reimbursement may not be expected—Section 655 entitles reimbursement where expenses are claimed.

instruction: Can I claim reimbursement for caring for my mentally ill brother when our father refuses to support him?
input: Section no 656 . To bear expenses in maintenance (palan poshan)of incompetent : person: If a person obliged to maintain (palan poshan) or take care of (herbichar) a person of unsound mind, a person with physical infirmity or a helpless minor having no income of his or her own refuses to maintain such a person and any other person maintains (palan poshan)or takes care of (herbichar) him or her, that other person shall be entitled to claim reimbursement for the expenses incurred therein from the person under such an obligation.
output:
According to Section 656...
