Rule: If the person legally obliged to maintain an incompetent (unsound mind, physically infirm, or helpless minor without income) refuses, any other person who maintains or cares for that person is entitled to claim reimbursement of expenses from the obliged person.
Application/Conclusion: Since your father is obliged to maintain your mentally ill brother and refuses, your expenses in maintaining him can be claimed from your father under Section 656.

instruction: I looked after my niece (a helpless minor) because her guardian refused. Can I demand money back from the guardian?
input: Section no 656 . To bear expenses in maintenance (palan poshan)of incompetent : person: If a person obliged to maintain (palan poshan) or take care of (herbichar) a person of unsound mind, a person with physical infirmity or a helpless minor having no income of his or her own refuses to maintain such a person and any other person maintains (palan poshan)or takes care of (herbichar) him or her, that other person shall be entitled to claim reimbursement for the expenses incurred therein from the person under such an obligation.
output:
According to Section 656...
Rule: A person obliged to maintain or take care of an incompetent or helpless minor must reimburse another who steps in and maintains or cares for that person when the obliged person refuses.
Application/Conclusion: You can claim reimbursement from the guardian who was obliged to support your niece but refused, because you provided maintenance in their stead.

instruction: My cousin with disabilities has no income. Their legal guardian refuses to help; I paid for care. What does the law allow me to recover?
input: Section no 656 . To bear expenses in maintenance (palan poshan)of incompetent : person: If a person obliged to maintain (palan poshan) or take care of (herbichar) a person of unsound mind, a person with physical infirmity or a helpless minor having no income of his or her own refuses to maintain such a person and any other person maintains (palan poshan)or takes care of (herbichar) him or her, that other person shall be entitled to claim reimbursement for the expenses incurred therein from the person under such an obligation.
output:
According to Section 656...
Rule: When the person legally obliged to maintain an incompetent or helpless person refuses, anyone else who maintains or cares for that person is entitled to reimbursement of the expenses from the obliged person.
Application/Conclusion: You may recover the expenses you incurred in caring for your cousin from the legal guardian who refused to perform their obligation.

instruction: A stranger paid for my treatment after an accident and asks me to reimburse. I'm the heir living in the joint family. Do I have to pay?
input: Section no 657 . Treatment expenses to be reimbursed : If a person becomes seriously ill owing to an accident or other reason and any other person, except his or her heir living in the joint family, relative or close person, conducts, or causes to be conducted medical treatment of him or her voluntarily, the heir, relative or close person to him 380 shall reimburse that other person who has conducted, or caused to be conducted, the treatment for the expenses incurred in such treatment. Provided that if the treatment has been conducted, or caused to be conducted, with the intention of doing so gratuitously, the expenses need not be reimbursed.
output:
According to Section 657...
Rule: If a person (other than the injured person's heir living in the joint family, relative, or close person) voluntarily conducts or causes medical treatment, then the heir, relative, or close person must reimburse the person who paid the treatment expenses. However, if the treatment was given gratuitously, expenses need not be reimbursed.
Application/Conclusion: Because you are an heir living in the joint family, Section 657 contemplates that someone other than you paid for treatment and the heir/relatives must reimburse them. As the heir in the joint family you are among those who must reimburse the stranger who voluntarily conducted or caused the treatment—unless the stranger clearly intended it to be gratuitous.

instruction: My friend paid for my hospital treatment after an accident. Can I refuse to repay since they said it's okay?
input: Section no 657 . Treatment expenses to be reimbursed : If a person becomes seriously ill owing to an accident or other reason and any other person, except his or her heir living in the joint family, relative or close person, conducts, or causes to be conducted medical treatment of him or her voluntarily, the heir, relative or close person to him 380 shall reimburse that other person who has conducted, or caused to be conducted, the treatment for the expenses incurred in such treatment. Provided that if the treatment has been conducted, or caused to be conducted, with the intention of doing so gratuitously, the expenses need not be reimbursed.
output:
According to Section 657...
Rule: When a third person (not an heir living in the joint family, relative, or close person) voluntarily conducts medical treatment, heirs/relatives/close persons must reimburse that person, unless the treatment was intended to be gratuitous.
Application/Conclusion: If your friend clearly said or showed they intended the treatment to be free (gratuitous), you are not required to reimburse. If there was no such gratuitous intention and they expect reimbursement, the heirs/close persons are obliged to repay the treatment expenses under Section 657.

instruction: A volunteer hospital worker paid for surgery of a stranger and now wants us (the family) to reimburse. Is that allowed?
input: Section no 657 . Treatment expenses to be reimbursed : If a person becomes seriously ill owing to an accident or other reason and any other person, except his or her heir living in the joint family, relative or close person, conducts, or causes to be conducted medical treatment of him or her voluntarily, the heir, relative or close person to him 380 shall reimburse that other person who has conducted, or caused to be conducted, the treatment for the expenses incurred in such treatment. Provided that if the treatment has been conducted, or caused to be conducted, with the intention of doing so gratuitously, the expenses need not be reimbursed.
output:
According to Section 657...
Rule: A voluntary provider (other than the patient’s heir in joint family, relative, or close person) who conducts or arranges medical treatment can claim reimbursement from the patient’s heir/relative/close person—unless the treatment was intended as gratuitous.
Application/Conclusion: The volunteer hospital worker may be entitled to reimbursement from the deceased/ill person’s heirs or close persons unless it is clear the worker intended the treatment to be gratuitous.

instruction: Government cleared a hazardous tree I refused to cut despite notices and now sent me a bill. Can they charge me?
input: Section no 658 . To bear expenses made by public bodies : If a person voluntarily omits to follow the necessary health or safety measures required to be followed according to law for the protection of body, life or property of him or her or of the public, and if any government or public body follows, or causes to be followed, such measures, the person shall pay reasonable expenses incurred for that purpose even if he or she does not agree to follow, or cause to be followed, such measures.
output:
According to Section 658...
Rule: If a person voluntarily fails to follow legally required health or safety measures, and a government/public body carries out those measures, the person must pay reasonable expenses incurred—even if they disagreed.
Application/Conclusion: Since you omitted required safety measures and the public body acted to address the risk, Section 658 allows the government to recover reasonable expenses from you.

instruction: Public health officials fumigated my property after I refused to allow spraying. Now they want me to pay. Is that legal?
input: Section no 658 . To bear expenses made by public bodies : If a person voluntarily omits to follow the necessary health or safety measures required to be followed according to law for the protection of body, life or property of him or her or of the public, and if any government or public body follows, or causes to be followed, such measures, the person shall pay reasonable expenses incurred for that purpose even if he or she does not agree to follow, or cause to be followed, such measures.
output:
According to Section 658...
Rule: A person who omits legally required health/safety measures must pay reasonable expenses incurred by government/public bodies that perform those measures on their behalf, regardless of agreement.
Application/Conclusion: The officials’ claim for reasonable fumigation expenses against you is supported by Section 658 because you refused to follow required public-health measures and they acted to protect public safety.

instruction: I paid a utility bill that my landlord promised to pay under a contract but didn’t. Can I get reimbursed by the landlord?
input: Section no 659 . To reimburse amount paid by person interested in : If a contract is so concluded that a person promises to pay any amount which another person is bound by law to pay and if that person fails to pay it, and other person who has to pay, pays it, the person concluding a contract shall reimburse such an amount to that person.
output:
According to Section 659...
Rule: Where a contract obliges someone to pay an amount that another is legally bound to pay, and that contracted person fails, any person who pays the amount is entitled to be reimbursed by the person who concluded the contract.
Application/Conclusion: You paid the utility bill that the landlord had contractually promised to pay and failed to. Under Section 659 the landlord (the person who concluded the contract) must reimburse you.

instruction: I promised the city to pay my brother's tax (he was legally obligated) but he didn't. I paid it. Can I recover that from him?
input: Section no 659 . To reimburse amount paid by person interested in : If a contract is so concluded that a person promises to pay any amount which another person is bound by law to pay and if that person fails to pay it, and other person who has to pay, pays it, the person concluding a contract shall reimburse such an amount to that person.
output:
According to Section 659...
Rule: If someone contracts to pay an amount another is legally bound to pay and fails, then a person who pays that amount can seek reimbursement from the person who made the contract.
Application/Conclusion: Because you paid the tax that your brother was legally bound to pay and someone had promised to cover it contractually, you can claim reimbursement from the person who made that contractual promise (or, depending on facts, from your brother) as provided by Section 659.

instruction: I delivered goods to a buyer who now refuses to pay. What does the law say?
input: Section no 660 . To pay price or remuneration : If a person delivers any goods to or does any work for another person, that other person shall pay the price of such goods or service or remuneration of the work to the person.
output:
According to Section 660...
Rule: When a person delivers goods or performs work for another, that other person must pay the price of the goods or the remuneration for the work.
Application/Conclusion: Since you delivered goods to the buyer, Section 660 entitles you to demand the agreed price; the buyer is legally obligated to pay you the price or remuneration.

instruction: I completed contracted labor but the employer hasn't paid my wages. Can I demand remuneration under the law?
input: Section no 660 . To pay price or remuneration : If a person delivers any goods to or does any work for another person, that other person shall pay the price of such goods or service or remuneration of the work to the person.
output:
According to Section 660...
Rule: A person who does work for another is entitled to payment of remuneration by that other person.
Application/Conclusion: You performed the contracted work; under Section 660 the employer must pay your remuneration. You can insist on payment and pursue legal remedies to recover it.

instruction: My aunt maintained an elderly neighbor (no relation) who was abandoned by family. Can she demand reimbursement from the neighbor's legal relatives?
input: Section no 656 . To bear expenses in maintenance (palan poshan)of incompetent : person: If a person obliged to maintain (palan poshan) or take care of (herbichar) a person of unsound mind, a person with physical infirmity or a helpless minor having no income of his or her own refuses to maintain such a person and any other person maintains (palan poshan)or takes care of (herbichar) him or her, that other person shall be entitled to claim reimbursement for the expenses incurred therein from the person under such an obligation.
output:
According to Section 656...
Rule: If the person legally obliged to maintain an incompetent or helpless person refuses, someone else who maintains or cares for that person can claim reimbursement from the obliged person.
Application/Conclusion: Your aunt, having maintained the abandoned neighbor, may claim reimbursement from the neighbor’s legal relatives who are obligated to maintain him but refused to do so.

instruction: Can a Nepali court decide other issues that are connected to a lawsuit brought against a foreigner here?
input: Section no 719 . Other matters concerning a case may also be settled by court of : Nepal: If it appears that any other matter related to any case involving a foreigner instituted in a court of Nepal under its jurisdiction to settle the main dispute should also be settled, the court may assume its jurisdiction over that matter also and settle it accordingly.
output: According to Section 719, the Rule: if any other matter related to a case involving a foreigner instituted in a Nepali court should also be settled, the court may assume jurisdiction over that related matter and settle it. Application/Conclusion: If your additional issue is related to the main dispute against the foreigner, you can ask the same Nepali court to hear and decide that issue — the court has authority to assume jurisdiction and settle it.

instruction: My counterclaim is about property connected to a case a foreigner started in Kathmandu. Can the same court hear it?
input: Section no 719 . Other matters concerning a case may also be settled by court of : Nepal: If it appears that any other matter related to any case involving a foreigner instituted in a court of Nepal under its jurisdiction to settle the main dispute should also be settled, the court may assume its jurisdiction over that matter also and settle it accordingly.
output: According to Section 719, the Rule: where another matter is related to a case involving a foreigner before a Nepali court, the court may assume jurisdiction over that related matter as well. Application/Conclusion: Your connected property counterclaim can be brought before the same court; the court is permitted to take jurisdiction and decide it along with the main case.

instruction: If there's a treaty covering my dispute, does this Part override that treaty?
input: Section no 720 . Treaty, if any, to apply : If any treaty to which Nepal is a party contains a separate provision on any matter set forth in this Part, nothing contained in this Part shall affect such provision.
output: According to Section 720, the Rule: where a treaty to which Nepal is a party contains a separate provision on any matter in this Part, the provisions in this Part do not affect the treaty provision. Application/Conclusion: If an applicable international treaty has its own rule on your issue, that treaty provision takes effect and this Part cannot be used to override it.

instruction: Are there cases where the rules in this Part simply do not apply in Nepal because of public order?
input: Section no 721 . Provisions of this Part not to apply : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Part, if the application of any legal provision under this Part in Nepal would be contrary to public order, the provision contained in this Part shall not be applicable in such circumstance.
output: According to Section 721(1), the Rule: if applying any provision of this Part in Nepal would be contrary to public order, that provision shall not be applicable. Application/Conclusion: When application of a provision would conflict with Nepal's public order, that provision cannot be applied in Nepal.

instruction: If a provision in this Part can't apply because of public order, which law governs the matter then?
input: Section no 721  part (2) : If there arises a circumstance referred to in subsection Section no 721  part (1) : , the matters contained in this Part shall be governed by other linking criteria, and if such criteria cannot be determined, by the law of Nepal.
output: According to Section 721(2), the Rule: where a provision of this Part cannot apply due to public order, the matter shall be governed by other linking criteria; if such criteria cannot be determined, the law of Nepal governs. Application/Conclusion: If the Part is inapplicable for public order reasons, you must next look to other connecting criteria; if none fit, Nepalese law will control the case.

instruction: Short question: Can the court take on related claims in a foreigner's suit?
input: Section no 719 . Other matters concerning a case may also be settled by court of : Nepal: If it appears that any other matter related to any case involving a foreigner instituted in a court of Nepal under its jurisdiction to settle the main dispute should also be settled, the court may assume its jurisdiction over that matter also and settle it accordingly.
output: According to Section 719, the Rule: the Nepali court may assume jurisdiction over other matters related to a case involving a foreigner and settle them. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the court can take on related claims connected to the foreigner's suit and adjudicate them.

instruction: Which section says Nepali courts can rule on matters linked to a case involving a foreign national?
input: Section no 719 . Other matters concerning a case may also be settled by court of : Nepal: If it appears that any other matter related to any case involving a foreigner instituted in a court of Nepal under its jurisdiction to settle the main dispute should also be settled, the court may assume its jurisdiction over that matter also and settle it accordingly.
output: According to Section 719, the Rule: Section 719 provides that a court of Nepal may assume jurisdiction over other matters related to a case involving a foreigner and settle them. Application/Conclusion: Use Section 719 as the legal basis to request the Nepali court to decide related matters arising from a foreigner's case.

instruction: My opponent says an international treaty governs my dispute so this Part doesn't matter — is that right?
input: Section no 720 . Treaty, if any, to apply : If any treaty to which Nepal is a party contains a separate provision on any matter set forth in this Part, nothing contained in this Part shall affect such provision.
output: According to Section 720, the Rule: any treaty provision to which Nepal is a party and which contains a separate rule on a matter in this Part is not affected by this Part. Application/Conclusion: Your opponent is correct if an applicable treaty has its own provision on the issue — the treaty provision prevails over this Part.

instruction: My case would require applying a rule that my lawyer says is against public order — can that rule be applied?
input: Section no 721 . Provisions of this Part not to apply : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Part, if the application of any legal provision under this Part in Nepal would be contrary to public order, the provision contained in this Part shall not be applicable in such circumstance.
output: According to Section 721(1), the Rule: any provision of this Part that would be contrary to public order in Nepal shall not be applicable. Application/Conclusion: If applying that rule would contravene public order, it cannot be applied in your case — you must instead rely on alternative connecting criteria or Nepalese law as provided.

instruction: If the Part is unusable because of public order, what hierarchy does the law establish for deciding the matter?
input: Section no 721  part (2) : If there arises a circumstance referred to in subsection Section no 721  part (1) : , the matters contained in this Part shall be governed by other linking criteria, and if such criteria cannot be determined, by the law of Nepal.
output: According to Section 721(2), the Rule: when the Part cannot be applied for public order reasons, matters are governed first by other linking criteria, and if those cannot be determined, by Nepalese law. Application/Conclusion: The established order is: (1) other linking criteria; (2) if none, law of Nepal — follow that sequence to determine applicable law.

instruction: I want a plain answer: does a treaty ever override the rules in this Part?
input: Section no 720 . Treaty, if any, to apply : If any treaty to which Nepal is a party contains a separate provision on any matter set forth in this Part, nothing contained in this Part shall affect such provision.
output: According to Section 720, the Rule: yes — any treaty provision to which Nepal is a party and that contains a separate rule on a matter in this Part is unaffected by the Part. Application/Conclusion: A treaty provision will override or take precedence over conflicting provisions in this Part for matters it specifically covers.

instruction: The statute mentions Section 699(2). What does clause (h) of Section 718 say about matters related to that subsection?
input: Section no 718  clause (h) : A matter to be adjudicated by a court of Nepal under sub section (2) of Section 699.
output: According to Section 718(h), the Rule: clause (h) identifies as within this Part any matter to be adjudicated by a court of Nepal under subsection (2) of Section 699. Application/Conclusion: If your matter is one that falls to be adjudicated under Section 699(2), it is within the scope described by Section 718(h) and thus addressed by this Part.

instruction: Layman's question: the law keeps saying 'public order' — what does the statute tell me will happen if something breaches public order?
input: Section no 721 . Provisions of this Part not to apply : (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Part, if the application of any legal provision under this Part in Nepal would be contrary to public order, the provision contained in this Part shall not be applicable in such circumstance.
output: According to Section 721(1), the Rule: where applying a provision of this Part would be contrary to public order, that provision cannot be applied. Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, the statute says that if using a rule would violate public order, that rule is off the table — the court must not apply it.

instruction: If courts refuse to apply a provision from this Part for public order reasons, are there fallback rules in the statute?
input: Section no 721  part (2) : If there arises a circumstance referred to in subsection Section no 721  part (1) : , the matters contained in this Part shall be governed by other linking criteria, and if such criteria cannot be determined, by the law of Nepal.
output: According to Section 721(2), the Rule: when a provision cannot be applied due to public order, the matter is governed by other linking criteria, or if those cannot be determined, by Nepalese law. Application/Conclusion: Yes — the statute provides a fallback: first look to other connecting criteria; if none fit, apply the law of Nepal.

instruction: I’m preparing a brief: under which section should I cite Nepali courts' authority to settle ancillary matters in foreigner-related suits?
input: Section no 719 . Other matters concerning a case may also be settled by court of : Nepal: If it appears that any other matter related to any case involving a foreigner instituted in a court of Nepal under its jurisdiction to settle the main dispute should also be settled, the court may assume its jurisdiction over that matter also and settle it accordingly.
output: According to Section 719, the Rule: Section 719 authorizes Nepali courts to assume jurisdiction over and settle other matters related to a case involving a foreigner. Application/Conclusion: Cite Section 719 to support the court's authority to hear and decide ancillary or related claims in proceedings involving a foreign national.

instruction: Someone says this Part can ignore treaties — is that true?
input: Section no 720 . Treaty, if any, to apply : If any treaty to which Nepal is a party contains a separate provision on any matter set forth in this Part, nothing contained in this Part shall affect such provision.
output: According to Section 720, the Rule: this Part does not affect treaty provisions on the same matters. Application/Conclusion: No — the Part cannot ignore or override a treaty provision; any treaty provision on the matter remains effective.

instruction: Can Nepal decide my legal capacity if I'm a foreign national living here?
input: (1) The legal capacity of any foreign natural person shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her nationality.
output: According to Section 693(1). Rule: The legal capacity of a foreign natural person is determined by the law of the person's country of nationality. Application/Conclusion: If you are a foreign national, Nepal will look to the law of your country of nationality to decide matters of your legal capacity rather than automatically applying Nepali law.

instruction: What if they can't prove my nationality — whose law decides my capacity then?
input: Section no 693  part (2) : If the nationality of a foreign natural person cannot be ascertained pursuant to sub-section (1), his or her capacity shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and even if such residence cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where he or she is residing for the time being.
output: According to Section 693(2). Rule: When nationality cannot be ascertained, legal capacity is determined by the law of the person's habitual residence; if that cannot be ascertained, by the law of the country where the person is residing at the time. Application/Conclusion: If your nationality cannot be established, Nepal will apply the law of where you habitually reside; failing that, the law of the country where you are currently residing.

instruction: Which country's law decides whether a foreign company can act legally in Nepal?
input: Section no 693  part (3) : The legal capacity or status of a body corporate shall be determined according to the law of the country where it is registered, if the country of registration cannot be so ascertained, according to the law of the country where the headquarters of such body is located, and if even such a country cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where the place of transaction of such a body is located.
output: According to Section 693(3). Rule: The capacity or status of a corporate body is governed by the law of the country where it is registered; if registration country cannot be ascertained, by law of the country of its headquarters; if that also cannot be ascertained, by law of the country where it transacts business. Application/Conclusion: For a foreign company operating in Nepal, Nepal will look first to the law of the country of its registration to determine its legal capacity; if that can't be found, the law of its headquarters or the country of its transaction place will be used.

instruction: A foreigner who lived here has gone missing. Whose law decides presumed death?
input: Section no 694 . Presumption of disappearance or death of foreigner : (1) If a presumption of the disappearance or death of a foreigner has to be made, the matter shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her nationality.
output: According to Section 694(1). Rule: Presumption of disappearance or death of a foreigner is to be determined by the law of the foreigner's country of nationality. Application/Conclusion: If a foreign resident in Nepal is presumed missing or dead, the court will apply the law of that person's nationality to decide the presumption of disappearance or death.

instruction: Their nationality is unknown — what law applies to presuming a foreigner's death?
input: Section no 694  part (2) : If the nationality of a foreigner cannot be ascertained pursuant to sub-section (1), it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and even if such residence cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country of his or her residence immediately before making presumption of his or her disappearance or death.
output: According to Section 694(2). Rule: If nationality cannot be ascertained, presumption of disappearance or death is determined by the law of the foreigner's habitual residence; if that is also unknown, by the law of the country where the person was residing immediately before the presumption. Application/Conclusion: If you cannot prove the missing person's nationality, Nepal will apply the law of their habitual residence, or if that is unknown, the law of the country where they lived just before being declared missing or dead.

instruction: My foreign parent lived in Nepal and recently died. Who counts as their successor here?
input: Section no 695 . Successor to be determined according to foreign law : While determining the successor to a foreigner residing in Nepal when his or her property is open for succession, the successor shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her nationality, if such country cannot be determined, according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and if even such residence cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where he or she is residing for the time being.
output: According to Section 695. Rule: The successor to a foreigner residing in Nepal is determined by the law of the deceased's country of nationality; if that cannot be determined, by the law of their habitual residence; if that also cannot be determined, by the law of the country where they were residing at the time. Application/Conclusion: To decide who inherits your foreign parent's property in Nepal, authorities will apply the deceased's national law first; if that is unavailable, they will use the law of their habitual residence or, failing that, the law of the country where they were living when succession opened.

instruction: My foreign uncle died in Nepal — which law decides who inherits land located in Nepal?
input: Section no 696 . Determination of succession of deceased : (1) If succession is open because of the death of any foreigner in Nepal and it is therefore necessary to determine his or her successor to the property situated in Nepal and the order of preference thereof, it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her nationality at the time of his or her death.
output: According to Section 696(1). Rule: Succession to property situated in Nepal of a foreigner who died in Nepal is determined by the law of the deceased's country of nationality at the time of death. Application/Conclusion: For your uncle's property in Nepal, the applicable succession rules will be those of his country of nationality as of his date of death; Nepal will apply that foreign law to determine successors and order of preference.

instruction: If we can't find the deceased's national law, can Nepalese law be used for succession?
input: Section no 696  part (2) : If the law referred to in sub-section (1) cannot be ascertained, it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence at the time of his or her death, and if even such country cannot be ascertained, according to the law of Nepal.
output: According to Section 696(2). Rule: If the deceased's national law cannot be ascertained, succession is governed by the law of the deceased's habitual residence at death; if that also cannot be ascertained, Nepali law applies. Application/Conclusion: If you cannot identify the applicable law of the deceased's nationality or habitual residence, Nepalese succession law will be used to determine inheritance for property in Nepal.

instruction: How do you tell whether a company or foundation is public or private for legal purposes?
input: Section no 697 . Determination of the nature of corporate body : Question as regards whether a company, foundation or other corporate body is public or private shall be determined according to the law of the country of incorporation of such a company, foundation or body, and if such law cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where the registered oﬀice or headquarters of such a company, foundation or corporate body is situated.
output: According to Section 697. Rule: Whether a corporate body is public or private is determined by the law of its country of incorporation; if that law cannot be ascertained, by the law of the country where its registered office or headquarters is located. Application/Conclusion: To classify a company or foundation as public or private, Nepal will first apply the law of the place of incorporation; if that is unknown, it will look to the law where the entity's registered office or headquarters sits.

instruction: Can Nepali authorities apply Nepali law if an overseas company's incorporation law is unknown when deciding its status?
input: Section no 697 . Determination of the nature of corporate body : Question as regards whether a company, foundation or other corporate body is public or private shall be determined according to the law of the country of incorporation of such a company, foundation or body, and if such law cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where the registered oﬀice or headquarters of such a company, foundation or corporate body is situated.
output: According to Section 697. Rule: If the law of incorporation cannot be ascertained, the law of the country where the entity's registered office or headquarters is situated is used to determine whether it is public or private. Application/Conclusion: If the overseas company's incorporation law is unknown, Nepal will apply the law of the country where its registered office or headquarters is located to decide its public/private nature.

instruction: My foreign corporation's registration country is unknown — can Nepal use the law of its headquarters to decide its legal capacity?
input: Section no 693  part (3) : The legal capacity or status of a body corporate shall be determined according to the law of the country where it is registered, if the country of registration cannot be so ascertained, according to the law of the country where the headquarters of such body is located, and if even such a country cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where the place of transaction of such a body is located.
output: According to Section 693(3). Rule: If the country of registration cannot be ascertained, the law of the country where the corporate headquarters is located determines legal capacity; if that also can't be ascertained, the law of the country where the body transacts business applies. Application/Conclusion: If your corporation's registration country is unknown, Nepal will look to the law of the country of its headquarters to decide legal capacity; only if that too is unknown will it consider the law of the country where it carries out transactions.

instruction: I'm a foreigner with no proof of nationality — can Nepal apply the law of the country where I'm currently living to my legal capacity?
input: Section no 693  part (2) : If the nationality of a foreign natural person cannot be ascertained pursuant to sub-section (1), his or her capacity shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and even if such residence cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where he or she is residing for the time being.
output: According to Section 693(2). Rule: When nationality cannot be established, legal capacity is governed by the law of the person's habitual residence; if that is unknown, by the law of the country where they are currently residing. Application/Conclusion: If you lack proof of nationality and habitual residence cannot be shown, Nepal may apply the law of the country where you are presently residing to determine your legal capacity.

instruction: My sibling is missing and we don't know their nationality — which law decides presumption of their death?
input: Section no 694  part (2) : If the nationality of a foreigner cannot be ascertained pursuant to sub-section (1), it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and even if such residence cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country of his or her residence immediately before making presumption of his or her disappearance or death.
output: According to Section 694(2). Rule: If a foreigner's nationality is unknown, presumption of disappearance or death is determined by the law of their habitual residence; if that cannot be ascertained, by the law of the country where they resided immediately before the presumption. Application/Conclusion: In your sibling's case, Nepal will apply the law of their habitual residence to decide presumption of death; if that is unknown, the law of where they last lived before being declared missing will be used.

instruction: Can Nepali courts use Nepalese succession law if neither nationality nor habitual residence of a deceased foreigner can be found?
input: Section no 696  part (2) : If the law referred to in sub-section (1) cannot be ascertained, it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence at the time of his or her death, and if even such country cannot be ascertained, according to the law of Nepal.
output: According to Section 696(2). Rule: If the deceased's national law cannot be ascertained, succession follows the law of their habitual residence at death; if that too cannot be ascertained, Nepali law applies. Application/Conclusion: Yes — if neither the deceased's national law nor the law of their habitual residence can be determined, Nepali law will govern succession to their property in Nepal.

instruction: Can you explain simply: what decides whether a foreign foundation is public or private?
input: Section no 697 . Determination of the nature of corporate body : Question as regards whether a company, foundation or other corporate body is public or private shall be determined according to the law of the country of incorporation of such a company, foundation or body, and if such law cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where the registered oﬀice or headquarters of such a company, foundation or corporate body is situated.
output: According to Section 697. Rule: The country of incorporation's law decides if a foundation is public or private; if that law can't be found, the law where its registered office or headquarters is located decides. Application/Conclusion: Put simply — look at the law where the foundation was incorporated; if you can't, look at the law of where its main office or headquarters is based.

instruction: My foreign relative lived in Nepal but had multiple residencies. Which law applies to succession if he died here?
input: Section no 696 . Determination of succession of deceased : (1) If succession is open because of the death of any foreigner in Nepal and it is therefore necessary to determine his or her successor to the property situated in Nepal and the order of preference thereof, it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her nationality at the time of his or her death.
output: According to Section 696(1). Rule: Succession for property in Nepal of a foreigner who died in Nepal is governed by the law of the deceased's country of nationality at death. Application/Conclusion: Even if your relative had multiple residencies, the primary rule is to apply the law of their nationality at the time of death to determine succession for property in Nepal; other residencies come into play only if that national law cannot be ascertained under Section 696(2).

instruction: Can you tell me, step by step, whose law is used to pick heirs when a foreigner living here dies and we don't know anything about their nationality or residence?
input: Section no 695 . Successor to be determined according to foreign law : While determining the successor to a foreigner residing in Nepal when his or her property is open for succession, the successor shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her nationality, if such country cannot be determined, according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and if even such residence cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country where he or she is residing for the time being.
output: According to Section 695. Rule: Sequence for determining successors is: (1) law of the deceased's country of nationality; (2) if unknown, law of their habitual residence; (3) if that is unknown, law of the country where they were residing at the time. Application/Conclusion: Step by step, authorities will try the deceased's national law first; if unavailable, they'll use the law of habitual residence; if that too is unavailable, they'll apply the law of the country where the person was residing when succession opened.

instruction: If my father died while living in India, which law governs succession to his bank account (movable property)?
input: Section no 698 . Regulation of property : (1) Succession to a movable property shall be governed by the law of the country of habitual residence of the deceased at the time of his or her death.
output: According to Section 698(1). Rule: Succession to movable property is governed by the law of the country of the deceased's habitual residence at death. Application/Conclusion: Because your father was habitually resident in India when he died, Indian law (the law of his habitual residence) will govern succession to his bank account (movable property).

instruction: I inherited a house that sits in Nepal but the deceased lived abroad. Which law controls succession to that land?
input: Section no 698  part (2) : Succession to an immovable property shall be governed by the law of the country where such property is situated.
output: According to Section 698(2). Rule: Succession to immovable property is governed by the law of the country where the property is located. Application/Conclusion: Since the house is situated in Nepal, Nepali law governs succession to that immovable property despite the deceased's habitual residence being abroad.

instruction: Can I, as a Nepalese citizen, marry in Germany without following Nepal's marriage capacity rules?
input: Section no 699 . Citizen of Nepal to follow law of Nepal while concluding : marriage abroad: (1) A citizen of Nepal shall, while concluding a marriage in a foreign country, comply with such competency, qualification and conditions for marriage as specified by the law of Nepal.
output: According to Section 699(1). Rule: A Nepali citizen marrying abroad must comply with the competency, qualification and conditions for marriage as required by Nepali law. Application/Conclusion: You cannot ignore Nepal's marriage capacity rules when marrying in Germany; you must satisfy the competency and qualification requirements specified by Nepali law.

instruction: If I marry at the Nepali embassy in London, which formalities do I need to follow?
input: Section no 699  part (2) : The formalities to be fulfilled by a citizen of Nepal while concluding a marriage in a foreign country shall be governed by the law of the country where the marriage is concluded. Provided that while concluding a marriage at an embassy or consulate general of Nepal situated in a foreign country, the formalities referred to in the law of Nepal shall be followed.
output: According to Section 699(2). Rule: Formalities for a Nepali citizen's marriage abroad are generally governed by the foreign country's law, except that marriages at a Nepali embassy/consulate must follow Nepali formalities. Application/Conclusion: Because you plan to marry at the Nepali embassy in London, you must follow the formalities prescribed by Nepali law.

instruction: What happens if a Nepali citizen marries abroad in breach of Sections 699(1) and (2)? Will Nepal recognize that marriage?
input: Section no 699  part (3) : A marriage concluded in contravention of subsections Section no 699  part (1) : and (2) shall not be recognized in Nepal.
output: According to Section 699(3). Rule: A marriage that contravenes Sections 699(1) and (2) will not be recognized in Nepal. Application/Conclusion: If your marriage abroad violates the competency/qualification requirements or the applicable formalities under 699(1) and 699(2), Nepal will not recognize the marriage.

instruction: A foreigner wants to marry a Nepali here in Nepal. Whose capacity rules apply — Nepal's or the foreigner's?
input: Section no 700 . Foreigner to follow law of his or her country while concluding : marriage in Nepal: (1) While concluding a marriage between 400 foreigners or between a foreigner and a citizen of Nepal in Nepal, each person entering into marriage shall comply with the capacity, qualification and condition as specified by the law of the respective country of his or her nationality.
output: According to Section 700(1). Rule: Each person marrying in Nepal must comply with the capacity, qualification and conditions specified by the law of their own country of nationality. Application/Conclusion: The foreign spouse must meet the capacity and qualification requirements of their country of nationality, and the Nepali spouse must meet those of Nepal; both sets of national capacity rules are relevant.

instruction: If a foreigner and a Nepali marry in Kathmandu, which formalities are required?
input: Section no 700  part (2) : The formalities to be fulfilled by the foreigners while concluding marriage in Nepal shall be governed by the law of Nepal. Provided that while concluding a marriage at a foreign embassy or consulate general situated in Nepal, the formalities referred to in the law of the concerned country shall be fulfilled.
output: According to Section 700(2). Rule: Formalities for marriages in Nepal are governed by Nepali law, except marriages at a foreign embassy/consulate in Nepal where the foreign country's formalities apply. Application/Conclusion: For a marriage in Kathmandu, the parties must comply with Nepal's formal requirements unless the marriage is conducted at the foreigner's embassy/consulate, in which case that country's formalities would apply.

instruction: Is a marriage in Nepal void if it breaches Sections 700(1) and (2)?
input: Section no 700  part (3) : A marriage concluded in contravention of subsections Section no 700  part (1) : and (2) shall not be recognized in Nepal.
output: According to Section 700(3). Rule: A marriage that contravenes Sections 700(1) and (2) will not be recognized in Nepal. Application/Conclusion: If the marriage in Nepal fails to meet the nationality-based capacity rules (700(1)) or the formalities required by Nepali law (700(2)), Nepal will refuse to recognize it.

instruction: We are both Nepalese — which law decides our matrimonial rights and obligations after marriage?
input: Section no 701 . Consequence of marriage to be according to law of one’s : country: (1) The matrimonial relationship between the couple after the marriage and the consequence of marriage shall be determined according to the law of the country of their nationality if both spouses have the same nationality, and if the country of their nationality is not the same, according to the law of the country of their habitual residence and if even such a country is not the same, according to the law of the country of their residence for the time being.
output: According to Section 701(1). Rule: If both spouses share the same nationality, matrimonial relationships and consequences are governed by the law of that country. Application/Conclusion: Since both of you are Nepalese, Nepali law will determine your matrimonial relationship and its legal consequences.

instruction: My partner and I have different nationalities and live in different habitual residences — how is the law chosen for matrimonial consequences?
input: Section no 701 . Consequence of marriage to be according to law of one’s : country: (1) The matrimonial relationship between the couple after the marriage and the consequence of marriage shall be determined according to the law of the country of their nationality if both spouses have the same nationality, and if the country of their nationality is not the same, according to the law of the country of their habitual residence and if even such a country is not the same, according to the law of the country of their residence for the time being.
output: According to Section 701(1). Rule: If spouses do not share nationality, the law of their country of habitual residence governs; if even habitual residences differ, then the law of their current country of residence governs. Application/Conclusion: Because you and your partner have different nationalities and live in different habitual residences, the law of the country where you habitually reside together (if any) will apply; if there is no common habitual residence, then the law of the country where you currently reside will determine matrimonial consequences.

instruction: We can't figure out which law applies under Section 701(1). What then?
input: Section no 701  part (2) : If the consequence of marriage cannot be determined pursuant to sub-section (1), it shall be determined according to the law of the country of their marriage.
output: According to Section 701(2). Rule: If you cannot determine the applicable law under subsection (1), then the law of the country where the marriage was performed governs. Application/Conclusion: If it's impossible to decide which country's law applies under 701(1), the legal consequences of your marriage will be governed by the law of the country where you were married.

instruction: Which law governs parental authority over my child who is a foreign national?
input: Section no 702 . Paternal authority to be governed by law of the country of : nationality: (1) The relationship between father, mother and son, 401 daughter including paternal authority shall be governed by the law of the country of nationality of the son or daughter, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 702(1). Rule: The parent–child relationship, including paternal authority, is governed by the law of the child's country of nationality. Application/Conclusion: Because your child is a foreign national, the law of the child's nationality will govern parental authority and related parent–child relationships.

instruction: If we can't identify which country's law applies to parental authority under Section 702(1), what's the fallback rule?
input: Section no 702  part (2) : If the law referred to in sub-section (1) is not ascertained, it shall be governed by the law of the country of habitual residence of the father, mother and, if even such country cannot be ascertained, by the law of the country of their residence for the time being.
output: According to Section 702(2). Rule: If the child's nationality law cannot be ascertained, parental authority is governed by the law of the parents' habitual residence; if that is also unascertainable, then by the law of their current country of residence. Application/Conclusion: If you cannot determine the applicable nationality law for your child, look to the law of the parents' habitual residence; if that's unclear too, use the law of the country where the parents presently reside.

instruction: Quick question: If a foreign couple marries at their embassy in Kathmandu, whose formalities control the marriage?
input: Section no 700  part (2) : The formalities to be fulfilled by the foreigners while concluding marriage in Nepal shall be governed by the law of Nepal. Provided that while concluding a marriage at a foreign embassy or consulate general situated in Nepal, the formalities referred to in the law of the concerned country shall be fulfilled.
output: According to Section 700(2). Rule: Generally, Nepali law governs formalities for marriages in Nepal, but marriages at a foreign embassy/consulate in Nepal must follow the concerned foreign country's formalities. Application/Conclusion: If the couple marries at their embassy in Kathmandu, they must follow the formalities required by their country's law (the concerned foreign country's law).

instruction: Under which section is paternal authority governed? I need the exact reference.
input: Section no 702 . Paternal authority to be governed by law of the country of : nationality: (1) The relationship between father, mother and son, 401 daughter including paternal authority shall be governed by the law of the country of nationality of the son or daughter, as the case may be.
output: According to Section 702(1). Rule: Section 702(1) governs paternal authority — it states that parent–child relationships including paternal authority are governed by the law of the child's country of nationality. Application/Conclusion: Use Section 702(1) as the legal reference when addressing issues of paternal authority tied to a child's nationality.

instruction: Can the court decide who becomes guardian of my mentally ill sister who has Nepalese nationality but lives abroad?
input: Section no 704 . Determination of guardianship or curatorship : (1) The guardianship or curatorship of an incompetent or quasi-competent person shall be determined according to the law of the country of nationality of that person.
output:
According to Section 704(1)...
Rule: The guardianship or curatorship of an incompetent or quasi-competent person is determined according to the law of the country of that person's nationality.
Application/Conclusion: Because your sister is a Nepalese national, the applicable law for appointing her guardian will be the law of Nepal. Therefore Nepali law governs who may be appointed as her guardian even if she currently lives abroad.

instruction: My elderly mother has no clear nationality records. Which country's law decides guardianship for her?
input: Section no 704  part (2) : If the country referred to in sub-section (1) cannot be ascertained, it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and if even such country 402 cannot be ascertained, according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence for the time being.
output:
According to Section 704(2)...
Rule: If the person's country of nationality cannot be ascertained, guardianship is determined by the law of the person's habitual residence; if that cannot be ascertained, by the law of the country of habitual residence for the time being.
Application/Conclusion: Since your mother’s nationality cannot be established, the court will look to where she habitually resides now. If that also cannot be fixed, the law of the country where she is habitually residing at present will apply to determine guardianship.

instruction: Who decides the legal relationship between a guardian and the person under guardianship — the guardian's country's law or the ward's?
input: Section no 704  part (3) : The relationship between the guardian or curator and the person under his or her guardianship or curatorship shall be determined according to the law of the country of the guardian or curator or the law of the country where the guardian or curator is appointed as such. Provided that if the habitual residence of the person who is under guardianship or curatorship is in Nepal, it shall be determined according to the law of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 704(3)...
Rule: The relationship between guardian/curator and the person under guardianship is governed by the law of the guardian’s country or the law of the country where the guardian is appointed; however, if the ward habitually resides in Nepal, Nepalese law governs.
Application/Conclusion: Normally the guardian’s national law or the law where the guardian is appointed will control the rights and duties between guardian and ward. But if the person under guardianship habitually resides in Nepal, Nepali law will determine that relationship regardless of the guardian’s country.

instruction: I live in Nepal; my nephew (the ward) is here too, but his guardian was appointed abroad. Which law decides their relationship?
input: Section no 704  part (3) : The relationship between the guardian or curator and the person under his or her guardianship or curatorship shall be determined according to the law of the country of the guardian or curator or the law of the country where the guardian or curator is appointed as such. Provided that if the habitual residence of the person who is under guardianship or curatorship is in Nepal, it shall be determined according to the law of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 704(3)...
Rule: Relationship between guardian and ward is governed by the guardian’s country law or the law of the country of appointment; but if the ward’s habitual residence is in Nepal, Nepalese law applies.
Application/Conclusion: Because your nephew’s habitual residence is in Nepal, Nepali law will determine the guardian-ward relationship even though the guardian was appointed abroad.

instruction: Can I claim alimony? My husband lives in country A and I in country B — which law applies to 'bread and board' separation?
input: Section no 705 . To be determined according to the law of residence : (1) The matter of separation of bread and board shall be governed by the law of the country of habitual residence of the married couple.
output:
According to Section 705(1)...
Rule: Matters of separation of bread and board are governed by the law of the country of the married couple’s habitual residence.
Application/Conclusion: If you and your husband have a shared habitual residence in one country, that country’s law will govern separation and related claims. If you live habitually in different countries, see subsection (2) for the tie-breaker rule.

instruction: Husband and wife live in different countries now. Which law decides their alimony claim?
input: Section no 705  part (2) : If, in governing the matter pursuant to sub-section (1), the country of habitual residence of the couple is not the same, it shall be governed by the law of the last country of their habitual residence, and if even such a country cannot be ascertained, by the law of the court where the case of alimony is sub judice.
output:
According to Section 705(2)...
Rule: If the couple do not share the same habitual residence, the law of the last country of their habitual residence governs; if that cannot be determined, the law of the court where the alimony case is pending applies.
Application/Conclusion: Since you and your husband currently habitually reside in different countries, the law of the country where you last habitually lived together will govern alimony. If that cannot be ascertained, the court hearing your alimony case will apply the law of the court’s country.

instruction: We divorced in a foreign country under that country's law. Will Nepal treat that divorce as valid?
input: Section no 706 . Divorce effected abroad to be recognized : If a divorce is effected between the citizens of Nepal or between a citizen of Nepal and a foreigner in a foreign country, such a divorce shall, if effected in accordance with the law of that country, be recognized and enforced in Nepal in accordance with the law of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 706...
Rule: A divorce effected abroad between Nepali citizens or between a Nepali and a foreigner will be recognized and enforceable in Nepal if it was effected in accordance with the law of that foreign country, subject to Nepali law.
Application/Conclusion: If your foreign divorce complied with the foreign country’s law, Nepal will recognize it and enforce consequences in Nepal under Nepali law. You should ensure the foreign divorce was legally valid where obtained and then follow Nepali procedures for recognition if needed.

instruction: My father transferred ownership of a house located in India. Which country's law decides whether the transfer was valid?
input: Section no 707 . Content of ownership to be determined according to law of : country where property is situated: (1) The content of ownership 403 or possession of any property shall be determined according to the law of the country where such property is situated.
output:
According to Section 707(1)...
Rule: The content of ownership or possession of any property is determined by the law of the country where the property is situated.
Application/Conclusion: Because the house is in India, Indian law will determine whether the transfer of ownership was valid, what rights passed, and any limitations — Nepali law will not govern the substantive ownership issues for that property.

instruction: Someone claims my entitlement to an immovable property abroad was terminated. Which law decides maintenance or termination of ownership?
input: Section no 707  part (2) : A question as regards the maintenance or termination of ownership in an immovable property shall be determined according to the law of the country where such property is situated.
output:
According to Section 707(2)...
Rule: Questions about maintenance or termination of ownership in immovable property are determined by the law of the country where the property is located.
Application/Conclusion: For an immovable property abroad, the foreign country’s law will govern disputes over continued ownership or termination. You must look to that country’s legal rules to defend your entitlement.

instruction: I’m transporting goods from India to Nepal by truck. Which law applies to these goods while they are in transit?
input: Section no 708 . Goods to be governed by law of destination : Any goods in transit in the course of carriage shall be governed by the law of their destination.
output:
According to Section 708...
Rule: Any goods in transit during carriage are governed by the law of their destination.
Application/Conclusion: While your goods are en route to Nepal, the law that will govern rights and obligations concerning them is the law of the destination (Nepal). Therefore Nepalese law will apply to disputes about the goods on arrival or in transit toward that destination.

instruction: We signed a contract that says 'English law applies.' Can the parties pick which country's law governs the contract?
input: Section no 709 . Governing law of contract to be as determined by parties : (1) The governing law of any contract shall be as determined in the contract by its parties.
output:
According to Section 709(1)...
Rule: The governing law of a contract is the law the parties specify in their contract.
Application/Conclusion: Yes — if your contract validly chooses English law, that choice will govern the contract. Courts will generally respect the parties’ selection of governing law subject to any overriding mandatory rules of the forum.

instruction: I'm a plain person — what does 'law of their destination' mean for goods in transit?
input: Section no 708 . Goods to be governed by law of destination : Any goods in transit in the course of carriage shall be governed by the law of their destination.
output:
According to Section 708...
Rule: Goods being transported are subject to the law of the place they are being sent to (their destination).
Application/Conclusion: In simple terms, this means that while goods move from A to B, the legal rules that matter (for ownership disputes, liabilities on carriage, etc.) are those of the country to which the goods are heading — not necessarily where they started or where the carrier is based.

instruction: My brother sold a parcel of land abroad and claims Nepali law applies — is that correct?
input: Section no 707 . Content of ownership to be determined according to law of : country where property is situated: (1) The content of ownership 403 or possession of any property shall be determined according to the law of the country where such property is situated.
output:
According to Section 707(1)...
Rule: Ownership and possession of property are determined by the law of the country where the property is located.
Application/Conclusion: If the parcel is located abroad, Nepali law does not determine its ownership. The foreign country’s law governs whether your brother had power to sell it and whether the sale was effective.

instruction: Short — is a foreign divorce valid here?
input: Section no 706 . Divorce effected abroad to be recognized : If a divorce is effected between the citizens of Nepal or between a citizen of Nepal and a foreigner in a foreign country, such a divorce shall, if effected in accordance with the law of that country, be recognized and enforced in Nepal in accordance with the law of Nepal.
output:
According to Section 706...
Rule: A divorce obtained abroad is recognized in Nepal if it was effected in accordance with the foreign law where it was obtained, and then enforced per Nepali law.
Application/Conclusion: Briefly — yes, if the foreign divorce was valid under that country's law, Nepal will recognize it subject to Nepali procedures.

instruction: We have a contract but didn’t choose a governing law. Which law will govern?
input: Section no 709 . Governing law of contract to be as determined by parties : (1) The governing law of any contract shall be as determined in the contract by its parties.
output:
According to Section 709(1)...
Rule: The governing law of a contract is the law the parties expressly determine in the contract.
Application/Conclusion: If no governing law was chosen in the contract, this section states the ideal rule (party choice). In practice, absence of choice means a court will determine the applicable law using conflict-of-law principles — but that detail is beyond this provision. The key point: parties should specify the governing law in their contract to avoid uncertainty.

instruction: I want to challenge the termination of ownership of an immovable my uncle left me in another country — what rule controls?
input: Section no 707  part (2) : A question as regards the maintenance or termination of ownership in an immovable property shall be determined according to the law of the country where such property is situated.
output:
According to Section 707(2)...
Rule: Disputes about maintenance or termination of ownership in immovable property are governed by the law of the country where that property is located.
Application/Conclusion: Your challenge must be assessed under the foreign country’s property law. You will need to consider that country's legal remedies and processes to contest termination of ownership for the immovable property in question.

instruction: Can a Nepali court decide a contract dispute that was concluded in Nepal between a foreigner and a Nepali?
input: Section no 718  clause (f) : A matter concerning a contract concluded in or to be performed in Nepal between foreigners or to which at least one party is a citizen or body corporate of Nepal,
output: According to Section 718 clause (f): Rule: A court of Nepal has jurisdiction over matters concerning a contract concluded in or to be performed in Nepal where at least one party is a citizen or body corporate of Nepal (or between foreigners when concluded/performed in Nepal). Application/Conclusion: Since your contract was concluded in Nepal and the dispute involves a Nepali party (or is to be performed here), a Nepali court has jurisdiction to hear and decide the contract dispute.

instruction: I'm a refugee — which country's law will govern my case if subsection (1) applies to me?
input: Section no 715  part (3) : If the matter referred to in sub-section (1) concerns a refugee or stateless person, it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her habitual residence, and if even such 406 a law cannot be determined, according to the law of the country of his or her residence for the time being.
output: According to Section 715(3): Rule: For refugees or stateless persons, the matter is determined by the law of the country of their habitual residence; if that law cannot be determined, it is determined by the law of the country of their residence for the time being. Application/Conclusion: If you are a refugee/stateless, first look to the law of your habitual residence; if that cannot be identified, the law of the country where you are currently residing will govern.

instruction: Can both parties ask a Nepali court to allow their case to be tried in the foreign court where one party lives?
input: Section no 716 . Power to give permission for trial of case by foreign court : (1) If both parties to a case which involves a foreign party and is sub judice in a court of Nepal make a joint petition to the court, specifying the reason that it is appropriate and practicable for that case to be resolved by a court of the country of residence of such party and the matter is found reasonable upon 214 examination of the petition, the court may give permission for the proceedings of the case by the foreign court as demanded by the parties to such a case.
output: According to Section 716(1): Rule: If both parties to a case before a Nepali court (which involves a foreign party) jointly petition and show it is appropriate and practicable for the foreign court of that party's residence to resolve the case, and the court finds the petition reasonable, the Nepali court may permit the foreign proceedings. Application/Conclusion: You and the other party can jointly petition the Nepali court asking it to allow the foreign court to hear your case; if the court finds your reasons reasonable, it may grant permission.

instruction: If the Nepali court lets the foreign court hear the case, can the same matter be litigated again in Nepal?
input: Section no 716  part (2) : Once the court has given permission for the proceeding of a case by a foreign court pursuant to sub-section (1), no proceeding shall be made again by a court of Nepal in the same matter.
output: According to Section 716(2): Rule: After a Nepali court grants permission for a foreign court to proceed under subsection (1), no proceedings on the same matter may be made again by a court of Nepal. Application/Conclusion: If the Nepali court permits the foreign trial, you cannot later re-litigate the same matter in Nepal — the Nepali courts will not entertain the same case again.

instruction: There's also a case between me and the other party in a foreign court that may directly affect our Nepali case. Can the Nepali court put our case on hold?
input: Section no 717 . Power to adjourn case sub judice in court of Nepal : If any case between the parties is sub judice in a court of Nepal and a case is running also in a foreign court between such parties in the same matter, and the parties, having considered that the case pending in the court of Nepal is likely to be directly affected by a judgment to be made in the case between them running in the foreign court, apply for the adjournment of the case running in Nepal, the court may adjourn such a case until their case pending in the foreign court is adjudged.
output: According to Section 717: Rule: Where the same parties have a case pending in Nepal and also in a foreign court, and they show the Nepal case is likely to be directly affected by the foreign court's judgment, they may apply and the Nepali court may adjourn the Nepal proceedings until the foreign case is decided. Application/Conclusion: You can apply to the Nepali court to adjourn your case; if the court agrees the foreign judgment will directly affect the Nepal case, the Nepali court may suspend proceedings until the foreign case is adjudicated.

instruction: Does Section 718 generally list what matters Nepali courts can decide?
input: Section no 718 . Court of Nepal to have jurisdiction : A court of Nepal shall have jurisdiction to adjudicate the proceedings and settle any disputes arising in connection with the following matters:
output: According to Section 718: Rule: Section 718 enumerates the categories of matters over which a court of Nepal has jurisdiction to adjudicate disputes. Application/Conclusion: To know whether a Nepali court can hear a particular dispute, check the specific categories listed in Section 718 (clauses a–g); Section 718 is the starting point for jurisdictional questions.

instruction: A dispute arose between two foreigners who live in Nepal about something governed by Nepali law — can Nepali courts hear it?
input: Section no 718  clause (a) : A matter between the foreigners who reside in Nepal or between a foreigner and a citizen of Nepal, that is governed by this Act or other law,
output: According to Section 718 clause (a): Rule: Matters between foreigners residing in Nepal, or between a foreigner and a Nepali citizen, that are governed by this Act or other law fall within Nepali courts' jurisdiction. Application/Conclusion: Because both foreigners reside in Nepal and the dispute is governed by Nepali law, you may bring the dispute before a Nepali court.

instruction: A foreigner living in Nepal is named defendant in my suit. Does a Nepali court have jurisdiction over that defendant?
input: Section no 718  clause (b) : A matter of a case of which a foreigner residing in Nepal is a defendant,
output: According to Section 718 clause (b): Rule: A Nepali court has jurisdiction over matters in which a foreigner residing in Nepal is a defendant. Application/Conclusion: Since the defendant is a foreigner residing in Nepal, the Nepali court has jurisdiction to adjudicate the case against that defendant.

instruction: A foreign national lived in Nepal and left property here when they died. Can Nepali courts deal with succession?
input: Section no 718  clause (c) : A matter as regards the succession of a foreigner who resided in Nepal and had property in Nepal at the time of his or her death,
output: According to Section 718 clause (c): Rule: Nepali courts have jurisdiction over succession matters relating to a foreigner who resided in Nepal and owned property in Nepal at death. Application/Conclusion: If the deceased foreigner lived in Nepal and had property here when they died, succession proceedings concerning that property can be brought before Nepali courts.

instruction: I agreed a financial deal abroad with a foreigner but the payment is to be made in Nepal — can I sue in Nepal?
input: Section no 718  clause (d) : A matter concerning payment to be made in Nepal on a financial transaction or dealing made abroad between a citizen of Nepal and a foreigner,
output: According to Section 718 clause (d): Rule: Matters concerning payments to be made in Nepal arising from financial transactions or dealings made abroad between a Nepali citizen and a foreigner fall under Nepali jurisdiction. Application/Conclusion: Because your transaction involves payment to be made in Nepal between you (a Nepali) and a foreigner, you can bring the payment dispute to a Nepali court.

instruction: The dispute is about property located in Nepal but the parties are foreigners. Can Nepal courts hear this?
input: Section no 718  clause (e) : A matter between foreigners or between a foreigner and a citizen of Nepal, concerning a property situated in Nepal,
output: According to Section 718 clause (e): Rule: Nepali courts have jurisdiction over matters concerning property situated in Nepal, even if the parties are foreigners or a mix of foreigner and Nepali. Application/Conclusion: Because the property is located in Nepal, you can bring the property dispute in a Nepali court despite the parties' foreign nationality.

instruction: A tort happened outside Nepal but both parties are either Nepali citizens or foreigners habitually resident here. Can Nepali courts take the case?
input: Section no 718  clause (g) : A matter concerning a tort, quasi-contract or unjust enrichment committed outside Nepal, where both parties are citizens of Nepal or foreigners who have habitual residence in Nepal, 408
output: According to Section 718 clause (g): Rule: Nepali courts have jurisdiction over torts, quasi-contracts or unjust enrichment committed outside Nepal if both parties are Nepali citizens or foreigners who have habitual residence in Nepal. Application/Conclusion: Since both parties are either Nepali or habitually resident in Nepal, a tort that occurred abroad may still be adjudicated by Nepali courts under this clause.

instruction: I hold dual nationality including Nepali. If the applicable foreign law can't be determined under subsection (1), which law governs the matter?
input: part (2) : If such a matter cannot be determined according to the law of the country referred to in sub-section (1), it shall be determined according to the law of the country of his or her nationality, to which he or she has most closest connection. Provided that in the case of a person who holds also the citizenship of Nepal or who has habitual residence in Nepal or is a non-resident Nepali citizen, it shall be determined according to the law of Nepal.
output: According to Section 715(2): Rule: If the law of the country referred to in subsection (1) cannot determine the matter, it is determined by the law of the country of the person's nationality with closest connection; however, if the person also holds Nepalese citizenship, has habitual residence in Nepal, or is a non-resident Nepali citizen, the matter shall be determined according to Nepalese law. Application/Conclusion: Because you hold Nepali citizenship as well, the applicable law will be Nepalese law rather than the other nationality's law when the subsection-(1) law cannot be determined.

instruction: What exactly must parties state in their joint petition if they want a Nepal court to allow a foreign court to try their case?
